title: Suffolk Tax Groups Back Measure on Referendums
description: Taxpayer groups in Suffolk County worked yesterday to distribute 75.000 fliers urging approval of a measure that would make possible a referendum on a county tax cut.

title: Global Aims, Domestic Need Rouse China
description: During all the years the late Mao Tsetung was chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, he only made two trips outside China, both to the Soviet Union. In Imperial China, the emperor never ventured abroad; he stayed in the Chinese capital to receive tribute missions from barbarian envoys.

title: New York Statewide Candidates
description: GOVERNOR Democratic, Liberal Hugh L. Carey Republican, Conservative Perry B. Duryea, Jr. Communist Jarvis Tyner Socialist Workers Dyanne M. Feeley Labor Paul Gallagher Right to Life Mary Jane Tobin Free Libertarian Gary Greenberg LT. GOVERNOR Democratic, Liberal Mario M. Cuomo Republican, Conservative Bruce Caputo Communist Grace Mora Socialist Worker Kevin E. Kellogg Labor J. Philip Rubinstein Right to Life Ellen McCormack Free Libertarian James Franz COMPTROLLER Democratic, Liberal Harrison J. Goldin Republican Conservative Edward V. Regan Communist Victor Perio Labor Richard Spida Free Libertarian Judith White ATTORNEY GENERAL Democratic, Liberal Robert L. Abrams Republican, Conservative Michael Roth Communist Jeffrey L. Reeves Socialist Worker Raymond H. Markey, Jr. Free Libertarian dolores Grande

title: Candidates of Major Parties for U.S. Senate and Governor
Archery, Back in Olympics, Sets Thousands Aquiver
description: ONCE a means of survival, then of war and the chase, archery evolved over centuries into an aesthetic diversion. Now it is recording a lively revival in the realm of competitive sports.

title: Candidates in Races in New Jersey and Connecticut
description: Candidates in Races in New Jersey and Connecticut

title: TV: Rainbow,
description: THE opening graphics logo for Rainbow, the NBC Monday Night Movie at 9, consists of eyes and a slightly pugged nose. Indicatively enough, for a biography of a great popular singer, there is no mouth. That is precisely one of the key problems with the film. The unique sound of Judy Garland, the tremulous vulnerability, turns to dullcolored putty. It's as if the second lead in an old Garland film, someone like Ann Rutherford, were pushed into the star part.

title: Saccharin Is Potential Carcinogen In Humans, Science Academy Says
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP)  The National Academy of Sciences has concluded that saccharin must be viewed as a potential cause of cancer in humans, not only because it is a weak cancercausing agent itself but also because it may promote the cancercausing activity of other substances.

title: GOV. GRASSO TERMED THE FRONTRUNNER
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 5  Gov. Ella T. Grasso, who four years ago became the nation's first woman to be elected Governor in her own right, is waging what manypoliticians regard as a closer fight for reelection on Tuesday against her Republican challenger, Representative Ronald A. Sarasin.

title: John Curry Bringing Ice Ballet to Forum
description: John Curry, sometimes called The Baryshnikov of Ice Skating, will bring his fusion of ballet and skates to the Felt Forum on Nov. 21. The show, called IceDancing, will run through. Dec. 3. Mr. Curry, who was the 1976 Olympic Gold Medal winner, will head a company of 12. Opposite him will be JoJo Starbuck.

title: Schubert Display Opens At Morgan Library Dec.5
description: The 150th anniversary of the death of Franz Schubert will be commemorated in an exhibition of the composer's letters and manuscripts at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, beginning Dec. 5.

title: Lucia M. Willard, 28; Classical Indian Dancer
description: Lucia Maloney Willard, a classical Indian dancer who studied in India and gave recitals there and in Geneva, Paris and New York City, died last Sept. 21 in a London hospital after a short illness.

title: New Jersey and Connecticut
description: The race for the United States Senate seat in New Jersey would, it appeared, be unusual, even amateurish, pitting two political novices  Bill Bradley, the basketball celebrity, and Jeffrey Bell, the singleissue taxcutter who unseated Clifford Case in the Republican primary. But it has turned out to be nearly a text- book campaign: two energetic young candidates arguing different positions, frequently in face-to-face debates. New Jersey voters could hardly ask for a clearer campaign or a cleaner choice.

title: Advances in Clean- Water Technology Proving Costly
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 5  The largescale transformation of sewage into nearnatural drinking water, an early dream of pollution fighters, appears to be going down the drain.

title: Candidate in Kentucky Breaks Speech Record
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 5 (AP) George Clarke Martin, a Democrat running against Representative Gene Snyder, the Republican incumbent in Kentucky's Fourth Congressional Dis- trict, set out to make a name for himself by breaking the record for the world's longest political speech. But just when Mr. Martin thought he had broken the record, he had to continue.

title: Suit on Tenure Cites Warlock
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 5  An Atlanta woman, denied tenure at an Atlanta art college because she dabbled in the occult, has brought a sex discrimination suit based on a contention that the school dismissed her but approved a male practitioner of witchcraft.

title: Party Chairmen Predict Upsets in Seven States
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UPI)  Bill Brock, the Republican national chairman, said today that his party's best chances to win upset victories in Senate elections Tuesday were in Montana, Kansas, Mississippi and Alabama. The Dembcratic chairman predicted good upset chances for his party in Texas, North Carolina and Massachusetts.

title: Putnam Voters to Elect First County Executive
description: CARMEL, N.Y., Nov. 5 (AP)  For the first time, voters in Putnam County will be electing a County Executive in Tuesday's elections.

title: List for Congress
description: List for Congress

title: Israel Told To Keep Sinai Oil
description: A group of American investors, seeking to protect its $100 million investment in a Sinai oil venture, are urging Israel not to cede control of its Alma oil field there to Egypt.

title: TENG TRANSFORMING CHINA OF MAO's ERA
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 5 With a series of swift and deftly engineered strokes, Teng Hsiaoping, China's Deputy Prime Minister, has ousted a cluster of his adversaries and introduced a new round of sweeping policy innovations that follow his own pragmatic thinking about how to develop China.

title: 15 States
description: WASHINGTON, Nov, 5  When voters go to the polls Tuesday, the most important decisions they make might be how many billions of dollars will be cut from the tax payments of middle- and upperincome Americans over the next few years.

title: Bradley Is Favored Over Bell in Jersey Race for Senate
description: TRENTON, Nov. 5  In a contest seen as providing a significant clue to antitax sentiment, New Jersey voters will decide Tuesday whether Bill Bradley or Jeffrey Bell should be their next United States Senator.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of inadvertant deleti(ALS made in editing, an article in Business Day m August 9 wrongly indicated and a caption incorrectly stated that Beck's beer is imported by AnheuserBusch. Dribeck Importers Inc. of Greenwich, Cum., imports Beck's, which has no cmnection with AnheuserBusch.

title: 54 Works by Degas Shown at Acquavella
description: THE art of Edgar Degas (18341917) is now so firmly established among the classics of French painting that it requires a certain leap of the imagination for us to grasp the real difficulties that this appealing body of work represented for the artist's first public. In the fine Degas exhibition that has just opened at the Acquavella Galleries, for example, almost half of the 54 paintings and pastels are devoted to ballet dancers. What, according to conventional opinion today, could be more delightful? There are also portraits  including a stunning early selfportrait and scenes of domestic life, the race track and the bourse. How could such subjects have ever been deemed controversial?

title: AgeGroup Runners Jam Sunny Van Cortlandt Park
description: Jan Merrill, a 1976 Olympic finalist, won. So did 17-year-old Mary Shea of Raleigh, N.C., a day after an impressive victory in Atlanta. So did Stacy Soskis of New Hyde Park, L.I.. and Eric Garvey of Flushing, Queens, each 5 years old and each a competitive veteran.

title: The Story of the Newspaper Walkout: Some Successes, Some Miscalculations
description: In early August, the top executives of The New York Times, The Daily News and The New York Post, committed to basic restructuring of their pressrooms that would save them millions of dollars a year, knew that they almost certainly faced a strike by the pressmen's union, but the newspapers felt the odds favored its being a short one if they remained united.

title: Carey and Duryea Clash Over Finances in Debate
description: Governor Carey and Perry B. Duryea traded bitter charges over their personal finances in a television debate yesterday morning and then went their separate ways. Mr. Carey took a threeborough automobile tour of the city, and Mr. Duryea made a flying trip upstate.

title: Soviet Predicts Record Grain Harvest
description: MOSCOW, Nov.5  The Soviet grain harvest this year will be the largest in history, more than 230 million metric tons, Prime Minister Aleksei N. Kosygin disclomcl in a Kremlin speech yesterday.

title: Fear Becomes Fancy Ina Man Whose Pet Has Eight Hairy Legs
description: BELLINGHAM, Wash. (UPI)  Dale Lund looked at the tarantula that was spread across his hand and said, Eventually, they just look like an eightlegged hamster.

title: How Sylvania Lit Up Detroit Via Ford
description: When the Ford Motor Company recently unveiled its 1979 Lincoln Versailles, it was cause for celebration at General Telephone and Electronics Corporation. The reason: One of G.T.E.'s smaller divisions, Sylvania Miniature Lighting, had just managed to crack one of the world's toughest markets.

title: Economic Scene
description: PARIS

title: Exceller Takes Oak Tree
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Nov. 5 (AP)  Exceller, conqueror of Seattle Slew and Affirmed in the recent Jockey Club Gold Cup at Belmont, made a dramatic charge in the stretch today and won the $150,000 Oak Tree Invitational, the closingday feature of Santa Anita's Oak Tree meetine.

title: U.S. Officials Fearful That Shah May Lose Control If He Does Not Take Decisive Steps Within 2 Days
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  The crescendo of violence and turbulence in Iran this weekend has caused serious fears in the Carter Administration that Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi maynot be able to survive the crisis unless he takes decisive action to revamp his Government within 24 to 48 hours.

title: A WagePrice Hot Line
description: WASHINGTON  In a drab, windowless room in downtown Washington sit 13 weary Government economists. From 8 A.M. to 6 P.M.  and sometimes later  they stare at the pictureless walls, and at each other, while working the endlessly ringing telephones that have become their daily companions.

title: After Two Conclaves, a Polish Pope
description: The election of Pope John Paul II. a strongwilled. vigorous Polish prelate and the first nonItalian head of the Roman Catholic Church in 455 years, has given a new dimension to the Vatican's global political role.

title: AliRnssman: Ethnic Matchup
description: BENNY Leonard, who fought his way from the streets of New York City to the world lightweight championship, was slugging away at Irish Eddy Kelly one day just after World War I. Finally the battered Kelly whispered: Hub rachmones. [Yiddish for take pity."] I'm really Bernie Schwartz.

title: Decline in Autopsies Is Criticized as Harmful to Science and Society
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  To viewers of television crime dramas such as Quincy, the autopsy may seem a necessary and important part of the American way of death. But the use of these post-mortem examinations actually is declining steadily.

title: The New Look: Hit or Miss?
description: American women are notoriously independent when it comes to fashion. Even the ones Who get real pleasure out of experimenting with clothes have been known to sit out a season when a new silhouette strikes them wrong.(The year of the midi skirt is the most conspicuous example).

title: Hopes Fading for a Negotiated Settlement in Iran as Shah Turns to Army
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 5  Since the beginning of the year, Iran has been shaken by tumultuous demonstrations that have taken more than a thousand lives, and it has been crippled by strikes that have shattered its economy.

title: Commodities
description: The Administration's announcement of dramatic dollarsupport moves broke the back of precious metals and foreigncurrency futures last week but (min and cotton futures showed surprising strength.

title: New Voice for vv omen In the White House
description: WASHINGTON  Sarah Ragle Weddington tells the tale of a little girl who asked her mother to read her a bedtime story.

title: NATION
description: President Imposes Inflation Guidelines but Reaction Is Cool

title: Pope Visits Shrine of St. Francis in Assisi
description: ASSISI, Italy, Nov. 5  Pope John Paul II, dramatizing his intention to remain an active, modern man despite the weight and pomp of his pontifical vestments, flew by helicopter today to the Umbrian hill town of Assisi to pray at the shrine of Saint Francis.

title: JERSEY TRANSPORT IS FOUND EFFICIENT
description: NEWARK, Nov. 5 (AP)  The state's largest bus company, Transport of New Jersey, is more efficiently run than publicly owned bus systems in other sections of the United States, but the line's riders may be paying more and getting less in return than riders elsewhere, a recent study shows.

title: Sports Briefs
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Nev. 5 CAP)  Wayne Levi and Bob Mann fired a runeunderpar 63 today for a threestroke victory in the National Team Golf Classic at Disney World.

title: Teng Begins Southeast Asian Tour To Counter Rising Soviet Influence
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 5  Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping of China arrived here today to begin what was viewed as a major Chinese effort to counter Soviet and Vietnamese influence in Southeast Asia;

title: United Press International
description: SIDELINED: O.J. Simpson of the 49ers, in cap, during second half of the Atlanta game. He suffered shoulder separation.

title: CARTER PREEMPTS REPUBLICAN ISSUES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  President Carter was resting at Camp David today after completing a fastpaced, final campaign swing in which he espoused the virtues of tight money, hard work and a strong national defense.

title: The Case for Governor Grasso
description: Ella Grasso is running, and running well, for a second term as Governor of Connecticut. She has earned it. Like Hugh Carey in New York, she came to office burdened with a huge deficit left by

title: WagePrice Guides: How They Work
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 5  President Carter has committed his Administration to a broadened antiinflation campaign that will operate on several fronts. The following questions and answers examine how the campaign's wage and price guidelines are supposed to work and assess their chances for success.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: BOSTON You come out of the subway, and there at the top of the stairs are six men holding Ed King signs. As neonle flush oast them. the men say:

title: In Nicaragua, Calm Before Likely Storm
description: The violence that convulsed Nicaragua during August and September has now given way to United States-sponsored negotiations between Government and opposition forces. Still, both sides seem convinced that the struggle will be settled on the battlefieid and not at the bargaining table. In fact, with both sides claiming to have emerged victorious from the fighting, it was only enormous pressure from Washington that persuaded them to sit down with envoys from the United States, Guatemala and the Dominican Republic.

title: Cordero Is Booed By Fans
description: They booed Angel Cordero Jr. when he lost yesterday, and they booed him when he won.

title: Vietnam Seeks New Friends
description: The war along the Vietnamese-Cambodian border rages on, with Vietnam apparently holding the upper hand but the Cambodian will to fight undiminished by losses. As a result, the wider conflict between Vietnam and China, set off by the war, deepens daily.

title: So Long a Silence
description: Our first feelings this morning are relief and eagerness  relief that the long, bitter, empty days are over, and eagerness to reclaim our readers, to reassert Pride of work and commitment to professional duty.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UPI)  President Carter signed legislation last night making Presidential papers public property, ending a twocenturyold tradition of giving outgoing Presidents control over their records, the White House announced today.

title: Allison Triumphs in a Weird Finish
description: HAMPTON, Ga., Nov. 5. (AP) Donnie Allison, who was shown two laps down on the scoreboard as Richard Petty and Dave Marcis crossed the line behind him in an apparent photo finish, was declared the winner of the $185,000 Dixie 500 Grand National stockcar race today.

title: Congress Wound UP With News Respect for Carter
description: WASHINGTON  On Oct. 12, just as a House and Senate conference co,rnmittee was about to begin its final work on the 1978 tax bill, Senator Russell B. Long and Representative Al Ullman emerged from a White lif:wase meeting looking, decidedly chastened. The President had made it clear, they said, that he regarded the windfall tax cut of nearly $30 billion just approved by the Senate as encessirely inflationary.

title: REGION
description: One thing you couldn't accuse Hugh Carey of was cronyism. First, his old Brooklyn comrade, State Senator Jeremiah B. Bloom, said he would run against him. Then it was Mr. Carey's own Lieutenant Governor, Mary Anne Krupsak, who turned on him. The Democratic primary was bitter and personal, but the Governor emerged the winner over his two lapsed associates.

title: Camden Teachers Ratify Pact
description: CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 5 (AP)  The 1,300 striking teachers in the Camden School District ratified a tentative contract by about a 6-to-I margin today. The action could end the monthlong strike in the South Jersey municipality. The Cam- den Education Association voted to strike on Oct. 5 and formed picket lines the next day. The union had been working without a contract since June 30. Terms of the tentative contract were unavailable.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: What exactly is the new rule in pro football restricting pass defenders actions against receivers?

title: 75Yard Play Caps Big Rally
description: DENVER, Nov.5 (AP)  Matt Robinson, the Jets quarterback connected with Wesley Walker on a 75yard bomb with 5 minutes 45 seconds left, capping a furious New York rally that carried the Jets to a 3128 upset of the Denver Broncos today.

title: 'First Monday in October' To Move and Extend Run
description: First Monday in October, the comedy starring Henry Fonda and Jane Alexander that has been doing excellent business at the Majestic Theater, has had its run extended for at least four weeks.

title: Exit Hull, On Skates
description: IN this era of instant success, it may be a trifle difficult to grasp. But when Bobby Hull retired as a hockey player the other day, these were the numbers: 1,012 goals and 988 assists in 1,623 games during 22 years on ice skates.

title: Contests in New York Area
description: A New York State political campaign that began with Governor Carey viewed as so unpopular that his own Lieutenant Governor challenged him in the Democratic primary headed into its last stage yesterday with some polls and politicians saying the Governor had moved ahead of his Republican opponent, Perry B. Dur Yea.

title: Vikings Beat Lions for Third in Row, 177
description: The Minnesota Vikings won their third straight game yesterday, defeating the Detroit Lions, 177, at Bloomington, Minn., and moved up another notch on the Green Bay Packers. The Vikings now trail the Packers, who lost to Philadelphia, by one game in the Central Division of the National Conference, and one of the Vikings six remaining games will be a contest at Green Bay on Nov. 26.

title: In Sequel to Story of Scandal and Blood, Texas Millionaire Goes on Trial in Murder Plot
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 5  The old revelations, as flamboyant and bloody as they had been, were fading fast when the startling new ones burst out of Fort Worth Aug. 20.

title: Spas Thrive on Diet, Fitness craze
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 5  A lot of money is being made these days in group starvation and exercise, as health spas spread across the nation. The spas are resortlike facilities with diet and exercise programs devoted to fitness and health.

title: Sadat Snubs Envoys Sent by Arabs
description: CAIRO, Nov. 5  In a gesture bound to invite Arab resentment, President Anwar elSadat has defied the Arab summit conference that is being held without him in Baghdad by snubbing the delegation that it dispatched to ask him to reconsider his plans for peace with Israel.

title: Manhunt Nets Some Biggies
description: The relentless police pursuit of those Western European terrorists still at large had some notable success. In Italy, on Sept. 13, officials arrested Conado Alunni, long sought as the suspected mastermind of the Red Bri-

title: More Civil War Bleeds Beirut
description: The Lebanese civil war seems neverending. In the late summer the fighting reached its greatest intensity yet. This time it was not Lebanese Christians and Syrians against Lebanese leftists and Palestinians. but Lebanese Chris- tian militias against Syrians. The attacks began on Aug. 9 and culminated in late September with ten terrible days of shelling that devastated Christian East Beirut and left 400 dead and 1,200 wounded.

title: Times Offers Information Update
description: Although The New York Times did not appear during the 88day strike of pressmen, news staff members maintained a record of current events for libraries and other research institutions.

title: Advertising
description: Plans for the largest advertising agency acquisition in history are expected to be announced today by the Interpublic Group of Companies, already the largest communications company of its kind in the world.

title: Upper West Side Getting Two New Film Theaters
description: Two new firstrun movie theaters will open on Dec. 8 at Broadway and 66th Street in the building now occupied by Cinema Studio.

title: Views of Carey and Duryea on the Campaign Issues
description: In a battle over issues ranging from A for Abortion to W for Welfare, Governor Carey and his RepublicanConservative challenger, Perry B. Duryea, have agreed on one view  that New York State is once again on the way up.

title: Nobel Prize to I.B. Singer
description: Isacc Bashevis Singer, the Yiddish master of storytelling, was awarded the 1978 Nobel Prize for Literature. Singer, who was born into a Polish rabbinical family on July 14, 1904, emigrated to America in 1935, the year that his first major novel, Satan in Goray, was published. Since then, always writing in Yiddish and publishing much of his work in serial form in The Jewish Daily Forward, he has produced a dozen novels, the best known of which make up his familychronical trilogy, The Family Moskat (1950), The Manor (1967), and The Estate (1965); numerous shortstory collections; a memoir, In My Father's Court (1966); and several children's books. The Swedish Academy cited Singer for his impasioned narratives which, with roots in a PolishJewish cultural tradition, bring universal human conditions life, which is another way of saying what admirers have always observed about Singer; that he has made of the East European Jew, especially the Hasid, an exemplar of the suffering modern man who has been exiled from his divine inheritance.

title: Transcript of Carter Remarks in an Interview on His Presidency and the Nation
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 5  Following is a transcript of President Carter's comments during an interview with James Reston of The New York Times. The interview was conducted on Octo- ber 12 in the Oval Office of the White House.

title: Chess:
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 5  The Soviet Union maintained a slim lead in the World Chess Olympiad here after an upset loss in the ninth round to West Germany, 21/24 1/2.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Teamsters Union will settle a master tracking contract next spring for wage and benefit gains totaling stout 7 percent, predicted Alfred Kahn, President Carter's new chief inflation fighter. He suggested that the union had adopted a moderate stance since the President's new antiinflation program was announced Oct. 24. But Mr. Kahn warned that the nation may have to accept severe strikes in key industries before inflation will be under control. [Page 1.]

title: Spending Rise Seen
description: Domestic capital spending by United States corporations will rise 10 percent next year from the 1978 level, according to a survey released yesterday by the McGrawHill Publications Company. However, after allowing for the projected inflation rate of 8 percent for capital goods, the socalled real rate of increase would be only 2 percent, the company said.

title: Heart Transplant Patient Dies
description: DENVER, Nov. 5 (UPI)  A 46year old heart transplant patient died today, 12 days after undergoing heart transplant surgery at Colorado General Hospital. Bernard McNulty, a lawyer, had progressed well until he suffered a relapse yesterday when his body's natural defenses rejected the new heart, a hospital spokesman said. The donor, an unidentified woman, was killed in a traffic accident.

title: News Summary
description: Iran's Prime Minister resigned after demonstrators demanding the ouster of the Shah rampaged in Teheran, setting fire to buildings. As strikes spread throughout the country, further crippling oil production and other industries, the Shah called on the military to restore order, and the authorities announced that they would strictly enforce martial law. The Shah, rebuffed in efforts to bring opposition figures into a provisional government, was expected to form a new government with military leaders in key posts. [Page 1, Columns 56.]

title: Television
description: 6:00(4)To Be Announced

title: For Iran. No Clear Alternative to the Shah
description: PARIS, November 5  Hectic negotiations just concluded in Paris between two Iranian leaders and their backers reflected just what united the opposition to Shah Riza Mohammed Pahlevi, and some of the important questions which continue to divide them.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Between the end of the current football season and the start of the next baseball season, Candlestick Park in San Francisco will switch from a synthetic playing surface to something closer to natural grass.

title: Charles Tandy, 60, Industrialist
description: FORT WORTH, Nov. 5 (UPI)  Charles David Tandy, who transformed a small family leather business into a multimilliondollar international conglomerate, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 60 years old.

title: The New York Tirees/Chester Higgins Jr.
description: Bronx Borough President Robert Abrams, candidate for State Attorney General, putting his case before Upper West Side voters during a final weekend campaign swing through the city yesterday.

title: Problems Ahead For Wage Program
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 5  The proposed real wage insurance  the only measure in President Carter's antiinflation program that requires legislation is unlikely to get quick approval from Congress, sources on Capitol Hill predict.

title: Westchester Is Torn By Police Merger Plan
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 5 (UPI)  In the Westchester County Office Building, the administration of County Executive; Alfred B. DelBello is working feverishly for passage of Proposition 1, while next door at the Westchester County Courthouse, opposition posters abound.

title: Other World Events
description: Uganda's President Idi Amin had cried wolf so often that at first no one really took seriously his claims late in October that fighting had broken out between his country and neighboring Tanzania. But last week it became all too clear that the latest report of war was real and moreover it was apparent that President Amin's forces had won at least the first round. On Nov. 1, President Amin announced that Uganda had seized a 710square mile salient of Fiinzanian territory west of Lake Victoria and stretching to the boundary of neighboring Rwanda. The next day, President Julius Nyerere of Tanzania confirmed the loss of the territory but exhorted his countrymen to repel the invaders. The Ugandan seizure of the territory, which it has long claimed, apparently caught the Tanzanians by surprise and there was considerable confusion among the defenders. One example of that confusion: Tanzanian forces shot down three Ugandan planes but that hardly offset the fact that they also shot down three of their own aircraft.

title: After Camp David Summit, A Valley of Hard Bargaining
description: WASHINGTON  This is one of those rare, bright moments of human history, President Carter declared as President Anwar elSadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel embraced in celebration of the accords they signed Sept. 17, after 13 days and nights of negotiations at Camp David.

title: Dance: San Francisco Ballet Conquers New York
description: NEW YORKERS have not seen the San Francisco Ballet since 1965 but on the evidence of the reception given it by a packed house at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Saturday evening at its ninth and penultimate New York perform- ance, the appealing young company has won many friends in a town that likes to think of itself as the major progenitor of the best in dance.

title: Ruth Gardner Davis Steinway, 88, A Historian of Plymouth, Mass.
description: A memorial service was held in New York on Oct. 26 for Ruth Gardner Davis Steinway, a historian of the Plymouth, Mass., area. She died at the Jordan Hospital in Plymouth on Aug. 28 at the age of 88.

title: Learning Their Lessons
description: The return to school this fall did not necessarily mean a return to normal as teachers strikes throughout the nation kept 450,000 pupils out of classes. The two main strikes in the metropolitan region occurred in Levittown, where the longest public school strike in Long Island history went on for eight weeks, and in Bridgeport. Conn. where more than 260 teachers were jailed during a 19day strike for refusing to obey a back-to-work court order.

title: SCIENCE
description: The Nobel prizes in science this year recognized a vast range of research achievements  the inner workings of cells and genes as well as the nature of the cosmos in its entirety.

title: Executive Changes
description: The American Telephone & Telegraph Company's 57-year-old president, Charles L Brown, was selected to Demme chairman and chief executive Feb.!, succeeding Jam D. deBatts, 63, who is retiring 19 months early amid speculation that he will step into a Federal post...The Ford Motor Company's Ptdllip Caldwell, 58-year-old vice chairman, also became president, succeeding Ise A. Iacocca, 54, who was fired last July but on Nov. 2 became president of Cbrysler...The Manufacturrs Hanover Corporation elected John F. McGillicuddy, 47, chairman and chief executive, effective April 1, 1979, when Gabriel Hake, chairman, retires...On Sept. 18, Nancy H. Testa became the first woman on the Federal Reserve Board...Forrner Federal Reserve Board Chairman Arthur Bur= became a consultant to Lazard Freres & Company...Alvin C. Rice, Bank of America's 54-year-old vice chairman and likely successor to Chief Executive A. W. Claim, resigned to spend his time helping develop a new fuel...Denaid D. Kummerfeld, 44. executive director of the New York City Emergency Financial Control Board, left to become president of Rupert Murdoch's U.S. publishing enterprisesJose Cahill Pfeiffer. 45, a former vice president of International Business Machines, was named chairman of the National Broadcasting Company...Herturt A. Sinus, the 62-year-old CarnegieMellon University professor who cast doubt on the traditional view that businessmen always act to maximize profits, won

title: Two for the House
description: Ever since the rich wore silk stockings, what is now labeled the 18th Congressional District, covering most of Manhattan's East Side, has been known as the Silk Stocking District. Never has it seemed richer than in this year's campaign for Congress. That is true in dollars. Both candidates, S. William Green, the Republican, and Carter Burden, the Democrat, are heirs fortunes and have proved it by investing hundreds of thousands of their own dollars in what must be the costliest House campaign ever, anywhere.

title: Weizman Briefs Israelis
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 5  Defense Minister Ezer Weizman today briefed the Israeli Cabinet on the latest developments in the Washington peace talks be- tween Israel and Egypt with an emphasis on the military aspects of a peace treaty.

title: Running for New York Assembly
description: Ballot that will be found on some Manhattan voting machines. Other areas have different candidates for minor offices.

title: New Post at Top At Thompson's
description: Wayne Fickinger has at age 52 moved into a newly created post at the J. Walter Thompson Company. He is to be president and chief operating officer for North America.

title: World News Briefs
description: VIENNA, Nov. 5 (Reuters)  The Socialist Government of Chancellor Bruno Kreisky suffered a defeat tonight in the first national referendum on the use of nuclear energy.

title: Kubrick Films The Shining In Secrecy in English Studio
description: Stanley Kubrick's new movie, The Shining, is being filmed with an excess of secrecy in a studio in England. No outsider is allowed on the set, nor are any interviews permitted with Mr. Kubrick or with his actors, Jack Nicholson and Shelley Duvall. All we've been told, says a spokesman Tor Warner Bros.  the studio that will distribute The Shining when and where Mr. Kubrick is willing to release it is that Stanley's trying to make a movie that will really scare people.

title: Rate for Operations, After a Pause, Increasing Again
description: The rate at which Americans undergo surgery, which mysteriously reached a plateau in 1976 after a decadelong increase, is again growing at its previous dramatic pace.

title: Drawing Lines In Rhodesia
description: For a long time, the one sure thing in Rhodesia has been the deterioration of conditions for the country's quarter of a million whites. But two recent events  Washington's permitting Prime Minister Ian D. Smith to tour the United States, and Rhodesian strikes into Zambia and Mozambique on Oct. 19 and 20 that left 2,000 guerrillas dead  have lifted white morale.

title: Fact Sheet on Inflation Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP)  The following is the fact sheet on President Carter's antiinflation program, released by the White House.

title: Other Business Developments
description: F.D.I.C. Owes a Bundle

title: Bridge:
description: Students of the Olympic Games, which began in Greece in both ancient and modem versions, are familiar with the 10event decathlon and the fiveevent pentathlon. The triathlon, however, is something new, but it also originated in Greece.

title: C.I.A. Head Accused of Tailoring Estimates to Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov 5.  Mm. Stansfield Turner, Director of Central Intelligence, is being accused in the intelligence community of distorting estimates to make them dovetail with the Carter Administration's foreign policy. He denies the allegations.

title: PURSUIT OF SPY CASE BY C.I.A. QUESTIONED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  The Central Intelligence Agency learned that information on its highly secret KH11 satellite reconnaissance system was in the hands of the Soviet Union more than two months before it came to suspect William P. Kampiles, the man charged with selling the secrets. according to senior intelligence sources.

title: Lubar Outruns 2,519 to Win in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, N,v. 5  Steve Lubar, who thinks nothing of competing in two distance races in two clays and hardly drawing a deep breath in between, won the Westchester County Run for Life today.

title: BUSINESS
description: The merger movement that began last year slowed down in the third quarter. According to W. T. Grimm & Company, a Chicago based concern which tracks corporate takeovers and acquisitions, the number of firms announcing merger plans dropped to 501 from 616 a year earlier. During the same period, however, the total value of $25 billion of mergers or stillpending acquisitices was way ahead of the conesponding period of 1977 when it amounted to $19.9 billion, the firm said.

title: Town Hall Surviving As Multipurpose Hall
description: Town Hall, which suspended operations on Aug. 31 and was faced with extinction, will survive as a multipurpose hall for drama, concerts and dance. Its lease has passed from New York University to the newly formed Town Hall Theater Foundation, and the Land- marks Commission will decide after Nov. 19 whether the 58-year-old building will receive landmark status. Whatever the outcome, of the Landmarks Commission's decision, Town Hall will be turned into a building with two auditoriums.

title: Books of The Times
description: HERE, in case you missed it, is World War II the fall of Singapore, the siege of Leningrad, the battle of Midway, Leyte Gulf, Overlord, Hiroshima  the whole shooting match, with grim and special emphasis on the Nazi death camps and the attempted genocide of European Jewry.

title: Fragonard and Robert At the National Gallery
description: Two unusual exhibitions of drawings  Drawings by Fragonard in North American Collections and Hubert Robert: Drawings and Watercolors will open at the National Gallery of Art in Washington on Nov. 19.

title: Sporting Gear
description: No more sliding off your air mattresses, campers. The latest Air Lift sleeping bag features a pocket to hold an air cushion  no need now to pile one on top of the other. Made of lightweight fiber and nylon, the sleeping bag weighs three-and-a-half or four pounds, depending on length (either 5 feet 11 inches or 6 feet 3 inches), and is protective to degrees Fahrenheit. A zipper opens and shuts the pocket, into which you can insert a 3-foot-6-inch or 6-foot-2-inch mattress. Each mattress, which folds to a 7-by-4-inch bundle for easy toting, is made of 10 individually inflated seamless tubes, restricting the shifting of air inside. One full breath of air will inflate a tube. The mattresses cost $19.50, $29 or $36 and can be purchased at Thunderbird Tepee, 2560 Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn; Tents & Trails, 21 Park Place, Manhattan, and Paragon, Broadway and East 18th Street, Manhattan, or directly from Air Lift, 2217 Roosevelt Avenue, Berkeley, Calif. 94703. The sleeping bags, $82 for the long one and $78.50 for the shorter one, are not carried by any stores in the New York area but can be ordered directly from Air Lift. Prices include shipping.

title: Races by Steingut and Goodman Highlight Contests for Legislature
description: Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut's battle for political survival and a lavishly financed attempt to unseat longtime State Senator Roy M. Goodman are among tomorrow's races for the New York State Legislature.

title: In Need of a Tax Break? Bourse Is French Haven
description: PARIS, Nov. 5  Not making much money on Wall Street? If you lived in France, you might try your luck on the Paris Bourse  and take a tax deduction besides.

title: Penn State Continues Drive
description: Penn State's drive for the No. 1 ranking in college football, a position the powerful Nittany Lions have yet to hold, kept right on track Saturday, as did the university's move for record gross receipts of about $7 million from football this season.

title: To Save a Speaker and a Senator
description: There may be sound reasons for challenging or dethroning a major New York political figure like Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut. But the sniper charges and candidacy of a Brooklyn upstart, Murray Weinstein. are not among them.

title: KAUFMAN CRITICIZES JUDGEOUSTER PLAN
description: A proposal to ease the removal of Federal judges does no less than pose an ominous threat to the republic and judicial branch, according to the highestranking Federal judge in New York State.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON  A political time bomb is ticking away in a windowless basement room of the Forsythe Street Federal Courthouse in Atlanta, Ga.

title: SOUTH AFRICA OPENS INQUIRY IN SCANDAL
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 5 With the Afrikaners reputation for rectitude at stake, a threeman judicial commission will begin tomorrow an inquiry into the largest political and financial scandal to hit South Africa's white minority Government in 30 years of National Party rule.

title: Still Higher Interest Rates Seen
description: Interest rates, already at their highest levels in four years, will continue climbing and could lead to a severe shortage of credit for business borrowers in corning months, according moneymarket economists and bankers.

title: Youth, 20, Is Stabbed, Companion Wounded On an East Side Street
description: A 20-year-old Queens man was stabbed to death and a companion was wounded Saturday night in an alleged attack by a knifewielding derelict on Manhattan's East Side. Bystanders summoned the police, who disarmed and seized the assailant at the scene of the attack several minutes later, homicide detectives said.

title: G.O.P. May Gain Nationally
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  Slight Republican gains around the nation seem likely as the 1978 election campaign winds to a close in a flurry of personal attacks in television commercials, deep voter distrust of campaign promises and concern over low voter turnout in Tuesday's midterm election.

title: Market Place
description: PRESIDENT Carter's dramatic plan to strengthen the dollar through new support guarantees abroad and higher official interest charges at home stopped a seller's panic on Wall Street last week and brought, on Wednesday, some of the best oneday gains in stock market history.

title: Tumult in the Markets
description: Financial markets at home and abroad have been devastated in recent weeks as frantic traders and in. castors scrambled to come to grips with the anti-inflation policies of the Carter Administration and the Federal Reserve Board. The problem has been one of worsening inflation, a declining dollar and an ongoing deep deficit in international trade.

title: SPORTS
description: In a rich, dull fight in New Orleans, Muhammad Ali won a unanimous 15round decision from Leon Spinks to become the first person to win the heavyweight title three times.

title: U.S. Asks U.N. Action in CambodiaVietnam Strife
description: UNITED NATIONS, New York, Nov. 5  The United States, reacting to reports of an intensifying border war between Vietnam and Cambodia, has called upon the Security Gotpcil to seek ways to ease the conflict.

title: INFLATION STRUGGLE MAY MEAN STRIKES, CARTER AIDE WARNS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  Alfred Kahn, President Carter's new chief inflation fighter, warned today that the nation might have to accept severe strikes in key industries before inflation could be brought under control.

title: Arab League Appeals to Egyptians To Renounce Accord With Israelis
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 5 (Reuters) The Arab League summit meeting ended tonight with an unexpectedly mild declaration calling on Egypt to renounce its peace accord with Israel and not to sign a peace treaty, but with no mention of sanctions against Egypt or direct criticism of President Anwar elSadat.

title: Mexican Ends Manila Visit
description: MANILA. Nov. 5 (AP)  President Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico left for home tonight after a 24hour visit to the Philippines. Mr. Lopez Portillo, who bad just come from China and Japan, met with President Ferdinand Marcos, and the two discussed proposals including an exchange of Philippine products for Mexican oil, officials said.

title: Topics of The Times Private Moments, Public Meeting Places
description: We were startled, while leafing through an out-of-town paper the other day, to see, smiling up from the obituary page, the picture of a New York woman we once worked with. It was shock: she was young, full of life, and we tell to remembering times like her shout of laughter when she realized how peculiar her monogram would be after marriage"deRMMcQ.

title: Fourteen Questions About Superman's Return
description: that defender of Truth, Right, and the American Way, that man with the vision to see through us: Superman.

title: Mary Fosburgh, 72; One of Cushing Sisters And a Leader in Arts
description: Mary Cushing Fosburgh, the eldest of the socially prominent Cushing sisters and widow or the painter James Whitney Fosburgh, died Saturday at her home in Manhattan after a long illness. She was 72 years old and lived at 32 East 69th Street.

title: New York State and City
description: Mr. Carey for Governor

title: UNESCO Withholding. Study of Israeli Occupation
description: PARIS, Nov. 5 (Reuters) A UNESCO report that acquitted Israel of cultural aggression against Arabs living in captured territories has been shelved by the organization.

title: Taxi Passengers Hear Commercials for Buses
description: BENNINGTON, Vt. (AP)  Drivers for the Red Top Cab Company have heard some unusual messages over their radios, and they want the Federal Communications Commission to do something about it.

title: Six Are Killed as a Fire Destroys Department Store in Des Moines
description: DES MOINES, Nov. 5 (UPI) At least six persons were killed today in a fire that flashed through the Younkers Department Store, forcing 15 to 20 employees to evacuate the building.

title: How to Do It
description: None of the seacoast states from New Jersey to Massachusetts has any general regulations that procommercial use with a net that is no more than 20 feet long and 4 feet deep.

title: PEOPLE
description: world chess champion Anatol), Karp,. of the Soviet Union emerged from battle of blunders in a circus atmosphere to win his title match with challenger Viktor Korchnol, a Soviet defector. in Baeuio City. the Philleeinelt. After the 47 -year-old Mr. Korchiii had fought back from a 23 deficit to force a 53 sudden death playoff, the 27yearold Mr. Karpov came to life to put away the 32d game and the match. Psychological warfare  a strategy of spiteprevailed throughout. Vladimir Zakhar, a parapsychologist accompa-

title: Canada Sees Growth of CondominiumWorkplace
description: TORONTO, Nov. 5  For years Clarence and Betty Vallee helplessly watched their rent jump sharply and regularly and the buying power of their savings dwindle as inflation took its costly toll on Canada's economv."lt just got to be silly, says Mrs. Vallee.

title: Soviet- Vietnamese Pact Spurs Cambodian Talk
description: PEKING, Nov. 5 (Reuters) A Chinese goverrunent delegation flew to Phnom Penh today, only two days after the signing in Moscow of a SovietVietnamese friendship treaty which Chinese officials believe has military overtones.

title: No Peril Seen to Democratic Rule Of State Congressional Delegation
description: Close, bitterly fought election races in Manhattan, Queens and Suffolk County highlight the contests for the United States House of Representatives in New York State. The heavily Democratic makeup of the state's Congressional delegation is not expected to change drastically.

title: Prospects Fade For Fast Treaty On the Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and the chief Egyptian and Israeli negotiators moved closer today toward removing the remaining obstacles to the formula for an Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty. But earlier hopes of a quick conclusion this week seemed to fade.

title: Cardinls Beat Giants, 20 to 10; Otis, Hart Star
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 5 (AP)  Jim Otis, the Cardinal fullback, smashed through the Giants defense for two short touchdowns, and Jim Hart's passes riddled a porous New York secondary, leading St. Louis to a 2010 triumph over the Giants in a National Football League game today.

title: New York Dairy Farmers Said to Have Best Year Ever
description: ALBANY, Nov. 3  Ncnv York State's dairy farmers are completing their best year ever financially, according to agricultural experts here.

title: Outdoors
description: IF YOU have ever driven along the shores of a bay or a salt pond on a late summer or fall night, you may have seen silvery cascades of small fish erupting skyward wherever your headlight beams touched the water.

title: Alice W. Poynter, 98
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Nov. 5 (UPI)  Alice W. Poynter, wife of the late newspaper publisher, Paul Poynter, and mother of the late Nelson Poynter, former board chairman The Times Publishing Company, died at her home last night. She was 98 years old.

title: Government's Knuckles Get Rapped
description: Justice Department attorneys ran into two angry Federal judges in Washington on Oct. 24 who criticized the Government's handling of the two unrelated corporate cases.

title: MARY JANE TRUMAN, PRESIDENT's SISTER
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 5 (AP) Mary Jane Truman, the sister of the late President Harry S. Truman, died Friday in suburban Grandview after a long illness. She was 89 years old.

title: Other National Events
description: Compromise in iViaine

title: IRAN PREMIER QUITS; RIOTERS CHALLENGE ARMY RULE BY SHAH
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 5  The Prime Minister of Iran resigned tonight after demonstrators demanding the ouster of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi rampaged through the streets of Teheran setting fire to buildings. Strikes spread through the country, further crippling oil production and other industries.

title: Twelve Yemenis Executed
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Nov. 5 (AP) Yemen executed 12 persons today for participating in last month's abortive attempt to overthrow President Ali Abdullah Saleh, the Iraqi news agency reported. The method of execution, in the Yemeni capital of Sana, was not mentioned. Among those executed were Abdul Salam Muqbil, the minister of labor, youth and social affairs; Salem alSaqqaf, deputy director of President Saleh's office, and Mohammed Ahmed Ibrahim, the director of cultural exchange at the Education Ministry.

title: 2 Killed in Miami Carpet Fire
description: MIAMI, Nov. 5 (UPI)  Two workmen were killed and another was critically injured yesterday when gasoline burst into flames as they were removing carpet remnants from a floor. The victims were identified as Juan Mola, 48 years old, and Ladislao Ferrarp, 46. Juan Inchauste, 31, was reported in critical condition at a hospital. The men, who were installing tile in the home of Jose Valdes, were using gasoline to remove carpet remnants when the gasoline exploded.

title: Where to Go for Archery Information
description: Among the Metropolitan area organizations that can supply information on archery are the following:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: According to a State Comptroller's report. New York City could fail to cover its 198082 budget gap by as much as $1 billion or as little as $4 million, de. pending on how much can be counted on in state and Federal funds. Deputy Comptroller Sidney Schwartz said figures in the report, issued yesterday, were based on the city's own estimate that the threeyear budget gap would be $2.33 billion rather than the $2.64 billion estimated by the state.

title: THE TIMES AND NEWS RESUME PUBLICATION
description: The New York Times and The Daily News resumed publication today after the resolution of a pressmen's strike and other labor disputes that had shut down operations at the two newspapers for 88 days and had prevented The New York Post from publishing for 56 days.

title: Researchers in Flordia Study Beetles to Build Vehicle That Walks
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla. (UPI)  University of Florida mechanical engineers are studying beetles legs with an eye toward building a vehicle that walks or runs instead of rolling on wheels.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yestefclny's Weath/w of 1 P.M: NatIonal Oceanic and AtmospherIc Administration/UPI

title: Redskins Without Allen: Wide Open and Winning
description: THE Washington Redskins do not miss George Allen. Oh, many of the players remember him fondly because he took such good care of them. and a few waved up to him from the sideline at the game against the San Francisco 49ers that he helped to broadcast for television. But the Allen era is decidedly over in the nation's capital, and, much as the Ford and Nixon Administrations, it is recalled only as a milestone of the past.

title: Oxford Fills Poetry Chair in Close Election
description: OXFORD, England, Nov. 5  John Jones, an Oxford literary critic, won the Oxford University Poetry Chair yesterday in an election that was, by the standards of recent years, subdued.

title: New York Senate
description: New York Senate

title: New Chief in South Africa Gets Tougher
description: Brinkmanship or bluff? After 18 months of mediation by Western powers, South Africa's policy on SouthWest Africa (Namibia) remains murky.

title: Carter at Midterm: Satisfied So Far But Ready to Admit His Mistakes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  President Carter thinks he may have misjudged the powers of his office in his first two years in the White House  being overly cau tious and even timid, he says  but he is still satisfied with the results and plans to concentrate for the next two years on controlling inflation at home and the nuclear arms race abroad.

title: OBITUARIES
description: Former Time Editor

title: Suddenly, Iran No Longer Stable
description: How much more time for the Shah of Iran? The question may turn out to be premature, but the fact that it was even raised is evidence that he faces the most serious danger to his rule since 1953, when the Central Intelligence Agency had to fly him to safety in Rome.

title: Philadelphia Judge Is Convicted Of Taking Bribes as Court's Chief
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 (AP)  A Federal jury has convicted Judge Louis Vignola of taking more than $30,000 in bribes while he headed Philadelphia Traffic Court.

title: Sell the Mets And Start New
description: MORE than ever, the Mets are the tragedy of New York sports. Instead of taking a more active interest in the club, as Mrs. Lorinda deRoulet promised last week, the Mets woman president should sell the franchise.

title: To Replace Two Institutions
description: With the retirement of Comptroller Arthur Levitt, after six terms, and Attorney General Louis Lefkowitz, after five, New York is losing two independent monitors of government in critical areas. The candidates to succeed them seek to redefine the jobs for a new era, but we have some reservations about all of them.

title: U.S. and Firestone Disagree Over Tire Recall Rules
description: DETROIT, Nov. 5  Differences of opinion between the Federal Government and the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company over the rules to be used in executing the largest tire recall in the nation's history have cast doubt on the prospects that the two will sign a formal agreement on the recall order, which had been scheduled for tomorrow in Washington.

title: ARTS
description: Although the curtain was down on West 43d Street, New York Times critics covered the cultural scene. Here are brief reviews of major openings that took place during the newspaper strike.

title: Stage: Tennis Game
description: EVEN though there is a kind of tennis court on the tiny stage of the South Street Theater, and an occasional outbreak of pantomimed play, The Tennis Game is more like a medieval dance of death brought up to date.

title: Iran's Turmoil Cuts Oil Surplus
description: The surplus of petroleum that has dogged the world's oil companies for the past year and a half, holding prices down, has evaporated in the wake of the political turmoil in Iran.

title: Jinx Plaguing U.S. Rider
description: Across Robert Ridland's jacket Saturday night the 27-year-old Columbia law student bore the purple sash of the leading rider at the 95th National Horse Show. Each Saturday nieht for the last three years at Madison Square Garden he had led the field in the open jumper class, but by Sunday the lead and the trophy eventually had gone to someone else.

title: Two Soviet Spies Get 50 Years
description: Russian spy cases in the United States seem usually to be followed quickly by similar cases in the Soviet Union. That was so with two Russian officials, Valdik A. Enger and Rudolf P. Chernyayev, detained in New Jersey in May as suspected spies.

title: MRS. GANDHI NEEDS VOTE IN INDIAN AREA
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 5  Voters in a remote area of South India cast their ballots today in a parliamentary byelection that could be a crucial turn in the long political career of Indira Gandhi.

title: Both East and West Regard Iran As Pivotal in the Power Balance
description: By any military measurement, from strategic geography to stocks of advanced weapons systems, Iran is a pivotal state in the global balance of power. Political and military writers in the Soviet Union share this appreciation of Military Analysis Iran's military importance with planners in the United States and Western Europe.

title: World Gold
description: MONDAY. NOV. 6, 1978

title: Litter Basket Vanishing
description: In 1964, the Sanitation Department had litter baskets on 52,000 of the city's 135.000 street corners.

title: OBSERVER
description: Back in the golden flush of summer when the newspaper strike was young and gay and I still suffered from the reading habit, my eye was fetched one day by a headline in The National Enquirer. At that time one still read anything, so desperate were the cravings

title: Bride:
description: Publishers of bridge books have evinced two deplorable tendencies in recent years. One is toward highly inflatee prices, which is perhaps unavoidable; the other is to duplicate existing titles, which certainly is not.

title: Horowitz Loses Recital in Contract Dispute
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6  A concert manager called off a recital here by Vladimir Horowitz scheduled for yesterday because, the manager said, the pianist had failed to meet a deadline for returning a signed contract.

title: New U. S. Law May Aid New York In Its Drive on Cigarette Smugglers
description: State tax undercover agents, who used to have to follow cigarette smugglers through several states from North Caro. lina before arresting them in New York, will now be able to arrest them in other states, under a law just signed by President Carter.

title: Hopes for Early Arms Accord Fade in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6--Government officials said today that SovietAmerican momentum toward achieving a new strategic arms accord bad slowed largely because of political considerations, but also because of recent efforts by Moscow to conceal missiletest information from, American intelligence collectors.

title: Market Place
description: Pooled Funds Performances

title: Commission Submits 5 Names For Appeals Court in Tennessee
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) A nominating commission has submitted the names of three men and two women from which President Carter will select a new Federal appeals court judge in Tennessee the Justice Department said today.

title: Quake Shakes Northern Japan
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Tuesday, Nov. (Reuters)  A moderate earthquake shook Hokkaido, the northernmost of Japan's main islands, today but there were no reports of damage or casualties

title: SPECIAL INTERESTS SPEND $60 MILLION
description: Legalized political spending by specialinterest groups soared to record highs during the offyear election campaign that closed yesterday, enabling some candidates to finance milliondollar drives in their states.

title: Investment Advisers: Can Individuals Sue?
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether individual shareholders could sue investment advisers for damages or whether Congress intended the Investment Advisers Act to be strictly an enforcement tool of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Chief Judgeship at Stake In Gubernatorial Election
description: New York's next Chief Judge may be chosen in today's election, although there has been barely any mention of that job during the campaign and his name does not even appear on the ballot.

title: Recital: Carlo Bergonzi Returns For 3d New York Appearance
description: CARLO BERGONZI'S belated New York recital debut three seasons ago and its sequel last year were such successful occasions that the veteran tenor now appears to be making the event an annual one. On Sunday night he returned to Carnegie Hall, again with John Wustman at the piano, and presented a familiar but tasteful selection of Italian songs and arias.

title: Amociatad Prem
description: SCENE OF FATAL BLAZE: The Younker! department store, gutted by flames on Sunday, yesterday in Des Moines. Several employees were killed when fire broke out before the store opened at the Merle Hay shopping center.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: JOHN CHEEVER begins one of the 61 stories in this splendid collection this way: I would not want to be one of those writers who begin each morning by exclaiming, 0 Gogol, 0 Chekhov, 0 Thackeray and Dickens, what would

title: Inquiry Set In Dollar Drop
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (Reuters) A Congressional staff has been investigating allegations that United States banks deliberately drove down the value of the dollar for profit, Representative Joseph G. Minish, Democrat of New Jersey, said today.

description: Spscial tone New York Items

title: Carey Is Reported Planning To Make Changes in Cabinet
description: Governor Carey is planning a major shakeup in his Cabinet if he is reelected today. More than a halfdozen top administration officials would change posts, resign or be dismissed by the end of the year, according to highranking state officials.

title: World News Briefs
description: Special to The New York Times

title: EARNINGS
description: Increased orders for commercial aircraft helped the Boeing Company more than double its profits in the third quarter and lift them by 72.9 percent in the first nine months this year, according to results reported yesterday by the nation's largest aircraft builder.

description: Irate Driver Clubs Pedestrian to Death

description: Foreign exchange traders continued to show their pleasure with the Carter Administration's dollarstrengthening program yesterday as United States currency had a strong day against most currencies at home and abroad, The Associated Press retorted.

title: U.S. Modifies Taiwan's Request for Advanced Planes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  The United States announced today that it had rejected Taiwan's request for advanced jet fighters able to strike the Chinese main, land and had instead decided to offer the Chinese Nationalists 48 more F5E's, strictly defensive planes.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Relative stability returned to the gold and silver futures markets yester day, while the much larger grain and soybean trade was unsettled by reports of bumper cmnn in the Snvipt irninn

title: U.S. Offers to Aid China In Energy Development
description: TOKYO, Nov. 6 (UPI)  The United States has offered to help China develop its immense energy reserves in what would be the first joint economic venture between the two countries since the 1919 Communist takeover, Energy Secretary James R. Schlesineer said today.

title: United Press International
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford campaigning with Republican Senator Charles H. Percy at Midway Airport in Chicago yesterday. Senator Percy's Democratic opponent in today's election is Alex R. Seith.

title: SACCHARIN QUESTION BACK TO CONGRESS
description: In an important sense, the National Research Council's new report on saccharin puts responsibility for continued use of that artificial sweetener back on Con gress.

title: Anger and Apathy Among Voters Reflected in Close Midwest Races
description: CHICAGO. Nov. 6  In naregion in the country are more close races for statewide offices in prospect for tomorrow's offyear election than in the Middle West.

title: Chinese Seem To Ease Reins On Economy
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 6  In what appears to be a startling departure from policy in recent years, China is giving signs of introducing a limited market economy, accompanied by the elimination of some shortcomings of its planned Communist system.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: Coast Rider Challenging Cauthen
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Nov. 6  Darrell McHargue, who usually does his own driving on fourlegged thoroughbreds, will arrive in New York tomorrow looking for a chauffeur. He needs the chauffeur, he thinks, to catch Steve Cauthen.

title: AntiTamperism
description: Imagine for a minute that some 16thcentury Galileo of biology had invented a method of crossing the genes of bacteria in order to create new life forms. What organization would you have expected to oppose such an attempt by humanity to tamper with God's handiwork?

title: Candidates in Connecticut Wind Up Campaigning
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 6  Gov. Ella T. Grasso and her Republican challenger, Representative Ronald A. Sarasin, made lastminute campaign appearances across the state today to try to get out their votes for tomorrow's gubernatorial election.

title: Mary Herling, a Leader In Community Activities
description: Maiy Fox Herling of Bethesda, Md., influential in many areas of community and labor endeavor in Washington and New York, died Saturday of Parkinson's disease at Suburban Hospital in Washington. She was 84 years old.

title: Iran's Students and Merchants Form Unlikely Alliance Against Shah
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 6  The gutted banks, smoldering automobile carcasses, and matted debris from dozens of stores looted during the fierce weekend rioting against Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi mark an unmistakable trail from modern Teheran University to the Islamic and traditionbound bazaar.

title: Events
description: Music

title: $500,000 Award for Wrong Diagnosis as Retardate
description: The Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court yesterday upheld the state's first educational malpractice award, finding 3 to 2 that Daniel Hoffman of Queens had been improperly assigned to classes for retarded children.

title: 13 Copies of a Manual on Satellite Are Missing, SpyTrial Jury Is Told
description: HAMMOND, Ind., Nov. 6 (UPI)  The C.I.A. has been unable to find 13 copies of a technical manual for a United States spy satellite that was distributed to its agents, prosecution and defense lawyers said today in the trial of a man accused of selling one of the manuals to the Russians.

description: Finance

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Attriopheric Administration/UPI

title: Argentine Chief Shuffles Cabinet But Gives No Role to the Parties
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 6  President Jorge Rafael Videla reorganized his Cabinet today for the first time in his more than two years in power but provided no participation for political oarties or labor unions.

title: Obituary 1 No Title
description: Braillo

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP)  The Government said today that a review of scientific studies has confirmed that several pills taken by about 1.5 million adult diabetics increase the risk of fatal heart attacks.

title: Device to Kill Pain Used by Bergey
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 (AP)  Bill Bergey, the Philadelphia Eagles linebacker, had more than his competitive juices firing him up in yesterday's 103 victory over the Green Bay Packers.

title: $99 Coast Round Trip By Pan Am
description: In the latest sally in the fierce planefare competition, Pan American World Airways said yesterday that it would offer a $99 roundtrip bargain rate between New York and Los Angeles starting Nov. 15.
