title: , American Ballet Theater Receives $1 Million Grant.
description: American Ballet neater has been awarded a $1 million challenge grant by the National Endowment for the Arts. It is the largest amount granted a dance company by the Federal agency this vear. Each dollar of the award must be matched by $3 in privately raised contributions. The Endowment said the award had been made to eliminate an accumulated deficit, to establish a cash reserve and to cover increased omrating expenses.

title: Election Day
description: The cuss words of the political campaign this fall seem to be singleissue politics. The words refer to the increasing power wielded by a host of splinter groups to sway elections. Their passions range from right-to-work to right-to-life, extending even, as in Oregon, to lowcost dentures. Their muscle is being extensively denounced as unhealthy and undemocratic.

title: Do-It-Yourself Credo Keeps Budgets in Line For Small Community
description: BRENTWOOD, N.H. (UPI)  Most towns would have hired a contractor to put up a new town office building. But not the people of Brentwood. They are building their own.

title: Nissan Introduces in U.S. $12,000 280ZX Sports Car
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6  Japan's Nissan Motor Company, which fed the American appetite for sports cars that Britain had discovered but all but abandoned, is gambling that there is substantial market in the United States for a $12000 sports car.

title: $2 Billion Yearly Saving Expected From the Eradication of Smallpox
description: World Health Organization specialists in infectious diseases expect the conquest of smallpox to save the world as much as two billion dollars a year that would otherwise be lost to the ravages of the disease and the expenses of immunization and surveillance programs.

title: Moscow- Aide Concedes Differences in the Soviet Leadership Over Arms Pact
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 6-A highranking Communist Party official has acknowledged differences of opinion within the leadership on how to remove the last ob stacles to an accord limiting strategic arms: He says the pact can be completed only if both Washington and Moscow make the needed nolitical concessions.

title: Visit of Chinese Official Raises British Hopes for an Arms Deal
description: LONDON, Nov. 6 (Reuters)  Wang Chen, a Deputy Prime Minister of China, arrived here today for a 10day visit that has raised British hopes of completing arrangements for a big arms sale to Peking.

title: Lawyers Win Right to Unionize
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 6 (AP)  A group of Public Utility Commission attorneys won a ruling today that for the first time will permit them to form a union. The Pennsylvania Labor Relations Board, ruling on a petition by the Public Utility Commission Bar Association, said the attorneys are eligible for collective bargaining representation. None of the state attorneys now belong to unions.

title: Advertising
description: Philip H. Dougherty

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 7,1978

title: Typhoon Toll in Philippines 314
description: MANILA, Nov. 6 (AP)  TIle death toll from a typhoon that tore through the Philippines two weeks ago rose to 314 today and is expected to increase after complete reports are received, relief officials said. The national disaster coordination center said that 143 persons were still missing.

title: Economic Scene
description: Leonard Silk

title: ARAB LEAGUE BARS MEETINGS IN CAIRO
description: CAIRO, Nov. 6  The Arab League has decided to hold no more meetings in Cairo because of Egypt's plans for peace with Israel, according to the organization's secretary general.

title: Callaghan, a Master of Political Tightrope, Hanging On in Commons
description: LONDON, Nov. 6  Prime Minister James Callaghan's capacity for political survival, which has kept his minority Government alive through 29 perilous months, is likely to be demonstrated again in the House of Commons this week.

title: Beech Aircraft President Finds CrackerBarrel Precepts Useful
description: WICHITA, Kan. (AP)  Of the hundreds of mementos and awards filling his office, Frank E. Hedrick, president of the Beech Aircraft Corporation, takes special pride in two: a track medal he won as a teenager and a plaque for selling spark plugs.

title: Iacocca's Plans for Chrysler
description: DETROIT, Nov. 6  This week is my listening week, Lee Iacocca said today as he settled into his new office chair and began his first week as president and chief operating officer of the Chrysler Corporation, the nation's No. 3 automobile maker.

title: Civil Servants in Ghana Strike
description: ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 6 (AP)  Civil Servants protesting inflation and shortages of food in this West African nation struck over the weekend, cutting off electricity and water supplies, although shops were Open and public transport was functioning.

title: Notes on People
description: Heir to Thailand Throne Starts His Monkhond

title: F.B.I. Is Studying Yugoslav Groups After a Murder and a Firebombing
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  The Federal Bureau of Investigation is looking into what is believed to be an international plot in which a New York man was recently murdered and a Chicago factory was firebombed in an apparent attempt to extort money from Americans of Yugo. slay descent, bureau officials said today.

title: CITIBANK LIFTS RATE ON HOME MORTGAGES TO 10% FROM 91/2%
description: Citibank yesterday raised the interest rate it charges on residential mortgage loans to 10 percent, the highest ever charged home buyers in New York State.

title: Exiled Holy Man Hints He'll Call For War in Iran
description: PARIS, Nov. 6  Ayatollah Khomeini, the exiled Iranian religious leader who a symbol of resistance to the Shah, said today that he would call for civil war in Iran if the present method of political struggle doesn't work.

title: Justice
description: Criminal courts are on trial, charged with failing to protect the American people against criminal violence. Some critics attribute the failure to a gross shortage of resources that forces prosecutors and judges to indulge in pleabargaining, offering serious criminals a mild penalty in return for a auilty plea.

title: TV News Conference Scheduled by Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UPI) President Carter will hold his first post election news conference in Kansas City, Mo., Thursday, the White House announced today.

title: For Nancy Mehta, Wife of the Conductor, Life Is a Gilded Cage
description: Nancy Mehta left her seat at Avery Fisher Hall before the intermission. This is something she tries not to do, especially when the orchestra is playing a new work, because she fears her absence might be misinterpreted. But her attention had been irretrievably drawn to her husband's ankles: Zubin Mehta was on the podium conducting the New York Philharmonic in his white tie, tails, and a pair of distinctly brown socks!

title: Newspaper Strike: Murdoch Split Cleared Way for Pact
description: When Rupert Murdoch threw his bomb on Sept. 27, pulling The New York Post out of joint talks to end the newspaper strike, the smart money said the show was over. The New York Times and The Daily News would have to make a quick  and hence unfavorable  settlement with the pressmen =I get back into print before The Post built up an intolerable competitive advantage.

title: IN THE NATION
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania  If there's any romance left in railroading, a train buff ought to find it on the long haul across Attica from Kapiri Mposhi in Zambia to Dar es Salaam on the Indian Ocean. The socalled TanZam Railway is one of the best examples of modern engineering, Chinesestyle,

title: Knickerbocker Given CableTV Franchise for Queens
description: After two and a half years of negotiations, the New York City Board of Estimate has approved an application for a 20year cabletelevision franchise in Queens, which will make it the second borough to be wired for cable.

title: Peace Causes Are Enshrined At Swarthmore
description: SWARTHMORE, Pa., Nov. 6  The Swarthmore Peace Collection will soon commemorate 50 years of devotion to struggle in which failure is predictable and success elusive.

title: A Study Reports Rate of Syphilis Increasing in Male Homosexuals
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UPI)  Venereal disease is increasing faster among homosexual males than among heterosexuals, partly because of a reluctance of men and their doctors to discuss homosexual behavior, says a medical publication.

title: Garbage Problems Continue to Grow But Officials Try To Put the Lid On
description: When I walk out of my apartment house in the morning, the streets are so littered I feel as if I'm wading through garbage. Am I wrong, or is New York really a lot dirtier than it used to be?

title: MEDIATION IS BEGUN IN TANZANIAN WAR
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 6  African countries began mediation efforts between Uganda and Tanzania today, as their troops settled in for a bitter undeclared war in remote bushland west of Lake Victoria.

title: Color TV Industry Tuning In Record Sales
description: Christmas should be just a little merrier this year for color television makers. Consumers are paying more for their sets but apparently not liking it less

title: Tillman Fined on Padded Expenses As Port Authority's Publicity Head
description: John Tillman, the former director of public affairs for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, was fined $1,000 yesterday after pleading guilty to charges growing out of the systematic padding of his expense account

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FRONT AND CENTER The popularity of those free musicales continues at the Atrium patio of the Citicorp Center's Market area, where crosssection of New Yorkers converges in early evening to enjoy concerts by some of the best entertainers in town.

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: REV. JOHN KLEKOTKA PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 (AP)  The Very Rev. John Klekotka, president of Villanova University from 1959 to 1965, died Saturday at FitzgeraldMercy Hospital at the age of 63. Father Klekotka, native of Philadelphia and a member of the Augustinian order of the Roman Catholic Church, leaves two sisters. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered tomorrow at the University Chapel of Villanova.

title: Crash of Irish Horse at Show Helps U.S. Team to Triumph
description: The United States squad of Melanie Smith, Bernie Traurig, Buddy Brown and Dennis Murphy narrowly won the international jumping team title for the second consecutive year at the 95th National Horse Show, which closed Sunday at Madison Square Garden.

title: City's Corrections Chief Realigns Jobs of 65 Top Prison Officials
description: In what Correction Department officials described as the largest administrative shakeup in the department's history, 65 to 70 of New York City's highestranking prison officials were demoted, promoted or reassigned yesterday.

title: Is Monroe the Answer To Sloppy Knick Team?
description: In the playgrounds they have names for players who run and gun, go one-onone, show little poise and to whom defense is a nasty word. They call them Hot Does.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Oscar Dystel, president and chief executive officer of Bantam Books since 1954, yesterday was named chairman of the company, the largest paperback company in the world. Marc Jaffe was named to the newly created post of president and editor in chief and Alberto Vitale was named to the new post of executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: U.N. Is Again Seeking Stable Wheat Trading
description: GENEVA, Nov. 6 - A United Nations conference resumed here today its attempt to conclude an international agreement to stabilize world trade in wheat after failing during a sixweek first session to overcome major obstacles to an accord.

title: Allied Supermarket Chain Files for Bankruptcy
description: The supermarket industry, already beset by problems, was rocked by more. bad news yesterday as Allied Supermarkets Inc. and a subsidiary, Great Scott Super Markets Inc., announced they had filed for reorganisation under Chapter XI of the Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: Oil Gloom, Rate Fears Hurt Stocks
description: Disappointment over drilling results in the Baltimore Canyon combined with the prospect of stiff increases in interest rates to send stock prices lower yesterday in late trading. A partial recovery in gold bullion prices and political turmoil in Iran, a major oilproducing nation, also served to chill stock market sentiment.

title: Bad Eating Habits Are Termed Forerunner of Later Diseases
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 6 (AP)  The 30 to 40 percent of Americans who eat improperly do not feel any immediate symptoms, but the price may be bad health 20 years later, according to a leading nutrition expert.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: fltas

title: Prison Editor Pleased To Find a Challenge Like on the Outside
description: FORT MADISON, Iowa (AP)  Paul Driggers is so enthusiastic about his lob as assistant editor of an awardwinning magazine that he returns to the office tour nights a week to keep up with his wrirk.

title: State's Highest Court to Weigh Modern Museum Building Plan
description: A crucial court hearing that will affect plans by the Museum of Modern Art to build its controversial 42story apartment tower has been set for Nov. 27 by the State Court of Appeals. On that day the museum will present arguments attempting to overthrow a lower court's decision that found unconstitutional special state legislation enacted to allow construction of the multimilliondollar project.

title: NATION VOTES TODAY IN SKEPTICAL MOOD
description: Issues Ignored as the Candidates Stress Personal Qualities

title: 4 Die in Kansas Plane Crash
description: VASSAR, Kan., Nov. 6 (UPI) Federal officials today began combing a wooded area covered with the scattered wreckage of a light plane to try to determine what caused a crash that killed all four persons aboard. The remants of the plane, which was reported missing Sunday night on a flight from Tulsa, Okla., to Topeka, Kan., were discovered early today. Although the bodies had not been positively identified, they were believed to be two Topeka couples.

title: S.E.C. Fines Fried and Firm
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange announced disciplinary actions yesterday against Albert Fried & Company, a specialist firm on the Big Board, and Albert Fried Jr.. managing partner of the firm.

title: Vote. Today Critical for Sohio
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6 The voters of Long Beach, the industrial port and bluecollar neighbor of Los Angeles. are going to the polls tomorrow to help decide whether Middle West oil bills should go up.LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6 - The showpiece of Sohlo's campaign on be. half of its proposed Long Brach tanker terminal  a farrasching agreement by Sohio to help clam up Its neighbor's pollution  may be thwarted from an unexpected quarter: the Internal Revenue Serrice.

title: SHAH PUTS MILITARY IN CONTROL IN IRAN; U.S. ENDORSES MOVE
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 6  Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi put Iran under military rule today and then told his people in a conciliatory address that the move was only a temporary one to restore order. He said he would continue his efforts to form a coalition government.

title: U.N. to Aid Nicaragua Refugees
description: GENEVA, Nov. 6 (AP)  The office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees announced a $430,000 assistance program today for 10,000 Nicaraguans who sought refuge in Honduras after a civil uprising against President Anastasio Somoza Debayle in September. Most of the funds will be used to construct temporary wooden housing for the 3,500 refugees considered to be in greatest need.

title: Volunteer Firefighters Thriving In Communities on Long Island
description: SETAUKET, L.I.  In this age of professionalism and specialization, experts are called in for anything from the diagnosis of an uncommon cold to the analysis of a city official's supposedly offhand comment. So it may come as a surprise to many who do not live there to learn that in many suburbs fires are fought by nonprofessionals, who are not at all inexpert but who make their living at other things in other nlaces.

title: Allison's Victory Official In Disputed Dixie 500
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Nov. (AP)  Donnie Allison was officially declared the winner today of the disputed Dixie 500 Grand National stock car race yesterday at Atlanta Interna tional Raceway.

title: Ciulla Testifies to Horse Race Fixes At Trial of Nine Jockeys and Trainers
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N.J.. Nov. 6  Anthony (Big Tony) Ciulla quietly continued spinning a lurid tale of race track corruption today in the trial of nine jockeys and trainers indicted for fixing races at Garden State Park four years ago.

title: Specials Are 'sweeping
description: November is a special month, in more ways than one. It is a month that yields a bumper crop of television specials, in deference to the drive by stations to attract as many viewers as possible, because advertising rates will be set in accordance with the ratings. November, like February and May, is sweep month, one when the A.C. Nielsen ratings are translated into future income.

title: Carter's New Image: Exercising Power With Confidence After a Period of Vacillation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 Whatever the outcome of tomorrow's elections, this fall, marked by the breakthrough at Camp David and the effort to rescue the dollar, will probably become known as the period when Jimmy Carter strength-

title: Panel in South Africa Meets for Investigation
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. (Reuters)  A judge and two leading lawyers today began investigating allegations that the South African Government had misused public funds for covert information activities. The controversy is being viewed as the most serious domestic political scandal faced by the National Party since it came to power 30 years ago.

title: Plans for Berlin Wall
description: EL PASO, Nov. 6  For nearly 20 years, aliens illegally entering this country from Mexico have been tunneling under, scampering over or crawling through the rickety chainlink fence that separates downtown El Paso from Juarez, Mexico, and nobody but the Border Patrol has seemed very much concerned.

title: 13 Teams Play Scoreboard Football In Race for 10 N.F.L. Playoff Berths
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Nov. 6 (AP) The National Football League informed the Green Bay Packers today that they have been cleared of any possible rules violation in their handling of a tryout for Duane Thomas, the former allpro running back.

title: Levich, in Preparing to Emigrate, Plans to Resign His Moscow Job
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 6-Veniamin 6- Levich, the highestranking Jewish scientist to apply for emigration, said today that he planned to resign from his job this week as a precondition for receiving a loneawaited visa.

title: Jones's 3 Touchdown Passes Lead COlts Over 'skins. 2117
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 6 (AP)  Bert Jones completed a courageous performance by hurling a 27yard touchdown pass to Roger Carr with minutes 8 seconds remaining to give the Baltimore Colts a 2117 upset victory over the Washington Redskins in National Football League game tonieht.

title: Guild Members, After Bitter Debate, Ratify Pact to End Times Strike
description: A bitter meeting of the Newspaper Guild unit at The New York Times continued amid shouting yuntil an early hour yesterday before members voted 226 to 121 to accept a new threeyear contract. The bargaining committee did not recommend the pact, and many union members complained that it was inferior and left numerous issues unresolved, to be settled through arbitration and mediation.

title: CORRECTION
description: The name of Ferdinand Kuhn, a former reporter for The Times, was given incorrectly in an obituary in Monday's issue.

title: Ellis Steals the Show as Spring Collections Open
description: Charisma. Star quality. Magnetism. Entertainers have it. So do politicians. And, to a great degree, fashioi designers. This explains, or at least describes, the response to Perry Ellis yesterday morning. Screams and yells and slightly glazed expressions, as when groupie meets her favorite rock staror her mother sees Frank Sinatra. This from grown women, working in highpressure jobs for large department stores. What fun, they murmured, order books clutched under their arms, as they emerged from the bleacher arrangement of seats the designer had set up in his new, unfinished, expanded quarters on Seventh Avenue.

description: 7% Limit Faces Negotiating Test

description: Yields rose on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and 182day maturities.

description: Sparky Lyle endured a season of unhappiness so he figures he can survive a few days of suspense before learning if the Yankees really are trading him to the Texas Rangers.

title: Sleds Are Born In Summer
description: DUNCANNON, Pa., Aug. 3 (AP) While almost everyone else is thinking about the seashore or swimming pools, only one thing is on the minds of employees sweltering in 90degree heat at the Standard Novelty Works here snow.

title: Woman and Her Daughter Killed In Staten Island Townhouse Fire
description: A woman and her 2-year-old daughter were burned to death yesterday morning in a fire in their condominium townhouse in the Arden Heights section of Staten_Island.

title: Happy All the Time
description: IT is difficult to describe happiness. Everyone remembers Dante's Inferno, but how many recall his Paradiso'? Most of our images of paradise are insipid: the Garden of Eden, angels floating in featureless space, or a promised land where the sun always shines, the buildings are of gold, and the rivers run with jewels.

title: Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov.  It is the time of season when the Giants start thinking seriously about Tom Rosantz.

title: Westchester Legislature Delays Vote on Raises for Top Officials
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 6  The Westchester County Board of Legislators delayed a vote today on raises for top county elected and appointed officials after more than 300 people turned out to oppose the move.

title: The Complex and Sometimes Indecisive Ruler of Iran
description: Shah Mohammed Riza Pahievi, the ruler of Iran, is a complex autocrat whose disparate traits have puzzled, charmed, surprised and infuriated friend and foe over the years.

title: Private Armies Stir Alarm in Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia  Small pri1 gate armies have sprung up in recent weeks around each of the three black, leaders who have joined with Prime Minister Ian D. Smith in a transitional coalition.

title: Tribute to a Driver
description: THOMPSON, Conn., Nov. 6 (AP) The proceeds from a benefit program for Fred DeSarro yesterday will help the family of the stockcar driver pay for medical expenses. More than 12,000 fans turned out at Thompson Speedway to pay tribute to the Rhode Islander who died last week as a result of an accident on the speedway last month.

title: Carey Back in Old Neighborhood, Duryea Upstate as Campaign Ends
description: On the last full day of campaigning before today's elections, Governor Carey and Assemblyman Perry B. Duryea toured friendly territory. The Governor spent much of yesterday in his old Brooklyn neighborhood, while Mr. Duryea went by plane into traditional Republican enclaves around the state.

title: A1 C'arirzines Inspired By Brush With Death
description: Death made a pass at Al Carmines this last year, and the protean minister, composer, pianist, lyricist, playwright and cabaret singer has requited in his usual manner. He has written a musical about it.

title: WESTCHESTER VOTES ON CONGRESS SEATS
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 6 Lively battles for two Congressional seats  one now held by the Republicans and the other by the Democrats  and a proposition to merge the Sheriff's office and the Parkway Police have developed into the most attentiongetting elements of tomorrow's balloting in Westchester County.

title: 2 New Indian Coaches
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 6 (AP)  The Cleveland Indians hired Dave Garcia and Chuck Hartenstein as coaches today, replacing Rocky Colavito and Harvey Haddix. Garcia, 58 years old, managed the California Angels from July 11, 1977, to last May 31.

title: Stage: Sam Shepard Offers Buried Child
description: SAM SHEPARD does not merely denounce chaos and anomie in American life, he mourns over them. His corrosive images and scenes of absurdity never soften to concede the presence of a lament, but it is there all the same.

description: The New York City Board of Education yesterday began an inspection of 290 schools to determine whether harmful levels of cancercausing asbestos were present in building materials.

description: DETROIT, Nov. 6 We do not accept Canadian money, read the sign at the end of the long counter at the McDonald's restaurant on Eight Mile Road here. __

description: DUDLEY, Mass., Nov. 6 (AP)  The deaths of two varsity football players and injuries to two other team members have ended the season for Nichols College and put the school in a period of mourning.

title: West Germany's Loyalty Checks Inspire Ridicule and Divide the Nation
description: BONN, Nov. 6  The soldier once said something subversive at breakfast, the loyalty report said. He gave himself away by suggesting that East Germany's sports organization was better than his own country's.

title: Blacks Mourning Death of Miller March to Wall Street in a Protest
description: From downtown Brooklyn across the bridge to the narrow streets of the financial district, hundreds of black residents of Crown Heights carried a message yesterday: We're fired up, we can't take no more,

title: UMW Preis International
description: RELIGIOUS VIOLENCE IN INDIA: Police in New Delhi clashing with Orthodox Sikhs who were protesting a meeting of a breakaway Sikh faction. Violeoce left three dead and about 100 injured.

title: Chinese Leader Warns Thailand About Soviet Expansionist
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 6  Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping of China, using thinly veiled language, warned Thailand tonight against Soviet 'expansionist activities in Southeast Asia.

title: C.A.B. End Set in Air Deregulation
description: WASEINOTON, Nov. 6 - After 40 years of regulating domestic airline mates, fares and mergers, the Civil Aeronautics Board is preparing to fly off into the sunset, allowing competition for markets to determine most of The nation's air servce in the future.

title: Consumer Debt Grows In Month
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP)  Consumers went more deeply into debt in September, increasing their outstanding installment credit by $3.28 billion in September, the Federal Reserve said today.

title: American Publishers Vote Against Signing Protocol With Russians
description: After two years of trying to work out an agreement that would lower the publishing and censorship bars between the United States and the Soviet Union, the board of directors of the nongovernmental Association of American Publishers has decided not to sign a protocol with the State Committee on Publishing, Printing and Book Trade, the official Soviet publishing agency.

title: 2 West Germans Lose in Appeal
description: BERN, Nov. 6 (Reuters)  A Swiss appeals court today dismissed complaints by two West Germans convicted as urban guerrillas that they had been denied fair trial. The two, Gabrielle KroecherTiedemann, 27 years old, and Christian Moller, 28, were sentenced in June to 15 and 11 years imprisonment respectively on charges that included attempted murder in a case involving the shooting and wounding of two Swiss customs at the SwissFrench border last December.

title: Black Educators Seek More Washington Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP)  Presidents of traditionally black colleges were in Washington today, attending workshops designed to help their schools to get bigger shares of Federal money.

title: SIGNING OF TAX CUT DELAYED BY CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  President Carter plans to wait until after Election Day to sign the $18.7 billion taxcut bill, White House sources said today, because he intends to criticize the legislation and does not want to harm the election prospects of the Congressional Democrats who out the bill together.

title: Iowa Beef Accepts Pacific Holding's Cash Offer
description: Iowa Beet Ptrocessors, the nation's largest producer of boxed beef, said yesterday that its board members had agreed to a $270 million cash marger deal with the Pacific Holding Corporation, a company owned by David H. Murdock, a Los Angeles businessman.

title: SINGAPORE ENJOYING INCONGRUOUS VISITS
description: SINGAPORE, Nov. 3  Having received Prime Minister Main Van Dong of Vietnam and a Soviet deputy foreign minister, Nikolai P. Firyubin, last month, and looking forward to the arrival Sunday of Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping of China, Singapore feels courted by those it feared and believes that Southeast Asia's nonCommunist nations have reason to reioice.

title: Luciano, Umpires
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 (UPI) Ron Luciano of the American League, who has been elected to a twoyear term as president of the Major League Umpires Association, announced plans today for a study of baseball.

description: Treasury Sale Puts Figure Close to 10.3%

title: Proposition 13, in 5 Months, Has Not Spurred Major Spending Cutbacks
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6- Five months after California's voters approved Proposition 13 by a margin of 2 to 1, the new limit on property taxes has not resulted in any significant cutbacks in spending or in the size of local Rovernment.

title: An Ethiopian Rebel Group Says It Seized Copter With 4 Aboard
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Nov. 6 (Reuters)  Members of an Ethiopian guerrilla group announced today that they had captured a helicopter carrying an American and three Ethiopians in Tigre, a northern province.

title: BOSTON WINS RULING IN A BALLOT DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  A divided Supreme Court refused today to block the city of Boston from spending taxpayer money to lobby for passage of a state constitutional amendment.

title: Shero Proving Modest About Ranger Success
description: With seven straight victories, the last three coming west of the Rockies and in two countries, the Rangers are rolling. Or are they?

title: Busing Distances Causing Population Shift in Los Angeles
description: CALABASAS, Calif., Nov. 6  When Paul Pulver emigrated from the Bronx after World War II, he followed the advice of a popular song and found his earthly paradise in the San Fernando Valiley of Los Angeles. A few weeks ago, Mr. Pulver abandoned his paradise for this fastgrowing community, north of the valley. Not long ago Calabasas was producing alfalfa and cattle.

title: Victory Sweet For Old Guy On Jet Team
description: Randy Rasmussen took some time yesterday to reflect on his feelings for Jim Turner, the enemy's kicker, while Rasmussen's Jet teammates remained excited after their dramatic victory over the Denver Broncos on Sunday.

title: Former Aide of Carter Is Convicted of Fraud In City School Billings
description: The deputy national field coordinator for President Carter's 1976 campaign has been convicted of fraudulently billing the New York City Board of Education for more than $100,000 for educational services his company did not provide.

title: BurnedOut Homes on Pine Street Being Replaced
description: The sounds of hammers, electric saws and a giant construction crane signaled a dramatic revival taking place on a Brooklyn block whose longtime workingclass stability was threatened by a fire that destroyed a row of a dozen small homes last March.

title: Maryland Man Given New Heart
description: RICHMOND, Nov. 6 (AP)  James E. Leasure, a 48-year-old retired automobile dealer from Bethesda, Md., received new heart in transplant surgery early today at the Medical College of Virginia. The heart was flown in Sunday night from an unidentified donor in Rochester, N.Y. A spokesman at MCV said Leasure was in satisfactory condition.

title: Piltdown Man Is Termed a Trap Set by One Geologist for Another
description: LONDON, Nov. 6  According to evidence that has just come to light, Piltdown Man, the faked missing link that bamboozled the anthropological world for two generations, was simply a trap set by one eminent geologist to make monkey out of another.

title: From Crafts Fairs to Cartier, Glittering all the Way
description: What are the odds that a street crafts seller will make it to Cartier? Probably hundreds of thousands to one. But Marsha Breslow made it. Her designs are not only in Cartier, but also have a corner of their own that just opened yesterday in Bloomingdale's fine jewelry department. And they are turning up at a lot of stores around the country, for a business that has done over $4 million so far this year.

title: 6 Die in Ohio Mobile Home Fire
description: ROGERS, Ohio, Nov. 6 (UPI)  Six members of a family died in a fire that destroyed their mobile borne early today, Columbia County sheriff's deputies reported. Six other members of the family escaped. Deputies said the cause of the fire was not immediately determined.

title: F.B.I. Agent Indicted in Brooklyn On Charges of Obstructing Justice
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New York, already under indictment on charges that he lied to a grand jury about accepting a bribe from an alleged underworld figure, was indicted again today in Brooklyn on charges of conspiracy and obstruction of justice stemming from the same incident.

title: Ted Brown Obstacle In Penn State's Path
description: Four years ago Thomas Edward Brown was a shorter-than-average high school basketball player in High Point, N.C., who felt certain 9 was better basketball player than football player.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weathat at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Ahnoaphenc Administration/UPI

title: Addressograph Seeking Microda.ta in Stock Deal
description: The AddressographMultigraph Corporatiqn, in its first major acquisition since an impressive turnaround under the leadership of Roy L Ash, said yesterday that it had offered to acquire the Microdata Corporation for stock.

title: TEACHER RESIDENCY IS SET TO BE ARGUED
description: Legal arguments will be heard tomorrow on a temporary judicial order that has prohibited the city's Board of Education from enforcing its stringent new residency requirements for 4,500 supervisors and administrators in the public schools.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AllSteel Inc., Aurora, Ill., manufacturer of metal office furniture and equipment and wholly owned subsidiary of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation, has elected Joseph H. Hartman to chairman of the board and George W. French to president and chief administrative officer.

title: Amusement Park Sued in Crash
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 7 (AP)  A 54.5 million damage suit has been filed against Six Flags Over MidAmerica, an amusement park, on behalf of a 12-year-old Chesterfield, Mo., girl who was iniured in a Cable car accident that killed her sister and two other relatives. The suit was filed yesterday in St. Louis Circuit Court on behalf of Jennine Weeks, who suffered multiple fractures and internal injuries when a cable car on the Sky Way ride plunged 70 feet to the ground. Her sister, Trisha, 10, a cousin, Kristen Johnson, 15, and an uncle, Clark F. Johnson, 25, were killed in the accident July 26.

title: Election Day Lockout Strands Councilwoman
description: City Councilwoman Ruth Messinger arrived at her office across the street from New York's City Hall yesterday and found the place locked for Election Day. an official holiday.

title: Bakshi Journeys to Middle Earth to Animate Lord of the Rings
description: LOS ANGELES

title: G.M.'s Dividend Cut Sends Stocks Reeling
description: The shock effect of a reduced yearend dividend from General Motors sent the stock market plummeting yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 19.81 points to finish at 800.07.

title: Prof. Everard M. Upjohn Of Columbia Dies at 74
description: Everard M. Upjohn, professor emeritus of art history at Columbia University, died Friday at his home in Hightstown, N.J. He was 74 years old.

title: Press and Public Role in Pretrial Hearing Argued
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  The question of when a judge can eject the public and the press from a pretrial hearing was argued before the Supreme Court today in a case with potentally broad implications for press coverage of criminal proceedings.

title: Bakers Strike in England
description: LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP) A strike by 26,000 members of the Bakers Union in England and Wales early today cut off 70 percent of the supply of baked goods, mostly packaged bread for supermarkets. The union wants a 26 percent raise to just over $103.

title: Recital: Italian Soprano
description: KATIA RICCIARELLI'S recital at Carnegie Hall on Monday night seemed to have been perversely designed to emphasize what the Italian soprano does not do well at this stage of her career. Having made something of a splash in international opera circles in recent seasons, she is apparently determined to expand her reputation into what may be called, with all due respect to the lyric theater, the more demanding field of the artsong.

title: ABRAMS IS VICTORIOUS
description: Governor Carey won a second term handily yesterday with a comeback reminiscent of Nelson A. Rockefeller's quadrennial electionyear resurrections.

title: Soviet Defense Minister, at Fete, Denounces the Policies of Peking
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 7  Marshal Dmitri F. Ustinov, the Soviet Defense Minister, accused China today of damaging revolu, tionary and national liberation movement in developing countries. It was an evident allusion to Vietnam, made while Hanoi's visiting party leader, Le Duan, listened with the Soviet Politburo atop the Lenin Mausoleum in Red Square.

title: Whites Are Attacked in Zambia In Reaction to Rhodesian Raids
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Nov. 7 (Reuters) Zambian crowds attacked whites in the center of Lusaka today in an outburst of anger and suspicion over Rhodesian inetirsinns into this country.

title: American Publishers Balk At Renewal of Trade Pact
description: Winthrop Knowlton, chairman of the Association of American Publishers, said yesterday that the book organization had no present plans to renew with the Soviet Union's committee on publishing a protocol design to facilitate trade between American and Soviet publishers.

title: A Portrait of Electorate: Large. Young and Reluctant
description: Voters who went to the polls yesterday came from the largest, youngest and most Southern and Western electorate in American history. They also came, by most experts estimates, from an electorate that was less likely to exercise its franchise than at almost any time in the 150 years that accurate records on voter turnout have been kent.

title: WASHINGTON Monnet At Ninety
description: WASHINGTON, Nov.7  After the chirpy trivialities of this election campaign, it's a relief to read the memoirs of Jean Monnet, who will be 90 this week and can still make the democratic process seem coherent and even noble.

title: Rising Exodus of Vietnamese Spurs Fear That Many Will Perish at Sea
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 7  A dramatically heightened flow of refugees leaving Vietnam on small fishing boats, which reached record levels this month, is vastly exceeding the present willingness of countries of asylum to accept them. Officials concerned with refugee problems here and in Malaysia fear that the result may be much greater loss of life.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Economy

title: Television
description: Morning

title: 3Month Sentence on Medicaid
description: Dr. George F. Frasca, a 3S-year-old chiropractor from Scarsdale, N.Y., was sentenced to three months in prison and five months of probation on Medicaidfraud charges. Judge Vincent L. Broderick imposed the sentence in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Dr. Frasca was said to have submitted invoices for services he had not rendered at Medicaid clinics in Manhattan and the Bronx.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Minter Keeps His Title As Foe Quits After 6th
description: LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP)  Alan Minter of Britain retained his European middleweight title tonight when Gratien Tonna of France retired at the end of the sixth round of their schedtlipei 15round fight.

title: Wine Talk
description: WHEN this column last appeared, on Aug. 9, most knowledgeable people in the French wine trade were predicting poor vintage this year. True, the sun had begun to shine after a cold spring and late-starting summer. But, the wine men said, it would have shine steadily until October and everyone knows that that never happens in the great vineyards of France. Well, it did, and 1978 will be a respectable year.

title: Camden Teachers Back at Work
description: CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 7 (UPI) Teachers here have returned to their classrooms after a monthlong strike that disrupted claSses for the district's 22,000 students. Attendance Monday was put at 90 percent at elementary schools and 85 percent at the high schools.

title: Mrs. Grasso Rides on Merit
description: In 1974, became the first woman in the country to be elected governor on her own merits rather than following husband into office, as was the case of Lurleen Wallace in Alabama began political life as protg of the late John Bailey, Democratic national chairman under. President John F. Kennedy and leader in Connecticut politics for 30 years  elected to Connecticut House of Representatives in 1953 and in 1958 won election as Secretary of State ... House of Representatives, in 1970 and again in 1972 ... born May 10, 1919, in Windsor Locks, Cmin., where she still lives .. . married to Thomai A. Grasso and has two adult children, Susane and James ... at first, her administration was marked by austerity programs, but in campaign she emphasized recent budget surpluses and vowed again, as she did four years ago, that she would never allow a state income tax ... educated at private schools and earned bachelor's anti master's degree at Mount Holyoke College.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: With the credit markets largely closed for Election Day, fixedincome securities showed little change in price yesterday and trading activity came to a nearstandstill. Corporate bond prices rose modestly.

title: Careers
description: THE master of business administration degree from a prestigious university remains a prime moneygetter upon graduation, despite the growing number of M.B.A.'s. People who got a degree in 1978 from the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration started at an average salary of $25,479 a year, a survey finds, compared with last year's $22,595. Part of the increase, of course, is a result of inflation. The Harvard survey drew responses from 636 students, about 90 percent of this year's class.

title: The Question Of Credibility
description: Right from the start, a major aim of Perry B. Duryea's campaign for Governor was to question the credibility of the incumbent, Hugh L. Carey. But in the final weeks of the campaign Mr. Dur-

title: Ruling on Fingerprinting of Juror
description: The fingerprints of prospective grand jurors cannot be retained by the state after they have been used to check whether the juror has a criminal record, a justice in State Supreme Court in Manhattan ruled Monday.

title: Letter by Spy Suspect Neglected
description: HAMMOND, Ind., Nov. 7 (UPI)  An employee of the Central Intelligence Agency who says he dreamed of becoming a fullfledged spy for the agency and who is now being tried as a spy for the Soviet Union wrote about his contacts with the Russians in a letter to his superiors, but the letter went unopened for two months, an agency official says.

title: Letters
description: Cambridge, Mass., Nov. 1, 1978 The writer, emeritus professor of chemistry at Harvard University, was assistant to President Eisenhower for science and technology.

title: Deaths
description: SCHLESINDER--,Abiwy. seip...e0 /..),. bend of Florence. Devoted father of Jeffrey & Susan. Cherished grandfather. Dear brother. Services to day, 10AM, at The Riverside Bronx, 179 St & Grand Concourse.

description: Two giant California savings and loan associations yesterday raised the interest rate they charge on residential mortgage loans to 103A percent from 101/2 percent, the highest rate on home loans there since 1974, when they exceeded 11 percent.

description: District Finals Are Played In the Largest Match Ever

title: Carrier Deal Studied By Technologies
description: Edward L. Hennessy, senior vice president of the United Technologies Corporation, said that the company's sales should exceed $6 billion in 1978 and $7 billion in 1979 with 1979 producing some $9 billion in sales if the proposed acquisition of the Carrier Corporation goes through.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1978

title: No Longer TreeTop Airways
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 7  When a 31yearold New Yorker, Francisco A. Lorenzo, and his equally young partner, Robert J. Carney, a New Englander, took control of Texas International Airlines six years ago, the company was a joke. Only recently had it changed its name from TransTexas Airways, and passengers still derided it as Tinker Toy or Tree Top Airways.

title: Ratchford, a Democrat, Winning Race for Sarasin Seat in Congress
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 7  William R. Ratchford, Democrat of Danbury, appeared tonight to have defeated his Republican opponent, State Senator George C. Guidera of Weston, in the only race for an open Congressional seat in Connectirtit

title: Tets 2, Nordiques 1
description: QUEBEC CITY, Nov. 7 (UPI) Mike Amodeo's goalat 3:56 of the third period broke a 11 tie tonight and lifted the Winnipeg Jets to a 21 triumph over the World Hockey Associationleading Quebec Nordiques. It was the Nordiques first loss in six games.

title: Republicans Win Governorship Contests in 7 States; Democrats Score Gains in Maine and South Carolina
description: The Republican Party headed toward some encouraging gains in governorships last night, ousting Democrats in a halfdozen states and threatening them in two or three others.

title: Martinelli Steps Ahead of Peyser In Contest in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 7  Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli of Yonl.;ersi RepublicanConservative, was leading Peter A. Peyser, the Democratic candidate, in early, scattered returns from today's balloting for the 23d Congressional District seat.

title: Screen: Avildsen's 'Slow Dancing':Rocky on the Hoof
description: THE hero of "Slow Dancing in the Big City" looks like a plain, ordinary big lug, but in fact he's a well-known lug-about-town whose very name  Lou Friedlander  is enough to make people ooh and aah and hope to catch his eye. Lou, played by Paul Sorvino, is a Very Famous Columnist for The Daily News, and his specialties are overworking metaphors and writing about the little guy. The more upbeat the little guy, the better  not for nothing is Lou's column advertised as "The Heart of the Apple." As the movie begins, Lou is hard at work on the tale of a man who tried to jump off the Brooklyn Bridge and the Eskimo named Comet who saved him. As Lou puts it, "Who says Eskimos are a dying breed?"If you're planning to watch "Slow Dancing in the Big City" with the kind of beatific optimism Lou lavishes on all his subjects, then you'd better suppose  from the facts that he works in his underwear, has a desk littered with beer cans and calls a lovesick cleaning woman his "muse"  that Lou is one great talent as well as one great guy.And you'll have to, as Lou himself might put it, turn the other cheek when the long arm of coincidence plants Sarah, an exotic hothouse flower of a dancer, in the relatively barren soil of Lou's brownstone. In other words, don't be surprised when this gorgeous, rich creature moves from her own palatial setup into a dreary cubbyhole across the hall from Lou.The script, chock-full of coincidences just this unlikely, has Sarah shrug about the grubbiness of the place and explain that she'll brighten it up when she brings a few things over. Sure enough, she later arrives with her parakeet, who has a clever name and lives in a very decorative cage.When John Avildsen was removed as the director of "Saturday Night Fever," there were complaints that he had been trying to recreate his prior triumph by turning that film into a dancing "Rocky." This time, having hung onto his dream and come up with a "Rocky" in toe shoes, Mr. Avildsen demonstrates the same kind of pluck and endurance his characters have  Lou, Sarah, Rocky or even Orville (Mr.) Wright, the parakeet. So Rocky talked to turtles? So Lou and Sarah hope that one day Orville will be set free, to spread his wings and find his piece of the sky.Sarah is the Rocky-ette of the piece, because she has just one great performance in her, and she must sweat and strain to go the distance. But Sarah, as played by Anne Ditchburn, the Canadian dancer, is so beautiful that she doesn't have to say much about this, especially because Lou is on hand to supply the sentiment. "I tellya, if we can beat the odds in New York, we can do anything  walk on the moon, kiss the stars, turn the garbage into roses," Lou enthuses, the first time he takes Sarah to dinner. "You're a poet," she replies. "You're beautiful," says he, bending forward to kiss her hand.Sarah's high-tone background is just evident enough to give the film a touch of class struggle, the better to establish that the Lou-Sarah romance is star-crossed while aiming the dance sequences at the "Turning Point" crowd. But Mr. Sorvino and Miss Ditchburn are so obviously mismatched that their incompatibility hardly needs special emphasis.Mr. Sorvino is perfectly plausible as a newsman. But when the screenplay finally rules out the possibility that Sarah merely regards him as a pal, it does him in. Miss Ditchburn, making her acting debut, is so glamorous and mystifyingly odd that she recalls the young Audrey Hepburn, but she, too, is sabotaged by the script. One character describes Sarah as "a natural spellbinder ... she tries not to be  that only makes things worse." This is not a helpful thing to say about a woman who never goes anywhere without the perfect strip of antique lace tied just-so, to flatter her perfect forehead.Clearly, Mr. Avildsen had better luck with "Rocky" than he's had this time, even though the material is similar enough to make comparisons inevitable. The formula's failure on its current go-round is a good deal less baffling than its first flush of success."Slow Dancing in the Big City" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). The featured romance is pointedly sexless, but there is some strong language elsewhere in the film, particularly in a subplot about street kids. And Miss Ditchburn's rehearsal outfits have a way of slipping off her shoulders.

title: Too Many Chefs idn't Spoil the Broth They Iced the Cake
description: CHATEAU DE VIZILLE, FRANCE

title: Bert Jones Makes Colts Go
description: Can there be such a thing as a oneman football team? Apparently there. can, the Baltimore Colts being the team and Bert Jones being the man. Confirmation comes from Roger Carr, the wide receiver with the big ears, who said after Baltimore beat Washington, 2117, on Monday night, Bert is the heart and guts of this team.

title: Abrams Tried Four Years Ago Against Lefkowitz
description: Bronx Borough President since Jan. 1, 1970 ... Unsuccessful Democratic candidate for State Attorney General four years ago against the Republican incumbent, Louis J. Lefkowitz ... considered a liberal, is antiorganization Democrat ... served four years as State Assemblyman, concentrating on reforms in prisons, curbing child abuse, election laws and consumer protection . .. practiced law for six years in Manhattan .. . received law degree from New York University Law School in 1963 after getting Bachelor of Arts degree from Columbia College in 1960 . born in the Bronx, July 9, 1919 Married the former Diane Schulder in 1979 and h(s a daughter, Rachel, 2 ... likes to collect stamps and travel ... has promised to make office of Attorney General the people's law firm.

title: Shapiro Apparently Beats Notte In Essex County Executive:Race
description: Assemblythan Peter Shapiro, the Democrat, apparently defeated his Republican rival, Robert F. Notte, yesterday in the race for the newly created post of County Executive in Essex County.

title: Entertainment Events
description: SPARROW IN FLIGHT, a musical based on the lite of Ethel Waters by Charles Fuller; based on conceot by Rosetta Lenoire; directed by Dean Irby; choreography and costume design by Ber nard Johnson; starring Ethel Ayler, at the AMAS Repertory Theater, Inc.. 1 East 164th Street, Thursday through Saturday, 7:30 P.M.; Sunday at 3 P.M., through Nov.19.

title: Implications of Uganda's Invasion Overshadow the Scale of Fighting
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov 7  Judging from the scale of combat and the prize involved  a small slice of not especially fertile land. the fighting between Uganda and Tanzania over their boundary west of Lake Victoria could be just another one of Africa's obscure bush wars. But the implications of the conflict are greater than that.

title: Policeman Stabbed
description: Two youths lured a policeman from his car in Brooklyn Monday night and one held him while the other knifed him in the arm.

title: Advertising
description: Philip H. Dougherty

title: Books of TheTimes
description: WHEN she was 5 years old, a child of my acquaintance one day announced a theory that she was inhabited by rabbits. There was a team of rabbits inside of her, she insisted, who were responsible for her every func-

title: Discos Through Russian Eyes
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 7 (AP)  A Soviet journalist says New York discotheques are havens of decadence and loneliness where dancers snort cocaine in the bathrooms and spend a whole night shaking with the lights and dreaming of fame, sucCESS and money.

title: Pennsylvania May Go to U.S. Court Over rocks Dam
description: PHILADELPHIA  While a bill that all but kills plans for the controversial Tucks Island Dam on the Delaware River awaits President Carter's signature, Pennsylvania is considering Federal court action over it.

title: A Practical Intellectual
description: Regarded as intellectual, practical, religious, a conciliator, introspective with a quick sense of humor ... born June 15, 1932, of immigrant parents . . . attended St. John's Prep and St. John's University and Law School ... practiced law in Queens and taught at St. John's Law SChool ... defended Corona, Queens, homeowners in 1966 against a city plan that would have destroyed their homes ... was Mayor John V. Lindsay's conciliator during controversy over plan for lowincome project in Forest Hills, Queens ... ran for Lieutenant Governor in 1974, but lost Democratic primary to Mary Anne Krupsak ... appointed Secretary of State by Governor Carey the next year ... lost to Edward I. Koch in Democratic primary and runoff for Mayor in 1977, then lost election, running on Liberal line ... asked to run for Lieutenant Governor by Governor Carey after Miss Krupsak's withdrawal ... wife, Matilda, is a teacher ... has five children and lives in Hollisvrood, Queens.

title: The Candidates and the Issues in Key Senatorial and Gubernatorial Contests
description: Donald Stewart, a Democrat who made a reputation as a consumer champion in the State Senate, seemed headed for victory over a littleknown Republican in the race to succeed the late Senator James Allen. But in late summer, former Representative James Martin jumped in with strong backing from the national Republican party.

title: Suffolk County Voters Approve Measure to Initiate Referendums
description: Taking a lead from the approval by California votersof taxlimiting Proposition 13, Suffolk County residents yesterday approved a measure that will give the electorate the right to put referendums on the ballot without the prior con. sent of the County Legislature.

title: In a Chili Ritual, the Torch Is Passed
description: TERLINGUA, Tex., Nov. 5 By early Saturday morning, the rocky landscape that distinguishes this forlorn part of Texas looked like a giant displaced persons camp whose inhabitants had been sustaining themselves for weeks on nothing but beer.

title: Pianist: VitaLia Boursouk
description: SCHUMANN'S Symphonic Etudes is one of the largescale 19thcentury masterpieces for piano, but it acquired exceptional breadth and grandeur in the performance by Vitalia BoUrsouk in Alice Tully Hall on Monday night. The artist gave over the second half of her program exclusively to it. By adding the five posthumous etudes, making all the repeats and taking, in some instances, extraordinarily slow tempos, she make the work fill the appropriate length easily.

title: Talking Business
description: The intensifying battle against inflation and the success of airline deregulation are causing considerable upheaval in the $22 billion trucking industry. For months motor carriers have been formulating arguments and strategies against the popular notion that regulation by the Interstate Commerce Com- mission has increased significantly the cost of truck transportation. Yesterday Arthur Imperatore, president of the APA Transport Corporatipn, one of the largest and most profitable trucking companies the country, gave his reaction to moves in Washington to speed up trucking deregulation.

title: Most Voters Stay With Democrats As AntiIncumbent Feeling Eases
description: American voters stayed with the Democrats yesterday. giving the Republicans only modest gains, if that, as they spurned the Republican Party's call for sharp Federal tax cuts.

title: TV: Cry
description: TONIGHT ON CBS, Mary Tyler Moore stars in First You Cry, the story of Betty Rollin, an NBC news correspondent, and her experience with breast cancer. Also tonight, The Good Doctor is on Channel 13, representing theefirst fulllength Neil Simon play produced for television. Both productions are scheduled for 9 P.M. If a viewing decision is required, Miss Moore wins quite handily in this corner.

title: South Africa Arras Sale Checked
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  The United States, Britain and Canada are investigating reports in London that a Canadianbased arms manufacturer has shipped artillery and shells to South Africa in violation of a United Nations embargo.

title: Some People Collect Just About Anything
description: THERE are collectors who will pay, as a couple of them did last year, $3,105 for a windup Mickey Mouse toy or $220,000 for a turn-of-the-century Faberge egg from Russia. And then there are the rest of us.

title: Age Barrier Is Overcome For Saturday Night Visit
description: ELYRIA, Ohio (AP)  Jeanne Hahn wanted to spend Saturday nights with her daughter on an island in Lake Erie, but the last plane left before she finished giving organ lessons. So, at 61 years old, she decided to learn to fly.

title: Na End Yet In Interest Rates Rise
description: A relatively long period of rising shortterm and longterm interest rates lies ahead, the Chase Money Market Report predicted yesterday after analyzing the behavior of interestrate trends of the postwar business cycles.

title: U.S. Draws on I.M.F.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (Reuters) The United States withdrew $2 billion in marks and yen from the International Monetary Fund today in a further effort to strengthen the dollar by limiting its circulation in world money markets.

title: Building Plans in Detroit Raising Hope for Future
description: DETROIT, Nov. 7  Time for the Renaissance News, says the announcer on WJZZ, a leading jazz radio station here. Take the Silver Streak to the RenCen! declares a commercial on another station, promoting Saturday morning train rides for only a buck from the affluent suburbs to the Renaissance Center in downtown Detroit.

title: World Gold
description: TUESDAY, NOV. 7, 1978

title: Lawrence Evans, 83, Managed Concert Stars
description: Lawrence Evans, a former manager of opera and concert performers, died in White Plains Hospital on Oct. 23. He was 83 years old.

title: Seaver Gets 5Year Pact
description: NAGOYA, Japan, Nov. 7 (AP) Tom Seaver, threetime National League Cy Young Award winner, has signed a fiveyear contract with the Cincinnati Reds, Dick Wagner, executive vice president, announced today.

title: Best Buys
description: FOOD bills have gone up a full 10 percent this year, the City Department of Consumer Affairs reports today, noting that one recent cause is soaring sugar prices. Last week alone, the price of a sixpack of cola drink went up 8 cents, to $1.89. Last year at this time it cost $1.68. Obviously, cutting back on soft drink consurnption is one way to fight back.

title: Former Athlete Victor in First Bid for Office
description: A 35-year-old exRhodes Scholar who was an AllAmerican basketball player at Princeton University 15 years ago and later a star with the New York Knicks  lives in Denville ... cam- paign for the Senate was first race for public office ... active in Democratic politics last year, supporting Governor Byrne ... defeated two other major candidates  former State Treasurer Richard C. Leone and former State Senator Alexander Merin  in the Democratic primary in June ... won easily after portraying himself as a moderate-to-liberal Democrat ... in the general election, endorsed the concept of a major tax cut but cautioned against the drastic cuts being pushed by conservative Republicans ... said he wanted to cut out the fat, not the heart of welfare programs ... during his 10 years with the Knicks, was one of the highestpaid basketball players. A financial statement he released earlier this year showed him to be a millionaire ... avoided controversey as far as possible during the campaign but drove himself and his staff hard ... on defense matters, portrayed himself as hardliner and protested when President Carter vetoed the spending of $2 billion for an atomicpowered aircraft carrier ... seemed to avoid allying his campaign with President Carter, although the President endorsed him at a labor convention in Atlantic City in September ... voters seemed to view him as a celebrity because of his acquaintance with television and motion picture actors, many of whom were responsible for much of the $1.5 million he in the election.

title: Iranian Opposition's Quandary: Coalition or Military Rule
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 7  The military rule that Shah Mohammed Riza PahleVi imposed on Iran yesterday confronts opposition groups with a difficult choice: whether to challenge the armed forces and risk the suppression of their

title: Islanders Defeat North Stars by 52
description: UNIONDALE,L.I., Nov. 7  The Islanders have no mercy. With Ham, Howell, the Minnesota North Stars coach, in the hospital, the Islanders handed his club a 52 defeat tonight at Nassau Coliseum. extending a victoryt(K% mad trio for Minnesota.

title: The Low and High of It
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  In the last two decades, Federal funds have been steadily diverted from the subsidizing of innovations to the maintenance of the status quo. As a result, the United States traditional world domi- nance in high technology is falling, the dollar is shrinking, and our standard of living is sinking toward that of our foreign coworkers.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP)  The dollar lost ground on European currency exchanges in light trading today after rebounding for four days on the strength of President Carter's rescue plan for the currency.

title: SovietVietnamese Treaty May Alter Sea Strategies
description: The signature of a treaty of friendship and cooperation between the Soviet Union and Vietnam complicates an already delicate strategic situation in East Asia involving the Soviets, the United States, China and North and South Korea.

title: Allied Lays Plight To Food Fair's Slip
description: DETROIT, Nov. 7  The financial distress of the Food Fair supermarket chain of Philadelphia was a prime factor in the decision by the Allied Supermarkets Inc. chain to seek protection from its creditors, Allied execntlyes say.

title: Why You Like Some Foods And Hate Others
description: EVERYBODY doesn't like something. Whether the aversion is to sauteed brains or McDonald's hamburgers, to Szechwan spiciness or Middle American blandness, everyone finds at least a few foods or flavors to be objectionable.

title: U.S. Warns Japan On Record Surpluses
description: TOKYO, Nov. 7 The United States Energy Secretary, James R. Schlesinger, winding up talks with Government officials here, warned today that Japan must reduce its record trade surpluses or run the risk that Congress will impose protectionist measures.

title: Gov. Grasso Wins 2d Term Easily; Bradley Defeats Bell for the Senate
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 7  Gov. Ella T. Grasso, the nation's first Governor elected in her own right four years ago, swept to a second term today after a campaign that focused on issues of state spending and opposition to a state income tax.

title: Real Estate
description: THE fight against inflation is moving full steam into the subsidized housing sector in the city. So far it has taken the form of a memorandum on developmentcost limits by the recently appointed area manager for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, Alan Wiener.

description: KAWASAKI, Japan, Nov. 7 (AP) Nancy Lopez, the sensation of the 1978 women's pro golf tour, won the individual event and combined with Ernesto Acosta for the team laurels today in an eightteam mixed doubles tournament.

title: Controls Help Medicaid Save Millions in Year
description: The phasingin at computerized controls over the $3 billion statewide Medicaid program for the sick poor has saved more than $24 million in New York City in the first year just ended, Barbara Blum, State Commissioner of Social Services, said yesterday.

title: Hamilton Stock
description: The Hamilton Brothers Petroleum Corporation said it might from time to time buy shares of its stock on the open market. A company spokesman said that such purchases would be made over an indefinite period with no plan to purchase a specific amount of stock. He said the purchases would be used to complement the company's treasury stock holdings.

title: Pitcher's Lib Movement?
description: It's time for a Pitcher's Lib movement. In yesterday's only national election, Jim Rice outpolled Ron Guidry for the American League's most valuable player award in the voting by,28 members of the Baseball Writers Association panel., Discrimination surfaced against Ron Guidry apparently for one reason  he's a pitcher. Jim Rice swings his big bat virtually every day, Ron Guidry fires his fast ball every fifth day. Jim Rice received 20 firstplace votes, Ron Guidry received the other eight. Jim Rice had a tremendous season.

title: Democrats Lead 31 Judicial Races
description: With early returns in, Democratic candidates, as expected, were leading in races for 17 Supreme Court seats and 14 Civil Court openings in New York City.

title: Public Hearing to Be Held Today On Homosexual Rights Measure
description: The homosexual rights bill, narrowly defeated in the City Council four years ago, is scheduled to be opened to new public debate today amid uncertainty over whether this time its chances for passage are any better.

title: HARRY BERTOIA, 63; SCULPTOR, DESIGNER
description: Harry Bertoia, a sculptor who also achieved a reputation as a designer of furniture and jewelry, died Monday at his home in Barto, Pa. He was 63 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: The rescue of 12 United States Navy airmen by a Soviet fishing trawler in the northern Pacific Oct. 26 has inspired Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the popular and often controversial Russian writer, to dash off a poem. Published yesterday in Pravda, the Soviet Communist Party newspaper, the 80line poem was prefaced with the comment of one of the rescued fliers, Lieut. Edward N. Caylor, who was quoted as saying, We met among the Soviet people displays of attention, sympathy, a desire to live in peace with American citizens.

title: Theater: 'sparrow, A Musical Biography
description: IN presenting Spartow in Flight, a musical biography of Ethel Waters, the AMAS Repertory Theater has come up with the barest sketch of an idea. It is not a bad idea; it has promise, in fact, but very little is done with it.

title: 2 Sikhs Quit India's Government After Police Fire on Protesters
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 7 (Reuters)  Two Sikh ministers resigned from the Government today to protest police gunfire againit Sikh demonstrators here two days ago.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, NOV. 7, 1978

title: Injured Are United in a Fellowship of Pain and Sympathy
description: At St. Vincent's Hospital in Greenwich Village, where 18 of the victims in the crash of a Staten Island ferry were treated, they helped and comforted one another and cheered up when Mayor Koch strode into the emergency room to commiserate with them.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Griffin Is Defeated in Michigan; Milliken ReElected as Governor
description: DETROIT, Nov. 7  Carl M. Levin, liberal Democrat, combined strong voter appeal in Detroit and its suburbs to unseat twoterm Senator Robert P. Griffin in Michigan's election today.

title: The Troubled Nation of Iran at a Glance
description: Vital Statistics  Iran is the world's second largest exporter of oil outside the Communist bloc and is a vital link in the coalition of Western allies in the Middle East that includes Saudi Ara- bia, the conservative Arab regimes of the Gulf, and Egypt. The 636,000squaremile nation, historically called Persia, is bounded on the north by the Caspian Sea and the Soviet Union, on the east by Afghanistan and Pakistan, on the south by the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman, and on the west by Iraq and Turkey. The country is a mixture of interior desert plains and highlands ranging in altitude from 3,000 to 5,000 feet. Mountains cover nearly 50 percent of the land, and only 30 percent of the country is inhabited and farmed. Precipitation and temperature vary widely from the western mountains and the Caspian coast, where some 50 inches of rain fall every year, to the central desert, where the annual average is less than 2 inches. The major cities are Teheran, the capital, with population of 5 million, Isfahan with 900,000, Meshed with 600,000 and Tabriz with 550,000.

title: High South African Official Quits In a Scandal Over Secret Activities
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 7 South Africa's secondranking Government minister, Cornelius P. Mulder, resigned tonight amid a growing scandal over the secret activities of the Information Ministry, which reportedly included an abortive $11.3 million attempt to buy control of The Washington Star.

title: Another Success in the Carey Success Story
description: For Gov. Hugh L. Carey, an aloof, strongwilled man who stood 30 points down in the polls in June, last night's results were a moment of sweet vindication.

title: Lag at Sears Raising Questions on Tactics
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company. America's largest retailer, is experiencing a prolonged sales decline in the face of competitors gains, raising questions about its current and future marketing strategy.

title: A Bloomieapolis Dreamer Goes Through The Cooking Glass
description: The following morning I had the vague feeling that I had lived out someone else's fantasy. Nothing in my Best & Company Lilliputian Bazaar childhood had prepared me for the delights, and .depravities, of Bloomingdale'sAfterHours.

title: Aleichem's `Inheritors
description: The Inheritors, Sholem Aleichem's comedy about impatient heirs awaiting the death of a rich relative and a favorite in the Yiddish theater, will open the Folksbiene Theater company's 64th season.

title: Hussein Meets Leaders in Bonn; Germans Stress His Peace Role
description: BONN, Nov. 7 (AP) King Hussein of Jordan, who came here from an Arab summit conference in Baghdad, met today with top West German leaders. The Germans expressed hope that the King would join in IsraeliEgyptian peace efforts.

title: I.C.C. Seeks to Spur Competition in Trucking
description: WASPIINGTON, Nov. 7  The Interstate Commerce Commission, Just step ahead of Carter Administration planners and congressional committees, pmposed today to lift many of the regulations it imposes on the trucking industry.

title: Brezhnev Memoir Gives Khrushchev a Bit of Credit
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 7  Leonid I. Brezhnev has done something that Soviet leaders since Stalin have almost never done in public. He has referred to his predecessor by name, as a real person, and not even as a complete scoundrel.

title: Old Excitement Missing as Race Is an Easy One
description: On West 84th Street, usually overflowing with Democrats who call themselves reformers pressing palm cards on potential voters, a Carey-for-Governor sandwich board was propped up next to a noparking sign.

title: EGYPT SAID TO URGE ARMS CURBS IN PACT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  Egypt has proposed to Israel that both countries renounce nuclear weapons and also accept limits on conventional arms as part of their projected peace treaty, participants in the neeotiaiions here said today.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NEW GARB Judging by the reputation of the St. Bart's Players for festively trim revivals of hit musicals, The Pajama Game should be in capable hands this weekend and the next. A Broadway reprise of the tuneful frolic of love and labor unions, with some new touches, didn't fare, too well a while back, although the original 1956 show ran for 1,053 performances at the St. James Theater.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Easily Wins Seat in India's Parliament
description: CHIICMAGALUR, India, Nov. 7  Former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi easily won a seat in Parliament as results of byelection were announced tonight in this lush green coffeegrowing region 1.000 miles south of New Delhi.

title: Rizzo Concedes Defeat on Plan to Seek a Third Term
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7  With none of the bombast that has come to be his signature, Mayor Frank L. Rizzo conceded defeat here tonight in his attempt to change the city charter to allow him to seek a third term.

title: Tunney, Boxing Champion Who Beat Dempsey, Dies
description: Gene Tunney, the former heavyweight boxing champion who twice defeated Jack Dempsey, died yesterday at the Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut. He was 80 years old and had been suffering from a circulation ailment.

title: Glitch
description: What computer experts call a glitch snuffed out the tabulations of voting totals last night just as heavy returns from the New York election began pouring in.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Dealing With Moscow
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  There are two things we dislike about the Soviet Union. One is its regime. We are repelled by the horrors of the Stalinist oast and by such present disgraces as the trials of dissidents. We can express our disapproval by symbolic gestures, but we have no ability to affect the regime directly. And sympathy for a regime can never be a condition to entering into diplomatic negotiations. It precisely because the Russians and we have dangerously conflicting interests that we Must try to develop them peacefully.

title: Reed Testing Knicks Again
description: Willis Reed may be making problems for himself. Last summer he demanded the Knicks get him a big center. Now he is demanding a vote of confidence. Both demands have caught Dayid A. (Sonny) Werblin, president of. Madison Square Garden Corporation, and Mike Burke, president of the Knicks, by surprise. It could hurt Reed's young coaching career.

title: Eight Oklahomans Die in Crash Of Small Plane in Mississippi
description: JACKSON. Miss., Nov. 7 (AP)  Eight Oklahomans died when the twinengine plane in which they were flying crashed in a wooded area short of the Jackson airnon. the authorities said today.

title: Perkins Courting Amex For Merger
description: Walter Perkins, president of the New York Cocoa Exchange, the smallest of the commodity exchanges in the city, is going courting for a merger again. The new suitor is the American Stock Exchange, or more accurately, the new Arnex Commodity Exchange, which, for the present, trades only in Government National Mortgage Association certificates, betterknown as Ginnie Maes.

title: Economies Reported In City Pay Changes For Terminal Leaves
description: In the months since changes in the city's policy on terminal leave for city employees were instituted last July 1, audits of claims by retiring city hospital executives show that the changes have resulted in a saving to the city of more than $93.000.

title: Times Has Deficit in 3d Quarter
description: The New York Times Company re: ported yesterday a thirdquarter net loss of $2.2 million because of the pressmen's strike that shut down operations of The New York Times newspaper for 88 days. The loss for the quarter ended Sept. 30 contrasted with net income of $5.8 million for the comparable period last year.

title: 5 Children Die in Mobile Home When Report on Fire Is Delayed
description: FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., Nov. 7 (AP)  Detectives today were investigating fire in a mobile home last night in which five children were smothered by smoke and died in their beds.

title: Governor Carey Still
description: We are pleased by the reelection of Hugh Carey as Governor of New York. The celebrations of last night notwithstanding, he well knows that the days of wine and roses are not much nearer now than at his first inaugural nearly four years ago. A Democrat astride New Deal coalition who understands the constraints on our budget and is prepared to contract it humanely the ideal governor for this time. His job, bluntly, is persuade New Yorkers to make do with still fewer state services in a period of general economic difficulty. That is the real meaning of all the promises to cut taxes further and of Mr. Carers pledge to make economic development his first priority.

title: Rockland Democrat Is Reelected
description: POMONA, N.Y., Nov. 7State Senator Linda Winikow, a DemocratLiberal, won reelection tonight over her RepublicanConservative challenger in her bid for third term representing the 38th Senatorial District, covering most of Rockland County and the town of Greenburgh in Westchester County.

title: Forster Has Surgery
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Nov. 7 (AP) Terry Forster, Los Angeles Dodger reliever, underwent successful surgery on his left elbow today at Centinela Valley Hospital. A bone chip was removed and a nerve relocated. The 26yearold pitcher was expected to be hospitalized for three days.

title: Deaths
description: C.,ENTLErIc. Pigeon Hill Cove, Bradford, Rhode Island end Sarasota, Florida. Loving father of Eileen Blum. Adored Sp4iete1her of Leslie and Evan. Devoted brother of Mario and Virgil.
