Contributions to yoOr favorite charity in lieu of flow. era.

title: 12th Body Found at Site of Fire
description: HONESDALE, Pa., Nov. 7 (AP)  In vestigators found the body of a 12th victim today at the scene of the Allen Motor Inn fire, the county coroner said. The victim was not immediately identified. The authorities feared that the death toll in the Sunday morning fire, which is believed to have been caused by arson, could rise to 15 persons.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of production errors, quotations for Monday's trading in stock options were incorrect yesterday in Business Day. Correct quotations for Monday's trading can be obtained by calling (212) 5561717 or 5567394.

title: Zambians, Outraged By Rhodesian Raids, Attack Whites in City
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Nov. 7 (Reuters) Hundreds of angry Zambian blacks, angered by recent Rhodesian air strikes deep into their country, attacked whites on the streets of Lusaka today in the worst outburst of racial violence here in at least 14 years. Diplomatic sources said there had been four to eight instances of whites being attacked or harassed.

title: U.S. Private Plane Lost in Egypt
description: CAIRO, Nov. 7 (AP)  Airplanes, helicopters and jeeps searched the desert today for a missing American oil company plane with 17 persons aboard, including an American identified as John Beck of Bariod International Co., an American oil service firm. Radio contact with the plane was lost Sunday morning about 15 minutes after the aircraft took off from Alexandria for a desert oilfield about AO miles inland.

title: Mets
description: Stockholders of the New York Mets will meet today amid indications that M. Donald Grant may either be forced out as chief operating officer or forced to reduce his role in running the baseball team.

title: $5-a- Year Levy Brings Tax Revolt in Carolina
description: STARR, S.C., Nov. 7 (AP)  Mayor Lewis Thompson says this town of 200 people could become a 1.5 milelong dark spot along the highway unless local residents decide to pay a new annual tax of $5 a person.

title: Autopsy Cites Natural Causes In Death of Richmond Millionaire
description: RICHMOND, Nov 7, (Reuter)  The death of a wealthy 84yearold Richmond woman in a Missouri commune last August was a result of natural causes, according to an autopsy report.

title: A Gala Tribute to Dance Photography
description: On the walls, frozen forever in time, some of the great dancers of the past were arrested midnight: Isadora Duncan on the steps of the Parthenon, Daniloya and Anna Pavlova, the Margot Fonteyn and Martha Graham of 40 years ago.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Instead of getting the ax yesterday, Edward J. Hanley got a sword. Mr. Hanley, 74 years old and former chairman and president of Allegheny Ludlum Industries, retired from the board of directors of the corporation and was presented with a specially made classic Wilkinson sword. Wilkinson is 44.4 percent owned by Allegheny Ludlum. Mr. Hanley was named president and chief executive officer in 1951 and was chairman from 1962 to 1972, when he became chairman of the finance committee.

title: Ontario Train Crash Spills Acid
description: THUNDER BAY, Ontario, Nov. 7 (AP)  About 40,000 gallons of sulphuric acid spilled into a ditch near a residential area last night when four cars of a 36car tanker train ruptured in a collision with freight train. The police said there were no injuries. A dike was built to contain the acid.

title: ABC Tops Ratings
description: With the Robert RedfordPaul Newman movie The Sting as its principal attraction, ABCTV last week scored large audiencepopularity ratings victory over the competing networks, something it has been doing fairly consistently in the eight weeks since the television season began.

title: Rice Is MVP., Guidry 2d
description: A long winter of baseball controversy was guaranteed yesterday when the slugger, Jim Rice of Boston, was named the American League's most valuable player over the pitcher, Ron Guidry of the Yankees.

title: Study Links Eggs to Increase In CholesterolCarrying Protein
description: People who cat a lot of eggs, the most concentrated form of cholesterol in the American diet, develop large amounts of potentially harmful blood protein that delivers cholesterol to cells, a new study has shown.

title: Associated Press
description: Former House Speaker John W. McCormack, left, with the present Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., in Boston yesterday. Both endorsed Democratic Representative Paul E. Tsongas, who ran against Senator Edward W. Brooke.

title: Carter Signs a Record 4Year, $51 Billion Bill for Roads and Transit
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  President Carter last night signed the record-breaking $51 billion, fouryear highway and mass transit bill, the White House announced today.

title: Green Beats Burden in HardFought Race on East Side
description: Republican Representative S. William Green defeated Carter Burden for a Congressional seat on Manhattan's East Side that the candidates, both millionaires, spent a good part of their personal fortunes trying to win.

title: Angola Announces Mobilization In Face of South Africa Threat
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 7 (Reuters) Angola has mobilized a militia force of 200,000 as well as a standing army of 31,000 to meet an avowed threat of South African aggression, the Angolan ambassador here said today

title: Speaker Steingut Loses
description: Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut yesterday lost the Brooklyn Assembly seat he has held for 26 years, and with it one of the state's most powerful political costs.

title: `Revolutionary Message
description: Your revolutionary message has been heard, Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, the selfdubbed King Kings, has now told his Iranian people. He admits past mistakes and promises that newly installed military rule will be brief  and be followed by free elections. This new effort to end the turbulence through accommodation seems genuine. The question now is, has it come in time?

title: China Protests to Vietnam Over Bloody Border Incident
description: PEKING, Nov. 7 (Reuters)  China lodged a strong protest with Vietnam today over a bloody border incident that occurred last Wednesday after having rejected a Vietnamese protest concerning the same incident.

The arrests appeared to be an important gesture toward the Shah's political opponents, who have in recent months shaken the country's nol it. ical structure and its oilbased economy.

description: Steingut's Numbers Add Up Wrong

title: TAX LIMITS PASSED IN SEVERAL STATES

title: World News Briefs
description: LA PAZ, Nov 6 (Reuters)  President Juan Pereda Asb1ln appointed a cabinet dominated by military men tonight to replace the mainly civilian team that resigned last week.

title: Most Airline Services To Teheran Resumed
description: Most international flights to Teheran resumed yesterday after airline officials decided that the safety of their planes, passengers and crews was no longer threatened by the civil unrest there that disrupted service earlier this week.

description: HAMDEN, Conn.As the first Slav to occupy the throne of Peter, John Paul II brings to the papacy a special perspective on the separated brethren of the Eastern Orthodox churches.

description: The winners were the Barber of Seville and Escamillo, the toreador, and the vote was a resounding Bravo!

title: Panatta Tops Stockton; McEnroe and Ashe Win
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov.7 (AP) Adrian Panatta and Torn Gullikson fought off match points and advanced to the second round of the $175,000 Stockholm open tennis tournament tonight. John McEnroe and Arthur Ashe also won

title: Armero is Winner In CrossCountry
description: Oscar Armero and Delores Bullivant, both of City College, swept to individual victories in the City University of New York crosscountry championships at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday, but Queens College won the men's and women's team championships.

title: Janet Flanner, Reporter in Paris For The New Yorker, Dies at 86
description: Janet Flanner, a writer and correspondent for The New Yorker magazine, died of a heart attack last night in Lenox Hill Hospital. Miss Flamer, who was 86 years old, made her home in Manhattan in recent years after having spent many years in France_

title: The Vote for Govern or
description: The following shows the county-bycounty tabulation of the vote for Governor early today.

title: OldLine Fans Bet Jockeys Are Honest
description: Trust among horseplayers at Aqueduct yesterday appeared to mellow with age.

title: Inflation Soars In Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 7  Argentina's virulent inflation drove up cotssumer prices almost 10 percent in October, the biggest monthly rise since April, according to official figures released today.

title: Around the Nation
description: DETROIT, Nov. 7  The General Motors Corporation said today it would recall all of the 320,000 Chevrolet Chevettes built during the 1976 and 1977 model years to make modifications aimed at strengthening their fuel systems.

title: For Vegetarians, Gujarati Cuisine
description: OVER the years, many people have made the unthinking and innocent protest that vegetarian dishes are cultish and boring, without reflecting for a second that vegetarian dishes are part and parcel of the routine American diet. There are, in fact, scores of vegetarian dishes in the Western repertory of cooking that will trigger salivation in any person with a healthy appetite, a socalled gourmet or otherwise. These would include fresh corn on the cob, dripping with butter; sliced fresh red, ripe tomatoes with new basil, olive oil and vinegar; buttered new beets and fresh cucumbers, Swedish style, with sugar, vinegar and chopped new dill.

title: Frances Sternhagen Joins Hellman Letter Readers
description: Frances Sternhagen is the third of a succession of letterreaders to take the stage and peruse aloud a letter written by Lillian Hellman to the House UnAmerican Activities Committee during the Communisthunt days of the early 1950's, which is included in Eric Bentley's play about the period, Are You Now or Have You Ever Been?

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: ONE of the great positive aspects of living in New York is the ability sample almost all the world's assorted cuisines  Chinese, Russian. Japanese, Greek, Italian and soon.

title: Lung Cancer Deaths in Texas Rise To Epidemic
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 7  Death from lung cancer in Texas, and particularly in the industrialized metropolitan area of Houston, has grown during the 1970's to what some health authorities are calling epidemic proportions, according to a study performed here by the University of Texas System Cancer Center.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: ONE day, when his daughter was quite young, Morris Forer paid a visit to some friends. The little girl was a poor sleeper, and Mr. Forer was in the habit of singing her as he rocked her at bedtime.

title: Private Economists Expect 79 Recession
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  Despite the Administration's assertion that growth in the national economy will be sustained next year, a consensus is emerging among private economists that the nation will slip into a recession, which means at least two consecutive calendar Quarters of falling national output.

title: Mrs. Meyner Only House Member To Lose Seat in New Jersey Voting
description: Except for the defeat of Helen S. Meyner, a Democrat in a district designed for Republicans, all Congressional incumbents appeared to have weathered their election tests in New Jersey yesterday.

title: Film: Dummy Takes Over in 'Magic':Wooden Handed
description: "MAGIC" looks like the year's most earnest effort to underestimate the intelligence of the public. The film, directed by Richard Attenborough and adapted by William Goldman from his own novel, is a no-frills, no-imagination reworking of the story about the ventriloquist who is taken over by his dummy. This is a fable you may fondly remember from the 1946 English film "Dead of Night," or from the later, very stylish "Alfred Hitchcock Presents" television show.Among other things, the word "magic" should evoke the sleight-of-hand by which one's attention is skillfully diverted from seeing what is taking place  which is precisely what "Magic" lacks. Unless you resolutely make yourself stare at the theater's exit sign, it's impossible not to see the wheels moving around inside this small, cumbersome movie.It's the sort of entertainment in which the most bizarre spectacle is the casting of that fine English actor, Anthony Hopkins, as a failed Catskill magician who suddenly hits the big time when he adds ventriloquism to his act. Equally fanciful is the casting of the irrepressible Ann-Margret  a personality for whom Las Vegas would have had to be invented had it not already existed  as the frumpy, off-season proprietor of a run-down Catskill camp, a woman whose love for the ventriloquist precipitates the movie's not-so-dread climax.The only actor in the cast who seems comfortable is Burgess Meredith, who plays a high-powered agent. He is unfortunately murdered early on when the ventriloquist suspects that the agent suspects that the ventriloquist has an unhealthy dependency on his foul-mouthed dummy. Would such suspicions be grounds for anything more than harsh words or, perhaps, advice? Not in any other movie, but "Magic" is even more desperate than its characters.Mr. Hopkins is top good an actor to be completely lost in this nonsense, but the best he can do is convince us of his intentions, to represent a timid soul in need of his dummy's identity. We believe none of it for a minute, partly because Mr. Goldman's screenplay spends too much time on irrelevant details, including flashbacks and jumps forward that neither inform nor amuse but simply look trendy in the dated fashion of that word.Mr. Attenborough ("A Bridge Too Far," "Oh, What a Lovely War") once made an effectively eerie film called "Seance on a Wet Afternoon." "Magic" is neither eerie nor effective. It is, however, very heavy of hand.

title: Leader of Malaysian Opposition Is Found Guilty in Secrets Case
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Nov. (Reuters)  The High Court today found Kim Lit Siang, the leader of the parliamentary opposition, guilty on five charges under the Official Secrets Act.

title: Private Lives
description: ASTRANGER called last week from Washington to say that John McHale had died. He assumed that I had known McHale better than I had. I embarrassed myself by pretending that he was right. He suggested that if wanted to write something about McHale, I might ask puckminster Fuller, with whom McHale had been associated, for a comment. I was told that Fuller was in New York.

title: BROOKE LOSES RACE FOR 3D SENATE TERM
description: BOSTON, Nov. 7  Edward W. Brooke, the nation's only black Senator, was defeated tonight for reelection to a third term after months of damaging disclosures about his personal life and family finances.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Household Is Weighing Raising American Offer

title: Blasts Hit San Salvador Banks
description: SAN SALVADOR, Nov. 7 (AP) Three explosions, believed to have been caused by bombs, damaged two banks here today but caused no injuries, officials said. No group took responsibility for the bombings.

title: Personal Health
description: THIS year more than one million American couples will find freedom from pills, IUD's, diaphragms, condoms, foam and the fear of unwanted pregnancies by either husband or wife having a simple operation that prevents them from hav-

title: `We'll Be Back,
description: Pledging, We'll be back, PerryDelmont Duryea conceded defeat at midnight, along with two of his three Republican running mates, in the campaign to unseat Governor Carey and c_anture other to state nosts.

title: Q&A
description: Q.In Spain recently, we dined on the most delicious bean stew with morcilia, a kind of sausage. Do you know what it is?

title: New Hopes Of Oil Find Off Jersey
description: Another drilling crew off the New Jersey coast is about to start advanced tests at a completed well, raising fresh hopes of a commercial oil or gas discovery in that closely monitored area.

title: DATA ON RACE ROLE IN I.Q. CALLED FALSE
description: Proponents of the idea that hereditary differences make whites intellectually superior to blacks have lost one of their maior bodies of evidence.

title: Majority of the Electorate Is Silent on the Sidelines
description: WAYNE, N.J., Nov. 7 Back in the 1960's, Al Lender marched in peace demonstrations and shouted slogans about changing the world. Today, he changes oil in car engines for a living and doesn't shout about anything, except perhaps football. And he does not vote.

title: Worst Ferry Disaster In City Was in 1871
description: New York Harbor has seen numerous ferry accidents over the years, but with relatively little loss of life.

title: Police Recount Theft by Wire Of $10 Million
description: LOS ANGELES. Nov. 7  The bizarre crime had an Ian Fleming plot. It was almost a master crime, the police say, and failed only because Stanley Mark Rifkin was not a master criminal.

title: A Simple No to UNESCO
description: In the name of press freedom, which few of them actually practice, a majority of the world's governments are trying once again to prescribe a code of conduct for all newspapers, press agencies and broadcasters. This foolish effort to codify the irreconcilable values of different political systems almost destroyed the United Nations Educationar, Scientific and Cultural Organization two years ago. A more delicately worded declaration this year will not avert that risk. There are many things on which democracies should compromise their interests to promote cooperation and understanding, but the definition of their most precious rights is not one of them.

title: Market Place
description: Robert Metz

title: U.S. Neutral on West Europe's Arms Sales to Peking
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  The United States has informed London that it has no objections to Britain's selling diesel engines to China for use in naval vessels, in what could be the first in a series of West European arms deals with Peking.

title: A Pattern of Stability
description: For all the preelection talk about the mood of revolt among the voters, the first results indicated that there was far less rebellion across the nation than had beer anticipated and that incumbents, ever those with liberal records, were faring

title: BILL CUTTING TAXES IS SIGNED BY CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  President Carter quietly signed the $18.7 billion taxcut bill, a $5 billion measure to expand Government programs for the handicapped and several other pieces of costly and controversial legislation over his long weekend at Camp David, White House officials said today.

title: 4 Children Die After Gas Leaks
description: RUSH SPRINGS, Okla., Nov. 7 (UPI)  A man concerned about his daughter's failure to answer the telephone early today found his four grandchildren dead and their parents unconscious, apparently all victims of a gas leak. James R. Pate, 23 years old, and his wife, Carrie, 20, were listed in stable condition at a hospital in nearby Chickasha. The police said that gas company officials were investigating the cause of the gas leak.

title: G.M. Betting on Diesel Engine
description: DETROIT, Nov. 8  After years of research and testing, the engineers at General Motors think they have a winner: a new massproduction auto engine, which would be the first one since the conventional gasoline power plant that dates to the days of the Model T.

title: Schenectady Shifts Government
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 8 (AP) Voters in this upstate city have approved a measure to create a strong mayor form of government, replacing the present citymanager concept. With 77 percent of the vote in, the proposition to create a strong mayor form of government was leading 7,315 to 6,673 votes. The approval, considered a victory for Mayor Frank Dud, would make the change effective following the mayoral election next November.

title: Rutgers Professor Asserts Press Shows ProShah Bias in Reports
description: James Cockcroft, a Rutgers University professor, said yesterday that events in Iran had been distorted by the UnitedStates Government and the American press to sustain a proShah foreign policy. He called for demonstrations against American volicv in Iran.

title: Teng Tells the Thais MoscowHanoi Treaty Perils World's Peace
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 8 China's visiting senior Deputy Prime Minister, Teng Hsiaoping, today called the SovietVietnamese friendship a: threat to world security and peace.

title: Blacks and Women Faltered in Contests for Congress
description: The ranki of women and blacks in Congress were trimmed in Tueisday's elections, despite strong drives . by both groups to broaden their roles on the national political level.

title: 2 CBSTV Shows Are Off
description: CBSTV yesterday relegated two of its newseason entries to offscreen status; one of them, People, to extinction, and the other,WKRP in Cincinnati, to a limbo from which it might in some indefinite future be recalled to active service.

title: Ballet: Joffrey Presents Bridegroom
description: HE Joffrey Ballet brought in a totally new cast for the major roles in A Bridegroom Called Death, Agnes de Mile's newest ballet for the company, Tuesday night at the City Center.

title: 10-Year-Olds Tackle Football
description: TEN years ago, when the world was new and I was operating under the misperception that the child who wears a seersucker jacket will stay out of jail, I used to routinely wheel my infant son past the local football field and be shocked at what I saw.

title: Democrats Sweep 31 Court Races
description: Candidates with Democratic backing won all 31 New York City court contests in Tuesday's election, in which 17 Supreme Court seats and 19 Civil Court openings were at stake.

title: Lighthouse's Low Vision Service Holding a ThreeDay Symposium
description: The New York Lighthouse Low Vision Service will mark its 25th anniversary with a threeday symposium at the New York Hilton Hotel tomorrow through Saturday.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterdays Weather at I P.M National Oceenlc lind Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: TV: A Musical L'il Abner
description: GENERAL BULLMOOSE shows up in Dogpatch to find why KPIGTV, which  he owns, keeps losing money. The reason turns out to be that the station manager has allowed an hour of entertainment to dilute the profits of 23 hours of commercials.

title: Sharp Drop Is Expected In Housing
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) Housing construction will drop sharply in the next year because of rising interest rates, according to the Commerce Department.

title: Anonymous Call to Juror. Is Basis Of Appeal in Indian Claims Case
description: BOSTON, Nov. 8 (AP)  A previously undisclosed anonymous telephone call to a juror in the Mashpee Indian case turned up today as grounds for an appeal to the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.

title: Voters Pass Over Half Of Bonds
description: Voters around the nation displayed a generally mixed reaction to proposed state and local bond issues on Election Day, approving many large proposals but rejecting others.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: GLINTER GRASS unbuttoned is rather like an amalgam of Rabelais and Claude LeviStrauss, a marvelous, irreverent, 1pngwinded, greasyfingered, anthropological and scatological swamp monster with too many ideas and not enough pigeonholes to put them in. The triumph of his new novel is that what seems a mess  a highly impressionistic history of the sexes, of nutrition, of nationalism, of religion and art and Giinter Grass  is actually shapely.

title: Carter News Session To Be on Radio, TV
description: President Carter's news conference in Kansas City, Mo., will be broadcast live at 1 P.M. today by all three national television networks (Channels 2, 4 and 7 in New York) and by radio stations WCBSAM, WINS and WMCA.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: HAIR DYE IS LINKED TO BREAST CANCER
description: A preliminary study by researchers at New York University suggests that women who started using hair dyes 10 or more years ago face an increased risk of develoning breast cancer.

title: Some Democrats Upset In Virgin Island Contests
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V.I., Nov. (UPI)  Heavily favored Democrats were upset in governorship and Congressional races, but the latest returns today showed Democrats retaining a majority in the Virgin Islands Legislature.

title: SHIPPING/MAILS
description: OUTGOING

title: Bordentown's Workfare
description: BORDENTOWN, N.J.  Until this summer, there were always 25 to 30 ablebodied adults on welfare in this old New Jersey town of 5,000.

title: New York City Inquiry Is Opened On Why Ferry Hit Battery Seawall
description: A city inquiry began questioning witnesses behind closed doors yesterday, with a Coast Guard observer present, into why the Staten Island ferryboat American Legion slammed into a Battery Park seawall Tuesday. Police reports tallied 240 persons injured, and 13 were still hospitalized yesterday.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Regrouping Giants Prepare for Redskins
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov.  Aftcr taking an extra day off to lick their wounds from the 2010 defeat at the hands of the St. Louis Cardinals last weekend, the Giants went. back to work today with the hope that they could continue their recent domination of the Redskins next Sunday in Washington.

title: 13 States Curb Taxes or Spending; A Variety of Other Initiatives Fail
description: A record number of initiatives were on ballots across the nation in Tuesday's elections, and the voters message was clear: Go slow on taxes, spending and innovations.

title: Associated Press
description: Gov. Meldrim Thomson Jr., who ran for reelection in New Hampshire, as he watched the election returns Tuesday night in Concord with his son, Peter.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: Beaths

title: Shedding Some. Light on Skylights
description: THE nicest light comes from overhead, said an architect who had a 16-by-4-foot skylight installed recently on the roof of his Beekman Place residence.

title: Seat in Congress Lost By Marijuana Smoker
description: TROY, N.Y., Nov. 8 (AP)  A Congressman who recently disclosed that he had smoked marijuana on occasion said that the disclosure had nothing to do with his loss yesterday.

title: PANEL REJECTS BILL ON HOMOSEXUALITY
description: After a raucous public hearing, interupted by cheers as well as catcalls, a New York City Council committee late last night rejected a bill that would have outlawed discrimination against homosexuals in housing, employment and public accommodations.

title: South African Bid to Jail Mrs. Mandela Fails Again
description: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 8 The South African Government's persistent effort to gain a court conviction against Winnie Mandela, the wife of Nelson Mandela, an imprisoned black leader, failed again today when a magistrate in Bloemfontein dismissed charges that she had broken her GOvernment banning order. Conviction could have sent Mrs. Mandela, black leader in her own right. to fail.

title: The Voting in Senatorial Contests
description: The Associated Press

title: Dance: Miss Gamson
description: ANNABELLE GAMSON is best known for her recreation of dances by Isadora Duncan and the German expressionist choreograrher Mary Wigman. Her Dance Umbrella program, presented on Tuesday at the Entermedia Theater, was for the most van of her own chore- ography. Miss damson's dances are smallscaled, literate solos that draw from a strong pictorial sense and her considerable expressiveness as a performer.

title: CAIRO'S ARAB FEUDS DON'T BLIGHT TRADE
description: CAIRO, Nov. 8  Several thousand shiny sedans rolling off Egypt's assembly lines this year have been diverted from the domestic market to what would seem an unlikely Arab customer, Iraq.

title: Sound
description: Hans Fantel

title: Home Improvement Matching Bits and Drills
description: Bernard Gladstone

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: A consortium of natural gas pipeline companies has agreed to build a major new line to distribute gas now being developed in the socalled Overthrust Belt region of the Rocky Mountains to the eastern twothirds of the country. The pipeline, dubbed the Trailblazer System, is the first commitment to tap the rapidly accumulating reserves in the Overthrust Belt, which has been the scene of hectic drilling over the last two years.

title: Hayes Signs Extension To Contract With Bullets
description: LANDOVER, Md., Nov. 8 (AP) Elvin Hayes has signed a threeyear, $1.3 million extension to his current contract with the Washington Bullets.

title: World News Briefs
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov 8  President Idi Amin declared today that Uganda would withdraw its troops from northern Tanzania as soon as assurances were given that Tanzania will never invade Uganda again and that it would stop arming Uganda exiles.

title: Zambian Capital Is Calm After Racial Violence
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Nov. 9 (UPI)  Police forces and militiamen patrolled downtown Lusaka today to prevent new attacks on whites by black mobs angered by reports of Rhodesian spies in the capital.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: LONDON, Nov. 8  A bout of heavy selling by exporters in Europe and Japan depressed the dollar on most foreign markets today, despite support operations from central banks in the United States and abroad.

title: Associated Press
description: In Bloomington, Minn., Republicans exulted after hearing early ballot figures Tuesday night. From left: Rudy Bosch. wilt, candidate for Senate; Albert Qule, who sought the governorship, and David Durenberger, Senate hopeful.

title: Argentina Accepts Mediation for Southern Islands
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 8 Argentine leaders have accepted a Chilean proposal that the help of a mediator be sought to reach a peaceful settlement of a dispute over three small islands in which both countries have mobilized combat forces.

title: Victorious Mrs. Grasso Is Now Challenged by a Budget
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 8  Gov. Ella T. Grasso, reelected yesterday in a strong Democratic sweep, faces at least two pressing financial problems: how to reconcile a potentially large state budget gap next year with her campaign promises of no tax increases and how to come up with a new way of financing public education.

title: Orr Bids Adieu to Hockey
description: Bobby Orr, the defenseman who changed the face of hockey and whose rushing style is imitated by youngsters wherever the game is played, aborted another comeback attempt yesterday and retired at the age of 30.

title: Glamour Stocks Lead Late Rise
description: A finalhour rally led by glamour Issues yesterday shored up a lagging stock market that had gone into shock after General Motors surprise dividend cut earlier this week.

title: Specialty Tools: Where to Look for Them
description: IT was 2 o'clock in the morning and 1 absolutely had to have a tack hammer. I'd been by the local hardware store earlier  at an hour normal commerce found acceptable  and been told that not only did they not have a tack hammer in stock. but also that they didn't expect to have any. Tack hammers, it seems, have been categorized as specialty tools. Customers are now expected to drive everything from licinch carpet tacks to 8d nails with the same one-poundbeaded hammer.

title: Alleged Espionage by ExU.S. Agent Cited at Trial
description: HAMMOND, Ind., Nov. 8 (AP)  A former Central Intelligence Agency employee charged with espionage was told by a Soviet agent in Greece to furnish information on missile sites and C.I.A. agents abroad, a Government witness testified today.

title: Carey Says He Will Seek Tax Cuts For Businesses and for the Elderly
description: An ebullient Governor Carey said yesterday that he would seek additional tax cuts for corporations and for the elderly, and he promised to change my personality and be more accessible to the public and the press in the next four years.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Companies

title: 3 G.O.P. Winners in Minnesota Are Congratulated by Mondale
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP)  Vice President Mondale, who concentrated his campaign efforts in his home state of Minnesota, offered his congratulations today to the three Republicans who defeated the Democrats he supported.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Look who's here, said David Mahoney, chairman of Norton Simon Inc., at the company's annual meeting yesterday at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. It was Hugh L. Carey, looking fresh and relaxed only a few hours after winning reelection as Governor of New York.

title: Political Jokes Make a Comeback in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 6  The comic is dressed as a cook and tells television viewers of a recipe for a democracy cake that he says is tasty but not swallowed by many.

title: Las Vegas SheriffIs Out On Surprising 21 Vote
description: LAS VEGAS, Nov. 8 (Reuters)  The Sheriff of Las Vegas, the most powerful politician in this desert gambling resort for the last 17 years, has been swept from office in a surprise vote.

description: Abigail McCarthy

title: Many Turns of Fortune Led to the State Comptrollership
description: The delegates at the Republican State Committee meeting back in 1970 were grbwing somewhat impatient. They were crammed in the stuffy ballroom of an upstate hotel waiting to meet the candidate for State Comptrol-

title: How Surveys Were Conducted
description: The New York Times and CBS News conducted three joint polls on the Congressional elections. One was a survey of incumbent members of the House of Representatives and other major party candidates for election to the House; the others were surveys of voters as they left the polling places in samplings of precincts throughout the country and in New York State. Also involved in the New York State poll was WCBSTV (channel 2).

title: New Warden at Bronx Men's Tail a Woman
description: After only a few hours on the job yesterday, the new warden of the Bronx Men's House of Detention had been blown a kiss by one inmate and been called beautiful by another.

title: 5 Accused of Wrongdoing Reelected to Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP)  Voters have ousted Senator Edward W. Brooke and at least two House members charged with misconduct but reelected five other Congressmen who have been accused of wrongdoing.

title: Tsongas Played Underdog Role To Oust Brooke in Senate Race
description: Senatorelect Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts has never started a political race as a favorite. But he has always won.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FRINGE BENEFITS Three lesserknown plays by two foreign masters, W. Somerset Maugham and George Bernard Shaw, have quietly appeared on the Off Off Broadway boards.

title: G.O.P. Victories in Texas Reflect Shift of Party Lines in Southwest
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 8  When Bill Clem.: ents became the first Republican since Reconstruction to be elected Governor of Texas, it was not only a smashing, largely unexpected victory for his party. ,It was also an indication of the new and sometimes contradictory political currents that appear to be running in the booming western half of the Sunbelt.

title: Stars End Rangers
description: There's an old baseball saying that goes: I'd rather be lucky than good. Now you can apply it to hockey. The Rangers are good, as their sevengame winning streak and No. 1 National Hockey League defensive record attest. And last night at Madison Square Garden, the Rangers looked better than the Minnesota North Stars, their opponents.

title: Song: A Salute to Porter
description: COLE PORTER's songs have provided the meat and potatoes for so many supper club, performances over the last 40 years that the prospect of another Salute to Cole Porter might not seem a cause for interested anticipation. But Portia Nelson and Steve Ross do not see it that way at all.

title: Putting the City Garden to Bed for the Winter
description: THE squirrels this fall have been ferreting out every nutlike thing they can lay their jaws on, even going as far as stripping the Chinese chestnuts from the trees before they have a chance to ripen. Their behavior bespeaks a harsh winter coming. Then again, the geese are lying over on the pond for two or three days at a time, appearing to be in no rush to go southward, indicating we should hardly be touched by the kind of weather the Northeast faced last winter.

title: Sohio Plan Is a Winner
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8  When the vote count was completed this morning, the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) had won a major victory in its effort to build an oil terminal at Long Beach to supply Alaskan oil to the Middle West.

title: Connecticut Official Decisively Defeated After Ethics Debate
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 8  State Senator William E. Strada Jr., considered an invincible votegetter after six election victories, was decisively beaten yesterday, a victim of disclosures in the final weeks of the campaign that his law firm represented gambling interests when he introduced legislation in 1972 legalizing gambling in the state.

title: 2 Children Among 6 Killed in a Fire in South Bronx
description: Six persons, including two children, died early yesterday and seven others were injured as flames engulfed a twofamily house in the South Bronx.

title: Gene Tunney, Who Beat Dempsey Twice for Ring Title, Is Dead at 80
description: Gene Tunney, the former heavyweight boxing champion who twice defeated Jack Dempsey, died late Tuesday at the Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut. He was 80 years old and had been suffering from a circulation ailment.

title: ABROAD AT HOME Something Happened
description: BOSTON, Nov. 8  As the returns came in, the radio and television commentators kept telling us that this election had little significance. It left things pretty much unchanged, said one. Another called it a nothing election.

title: 76ers Fend Off Nets In Double Overtime
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 The New Jersey Nets, without Coach Kevin Loughery, Bernard King and Bob Elliot, lost through ejection and injury along the way, took the Philadelphia 76ers into double overtime tonight in the Spectrum only to lose, 137131 It was a wild cliffhanging game that saw 11 technical fouls called in regulation timeall but two against the Nets.

title: U.S. Still Giving Pentecostalists Soviet Asylum
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 8  Seven Pentecostals who have been staying in the United States Embassy since June said today that they would remain, despite American objections, until the Soviet Government lets them emigrate.

title: The Tax Bill: A Special Report
description: The $19 billion taxcut program quietly signed by President Carter on Monday night is part of a fundamental shift in priorities from redistributing income to stimulating investment, in the view of many analysts. Despite the size of the cut, most people will find little difference in their takehome pay when the provisions take effect in January. These and other aspects of the law, including such questions as when a country club is not a country club for people on expense accounts, are discussed in a special Business Day report beginning on page D1.

title: Terrorists Kill Italian Prosecutor and 2 in His Escort
description: ROME, Nov. 8  A provincial prosecutor, his driver and his bodyguard were machinegunned to death on a country road south of here today by political terrorists, who also wounded one of their accomplices and later killed him.

title: Results of Balloting On Long Island
description: Congress

title: Knicks Victors Over the Sonics
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 8 (AP) Bob McAdoo scored 31 points and helped break open a tight game in the last 31/2 minutes to lead the New York Knicks to a 104100 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

title: Israel Again Rebuffs Link Between Egyptian Pact and Wider Peace
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  Israel's chief peace negotiators told Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance today that their Government had again rejected compromise language aimed at resolving a crucial political issue delaying an EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty.

title: Jersey Democrats Contend Bradley Will Mean Big Plus
description: TRENTON, Nov. 8  Bill Bradley's election yesterday will give New Jersey two Democrats in the United States Sen- ate for the first time in 40 years, and top state Democrats said today that it would be a big plus for the state.

title: Blow by Blow in Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 8 Richie Giachetti, manager of the man who probably will be the undisputed heavyweight champion of the world soon, was watching the suckers in the lobby of Caesars Palace Hotel this morning.

title: Durable Goods Orders Up 28%
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI)New orders for durable goods for export sales were up 28 percent for September, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Millions in U.S. Loans Squandered In Minority Program, Inquiry Finds
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  Millions of dollars in funds advanced by the Small Business Administration to businesses owned by members of minority groups in New York and other cities have been squandered, siphoned oft and lost through the agency's mismanagement in the last three years, according to a secret investigation just completed by the agency.

title: McCowen to Give Show At White House Nov.22
description: Alec McCowen, whose oneman performance of St. Mark's Gospel is a current Broadway hit, will do his show at the White House on Wednesday evening, Nov. 22, at the invitation of President and Mrs. Carter.

title: Highlights of the Tax Law Signed by President Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  The following is a summary of major provisions of Revenue Act of 1978, an $18.7 billion taxcut bill that President Carter signed Monday night. Changes take effect Jan. 1, 1979, unless otherwise noted.

title: Q&A
description: QI have a backyard fence made of  1-by-12 pine boards nailed horizontally to .4-by-I wood posts. In the past this has been painted with both oilbase enamel and latex paints, in white. The white paint is continually stained by fallen leaves from an oak tree. Is there any exterior paint that will resist this kind of staining and discoloration, and that will require only removal of old loose paint plus a light sanding or cleaning?Mrs. R.D., Cranford, N.J.

title: Yanks
description: Andy Messersmith's brief tenure with the Yankees has ended, Sparky Lyle's colorful career with them hasn't ended yet and Tommy. John's and/or Larry Gura's rich career with them could be in the process of beginning.

title: Strike May Halt TV Ads
description: Two major'actors unions are making preparations for a strike that would halt the prediction of television commercials.

title: Miss Stove Upset, 62, 62
description: OLDSMAR, Fla., Nov. 8 (AP) Renee Blount matched Betty Stove's power game stroke for stroke today to upset the fifthseeded Dutch star in firstround play of a $75,000 tennis tournament. Miss Blount, from St. Louis, triumphed by 62, 62 as Miss Stove became the first seeded player to fall. In another firstround match, Jeanne Evert outlasted 15-year-old Bettina Bunge, 46, 63, 76.

title: Mother Sues Over Ban On Her BreastFeeding
description: A 33-year-old Long Island woman filed a $500,000 suit against the Village of Williston Park yesterday because she was not allowed to breastfeed her 3-monthold baby beside a community wading pool.

title: Topics Price Nostalgia
description: The Cost of Shoes

title: SHAH ORDERS ARREST OF FORMER PREMIER
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 8  Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi today ordered the arrest of the man who was his closest adviser for 13 years and called for an investigation into the holdings of the imperial family as part of continued moves to rebuild his public support.

title: Hershey Price Rises
description: The Hershey Foods Corporation said yesterday plans to increase the wholesale price of its chocolate bars and most other standard candy bars by 25 percent, effective Nov. 27. A spokesman for the company said the weight of the chocolate bar would be increased to 1.2 ounces from 1.05 ounces concurrent with the increase in the wholesale prices.

title: U.S. Bills Yield 9.31%
description: The Treasury auctioned oneyear billsyesterday at an average discount rate o19:31 percent  a rate that is the equivalent of a yield of 10.17 percent on couponbearing securities. The discount rate is the highest for oneyear bills since August 1974, when they sold at a record 9.56 percent.

title: The 2 Men Who Waged a War on Stanley Steingut
description: It began earlier this year, Andrew Stein said yesterday, when he realized that, despite close associations with those involved in the nursinghome scandal, Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut was not going to be indicted, so subjectively and politically I made up my mind to destroy him.

title: Club Dues Deduction Lost in the Rush
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  Question: When is a country club not a country club? Answer: When it is Congressional misstatement uttered during a HouseSenate taxwriting conference that sits until 4 A.M. of the Sunday on which Congress adjourned for the year.

title: Upsets and Split Verdicts Mark Voting in Middle Atlantic States
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 8  Upsets, suspensefilled indecision and split verdicts on politicians charged with corruption marked the pattern of voting yesterday in the Middle Atlantic states.

title: Design Notebook
description: Paul Goldberger

title: Regan Pledges To Follow Style Used by Levitt
description: Edward Regan surprised some politicians yesterday by becoming New York's only statewide Republican winner and attributed his election as State Comptroller to an urbanoriented image of his own and the help of the Democratic incumbent, Arthur Levitt.

title: Reimbursement Bill Vetoed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP)  President Carter today pocket vetoed a bill that would have provided Government reimbursement to businesses that had lost money because of a ban on the use of the chemical Tris in children's sleepwear. He said that the bill would establish an unprecedented and unwise use of taxpayers funds to indemnify private companies for losses incurred as a result of compliance with a Federal standard.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: NEW &
description: ArchitectDesigned Cookie Cutters

title: Inside Woody Allen's Interiors
description: T was the Wednesday before the Monday that shooting was to begin in the Southampton house selected as one of the major locations for Woody Allen's new film Interiors. The turn-of-the-century, 30- room house, said to have been designed by Stanford White, and now owned by Vincent and Ann Caristo, had been transformed internally by the film crew from its former traditional rollarm sofa, wall-to-wall carpeted self into something almost neoclassical in aspect  taupecolored walls, bare floors and rare, stark furnishings. Just as the finishing touches were being applied, Woody Allen arrived to inspect the metamorphosis.

title: L.I. Conservative a First in House
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Nov. 8 The first enrolled Conservative Party member ever elected to the House of Representatives, William Carney, says he hopes to bring national attention to the party, as well as to the First Congressional District at the East End of Long Island. Mr. Carney, a 36-year-old former salesman and member of the Suffolk County Legislature, overwhelmingly defeated his Democratic opponent, John Randolph, who had the endorsement of Representative Otis G. Pike, who is retiring after 18 years in Congress.

title: Dr. Howard Bitterman, 45, Gynecologist at Beth Israel
description: Dr. Howard Bitterman, attending obstetrician and gynecologist at Beth Israel Hospital and a member of the staff of Mount Sinai Hospital, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in New Rochelle. He was 45 years old.

title: Social Reforms and Arms Accord Likely to Face Snag on Capitol Hill
description: President Carter seems likely to face greater difficulty in the next Congress in winning support for social reforms and an arms agreement With the Russians, even though the numerical gains won by Republicans in Tuesday's elections were only modest.

title: Conrail Train Kills Man in Jersey
description: ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 8 (AP)  A New Yorkbound Conrail commuter train struck and killed an Essex County man here early today. The police said the man, Richard Nesbitt, had been standing on the tracks near the Highland Avenue Station. Mr. Nesbitt, 35 years old, was pronounced dead at the scene. The police said the incident was under investigation.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Precious metals futures prices re bounded on a broad front yesterday, reflecting both the pent up buy orders on hand before the Election Day holiday and the strong advance on European markets during the last two sessions.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, Nov. 8, 1978

title: 'superEurope
description: WASHINGTON  While the dollar was falling and rising, the Europeans were negotiating a new form of monetary union: the creation of a kind of deutschemark zone in Western Europe. This was no coincidence.

title: Money
description: WEDNESDAY, NOV. 8, 1978

title: Yonkers Sells Bonds and Improves Its Fiscal Status
description: YONKERS, Nov. 8  Yonkers, which like its larger neighbor to the south was near bankruptcy three years ago, successfully sold $7.2 million in bonds today and moved closer to getting the financial communities seal of fiscal rehabilitation.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: MACGREGORArthur S. MD. The family of Dr. Arthur S. MacGregor records with deep sorrow his death on September 9.1978. He was a member of the attending staff of the Luthuran Medical Center and the Long Island College Hospital.

title: Albert I. Beldoch, Long a Leader In the Knitting Industry
description: Albert I. Beldoch, a pioneer in the knitting industry, died Monday at the Long Isand Jewish Hospital, New Hyde Park. L.I., following a heart attack. He was 77 years old.

title: KennecottCurtiss Talks To End Fight Said to Fail
description: A secret effort to negotiate a peaceful settlement between the Kennecott Copper Corporation and the CurtissWright Corporation has broken down, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

title: I.T.T. Profit Down 13% In Quarter
description: Thirdquarter profits of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation toppled 13 percent as continued pressure on the dollar cut sharply into earnings, the company said yesterday.

title: Republicans Gain in Middle West As Humphrey Party Meets Defeat
description: MINNEAPOLIS; Nov. 8  The divided Democratic-Farmer-Labor party of the late Hubert H. Humphrey went down to shattering defeat in Minnesota as yesterday's elections saw Republicans make substantial gains throughout much of the Middle West.

title: CARTER ISSUES GUIDE FOR NAMING JUDGES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  President Carter today issued guidelines for Senators for selecting Federal district judges on the basis of merit rather than politics.

title: SUCCESSORS SOUGHT FOR 2 ALBANY POSTS
description: Maneuvering began yesterday in the State Assembly to fill an unusual leadership vacuum in both parties.

title: Tenneco Oil Convicted of Bribe
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov, 8 (AP)  The Tenneco Oil Company, a subsidiary of one of the nation's biggest corporations, has been found guilty of 30 counts of mail fraud in the bribing of the sheriff of a suburban community where it has a large refinery.

title: U.S. Banks Slip Down World List
description: LONDON, Nov. 8  The sharp decline of the dollar has knocked several American banks from the top echelons of world banking and has made generally harder for American bankers to compete for international business.

description: Rise in Premium Income Is Major Factor in Gain

title: Police in Belfast Receive a Tip On a German Kidnapped in 1973
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 8 (AP)  Policemen acting on a tip renewed a search for a kidnapped German industrialist missing for five years. They combed a twoacre site between Cushendall and Cushenden overlooking the Irish Sea.

description: Deaths

title: Which Private School?
description: ALARGE school or a small one? Coeducational or single sex? Open classroom or structured environment? An independent nursery school or one allied with an ongoing institution?

description: Brooklyn

title: Tax Cut May Mean Little Relief
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  In spite of an impressive $19 billion price tag on the 1979 taxcut legislation that President Carter quietly signed into law Monday evening, a great many taxpayers will discover next January that their takehome pay is only a few dollars more, if that much.

title: Calendar of Events: Tiffany's Windows and a Tour

title: ESSAY Dishing The Whigs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  Don't you see we have dished the Whigs? That was the delighted observation of England's Lord Derby a century ago, when his conservatives stole the opposition platform and rode the Whig reforms to a Tory victory.

title: Philadelphia's Message to Rizzo: Enough
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8  Frank L. Rizzo, a huge man (6feet2, 250 pounds, size 50long suit), had come into the sunlight from his next to last campaign speech. Mr. Rizzo, the Mayor of Philadelphia these last seven years, craned his 19inch neck. Above, beneath a mare's tail of cirrus, a skywriter had written: Vote Yes. Mr. Rizzo smiled.

title: Memorial Services Held For A. H. Maremont, 74
description: Memorial services were held yesterday for Arnold H. Maremont, director emeritus of the Maremont Corporation in Chicago and a wellknown art collector and civic leader. He died of a heart attack on Sunday at the Carlyle Hotel in Manhattan at the age of 74.

title: Poll Indicates Congress Candidates Were More Extreme Than Voters
description: On each major issue in the campaign, either the Democratic or Republican candidates for Congress, or both groups, appeared to have staked out positions more extreme than the rank-and-file voters of their parties in Tuesday' elections, according to two New York TimesCBS News mils.

title: Associated Press
description: DEAD AT 84: Norman Rockwell, the widely popular artist best known for his cover illustrations for The Saturday Evening Post, died late last night at his home in Stockbridge, Mass. His wife, Molly, who announced the death, said: He didn't die of anything except being 84 years old. He had been ill a long time. A full obituary will appear In The Times tomorrow.

title: A Harvest of Crafts On Madison Avenue
description: The return-to-the-earth movement of the 1960's has produced a bountiful harvest for the 70's of fine craftsmen working in clay, glass, fibers and metals. Artists who once would have struggled in Greenwich Village studios are now living on farms, supporting their simple needs with their pottery. wall hane- ings, blown glass and jewelry  which are a lot easier to sell than abstract paintings or massive sculptures. People don't have to be serious collectors to understand them  and afford them. And a crafts gallery is not nearly as intimidating as an art gallery.

Prize money for the event will be in excess of $100,000, making it the richest GT sports car race in America.

The prize, from the Association of Danish Ingenuity, was for a pocketsize device consisting of a piece of cardboard, two plastic bags and some sand. As in New York, Danes are required by law to clean up after their pets.

Ani, the older sister, is already fairly well known as a soloist, while until Tuesday night the most prominent appearances of Ida had been as part of the chamber group known as Tashi.

However, many analysts contend that it is part of a fundamental shift in national priorities  from a goal of redistributing income to a push to stimulate invest- ment. If so, they say, the new tax law could markedly improve the nation's business climate in the 1980's.

title: New Faces on the National Political Scene
description: Thirtysix years ago, a crimebusting prosecutor named Thomas. E. Dewey parlayed his reputation into .the New York governship. Pennsylvania voters followed a similar pattern yesterday when they chose Richard L. Thornburgh as their new Governor. Whether Mr. Thornburgh follows Mr. Dewey into presidential remains to be seen, but his victory immediately ranks him as one of his party's bright new lights. The new Governor won his reputation as the U.S. Attorney for Western Pennsylvania when he threw a motley lot of local politicians into jail for various offenses. Then came a tour as an Assistant Attorney General, but when he returned home and began his campaign, he found that, politicians do not live by press clippings alone. Pennsylvania's rich Republican families, from the Melions to the Heinzes, tossed in 57 varieties of campaign contributions, and his multimilliondollar war chest bought him an exceptionally wellorganized campaign operation. But the Yaletrained lawyer also showed a good political touch. At a cattle auction in Lancaster in the last few weeks he worked the crowd with easy cameraderie and would have stayed all day if his aides had not pulled him on to the next stop. Now Mr. Clean has a chance to scrub down the statehouse in Harrisburg. And national kingmakers will be watching to see if he can - make it sparkle.

The violence was called Crystal Night. because of masses of broken window glass left in the streets.

title: Rock: Dr. John's Band
description: MAC REBENNACK, who records and performs as Dr. John, is entering his third decade in rock-androll. First he was a session guitarist, pianist, and songwriter in New Orleans, then a purveyor of his own unique brand of psychedelic voodoo music. then a more conventional ner- former of more or less commercial funk. But these differences are more apparent than real. Dr. John has always been a New Orleans musician first, mixing African and Caribbean rhythms, blues, jazz, and rock into thick gumbo.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1978

title: Grant Will Step Down as Mets
description: The longrumored shakeup of the top management of the New York Mets was decreed yesterday when the team's ruling family forced M. Donald Grant to step down as chairman of the board of directors.

title: Suit Says Roots Copied From Novel
description: A suit is under way to determine if the enormously successful book Roots contains substantial material copied from a relatively unknown novel about slavery.

title: The Doctor and the Press
description: When The Times fell silent last Aug. 9, our colleague M. A. Farber had just gone to jail for refusing show his notes about a New Jersey murder case to judge at the trial of Dr. Mario Jascalevich. That most curious criminal case has since ended in a most curious fashion. The doctor, after enduring a 34week trial and many years of strain on his professional reputation, was acquitted on all counts by a jury that in the opinion of trial observers reached a proper verdict. And as the case ended on Oct. 24, so did the punishment of The New York Times and Mr. Farber, whose stories two years ago had revived interest in some mysterious deaths a decade earlier. But our criminal convictions stand. Mr. Farber spent nearly six weeks in jail and The Times paid fines totaling $285,000 for both civil and criminal contempt of court.

title: Screen: Gilroy's 'Once in Paris':All Abroad
description: THOUGH its hero, a high-powered screenwriter, travels by Concorde, Frank D. Gilroy's "Once in Parts" appears to be a tale out of the comparatively nave, propeller-driven 1950's rather than the more jaded, jet-propelled 1970's, the period when it's all supposed to take place. The movie, which opens today at the 68th Street Playhouse, is a sweet-natured, gentle comedy about a happily married, almost incredibly innocent American who, while on a script-fixing assignment in Paris (which he has never seen before), has the kind of picturesque adventure that, I suspect, was much more believable when Paris was a week (or at least a day) away from New York, instead of a mere three and one-half hours."Once in Paris" is obviously a labor of a great deal of love, which is also what the film is all about. Mr. Gilroy, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright ("The Subject Was Roses") and film writer-director ("Desperate Characters," "From Noon Till Three"), produced as well as wrote and directed "Once in Paris." In addition, he is apparently tending to the film's distribution himself. After his stylish and witty "From Noon Till Three" (one of the few Charles Bronson movies not to make a fortune) was more or less dismissed by its distributor, he wants, as he has reportedly said, to make his own mistakes."Once in Paris" is not a mistake, but it's too innocent and too without guile for its own good. Like its writer-hero, Michael Moore, played by Wayne Rogers (of the "M*A*S*H" and "City of Angels" television series), "Once in Paris" discovers movie clichs with a sense of wonderment we seldom share. Though Michael may never have been to Paris before, most of the rest of us have, if only in the movies.The first thing that happens to Michael is that he is taken in hand by a colorful native, whom such movies present as a tour guide or a taxi driver or a panhandler but always as a figure of comic wisdom. In this case the native is a pushy, know-it-all chauffeur named Jean-Paul, played by Jack Lenoir, a French actor of singularly little charm. Next, Michael meets Susan, the woman every man dreams of meeting in Paris while on temporary leave of domestic obligations. As played by Gayle Hunnicutt, Susan is smashing  an Englishwoman of beauty, intelligence and, best of all (thinks Michael), no wish for permanent attachments.In the mornings Michael and Susan take care of their career duties  she has "an interest in a department store" somewhere. In the afternoons they go sightseeing  the Eiffel Tower, Arc de Triomphe, Tuileries gardens, the flower markets, etc. There are also picnics on the grass, cozy meals at undiscovered restaurants, glimpses of the city at dawn from the Trocadero and, in between, love, love, love.Mr. Rogers has a good, substantial, amused screen personality that is of great benefit to the film, and he and Miss Hunnicutt make an appealing couple. If Mr. Lenoir is less successful, it may be that the character is essentially off-putting. Small, ragged, adolescent hustlers in bombed-out cities are, if not socially acceptable, then understandable. Middle-aged fellows playing the same game are sometimes called pimps.That may be to take "Once in Paris" more seriously than Mr. Gilroy ever intended. The film means to be a romantic lark, but this lark seldom becomes airborne.

This weekend, the festival Makes a bow to modern dance's vital, continuing traditions in its closing performances at the Entermedia Theater with appearances by the May O'Donnell Concert Dance Company in a program that spans Miss O'Donnell's 35 years as a choreographer.

title: Strong Man Caps His Record
description: STOCKHOLM (Reuters)  A Belgian man has beaten his own world record for pulling train cars with his teeth, the Swedish news agency Tete reported. John Massis pulled train coaches weighing 126.3 tons for 3.43 yards, beating his three-year-old record by more than five tons, Tete said.

title: The Pop Life
description: OTHERS may tick through the lyrics to More Songs About Buildings and Food, the new Talking Heads album, but for this listener, at least, the subject of the album is arooves. No, not the micro- scopic furrows on the surface of the disk, but the grooves in the music. For unlike most rock bands, which are able to handle only a handful of grooves the fast rocking groove, the mediumtempo shuffle, the disco sound, the heavy backbeat, and so on - Talking Heads creates a distinctive rhythmic universe with each song.

title: Agreement on Safety Inspection

Alexander Jr. and Labor Secretary Ray Marshall signed an agreement that gives Labor Department inspectors access to all areas of Governmentowned, contractoroperated ammunition plants. In the past, inspectors were permitted only in areas where there were no explosives.

title: Flora Campbell, 67, Actress on Broadway And in Soap Operas
description: Flora Campbell, an actress whose career on Broadway, radio and television spanned more than 40 years, died Monday of cancer in the Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Meany Says Voting Results Show Carter Might Lose ReElection Bid
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  George Meany, organized labor's top spokesman, Said today that President Carter was the most conservative President I have seen in my lifetime, and that Tuesday's elections results indicated that Mr. Carier might not be reelected in 1980.

title: Cartel to Cut Excess Fiber Output Held Illegal by Common Market octy
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 9  Western Europe's troubled synthetic fiber manufacturers, which have run up losses totaling more than $2 billion in the last three years, suffered a new setback today when the Common Market's executive commission ruled that the cartel they had recently set up in a bid to improve their fortunes was illegal, at least in its present form.

title: 2 14-Year-Old Boys Seized in Fire Fatal to 6 Persons in South Bronx
description: Two 14-year-old boys were arrested early today and accused of setting Wednesday morning's fire in the South/ Bronx in which two adults and four children died.

title: 89 of 104 Bankers Trust Offices Will. Be Sold to Bank of Montreal
description: The Bankers Trust Company, the na; tion's eighthlargest bank and New York City's sixthlargest, said yesterday that it planned to sell 89 of its 104 branch offices! in the metropolitan New York area to the Bank of Montreal, the thirdlargest bank, in Canada.

title: Japan Will Pay More of the Cost Of Keeping U.S. Military There
description: TOKYO, Nov. 9  Defense Secretary Harold Brown said here today that Japan planned to increase its contribution to. ward the cost of keeping United States troops in the country.

title: Court Told Ford Hid Payment
description: In a stockholder suit against the management of the Ford Motor Company, Roy M. Cohn, the plaintiffs lawyer, charged yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan that confidential Ford documents showed that Ford's general counsel sought to deflect a Justice Department investigation into whether the company paid a bribe in Indonesia in 1975.

title: Vance Reported to Warn South Africa on Namibia
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov.9Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, acting on Western intelligence reports, reportedly has warned South Africa against military buildup near the Angolan border that could damage negotiating efforts here aimed at obtaining independence for SouthWest Africa.

title: Bringing Rights Out of the Closet
description: For the fourth time in seven years, a bill to prohibit discrimination against homosexuals in employment, housing and public accommodations has been defeated in the New York City Council. The latest version was voted down Wednesday by the Council's General Welfare Committee despite a strong plea for it by Mayor Koch.

title: Law School Acts on Bakke Rule
description: NEWARK, Nov. 9  The faculty of the Rutgers University School of Law voted today to modify the minoritystudent admissions program to eliminate any possible conflict with the United States Supreme Court decision in the Bakke case.

title: Casino Operator's Profit Soars in Third Quarter
description: Resorts International, operator of the East Coast's first legal gambling casino, announced yesterday that net earnings for the third quarter soared to $23.9 million, or $2 a share, from $1.35 million, or 14 cents a share, in the corresponding period of 1977, which included an extraordinary credit of $317,000.

title: Nine Food Outlets Are Charged With Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health yesterday cited nine food places for violating the Health Code. The places were listed as follows:

title: Events/Sports
description: 111:36 A.M., WNYCAM: House Assassination Committee Hearings on Kennedy and Martin Luther King. Live.

title: Agency Plans a FullScale Inquiry Into Loans to Minority Businesses
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  Officials of the Small Business Administration met today with representatives of the Feeral Bureau of Investigation and the Justice Department to plan a fullscale investigation of fraud and mismanagement in the agency's program to aid businesses owned by members of minority groups.

title: Kristallnacht
description: The day began with a thudding through my pilldw. Jolts waked me. Then, like an alarm clock, the doorbell rang. It was six in the morning. My father, my mother, my little brother and I all met in the foyer, all in our robes. We did not know yet exactly what. But we knew. We were Jews in Vienna in 1938. Everything in our lives, including our beds, stood on a cliff.

title: New York Stores to Assist Drive By the American Cancer Society
description: More than 30 New York City stores will contribute a percentage of their sales to the American Cancer Society on Nov. 16 as part of a nationwide Quit Smoking Day sponsored by the society.

title: Price Rein: Carter vs. Hershey
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9In the first public test of the Administration's new price guideline, President Carter expressed provisional disapproval today of a price rise for Hershey chocolate products.

description: Music

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesteglav's Woathef at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: Abbott, at 91, Tries Off Broadway
description: George Abbott couldn't stop working if he wanted to. I had a project for so many years of my life, it's a habit, the 91-year-old writer and director said as he took time to talk about his latest venture: he's directing Winning Isn't Everything, which opens tonight at the Hudson Guild Theater, his first Off Broadway venture after a lifetime on the main stem.

title: Suits Accuse A.M.A. And Labor of Evading Political Donor Laws
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  Lawsuits charging labor unions and medical associations with violating legal limits on their political spending have raised questions whether millions of dollars will continue to flow into future Presidential and Congressional campaigns.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Celanese Corporation and the Olin Corporation announced yesterday that they had terminated their merger negotiations. Under an agreement in principle announced last month, Celanese would have acquired Olin for an estimated $720 million in cash and stock, thus creating the nation's fifthlargest chemical producing company.

title: Joe Louis Would Kill Clay
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 9 In the years to come, tomorrow night's World Boxing Council heavyweight title fight between Larry Holmes and Alfredo Evangelista will be just another line in The Ring record book. The memory to treasure will be the tribute to Joe Louis at Caesars Palace tonight.

title: Jazz: Mulligan Band at Storytowne
description: AST July at the Newport Jazz Festival, when Gerry Mulligan was scheduled to appear with small group, he also brought along  on a whim and at his own ex- pense  a 13piece band that was revival of the concert jazz band he led in the early 1960's. That whim has now been solidified into a purposeful project. The Mulligan big band is once again an ongoing group, and, after threeweek breakin tour of the Middle West, it is playing at Storytowne, 41 East 58th Street, tonight and tomorrow evening and next week from Wednesday through Saturday.

title: Anna Lucasta
description: It must be a measure of something that Anna Lucasta, a play that was born and burgeoned immediately into hit in Harlem 34 years ago, is going to be reborn this weekend on the Lower East Side, its newest stage in a career that has taken it to Broadway, to Hollywood and to revivals along the way.

title: Nuggets Turn Back Knicks, 116109
description: DENVER, Nov. 9 (AP)  George McGinnis scored 15 of his teamhigh 25 points as Denver took a 64.38 halftime lead over the New York Knicks tonight, and the Nuggets went on to take a 116109 victory in a'National Basketball Association game.

title: VETERANS DAY
description: Tomorrow is Veterans Day. But be- cause the holiday falls on a Saturday, most government offices and courts will observe it today and will be closed.

title: Deepening Uganda Crisis Tests Amin
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 9  A major crisis appears to be shaping up for President Idi Amin of Uganda, although it has been overshadowed by fighting between Ugandan and Tanzanian troops. Many diplomats believe the crisis is the worst in President Amin's seven years of rule.

title: Andrew G. Kershaw, Chairman Of the Ogilvy &Mather Agency
description: Andrew G. Kershaw, chairman of Ogilvy & Mather, one of the world's largest advertising agencies, died Oct. 28 at his home in Pound Ridge, N.Y. He was 56.

description: What's wrong with Steve Cauthen, the wonder jockey of 1977?

title: Carter and Giscard Are Expected To Pay Visits to Japan Next Year
description: TOKYO, Nov 9. (Reuters)  Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda said today that President Carter and President Valery Giscard d'Estaini planned to make separate state visits to Japan before or after the sevennation economic summit conference in Tokyo next June.

title: John O'Neil, ExCity Aide, Die..
description: John O'Neil, a former New York City Buildings Commissioner, but more recently executive officer and chief engineer for the Transit Authority, died yesterday f He was 69 years old and lived at 366 Tysens Lane on Staten Island.

title: At Long Nazi Trial, the Sense of Horror Is Vanishing in a Murmur of Legalisms
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, Nov.  On many days the horror of the Maidanek concentration camp stops at the courtroom door.

title: Hawks 125, Clippers 101
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 9 (AP)  John Drew scored a seasonhigh 35 points to lead the Atlanta Hawks to a 125101 N.B.A. victory over the San Diego Clippers tonight.

title: ARMS UNIT NOMINEE HELD CONTROVERSIAL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9President Carter's nomination of a retired threestar army general to head the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency is raising questions here after disclosure that he belonged to a group seeking to thwart an agreement limiting strategic arms.

title: Fugitive Pornographer Captured
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 9 (AP)  Mike Thevis, the fugitive pornographer who is one of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's most wanted men, has been captured, the F.B.I. said today. Mr. Thevis  was captured in the Northeast region of the United States, a spokesman, Bill McGrath, said. Mr. Thevis, 46 years old, escaped in April about two months before he was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Atlanta on charges of arson, murder and extortion in the building of his Xrated bookstore and peepshow empire.

title: About Real Estate A New Office Building With Public Amenities
description: We all remember, do we not, the old Cathedral High School that the Archdiocese of New York ran on the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and 50th Street, in the days before it built new school at 55th Street and First Avenue. And we remember, too, that after the high school moved out in 1972, Hunter College moved in as a tenant until last year.

title: Bridge:
description: There have been exciting international championships, with the results in doubt in the final session. But perhaps nothing has ever quite equaled the tension of the South American Championships last week in Caracas, Venezuela, where the title hinged on the last deal.

title: Cordero Weighing Suit On RaceFixing Article
description: Angel Cordero plans to sue Sports Illustrated for a recent article containing racefixing allegations against him and five other top New Yorkbased jockeys.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Bond Prices Steady in Slow Day
description: The credit markets continued to hold their ground yesterday, moving up or down only slightly as traders again sought to assess the Federal Reserve's more restictive monetary policy, which was announced more than a week ago. Trading activity remained light.

title: Le Anne Schreiber Is Appointed As Sports Editor of The Times
description: Le Anne Schreiber, assistant sports editor of The New York Times, has been appointed sports editor, A. M. Rosenthal, executive editor, announced yesterday.

description: Steel production for the week ended Nov. 4 fell to 2.765 million tons, down 0.1 percent from the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry produced 2.769 million tons the week before.

description: Hartwick College, the defending national soccer champion, was seeded third yesterday in the New York regional phase of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Senator Clark's Staff Takes Loss With Sadness and Fond Regret
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  The time for weeping and wailing had passed. Their man had lost on Election Day. And so the staff of Senator Dick Clark, Democrat of Iowa, reluctantly, puzzled and surprised, turned to the task at hand: finding new jobs and winding up work in the space that some had occupied for six years.

title: 2 Are Sworn to Begin Special Senate Terms
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) A Republican and a Democrat who were elected to abbreviated terms in the Senate were sworn into office today.

description: HONG KONG, Nov. 9 (AP)  Secondseeded John Alexander of Australia and seventhseeded Brian Teacher of the United States suffered defeats against unranked opponents in secondround matches of the $75,000 Hong Kong Tennis Classic today.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP)  Trans portation Secretary Brock Adams proposed today the creation of a new Surface Transportation Administration by merging two existing agencies.

title: Theater: A Nihtcap Without a Kick
description: ASHORT story can be published and anthologized, but short play is something of foundling. Producers prefer longer, seemingly more substantial evenings of theater, although one need only look at the work of Samuel Beckett to realize that in brevity there can be complexity. The Circle Repertory Company is performing a valuable service with its latenight series of oneact plays. The program offers oppor. tunities for playwrights as well as theatergoers who would like a dramatic dessert after dinner. Unfortunately, the Circle's current 11 P.M. late show, Stargazing, by Tom Cone, is both short (45 minutes) and slight.

title: JERSEY OFFERS PLAN TO CURB POLLUTION
description: TRENTON, Nov. 9  New Jersey's new pollution controls, which eventually will take 240,000 tons a year of pollutants from the air and include a limited crackdown on chemical carcinogens, were unveiled today.
