title: Sports News Briefs
description: TORONTO, Nov. 9  Mark Laskin, an unheralded Canadian rider, piloted Demuraz to a narrow victory in the open jumper class today at the opening session of the 10day Royal Winter Fair Horse Show.

title: 0.E.C.D. Cites Gains in Prices
description: PARIS, Nov..9 (UPI)  Consumer prices in Western industrial countries rose an average 0.7 percent In September, more rapidly than in August but at the same rate as in June and July, the Organization for Econoniic Cooperation and Development said today.

title: FBI Agent Tied to Bribery Case Pleads Guilty to Obstruction Count
description: The first agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to be indicted for a crime while on active duty pleaded guilty yesterday to a charge of obstructing justice. The charge was related to a bribe the agent allegedly received from a Manhattan bookmaker.

title: M.LT.'s President Sees a Threat In AcademicGovernment Rifts
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  After three decades of amiability, the relationship between the Federal Government and those engaged in academic research is floundering, Dr. Jerome B. Wiesner, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said today.

title: Broadway
description: LOOK for Summer the first week in March. Summer is the title of the next Hugh Leonard play headed for Broadway. Originally was on the fall schedule at the Hudson Guild, the Off Off Broadway theater that gave birth to the awardwinning Broadway production of Mr. Leonard's Da, the sleeper hit of last season. Now, however, it has been bought for production by Lester Osterman. Marilyn Strauss amd Marc'Howard, the same team that brought Da to uroaaway. Lome spring, Mr. Leonard will have two plays on Broadway. Four years ago Summer received its premiere at the Olney Theater in Maryland (the first theater to present Da), and was then staged for one week at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, and in Chicago and Dublin. At one point it was optioned for Broadway, but  as also happened early in the life of Dawas dropped. Da has opened doors for other plays by this prolific Irish playwright.

title: Conceit I Musici's Bach
description: IT sometimes seems that the more we know, the less we can be sure. In recent decades, for instance, scholars and practical musicians have uncovered an enormous amount of evidence about how Bach's music was performed. There is wide agreement about such matters as the optimum number of players, the range of available sonorities, instrumentation, and much else. And vet arguments over Baroque performance practice probably generate more heat nowadays than ever before.

title: Figaro Meets Fiddler
description: A Conference on Opera/Musical Theater, a prenuptial meeting of the families to arrange a sort of marriage of convenience between The Barber of Seville and Fiddler on the Roof, began yesterday in the board room of the Metropolitan Opera House where, through Saturday morning, it will hear from some of the more important people, from both sides

title: Ali, Upstaging Holmes, Hints Retirement Again
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov.9  Larry Holmes was upstaged on the eve of his first defense of the World Boxing Council heavyweight title today by a former sparring partner named Muhammad Ali.

title: Benjamin H. Bartholow, at 84, Treasury Official, 1929 to 1932
description: Benjamin H. Bartholow, a former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, died Monday at the Harkness Pavillion at Presbyterian Medical Center of heart failure. He was 84 years old and lived in New York City.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI)  The American steel industry has promised the Administration that it will comply with President Carter's antiinflation program, a Treast'ry official said today.

title: 3 F.B.I. Agents in Breakin Case Are Said to Have Left the Bureau
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  In the seven months that the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been considering what to do about 68 agents involved in allegedly illegal breakins, at least three of tht men have left the bureau and are now outside the reach of administrative sanctions, according to persons familiar with the case.

title: Merrill Brokers Get Subpoenas
description: The Massachusetts Securities Division announced yesterday that 11 brokers for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith were issued a total of 16 subpoenas in connection with its investigation of abuses in salac nrartirac This statement corrected an earlier announcement that 31 Merrill Lynch brokers had been subpoened to testify before the division.

title: Nakian Carves old Stories n New Shapes
description: THE career of Reuben Naltian is one of the longest and most distinguished in American sculpture. Born in 1897, he had his first oneman show at the old Whitney Studio Club  forerunner of the Whitney Museum  in 1926. He had already served an apprenticeship in the studio of Paul Manship and for a time had also shared a studio with Gaston Lachaise. He was, from the beginning, an artist deeply versed in the traditions and techniques of the masters of Western sculpture, and their aura continues to haunt him.

description: Friday

description: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 9 The bitterly tided Democratic-Farmer-Labor irty, which suffered a bruising defeat in esday's election, is taking a long, hard Rt at itself and trying to put the pieces ck together before 1980. With Hubert H. Humphrey, a founder the party in the mid1940's, dead, and th the loss this week of two Senate seats d the Governor's office, the party is left pout a leader to rally around as it tries heal the wounds left by this year's rsh feuding among its liberal moderIs and conservative factions.

If his spirit lingers in this country rather than in his native Armenia, it may well be present at the Newark Museum next Thursday. For this is the opening date of Murals Without Walls, an extraordinary exhibition that will feature two of the 10 panels the artist painted at Newark Airport in 1936-37

title: Japan Car Imports Up
description: TOKYO, .Nov. 9 (AP)  Importers reported today that they sold 3,068 imported cars in October, up 18 percent from a year earlier, but added that American cars fared poorly. An official of the Japan Automobile Importers Association said the sales of large cars with displacement of more than 2,000 cubic centimeters, or about 121 cubic inches declined 0.6 percent, and compact cars gained 39.2 percents

description: A trigger price mechanism designed to prevent foreign steel companies from dumping steel on the domestic

title: Associated Press
description: LEANING INTO THE ACTION: San Diego Clippers Lloyd Free driving past Hawks Rick Wilson at the Omni in Atlanta last night during the first period. Atlanta won game, 125101.

title: Will It Fly Without Controls?
description: During two years of legislative combat, President Carter shied from a serious attack on inflation as one battle too many. Now that he faces doubledigit inflation and bellwether labor negotiations in the oil refining, trucking and auto industries, the President has finally acted. There is doubt that his package of voluntary wageprice guidelines, wage insurance and a stiff dose of fiscal and monetary restraint can work without a slide into recession. But given the alternatives, there should be little doubt that the risk worth taking. Inaction would only guarantee recession, and a deeper one at that.

title: City Council Panel Votes to Keep Employee Residency Restriction
description: The City Council's Civil Service Committee yesterday voted out an amendment to preserve the restrictions of the employee residency law that was recently ruled unconstitutional by the State Supreme Court. The move was designed to offset possible lawsuits.

title: C4 Serban Conjures The Devil at Public
description: The Master and Margarita, the monumental satiric novel by the late Russian playwright and novelist Mikhail Bulgakov, is coming to life on the American stage - beginning this evening at the Public Theater. The adapter as well as director is the innovative Rumanian Andrei Serban, in his first attempt at writing a play. Although this is a lowbudget, workshop pkoduction, scheduled for a limited number of free performances, it has an epic scale matching that of the original book. In its barest outline, this Faus- tian novel-as-play deals with the visit of the Devil to Moscow. The full title of Mr. Serban's dramatization is The Master and Margarita (in Moscow, or the Gospel According to the Devil).

title: At the Movies
description: WHEN last heard from in June, Sigourney Weaver was waiting in her modest West Side brownstone apartment for the limousine that would carry her in unfamiliar splendor to Kennedy Airport. From there she was to fly, first class, of course, to London, where this hitherto unheralded young Off Broadway actress was to begin her screen career with a staffing role in The Alien.

title: New York Getting 2 Power Plants
description: Two modestsized hydroelectric plants will be constructed at two upstate city reservoirs in a move that would reduce the city's need for imported oil by 75,000 barrels a year, Mayor Koch and Frederick R. Clark, the State Power Authority chairman, announced yesterday.

title: Art: Choice Landscapes
description: LANDSCAPE painting was for many generations an auxiliary activity. Every great artist had to be able to handle landscape, just as he had to be able to handle still life. But the main business of art was with the human figure. Whether in portraiture, or in subjects taken from history, mythology or the Bible, it was the figure that really counted. Landscapepainting as an independent form of art had a very slow start.

title: Earnings Soar at A.M.C. in Quarter
description: DETROIT, Nov. 9  The American Motors Corporation today announced its strongest fiscal fourth quarter on record, with profits soaring to $26 million, or 86 cents a share, compared with the yearearlier $3 million, or 9 cents share.

title: IN THE NATION
description: DAR ES SALAAM, TanzaniaWhen President Julius Nyerere of Tanzania met with President Carter in the White House last year, Mr. Carter said forthrightly that he could not support an unelected government for Zimbabwe, as Rhodesia will be called when its black majority takes power.

title: Movies: Rocky Goes to Limbo in 'Paradise Alley':Rocky as Wrestler
description: SYLVESTER STALLONE needs help. If he continues to write, direct and star in movies like "Paradise Alley," the career that only really began with "Rocky" may turn out to have been an extremely brief dream. He won't be going the course."Paradise Alley," which opens at three theaters today, is a phony, attitudinizing, self-indulgent mess, a multimillion-dollar B (for boring) picture with the ear of a cauliflower, the heart of a hustler and the soul of a used-car salesman. It's so gross it's almost funny but, by not being funny, it makes one even more impatient than is absolutely necessary.If there had been just a tiny bit of wit involved, or a consistent point of view, or genuine feeling, "Paradise Alley" might have been an engaging throwback to the true B pictures of yesteryear. As it is, it's "Rocky" warmed over and then thrown out.Mr. Stallone's screenplay is set in New York's Hell's Kitchen in 1946, though it often looks like the Lower East Side in 1933 and San Francisco's Barbary Coast in 1890. In any case we get the idea it's a place people want to escape from  to go uptown or down town, as the geography might have it.There are three brothers, Italian Americans, trying to make a go of things. Cosmo (Mr. Stallone), the middle brother, wears a gold earring and his hair long, which he says are his trademarks. Cosmo is the con artist. Lenny (Armand Assante), the oldest brother, was wounded in world War II, and walks with a slight limp. Lenny works in an embalming parlor and is, in the language of such fiction, bitter at the world. Though the work is quiet and steady, there's no great future in embalming. The youngest brother, Victor (Lee Canalito), is a huge, immensely strong but gentle fellow, not unlike Lenny in "Of Mice and Men."In dramatizing the story of how Lenny and Cosmo attempt to promote Victor as a saloon wrestler to finance their way out of Hell's Kitchen, Mr. Stallone, the writer and director, introduces an assortment of eccentric and sentimental characters who seem to have been borrowed from other people's fiction. They include a small-time Irish hood, nicely played by Kevin Conway, who appeared with Mr. Stallone in "F.I.S.T.," and Frank McRae, as a down-and-out black wrestler, the only actor in the movie with a decently funny and appealing scene.The women in the brothers' lives are a lovely, virtuous redhead (Anne Archer), who works in a dime-a-dance hall; a faithful whore (Joyce Ingalls) and a terrifically literate Chinese-American (Aimee Eccles) who cares about Victor enough to read him passages from the dictionary at night. She wants to improve his brain.The movie sort of coasts along from one predictable confrontation to another, bending characters to suit the plot, until the climactic wrestling bout on Christmas night when poor Victor must fight for a $9,000 purse.Mr. Stallone is no more interesting as a director than he is as an actor, nor does he have much sense of self-preservation. In "Paradise Alley," bracketed by Mr. Canalito, who makes him look the size of Mickey Rooney, and by Mr. Assante, who gives indications of being a good actor, he becomes virtually invisible. Which isn't entirely bad."Paradise Alley," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), includes some scenes of violence in the wrestling arena and some mildly vulgar language.

title: State Unit Approves Revised Plan By Koch on 4- Year City Financing
description: New York State's Financial Control Board yesterday approved Mayor Koch's revised fouryear financial plan for New York City and the city's request to issue the first of its new federally guaranteed bonds probably next week.

title: Captain Says Riders'
description: The forward rush of passengers on ferryboat that was off its course in dense fog apparently caused its propellers to rise out of the water and contributed to the crash Tuesday that injured 240 persons, the boat's captain testified yesterday

title: Deaths
description: BERNSTCINNell. AKA Nell Burstyn. Actor and writer. Beloved son of Florence and Hyman. Dear brother of Donna Fawcett. Services at the I.J. Morris Inc Funeral Home, 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead. For time of service, call funeral home.

title: Western States
description: DENVER, Nov. 9  Western voters mounted horse and galloped off in several directions in Tuesday's elections, defying all analysts to spot a trend.

title: Streetbroken
description: They said it couldn't be done; New Yorkers would never submit to such violation of their dogs civil liberties. They were wrong. The city's canine population has been streetbroken. True, some dogs have been abandoned or destroyed because of the new rule, and the cleanup task is onerous for some elderly dog owners. But on the whole, the astonishing has been achieved, with inestimable benefits to New York's heart and soul, its pedestrians.

title: IRANIAN OPPOSITION TO CONTINUE STRIKES
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 9 Iran's main opposition party vowed today to use the continuing strikes at oilfields and factories as its main weapon against Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi now that the nation is under military rule.

title: Radio Playing in Subways Down
description: The three-week-old crackdown on blaring radios and tape recorders in subways has resulted in the issuance of 83 summonses by Transit Authority police officers and a 75 percent reduction in the playing of the portables, Mayor Koch said yesterday. Chief Sanford Garelik of the Transit police has informed me that in the past the unlawful radio playing was four'tithes more frequent than it was in the last few weeks, Mr. Koch said.

title: HinduMoslem Clashes in Aligarh Are Reported to Take Lives of 10
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 9 (UPI)  At least 10 people have been killed in rioting between Hindu and Moslem mobs in the city of Aligarh, 70 miles southeast of New Delhi, the Press of India said today.

title: 2 Authority Officials Say Reported Junket Was a Rescue Mission
description: Late last spring, Alphonse D'Ambrose, the general counsel of the Transit Authority, and his wife, Carol, vacationing together in south Florida, telephoned Transit Authority headquarters in New York with a rambling, incoherent tale of being drugged, assaulted and robbed.

title: Tennis Moves to Improve Officiating
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 9 (AP)  Bjorn Borg of Sweden routed Bernie Mitton of South Africa, 62, 64, and the defending champion, Sandy Mayer of the United States, edged Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia, 75, 7.6, tonight. The winners moved into the third round of the $175,000 Stockholm open tennis tournament.

title: Expansion Of Futures In Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 9  The Chicago Mercantile Exchange announced plans today for a major expansion of futures trading in its International Monetary Market Division, including futures contracts based on stockprice movements and interestrate futures based on Eurodollars.

title: French Bread Fills Gap In Strikebound Britain
description: DOVER, England, Nov. 9 (AP) Britain's bakers are on strike, but fresh bread from across the English Channel was on sale in this port city today.

title: Manufacturers in Accord To Acquire Lionel Edie
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company announced yesterday an agreement in principle to acquire the investment counseling firm of Lionel D. Edie & Company Inc. A spokesman for Manufacturers said that the purchase price for Edie  which has recently been rumored to be for sale would not be disclosed.

title: Tips on Tickets
description: The Master and margarita will be presented tonight, tomorrow and Sunday at 8 P.M. at the Public Theater, with a matinee on Sunday at 3 P.M. Fathers and Sons will be presented tomorrow and Sunday at 8 P.M., with a Sunday matinee at 3 P.M. All tickets are free, but seating is limited. Telephone 6776350 for reservations.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAHAMBen W. The Officers, Di. rectors and New York Stall of The American Committee for Shaer Zedek Hospitals In Jerusalem Inc., expresses heartfelt condolences on the passing of Mr. Ben W. Abraham, for. mer Executive Vice President of our Institution. May the bereaved family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Schmidt Says Germans Still Bear Onus for Nazism.
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, Nov. (AP)  Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, speaking at a 40thanniversary commemoration of the first major Nazi attack on Jews, said today that Germans, while mostly innocent as individuals, must bear collective responsibility for the atrocities of the Hitler era.

title: Loans to Corporations By Banks Up Sharply
description: Commercial banks are increasing their loans to corporations more sharply, figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve showed.

title: CARTER URGES EGYPT AND ISRAEL TO DROP DISPUTE ON LINKAGE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  President Carter urged the Governments of Egypt and Israel today to stop debating over details and to agree to compromise language already accepted by negotiators  that would link an EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty to an overall Middle East settlement.

title: Dance: A 1943 O'Donnell Remains Fresh as Ever
description: IN its final entry, the Dance Umbrella series presented the May O'Donnell Concert Dance Company Wednesday night at the Entermedia Theater.

title: Energy Act Is Signed; Limits Seen
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  President Carter today signed the vigorously debated National Energy Act of 1978, which should deliver about half of what the President asked for when he introduced the legislation as the moral equivalent of war, according to Administration estimates.

title: Restaurants
description: IN the last two or three years, tnere has peen burgeoning interest in fish and shellfish, for reasons of health as well as esthetics. Until now, however, that interest has not been matched by an increase in the number of good seafood restaurants in the city. This imbalance is due, no doubt, to the specialized skill and knowledge such a restaurant operation requires. Really fresh sea- food is hard to come by, and, once procured, it must be handled properly because it is so perishable. Then, too, it must be prepared with consummate care to avoid overcooking or dryness, the most common flaws in fish preparations.

This happened last January, when Nina Beilina made her first official American appearance at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. The Music critics of the New York dailies pulled out their best adjectives to describe the violinist's playing. In The New York Times. Harold C. Schonberg wrote:

title: Shell With Name Is Near Body
description: CROSSVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 9 (AP) buckshot shotgun shell found near William Cox's body today had his name on it, literally. According to the Cumberland County Sheriff's Department, two deputies, Larry Lowe and John Dishman, found Mr. Cox's body at 1 A.M. at the entrance to the oRenegade Resort near Crossville. About 45 feet away were four spent 12gauge shotgun shells. One of the shells had the name Billy written on it in ink.

title: Notes on People
description: EMBOLDENED by Republican victories in his home state of Minnesota and elsewhere in Tuesday's election, Harold Stassen, the never-say-die perennial Presidential candidate, yesterday again threw his hat in the ring. The former Governor announced in St. Paul that he would seek the Republican nomination in the 1980 primaries on platform to clean out the cofruption in Washington and overcome inflation with full employment. The 70-year-old

title: CAREY IS EXPECTED TO NAME PATERSON
description: Governor Carey will very likely appoint Deputy Mayor Basil A. Paterson as New York Secretary of State succeeding Lieut. Gov.elect Mario M. Cuomo, top Carey aides said yesterday.

title: RESIDENTS HAIL MAN WHO KILLED ROBBER
description: The patrons of a drycleaning shop in the South Bronx were eager yesterday to thank the store's coowner, Peter Geron, who shot and killed a 17-year-old gunman Wednesday night. They wanted to thank him for what they regarded as a contribution toward making their neighborhood safer place to live.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title

title: Music: Bach Aria Group
description: THOUGH music ensembles tend to come and go in New York's musical life, the Bach Aria Group is one of the relatively few that seems to go on forever. Thus, the familiar purveyors of cantatas and cantata excerpts came back to Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night to begin another season.

title: New Head of Fiscal Control Unit
description: From his corner office on the 21st floor of the State Office Building at Broadway  and Chambers Street, Corner Swift Coppie, the new executive director of the Emeregency Financial Control Board, has an eagle's aerie Man In the News view of the two power centers whose interests it is now his job to reconcile.

title: Chemical Payout Up to 79c
description: The Chemical New York. Corporation, parent company of the Chemical Bank, announced yesterday that its directors had increased the quarterly commonstock dividend to 79 cents share from 75 cents a share. The increased dividend is payable Jan. 1 to holders of record Dec. 15.

title: Auctions
description: NOVEMBER is traditionally the time to buy pumpkins at country markets and prints at city auctions, Graphics collectors, true to form, will be attending two art feasts, today at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, and next Thursday at 10:30 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Christie, Manson & Woods, Park Avenue at Nth Street. There will, as usual, be two chances to acquire certain works at these auctions because of duplications. For example, there are at least two Picasso etchings and two ToulouseLautrec lithographs. All are among the more popular examples of the genre. The Picasso etchings are The Frugal Repast (presale estimate is around $16,000 at both auction houses) and an important aquatint etching from the Vollard Suite, depicting a faun and a woman (estimates are about $10,000). The ToulouseLautrec lithographs in both sales are a portrait of Marcelle Lender, estimated to bring at least $4,500, and a poster for the magazine La Revue Blanche, which is expected to bring about $5,000.

title: English Trifle, 151, Wins Feature at Meadowlands
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 9.  Thomas P. Whitney's English Trifle, a 151 longshot, led a sixhorse field at the Meadowlands tonight and captured the 552.800 Honey Bee by l'h lengths.

title: $223 Million Dart Bid For Mallory Planned
description: Dart Industries said yesterday in a surprise disclosure that it was planning an offer of $96 a share  or $223 million in cash  for P. R. Mallory & Company, the battery maker. Mallory, which was given no advance warning, took immediate court action to fight the takeover.

title: ANGRY HOMOSEXUALS PARADE UP 8TH AVE.
description: Chanting Gay rights  right now, more than 2,000 angry demonstrators paraded through Greenwich Village and midtown Manhattan last night after staging a rally in Sheridan Square to denounce a City Council committee vote against a bill to outlaw discrimination against homosexuals.

title: The Energy Law and Inflation
description: One of the chief concerns voiced over the original energy package proposed by President Carter a year and a half ago was its potential impact on the inflation rate, which at that time was hovering just above 5 percent. Today,

title: Harvests at Peak But Cost of Food Will Still Go Up
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  Although American farmers this week finished harvesting the largest corn and soybean crops ever grown, this abundance is not expected to help President Carter immediately in his campaign to check inflation.

title: WASHINGTON Rhetoric And Reality,
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  President Carter is now facing the hardest choices of his first two years in office. In the preparation of his budget between now and the end of the year, he must decide between the conservative themes of the November election and the rising financial claims of his domestic and foreign policies.

title: Art: Prints at Met Relish Past Repasts
description: IT is said that the French landscapist, Calude, started life as cake decorator and, considering those fluffy trees he did, the story is easy to believe. More recently, people like Claes Oldenburg and Wayne Thibaud have also rendered art out of food. But, on the whole, artists have traditionally dealt with the subject in its raw state, depicting it either as a still life or as an accessory to a larger idea.

title: Girl Student, Stripped In a Search, Is Upheld
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday set aside a jury verdict that had cleared the Board of Education of charges of improperly stripping a 15-year-old highschool girl in a search for a small pipe used for smoking mariivana.

title: Loves Join the Fold
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 9 (AP) The Indiana Loves, not broke yet but losing $1,500 a day, followed in the footsteps of four other World Team Tennis franchises and folded today.

title: Music: The Endymions
description: THE Endymion Ensemble, which presented a concert Wednesday evening at Carnegie Recital Hall, offered two orchestral works and one for chamber wind ensemble. Because the Endymions are a chamber ensemble, and Carnegie Recital Hall is not normally the site of fulldress orchestral events, the two orchestral works were necessarily given with reduced forces. This proved interesting but not entirely convincing, yet whatever reservations one had worked up before the intermission were mutedd by the superb piece and performance at the end.

title: Con. Edison Proposes a Partnership to Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 9  The Consolidated Edison Company, which has been battling Westchester over a controversial plan for a county takeover of its distribution network, in a surprise move today proposed a partnership with the county to solve two other longstanding and nettlesome problems.

title: JACOBSON WARNED OF BAIL REVOCATION
description: Howard Jacobson, the businessman and former horsetrainer accused of murdering his former girlfriend's lover, was barred yesterday from trying to talk to the woman, Melanie Cain, a $100,000-ayear model.

title: Stanley Simon Is Held Most Likely Successor To Abrams in Bronx
description: City Councilman Stanley Simon emerged yesterday as the frontrunner in a scramble among Bronx politicians for the office of Borough President, which will be vacated at the end of the year when the incumbent, Robert Abrams, goes to Albany as State Attorney General.

title: U.S. Legislation Aids Effort To Save Jersey's Pinelands

title: Leading Figure in Somoza Party Is Fatally Shot at Home in Leon
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 9 (Reuters)  A leading member of President Anastasio Somoza's ruling Liberal Party has died after being shot in the head at his home Tuesday, the police said here today.

title: Chase Lifts Interest Rate On Home Loans to 10%
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, following the lead set last Monday by the Citibank, yesterday raised its maximum interest rate on residential mortgages to 10 percent, the highest ever posted in the state

title: Designing for Spring With Cheer, Not a Leer
description: The fashion people who swept into New York this week from stores all over the country to check out spring collections choked Seventh Avenue's elevators and showrooms. To accommodate them, designers took their collections to places like the Whitney Museum and Lincoln Center, thereby lending cultural overtones to the presentation of spring clothes.

title: Blue Law vs. Automatic Teller
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 9  The First Stamford Bank and Trust Company filed suit today in Superior Court against four competitors, chatting that they were in violation of the state's new blue law by operating automatic teller machines on Sunday.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: THE main event on ABC tonight at 8 features Larry Holmes in his first heavyweight title defense. He faces Alberto Evangelista in a scheduled 15round match in Las Vegas. Holmes won his World Boxing Council title last June from Ken Norton, who can also be seen tonight, in a preliminary bout with Randy Stephens.

title: TEAMSTERS'
description: President Carter's voluntary wagebenefit guideline of 7 percent is unacceptable to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the nation's largest union, Frank E. Fitzsimmons, the union president, said yesterday.

title: COMMODITIES

Prices of gold, silver and platinum futures in New York dropped their respective daily permissible limits or closed within a few cents of them.

description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. (AP)  Hale Irwin of the United States shot a courserecord 64 in the first round of the Australian Professional Golfers Association Championship on the Royal Melbourne course today. His score broke the mark by one stroke.

title: La Mama Is Home To Young jazzmen
description: In jazz, reputations are seldom made overnight. But jazz musicians, espedaily younger ones, often develop in dramatic spurts, and sometimes the public discovers them suddenly. Several of New York's younger jazzmen have been developing rapidly and are beginning to enjoy increasing recognition. Three of them are per- forming this weekend in a new concert series at the La Mama theater, 74A East Fourth Street between Second Avenue and the Bowery. The first concert, which begins at 8 tonight, features the flutist James Newton. Admission is $3, $2 for students and the elderly.

title: The Repressed Conscience
description: Alexander Podrabinek is, in a way, a lucky man. He is a young Russian medical assistant who was sentenced in Moscow in August for deliberate fabrications which defame the Soviet system. This now familiar catchall charge was occasioned by Mr. Podrabinek's book, Punitive Medicine, a report on the treatment of Soviet dissenters. He is lucky because he was given only five years of internal exile.

description: BOSTON, Nov. 9 (AP)  Rick Middleton scored two goals, and Bobby Schmautz got the 200th goal of his career tonight as the Boston Bruins defeated the Washington Capitals, 62, in a National Hockey League game_

title: People in Sports . . .
description: Mike Caldwell, who suffered through three losing seasons after undergoing arm surgery in 1979, has been named the American League's comeback player of the year by United Press International. The 30-year-old left- handed pitcher for the Milwaukee Brewers won 22 games and lost nine last season, setting a club record for most victories in a season. After posting a 195 wonlost record for the San Francisco Giants in 1979, Caldwell had a bone spur removed from his left elbow and did not regain his winning touch until this season. Caldwell received 15 votes, six more than Catfish Hunter of the Yankees, who was second in the voting.

title: Most of Blenheim Hotel Is Razed
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 9 (AP)Demolition experts blew up much of the historic Blenheim Hotel today to make way for a $100 million casinohotel complex on the Boardwalk.

title: Pennsylvania Blaze Fatal to 12 Laid to Arson by Investigators
description: Two New York City Fire Department investigators have confirmed that the fire in a Honesdale, Pa., hotel that killed 12 people was set by arsonists who apparenity torched the building in two places.

title: Vic Dickenson, 72, Back on Stand
description: Crawdaddy, the New Orleans-flavored restaurant at 45th Streeet and Vanderbilt Avenue, is developing the autumnal blooming of veteran jazz musicians into somethine of a stecialtv Last year, it gave Doc Cheatham, a 72yearold trumpet player who had spent his entire career as a sideman, his first opportunity to lead his own group, trio. Mr. Cheatham not only showed himself a versatile and subtle performer with an interesting collection of tunes gathered through the years, but he also made his debut as a singer, and proved to be an absolute charmer.

description: Mayor Koch spent yesterday afternoon at Yale University, talking with students, faculty members and some visiting parents as a Chubb Fellow in public affairs.

title: Inmates Tell of Texas Prison Brutality
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 10  For six weeks, a harsh picture of brutality, overcrowding, and inadequate medical care in Texas prisons has been emerging in testimony before a Federal judge. Yesterday, in one of the most dramatic accounts so far, former prisoner told of losing both his arms telow the elbow five years ago after he was ordered by supervisors at a state prison farm to feed silage into a threshing machine by hand, a violation, of normal safety procedures.

description: Nat, Fleischer rernernbered him as a ring scientist Ring Lardner remembered him this way: He studied, analyzed rehearsed, pondered. He saw his opponent as a case history, a specimen, an anatomical Sbbject. To Jack Dempsey who lost to hint twice, James Joseph Tunney was handsome blacid but a toutth scientific boxer.

title: Burton in 'Wild Geese,' Film About Mercenaries:African Big Horn
description: A movie that makes it impossible to tell whether Richard Burton's eyes are blue, green, pale gray or puce is a movie that has not been photographed properly. "The Wild Geese," which opened yesterday at Loews State and other theaters, is just as bewildering about the shade of Richard Harris's hair, which looks chartreuse. Those parts of the film that are set in London appear to have been staged indoors, even if they weren't, in a makeshift studio lit with one or two fluorescent bulbs. The African sequences are so dim and grainy that they seem to be taking place inside a tea bag.Reginald Rose's screenplay may not provide the definitive account of mercenary soldiers in present-day Africa, but it deserved better treatment than this. Mr. Rose, whose credits include "The Defenders" television series and "Twelve Angry Men," is an old-fashioned scenarist mindful of such old-fashioned niceties as pacing, clarity and economy. And his story gives each supporting character a memorable establishing line or two while still moving along at a brisk clip. There's actually quite an effective war movie lurking behind the unsightly facade of "The Wild Geese."The plot concerns a band of seasoned mercenaries hired by a wealthy British industrialist (Stewart Granger) to execute a mission in Africa. This tiny army, recruited by Mr. Burton, Mr. Harris and Roger Moore, is being sent to kidnap an African leader (Winston Ntshona) who has long been held prisoner and is believed by his followers to be dead. At the time the story starts, it suits Mr. Granger and his copper-mining interests to restore this leader to the public eye.But rich industrialists' interests have a way of changing. Things go swimmingly for Mr. Burton and his colorful, high-priced recruits until Mr. Granger decides, about an hour and a half into the story, to make a change in his plans. At this point, the faint-hearted would be well-advised to take themselves elsewhere, because the rest of the film is devoted to sickening, wholesale slaughter. There's no sex and not much profanity in "The Wild Geese," but the film has an R rating. Let that serve as the warning it's supposed to be.Until "The Wild Geese" begins devoting itself solely to violence, it's well-suited to a general audience; that makes the change of mood particularly unfortunate. Andrew V. McLaglen, best known as the director of John Wayne's lesser westerns, spends the early part of the film alternating long shots with abrupt close-ups that don't match, but the caliber of the cast and the sparkle of the screenplay are enough to hold one's attention.Later, Mr. McLaglen does greater damage when he begins treating hordes of African soldiers, who out-number the mercenaries about 600 to 1, as if they were Indians at Little Big Horn. "The Wild Geese" is not about to address itself to the complexities of contemporary Africa  that becomes clear when the political hostage says "If we have no future together, white man, we have no future, and quickly moves on to a less inflammatory subject. But it's a shame the film makers managed to travel so far without capturing even the faintest flavor of their story's exotic backdrop.

This remarkable comeback is more a tribute to Mrs. Gandhi's persistence and political skill than to herrecord. title: Lessons of Swine Flu
description: The Swine Flu Affair, by Harvard Profs. Richard E. Neustadt and Harvey V. Fineberg, is a cautionary case study of the Federal Government's 1976 immunization fiasco. It demonstrates the consequences of the imperfect teamwork between Washington's two cultures, one composed mainly of politicians and lawyers and the other of scientists and engineers. Its les- sons can be applied to a growing number of policy issues, such as how much research should be allowed on recombinant DNA, and what limits should be put on carcinogens and poisons in the environment. Such complex technical decisions must be made by public officials who may never have taken even an elementary curse in biolua, chemistry or physics.

title: Ideologies and Factions Complicate Economic Plans
description: WASHINGTON It was a small incident, but symbolic. To complete the appointment of Alfred E. title: THAT HOLLYWOOD TOUCH
description: On a cold, fogshrouded morning one day this past summer, Hollywood's most charming director kicked at the sand on a Malibu beach like a kid with blue lips who has been ordered out of the water. Herbert Ross, tall, craggyfaced and 10 pounds lighter than when he began filming the movie version of Neil Simon's hit play California Suite, on March 20, petulantly paced the misty beach awaiting the arrival of sunshine that would allow him to complete the final day of shooting what had been an exhausting, complex project. Over the previous four months, he had worked with four separate acting teams to film what is ostensibly four individual oneact plays whose only common denominator is that each story line unfolds in the posh environs of the Beverly Hills Hotel. Ross allowed one week of rehearsal and three weeks of filming for each act. It was like starting a new movie every fourth week, he said. Simply murderous.

Aided by a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts and cosponsored by the Philadelphia Museum of Art, the show will be on view in New York through Jan. 7.

There, as whodunnit fans know, criminals and scoundrels found the sewer system a superb place to scurry about and hide from the long-but-clean arm of the law. What spitshined copper wanted to delve into the understreet slime just to catch a simple thief or murderer?

title: Other National Events
description: Some of Henry A. Kissinger's cherished secrets of statecraft, and some personal moments as well, may be public property after all, if a United States District Court of Appeals ruling in Washington last week is upheld by the United States Supreme Court. The appeals court held that the former Secretary of State's diaries  transcribed by secretaries, who, on Mr. Kissinger's direction listened in on most calls, including those with family and friends  are not his personal possessions. The transcipts are believed to contain outspoken comments on domestic as well as foreign policy, including Watergate.

title: ART VIEW
description: After the noxious experience of the legal battles that did so much to make the name of Mark Rothko famous for all the wrong reasons, it is an immense relief to be able to return at last to the paintings that are, despite suicide and financial scandal, the first and last reasons for our interest in this difficult and still very enigmatic artist. The exhi- bition that Diane Waldman has now organized at the Guggenheim;Museum  Mark Rothko, 19031970: A Retrospective  is the most complete survey of the man's work anyone has yet given us. In addition, the Pace Gallery has simultaneously mounted an exhibition of The 19581959 Murals, which have never before been shown as a group. These exhibitions by no means exhaust the entire Rothko oeuvre, but they do give us a very ample basis on which come to terms with the artist's accomplishment. Future shows may y amplify or modify our understanding of one another aspect of that accomplishment, but the fundamental experience of Rothko's art has now been laid before us. For anyone with an interest in the art of our time, it is an experience not to be missed.

title: Butch Cassidy
description: William Goldman, one of America's most successful commercial writers, had a new movie open late last week called Magic, which he adapted from his 1976 page turner by that name. It's a psycholog- idal thriller which may well prove popular and thus another illustration of Mr. Goldman's enviable ability to rove freely back and forth between bigselling novels and bigattendance films. The only catch is that the author has never climbed from the great plains of popular art to the mountains Where the literary laurels bloom. But ttiat doesn't mean his knack is negligible. He won his first Academy Award for best original screenplay for Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid (1969) and a second for best adaptation for All the President's Men (1976). His Marathan Man (1974), which he also adapted for the screen, was on the paperback bestseller list as well as on the upper reaches of Variety's box-office chart. title: Other Regional Events
description: Theories abounded last week following an accident that injured 240 passengers on a Staten Island ferryboat. The ferry American Legion missed its landing slip in lower Manhattan Tuesday morning and crashed into a concrete seawall. Definitive placing of blame is probably weeks away. But possible contrib uting factors in the mishap, the worst involving municipal ferries in 20 years, were said to include thick fog that obscured flashing guide lights on the shore, stiff current and a sudden shift by passengers that could have made the boat's emergency reversal of engines ineffective.

Harriman bought the line at auction before the turn of the century, Mr. Evans has the company looking at additional rail acquisitions and pouring record amounts of capital into its rail operations.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: The farther out comedy gets, the more obliged it not to show strain. Of course comedy has a right to its outrageousness; it may just possibly have duty to be rude. No matter what direction serious theater and serious thinking may be taking at any given moment, comedy must keep two steps ahead if it's going to do what it was born to do: trip seriousness up, land it flat on its face. Something's got to keep from turning pompoue.

title: Food
description: There is a good deal to be said for the conceits of cookery, those amusing incidentals that add color, a touch of flavor and sometimes whimsy to various dishes. Our small (very small) catalogue of such things would include candied violets, cockscombs, periwinkles and capers. Capers are one of the most universal of these conceits. And one of the most versatile, especially with eggs and fish. They are, according to Larousse Gastronomique, the floral bud of the caper bush, which grows wild in the south of France, in Algeria, Turkey, in Asia Minor, etc. Capers are pickled in vinegar and used as a seasoning and condiment.

title: Headliners
description: It wasn't their finest hour. Britain's Conservative Party leadership instructed their members of parliament to abstain from voting on the renewal of trade sanctions against Rhodesia. But 116 members defied the order and voted No. One them was Winston Churchill, grandson of the wartime Prime Minister and spokesman for defense policy on the Tories front bench. As potential ministers in a potential Conservative government, frontbenchers are supposed to behave, so Margaret Thatcher, the Conservative party leader, gave Mr. Churchill the sack. Rather than vowing to fight his party on the benches, as perhaps his ancestor might have done, Mr. Churchill gave mild impromptu press conference and said, Politics is full ups and downs, isn't it?

title: Malaysians Bar Huge Boatload Of Ill Refugees
description: PORT KLANG, Malaysia, Nov. 11 On a decrepit freighter of uncertain origin, riding at anchor for nearly three days outside this port near Kuala Lumpur, more than 2,500 refugees from Vietnam are jammed into every available inch of space. title: Deaths

description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John L. Wood of Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their, daughter, Barbara Lane Wood, to Peter Lynn Rackow, son of Prof. and Mrs. Felix Rackow of St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: Ban on Park Hiking Is Continued
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN STATE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 11 (UPI)  The Palisades Interstate Parks Commission said today that it would continue to prohibit hiking on trails and in woodland sections of its 23 parks because of continuing dry weather. The park's general manager, Nash Castro, said two forest fires charred 15 acres on Friday. There have been 17 fires since Oct. 25, he added. Mr. Castro said picnicking would be permitted in open areas, although cooking is restricted to fireplaces.

title: TV ENTERS POLITICS IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 10  Television advertising apparently played a crucial role in helping two inexperienced and virtually unknown candidates unseat veteran political figures in Tuesday's ejection here, and this is likely to have significant impact on the conduct of the 1980 Presidential primaries in New Hampshire.

title: Late Williams Touchdown Overcomes Amherst, 7 to 2
description: AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 11 (AP)  A 7yard run late in the final quarter by Jay Wheatley provided the only touchdown today as Williams spoiled an Amherst homecoming with a 72 victory in a Little Three football conference game.

description: DON'T play taps for the short story as a literary form, at least not when Sylvia and Sam Tankel of Great Neck are around.

title: Officials Worried Over Charges By Gas Stations to Use Air Pump
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI)  Government safety officials are worried about what may be a growing trend at gasoline stationsa charge to use the air pump. One device being used requires motorist to insert a quarter to obtain four minutes worth of air.

title: Law The Press, The Courts, The Law, The Battle
description: The late Alexander Bickel, the Yale Law Professor who argued the Pentagon Papers case for The New York Times, said afterward that the First Amendment ordains an unruly contest between the press and government. The government he had in mind was the Executive Branch. Nowadays the contest is mainly between the press and the judiciary. Or so it seems to reporters and editors and broadcasters, who feel increasingly threatened by decisions of the courts.

title: 18,096 See Knicks Beat Celtics, 11198
description: The largest Madison Square Garden crowd of the season, an announced 18,096 spectators, saw the New York Knicks defeat the Boston Celtics, 11198, last night in their first game this year under Red Holzman, who replaced Willis Reed as the head coach yesterday.

title: V.C. Arguimbau 3d To Wed Miss Ford
description: The engagement of Hilarie Burdick Ford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Quintin Urisarri Ford of Darien, Conn., to Vincent Charles Arguimbau 3d, son of'Mr. and Mrs. Arguimbau Jr., also of Darien, has been announced by the future bride's parents. Plans have been made for a wedding next May.

title: When He Sings, the Robot Lights Up
description: PLAYING in a hand means being dependant not only on the guitarist but also on the guitarist's mother, landlord and parole board, according to Monte Farber, a singersongwriter of East Hampton. Personally, I prefer to be selfsufficient .

description: Brooklyn Tech successfully defended Its team title in the Public Schools Athletic League cross-country championship yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park In the Bronx.

title: Most School Levies in Ohio Were Defeated, and Issue Is Not Solved
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 10  Kent McGough, one of this state's most seasoned Republican Party strategists, was asked last spring what would determine the race for governor. He replied, The bottom line is whether the schools are open next November.

description: APROPOSAL to authorize jai alai gambling in New Jersey was rejected by the state's voters last Tuesday, but the last of it may not yet have been heard.

title: Westchester Ponders OTB Plan Netting Up to $3.1 Million a Year
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 11  Westchester County could net $1.4 million to $3.1 million a year by legalizing offtrack betting, county legislators were told in a preliminary report on a consultant's study.

title: Prevent Nuclear War, Hiroshima Pilot Urges
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 11 (UPI)  Brig. Gen. Paul W. Tibbets Jr. of the Air Force, retired, the pilot of the B29 that dropped the first atomic bomb in World War II, said yesterday that his experiences since Hiroshima had left him opposed to nuclear warfare.

According to a Merrill Lynch personnel executive, many staff members quit their jobs immediately, not even staying around long enough to find out about severance pay.

title: $250,000 in Jewelry Is Stolen During Night From Bloomingdale's
description: More than $250,000 worth of gold bracelets and necklaces were stolen from display cases at Bloomingdale's in an apparent burglary in the early hours of yesterday, the police reported.

title: Castro Finds There Are Risks As the Policeman of Africa
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  In April 1965, a man travelling under a false passport boarded a plane at Havana, his attache case bulging with books, solo chess problems and inhalers for chronic asthma. For a long time, his whereabouts were to remain a mystery. Who would have thought that Ernesto Che Guevara was deep in the African jungle?

title: Americans Trail Badly In Japanese Golf Classic
description: ONO, Japan, Nov. 11 (AP)  Japan, led by its defending champion, Isao Aoki, built a virtually insurmountable 54stroke lead over the United States, today in the third round of the eighth United StatesJapan professional golf match.

title: Governor of Virgin Islands Wins A Full Term on NoParty
description: ST. CROIX, U.S. Virgin Islands, Nov. 11  Juan Luis, a native of Puerto Rico who ran on a noparty ticket, was elected this week to a full term as Governor by a 2to1 vote, dashing Democrats hopes of taking over the Governorship for the first time in nine years.

title: Nets Set Back Bulls As King Scores 38
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (UPI)  Bernard King scored a seasonhigh 38 points and Eric Money scored 8 points during an 11second span tonight to lead the New Jersey Nets to a 125112 victory over the Chicago Bulls.

title: Philomusica Picks Out Rare Works
description: How often has anyone heard one of Haydn's eight Notturnos played in New York? The chances are that few people have even heard of them at all, owing to this music's unconventional instrumental combination of 10 to 12 string and wind players. In other words, these scores remain unperformed because they inhabit that nevernever land somewhere between chamber and orchestral music, too large for small groups and too intimate for symphonic programs.

title: Elis Top Princeton in Bowl by 237
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 11  Mike Patterson, an obscure reserve fullback, plunged into the Princeton end zone on the nexttolast play of the game for touchdown and the white handkerchiefs came whipping out in the Yale stands. The supporters of the Elis were giving the Tigers the traditional byebye salute because the Yale team had beaten Princeton again, 237, for the 12th straight time.

title: 3 BILLS ARE VETOED AS AIDING INFLATION
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11  The White House announced today that President Carter, as part of his efforts to fight inflation, had vetoed three bills that he considered either inflationary on their face, or serious limits on his ability to deal with inflation.

title: Holmes's Grip on Title Strengthened
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 11  If Larry Holmes's spectacularly easy victory over Alfredo Evangelista in his first defense of the World Boxing Council heavyweight title was onesided, just wait.

title: A Correction
description: A recent reference to Thomm's Restaurant at 80 Park Avenue, Newark, as menacing in the course of a humorous story on New Jersey attractions was meant to convey in a humorous fashion that the restaurant, in the writer's opinion, was not bright. It was an atmospheric reference and was not meant to convey a judgment of the longestablished restaurant's food, service, goodwill or reputation. The word menacing in no way was intended to apply to the quality of the food or the caliber and courtesy of the staff and management.

title: Gallery Opens New Vistas at Home for Aged
description: CELIA ZIRNISKY is something of a celebrity at the residence for the elderly where she lives. When a visitor entered, the 80yearold woman proudly mentioned a group of paintings seen by everyone at the institution and said, My son and grandson did those.

title: Budget. Fights Loom in Congress With Few New Initiatives Likely
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11  When the 96th Congress convenes at noon on Jan. 15, it probably will face a considerably lighter agenda . than its predecessor, which was asked to pass on everything from Panama Canal treaties to tax cuts, from naturalgas price increases to reforms in the Federal bureaucracy.

title: Should Broadcasters Be Freed From Federal Controls?
description: Tkink of television and radio without regulation, with as much freedom on the airwaves as print media enjoy. Imagine the broadcast media governed only by market forces, like, the books and magazines on candystore racks, with no statutory obligation to provide cultural, informational, educational, religious or publicservice fare.

title: SOMOZA SEEKS VOTE ON FOES
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 11 President Anastasio Somoza Debayle called last night for a nationwide plebiscite to test the electoral strength of his foes, but the proposal was immediately rejected by the opposition because it did not contemplate the besieged ruler's early resignation.

title: The Bell Finally Tolls (Figuratively) for St. Paul's
description: The bell that is rung when St. Paul's defeats Poly Prep has been silent for 27 years. Yesterday, amidst the bedlam resulting from St. Paul's 90 victory over the Blue Devils in the second oldest schoolboy rivalry in the nation, the bell was still silent.

title: Passaic Valley Wins Battle of Unbeatens
description: Passaic Valley ran its record to 70 and gained a berth in the North Jersey, Section One Group Four state tournament with a 3112 victory over previously undefeated Hackensack yesterday in Ilackensack.

title: The Latest Thing in Design Is. . . the Tent

title: Poetry:Of Strikes and Stan
description: John Peck's work is distinguished by its impressive intelligence, as his first book, Shagbark, demonstrated. Mr. Peck's new volume, part of the third series of Godine Poetry Chapbooks, again combines that intelligence with qualities almost as rare.

title: Farmingdale Defense Is Perfect
description: Farmingdale, one of the few Long Island schools that was operating before suburban sprawl set in, turned in its first unscoredupon regular season yesterday when it defeated Hicksville, 280, in a Nassau, Conference IDivision A game at Hicksville.

title: To Our Readers
description: Since the end of the newspaper strike last week, delivery of The Times has been delayed in some areas. The lateness was caused by production startup problems and an unusually large volume of news and advertising. Production and delivery are improving daily, and normal service is expected soon. The Times regrets the inconvenience to its readers.

description: HONG KONG (Reuters)  Authorities in this bustling shoppers paradise are investigating the growth of fraud in the selling of garments and other popular consumer items.

title: U.S. World War I Dead Honored Across France
description: Every Memorial Day, villagers from surrounding towns visit Belleau, 50 miles west of Paris, to join local citizens in laying a wreath in the cemetery there. None of the graves are French. Belleau is the site of the AisneMarne American Cemetery and Memorial, one of six American World War I cemeteries on French soil, all of them on land granted by France to the United States in perpetuity, free of rent and taxes.

title: ANTIQUES
description: SILVER played an important role in Colonial American life. In addition to its visual and decorative appeal, the ownership of tankards, teapots, porringers and flatware conveyed a tangible message about the owner's social rank within the community. In the days before banks, it also made sense to keep one's wealth in the form of silver plate, which was functional and more readily identifiable if it was lost or stolen.

title: CITY'S VOTE DECLINE PERIL TO INFLUENCE
description: The voter turnout in New York City last Tuesday  despite Governor Carey's calls for a heavy city vote .continued decline that threatens to reduce the city's representation and influence in state affairs.

title: Environmentalists Registered Both Gains and Reverses in Elections
description: Environmental activists chalked up noteworthy gains, but reverses, as well, in the national elections this week.

title: IN BRIEF
description: In spite of record corn and soybean crops in 1978, the Agriculture Department warned consumers not to expect lower food costs in the coming year. The Department predicted that 6.89 billion bushels of corn and 1.81 billion bushels of soybeans would be harvested, but also stuck to an earlier forecast of a 7 to 10 percent hike in food costs for 1979. ... Consumer borrowing expanded $3.28 billion in September, according to the Federal Reserve Board. That was quicker than August's pace, but the Board noted that in the third quarter its measure of consumer credit slowed to 16 percent from 20 percent in the second quarter.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE story of Rolf Baumgartner, the chefpartner of Brasserie Swiss, is similar to some you've heard before, but it is worth retelling, for it describes the genesis of many of the fine restaurants in this country.

title: A 50Year Affair With Orchids
description: AFEW dozen years ago, Rodney Jones and his wife visited Cairo in search of orchids and were startled to find a blackgarbed woman following them. She rushed them into a taxicab, sent them back to their hotel and warned them to stay there until morning. Later that night, King Farouk fell from power.

title: Police Officer Arrested After Shooting Incident
description: A New York City police officer was suspended after being arrested yesterday in Nassau County for shooting at a station wagon that had reportedly forced his small car onto. a shoulder eastbound on the Long Island Expressway. No one was injured by the bullet, which struck the rear window and lodged in the rear of the station wagon.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Last summer, the American Dance Festival completed its first season at Duke University, in Durham, N.C. After 30 years at Connecticut College in New London, this move to a new setting was closely watched in the dance world. How did it go? All indications point to a smashing success. The evidence was everywhere and since Festival spokesmen liked to speak publicly of their marriage with Durham, is only appropriate to single out something old and something new to symbolize the honeymoon. The new was the extraordinary reception by local citizens. One image particularly stands out in this writer's mind thinking back on the festival's sixweek season. That was the time a man introduced himself to Charles Reinhart, the Festival's president. The man identified himself as assistant basketball coach at Duke. Congratulations, he said, the Festival is outstanding. We go all the time.

title: Gap Between South's Rich and Poor Is Found Same as 25 Years Ago
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 11  Despite the economic boom and growing industrialization in the South, the gap between rich and poor remains almost exactly the same as it was 25 years ago, and the number of people living below the poverty line declined only marginally in the first half of this decade.

title: Deep Government Disunity Alarms Many U.S. Leaders
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11  The United States is becoming increasingly difficult to govern because of a fragmented, inefficient system of authority and procedures that has developed over the last decade and now appears to be gaining strength and impact, according to political leaders, scholars and public interest groups across the country.

title: Ivery Runs to Record 356 Yards
description: AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo., Nov. 11 (UPI)  Eddie Lee Ivery set a National Collegiate singlegame rushing record of 356 yards and scored three touchdowns today as he led Georgia Tech to a 4221 victory over Air. Force in bitterly cold Rocky Mountain weather.

title: Investment Banker Breaks New Ground With Beauty Salon and MiniShopping Center in Locust Valley

title: Army Tops B.C. By 2926
description: WEST POINT, N.Y. Nov. 11  After rallying from a 247 thirdquarter deficit to take the lead, Army's football team kept a crowd of 28,099 in Michie Stadium on the edge of their seats down to the final gun today as the Cadets salvaged a 2926 triumph.

title: Homosexual Issue Persists at Seminary

Its General Assembly de- dared, at its annual meeting in San Diego last May, that to ordain self-affirmiPg homosexual persons would be an act in contradiction to the church's charter and calling.

title: Other Ideas &
description: When diabetes pills came on the market about 20 years ago, many diabetics, freed from the tyranny of the daily insulin shot, felt liberated. Their euphoria lasted only a decade or so. Then researchers began to suspect that the pills might be less effective, and less safe, than had been thought. The most persuasive evidence came from a nineyear study sponsored by the National Institutes of Health and completed in 1970. The antidiabetic drug tolbutamide, the study found, increases the risk of fatal heart attacks. Many scientists believed  and still believe  that the study was flawed, but the Arneric,an Medical Association supported it and estimated that oral diabetes drugs caused 10,000 to 15,000 premature deaths a year. Now the Food and Drug Administration has reviewed the evidence. Its auditors said they had found errors in the study but none important enough to invalidate the conclusion. Cardiovascular mortality, the agency said, was higher in patients treated with tolbutamide.

title: ANTIQUES
description: WHEN this country was settled, pewter in large amounts garnished the cupboards of only the well-to-do. For most families, whose ordinary tableware was made of wood, a single piece of pewter represented prized possession to be handed down from generation to generation. To col- lectors of antiques today, American pewter has assumed the same if not greater importance. To hand over pewter collection now is to bequeath shares in one of the steadiest rising antiques investment markets.

title: Last Week's Israeli Municipal Elections Hinted at Change

Since the results often depended on local issues and local personalities, divining much national significance from them is a chancy business.

title: Marshall Tucker Rock Group At the Madison Sauare Garden
description: Overnight sensations are no longer common in rock. Individuals and groups do sometimes manage to shoot out of nowhere into sudden national prominence, but, for the most part, today's successful rock performers tend to be seasoned professionals who rose gradually to their eminence. The Marshall Tucker Band, a sextet from Spartanburg, S.C., that headlined at Madison Square Garden Thursday night, is a case in point. The group has been recording for Capricorn since 1973 and has been slowly building its following through steady album sales and an occasional hit single. Now that following is large enough to fill the Garden.

title: Other World Events
description: Italy's terrorist organizations are like plants  the more you snip away at them, the faster they seem to grow. Despite Government claims that the movement has been broken by a mass roundup of suspects and weapons this fall, attacks against persons and property (there have been 2,000 this year) show no sign of abating. The latest victims were a provincial prosecutor, Fedele Calvosa, his driver and his bodyguard, who were machinegunned to death last week on a country road south of. Rome. One attacker was wounded in the ambush and later killed by his compatriots, apparently to prevent him from giving information to the police.

In the early 60's, he and Elizabeth Whittington, his wife at the time, established Poseidon Records totally without grants or other outsideckupport, initially to produce tapes of his own music that would not otherwise be publicly available. title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Global man. What is Peter Mayer going to do now? The question was one that publishing folk asked each other frequently last summer, after the head of Pocket lit toks parted ways with Richard E. Snyder, head of Simon & Schuster, Pocket 's pa rent company, citing differences of opinion as to what the future of book publishing was likely to be. The question was all the more tantalizing because Mr. Mayer is generally considered one of the most colorful, dynamic and innovative men in the business. In 13 years he built up Avon Books from a midget to a giant massmarket house; in the past two years he brought new vigor to the ailing veteran, Pocket Books. lie accomplished this by paying attention to reprints and originals that sold millions of copies as well as to imprints (Avon's Discus and Bard, Pocket's Archway and Quokka) of new and old classics selling only hunof thousands of copies.

title: The No. 2 Cabinet,Minister Was Forced Out Last Week

Editorials in antigovernment newspapers pointed with pride the roles played by a courageous judge and a resourceful press in penetrating a coverup that appeared to have reached into the highest offices in the land. When Prime Minister P. W. Botha reacted to the disclosures by tiring the judge and menacing the press, the parallels with Richard Nixon's Washington seemed complete.

The monkeys have the sandwiches on toast, if you don't mind, cut into cageconvenient morsels adapted from the cocktail parties of human evolution.
