But they are deeply worried about the economic consequences of those initiatives for the cities and for the poor people who live in them.

title: DEFENSE HIERARCHY PUZZLED ON BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  Despite President Carter's pledge last week in sharply increase the defense budget, military and civilian officials in the defense hierarchy are puzzled and uncertain about the size of the new arms budget. about the scope of the programs sought by the Pentagon and about the Administration's commitment to boost arms spending in Europe.

title: Associated Press
description: HOORAY FOR  Searchlights and laser beams crisscrossing across the night sky at the dedication of the new sign Mount Lee above Hollywood, Calif. The sign, which replaced one built in 1923, cost about $27,000 a letter.

title: TV SPORTS
description: 8:00 (11)Coliege football:

title: Cleveland Caught in Long Decline
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 7  The best location in the nation was the way the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company characterized this big industrial city in 1944. So promising did the city's future seem that the slogan was picked up by the city's leaders and became its unof???

title: Hungary Readjusts Forint
description: BUDAPEST, Nov. 11 (AP)  Hungary has devalued its currency, the forint, in comparison with six Western European currencies and has revalued it upward by 5 percent against the United States dollar, the Hungarian press agency, MTI, reported. The currencies of West Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg and Austria went up 6 percent in relation to the torint Friday, while the Swiss franc went up 8 percent.

title: Easing Set On Fares By I.A.T.A.
description: GENEVA, Nov. 12  The International Air Transport Association has decided to roll with the punches of the United States Civil Aeronautics Board's anticartel stance and the ratecutting that has followed it. The group is planning to allow its member airlines to remain within its fold even though they may drop out of the organization's farefixine machinery.

title: End SouEht to Winter Navigation Program on Upper Great Lakes
description: LANSING, Mich., Nov. 12  Following the course set last summer by Gov. Hugh Carey of New York, the 100,000member Michigan United Conservation Club has officially asked the Army Corps of Engineers to end the Winter Navigation Demonstration Program on the upper Great Lakes this year, saying that environmental impact studies are inadenn.rp.

title: Holzman the Taskmaster Is Back and Knicks Know It
description: Red Holzman sat on the edge of his chair. He crouched on one knee. He jumped up after almost every Knick score. He continually pointed and reminded his players to get back quickly on defense.

title: Israeli Teachers Strike Over Pay
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 12 (Reuters) Highschool teachers throughout Israel went on strike today in support of demands for higher salaries, leaving some 300,000 pupils idle. The teachers want 10 percent more than the salary increases granted to other public workers 15 percent with an additional 7 percent in fringe benefits.

title: Tanzania's Offensive Halted, Uganda Says, With Crocodiles A id
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Nov. 12 (UPI)  Uganda said today that its troops had repulsed Tanzania's counteroffensive of yesterday and that many Tanzanian soldiers were eaten by crocodiles in a river dividing the two armies. But a Tanzanian military communiqu said the fighting was still raging tonight in the 700squaremile salient that Uganda forces had secured since their invasion two weeks ago.

title: Leasing of Coal Areas Is Called a Giveaway Despite U.S. Reforms
description: Despite several years of supposed reforms and a new emphasis on increased coal production, Federal and state coal leasing on public lands in the West is still a giveaway. of public resources, according to a research organization report published yesterday.

title: Clark Defeat in Iowa Laid to Abortion Issue
description: DES MOINES, Nov. 12  Much has been made of the impact that dedicated singleissue blocs could have this year at the polls, especially when apathy was obviously in fashion among the majority of potential voters.

title: United Goes Ahead With Offer
description: The United Technologies Corporation, which Friday won a favorable riling from the New York Attorney General's office on its proposed tender offer for the Carrier Corporation, announced yesterday that it would begin its offer today.

title: Boxing: Giachetti A HardKnocks Man
description: They didn't tell Richie Giachetti until the postfight victory party that his uncle Johnny, the one who had stood up for him at his Confirmation, the one who had taught him the left jab, had died only a few hours before Larry Holmes knocked out Alfredo Evangelista.

title: Esther Woodcut Theft Reported From Laguna Beach Art Galler'y
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Nov. 12 (UPI)  An $18,000 woodcut by the Dutch artist M.C. Escher was reported stolen yesterday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: KNOWLEDGE HOURS To listen is to learn, and two lecture series are drawing attentive crowds in midtown and in the downtown business area. Today's program, starting at 12:30 P.M. at the New York Public Library's Donnell Center, is the fourth of six free weekly lectures by investment experts, coordinated by Eliot H. Sharp, former publisher of Investment Dealers Digest. This is a further expansion in the lecture field for the center, whose sideline activities include a wide variety of talks, concerts, film screenings (with film makers) and theater readings. The library is at 20 West 53d Street, opposite the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Action on Dollar: Economic, Not Political
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  On Nov. 1 the United States took its most important monetary action of the last half dozen years. In the process, President Carter for the first time gave more weight to the views of his economic advisers than to the opinions of his political counselors.

title: California Supreme Court Believed to Have Delayed Ruling to Aid Chief Justice's Election
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12  Apprehension has grown, among insiders in politics and the law, that the respected California Supreme Court has delayed issuance of a controversial opinion in order to enhance Chief Justice Rose E. Bird's rhanrpg of retaining her nnsitinn.

title: Soviet Is Said to Schedule Trial For an Armenian Rights Leadei
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 12 (Reuters)  The leader of a dissident humanrights group in Soviet Armenia, Robert Nazaryan, will go on trial on Wednesday, Andrei D. Sakharnv cam trvinv.

title: 3 MEDIATORS LEAVE MANAGUA FOR HOME
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 12  Thf United Statesled mediation team that is trying to negotiate a peaceful solution tt Nicaragua's political crisis flew home today for urgent consultations following Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle's formal rejection of opposition demands that In resign as President.

title: Cuomo Pledges to Resign Without Important Role
description: Lieut. Gov.elect Mario M. Cuomo is determined that Governor Carey will keep at least one of his campaign promises: the pledge to make Mr. Cuomo an imnortant nart of his administration.

title: B. Dalton to Open a Flagship Bookstore
description: When the B. Dalton chain opens a flagship bookstore on Fifth Avenue tomorrow, joining the Waldenbooks store that opened last month on lower Broadway, the supermarket concept of selling books will be newly underlined in Manhattan. New York, capital of publishing in the Umtea states, can now stake out a claim as capital ot book selling, too.

title: SOVIET CAUTIONS U.S. ON PACT WITH CHINA
description: LONDON, Nov. 12 A senior Soviet official has said that an alliance between the United States and China could destroy detente between Moscow and the West.

title: TV: Specials on Food, Arms Suppliers
description: STASHED away behind public television's glut of old movies and imports, the documentary pot appears to be simmering once again. Two worthy examples are at hand: one a threehour survey of world food supplies and distribution, the other an investigation into an American connection in illegal shipments of arms to South Africa.

title: Deaths
description: TAKERGladys. Past away in New London, Conn. on November 10, len. She was from Fishers Island, N.Y. Born July 1. 1897 in New London, Com.,dauohter of Henry and Ella, Stearns. She is survived by two sons, James H. of Madison. N.J. and Richard S. Baker of Fishers Island; one brother. Raymond Stearns, Waterford, Conn. and 5 grandchildren.

title: Carter Adopts a Program to Bolster Civil Defense in a Nuclear Attack
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  President Carter has approved a new program for bolstering the nation's civil defense against nuclear attack, a move, Government officials said today, that was designed to protect as many as 190 million Americans in the event of a major war with the Soviet Union.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: The City
description: A young man who had asserted he was a member of the du Pont de Nemours chemicalmanufacturing family while running up unpaid restaurant bills, was found dead in his apartment at 207 East 52d Street Saturday evening. He had been tied, gagged and apparently beaten to death, according to the police.

title: Kivitt of Ballet Theater Joins Pennsylvania Ballet
description: The Pensylvania Ballet has announced that Ted Kivitt, formerly a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater has joined the company.

title: Dance: Greek Parthenon Group
description: PCTURESQUE and often vibrant, the Parthenon Dancers of Greece offered an unusual folk dance evening Saturday night at Carnegie Hall.

title: Southland Royalty In Shenandoah Pact
description: The Southland Royalty Compiny announced that it had agreed to buy certain producing oil and gas properties of the Shenandoah Oil Corporation situated in the Permian Basin of west Texas and southeast New Mexico for $126.1 million, subject to certain adjustments. The transaction will be effective Feb. 1, 1979, subject to approval of a plan of complete liquidation of Shenandoah at a meeting of stockholders on Nov. 13.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON MUCH of Washington is watching the legislati ve package that will accompany the wageprice guidelines and other antiinflation measures. It is to include the real wage insurance plan  designed to protect workers if inflation rises by more than 7 percent  and high Administration officials say the legislation is also almost certain to contain a proposal to revitalize the hospital cost containment legislation that died last year.

title: Spring Fashions: Inspired Diversity
description: Don't anyone complain that all clothes look alike. Not after the spring styles being shown on Seventh Avenue hit the stores in a few months. The choices run from sexy to starchy. For women who are tired of keeping their shapes under wraps, there is ample opportunity to show off legs, waistlines and virtually every other part of the anatomy with bcense from the best designers. For women who want to retain the ease and freedom of clothes of the past few years. there is also equal opportunity.

title: Derailment Causes Acid Spill
description: SHARON HILL, Pa., Nov. 12 (UPI) Five hundred families were evacuated after a train derailment caused a sulphuric acid spill late yesterday about 10 miles southwest of Philadelphia. Authorities said they believed vandals tampering with a track were responsible. There were no injuries and residents were permitted to return to their homes by dawn today, a civil defense spokesman said.

title: Israeli TV Broadcasts Military Plan It Says Covers Sinai Pullout
description: TELAVIV. Nov. 12  What were said to be details of a military accord for the Israeli withdrawal from Sinai that is to be part of the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty were broadcast tonight by Israeli television. The stateowneu SWUM'S military correspondent said the negotiators in Washington had fully agreed on a withdrawal plan but the accord could not be concluded because of a disagreenient on one matter.

title: London Bridge Inherits Money as Well as Fame
description: LONDON, Nov. 5 In its 970 years of recorded history, London Bridge has earned many claims to fame and affection.

title: Swann
description: A great novel should be able to survive any number of social changes. Even if the author has shown himself sympathetic to a character who seems morally flawed to our later vision, this should not affect our enjoyment of the book so long as the character is portrayed in depth. I was amused to discover on a recent rereading of Swann's Way that Proust's hero is a male chauvinist pig of the worst sort for whose misery I haven't the slightest sympathy. Yet my delight in his story was unimpaired.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Nearly every serious paddleball and racquetball player is looking for the perfect shoe. It should be as light as a feather, as tough as nails, goodlooking and comfortable. Keep the price down, and you have a winner. The makers of the new Howie Hammer shoe claim all the above. The polyurethane shoe has outstanding flex, is lightweight and is difficult to wear out. Suede leather reinforces z twill upper body, the high back gives extra support, and the insoles are cushioned. Who is Howie Hammer? He is a former United States paddleball champion, but the shoes are good for any kind of court, indoors or out. Under S25 at Paragon, Morsan and Caldor.

title: PAUL MALLOFF
description: Paul Mellott, treasurer of Walco National Corporation, a business conglomerate of 743 Fifth Avenue, and a financial adviser to Representative Frederick W. Richmond of Brooklyn for more than 30 years, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. Mr. Mellott, who lived at 1385 York Avenue, was 61 years old.

title: Soviet Cars Roll in Canada
description: TORONTO, Nov. 7  The Russians havdcome! The Russians have come! In their own cars! In their own cars!

title: World Airways Pact
description: World Airways has announced that It and Jetsave, a British transAtlantic travel company, have agreed to threeyear travel program valued at $60 million. The program, disclosed last week, centers on lowcost vacation flights between the United States and Britain starting April 1.

title: Islanders Hold Off Ranger Surge, 53
description: The Rangers and Islanders were at again last night in Madison Square Garden in the second of their eight scheduled National Hockey League confrontations this season. And at long last it seemed that the madeinNew York rivalry had achieved some of the parity the fans had been hoping for.

title: The Swedes: A Classy Act In Tandem
description: THE Swedes have been together for so long you'd think they were joined at the hip. Together in Sweden on the national team. Together in Winnipeg on the Jets. Together again in New York on the Rangers. They have worn the same uniform and been invited to the same parties, endorsed the same line of clothing and been rewarded by receiving the same wardrobe. They recently boueht homes in Scarsdale.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Avis Rent A Car System Inc., a subsidiary of Avis Inc., has appointed G. Scott Brodey as vice president and general sales manager, U.S. Rent A Car.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE Levitt's Next Position: At Lincoln Savings Bank
description: Arthur Levitt, the New York State Comptroller, will become chief financial adviser to the Lincoln Savings Bank of Brooklyn on Jan. 2. After 24 years as the state's fiscal watchdog, Mr. Levitt chose not to run again. Edward Regan, Erie County Executive, was elected last week to succeed Mr. Levitt as Comptroller.

title: RUSSELL C. TREIBER
description: Russell C. Treiber, president of the John Treiber Insurance Agency, which was founded by his father in 1899 in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, died Saturday in Brooklyn Hospital after brief illness. He was 65 years old.

title: Deaths
description: ROSENBERGMollie, Beloved wife of the hitt MIR:6 GeWred mie.' ai Pearl Inson and Bernard, dear sister of Minnie Sddeider, Fennie Price and David tioniseAccen. loving Or ardmetter end greetgrandrnottier. Ser:ices today. 1:15PM at The Colonial Chapels of I.J. Morris. Inc., 16 Greenwich St. Hempstead. L.I.

title: New York's Fiscal Crisis Is Not Over
description: Many New Yorkers may take the news of recent days as a part of the happy ending to the city's fiscal crisis they thought they celebrated last summer. The Emergency Financial Control Board, the state supervisor of city accounts, has approved a muchrevised financial plan for the next four budget years. Let all be warned: the Board's message is far from cheerful. Its action reflects only its belief that the city could be run on a balanced budget in the fiscal year that started July 1, and that there exists a reasonable chance of closing the huge budget gaps that loom beyond.

title: IRAN'S OIL WORKERS TOLD TO END STRIKE OR FACE DISCHARGE
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 12  The military Government formed by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi today ordered striking oil employees back to work and threatened to dismiss those who refused.

title: Piano: Maria Clodes
description: MARIA CLODES, who was heard in an unusually rewarding piano recital at Carnegie Recital Hall Saturday night, is a native of Brazil now on the faculty of Boston Universitu chp is a fnrrnidable technician with lots of temperament, and if her fondness for fluctuating tempos sometimes steers the music off course, it can also result in moments of wonderful fluidity and breadth.

title: Airline Dispute Strains U.S.Australia Relations
description: SYDNEY, Australia Nov. 12  The Australian Government has reacted bitterly to a threat from Washington to deny or curtail landing rights for Qantas, the Australian airline, if agreement in a dispute over air routes and fares is not reached this week. The yearold controversy over United States proposals to reduce fares to Australia and allow a second American airline to operate on the South Pacific route has strained relations on both sides.

title: R. S. Rothschild Jr. Weds Judith Crown
description: Judith Ellen Crown, daughter of Mrs. George Koch of Yonkers and the late Arthur Crown, was married in New Rochelle, N.Y., yesterday to Richard Sutro Rothschild Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rothschild of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi David Greenberg performed the ceremony at the Greentree Country Club.

title: Denison Stock Split
description: Denison Mines Ltd. announced that planned a 4for1 stock split. The company has 4.56 million shares outstanding that would become 18.27 million shares following the split. The split is subject to shareholder approval at the company's annual meeting early in 1979. The company also said it planned to pay quarterly dividends on the new shares beginning in March 1979 at 25 cents a share, which would be equal to $1 on the present shares. Denison has been paying 60 cents quarterly.

title: Interest on Checking: FarRanging Impact
description: For anyone with a checking account, banking is changing fast these days, and the changes are expected to have a ripple effect reaching into the very basics of American monetary policy.

title: Peak Seen for Rates
description: Longterm interest rates have peaked, Ronald Morse, manager of corporate bond trading at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, said late last week after assessing the performance of the credit markets in the wake of President Carter's Nov. 1 program to strengthen the dollar and fight inflation.

title: Taiwan Trade Surplus
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 11 (AP) Taiwan had a trade surplus of $1.46 billion for the first 10 months of 1978, more than double the yearearlier surplus of $572.5 million, the Directorate General of the Budget, Accounting and Statistics reported Friday. This year's exports through Oct. 31 totaled $10.25 billion, up 37.7 percent. and imports totaled $9.79 billion, up 27.9 percent.,

title: Koch Seeks Improved Racial Balance on Board
description: Race  in particular the present lack of a black or Puerto Rican on the Board of Estimate  should be a major consideration in picking an interim Borough President for the Bronx, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: Huge Drug Haul Is Taken in Raid At Jamaica Bay
description: A band of drug smugglers fled from small marina on the shore of Jamaica Bay late Saturday night, eluding by minutes the Coast Guard and an army of policemen and leaving behind 20 tons of marijuana, 10 million tablets of a powerful sedative and a halfeaten smorgasbord of cold cuts, macaroni salad and pickled pigs feet.

title: Opera: Pallo Conducts New Flute at City Opera
description: THE production of Mozart's The Magic Flute at the New York City Opera this fall consists of a resuscitation by Cynthia Auerbach of the direction that Julius Rudel had applied last fall to settings by Beni Montresor that date back earlier still. The result as seen Saturday afternoon was a perfunctory account of this wonderful masterpiece. was so plodding and unimaginative, and so lumpishly executed by nearly everyone involved, that time passed very slowly indeed  and this is on opera in which almost any production can captivate.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Concerto in F for Horn and Chamber Orchestra, Mercadante; Prelude No. 10 in B Minor, Rachmaninov; Concerto in E minor for Flute, Violin, Bassoon. and Continuo, Boismortler; Botticell Tryptich, excerpt. Respighi; Creatures of Prometheus, Overture, Beethoven; Polonaise in D No. 4, W.F. Bach; Aida, Grand March, Verdi.

title: ATLANTA MAN SEIZED IN ABDUCTION DEATH
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 12  A 19yearold Atlanta man was arrested and charged today with the kidnapping and murder of Michele Louise Stern, 18, of New York, freshman at Emory University here. Miss Stern was shot to death when she attempted to escape from two men who abducted and apparently raped her early vesterdair morning.

title: Montreal Mayor Wins a 7th Term
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 12Jean Drapeau, who has been mayor of Montreal for 21 of the last 24 years, easily defeated two opponents in municipal elections today to win his seventh term. The 62yearold mayor, Lanada'S most durable and popular politician, won more than 60 percent of the vote despite attacks by the press and by his two opponents, Serge Joyal and Guy Duquette, against his autocratic style and his emphasis on expensive prestige projects.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: WE return to the scene of Hopscotch. That scene, of course, is Paris, a Paris littered with Latin American intellectuals for whom culture is a kind of disease. Thus at any one time in A Manual for Manuel the characters.

title: Entertainment Events
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Blur:, Carmen, 8.

title: Bridge:
description: On this side of the Atlantic, the title of grandmaster, awarded by the World Bridge Federation for outstanding performance in international competition, has been a masculine monopoly. But last week the federation announced that this title, which represents the summit of tournament achievement, had been awarded to Mary Jane Farell of Los Angeles and Dorothy Hayden Truscott of New York.

title: Childless Couples Adopt In Mexico, Often Illegally
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 A California couple, with what the man later described as tears of joy, crossed the Mexican border into the United States Oct. 22, 1975, with an infant who was rinictsbnpd Cynthia Elizabeth.

title: Dolphins Beat Bills, 2524, And Gain in Playoff Bid
description: With Delvin Williams running for 144 yards, including touchdown jaunts of 25 and 26 yards, the Miami Dolphins downed the Buffalo Bills, 2524, yesterday at Orchard Park, N. Y,. and made their National Football League playoff prospects decidedly rosy.

title: Redskins Win
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  The Giants bounced back from two losses and lost again today. This time it was different. This time they played well, and it took a 45yard field goal by Mark Moseley after 8 minutes 32 seconds of overtime to give the firstplace Washington Redskins a 1613 victory.

title: Mrs. Meir Called Stable And in a Feisty Mood
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 12 (AP)  Former Prime Minister Golda Meir was in stable condition today, a spokesman at Hadassah Hospital said.. The 80yearsold Mrs. Meir was reported in feisty temperament and secretive about her ailment. She has been treated for two weeks for back problems and a virus, but the hospital spokesman refused to be more specific. He said the hospital asked her for permission to release details of her illness, but she replied, It's nobody's business.

title: Recital: Clamma Dale Presents Lieder
description: CLAMMA DALE is a most promising and appealing young soprano who called greater attention to herself than most young sopranos manage to do with her commanding Bess in the Houston Grand Opera nroduction of Porgy and Bess on Broadway in the fall of 1976. Since then she has continued to develop her career on the opera and recital stage. It's a career well worth developing, as her generally appealing lieder recital yesterday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall indicated. But  not to whine, since the point has been made before  she is by no means a great performer. Ordinarily one wouldn't care, but the Lincoln Center Great Performers series pretentiously sets up expectations for anyone booked under its aegis.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: The broken cloud pattern across much of the Far West signifies a decaying storm system now centered in the Rockies. Rain and wet snow are part of a storm system centered North Dakota. A streak of clouds across the East depicts the separation of cold air to nnrfh and mild air fn fha anidh

title: Stage: Alexis Smith Stars in Platinum, a Musical
description: P LATINUM is one less musical about show business. It takes an idea that is limp to the point of formlessness, pours it into an. illwritten book, decks it out with inferior rock music, stages it shoddily and performs it with a widespread lack of skill.

title: 4,688 Are Surveyed In Over 14 Counties
description: The New York Times's suburban survey was conducted from May 22 through June 19, 1978, in five waves of telephone interviews with 3,496 residents of 14 counties surrounding New York City. In addition, 1,192 others were interviewed in an exurban belt adjacent to these suburban counties in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey.

title: News Summary
description: Iran's striking oil workers were ordered back to work by the military Government, with the threat of dismissal for those who refused. The 35,000 workers demand wage increases, the release of all political prisoners and the expulsion of foreigners from the oil industry. The backtowork order came in the wake of bloody clashes between army troops and antiShah demonstrators in Ahwaz and Khorramshahr, cities in the heart of the oil region. A call for general strike from the Shah's opponents went largely unheeded in Teheran. [Page A1, Column 6.].

title: Penn State Homers Calm Over Success
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Nov. 12 There are college townsout of whim, Tuscaloosa, Ala., is one that comes to mind  that would verge on tumbling down today had their football teams achieved what Penn State University's team achieved here yesterday.

title: World News Briefs
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Nov. iz (AP)  More than 2,500 Vietnamese crammed aboard a freighter of mysterious origin that is anchored off the Malaysian coast will not be allowed to land because the Government considers them migrants who paid their way, rather than refugees, the police said today.

title: Commodities
description: If the futures market in precious metals seemed unusually disoriented last week, it was not just because gold prices had lost $4.80 ounce, basis the near December delivery, in a week interrupted by Election Day. Nor was because gold futures had plunges mom a record $249.50 on Oct. 31, the day before President Carter revealed his dollar rescue plan, to $210.20 last Friday.

title: Aspirin Instead Of Surgery
description: FOR the Knicks, the restoration of Red Holzman as the coach is merely temporary relief, an aspirin for an organization that needs surgery. But for now aspirin is important. The players need to relax. So do Sonny Werblin, Mike Burke and Eddie Donovan in the front office. And so does Willis Reed, the captain who never was comfortable as the coach.

title: The Case of Nguyen Ngoc Loan
description: Nguyen Ngoc Loan attained instant worldwide infamy in 1968 when a photograph was published showing him with his pistol at the head of a bound Vietcong suspect; at that moment, Gen. Loan squeezed the trigger. After the dissolution of South Vietnam, the former police chief and brigadier general was admitted to the United States and allowed to proceed toward American citizenship. He lives today in a Virginia suburb of Washington, D.C., where he manages a small restaurant.

title: C.I.A. Analyst Forced Out for Giving Senator Secret Data
description: A strategic analyst for the Central Intelligence Agency was forced to resign last summer after confessing that he had supplied copies of topsecret C.I.A. reports on strategic arms limitation talks to a key staff aide of Senator Henry M. Jackson, a leading Senate critic of the current arms negotiations, Administra???

title: Eagles Victors
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12  The Eagles were too tall and the Jets were too small today.

title: 5 Demonstrators Held in Protest On Nuclear Reactor at Seabrook
description: SEABROOK, N.H., Nov. 12 (UPI) The police yesterday arrested five antinuclear demonstrators who climbed a fence around a pier to protest the arrival of an atomic reactor for the $2.3 billion Seabrook nuclear power plant.

title: President Visits Farm For Religious Retreat
description: ROYAL OAK, Md.. Nov. 12 (AP) President and Mrs. Carter attended a religious retreat today at the Maryland farm of former Senator and Mrs. Harold Hughes.

title: Layoffs Looming in Jersey Austerity Drive
description: TRENTON, Nov. 12  Tomorrow or the next day, depending on how fast the mail moves, hundreds of Newark's municipal employees are expected to get notices that they are in danger of losing their jobs..

title: Violin: Nina Beilina Gives Her Second Recital at Y
description: WHEN Nina Beilina made her New York debut last January at the 92d Street Young Men'sYoung Women's Hebrew Association, word went out quickly that a major violinist was in our midst. Virtually unknown here before emigrating to the United States two years ago, Miss Beilina has had a distinguished career in her native Russia and doubtlessly it will not be too long before she is equally famous in this country.

title: Notes on People
description: Making her first foreign pilgrimage since her defeat 20 months ago in India's general election, the former Prime Minister, Indira Gandhi, yesterday dodged crowds of chanting Indian demonstrators outside London's Heathrow Airport. Some of the demonstrators voiced support. Others shouted fascist dictator.

title: 8 Held in Death of Italian Youth
description: MONZA, Italy, Nov. 12 (Reuters) Eight persons have been,:letained in connection with the kidnapping and killing of a 16yearold youth whose remains were found in a burnedout car here two days ago, according to the police. The youth was abducted on Thursday.

title: De Gustibus
description: In all food lore there is, to one food historian's mind, no single subject as all embracing in its vastness and interest than the various forms of pasta. Pasta, of course, takes into account an almost endless array of shapes and names  spaghetti (the most basic and bestknown worldwide), macaroni, ermicelli, linguine, lasagne, fettucine and so on, ad infinitum.

title: At lunchtime, a lot of people don't feel right until they hit their favorite joint.
description: Any lunch hour, head for the nearest park. Chances are, you'll see some people who don't keep off the grass. their steady customers.

title: The Region
description: HAKISVALL., N.Y.  the Greenburgh police said yesterday that they were investigating whether the nuts were deliberately removed from a set of temporary bleachers that collapsed during a football game between Woodlawn and Eastchester High Schools Saturday afternoon. The police said 27 of the 300 fans were taken to four Westchester County hospitals, most of them having suffered broken ankles. One Eastchester High fan apparently suffered a heart attack.

title: Bunker Cuts Price
description: The price of lead settled at 38 cents pound as one of the major primary producers, the Bunker Hill Company, cut its price from 39 to 38 cents yesterday. Bunker Hill had tried to push the price to 39 cents, but other major producers, such as the St. Joe Lead Company and the Amax Lead and Zinc Company, raised prices by only one cent, to 38 cents a pound.

title: Philharmonia Plays All Wagner
description: LUKAS FOSS and the Brooklyn Philharmonia opened their major 197879 subscription series over the weekend with an allWagner concert at the Academy of Music. The program included the Siegfried 14.10 the Wesendonck Lieder, and excerpts from Tannhauser,Die Walkiire  and Tristan and Isolde. This added up to a potent dose, and it was potently administered.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON NOV. 14 (UP) internal documents of asbestos companies indicate that the industry may have tried to hide the health dangers of asbestos exposure from the 1930's onward, it was reported today.

title: ACCORD IS REPORTED ON WEST BANK LINK
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  Working into the early morning hours, Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel were reported today to have reached tentative agreement on a new linkage formula to end the deadlock in the EgyptianIsraeli peacetreaty negotiations.

title: Quebec Regime Pushes Nationalist Aim With Voters
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 8  The Quebec Government has begun a fullscale campaign to persuade the province's Frenchspeaking majority that it has nothing to lose in a future referendum if it votes to approve a proposal to make Quebec sovereign. The first indications are that the Government may succeed.

title: U.S. Envoy in Iran Viewed as Tough and Forceful in Dealing With Shah
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 12  In the American Embassy here the spiral staircase that winds up to the ambassador's secondfloor office is lined with framed photographs of the Shah, who posed smilingly with every American President from Franklin D. Roosevelt to Jimmy Carter  conspicuous symbols of nearly four decades of close United StatesIranian ties that have survived every challenge so far.

title: CORRECTION
description: A photograph published in the Times on July 17 incorrectly identified Mario Trevino as a member of a group called the Brown Berets marching down a street in Plainview, Tex. Mr. Trevino was not in the photograph and is not a member of the Brown Berets.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: During the long period when The Times went unpublished, it seemed that the character of public opinion suffered a decline. Perhaps we have not adequately recognized how this whole nation depends upon the intellectual stimulus that is furnished by New York's leading newspaper.

title: Racing: Seattle Slew Horse of the Year?
description: As the frontrunner cruised toward the finish line all by himself, the track announcer's voice rose to a theatrical flourish.

title: New Law Restricts Bankers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  President Carter has quietly signed legislation that prohibits many of the banking practices that forced Bert Lance out of office last year. Mr. Lance was Mr. Carter's first Director of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: Necessities In Steepest Price Rises
description: Prices of the four basic necessities of life  food, fuel, housing and medical care are rising twice as fast as inflation in other goods and services, according to figures just issued by the Exploratory Project for Economic Alternatives, a Washington research group.

title: A Fickle Davin Fall
description: For 7yearold Anthony Morgan, autumn translated painfully into fall  fall as in tumble. His rented roller skates scooted out from under him, and Anthony made more of an impression on Central Park than he had intended.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 11 (UPI)  John McEnroe, 19 years old, upset Bjorn Borg, the threetime Wimbledon champion, 63, 64, and will meet another American, Tim Gullikson, in tomorrow's final of the $190,000 Stockholm open Grand Prix tennis tournament.

title: Outdoors: Pressure on the Bluefish
description: WITHOUT the bluefish, the Northeast's lighttackle saltwater sport fishing industry would collapse overnight, and the harvesting of this highly prized and hardfighting food and game fish continues to increase at a rate that is subjecting it to mounting pressure.

title: Secret Officers Aid Effort to End Police Corruption
description: A secret group of police officers and detectives, whose members serve voluntarily and without reward or recognition, has emerged as an important weapon in the New York City Police Department's efforts to fight corruption in its ranks.

title: Late Returns

title: Stargell Is Injured Slightly While Target Shooting
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 12 (UP1)Willie Stargell, the Pittsburgh Pirates first baseman, sustained a slight leg wound today when a pistol discharged accidentally while he was target shooting. a team spokesman said.

title: Saccharin: To Take It or Leave It?
description: Remember last year how saccharin boosters tried to laugh off that Canadian study in which rats, fed large doses of the sweetener, developed cancer? human would have to drink 800 cans of diet soda a day to take in that much saccharin, they scoffed  surely no basis for banning a substance that allows weightconscious Americans to satisfy their craving for sweets without adding calories.

description: Left unattended for about 10 minutes, 17monthold boy was burned to death and his 3yearold sister was felled by smoke yesterday afternoon in a Brooklyn apartment fire apparently touched off by the children playing with matches while their mother was out at a grocery store, the police renorted.

title: Oiler Rally Catches Patriots, 2623
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Nov. 12  The New England Patriots march through the National Football League that began seven glorious Sundays ago came to a sudden end today at Schaeffer Stadium. The home team. which had assumed a 230 lead with ridiculous ease in the first 27 minutes of the contest, wound up losing by 2623 to the Houston Oilers, a tough outfit that has now won four of its last five games.

title: DM Holdings Offer

The tender offer is scheduled to expire on Nov. 13 unless extended. The McKee Corporation is a provider of engineering and construction services to the basic industries. The Davy Corporation is a diversified engineering and construction concern.

title: Nancy

Understandably, the sunflower is the state symbol. Yet many Kansans feel that they live in shadowed obscurity because Kansas is dim in the national consciousness.

Will the Dow keep falling, possibly as low as 750, as some analysts predict? Or, as still other analysts say, should one expect a smart turnabout and clean recovery to 850 or even 900?

title: Screen: 'Killer of Sheep' Is Shown at the Whitney:Nonprofessional Cast
description: "KILLER OF SHEEP," which opens today at the Whitney Museum, is a film to make one mindful of the difference between genuinely abstract art and iciness for its own sake. The program notes say that Charles Burnett, the director, thinks the idea of the film "is to try to recreate a situation without reducing life to a simple plot," but his film has just enough of a story to make it taxing.The action, which of course is hardly supposed to be action at all, revolves around a black man whose only measure of prosperity is the fact that he's well enough off to give things to the Salvation Army. He is remote and depressed. His wife is bored and sexually frustrated, and she's depressed, too.He has two children, whom we see eating breakfast and scratching and walking around the neighborhood. He has a lot of young and reasonably attractive male friends who live with grotesquely bloated women; sometimes the men get together and fix cars, or worry. The central character works in a slaughterhouse, hence the none-too-apt title.To all this monotony and alienation Mr. Burnett brings an estrangement of his own. The film consists of loosely linked glimpses of the characters' lives, punctuated by occasional cuts to the slaughterhouse. It is acted by non-professionals, who call attention to the falseness of many of the situations. It is beautifully photographed in black and white, and very spare.The dialogue, which is read with either insufficient or excessive emphasis by the nonactors, is often buried under a soundtrack of vintage blues, making it doubly hard to follow. Even the slaughter of the sheep is numbingly uneventful.That may be Mr. Burnett's very point, but he makes it so studiedly that the character's estrangement from his surroundings overlaps too conveniently with the director's arty detachment from his material.And for all its air of starkness, "Killer of Sheep" is more often arid than it is genuinely economical. Mr. Burnett obviously has a keen eye for tiny moments  the way a child pulls up a sock, the way a man's hands move on machinery  but he doesn't demonstrate the kind of coherence that might give them larger meaning.

title: Hirsh, Fredell Lack Give Concert
description: THE VIOLINIST Fredell Lack and the pianist Albert Hirsh, artists of long experience who now teach at the University of Houston, were heard in recital Sunday night at the 92d Street Young Men'sYoung Women's Hebrew Association. Both are sensitive, highly skilled musicians with fine collaborative instincts, and the main pleasure of their performances was the music itself.

He phoned the major midtown hotels, but without success. Finally, through the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, he was able to book his friends into a highrise chain motel in Saddle River, N.J.
