Purcell said today.

title: Todd or Robinson: That Is the Question (for, Jets); Regular Quarterback's Return from Collarbone Injury Creates Problem for Coach Michaels Against Patriots; Robinson Looks Back; A Coach's Perspective; A Quarterback Problem
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 13  Acting like an intruder, Richard Todd sheepishly took his hair brush from his locker after practice today, careful not to disturb Matt Robinson, who has the adjacent cubicle, and silently disappeared from the Jets camp.

title: Many Foreclosed Buildings Are Again in Arrears
description: Of 127 residential buildings seized by New York City for nonpayment of taxes and sold at public auction during the first four months of this year, 91.3 percent are now in tax arrears, Councilman Stanley E. Michels said yesterday.

title: BRAZILIAN CHANGES FACING TEST IN VOTE
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 13  The political changes approved by the Brazilian military Government and accepted by Congress face an important test this week.

title: Frenchman Dies in Paris Blast
description: PARIS, Nov. 13 (Reuters)  An explosion wrecked two floors of an apartment house here today, killing one man and injuring two people. The cause of the explosion in the fivestory building in southern Paris was not immediately known. It looks like gas, but we can't be certain, fire chief told reporters.

title: Deaths
description: MILLET  Carmen, Widow of Dr. John A. P. Millet, late of Nyack N.Y. on Saturday November 11, 1978. Survived by her son DeForest Manice and grandson Alexis Coster Manice. Funeral private.

title: Special Interests Gaining Power As Voter Disillusionment Grows
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. I3 Since President Carter's inauguration almost two years ago, hundreds of new special interest groups have set up shop here, established political action committees and applied pressure on the Government for multitude of causes, private and public.

title: Labor's View: Future Is Dim
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13  Like heavyweight fighter who has been staggered by a combination of sharp blows, organized labor is now preparing to cover up and hang on until it regains its strength.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: YOU'D never know it from the way the stock market is pricing earnings these days, but the new tax laws promise to have a significant impact on corporate profits and, by extension, on the rewards investors hope to reap.

title: Carter's Son Chip and Wife Are Separated
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13  The White House announced today that President Carter's son, James Earl Carter 3d, who is known as Chip, and his wife, Caron, have separated after five years of marriage.

title: TV: The Word Raises Questions
description: CBS's THE WORD, which this evening at 9 reaches the third of four consecutive nightly installments, provides still another representative example of how the concept of small series is being developed generally on the networks. While Brit. ain, where the form is commonplace, pays some attention to Leo Tolstoy or Robert Graves or Thomas Hardy or Henry James, CBS gives us Irving Wallace. Coming up soon, on another network, is Harold Robbins.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Your Nov. 7 news article describing the sad state of sanitation in New York City (and the city's apparent inability to cope with the problem) offers an insight as to why many citizens believe that New York's survival is very much in doubt, despite protestations to the contrary by our elected officials.

title: Advertising
description: EARLY next year, Mariah Outside, a magazine for lovers of the great outdoors, will make its debut containing the most popular features of two formerly separate publications. And, gradually over the course of year or so, as the magazine follows its sixtimesayear frequency, the Mariah portion of its name will fade from sight and the magazine will become simply Outside.

title: DiCarlo Top Duryea Heir
description: Dominick L. Mario, a conservative Bay Ridge Republican, emerged yesterday as the apparent heir to the Assembly minority'leader's post being vacated by Perry B. Duryea.

title: United Press International
description: CAVALIER EFFORT: Terry Furlow driving to basket Sunday night, In Cleveland's losing effort to Portland, 9891.

title: GOING OUT Gulde
description: WEE BIT O SCOTCH An hour or so of songs from Scotland plus some traditional native dances is tonight's free entertainment at the Yorkville branch of the Manhattan Savings Bank, 86th Street and Third Avenue, starting at S. Such a concert will naturally include ballads with lyrics by Robert Burns. But the soprano Aileen Hamilton will concentrate on unfamiliar songs of the Gaelicspeaking people of the Inner and Outer Hebridean Islands. Much of the music was saved from oblivion by the song collectors, Marjorie KennedyFraser and Dr. Kenneth McCloud. Rounding out the program will be the Mary Stewart Highland Dancers of Kearney, NJ.. accompanied by John Nisbet. Dicer.

title: Begin, Back in Israel, Schedules a Cabinet Debate on Treaty Impasse
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 13 Prime Minister Menachem Begin returned today from New York and said the Israeli Cabinet would consider various proposals to revive the peace talks with Egypt.

title: Mr. Carter's Fallout Biscuits
description: The cry of civil defense is about to be heard in the land again. President Carter has been persuaded bamboozled may be the better word  to throw $2 billion into a Federal program to plan the speedy evacuation of 140 million Americans from large cities in case of nuclear attack. His real concern, of course, is not for the defense of the population against the Russians but the defense of an arms control treaty against the Senate. Still, the idea does not augur well for the President's style of argument in that coming debate.

title: Schaefer Lenders Agree To Defer Loan Payments
description: The F. & M. Schaefer Corporation, obtaining relief from finanicia1 pressures, said yesterday that Its lenders had agreed to defer $29 million in interest and payments until the mid1980's on the concern's longterm debt.

title: Chemical Company Researcher Dies in a Plunge at 39th Street
description: A 40yearold research analyst for the Allied Chemical Company jumped or tell to his death yesterday from the roof of a 40story building at Broadway and 39th Street. the police said.

title: Associated Press
description: AMIN BRIEFS UGANDA FLYERS: Photograph from an Uganda newspaper is described as showing President Idi Amin, at center, rear, briefing pilots who led a bombing raid over Tanzania. No date was given for raid.

title: PROPOSED U.S. RULES REQUIRE DISCLOSURE OF USEDCAR FAULTS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13  The staff of the Federal Trade Commission proposed today that usedcar dealers be required to disclose defects in their vehicles and state plainly what warranty protection would be provided.

title: Theater: Marriage
description: GOGOL'S Marriage is comic dream that continually threatens to become a comic nightmare.

title: Deaths
description: R I VLI N  F AY. Survived by hvo daughters Jeanne Shapiro. Harriet Rlvlin and son Martin It !Ain and 7 grandchildren. Services today 1:15pm. Boulevard Perk West Chapels, 150W. 79th St. N.Y.C.

title: BELLA GROSS
description: Bella Gross, a member of The New York Times staff for nearly 30 years, died Sunday at Montefiore Hospital after brief illness. She was 62 years old.

title: Nebraska, First to Be Picked, Goes to Orange Bowl
description: Nebraska became yesterday the first team assured of a berth in one of the four major football bowl games when the Orange Bowl Selection Committee announced that the Cornhuskers would be the host team even if they lost their final regularseason game to Missouri this Saturday.

title: Poll of Suburbanites Shows a Growing Sense of a Separate World
description: Joseph and Selma Shill moved to Ardsley, a Westchester suburb, from Jackson Heights in Queens 11 years ago. Mr. Shill s a project engineer at. Columbia University's Nevis Laboratories in Irvington, which is only four miles from his home.

title: Wounded Soldier Dies in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 13 (Reuters)  A 19yearold British soldier, wounded when a boobytrap exploded days before he was due to leave Northern Ireland, died in a hospital during the night. Pvt. Gareth Wheddon, Royal Marine commando, who was injured while on patrol last Thursday, had undergone surgery for head wounds. His regiment was due to leave Northern Ireland this week.

title: The New Volt Times/Chester Higgins Jr.
description: LOOKING FOR A HANDOUT, two pigeons approached a benchsitter having lunch at Central Park yesterday in brisk overcast weather and were looked on with some misgivings.

title: Suspensions Directed For Seven Policemen For SickLeave Abuse
description: Seven New York City police officers will be suspended without pay for 10 to 30 days as part of the Police Department's new crackdown on chronic sickleave abuses.

title: New Times Square Waiting in the Wings
description: If all goes as planned, the cars and buses that now rush down Broadway between 45th and 48th Streets, blaring horns and spewing exhaust, will be replaced by a pedestrian mall with trees, walkways and outdoor dining.

title: Market Place
description: DURING the worst days of the October bear market  particularly on Tuesday, Oct. 31 it was obvious that the stock market was perilousiv close to an oldfashioned panic.

title: IN THE NATION
description: MAPUTO, Mozambique  A strong but disheartening impression emerges from brief visits to the three most involved of the five frontline states that have been working for independence and black majority rule in Zimbabwe, now known as Rhodesia.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: jazz: Mangelsdorff
description: ALBERT MANGELSDORFF. West German trombonist, has been an important contributor to European jazz since the early 1950's. For most of the 60's he was probably the most advanced jazz trombonist in the world, and although several younger Americans have now matched or surpassed his ability to get around on the horn and to use the aspects of the entire jazz trombone tradition in his improvisations, Mr. Mandelsdorff continues to break new ground.

title: Margaret Livingston Pelz, 33, University Teaching Assistant
description: Margaret Livingston Pelz, a teaching assistant at the University of Washington and former resident of New York City. died Saturday night as the result of an automobile accident near Granite Falls, Wash. Miss Pelz, a passenger in the car, was 33 years old.

title: McEnroe Wins Stockholm Final
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 13 (UPI) John McEnroe won the $175,000 Stockholm Grand Prix tennis tournament today by beating a fellow American, Tim GuIliksoil, 62, 62, in a onesided final. The winner, who left the amateur ranks less than five months ago, received $15,000.

title: TV: Dyan Cannon Plays Madam in NBC Movie
description: AS long as they think I'm that kind of woman, I'll be that kind of woman, Dyan Cannon exclaims about twothirds of the way through Lady of the House, a madefortelevision film that will be shown from 9 to 11 tonight on Channel 4.

title: The Dollar Battle  and the War
description: If the President has his way  and most economists think he will  the yearlong decline of the dollar in foreign currency markets should be checked, at least for now. Mr. Carter's decision to intervene directly on the dollar's behalf, backed up by sharp increases in interest rates, should counter the psychology that has lowered the dollar's purchasing power abroad by an average of 16 percent. That is good news for inflation fighters: every 10 percent dip in the dollar overseas translates into DA percent more inflation at home.

title: White Emigration From Rhodesia Is Rising Sharply
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 10  The rate of white emigration from this country a factor that may prove more decigive than military victories or international pressures in forcing a resolution to the long Rhodesian drama  is rising steadily and sharply.

title: Bowery Is Adding Equitable, Stays Top Savings Bank in City
description: The Bowery Savings Bank and the Equitable Federal Savings and Loan Association of New York yesterday announced a definitive agreement to merge, thus cementing Bowery's position as the largest savings bank in the city.

title: About New York
description: It was quiet on the set over in Astoria, Queens, yesterday in the cavernous old movie studio where, 50 years ago, the Marx Brothers romped through Animal Crackers and Gloria Swanson preened her way through film after film as part of her lifelong love affair with this city.

title: Drug Smugglers Escaped Because of Raiders Error
description: While a searaiding party of eight coastguardsmen in two small cutters made Saturday night's $25 million drug haul at a Queens pier, their backup units of United States customs agents, counted on to cut off any escape of smugglers by land, spent two hours procuring weapons and cars and searching for the pier in Brooklyn.

title: Deaths
description: COHEN  Isidore Beloved husband of Elsie, devoted father of Mildred and Chet Davidson and Bill and Mimi Cohen. adored grandfather of Karen, Laurie. Beverly, Eric and Barry. Services BoulevardPark West, 115 W 79 St, Tuesday at 2PM.

title: Soviet Five Tops Purdue For 6th Victory in 7 Games
description: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 13 (AP)  Vladimir Tkachenko, the Soviet Union's 7toot 4inch center, scored 19 points tonight in a 6561 exhibition basketball victory over Purdue University.

title: L.A.T.A. Approves TwoTier Structure
description: GENEVA, Nov. 13  Members of the International Air Transport Association approved today a compromise proposal under which they would be allowed to drop out of the group's faresetting machinery while continuing to participate in the technical work of the association.

title: John Cappelletti's Rebirth
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13  In his Heisman Trophy speech five years ago, John Cappelletti talked about his little brother Joey, who had leukemia. After his brother had died, a TV movie was produced. Its title was Something for Joey, andback East, where John Cappelletti had played for Penn State, people remembered that he was with the Los Angeles Rams now. But he was just another dependable running back in the National Football League, just another good football player. Run, catch passes, block. He did ever/thine well, but nothing spectacularly. John Cap. pelletti rushed for 696 yards two seasons ago and 596 last season, but he was always running in Lawrence McCutcheon's shadow. Lawrence McCutcheon, with John Cappelletti blocking for him, rushed for more tnan Low yarns in each of the last two seasons. But last night, in a nationally televised primetime game, John Cappelletti broke loose for 106 yards, including a 26yard burst that positioned the Rams winning touchdown in a 107 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers, leaving both teams with the best wonlost records, 92, this season.

title: 7 IN COAST SKID ROW KILLED IN 3 WEEKS
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13 (UPI) Someone who, the police say, takes pleasure in killing has stabbed seven Skid Row residents to death since Oct. 23.

title: Dividends
description: X.4 for 1 solitectIsci to sfrtidrs =ravel, record and oar dotes marrorced.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Wrather Corporation, owner and operator of the Disneyland Hotel, announced yesterday that it planned to purchase in the open market or from institutional investors up to 450,000 shares of the Teleprompter Corporation, operator of cable television systems.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Infants SickleCell Test
description: Researchers at the University of California in San Francisco have developed a safe, rapid test for sickle cell anemia in unborn infants.

title: Japan Imports Up (in Dollars)
description: TOKYO, Nov. 13 (AP) '014; Japan's licensed imports in October, on a dollar basis, rose more than 15 percent from the yearearlier level vThile, nn n eon basis, they fell more than 17 percent, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry announced today. The yen has increased in value against the dollar by more than 30 percent in the last 12 months, so it takes fewer yen now to buy imported goods that are oriced in dollars.

title: Mohawk to Close Truck Tire Plant
description: AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 13  The 75 yearold Mohawk Rubber Company of Akron has announced that it will close its truck tire plant on Thanksgiving, eliminating 318 jobs and making it the third rubber company to halt tire operations here this year.

title: New Views Into the Body Aid Diagnosis
description: MINUTES after the patient rises from a table, having sustained no more than a brief intravenous injection, a motion picture of a cross section of his beating heart appears on a video screen.

title: High Court Bars Suit Against A.T. & T. Centrex
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13  The Supreme Court today let stand the dismissal of a private antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and 23 Bell System companies by more than 1,000 large customers.

title: S.E.C. Sees Lie On Becton Sale
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, in a surprise move, charged in open court here yesterday that a senior official of Salomon Brothers, the investment banking house, had lied to the Sun Company, its client, to induce tne oil company to buy a huge chunk of Becton, Dickinson & Company, the medical supply company.

title: Corporate Earnings Are Reported for the Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange.(A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Topics
description: Officially, you can say I'm out,' said Richard Nixon at the start of his current trip through the South. Consider those simple words I'm out. They imply that he  no less than his jailed lieutenants  has bravely and silently endured a heavy sentence. It has been spent at San Clemente, not exactly a prison, but still he has been in.

title: Purchased Mortgages Up in Yield
description: The average weighted yield of mortgages accepted under the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation's weekly purchase program rose to 10.21 percent yesterday from 10.13 percent last week and from 10.02 percent the week before that, the Governmentsponsored agency reported. The rate was the highest since it began weekly purchases in May 1977.

title: Gunfire and Rocks Hit Trucks in Steel Haulers Strike in the Midwest
description: Independent steel haulers are trying to chase the giant steelcarrying rigs from MiddleWestern highways in the latest clash in a 10year battle with the teamsters union.

title: Nazarius Takes Jumpoff At Toronto Horse Show
description: TORONTO, Nov. 13 Bob Ridland of the United States Equestrian Team rode Nazarius to victory over 26 rivals tonight in the international open jumper class at the Royal Winter Fair horse show.

title: The New York Times/ Fred R. Cotirad
description: The Roosevelt Island aerial tramway over the East River closed for two weeks yesterday to allow replacement of its seventon, steel hauling cable, pulling in the gangplank to Manhattan for nearly 5,000 residents and guaranteeing that over the river and through the air will not be a usable route for Thanksgiving visitors to or from the island.

title: CARTER POLICY TEST SEEN IN UNION TALKS
description: The'first major test of President Carter's inflation policy is at hand in bargaining between the oil industry and the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers.

title: New Oil Find in Mexico
description: CANCUN, Mexico, Nov. 13 (UPI)  A new petroleum field that Mexican officials said contained more than 100 billion barrels of crude oil has been found in the Tampico area off the Gulf of Mexico, the director of Petroleos Mexicanos, Jorge Diaz Serrano, reported over the weekend.

title: DelBello Plans To Reduce Tax In Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 13Alfred B. Del Bello, Westchester's County Executive, proposed today a 1979 county budget of $419 million, an increase of $15.4 million over thecurrent year, but with a reduction in the property tax.

title: The City
description: A proposed truthinmenu bill, aimed at preventing restaurateurs from making inaccurate statements on their menus, was the subject of a hearing before the City Council's Consumer Affairs Committee under the direction of Councilwoman Carol Greitzer, the author of the proposal. Bruce Ratner, the Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, spoke in favor of the bill, which would make it illegal for a restaurant owner to misrepresent the quality, quantity or place of origin of food served.

title: Trade Gap Reduction Seen in 1979
description: Forecasts of a dramatic reduction in the United States trade deficit by mid1979 were voiced by Government and business leaders at the opening in New York yesterday of the 65th National Foreign Trade Convention.

title: 50 Stations To Present Edward VII
description: CBSTV, which once held the United States rights to a British television series on the life of Edward VII of England, now may wish it had aired the program during the last two years, when it had the rights, instead of relinquishing the privilege to the Mobil Oil Corporation.

title: Money
description: MONDAY, NOV. 13, 1978

title: Chrysler Lobby Focus of Dispute
description: YOU can make a beautiful thing more beautiful is how Josephine Sokolski, an interior designer, defends her plan for redoing the lobby of the Chrysler Building.

title: Three on School Bus Killed
description: BENTON, Mo., Nov. 13 (UPI)  A gravel truck crashed into the rear of school bus stopped on a sloping curve in fog today, killing three students and injuring 20 others. The coroner, Gene Nunnelee, identified the dead students as Billy Nall, 9 years old; Brian Milam, 15, and his cousin, Rodney Milam, also 15.

title: China Seeking To Join Tennis Federation
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 13 (AP)  China has formally applied for membership in the International Tennis Federation.

title: Rockland Expects Tax Rise
description: NEW CITY. N.Y., Nov. 13  Budget heartngs are to resume here tomorrow on a proposed $132,459,029 Rockland County budget, which calls for the first increase in three years in county property taxes.

title: United Press International
description: Officials in Gettysburg recount ballots In House seat race that ended in.

title: London Times Faces Long Shutdown
description: LONDON, Nov. 13 The Times of London and The Sunday Times face a possibly protracted suspension of publication in less than three weeks as a result of complicated labor dispute.

title: WALTER TYRIE STEVENS JR.
description: Walter Tyrie Stevens Jr., founder and director of the Stevens Institute in Mexico City, died there last Saturday after an asthma attack. He was 61 years old.

title: In a Recession, Erosion of Jobs Feared for City
description: After a year of small increases, the creation of jobs in the private sector has virtually stopped in New York City, and economists voiced fear yesterday of a return to job erosion here similar to but perhaps not as severe as that which accompanied previous national economic slowdowns.

title: City Emigrants Adapt to Westchester Life
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y.  If Patrick Turner had not lost his job as a city plannet during New York City's fiscal crisis three years ago, he and his wife, Lowrie, would probably have never moved to Westchester County.

title: XRay on Universe Launched
description: An American spacecraft carrying the largest Xray telescope ever built was launched into Earth orbit yesterday to study some of the most intriguing phenomena of the universe pulsars, quasars, exploding galaxies and black holes in space.

title: H. W. Barclay, Business Writer
description: Hartley Wade Barclay, a manufacturing consultant and former business writer for The New York Times, died yesterday at his home in the Rye, N.Y. He was 73 years old.

title: LEFKOWITZ SEEKING ESPOSITO'S REMOVAL
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has moved to relieve Meade H. Esposito of his Brooklyn Democratic leadership because of his alleged involvement with race track, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: United Press International
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 13 (AP)  The Oakland Raiders, flirting with their worst season in 12 years, got off to a shaky start against the struggling Cincinnati Bengals tonight, then righted themselves, took advantage of seven Bengal turnovers and posted a 3421 victory.

title: Democrats Put Together Finely Tuned Delegation
description: New York State Democrats yesterday selected 13 delegatesatlarge to the party's national midterm convention in Memphis next month to complete a state delegation marked by its adherence to quotas of women, young people and minorities.

title: Prime Rate Set at 11% By 3 Banks
description: The First National Bank of Chicago, the nation's ninthlargest bank, raised its prime rate yesterday to II percent from 10% percent as the banking industry began to feel the pinch of Washington's latest efforts to strengthen the dollar and fight inflation.

title: Drunks of Times Square Giving Area a Hangover
description: Just when plan, to revitalize Times Square are progressing, the number of drunks wandering around thd area appears to be growing.

title: Notes on People
description: Today may be trauma time for Prince Charles of Britain. The heir to his mother's throne turns 30, and to ease the passage the Prince last night attended the gala premiere of a new production of Meyerbeer's L'Africaine, performed at the Royal Opera House in London for the first time in 110 years. The American soprano Grace Bumbry starred in the title role. Next to polo, the opera is one of the Prince's favorite pastimes, a spokesman for Miss Bumbry said yesterday in New York, and so at midnight, after the performance, the singer was to present Charles with her personal rare copy of the score of L'Africaine.

title: EARNINGS Unilever Quarter Net Up 24.8% as Sales Climb 9%
description: Unilever, the international manufacturer of foods, detergents and toiletries, reported yesterday a 24.8 percent increase in thirdquarter profits on a sales gain of 9 percent. of the sales rise, about 6 percent reflected increased volume, the report said.

title: News Summary
description: Iranian oil production rose. The military Government made major gains toward halting the twoweek strike in the oilfields that has been a key weapon of the Shah's opponents, with most workers returning when threats were carried out to dismiss strikers and arrest their leaders if the walkout continued. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Alouettes, Three Others Remain In C.F.L. Playoffs
description: The Montreal Alouettes will play the Ottawa Rough Riders, and the Calgary Stampeders will meet the Edmonton Eskimos next weekend in the Canadian Football League playoffs to determine the two teams that will play in the Grey Cup final on Nov. 26.

title: Shah Is a Beneficent Father Figure to Iran's Military
description: TEHERAN, Iran. Nov. 13  Since the military Government of Gen. Gholain Riza Azhari came to power on Nov. 6. the Imperial Army of Iran has left little doubt that it has taken over the country, and it is displaying this with unmistakable strength.

title: Horses Provide Clues To V.D. in Humans
description: CAMBRIDGE. England  British scientists have found evidence of a possible link between a bacterium that caused recent outbreaks of venereal disease in thoroughbred horses and cases of venereal disease in humans.

title: Deaths
description: STEINBACH  Doctor A. Alan The Executive Board of the JYVB Jewish Book Council mourns the passing on November 12. In Hollywood Florida of our illustrious & most beloved Past president Dr. A. Alan Steinbath, who devoted years to the dissemination of the Jewish Boot. Our deepest sympathy to the members of the bereaved family.

title: The Lady on the Pedestal
description: Times change, wounds heal and yesterday's torments become history. The world was not remade bythe militant students of the 1960's and the greening of America proved not to be an eternal spring.

title: U.N. Council Tells South Africa It Faces Sanctions Over Namibia
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 13 With the United States and four other Western countries abstaining, the Security Council voted today to warn South Africa that it faced sanctions unless agreed to elections in SouthWest Africa supervised by the United Nations.

title: Events
description: KILLER OF SHEEP, by Charles Burnett; starring Henry G. Sanders, Kawee Moore, Charles Bracv, and Angela Burnett. Shown daily et the Whitney Musetim of American Art, 12, 2, and 1, with additional shows Tuesday at 6:25 and 8.

title: Iranian Press Aide Says Reporters Were Bribed
description: A defecting Iranian press official charged yesterday that American and British reporters had been paid substantial sums to write articles favorable to the Shah, and that the Iranian Ambassador to the United States, Ardeshir Zahedi, might have been aware of it.

title: U.S. Also Sues to Bar Bid For Carrier Corporation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13  The Justice Department went to court today to stop the United Technologies Corporation of Hartford from acquiring a con trolling interest in the shares of Carrier Corporation of Syracuse.

title: Palestinians Offer Lebanese Right Amity If It Will Cut Links to Israel
description: BEIRUT, Nov. 13  The Palestinian guerrillas, fearing a major confrontation with Israel if a projected peace treaty is signed by Egypt and Israel and wanting to insure that their rear is protected, have offered to end their conflict with Lebanese Christians on condition that they terminate their cooperation with the Israelis.

title: Books: New York Guide Traces Jewish Settlement
description: THE history of New York's Jewish community began in 1654, and it is a story that in many ways reflects the shifting tides of adversity that periodically shook Europe over the centuries, and it also mirrors the development of the city and the country. One of New York's most ancient surviving manmade relics, perhaps its oldest, is the little patch that is the Jewish cemetery on St. James Place, on Chinatown's southern border. It was begun by the small group of 27 Jews who landed in New Amsterdam from Brazil and are the ancestors, so to speak, of the almost two million Jews that populate the city and the neighboring counties of Westchester. Nassau and Suffolk.

title: King Lost as Giants Aim at a Big Eagle
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 13  Things can get worse for the Giants. In fact, they did today.

title: Doomsday Debate: How Near Is the End?
description: THE doomsday question When and how will the human race die out?  has assumed new perspective as scientific knowledge has advanced in several areas.

title: In Thailand, Refugees Horror and Misery
description: Reports from newcomers are truly distressing. With their little crops destroyed by poison gas, they leave their villages with no food provisions. For weeks they hide in mountain jungles avoiding Vietnamese and Pathet Lao patrols. They eat roots and leaves.

title: U.S. Steel Plans Major Investment
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 13 Indicating that the United States Steel Corporation is loosening its tight hold on the purse strings for investments in new steel facilities, Robert W. Smith, the vice president and manager of the company's eastern steel division, has announced that the company is moving ahead with plans to build a continuous caster at its plant in Lorain, Ohio.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Up a Bit Abroad; Gold Prices Show Rises
description: 188.48 on Friday. The Canadian dollar cost 85.33 United States cents, a bit less than its Friday rate of 85.36, and the British pound traded at $1.9720 compared with $1.9666 on Friday.

title: F.B.I. Hunts Firebomber Of U.N. Official's Auto
description: The firebombing of a United Nations official's car outside his Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., home last week remained under investigation yesterday by local police detectives and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, but no new leads were reported.

title: Are They Serious? Happily, Some Designers Aren't
description: Not all the clothes that are being offered for spring are full of high seriousness. There's still plenty of room for frivolity, which is how should be. When dressing becomes a grim business, it is time to turn uniforms.

title: Young Rothschilds: Bigger Role
description: PARIS, Nov. 13  The younger French Rothschilds are trying to bolster their family's fortunes and retrieve its reputation for financial wizardry, both of which now seem threatened by poor investments made by their fathers.

title: Williams Plans Major Evaluation Of Human Resources Programs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI)  Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. said this weekend that he was planning a major evaluation of 900 Federal programs overseen by the Senate Human Resourses Committee.

title: Oil Use in West Level Since 73
description: GENEVA, Nov. 13 (UPI)  Industrial nations succeeded in avoiding any increase in petroleum consumption from the time of the 1973 oil crisis to the end of 1977, it was reported today.

title: Bridge:
description: Until last, week New York had five grandmasters, oneeighth of the world's total supply: B. Jay Becker, George Rapee, Howard Schenken and Sam Stayman, members of a team that dominated the world scene a quarter of a century ago, and Ira Rubin, a 1976 world champion.

title: Quebec Draws Ambitious Plans as Bid for Asbestos Continues
description: QUEBEC  A new company owned by the provincial government of Quebec is drawing up ambitious future plans as talks continue on the government's plans to take over the giant Asbestos Corporation, which is controlled by United States interests.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Stock Exchange has appointed E.L. Alvey, 36 years old, as vice president, Membership Services Division.

title: Mrs. Meir Develops an Infection
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 13 (AP)  Former Prime Minister Golda Meir developed an internal infection today and is running temperature of 100 degrees, a spokesman for Jerusalem's Hadassah Hospital said. Mrs. Meir, who is 80, has been in and out of the hospital for the last two months with back trouble.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: Natioral Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UN

title: World News Briefs
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Nov, 13 (Reuters)  A United Nations refugee official spent two hours today trying to persuade the Malaysian government to allow ashore the 2.500 Vietnamese who have been cramped for five days aboard a freighter.

title: Israeli Minister Proposes New Town in Gaza Strip
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 13  Minister of Agricultural Ariel Sharon said tonight that he proposed building a new Israeli town at the southern end of the Gaza Strip as buffer between Sinai and the 450,000 Arabs in the Strip.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Decline
description: Yields declined on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and 182day maturities. average bill was 8.593 percent, down from 9.028 percent for the preceding week. The average rate for the sixmonth bill was 9.291 percent, down from 9.919 percent from the week earlier.

title: BUSINESS
description: The stock market plunged anew in light trading as investors grew more anxious over the sustained upward march of interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average toppled 15.08 points and closed at 792.01  decisively below the 800 barrier. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 20.96 million shares. [Page D1.]

title: Alaska Gas Pipeline May Need U.S. Aid
description: Harnessing Alaska's great gas reserves to ease the energy pinch is shaping up as a tougher undertaking than bringing down Alaskan oil  so tough that the nation's taxpayers may be called on to help out.

title: Science Watch: Microbe Weaponry
description: APREVIOUSLY unknown weapon used by some bacteria is teaching scientists something new about the ageold war between man and microbe.Many of the germs that live on and in the human body get along peacefully with their unwitting landlords; indeed. some bacteria are vital to the human who harbors them. But the whole history of infectious disease testifies that some microbes that infect man are not so accomodating.

title: Adams Warns On Rail Rates
description: Secretary of Transportation Brock Adams yesterday warned a group of top railroad executives and union leaders to modify a proposed 8.3 percent freightrate rise and to prepare for regulatory changes in the industry.

title: COMMODITIES
description: A late spurt of buying yesterday in the gold and silver futures market confirmed an earler firm trend traceable to stronger London bullion prices. Based on the second bullion fixing in London, gold advanced $1.85 an ounce to $208.10 on the day.

title: SHIPPING/MAILS
description: AMERICAN ARROW (U.S. Lines). Hamburg Nov. 30 and Rotterdam Dec. 2; sails from Howland Hook, Staten Island.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Nocturne in C minor, Chopin; Lemminkainen's Homeward Journey, Sibelius: Gold and Silver Waltz, Lehar ; Adieu mes amours, Cornish: Chinese Galop, J. Strauss Sr.; Etude No. 3, Chopin; Trio for 2 Horns and Bassoon, excerpt, Reicha.

title: Three Jazz Guitarists Bridge the Generation Gap
description: THREE generations of jazz guitarists appeared together on Sunday at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th Street at Fifth Avenue, as part of the third season of the Heavenly Jazz series there.

title: Frontiers: Space
description: ASTEROIDS used to appeal to poets more than scientists. An asteroid was the home of the young hero in Antoine de SaintExupery's charming fable The Little Prince. There the prince lived and cared for a single, beautiful flower. And when he set out for Earth, he used other asteroids of different sizes, shapes and colors as steppingstones of discovery.

title: New War Against Truancy
description: The New York City Board of Education is revising its attendance regulations and procedures, emphasizing the carrot over the stick in an attempt to deal with a growing truancy problem.

title: Aides to President Warn Officials Of Cutbacks in Programs Growth.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  President Carter's inner circle of advisers has gone on the offensive to convey the hard news to the Federal bureaucracy and major Democratic Party constituencies that Mr. Carter's commitment to a tighter 1980 budget will mean not only delaying new programs but also cutting back on existing ones.

title: Debrett's: A Touch Of Brass
description: LONDON FROM 1768 until two years ago, Debrett's Peerage Ltd. was just what its name said, a company that recorded the lineages of Britain's titled families. Its occasional publishing excursions beyond that addressed such questions as what to call a countess who is also one's employer (Your Ladyship).

title: PENTAGON INCLUDES TWO NEW MISSILES IN ITS 1979 BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14The Defense Department has approved a plan for developing two new intercontinental missiles as part of a $2.2 billion supplemental budget request that would go to Congress for approval next January, Government officials said today.

title: Jersey Will Sue Scouts for Policy On the Disabled
description: TRENTON, Nov. 14The New Jersey Public Advocate's office said today that would sue the Boy Scouts of America because the organization discriminated against handicapped youngsters.

title: The New York Times/Tyrone Dukes
description: Thirteen months after a visit by President Carter to the South Bronx that touched off an ambitious plan to rebuild it, there is little visible change in that deeply troubled area.

title: Dividends
description: IRREGULAR

title: For the Holidays, Real
description: To poultryman Sam Kramer, the sounds of hens cackling, ducks quacking and pigeons cooing, is sheer musical poetry

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Could it be that a majnr obstacle to stopping inflation is a widely accepted assumption: Everybody wants inflation to be controlled, including the members of labor unions? (Another nonhelpful verse from the President's news conference in Kansas City.) For I have the feeling that if this were so inflation would in fact be stopped.

title: Jury Is Studying City Aides Role In Driver Strike
description: A Federal grand jury is investigating charges that Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin and Moms Tarshis, the director of the Bureau of Franchises, tried to revoke the franchise of an airport limousine company as a favor to a teamsters local that was striking the concern.

title: Technology
description: CAMBRIDGE, MASS. DOWNSIZING of automobiles may cause a consumer rebellion by the early 1980's. Downsizing is the process by which Detroit is shrinking and lightening its cars to comply with a 1985 Federal goal of 27.5 miles a gallon. The specter ofwidespread sales resistance was the unneripng theme at a conference held here last month on technology, Government regulation and the automotive industry. Participants in the symposium based their gloomy conjecture on the fact that consumers are largely unaware of what the car of the future will look like.

title: Thomas Leishman, 77, Lectured On the Bible in U.S. and Abroad
description: Thomas L. Leishman, a retired lecturer in the United States and abroad on the Bible and a writer on religious subjects, died Sunday in a nursing home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 77 years old and was a resident of Heritage Village in Southbury, Conn.

title: Ullman Critical Of Carter's Plan For Insuring Pay
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  Representative Al Ullman, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, expressed farreaching criticism today of the Administration's proposal for real wage insurance, a plan that is integral to President Carter's campaign against inflation.

title: Fauchon Reopens To Gourmets Relief
description: PARIS, Nov. 14 Following a devastating bombing last December which virtually closed down this gastronomic shrine and deprived certain disconsolate Parisians of their daily foie gras, Fauchon has now risen from the nibble  more opulent, luxurious and mouthwatering than before.

title: Deaths
description: FITZGERALDHugh B.,D.C. on Nov 13, 1978. Beloved husband of Bernice (nee Siegel). Devoted father of Irene M. Accanando. Dear Son of Ethel & I the late Hugh A. FitzGerald. Brother of Evelyn Burke, Avis Casey & Joan O'Hara. Also survived by 2 grandchildren. Reposing; at the Macken Mortuary, 52 Clinton Ave, Rockville Ctr, LI. Mass of the Ressurection St. Agnes Cathedral, Thurs. Nov 16 at 10am. Interment Pinelawn PAernor. lel Park Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI. Family will receive friends 23 & 7. 9pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Arthritis Foundation preferred.

title: Reject BusShelter Pact, 6 on Council Urge Board
description: Charging that bus shelters posed threat of visual pollution and that community landuse rights had been usurped, six City Council members from Manhattan urged the Board of Estimate to oppose a contract scheduled for review by the board tomorrow.

title: U.S. Brief Suggests Wilmington 10 Were Denied Due Process in Trial
description: In an unusual legal move that Federal officials said might be without precedent, the Justice Department filed a court brief yesterday supporting a defense contention that the civil rights activists known as the Wilmington 10 might have been denied due process of law and, thus, a fair trial.

title: EARNINGS
description: The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday a 36.3 percent jump in thirdquarter earnings, to $135.1 million from $99.4 million in the like three months last year.

title: The New York Times/Larry Morris
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Nov. 14  Bernard King, on a personal crusade against the Philadelphia 76ers tonight, inspired the New Jersey Nets to a 124108 victory over the Atlantic Division leaders.

title: The Valves of Inflation
description: I believe there are three areas that we should focus on in grappling with the problem of inflation today.

title: chess:
description: BUENOS AIRES  In the 10th round of the World Chess Olympiad, which ended here recently with Hungary as the top team, James Tarjan scored with a positional queen sacrifice over Amador Rodriguez in the UnitedStates Cuba match.

title: Best Byus
description: WHEN it comes to food prices, consumers are unquestionably fighting a losing battle. Take turkeys.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Iran: Islam's Rumblings
description: At the height of Algeria's anticolonial struggle, the Algerians and the French fought a symbolic battle over the veil: The French, posing as progressives, wanted to unveil Algerian women; the Algerians saw in the veil and in Islam a way of resisting the colonizer. The veil, we are now told, recently reappeared on Iranian campuses, not so much as a sign of Islamic piety but an act of defiance against the Shah's Government and its perceived Westernism.

title: Turkeys to Go (And Pts Too)
description: If preparing the entire Thanksgiving meal suddenly seems a little more than you bargained for a few months ago when you invited guests to dinner, you will be pleased to know relief is in sight. A number of food shops around town will prepare various elements of that traditional meal, so that you may do only those courses you feel up to  or do none at all and simply purchase the whole meal readymade. Because of the holiday rush it is wise to place orders well in advance. In most cases, orders must be picked up on the Wednesday before Thanksgiving.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Chanel Inc., the perfume and cosmetics manufacturer, has announced that its chairman, Alain Wertheimer, will assume the additional title of president, upon the departure of Robert Kamerschen to Norton Simon Inc., as reported yesterday.

title: Notes on People
description: A Long Island sculptor's loving memorial to Albert Einstein has been commissioned by the National Academy of Science for display on the lawn of the academy, at Constitution Avenue and 22d Street in Washington. Robert Berks, who lives and works in the Suffolk County town of Orient, said yesterday that his statue of the giant of ??? century science has been a labor of love that I have worked on off and on since 1954.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows the past week (Monday, Nov. 6, to Sunday. Nov, 12), listed according to their rank in the ratings complied by the A.G. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Mead Corporation, manufacturer of printing and construction materials, announced yesterday that it had withdrawn its appeal of the ruling by the Ohio Division of Securities on the Occidental Petroleum Corporation's tender offer for Mead.

title: Economic Scene
description: A simplistic definition of inflation is too much money chasing too few goods. And monetary purists contend that the only way to stop inflation is to hold the growth of the money supply to rate consistent with the growth of the potential of the economy to produce real goods and services, or about 3 percent a year.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LONDON, Nov. 19 (UPI)  Eddie Dibbs, Sandy Mayer and Brian Gottfried scored straightset victories today and eighthseeded Roscoe Tanner had to scramble for victory to join his compatriots in the second round of a $175,000 tennis championship at Wembley arena.

title: Lessons of a Bush War
description: Idi Amin's cruel and barbaric acts sometimes re flect the twisted logic of a desperate man one step ahead of the posse. Such was prc:lmbly the case with the socalled bu.,,h war that he initatlx1 by occupying i0squaremile salient in the remote and lightly populated northeast corner of Tanzania. There is a strong possibility that he sent some 3,000 troops across the border not to repel an attack by Tanzania or by Ugandan exiles, as he claimed, but rather to pursue Ugandan troops who had mutinied or fled one of Mr. Amin's frequent tribal pogroms. The Field Marshal's latest diversion is not likely to blossom into a serious threat Tanzania's territorial integrity. Repeated purges have left his army with perhaps the worst officer corps in the world and the Ugandan forces would run out of gas they attempted to go much farther.

title: United Press International; Lord Boothby, whose views have created much controversy In Britain; Was Sir Winston Cruel? Britons Battle by Letter; 'saved Britain From Defeat
description: LONDON, Nov. 14  Like many other countries, Britain is short of heroes at the moment.

title: M.A.C. to Raise New Bond Offer; Move Helps City
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation, buoyed by an upgrading of its bond rating by Moody's Investors Service, decided yesterday to increase its new public offering of bonds by $125 million, an action that may deter New York City's longawaited plan to otter its own notes next month.

title: Advertising
description: REMEMBER that rumor last August that John J. Morrissey would be leaving Ford? That was true.

title: Indiana Standard Drops Kennecott Purchase Plan
description: A complex plan for the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) to buy the Kennecott Copper Corporation for close to $1 billion and to then sell Kennecott's interest in the Carborundum Company to the Continental Group have collapsed, industry sources said yesterday.

title: Asbestos Levels In 2 Schools Top Those in Streets
description: The level of asbestos found in the air at two Harlem schools is higher than normal levels in the streets, but lower than in areas where asbestos has been linked to cancer and respiratory disease, according to tests released yesterday.

title: The Many Faces of the Suburban Life
description: Bob and Sue Pitiger have moved three times in the last five years, but the moving van did not have far to go each time.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP)  The Federal Communications Commission approved today a $235 million rate reduction for telephone calls from the United States to foreign countries.

title: BARTEL W. ANTELL
description: Bartel W. Ante11, retired chairman of the management consultant concern of Antell, Wright & Nagel, died Monday of complications from pneumonia at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 71 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Pentagon Says Even Vast Effort By Soviet Can't Stop New Missile
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  The Pentagon's research chief, William Perry, said today that the United States's cruise missile will be able to penetrate Soviet air defenses even if the Russians spend. as much as $50 billion to defend against the weapon.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: U.S. URGES INTEREST ON ASSETS IT FROZE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  The Treasury said today that banks and other financial institutions should be required to begin paying interest on frozen foreign assets, including Chinese accounts seized in 1950 after Peking intervened in the Korean war.

title: The City
description: The New York City Council approved unanimously yesterday a resolution setting up a Public Utility Review Board to study the spiraling cost electricity and the feasability of forming a publicly owned power utility.

title: KEY WITNESS TELLS OF MURDER FOR HIRE
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 14  Charles David McCrary, the state's star witness in the trial of T. Cullen Davis, a Texas oil industrialist, told jurors today that Mr. Davis hired him to arrange for the murder of his estranged wife, Priscilla, his younger brother, two judges and witnesses who testified against him in an earlier trial.

title: Stage: Henry Street Offers Anna Lucasta
description: IN 1949, the American Negro Theater production of Philip Yordan's Anna Lucasta moved from Harlem to Broadway and became a phenomenal success, running for 957 performances. Ironically, Anna Lucasta was not originally written as a black play. It was about a PolishAmerican family in Philadelphia. The title was Anna Lucaska. In its first movie incarnation, in 1949, the play returned to its source and became a vehicle for Paulette Goddard; in a second movie version, Eartha Kitt played the title role.

title: New Process Helps Identify Stolen Diamonds
description: Diamonds are everybody's best friend these days, and the dizzying levels of current gem prices have increased the risk of theft. But now jewelers and law enforcement agencies are turning to a new process that is said to provide identification of diamonds with the reliability of human fingerprints.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar recovered in late trading yesterday, posting small gains against all major currencies in New York after closing lower in most markets abroad.

title: Carlo Bini Makes Met Stage Debut
description: CARLO BINI who made his Metropolitan Opera stage debut in Carmen Monday night in place of the indisposed Guy Chauvet, may not be the most stylish Don Jose in memory, but his fervor enormously helped the production as a whole.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Sees Callaghan
description: LONDON, Nov. 14 (Reuters)  Former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India met with Prime Minister James Callaghan today for nearly an hour. A spokesman said they discussed IndianBritish relations, contributions of the large Indian community in British life, and the political situation in Asia. Mrs. Gandhi also spent an hour in the House of ComMons, and later met privately with the opposition leader, Margaret Thatcher.

title: Soviet Jet in Stockholm Mishap
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 14 (AP)  A Soviet TU54 jet skidded off a runway in an aborted takeoff today and ended in ditch, Swedish aviation authorities said. The 65 passengers were not injured.

title: Hunted Animals Win Comeback, Bringing New Wildlife Problems
description: Since the turn of the century, the proliferation of hunters and the urbanization of America have caused a decline in and redistribution of the population of hundreds of species, of wild animals. Some of the more glamorous types, such as wolves, foxes, bears, hawks and eagles, together with many smaller animals and common songbirds, have been decimated by killing and the destruction of their traditional habitats.

title: SADAT SAID TO LINK GAZA TO PEACE PACT
description: CAIRO, Nov. 19  President Anwar elSadat was reported today to have declared that Egypt would not accept peace treaty being negotiated in Washington unless Israel relinquished the occupied Gaza Strip along with the Sinai Peninsula.

title: Wife of Leader Of A lbany Panel Is in Debt to City
description: Alma Miller, the wife of the chairman of the New York State Assembly Banking Committee, is in arrears $193,000 in payments to the city on a $461,000 housing rehabilitation loan and owes $54,000 more in back taxes and water and sewage fees, a spokesman for the Department of Housing Preservation and Development said yesterday.

title: Associated Press
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov.14 (AP)  The Los Angeles Dodgers signed Derrel Thomas, a freeagent utility player, to a fiveyear contract today.

title: Child Abductors Held in Manila
description: MANILA, Nov. 14 (Reuters)  The police today arrested three women believed to be running a gang responsible for the abduction and selling of children. A police spokesman said the women had been seized while negotiating the sale of a 2yearold girl in the Tondo waterfront district.

title: Deaths
description: QUINLANJoseph F. Of Flanders, NY. On November 13, 1978. Beloved husband of Mary. Loving father of Joseph Jr of Wilmington, Del. and Virginia O'Neill of Garden City. Reposing at the McFarland and Carman Funeral Home, Hampton Bays. Mass of Christian Burial. Thursday, 10:30AM.at St. Rosalie's RC Church Hampton Bays. Interment Sacred Heart Cemetery. Southampton.

title: Scandinavian Tractor Pact
description: Valmet Oy, Finland's largest engineering and shipbuilding group, announced yesterday that it had signed a let ter of intent with Volvo of Sweden to develop jointly a line of agricultural tractors for the 1980's. The two concerns are the sole Scandinavian manufacturers of tractors.

title: BISHOPS SET REVIEW OF SUPERCOMMITTEE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  As a result of a dispute over the reinstatement of wellknown Roman Catholic priest as labor consultant, steps were taken today by the president of the American Bishops conference to review the functions of powerful group of bishops whose decision to prematurely retire the priest touched off the furor.

title: U.S., Short on Intelligence and Tied to the Shah, Decided It Had to Support Him
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14Early this month, as the political turmoil in Iran appeared to be getting out of control, a highlevel group of Carter Administration aides met to determine what, if anything, the United States could do to help stabilize the situation.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: In 1942, the Carrier Corporation presented a scroll to the Syracuse Chamber of Commerce in recognition of the chamber's efforts to bring the company to the city during the Depression. Five years earlier, the chamber had pulled together a group of citizens who raised $250,000 to enable Carrier to move there from New Jersey.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Retail food prices will rise 8 to 10 percent next year, the Agriculture Department predicted in a report with implications for President Carter's antiinflation program. Since roughly 60 percent of retail food costs are in transportation, packaging and processing after food leaves the farm, general inflationary pressures will force prices up regardless of supplies, an official said. [Page A1.]

title: The Region
description: SYRACUSE  A 6yearold boy and his teenage babysitter died in a fire that engulfed one apartment of a fivefamily house here. Firemen rescued the boy's father and 3yearold brother, both of whom were in critical condition at the State University Hospital.

title: Penney Net Down 6.8% For Quarter
description: Rises in interest costs and other expenses and a foreign currency loss reduced earnings of the J. C. Penney Company by 6.8 percent in its third fiscal quarter, ended Oct. 28, according to yesterday's report of the nation's thirdlamest retailer.

title: Turner Seeks to Keep Slew in Barn
description: Seattle Slew's former trainer. Billy Turner, is trying to block the 1977 triple crown winner from beginning his breeding career on schedule.

title: New Yorkers, etc
description: MOST people think that being rich is never having to worry about money, which isn't true at all. The rich worry a lot about money and the very word bargain makes their eyes sparkle almost as brilliantly as their diamonds.

title: British Unions Withhold PayRestraint Approval
description: LONDON, Nov. 14  Britain's labor union leaders, in a vote today, surprisingly refused to approve a tactical wagebargaining agreement that the Labor Government had hoped would help minimize wage demands.

title: Deathss
description: STEINBACHRabbi Alexander AlanThe Officers, Trustees and Members of Temple Ahavath Stator record with great sorrow the passing of our beloved and distinguished Rabbi Emeritus. Doctor Alexander Alan Steinbach, leader of our congregation for 32 years. We cherish his memory and extend heartfelt sympathy to his wife Joy and family. Services at Washington Hebrew Congregation, Massachusetts Ave and MacSt, N.W., Washington, D.C. at 1. PM. Wednesday, November 15th.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: It's been considered a classic ever since its first jaunty appearance in England in the 1920's, and now a quite extensive selection of Herbert Johnson's Murray cap can be found on the elegant shelves of the new Burberry's shop on East 57th Street. Mr. Johnson, fondly referred to by the Burberry staff as Herbie J., is the gentleman who took to the hat trade at the advice of Edward VII (whose benificence the Duchess of Duke Street we are now familiar with) and henceforth became London's leading hatter; Murray is the name given to the soft wool tweed cap whose brim is stitched to its upper part. The fullylined cap is made in England; the wool tweed is woven, as has always been, by the women of the Scottish town of Galashiels. The softchecks and plaids, are predominantly browns and tans, favorite shades of the British hunting set. The cap, which rolls up easily for stuffing (gently) into a pocket, is $25 at Herbert Johnson Hat Shop on the fifth floor at Burberry's, 9 East 57th Street.

title: Addressograph in Bid
description: The AddressographMultigraph Corporation and the Microdata Corporation announced yesterday that they had agreed to exchange information and to begin talks leading to the establishment of agreements under which Addressograph would acquire Microdata. On Nov. 7 the two companies announced an offer by Addressograph to acquire Microdata under a formula approximating the exchange of one share of Addressograph common for each of the about 2.3 million outstanding shares of Microdata.

title: Izetta Jewel Miller Is Dead at 94; ExActress and Political Activist
description: LA JOLLA, Calif. (AP)  Izetta Jewel Miller, a former actress and onetime activist in the women's rights movement, died today at the Torrey Pines Convalescent Center, where she lived since 1972. She was 94 years old.

title: Clifford Hood, Former President Of U.S. Steel Corp., Is Dead at 84
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 14  Clifford F. Hood, past president and board member of the United States Steel Corporation, died Nov. 9 here, where he had lived since 1969. He was 84 years old.

title: The Theater: Jeffrey Sweet's Porch
description: AFTER writing an interesting book about the growth of the Chicago school of improvisational comedy  the Second City, its forebears and its progeny Jeffrey Sweet has turned to playwriting.

title: Rock: Captain Beefheart
description: CAPTAIN BEEFHEART, who ended a twonight comeback engagement at the Bottom Line Monday, goes back a long way. In the late 1960's he was associated with Frank Zappa as a leader of what might be called acid surrealism a form of highly theatrical, zanily poetic rock music that borrowed heavily from avantgarde jazz and various kinds of folk and ethnic music. It was a style both fascinating and influential, and it proved conclusively that there was more to Los Angeles music than country rock. One could even make a case that California musical eccentricity laps well beyond the shores of rock, and that a supposedly classical composer like Harry Partch shares much with Mr. Zappa and Captain Beefheart.

title: Abuses by Local Movers and Warehousers Charged
description: Victims of fire, domestic tragedy and other emergencies who are forced from their apartments continue to be bilked by unscrupulous moving and storage operators, according to consumerfraud agencies.

title: Big Four Auto Makers Report Decline in Sales
description: DETROIT, Nov. 14  Sales of new cars in the first 10 days of November dipped 5.5 percent below the yearago level, with all the Big Four automobile makers reporting declines but cautioning against quick interpretation of the meaning of the figures.

title: Deaths
description: GOODMAN4. Leon. The partners of Solomon, Rosenbaum, Reler & Ross mourn the loss of their long time partner, I. Leon Goodman, who retired early this year after a long illness. We extend our condolences to his widow, Ruth, and his children.

title: About Real Estate Alexander's Weighs ExMacy Jamaica Site
description: It hardly helped the city's longterm effort to revitalize the commercial center of Jamaica a year ago when R.H. Macy closed its 30yearold department store on 165th Street. But by then Macy's had already moved into an upgrading program in which the Jamaica store, an outlet for apparel and soft goods almost exclusively, did not seem to fit. The closing was considered all but inevitable.

title: The New York Times /Joyce Dopkeen
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 19  A 21yearold chauffeur and handyman for Linda Scott, the countrywestern singer, was arraigned here this morning on charges of seconddegree murder in connection with her bludgeoning death last Friday.

title: News Summary
description: Iran's all strike collapsed in the refineries and the offshore installations under pressure from the Shah's military Government. But resistance continued among some oilfield workers. Reports from the key oil centers said that while many workers had returned to their jobs at the facilities that can produce more than six million barrels of crude oil a day, some were engaged in a slowdown. [Page Al, Column 1.]

title: Honors for Soviet Writers
description: Two controversial Soviet writers whose works have gotten them into trouble are being honored this week in New York for their contributions to literature and art.

title: California Church Group Loses Its Town
description: EUREKA, Calif., Nov. 14The dream of a small band of fundamentalist Christians to turn the old town of Bridgeville into a religious community appears to have died.

title: George Steinbrenner: First in War
description: The only thing older than Luis Tiant last summer in Fenway Park was the monster, the great green leftfield wall. And if the wall had an agent, chances are the New York Yankees would be trying to sign it up, too, and spirit it away from the Boston Red Sox along with old Luis.

title: Dr. Alexander A. Steinbach, 84, Brooklyn Temple's Retired Rabbi
description: Dr. Alexander A. Steinbach, rabbi emeritus of Temple Ahavath Sholom at Avenue R and East 16th Street in Flatbush, Brooklyn, died Sunday in Hollywood, Fla., where he had lived since his retirement in 1966. He was 84 years old.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, Noy. 14, 1978

title: Books of The Times
description: G ODDAM I love you, Willie. You're my best friend, says James Jones to Willie Morris near the end of James Jones: A Friendship. I love you too, Mr. Morris answers him. You' re the best friend I ever had. Unless you are very much caught up in the spirit of this touching homage to the novelist, who died in 1977 of congestive heart failure at the age of 56, you are going to avert your eyes at this exchange. Indeed, it would be easy to debunk this entire book, if you were of a mind to do so. For one thing, in reconstructing the career of James Jones, it tells a story that is already largely familiar, and it does so, in large part, with other people's words.

title: Social Security Changes Asked
description: The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants yesterday announced that it would propose major reforms of the Social Security System at a meeting in Coronado, Calif., on Dec. 4 and 5.

title: Election Panel Closes Its Inquiry on Lindsay Despite Debt Mystery
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  The Federal Election Commission has closed a sixyear investigation of the abortive 1972 Presidential campaign of John V. Lindsay, the former Mayor of New York, despite a continuing mystery about more than $250,000 in political debts.

title: Private Lives
description: AUGUST: It was the first weekend of the New York newspaper strike and the last day the 1960's weddings, in 1978, in a public park in Rochester. There were horses nearby. and a keg of foamy beer, and a volleyball net, and a bluegrass band. The food, of course, was vegetarian. The bride, of course, wore flowers in her hair, but managed to keep her shoes on until after the vows had been exchanged under the big sad tree. I am happy to report that no one quoted Kahlil Gibran or. for that matter, the Kama Sutra. The bride was the only sister I have who plays the guitar and sets type. The groom was estimable. I found it hard to summon up the usual ambivalence. Presently, we would consume seaweed and turnip extract and then, with bare feet, squaredance on the lawn.

title: Finally! Penn State Gets No. 1 Ranking
description: Penn State was ranked as the No. majorcollege football team in the nation yesterday by both The Associated Press and United Press International weekly polls.

title: Esposito Reports Getting $20,000 In Fees Illegally
description: Meade H. Esposito acknowledged yesterday that he had received $20,000 in consultant fees from one of the financiers of the proposed Parr Meadows race track and had also handled some of the track insurance without realizing that such activity was a violation of state law and that it subjected him to forfeiture of his Democratic county leadership in Brooklyn.

title: Oil Executives See Energy Law as Start

Haynes, chairman of the Standard Oil Company of California, voicing theme heard repeatedly from oil executives meeting here less than a week after President Carter signed an energy bill over which Congress had struggled much of its last session.

title: Topics
description: We cannot imagine why the National Automobile Dealers Association should be responding negatively to the Federal Trade Commission's newly proposed rules on used cars. Dealers would simply be required to tell a prospective buyer what needs fixing and how much it would cost. Surely, usedcar salesmen are not now permitting customers to drive away cars whose brakes are on the verge of dissolution without mentioning it; surely usedcar salesmen are not now leading customers to believe that a transmission job costs a pittance. The new rules, we are confident, would confirm the common honesty of members of the National Automobile Dealers Association.

description: Shortterm interest rates rose sharply and longterm yields declined slightly in the taxexempt securities market yesterday as a heavy volume of highgrade state bonds and Governmentbacked notes was marketed.

title: Carter Campaign Visits Cost $5,000 to $10,000
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) Democratic candidates paid from $5,000 to $10,000 each to finance autumn campaign visits by President Carter, figures obtained from the White House show.

description: As expected, the board of directors of P.R. Mallory & Company decided yesterday that the $226 million tender offer by Dart Industries was inadequate and recommended that Mallory shareholders reject the bid.

description: New York State's southern zone deer season for muzzleloaders opened Monday and lasts through next Sunday, but those who truly enjoy the challenge of using this oldfashioned weapon (how quickly things become primitive in the 20th century) really have much more time than that to pursue their sport.

description: RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 14 (UPI) More than 40 members of the National Guard and their families were hospitalized with suspected food poisoning after attending a Thanksgiving dinner at an armory, a national guard spokesman said today.

title: Special to The New York  Times
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  The MX program has two basic components: the missile itself and the basing mode, the way in which the missile will be housed. The two are related but are being developed independently. MX Weapons To Be Larger, More Potent

description: American business executives say they will try hard to comply with President Carter's wage and price guidelines, according to a spot check of corporate officials by The New York Times. For one thine. they fear that the alternative to a voluntary program is mandatory controls, which most say would create additional economic turmoil.

Rosenthal, executitre editor, announced yesterday. Mr. Sterne will succeed Robert Crandall as head of the newspaper's Sunday travel section, effective next Monday.

description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 14  Connecticut's controversial law banning certain stores from being open on Sunday, which has been in effect only since Oct. 1, was struck down as unconstitutional in Superior Court today.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  In cramped office in downtown Washington, Robert Muller sits in a wheelchair and speaks with piercing anguish and fury.

title: Masters of the Palette and Palate
description: A MONGpainters and sculptors, to eat well is one of the laws of life. Their whole activity predisposes them to it. They deal day in and day out with color and texture. substance and aroma. Studio and kitchen have much in common. Touch and timing are as fundamental to cooking as they are to art. Writing as physical activity has its sensuous side, but the hand that rocks the electric typewriter does not seem to us a natural for the sauce boat and the double boiler.

title: Personal Health
description: IT was the only sensible thing to do, said a Middle Western father of four children, only one of them planned. One child was the result of a condom failure, another the result of a diaphragm failure and a third that of a foam failure. I just couldn't see my wife staying on the pill for another 10 to 15 years, the father said. Her spirits lifted as soon as I decided to have the operation.

title: Star Center Replacing Sanders
description: The Boston Celtics dismissed as head coach yesterday one of the outstanding playersof their glorious past and replaced him with one of the outstanding players of their notsoglorious present. Tom (Satch) Sanders, a forward during the Celtic dynasty of the 1960's, was dropped and his job was filled by the fiery and controversial Dave Cowens. The 30yearold Cowens, one of the outstanding centers in the National Basketball Association, becomes the second playercoach in Celtic history. The other was another center, Bill Russell, who replaced the retiring Red Auerbach for the 196667 season and won two N.B.A. championships in three seasons.

title: Courtesy, the Morris Gallery
description: Vestie E. Davis, a primitive painter of New York and other scenes, died yesterday at the Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center. He was 75 years old and lived in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn.

title: When a Turkey Puts Its Best Foot Forward
description: ALMOST all holiday symbols are directly traceable to their origins. The Easter egg is attributable to pagan rites of spring and the season of rebirth; the custom of a Yuletide goose is almost certainly an offspring of that celebrated feast in Dickens's A Christmas Carol. No one knows precisely, however, when the turkey became the national bird for the Thanksgiving table. It is presumed that the serving of a roasted tom turkey, a gobbler, came into popularity about the beginning of the 19th century. As pointed out in a marvelously researched work on the Thanksgiving bird, The Wild Turkey by A.W. Schorger (University of Oklahoma Press), There is a widespread lief that from the first Thanksgiving in New England in 1621 this celebration became an annual affair and that turkey was always served. Not so, says the author. In the beginning, Thanksgiving was celebrated only on an irregular basis. The time of celebration was proclaimed by the heads of individual colonies or states. Thanksgiving first became a national holiday through a proclamation of President Lincoln, and it was celebrated on the fourth Thursday of November 1864. Since that time each successive President has followed his example. (Curiously, some Southern states had objected to the proclamation on the ground that it was a relic of Puritanic bigotry.) Perhaps the first official association of the holiday and turkey was made Alexander Hamilton, the statesman and first Secretary of the Treasury from 1789 to 1795. No citizen of the United States, he opined, should refrain from turkey on Thanksgiving Day.

William Green, Republican of Manhattan, as a member. Mr. Green is not affiliated with the group.

The dead, including two children, were killed by smoke and fumes after the boys allegedly dropped a torch into the basement of their twofamily home, looking for a lost coat.

But maybe they'll have time to consider an incident at the birth of the Constitution of the United States.

A slot of mostly clear weather Is over the Midwest followed by broken overcast clouds across the Northern Plains States and Rockies. Layered clouds are swirling over western Texas. This area of moisture will move Into the New York metropolitan area as steady rain on Thursday.

More and more, it has crossed my notice Mb that mustard is being used to a far vaster extent these days as an ingredient to give a piquancy to sauces  and not only to the likes of mayonnaise and hollandaise but a variety of hot sauces as well.

This season her recitals have been devoted to the six unaccompanied works for violin by Bach. Three were played on Oct. 30 and the remaining three on Monday night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

Summer is a hot flash, a bath of light and air, a game in which city people try to go back to that other nature, away from their own. Summer is the child in them, but even children get bored with playing. When their heads grow cool again, New Yorkers feel a cityhunger, a nostalgia for their anxiety, for the burden of life.

Not a prescription fora harmonious community. So it is heartening that recent weeks both New York City and the State of New Jersey have managed to devise rules that maintain balance between the pleasures of some and the antipathies of others.

title: Film: 'Lord of Rings' From Ralph Bakshi:Animated Mythology
description: RALPH BAKSHI ("Fritz The Cat," "Heavy Traffic" and so on) is probably the wittiest, most original animator now working in American theatrical films, and his big, busy, very long screen adaptation of the late J.R.R. Tolkien's trilogy. "The Lord of the Rings," is both numbing and impressive.Yet it would be difficult to recommend this movie to anyone not wholly absorbed by the uses of motion-picture animation or to anyone not familiar with Tolkien's home-made mythology, which borrows liberally from various Norse myths, the Eddas, the Nibelungs and maybe even Beatrix Potter. In the way of grand opera sung in Urdu, "The Lord of the Rings" is likely to be total confusion to someone who doesn't speak the language.In 1956, Edmund Wilson said it very well in The Nation when he described Tolkien's trilogy as "essentially a children's book which has somehow got out of hand." To be exact, it's out of hand by half a million words plus indexes, appendixes, footnotes and maps.The three books, set in the mythological past of Middle Earth, recount an epic battle between good and evil, between heaven and hell, when the dark powers, in order to rule the world, attempt to recover a magic ring that has fallen into the possession of a heroic hobbit named Frodo. The cast of characters includes wizards (good and bad), dragons, men, elves, dwarfs, goblins and, of course, hobbits, which are sort of superdwarfs. Hobbits are smaller than the dwarfs of conventional fairy tales but they are jollier, heartier, cuter, braver and in general much more difficult to stomach than Sneezy, Sleepy, Doc, Dopey and the rest of that crowd.W.H. Auden and other pro-Tolkien critics have found in "The Lord of the Rings" comparisons to Milton, Dante and other epic-makers, and they may be right. I must admit that since I reached voting age I haven't been as fascinated by confrontations between good and evil (with the exception of "Star Wars," which was funny) as I've been by attempts to cope with what Grace Paley identified as "the little disturbances of man."
