Until I can understand how Con Ed operates, heaven (and hell can wait.The movie, which opens today at the Ziegfeld Theater, includes material from the first two books of the trilogy. "The Fellowship of the Ring" and "The Two Towers," and ends more or less in mid-crisis (after more than two hours) with the screen message, "Here con-cludes the first part of the history of the War of the Ring." It's not a movie for the child (or adult) who has yet to conquer his need for instant gratification. Mr. Bakshi is, I'm told, already working on the second part utilizing the third book, "The Return of the Ring." You are thus warned to have some kind of explanation ready for your child when the movie ends without actually ending. If the child is my age, watch out that he doesn't rip up a seat.The major fault of the screenplay by Chris Conkling and Peter S. Beagle is that the film attempts to cover too much ground too quickly, packing in more incomprehensible exposition in the first 15 minutes than you'd get in a year of "All My Children." I know one 12-year-old Tolkien scholar, who otherwise thoroughly approved of the movie, who was disappointed because a lot of the events of the books had been ''simplified" in the movie. This comment prompted a certain amount of awe among a small group of adults who'd had difficulty following the simplified material.After some introductory information about the origin of the magic ring, the film settles down to attend to the adventures of the hobbit named Frodo as he attempts to return the ring to Mount Doom, in the land of Modor, where the ring was cast and can be destroyed, in this way to keep it out of the clutches of the evil Sauron. Frodo's companions on his quest include a wise wizard named Gandalf; a faithful, comic servant named Sam, and other assorted types with such names as Aragorn, Boromir, Merry and Pippin. There are terrible goblins called ores, and one very skinny, ugly, unreliable, obsequious, completely winning creature named Smeagol, who is a gollum.As in all his films, Mr. Bakshi, attempts to go beyond the limits of movie animation as we know it. Before he and his staff began the actual animation, he shot most of his script with live actors in Spain (where else?) and used this material as a guide for the animators. Some of this original material appears to have been incorporated into the finished production, though it has the look of video tape that has been electronically altered to give it an unworldly, unfilmlike quality. Sometimes this is most effective; at other times it simply looks like badly developed film stock. Still, the film is visually compelling even when murk overtakes the narrative.If Tolkien was not above quoting the mythology of others, Mr. Bakshi appears to have had his own fun quoting such films as "2001," "Ivan the Terrible." "Henry V" and "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs." His hobbits look very much like Disney dwarfs, though somewhat more introspective, and not once does anyone waste time wishing on a star. The War of the Ring is serious business, and the movie seldom makes light of it, which is something parents should keep in mind."The Lord of the Rings," which is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains much fantastic material that could frighten very small children or confuse those less susceptible to nightmares.

title: Fraud Trial of Eight Unfolds in Bankruptcy of the Premier Theater
description: A long trial focusing on fraud charges involving the Westchester Premier Thea ter, with references to prominent members of the entertainment world and the underworld, continued to unfold yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: $2 Million in Bogus Bills Seized
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 (UPI) The Secret Service last night seized $2 million in counterfeit $20 and $50 bills and arrested a Chadds Ford, Pa., man who allegedly manufactured them, it was announced today. Paul W. Morgan, 33 years old, the owner of the Valley Brook golf course and an adjacent Dairy Queen ice cream store, was charged with manufacturing and possessing counterfeit notes and their negatives and counterfeiting paraphenalia. About $800 worth of the bills have been passed on to the public so far, an agent said.

title: Buses, Glass Houses and Stones
description: A handsome and practical addition to the New York streetscape in the past three years has been the glass shelter at bus stops. Without a penny of expense to the city, 350 of them have risen on street corners under an exploratory franchise arrangement with Bustop Shelters, Inc., the only developer initially willing put money into such a venture. The Bustop company gets its return from the two advertising panels in each shelter and the city has been receiving 5 percent of the gross revenue.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: To ask how to obtain a copy of the City's new critique of the National Park Service's $300 million plan for the Gateway National Recreation Area, I called the Mayor's Office, writes Lincoln Diamant.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAHAMDavId. Passed away 6n November 14. 1978 beloved son of AnBrea and James Abraham. Grand. son of Helene and Alexander Abraham and Harriet and Marlin Straw gin. Services at The Stanetsky. Schlossberg Solomon Memorial pHs. 1668 Beacon St. Brookline, Mess Wednesday November 15. 1978 at 12 Noon. In lieu of flowers donations scored/fed to the Jimmy Fund, Chiltrens Hospital. Boston ?MSS.

title: New South Africa Premier Picks Moderate as BlackAffairs Chief
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 14  In his first major move on relations with South Africa's black majority, Prime Minister P.W. Botha today appointed one of the most reformminded ministers in his Government, Pieter G. Koornhof, as minister responsible for black affairs.

title: Careers
description: PAUL SCHULZE specializes in witchery. As director of design for Steuben Glass, he supervises the magic that transforms blobs of molten glass into crystal works of art ranging from a tiny glass animal that costs $75 to the elaborately engraved Romance of the Rose, which recently sold for about $95,000. This magnificent vase, reportedly bought by a South American, has multifaceted sides etched with scenes from the French classic story that was written in the Middle Ages as an allegory about love.

title: TV: Bud and Lou And the Royal Ballet
description: IN NBC's Wednesday night movie at 9, Bud and Lou are Bud Abbott and Lou Costello, the comedy team that went from burlesque in the 1930's to national fame in radio and film during the 90's. With tall, slim Abbott as straight man, and short, fat Costello as clown, they made 28 movies, in the process taking Universal Pictures out of the red. At the box office, Buck Privates outgrossed such prestige hits as Sergeant York and How Green Was My Valley.

title: United Press International
description: NO HALFTIME RESPITE: John Garcia, a 17yearold placekicker and punter for the Ray High School football team in Corpus Christi, Tex., gets no rest at halftime. He doffs his helmet, grabs his trumpet, and joins the school's marching band.

title: Chinese Leader Back in Peking
description: PEKING, Nov. 14 (Reuters)  Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping of China returned to Peking tonight after a 10day visit to Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore and Burma.

title: Concert: Cissy Houston
description: CISSY HOUSTON always brings a little of her experience as church singer and choir director to her performances, even when she is doing pop tunes at Reno Sweeney. On Monday night, she was at Carnegie Hall giving a benefit concert for the United Negro College Fund, and she brought the choir from her church, the New Hope Baptist Church in Newark. Their voices combined with the college fund choir into a mighty chorus of around 100 wingers. And when they joined Miss Houston for the final third of the concert, they inspired one of the finest performances this reviewer has seen her give.

title: Officer in Mental Care After Youth's Slaying Is Certified for Release
description: State mental health officials have recommended the release of a former police officer, Robert Torsney, who was acquitted of slaying a 15yearold black youth by reason of insanity, after less than a year of mental care.

title: GOING OUT  GUIDE
description: QUEEN KIT When Katharine Cornell died in 1974, a regal Broadway glow dimmed forever. The aspiring young actress from Buffalo attained legendary status in her craft over the years, retiring in 1961 upon the death of her husband and director, Guthrie McClintic. Brooks Atkinson once wrote that something electric happened when she stepped on the stage. Audiences felt it, in such productions as Shaw's St. Joan and her Shakespeare, Juliet to Cleopatra; in Mauer am's The Letter and, of course, the beloved, longrunning The Barretts of Wimpole Street.

title: To Top Off the Turkey, Two Outrageous Desserts
description: While turkey is an annual must for most Thanksgiving tables, the trimmings may vary from year to year. Dessert is one area where cooks can turn away from the traditional, offering instead the fruits of fall that provide an alternative to pumpkin and mincemeat.

title: Steps by Labor Dept. Will Seek to Prevent JobProgram Abuses
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall today announced a new drive designed to prevent the fraud and abuse that have plagued the Labor Department's multibilliondollar job programs.

title: Hall's Landmark Hearing Ends
description: The city's Landmarks Preservation Commission completed its public hearing yesterday on granting landmark status to Town Hall, the historic concert hall on 43d Street east of Broadway. The commission's ruling may affect plans to convert the auditorium into a cultural facility run by the Town Hall Theater Foundation.

title: Stocks Drop as Trading Rises
description: Continued investor jitters over rising interest rates sent the stock market into a broad retreat yesterday in accelerated trading.

title: TV: Afterschool Gluttony
description: CONSIDERING the millions of tons of blubber that American youngsters are carrying around with them, the subject of overweight was a logical one for the ABC Afterschool Specials series to tackle. However. Dinky Hocker, which will be shown from 4:30 to 5:30 P.M. today on Channel 7, while on the side of the angels rather than the angel cake, doesn't measure up to many previous offerings of this estimable series in dramatizing the problem.

title: Lots of Problems Face Pennsylvania GovernorElect
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 14  At the moment, Richard L. Thornburgh, the next Governor of Pennsylvania, feels the sanguineness of a winner in the sunshine. One week ago today, Mr. Thornburgh, Republican, achieved a victory that amazed political analysts here. Today, he and his wife set off for a week's vacation at a spot known only to them and their closest kin.

title: Hearing Is Set Over Trial Status Of Two 14YearOlds in Fatal Fire
description: A hearing has been scheduled in Bronx Criminal Court tomorrow morning on the question of whether two 14yearold boys charged with setting a fire that killed six people should be tried as adults or juveniles.

title: Simpsoniana on Display
description: While Adele Simpson designed her collections, she also collected designs.

title: Parents Ired by TV Ads
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14Is it a deceptive trade practice for Fred Flinstone to tell your 8yearold child: Yabba dabba doo, Flintstone Vitamins are Rood for you'?

title: Effort to Revive Talks On Fund for Poor Lands
description: GENEVA, Nov 14  An attempt to revive the faltering northsouth dialogue got off to an uncertain start today at a United Nations conference on projected international fund to finance the earnings of developing countries from their exports of raw materials.

title: UNESCO May Shelve News Code Opposed by West
description: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization's controversial draft declaration on news coverage, which has been viewed in the West as a threat to a free press, may be replaced by a new document with no references to governmental control of the press.

title: PRESSURE BY SOVIET ON FINNS CHARGED
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 14 Despite official denials by the Finnish Government, Nordic military and political leaders say there is now conclusive evidence that the Soviet Union raised, the question of joint FinnishSoviet military maneuvers during a visit here by the Soviet Defense Minister.

title: PublicTV Survey Finds Wide Reaction
description: A new study of television that avoided the usual statistics put the classical televisionnews question to viewers  how do you feel about it? and came up with a broad spectrum of response.

title: Textile Advances In N.C.A.A. Soccer
description: There are four undefeated teams in the majorcollege soccer ranks, and the one with the best record passed its first test handsomely yesterday in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Money
description: Federal fundsrate:

title: Major JumboJet Orders Due by Delta, American
description: Two of the nation's largest airlines, Delta and American, will probably announce new jumbojet orders today at cost that could come to $2 billion or more, according to industry sources.

title: Memorial Set for Slain Student
description: A memorial service for 18yearold Louise Stern, who was kidnapped, raped and killed over the weekend in Atlanta, will be held in New York City at 5.P.M. today at Marymount School, 85th Street and Fifth Avenue. The Emory University freshman was abducted Saturday with her friend, Resier Williams, a student at Fordham University, managed to escape unharmed.

title: THOMAS P. BLYTHE Jr.
description: MERRITT ISLAND, Fla..Nov.14 (UPI)Thomas P. Blythe Jr., assistant national sales manager of The Chicago TribuneNew York News Syndiclite, died of a heart attack yesterday at his family's home here. He was 51 yeait old.

title: Associated Press
description: All eyes were on the puck as Rockies Paul Gardner skated between Islanders goalie, Glenn Resch, right, and Stefan Persson after puck was deflected Into the corner during the first period last night at Uniondale, LI.

title: Piano: Marlboro Quartet
description: THE PIANO quartet is one of the most difficult species of chamber music to bring into balance. Composers tend to give the piano too heavy a role to play, thickening the textures so that the three string parts cannot be made to sound through the muddle with much consistency.

title: 8% to 10% Increase in Food Costs Is Seen by Agriculture Department
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  The Agriculture Department predicted today that retail food prices would rise 8 to 10 percent in 1979  a development that could have major implications for the Administration's antiinflation fight, since food prices make up 20 percent of the Consumer Price Index.

title: Food Fair Cites Daily Losses
description: Food Fair Inc. said yesterday that it had lost about $500,000 a day, or $10.7 million, in a 20day period that began Oct. 2  the day it filed for court protection under the Chapter XI provisions of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: SOUTHERN REAL ESTATE (300)
description: SOUTHERN REAL ESTATE (300)

title: The U.N. Day
description: Meets on the question of Cyprus P.M.

title: 189 Moslem Pilgrims Feared Dead In Charter Jet Crash in Sri Lanka
description: A chartered DC8 jetliner carrying Indonesian Moslems home from a pilgrimage to Mecca, Saudi Arabia, crashed in coconut plantation outside the aitport in Colombo, Sri Lanka, yesterday, killing 189 of the 259 persons aboard, according to Icelandic Airline officials.

title: Economic News Spurs Market
description: Favorable economic news helped the stock market post a small advance yesterday after two consecutive sessions of sharp setbacks.

title: Sheets Fit For a Princess
description: PRINCESS GRACE. long a collector and arranger of flowers. is letting Springmaid make sheets from her arrangements.

title: Vote in Brazil Today To Measure Support For Military Leaders
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 15  Brazilians voted today for a Congress due to be the first in a decade to start functioning without the threat of shutdown by the military President.

title: An Amendment: Bus Stop Revisited
description: In weighing the competing claims of two companies that want to build more of those convenient glass shelters at bus stops, we yesterday rated the dependability of one, Bustop Shelters, as proven while raising a question about the challenger, Convenience and Safety.

title: A Singular Issue
description: BOSTON  Over the last few years political analysts have noted the significance of the singleissue voter: the person who cares only about a candidate's views on gun control, for example, or busing, or capital punishment.

title: Grandmother to the World
description: Death was the only force that could still her. Even well into her seventies, Margaret Mead was lecturing, writing, researching, teaching and gadding about at pace that left younger colleagues breathless. Draped her grandmotherly shawl, brandishing her staff, she would command our attention  and admonish an errant world to mend its ways.

title: The City
description: The first of expected damage claims gwing out of t the Election Day ferryboat crash  a $1.1 million bid by woman passenger and her husbandwas filed with the City Comptroller yes terday. The police had listed 240 persons as injured, and hospitals reported treating 178 of these, including 12 admitted.

title: WILLIAM D. BURDEN, NATURALIST, IS DEAD
description: William Douglas Burden, an explorer, naturalist and conservationist, died Tuesday at his home in Charlotte, Vt. He was 80 years old.

title: Restoring Antique Trays
description: ANTIQUE furniture often shows its age not only by its craftsmanship and design, but also by less sightly signs of wear and tear. Many pieces, however, are well worth the expense of careful rponration.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, NOV. 15, 1978

title: Gas Xenon Is Converted to a Metallic Form by Scientists at Cornell
description: Scientists at Cornell University have created a metallic form of the elemental gas xenon by subjecting it to unprecedented pressure. Their success has heightened hopes that metallic hydrogen, a hypothetical substance that would have enormous practical utility, may soon be within reach.

title: Moynihan Says Recent Studies Raise Doubts About Negative Income Tax Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, Nov, 15  Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, long a leading proponent of a negative income tax as a substitute for the welfare system, today declared that he now had serious doubts the content would work.

title: 6 L.I.R.R. Officials Faked Expenses, Levitt Charges
description: An audit by State Comptroller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday that six highlevel Long Island Rail Road officials have submitted falsified or otherwise improper expense accounts and that four had continued the practice even after it had been announced that the audit had begun.

title: GARDENING
description: BEGONIAS are a passion of Curtiss Engle's. Such a passion, she has become a begonia activist. She grows. collects. propagates, photographs, shows, judges and lectures on begonias. And not one plant is a favorite.

title: Paying the Bills for CUNY
description: When free tuition at CUNY came to an end in 1976, the last real difference between the City University and the State University disappeared. What had evaporated even earlier was New York City's capacity keep financing a major university. CUNY has since drifted from crisis to crisis, and it has been saved each instance only by increasing amounts of subsidy from Albany.

title: Disability Pension Sought For Policeman in Slaying
description: Robert Torsney's attorney has begun legal procedures he hopes will gain $15,000ayear police disability pension for Mr. Torsney, a policeman who was acquitted, by reason of insanity, of having killed a a teenager.

title: The Theater: Unicorn, A Political Play of Deceit
description: MEL ARRIGHI'S The Unicorn in Captivity, at the Impossible Ragtime Theater, is about compromise and expediency, hypocrisy and conupdon. In other words, this is a political play with a familiar message a postWatergate journey through the land of deceit.

title: Home Beat
description: HE is English, 25 years old, and holds a postgraduate degree in economics. His family owns a supermarket chain that, give or take a million, has annual sales of roughly $2 billion. He is traveling around the United States having marvelously good time because he recently bought Design Research. His name is John Porter and you might want to mark that down  we are bound to be hearing from him.

title: Record Gains In Certificates
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UPI) Financial institutions posted record gains for sixmonth money market certificates during October, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported.

title: Letter On UNESCO Censorship
description: To the Editor: Your Nov. 8 editorial concerning the proposed action by UNESCO to establish a code of conduct for newspapers, press agencies and broadcasters was well put. You might have added that this would lay the groundwork for censorship of books, magazines and other writings, such as now exists to greater or lesser degree in nations subject to autocratic rule.

title: Mother, 35, Acquitted Of Kidnapping Sons In Custody of Father
description: The first woman to be criminally prosecuted for kidnapping her own children has been acquitted by a jury in Brooklyn Criminal Court of charges of custodial inteference.

title: Schlesinger, Offering Fuel Plan, Cites Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Nov.15  Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger said today that the temporary shutdown of crude oil production in Iran demonstrated that the United States and other industrial countries were heavily dependent for energy supplies on a complex and occasionally precarious production and distribution system.

title: Issue and Debate Are Little League Sports
description: Often, they look like grotesque caricatures of their bigleague idols: a youngster spitting out makebelieve tobacco juice before he steps up to the plate; a child not yet 10 years old running around the soccer field with his arms raised in elation after goal, or a child spiking a football in the end zone.

title: Talks Start In Geneva On Trade
description: GENEVA, Nov. 15  In a crisisladen atmosphere, the United States and other major Western nations today began three days of negotiations here that will pave the way for freer and fairer trade in the 1980's if they succeed, but that could touch off new trade wars if they do not.

title: City Opera Raises Ticket Prices
description: Because of rising production costs,the New York City Opera will raise some individual ticket prices for the spring season next year.

title: Chico, Calif.: The Fallout 17 Years Later
description: CHICO, CALIF. IN 1961, a group of 34 New Yorkers looked long and carefully at geological survey maps of the United States, checked weather reports for prevailing winds, concluded that Chico, Calif., was one of the safest places in the country to survive a nuclear war and moved here.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: News Summary
description: A major air crash reportedly killed 189 persons near Colombo, Sri Lanka. A chartered DC8 jetliner carrying Indonesian Moslems home from a pilgrimage to Mecca plunged into a plantation near the airport in a heavy thunderstorm. [Page Al, Columns 34.].

title: Music: Watts Starts Schubert Salute
description: IT is the Schubert sesquicentennial, but even at that Andr Watts is going out of his way to commemorate the composer. Last night in Alice Tully Hall, he started the first of eight concerts devoted exclusively to Franz Schubert. Mr. Watts is taking stage center. as a participant in all of the concerts, but the series is not devoted entirely to piano music. Schubert's songs and chamber music will also be examined.

title: COMMODITIES Precious Metals Futures Fall Near Daily Limits
description: All New York futures prices of precious metals  gold, silver and platinum  closed down their respective daily permissible limits yesterday or within a few pennies of them. In the gold and platinum markets, the limit is $10 an ounce, while the maximum daily move in silver is 20 cents an ounce.

title: Uniroyal Omits Payment Of Quarterly Dividends
description: Uniroyal Inc., the international manufacturer of rubber and chemical products and one of the nation's largest producers of footwear, announced yesterday that because of expected low earnings for 1978 the company's board of directors had voted to omit fourth quarter dividend payments on its first preferred and common stocks.

title: Battle of Bands Planned
description: Andrew J. Stein, Borough President of Manhattan, yesterday announced the details of the Manhattan Music Playoffs. a boroughwide amateur battle of the bands. The contest is the first project of Mr. Stein's newly formed Manhattan Music Task Force, which is designed to revitalize the city's music Industry.

title: Drops in Welfare Pleases New York City, but State Isn't Impressed
description: New York City looked at its welfare statistics yesterday and pointed with pride to a reduction of 38,000 recipients since the beginning of the year.

title: Winter Forecast: Colder, Less Snow
description: The winter of 197879 will be slightly colder than average but with near normal amounts of snow, according to Bob Harris, meteorologist for The New York Times.

title: Sadat Aide Brings Carter a Message on Peace Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  With the EevptianIsraeli peace talks at a crucial stage, Egypt's Vice President arrived here today with a special message to President Carter from President Anwar elSadat on a need to link the projected peace treaty to a timetable for solving the Palestinian problem.

title: Overgraded Workers Are Said to Cost U. S. $436 Million in Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP)  Carter Administration officials estimate taxpayers are being billed $436 million extra a year because 11.5 percent of the Government' whitecollar workers enjoy rank and salaries too high for their duties.

title: Tough Law Is Applied To Trivial Complaints
description: The new juvenile justicelaw was designed to deal more severely with violenceprone youngsters. Legal Aid Society lawyers, however, contend that along with teenagers arrested on heavy, or serious charges, such as murder or arson, youths are picked up under the law on seemingly trivial complaints.

title: New Times Magazine Is Ending Publication; Me Decade Blamed
description: New Times announced yesterday that it would cease publication at the end of, the year. George A. Hirsch, the publisher, attributed the fiveyearold magazine's demise to lack of reader interest in investigative reporting, social issues or nublic affairs.

title: City Ballet Opens Season With Jewels
description: THE New York City Ballet opened its season Tuesday night at the New York State Theater with George Balanchine's Jewels, Mikhail Baryshnikov's local debut with the company and one of the worst audiences in its history.

title: L.I. AirTraffic Computer Failure Delays Jetport Arrivals an Hour
description: A computer malfunction in the Long Island center of the Federal Aviation Administration yesterday forced air traffic controllers to switch to an oldfashioned radar system, causing delays of up to an hour in arriving flights.

title: Avianca Buys Its Stock
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 15 (UPI)  Avianca Airlines announced today the purchase of more than 12 million shares of its stock held by Pan American World Airways. The transaction puts virtually all Avianca stock in Colombian hands. The company said that the purchase was made in September, but did not disclose the price.

title: Letters
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Pope, Criticizing Abortion, Calls Human Life Too Sacred a Value
description: ROME, Nov. 15 (UPI)  Pope John Paul II condemned abortion today, declaring that a new human life was too great, too sacred a value to be ended because of social pressure.

title: New Arab Arms Plant May Ease Reliance on Soviet
description: Several moderate Arab countries plan to establish an advanced weapons industry in Egypt in a move that may lead to greater Arab arms independence from both the Soviet Union and the United States.

title: U.S. Rider Triumphs At Toronto Horse Show
description: TORONTO, Nov. 15  Dennis Murphy rode Do Right to victory in the International jumper class at the Royal Winter Fair horse show last night and pulled the United States Equestrian Team to within seven points of first place.

title: Hickey Gets 3 Goals In 81 Ranger Romp
description: Everything went right for the Rangers last night.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ShortTerm Interest Declines
description: The money market became less crimped yesterday, and shortterm interest rates declined, permeating the credit markets with greater optimism. Fixedincome securities prices rose sharply.

title: Market Place
description: THE surprise decision by the Indiana Securitieq Commission to withdraw objections to a tender offer by Dart Industries for Indianapolisbased P.R. Mallory & Company helped send the latter's shares soaring yesterday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Wilmington 10 in The Times yesterday stated erroneously that Benjamin R. Chavis, the only member of the civil rights activist group still in jail, would be eligible for parole next January. He will be eligible in January 1980.

title: Boeing Has $2 Billion Jet Order
description: In the biggest singleday sale of airliners ever, the Boeing Company received orders yesterday for more than $2 billion in aircraft, mostly newgeneration 767 jumbo jetliners, from American and Delta Airlines.

title: Jets' Todd Gets His Job Back; Giants Waive Shaky Bryant
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 15  Bill Bryant, his shoes and other belongings in a plastic garbage bag, left the Giants' locker room today and headed for an evening on the town.

title: U.N. Says 5,000 Burma Moslems Have Left Bangladesh for Home
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Nov. 15 (Reuters)  More than 5,000 of the scores of thousands of Burmese Moslems who fled to this country six months ago have been repatriated, United Nations officials said today.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: BROWN  Russell R., at Greenwich, Conn., November 7, 1978. Husband of Mildred Moore Brown. Memorial service at Christ Church Chapel. Greenwich, on Saturday, November 18th at 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to your fa vice charity.

title: Design Notebook
description: THE welldesigned object has become a standard of our time  it is no longer surprising to walk into a New York apartment and find sleek Marcel Breuer chairs of cane and tubular steel, elegant tulipshaped wineglasses, or handsome sofas covered in Haitian cotton.

title: Antiinflation Spotlight on Fed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  The 11 men and one woman who sit on the Federal Reserve System's highest policymaking council, the Federal Open Market Committee, are suddenly spearheading the Government's. antiinflation assault.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: In a letter to The Times published June 2, 1974, I wrote that the reemergence of Teng Hsiaoping should be seen as prelude to his return to leadership and as Chou Enlai's last supreme act of statesmanship in bequeathing a peaceful transition to his country. In a later letter (10,113/76) I wrote that with Mao's departure the radicals would be easily defeated and Chou's disciples become the Church Fathers. Shortly thereafter, the Gang of Four were arrested and Chou's successors seized power and began at once to carry out his program for rapid modernization.

title: Women's Political Gains in States Are Expected to Spread to Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  When state legislatures reconvene, women will hold more than 10 percent of the seats for the first time in history. Ten women will be serving as secretaries of state, six as lieutenant governors and six as state treasurers.

title: Connecticut Tax Aide Quitting
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 15 (AP)  Gerald J. Heffernan is quitting his job as State Tax Commissioner to rejoin a Bridgeport insurance firm.

title: BUSINESS
description: Heating oil prices are soaring, and the coming winter probably will be the costliest in history as a result. Retail prices of No. 2 have jumpedas much as 4 cents a gallon in two months, the biggest advance since the aftermath of the Middle East oil embargo. With the cold weather just beginning, further price increases are on the way, say oil specialists. [Page Al.]

title: Hilton Hotel Executive Honored
description: The Broadway Association yesterday honored Alphonse W. Salomone, senior vice president of the Hilton Hotels Corporation and chairman of the Council of Midtown Associations, for his tireless efforts on behalf of New York City.

title: Cutbacks Expected at Hospitals
description: Some thinning out of the staffs at some of the New York City's 17 municipal hospitals is expected within the next several weeks, a spokesman for the Health and Hospitals Corporation said last night. Ed Silverman. the corporation's director of public affairs, said that refining as well as thinning out of personnel was expected within the framework of the corporation's efforts at decentralization.

title: U.S. Leads Efforts to Oust Somoza And Lead Nicaragua to Democracy
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 15  The United States, having helped keep the Somoza family in power in Nicaragua for four decades, is now deeply involved in trying to force President Anastasio Somoza Debayle to resign and replace him with a stable democratic government.

title: PEEKSKILL SEEKING SOLIDWASTE PLANT
description: PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 15  In a departure from the attitude of most Westchester communities, this city in the northern part of the county said today that it would welcome a solidwaste disposal and electrical generation plant if it provided cheap power for industrial development.

title: The Celtics' New Motivator
description: In professional sports, the Boston Celtics have long been known as a team heavily bound to tradition. Since Red Auerbach retired as the coach in 1966, the Celtics have been led by Bill Russell. Tom Heinsohn, Tom Sanders and now David William Cowens, all Celtics' plavers. Only Russell. and Man in the News now Coweni, have been playing coaches in the 32year history of the franchise. When Cowens took over the team Tuesday afternoon, the Celtics had a 212 wonlost record in the Atlantic Division of the National Basketball Association, unacceptable in the Celtics tradition, which boasts 13 championships.

title: NuclearAttack Plan Calls for New Yorkers To Retreat to Upstate
description: Uncle Sam wants you  in the case of imminent nuclear attack  to head for Sullivan County if you live in Manhattan and have a car (260,000 residents) or, you do not (970,000 residents), to one of five other counties perhaps in the Utica area  by bus. rail or water.

title: Music: Kuerti in Second Beethoven Sonata Series
description: ALTHOUGH Franz Schubert, who died 150 years ago this month, is the composer getting the lion's share of special attention these days, the 92d Street Young Men'sYoung Women's Hebrew Association apparently decided that Beethoven, who died a year earlier than Schubert, was still worth featuring in a series of eight recitals devoted to the 32 piano sonatas.

title: Suburbs Face More of Ills Already Troubling Cities
description: When The New York Times interviewed thousands of suburbanites in the Ncw York area recently, it found that significant proportion of them particularly the young  felt their communities were becoming worse places in which to live and more like bie cities.

title: Deaths
description: SCHOFF  Helen Noose. On November 14, 1978. Wife of James S. Schott, Sr. Mother of James S.. Jr. and Peter M., Sr. Grandmother of Susan J., Elizabeth H., James L., Hilary A. and Peter M., Jr. Memorial service Friday 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue at 81 St. In lieu of flowers a contribution to Copley Hospital Development Fund. Morrisville, Vt. 05661 would be ao0reciated.

title: Buying Furniture? Look for the Byline
description: IF the activity in certain showrooms is telling, furniture is going the way of clothing and cologne, as more and more wellknown designers put their names on collections.

title: How to Pot A Begonia
description: Begonias require a light pointing mixture that drains well. The following recipe is a good one:

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets on Cyprus question3 P.M.

title: Flight From the Farms and Rapid Industrialization Tormenting Iran
description: NAZARABAD, Iran, Nov. 14  Ali Dasagir received his 20acre plot under a landreform program decreed by Shah Mohammed Rizzi Pahlevi 15 years ago.

title: Deaths
description: DELSON  Theodcre U. The Members & Board of Directors of the Men's Club of Congregation EmanuEI of the City of New York note with sorrow the passing of our past president. We extend our deepest condolences to his bereaved family.

title: Notes on People
description: Malcolm Forbes said yesterday that he had paid a record $85,000 for the handwritten log of the copilot of the Enola Gay, which dropped the first atomic bomb on Hiroshima Aug. 6, 1945. The document, bought from the Elsie 0. and Phillip Sang Foundation of Chicago in an auction at Sotheby Parke Bernet galleries in New York, will be added to the Forbes magazine manuscript collection.

title: Plywood Case: Damage Action
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 15 (AP) The nation's three biggest manufacturers of plywood, having been convicted of conspiring to fix prices, now face another Federal court trial to determine the amount of damages.

title: Business Records
description: Petition Flied By:

title: RollsRoyce Winner
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 15 (AP) Nicholas R. Wilson's skill at dealing in stock options earned him a 1971 Silver Shadow RollsRoyce from his grateful client, Roger M. Haendiges. Last summer Mr. Haendiges told Mr. Wilson that if he could turn $500,000 profit in the next six months. Mr. Haendiges would give him his RollsRoyce. At the time, Mr. Wilson had already made $250,000 for Mr. Haendiges. Mr. Wilson, an Englishman, did not need the six months. He simply stepped up the pace of operations on the options market and cleared the $500,000 profit in less than three months.

title: Moro's Home in Rome Robbed
description: ROME, Nov. 15 (UPI)  Burglars broke into the home of the family of Aldo Moro, the political leader who had been slain by terrorists, and stole two watches and a necktie clip, the police said today.

title: Associated Press, TM New York Times
description: AMERICAN AIRLINES QUITS CITY: Albert V. Casey, president of American Airlines, telling reporters here that the company will move to Dallas. Mayor Koch called the move a betrayal of New York City. Page D19.

title: A New Turn in the Old West Side Highway
description: A jogger running along the closed section of the West Side Highway near the World Trade Center yesterday became  for the time it took him cover about two blocks  another element in a series of shapes and lines painted on the timeand tireworn pavement. Viewed from the higher offices of the Twin Towers the horizontal mural is seen as a repeating pattern of light and dark chevrons. As the controversial Westway project looms in the future, the old roadway has become not only a medium for street artists, but a haven for joggers, strollers and cyclists.

title: Musical, 'sweeney Todd, Due on Broadway Feb.
description: Sweeney Todd, a new musical starring Angela Lansbury and Len Cariou, will open at the Uris Teater on Feb. 19. Previews will begin Jan. 23.

title: Moscow Clears Way for Parents To Take Their Sick Baby to U.S.
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 15  Boris and Natalya Kats, a Jewish couple who battled for a year to get their sick baby, Jessica, to the United States for medical treatment, were notified today that they could pick up their exit visas and leave by Dec. 4.

title: Sound
description: HAVING delivered a rather fulminant sermon against the folly of excess power last week, let me reverse the coin and argue the importance of having enough power and suggest ways to determine how much power is enough.

title: Suit Over Funds Seeks to Oust CORE Leader
description: A dissident faction in the Congress of Racial Equality contended yesterday that the group's national chairman, Roy Innis, unlawfully diverted organization funds and conducted organization meetings in secret.

title: And After the Ali Era Ends
description: Not counting the punch that Billy Martin threw at newspaperman in Reno the other night, the sweet science of fighting suffered some sour and even sad moments last week. They remind us that, except for the huge paydays for some of the fighters, not many redeeming qualities are left from the oncebright era of Muhammad Ali.

title: PEKING, IN A SHIFT, IS SEEKING U.N. AID
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15 China, in a shift away from its traditional policy of selfreliance, is actively seeking United Nations help for economic development.

title: U.S. Says Cuba Receives Advanced Soviet Planes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  The Carter Administration announced today that Cuba had received advanced fighter planes from the Soviet Union. But officials said that the aircraft did not have the capability to deliver nuclear weapons against the United States.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAHAM  David, Passed away on November 14, 1978 beloved son of Andrea and James Abraham. Grandson of Helene and Alexander Abraham and Harriet and Martin Strongin. Services at The StanetskySchlossberg Solomon Memorial Chapels, 1648 Beacon St. Brookline, Mass Wednesday November 15, 1978 at 12 Noon. In lieu of flowers donations appreciated to the Jimmy Fund, Childrens Hospital, Boston Mass.

title: Carter Mourns Anthropologist
description: Margaret Mead, the anthropologist, author, lecturer and social critic, died yesterday at New York Hospital after a yearlong battle with cancer. She was 76 years old.

title: Bus Shelter Contract Held Up by Objections From Transport Panel
description: A chief stumbling block to a proposed contract to build 4,100 bus shelters throughout the city has been the Department of Transportation's objections to 50 percent of the proposed sites for the shelters, the Board of Estimate was told at its executive session yesterday.

title: Aide Says HolmesAli Is Possible
description: The attorney for Larry Holmes said yesterday that the World Boxing Council's heavyweight champion was not under contract to Don King and thus would be free for a fight with Muhammad Ali.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: EARLY SEASON One of midtown's most dependable dropin spots, the compactly attractive Kodak Photo Gallery, has opened a beguiling new exhibition, The Story of Christmas, using 150 photographs, artifacts, slide shows and movies to depict celebrations around the globe. One section traces the history of the Christmas tree, from the holly bush symbol of the Dark Ages to the present.

title: Squash Court, Sweet Squash Court
description: PRINCETON FOR an outoftheway structure renovated into your morethangardenvariety living establishment, there is always the converted barn.

title: 15 YecaOld With 13 Prior Arrests Facing Indictment for Rape of it
description: A 15yearold Brooklyn youth with 13 prior arrests, six prior convictions and record of six escapes is to be indicted in Manhattan today for the rape of a 15yearold girl on the Upper East Side last October.

title: Around the Nation
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 (AP) Damage claims totaling more than $2.64 billion have been filed against the Federal Government and more are expected as the Dec. 16 deadline nears for claims stemming from the 1976 swine flu immunization program.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: GIFT HORSE: Sonsam, shown in one of his 14 victories,was syndicated yesterday by Morton Finder for a record $3 million.

title: Sindona Loses In Court Ruling
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that Michele Sindona, the Italian financier, could be extradited to Milan to face charges of fraudulent bankruptcy there.

title: Protection for Reporter
description: ANCHORAGE, Nov. 15 (AP)  A reporter for the Anchorage Daily News, Bob Porterfield, need not disclose his sources or turn over his notes to defense attorneys in a fraud trial, a Superior Court judge has ruled.

title: SCHOOLS CRITICIZED AT INDIAN MEETING
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 15  Participants in the National Indian Child Conference, a threeday meeting that opened this week, have spent much of that time in heated debate over the major issue before it: whether to scrap the Bureau of Indian Affairs boarding school system, root and branch.

title: Agreement Is Reached On Terms of City Loan
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation and all parties to New York City's $4.5 billion financing plan reached final agreement late yesterday afternoon on terms and conditions of the first series of loans to meet the city's need for cash.

title: Books: 'seizure, True Story of Recovery From a Brain Tumor
description: IN TERMS of public discussion or research effort, the most slighted major form of cancer is probably the brain tumor. Perhaps publicrelations campaign ought to be waged to get it more attention. Maybe if It were renamed the GershwinGunther dancer after those two illustrious victims  George Gershwin and the 16yearold son of John Gunther this neglected ailment might get the attention it needs.

title: Slain School Principal Is Said to Have Had Criminal Links
description: NEWARK, Nov. 15  Authorities investigating the ganglandstyle killing of a 35yearold Newark high school principal on Nov. 1, believe he was involved with the underworld, and they are seeking clues that could link the slaying to gambling and drug trafficking, according to Essex County law enforcement officials here.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Frontal band of clouds Is moving slowly northward from the Middle Atlantic states. more extensive area of multilayered clouds covers much of the Midwest with highest clouds over Arkansas. A new surge of moisture shows up as a swirling cloud pattern the Pacific Northwest. Scattered fair weather cumulus clouds prevail over the Southwestern states.

title: Talking Business
description: ST. LOUIS

title: Disks: Turangabla by Messiaen
description: OLIVIER MESSIAEN'S position in posterity's musical hierarchy is by no means clear. Throughout his long life this leading French avantgarde composer has been both honored and scorned. He's been honored for his demonstrable independence and integrity, his undeniable contributions to the vocabulary and direction of new music and his role as teacher to the likes of Stockhausen and Boulez. He's been scorned for that same independence, for an unfashionable opulence and innocence of expression that run counter to the astringent austerity so popular among the composers of the last three decades, in this country especially.

title: Michigan High Court Won't Bar Scrutiny Of a Reporter's Notes
description: LANSING, Mich., Nov. 15 (UPI)  The Michigan Supreme Court rejected a plea today by The Traverse City RecordEagle to prevent a prosecutor from examining a reporter's notes from a jailhouse interview with an accused murderer.

title: IRAN'S OIL WORKERS STAGING SLOWDOWN
description: AHWAZ. Iran, Nov. 15  Despite official assertions by the National Iranian Oil Company that production has steadily increased, striking workers in this center of Iran's oil industry say that many Iranian workers have stayed home over the last two days and that those who have reported to their jobs have done little or no work at all.

title: S.E.C. Softens Disclosure Proposals on Directors
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  Stung by the vigorous opposition of the business Fommunity, the Securities and Exchange Commission softened and rejected today portions of its wideranging proposals aimed at forcing companies to disclose new information to shareholders about the quality and effectiveness of corporate boards of directors.

title: Auxiliary Police Recruiting Assailed
description: The New York City Police Department has begun a recruitment drive aimed at doubling the strength the 4,000member auxiliary force, but the move being criticized by the city's Patrolmen's Benevolent ARsociation.

title: The Riches of Rag Rugs
description: BEFORE Sister Parrish began using them a lot and Angelo Donghia covered an overstuffed armchair with one, the rag rug occupied relatively low rung on the ladder of livingroom status symbols. But that is not to say that these colorful pieceworks of castoff curtains and clothes haven't always had their admirers. They have. And Eve Olsan, Finnish weaver extraordinaire, now living and working in New York, is an ardent one.

title: 3 Children in Queens Badly Burned in Fire
description: Three Queens children were gravely burned when flames raced through their apartment last night while their mother left them unattended and visited their grandmother the notice renorted.

title: 23 on River Ferry Drown in India
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 15 (UPI)  Officials said 23 persons drowned in northeast India when a ferry sank today on the Balan River in Begusarai District of Bihar state. Others among the 50 passengers swamp ashore, the Press Trust of India reported.

title: Jaffrey Dances Parade
description: IF Robert Joffrey had done nothing more than revive the Diaghilev period Parade, dance audiences would be in his debt. The Leonide Massine ballet received its first performance of the season on Tuesday at the City Center and, despite recent talk of its wearying sets and costumes, Parade remains as pungent as fresh paint and as witty a ballet as would be expected from a creative triumvirate like Picasso, Cocteau and Satie.

title: The Art of Crafts Caught on Film
description: ACANNIBAL craftsman from New Guinea carves out an ancestor pole; a Korean potter constructs a monumental vessel for the storage of pickled vegetables; an English glass blower blows yardofale, a 36inch trumpetshaped container for beverages. These craftsmen and otners are reatured in tne Third International Craft Film Festival, sponsored by New York State Craftsmen.

title: SaxonEgypt Pact
description: Saxon Industries announced a joint venture to manufacture photocopiers in Alexandria, Egypt. The company said it was forming a subsidiary, the Saxon Egypt Company, under an Egyptian law designed to encourage investment in Egypt. Saxon Industries will provide the expertise and technology required to design and construct the photocopier facility. The copier will be marketed and serviced by an Egyptian distribution company throughout the Middle East.

title: Douglas H. Brown, at 62, Served As Health Officer in Westchester
description: CAPE ELIZABETH, Me, Nov. 15  Dr. Douglas H. Brown, former deputy commissioner of health in Westchester County, N.Y., and former Health Director of the city of Portland, died in his home here Monday. He was 62 years old.

title: Appeals Court Hears Argument On Contempt Case Against Bell
description: Arguments on a contempt citation against Attorney General Griffin B. Bell were heard by a Federal appellate court yesterday in the Socialist Workers Party's $40 million suit against the Federal Bureau of Investigation and other government aeencies.

title: Corporate Earnings Are Reported for the Quarter
description: For period$ a$ shown. (N) indicafe$ stock i$ listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) over thecounter.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Columbia, Gottschalk; Fanfares, Mouret; Mouvement Perpetual No. 1, Poulenc; Evening in Georgia, IppolitovIvanov; Odieu mes amours, Des Pres; Norwegian Dance No. 1 in D minor, Grieg; Kikimora, Lladov.

title: KOCH WANTS CITY U. BUT NOT THE COSTS
description: Mayor Koch has told the Board of Higher Education that he will oppose attempts to merge the city and state university systems, but he has asked its support of a proposal that would transfer the total operating and capital costs of the City University's fouryear colleges to the state, according to members of the board.

title: U.S. Revises Agreement On Westinghouse Bribes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP)  The Government today withdrew its promise to conceal the identity of a foreign official alleged to have received 1322,000 in bribes from the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

title: Economists Warn on Guidelines
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UPI) President Carter's voluntary wageprice guidelines will fail and unemployment may jump to 7 percent next year, pessimistic private economists told Congressional hearing today.

title: Sutherland Ticket Sale Slated
description: Remaining tickets for the joint concert by Joan Sutherland and Luciano Pavarotti at Avery Fisher Hall on Jan. 22 will go on sale at the box office next Sunday at noon. The available tickets are $30, those at other prices having been sold out. The program of duets and arias will be accompanied by an orchestra directed by Richard Bonyinge.

title: U.S. Finds French Offer Restrictive
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15State Department officials said today they have been told that the French offer to accept the passengers on the Hai Hong was highly nualified and restrictive.

title: 2 Studies Find Violations In New Generic Drug Act
description: Pharmacists are widely violating the state's generic drug substitution law, depriving the public of estimated millions of dollars in anticipated savings, two consumer agencies charged yesterday.

title: HighGrade Utilities Off In Yield
description: An issue of highgrade utility bonds was offered to investors yesterday at a yield of 9.30 percent, a rate onequarter of 1 percent lower than the yield on similar bonds marketed two weeks ago. Investors nevertheless quickly bought the $100 million offering, and the bonds rose to a small premium in price.

title: Q & A
description: Q. We have moved into a house in which all the bedrooms were papered and then, apparently, painted over. Now the paper is coming away in places and some of the patterns are showing through. We would like to remove all the paper and start from scratch, but a wallpaper steamer just does not work on this material. Is there a method you can suggest?  D. R. Y., New Orleans.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 15  This essay is intended for the eyes only of professional speechwriters; its purpose is to illustrate the latest techniques in weaselwording.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 15 (AP)  An armed man tried to hijack a Soviet airliner during a domestic flight near the Iranian and Turkish borders, but security guards foiled the attempt and killed him, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.

title: Kahn Cautions On Depression
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  Alfred E. Kahn, the Government's chief inflation fighter, warned today that the nation faced a deep, deep depression or mandatory wageandprice controls the President's voluntary inflation program failed to curb rising prices.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Berkey Photo Inc. has formed a new Technical Group to include Berkey Technical U.S., Berkey Colortran U.S., Berkey Colortran U.K., Berkey Technical U.K., and Berkey Technical A/ Denmark companies, and named Peter T. Coe president of the new group. Mr. Coe will also be general manager of Berkey Technical U.S.

title: Margin Debt Down Sharply
description: Investors debt to New York Stock Exchange member firms plunged by $310 million in October as the stock market's decline eroded portfolio values and forced sales of stock to cover loans, the exchange said yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Vornado Inc., operator of the Two Guys discount store chain and other stores, announced plans yesterday for two hotelcasinos on land owned by the company in Atlantic City. Vornado said it would present its preliminary proposal to the Atlantic City Planning board in a preapplication meeting.

title: JARVIS GAVE T0 138 IN CONGRESS RACES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  Howard Jarvis, coauthor of California's Proposition 13, contributed to 138 Congressional campaigns after demanding that candidates sign up in support of his plan to cut $100 billion in Federal spending in order to get his help.

title: Malaysia Wary of Refugees
description: PORT KLANG, Malaysia, Nov. 15 (AP)  Despite a personal appeal from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Malaysia decided today to force a freighter packed with 2,500 Vietnamese to leave its waters.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Improves Broadly; Gold Falls $5 an Ounce
description: The dollar continued to improve against major world currencies in New York and European currency trading yesterday while the price of gold dropped by $5 an ounce. beaters said trading in currency markets remained calm as it has been all week and the dollar's modest gains apparently were made with little help needed from government central banks pledged to support President Carter's rescue plan for the ailing dollar.

title: Books: A Literary Journalist
description: NONA BALAICIAN describes herself as a literary journalist, meaning that for the last quartercentury and more she has been a workaday book reviewer, interviewer, essayist and editor whose product has appeared largely in the oaees of The New York Times. But on the testimony of this book, a collection of her pieces, she is also a bellelettrist critic of keen perceptiveness, unusual sensitivity and serious concern who possesses an agreeable style.

title: Tree Ornaments Making an Early Bow
description: CHRISTMAS is being celebrated early this year at the Museum of Contemporary Crafts and for a very good reason. The collection of Christmas tree ornaments on exhibit in their little secondfloor gallery will journey to Washington on Dec. 1 to hang on the tree in the grand foyer of the VicePresidential mansion.

title: Sportsysterns Bid
description: Niagara Frontier Services Inc. and the Sportsystems Corporation, both of Buffalo, announced the withdrawal by Sportsystems of its proposal to acquire Niagara Frontier for $79.5 million and the termination of merger discussions.

title: U.S. Industrial Output Climbed 0.5% in October
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP)  Output of the nation's industry expanded by a healthy 0.5 percent in October as the economy continued to perform at a level that gave no indication of an impending slowdown, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: 40,000 in Suffolk Sign Petitions on Tax Relief
description: AMITYVILLE, L.I., Nov. 15  Petitions bearing the names of 40,000 Suffolk County taxpayers seeking to eliminate the school property tax and require the state to pay for public education through the state income tax were presented today to Assemblymanelect Louis T. Howard, a Republican and member of the Suffolk County Legislature.The signatures were gathered by group called the Citizens for Tax Relief.

title: Deaths
description: CHESTER  Mack, beloved husband of Esther, devoted father of Rosalyn Myles, Isabelle Katzman, Syma Yet Iln & Barbera Diane Palumbo, lovInd grandfather & great grandtaftk er. Services today 9:30AM. West End Funeral Chapel. 1283 Coney Island Ave, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Price Is Soaring For Heating Oil; Inventories Low
description: Heating oil prices are soaring. In two months, No. 2 oil, the lighter grade of boiler fuel that is commonly burned in homes and small apartment buildings, has jumped nationwide by as much as cents a gallon and now retails for up to 55 cents a gallon in some areas.

title: Analysis Shows 3 of 4 Youngsters Avoid Adult Court System
description: Charges against three of every four teenagers arrested in New York City under the state's twomonthold stricter juvenile justice law have been dismissed or transferred from adult Criminal Court to the Family Court, an analysis of court records by The New York Times has found.

title: Oil Imports Down
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (Reuters) United States oil imports for the first 10 months of this year were 10.5 percent below last year's level, the American Petroleum Institute reported today.

title: S.B.A. Delays Criticized
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  Some minority broadcasters today complained that the Small Business Administration had dragged its feet in a program of loans originally intended to help minorities buy broadcasting stations.

title: About New York
description: Like every other status in this city, being poor must have its ceremony, too. And so, back from the crumbling blockfront of Fulton Street in eastern Brooklyn, it is time for Geraldine Swindell, a chronic welfare recipient, to clear her throat and present small plaques of gratitude to the people at the Nevins welfare center who keep the checks coming.

title: SHIPPING/MAILS
description: ATLANTIC CHAMPAGNE (AtlanticContalnef ). Le Havre Nov. 21, Rotterdam 25 and Southampton 2A; sails from Pt. Elizabeth, N.J.

title: Hers
description: ONE evening, wheril came off the New YorktoWashington shuttle, I found myself an exuberant African student's very first cab customer. lie drove with abandon, bouncing up and down, half singing to me and to the whole world, I love to drive the motorcar oh, I love to drive the motorcar!

title: Bridge:
description: Since bridge is an activity of the mind, it is perhaps appropriate that bridge players should focus their charitable efforts in the field of mental health. The Charity Foundation of the American Contract Bridge League recently announced that the Mental Health Association would be its principal beneficiary for the second consecutive year.

title: RIGHTS UNITS BATTLE OVER ALABAMA CASE
description: Three national civil rights organizations are moving toward an open courtroom fight over who should handle a wellpublicized Alabama rape case.

title: Gerard Gets Delay On Prison Term
description: Dr. Mark Gerard was granted a long postponement yesterday of a oneyear prison term that he received for a conviction in a horseswitching scandal.

title: Mondale's Future
description: WASHINGTONThe results of the 1978 election made Walter Mondale into a lameduck Vice President.

title: Japan Cuts Its Trade Surplus
description: TOKYO, Nov. 15  Japan trimmed its politically troublesome worldwide trade surplus in October to $1.535 billion from $2.09 billion in September and its surplus against the United States to $793 million from $1.035 billion.

title: Van Truex: Designer And Catalyst
description: IMAGINE this. Your telephone rings. Tiffany's Walter Hoving is on the wire. He says: Come over here to Tiffany. Tell us what is beautiful. We don't want anything in here that you don't approve of. And, by the way, don't give a thought to what it costs or how sells.

title: Amtrak Won't Meet Speed Goal
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  Bedeviled by rising costs and sinking hopes for a quick turnaround, Amtrak now concedes that only some of its 58 daily trains between Washington and New York will attain a muchpublicized goal of twohour 40minute schedules between the two cities in 1981.

title: NEW & USEFUL
description: Coffee lovers, perk up! There's good news. It's no longer necessary to settle for instant coffee when you're too lazy to brew just one cup in a pot. There's now a goldplated mesh filter set into a plastic vessel that sits right on your cup and permits you to make fresh coffee by the drip method anywhere anytime. All you need is finely ground coffee and boiling water. It's great for traveling, for the office, even for the home when a pot of coffee is too much trouble. The filter, called Rittergold, comes with a plastic lid that doubles as a trivet. It's $9 at BaileyHuebner in Henri Bendel. A word of warning: The directions for use that come in the package are more confusing than helpful. Just use common sense, and it's simplicity itself.

title: A Pioneer and an Innovator
description: If anthropology is a window on human nature in all its expressions, Margaret Mead not only kept that window open, but also enlarged it immeasurably and invited millions to look through it with her. She taught many that the most revealing window often a mirror.

title: Trotter Leaves Post In Split Over Policy
description: Tommy Trotter, who shaped the kind of races New York horseplayers bet on, resigned yesterday as racing secretary for the state's three major thoroughbred tracks.

title: Missing Plane Found in Maine
description: NEWRY, Me., Nov. 15 (AP) Searchers today located a small plane that crashed in remote, mountainous western Maine on Friday, killing all six persons aboard. The victims, who were flying from Canada to Pennsylvania, were identified as Peter Smith, 22 years old, of St. John, New Brunswick, the pilot; Thomas Soucy, 35, also believed to be from New Brunswick; George Richardson, 33, of Williamsport, Pa., and James and Mary Payne and their 8yearold son Jeffrey, also of Williamsport.

title: PEACE TALK REVIEW RECESSED BY ISRAEL
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 15  Prime Minister Menachem Begin recessed a major Cabinet review of the state of the IsraeliEgyptian peace negotiations today until Israel has received clarification of Cairo's latest proposals.

title: Pirates' Parker M.V.P.
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 15 (AP)Dave Parker of the Pittsburgh Pirates was named the National League's most valuable player today. Shortly afterward, the Pirates pledged to keep him under contract and not allow him to become a free agent after next season.

title: Backgammon:
description: This last summer a major backgammon tournament for the benefit of the Children's Cancer Fund of America was held in Westhampton, L.I. Tanner Hirsch directed the event. Lila Swan was tournament coordinator.

title: Peru, Poor and Demoralized, Awaits End of Military Rule
description: LIMA. Peru, Nnv. 11  When the armed forces of Peru overthrew an elected civilian Government that was in its final months in office 10 years ago, they set out to transform their society through a revolution of the left declared to be neither caoitalist nor socialist.

title: WHITE HOUSE PLANS RISE TO $124 BILLION IN MILITARY BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  President Carter has tentatively decided to increase the military budget to nearly $124 billion next year in a move designed to strengthen the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and bolster American weaponry and equipment in Europe, Administration officials said today.

title: 76ers Set Back Nuggets in Overtime
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 (AP)Julius Erving scored 10 of his gamehigh 33 points in a fiveminute overtime period as the Philadelphia 76ers defeated the Denver Nuggets, 109103, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

title: Rights Group Charges Ethiopia With Torture of Its Prisoners
description: LONDON, Nov. 15 (AP)  Ethiopia's military Government is holding thousands of prisoners without trial in cramped, unsanitary conditions and has practiced torture and terror against its own citizens, a humanrights organization said today.

title: TV: Pearl, Series About Bombing
description: PEARL is yet another television exercise in transforming fact into a vehicle for melodrama. We have had, among other things, the Nazi haloratigt reduced to domestic soap opera.

title: Oil Deal Stirs Fight In Ottawa
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 15  A move by the Canadian Government to increase its share of the domestic oil business, field dominated by foreign private in terests up to now, has kicked off a poll t ical dispute.

title: Carter Urged to Shun Dukakis for Key Post
description: BOSTON, Nov. 15 (AP)  The Massachusetts Executive Council voted today to ask President Carter to keep. Gov. Michael S. Dukakis out of his Cabinet.

title: Neil Simon to Move Back to New York PartTime
description: WLOS ANGELES NEIL SIMON is moving back to New York  parttime. I miss New York for many reasons, the playwright, who abandoned his hometown for the California sun more than three years ago, said at a banquet in his honor sponsored this week by Delta Kappa Alpha, an honorary cinema fraternity. Without having been born there, I don't think I could have become a writer.

title: Sports Today
description: Knicks vs. Cavaliers, at Cleveland. (Television Channel 9, 8 P.M.)

title: Solaria Sunny Additions
description: BEFORE abandoning your terrace, porch or patio to the howling winter winds, consider enclosing a portion of the outdoor space with a glass or clearacrylic solarium. Solaria come in many sleek, standard sizes, are relatively inexpensive and are energy and snace efficient.

title: Parley Focuses on Social Changes in Birmingham
description: BIRMINGHAM, Nov. 15  At a reception here, Mayor David Vann reminded the Rev. Fred L. Shuttlesworth that before 1840 it was illegal to license black preachers in Alabama. Maybe they should have tried to stop you by taking your license away, joked Mr. Vann. who is white.

title: Texas Analysts Wonder if Gains By Republicans Will Be Lasting
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 15  When John F. Kennedy was President, Texas Republicans had a dream. They would build a coalition of conservative, middleclass, urban sophisticates and conservative, rural Democrats unhappy with Kennedy liberalism. With it, they would turn oneparty Texas into a twoparty state.

title: Home Improvement
description: ADOORBELL or chime is a convenience that most homeowners take for granted  until it fails to operate as it should.

title: Chile Under Mounting Pressure From Church on Human Rights
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 15  The Roman Catholic Church in Chile is putting increasing pressure on the military regime headed by President Augusto Pinochet over humanrights violations and labor restrictions.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Robert Cruikshank, an executive vice president and chief planning officer of Blyth Eastman Dillon & Company, the brokerage and investment banking firm, has resigned to become partner of E.F. Neild & Company, Chicago marketmaking concern. And thereby hangs a tale.

title: More Than Merely Power:
description: WI LLIAMSTOV/N, Mass.Countless Americans who won office for the first time on election day are savoring the moment when they will assume power. Most of them will be disapnninted.

title: France to Accept Some Vietnamese Refugees on Ship
description: PARIS, Nov. 15  The French Government offered today to accept qualified refugees among the 2,500 Vietnamese aboard a ship off the ;Malaysian coast after Malaysia decided that the vessel would have to leave.

title: Advertising
description: N OBODY knows who Charter Publishing is, said Peter A. Bonanni. And he has a particular interest in an informed public. After all, it's no fun being president of something nobody ever heard of.

title: The New York Times/ Neal Bonezi
description: At the Central Park Zoo, a baby llama, above, looks up at its mother, and a proud father keeps watch over newborn aoudad.

title: Gilzenberg, 77, Sports Promoter
description: William (Willie) L. Gilzenberg, a boxing and wrestling promoter in New Jersey for more than 60 years, died of cancer yesterday in the South Miami (Fla.) Hospital. lie was 77 years old.

title: Soldier Who Blew Taps to Signal End of World War IIs Dead at 83
description: DENISON, Tex., Nov. 15, (Reuter) The soldier who blew taps to signal the end of World War I has died here at the age of 83.

title: Calendar of Events: Japanese Folk Art
description: Folk Traditions in Japanese Art Exhibition, Japan House Gallery, 333 East 47th Street.

title: EARNINGS
description: Profits of several merchandising chains increased in the third fiscal quarter ended with October, reflecting higher sales, according to their results reported yesterday. The figures were fai more favorable than had been anticipated in view of rising interest expenditures and other operating costs and the public's shrinking purchasing power because of rampant inflation.

title: Flames 5, Wings 3
description: ATLANTA. Nov. 15 (AP)  Jean Pronovost and Willie Plett scored goals 46 seconds apart in the third period tonight to give the Atlanta Flames a 53 National Hockey League victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

title: WeaponsProgram Cost Drops
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP)  The cost of 53 major military weapons programs dropped by $399.5 million in the JulytoSeptember quarter, the Pentagon said today. The decrease was attributed largely to changes in the Navy's LAMPS antisubmarine warfare helicopter program. The quarterly report said that it would cost nearly $210.5 billion to complete the programs.

title: From Regent Street To East 60th
description: JOINING the recent stampede of foreign boutiques to Madison Avenue. a little bit of old England is coming to New York next Wednesday when Liberty of London will open a shop at 229 East 60th Street.

title: Entertainment Events
description: THE PLAYBOY OF THE WEEKEND WORLD, solo entertainment with Ernlyn Williams. Directed by Peter Woodthorpe. At the Playhouse Theater, 3S7 Westl8th Street, at 7.

title: San Francisco Vexed by a CableCar Strike
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15  The romantic image that attracts so many visitors to this port and reassures residents of the city's preeminence was shaken today because of a wildcat strike by cablecar operators that shut down all three lines.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WEMBLEY, England, Nov. 15 (AP)  John McEnroe, Dick Stockton and Stan Smith of the United States posted secondround victories today in the $175,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament at the Empire Pool.

title: Steingut Aide Due for State Post
description: Michael J. DelGiudice, secretary to Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut, is almost certain to join Governor Carey's administration in a highlevel post, probably as State Director of Operations, aides close to Mr. Carey's office said yes. terday.

title: Deaths
description: LIEBERMAN  Charles. In Miami Beach. Devoted husband of Rose. Dear brother of Bernard Lieberman and Matilda (Tillie) Halle and the late Nathan and Isadore Lieberman Services Thursday, 1:15PM, Park west Chapel, 115 West 79 St, NYC.

title: Sadat Concedes a Crisis
description: CAIRO, Nov. 15  President Anwar elSadat conceded today that Egypt's peace negotiations with Israel were undergoing a difficult crisis but added that he would keep striving to achieve a peace, treaty.

title: Cabaret: Frances Faye
description: FRANCES FAYE. still a brash breath of 52d Street when it was a welter of singers, comedians. jazz musicians and strippers, is back in town for the first time in three years. pounding her Piano. shouting out songs in a voice that has mellowed only slightly with the years and mixing bits and pieces in a craftily calculated disarray.

title: Catholic Bishops Oppose Change In Church's Communion Practice
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) Roman Catholic bishops showed strong opposition today to a change that would make the church's communion more like that of Protestant churches and the Eastern Orthodoxy.

title: DOW DENIES A ROLE IN FISH POISONINGS
description: MIDLAND, Mich. Nov. 15  The Dow Chemical Company today said that traces of highly poisonous chemicals found in fish caught near its plant here had come from natural causes and had not leaked from the plant's herbicide and pesticide operations.

title: New York Aides Fear Drastic Steps Are Necessary to Solve Budget Gap
description: I don't see us making it unless something drastic occurs, Carol Bellamy, the City Council President, said in an interview. We need extraordinary remedies, and we don't have them in hand.

title: Kuwait Aids St. Luke's Hospital
description: Kuwait has granted $1 million to St. Luke's Hospital Center to endow a professorship in metabolism and nutrition, the center, a teaching affiliate of the Columbia University Medical School, announced yesterday.

title: New Airlines vs. Lack of Space
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  New Government policies designed to increase competition in the airline industry may soon be undercut by a shortage of planes and a scarcity of airport facilities, the chief of the Federal Aviation Administration said today. The F.A.A. is responsible for enforcing flight safety regulations.

title: Dropped by Department, He Faces Four Years
description: An offduty New York City police officer who was sitting in his car fighting with his wife on West 83d Street jumped out and assaulted a Consolidated Edison security officer without provocation, according to an indictment announced yesterday by Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney.

title: Columbia Surprises Hartwick in Soccer
description: Taking advantage of Hartwick's conservative play, Columbia eliminated the defending national champions from the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament yesterday with a 32 victory at Baker Field. The Lions will face St. Francis of Brooklyn next in the New York regional title game.

title: On Laying Murders to Rest
description: If the United States keeps reopening investigations of the assassination of President Kennedy, a New Republic writer recently suggested, well then let Italy reopen an inquiry into the assassination of Julius Caesar. Whose word do we have anyhow that Caesar said Et tu, Brute!'? If he said no such thing the whole story is wide open. Such acid comment was prompted by the House Assassinations Committee and was surely justified by the way it began investigating the murders of John Kennedy and Martin Luther King Jr. and the conspiracy theories generated by both. Poisonous feuds and lurid leaks soon made the committee look even more irresponsible than the fearful fantasies.

title: The Region
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I. (AP)  The Suffolk County Legislature voted 13 to 5 to let an air cargo company fly pregnant cattle out of Westhampton airport to Iran and other Middle Eastern countries. Five communities near the airport had objected because they said the county would have to spend about $600,000 to get airport runways in shape and because they feared excessive noise. The air cargo company, Skylfit Internatinal, said the project would create local jobs and bring the county $300,000 in revenue over five years. He said pregnant cows were flown out because it was a convenient way to ship two cows and because the company was paid for two cows if one was preg.

title: BoysGirls High Eases Troubles With Transfers
description: In an effort to improve conditions at beleagured Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn, the Board of Education has been sending students from the school to neighboring schools, which are now reporting overcrowding and security problems  the same troubles that plagued Boys and Girls High last spring.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: WHEN he was a small D0y, he liked being on his brother's sailboat; the thought, when the boat was becalmed, that eventually there would be wind and then more wind rpaccured him about the future. He made a new best friend and was put off when he met the boy's parents, to find that the mother was taller than the father. At mass in church, he practiced separating the fingers of each hand alternately twoandtwo, then onetoone.

title: Miracle on 34th Street: SelfHelp Decorating
