description: L IVING with nature on 34th Street is how Tim and Dagny Du Val describe their life in the factory building they renovated between Ninth and Tenth Avenues. The first floor is a forest of exotic plants and trees, the ground floor of their business, Plant Specialists. The second floor is office space for their firm; the third is the living floor, shared with two Himalayan cats. On the roof are spillover plants, a small potting shed and a chicken coop housing a bantam rooster and five hens that provide fresh eggs.

title: Economic Scene
description: AS a prophet Robert Triffin, F. W. Beinecke Professor of Economics at Yale, is not without honor in his own profession  or even in the anxietyridden world of central bankers, where dire forecast is often regarded as an act of treason.

title: Music: Bright New Trio
description: CHAMBER music is one of the experimental arts. New constellations of instrumentalists are continually getting together, forming hopeful but necessarily tentative alliances and then, more often than not, breaking apart. in a music capital such as New York there is a ceaseless realigning of talent as musicians flutter about in search of just the right combination of talents, temperaments and tastes. At rare intervals, some fortunate grouping turns out to have all the ingredients in the proper proportions and we see the birth of a Budapest, a Juilliard, a Guarneri, a Beaux Arts.

title: Auctions
description: THE decorative arts of this century frequently rival in design, technical innovation and sophistication those of the Renaissance through the 18th century. This season auctions in this country and abroad are chockfull of some of the most refined, witty or imaginative examples of both Art Nouveau and Art Deco furnishings, accessories, posters and jewelry. The sale last night by Christie, Manson & Woods in Geneva of H. Robert Greene's extraordinary collection of rarities  Art Deco clocks by Cartier, precious hardstone objects and jewelry  will be followed tomorrow afternoon and evening by another stunning event, conducted this time by Sotheby Parke Bernet in Monaco. This auction boasts a gem of a bronze dore lamp sculpture by Raoul Larche, depicting LoYe Fuller in her dance of the veils (it may sell for $10,000 to $15,000), numerous Wiener Werkstatte and Georges Fouquet jewelry designs, ceramic figurines by Georg Klimt and a barrel of glorious colorwashed French art glass by Emile Galle, Rene Lalique and G. D'ArgyRousseau.

title: Governor Frees Jailed Teacher Who Led 53Day Long Island Strike
description: Governor Carey yesterday commuted the 20day jail sentence of the president of the teachers union that for 53 days struck the Levittown School District on Long Island.

title: Two Soviet Astronauts Reported To Readjust Quickly to Gravity
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 16  A Soviet medical expert reported today that the two Soviet astronauts who completed the recordbreaking 140day space flight Nov. 2 had readapted quickly to the earth's gravity and had suffered no significant physical disabilities.

title: STUDIES ON CANCER CALLED INACCURATE
description: BOSTON, Nov. 16 (AP)  Yale researchers who studied cancer of the uterus say that earlier studies linking the disease to estrogen pills were based on inaccurate research with a builtin bias toward finding cancer.

title: Bridgeport Authorities Begin Patrol ofStreets In ArsonWave Battle
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 16  A score of police cars prowl the quiet streets in the postmidnight hours here, and officers stop hundreds of pedestrians and motorists in an effort to halt a wave of arson that has taken four lives this month.

title: More Civilians Named to Cabinet
description: TEHERAN, Nov. 16 (Reuters) Iran's military Prime Minister, Gen. Gholam Riza Azhari, named eight more civilians today to his 11dayold Cabinet.

title: Books: Beyond Fundamentalism
description: EVANGELICALS, 40 million strong, represent the largest and most vigorous bloc of American Christians. Even though their numbers had been swelling and their influence mounting for two decades, it was the candidacy of Jimmy Carter, an avowed born again Southern Baptist, that put them on the map.

title: The Temple and the Obelisk
description: This is not another Upstairs, Downstairs, but an Inside, Outside saga taking place at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Enshrined at the museum in a glassenclosed new wing that appears to be about the size of football field is the recently unveiled and longawaited Temple of Dendur. This tiny temple is modest as Egyptian monuments go, notable chiefly for its smallscale beauty and delicate detail. It now stands on a vast, stony, indoor plaza under a protective enclosure, alone in a stark setting. But Dendur is safe for the ages.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: Below 42d Street

title: The New York Times/D. Gorton
description: WATERWORKS DISPLAY: New York City's Firefighter, right, was joined by sister fireboats yesterday as she marked her 40th year in service. The world's biggest and busiest fireboat, she is a veteran of New York Harbor's worst fires, including those on the liner Normandie in 1992 and the aircraft carrier Constellation in 1960.

title: New Juvenile Unit on Rikers: A View From Within
description: They are the anonymous children of the streets, given dubious recognition now only because of their alleged adult acts of violence.

title: Inflation Plan Called Peril to World Recovery
description: PARTS, Nov. 16The Carter Admin. istration's antiinflation plan may cut American economic growth sharply enough to risk not only recession at home but also the tenuous world recovery.

title: City Planner Brings Hope For a New South Bronx
description: When President Carter stood on devastated, rubblestrewn site on Charlotte Street in the South Bronx last year, people wondered whether the committment he later made explicit  to do something substantial and significant for an area that has become the nation's foremost symbol of urban decay  could become real. Even though the Board of Estimate has approved a housing project for

title: World Gold
description: THURSDAY, NOV 16, 1978

title: Beard Plays Pupil To His Old Mentor
description: RICHFIELD. Ohio, Nov. 16  Butch Beard, a member of Golden State's 1975 championship team and an allstar from the Cleveland Cavaliers in 1972, quit the New York Knicks three weeks ago, disgusted with his lack of playing time and dissatisfied with the club's oncourt operation. In plain words, Beard and Willis Reed, the former New York coach, did not mesh.

title: CAIRO AIDE REPORTS TO U.S. AND ISRAELIS ON TREATY LINKAGE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  Egypt disclosed to the United States and Israel today its latest ideas on linking the projected EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty to a solution of the problems of Palestinians living in the West Bank of the Jordan and the Gaza Strip.

title: Deaths
description: HARKAVYLeona B. WIN of the late Alexander S. Haricavy. Survived by sister Gladys B. Zimmerman. Ser. vice today 2:45PM The Riverside 76 51 & Amsterdam Ave.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: AFTER the grand disaster of Divorce His, Divorce Hers several years back, Elizabeth Taylor is back on television tonight in a slight curiosity called Return Engagement. Written by James Prideaux and directed by Joseph Elizabeth Taylor in Return Engagement, tonight at 9:30 on NBC. Hardy, the Hallmark Hall of Fame drama can be seen at 9:30 on NBC.

title: Stage: Late Afternoon of Said
description: WITH its square of green carpet and its comfortable basketchair, the stage is an English country garden. The lighting suggests a late afternoon. And into the glow steps Emlyn Williams, dressed in a blue blazer and white flannels, head held back but bobbing forward discouragedly with each step, rather like a sad camel.

title: Music From the Andes And India on Schedule
description: Music from the Andes and India will be featured in concerts this weekend at the Alternative Center for International Arts, 28 East Fourth Street.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Butler Manufacturing Company, Kansas Citybased manufacturer of preengineered buildings and agricultural equipment, has elected Donald H. Pratt a senior vice president and general manager of the company's buildings division.

title: Publishing: Sinyavasky
description: ANDREI SINYAVSKY, the 53. yearold Soviet dissident writer, who served six years in a Russian labor camp because he had published his work outside the Soviet Union under the name of Abram Tertz. received the Bennett Award last night in ceremonies at the Grolier Club. It is the Russian writer's first visit to this country. After his release from prison in 1973 he was allowed to immigrate to France, where he now teaches in Paris at the Sorbonne.

title: Deaths
description: DELSONTheodore U. Of the Zelda Redow Weintraub Cancer Fund mourns the passing of their esteemed Member Director. We cherish his memory and extend heartfelt sympathy to his family.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: MAX Eastman, 18831969, preacher teacher  critic poet, who went in one very long lifetime from the editor of The Masses to a roving editor for Reader's Digest, from an admirer of Lenin to an admirer of Joseph R. McCarthy, from Greenwich Village to Martha's Vineyard, has been variously described by his friends and his biographer as a lyrical leftist, the John Barrymore of radical letters, the Byron of the Left, the reeinbodiment of Lorenzo it Magnifico with less business ability, a bit more charm, and immensely more passion and a winter log.

title: Reviving Yiddish Klezmer Music
description: Some people think that David Tarras is to Yiddish music what Isaac Bashevis Singer is to Yiddish literature. For decades, Mr. Tarras has been the leading exponent of the traditional Jewish instrumental music known as klezmer.

title: Deaths
description: RAFTERMANNat. The Friendship Club, LifeLong Friends Pause to sadly announce the Passing of a dear friend. Words are inadequate to exPress our sentiments to his devoted wife Phylis.

title: Commercialism Curb at Yosemite Is Urged
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif.  After a decade of controversy touched even by the Watergate scandal, public hearings will begin late this month on plan for the future of Yosemite National Park that seeks to reclaim much of its natural serenity from the automobile and commercial developments.

title: Screen: 'Star Wars' Miniaturized:Far Out
description: NOTHING looks right in "Message From Space," a Japanese science-fiction film that's so terrible it has a certain comic integrity. The meteors resemble intergalactic lint, and the earth, as seen from afar, is a big, blue volleyball with eczema. The space-walk special effects are straight out of "Peter Pan."The beleaguered people of the planet Jillucia wear wreaths of plastic leaves around their foreheads and travel in a vehicle that looks like the Flying Dutchman with a battery pack. The surface of Jillucia is made up of big gray hunks of papier-mch. The spaceships are so obviously miniatures that it becomes fun to imagine what would have happened if a real live mouse had wandered into the frame. The mouse would have looked like Rodan.However, the plot of "Message From Space," which opens today at Loews State and 86th Street East theaters, is pleasantly indecipherable, and the screenplay seems to have passed through a food processor with a sense of humor. Wicked old crone describing the mountains near her home: "And then there is the wolves who roam about very hungry at this time of year." Madcap heiress with spunk, ex-plaining why she has decided to follow the Jillucians to their new planet after the old one has been demolished: "Because I feel my life would have some purpose there."If you were spinning your television dial at 1 A.M. and happened upon "Message From Space," you would undoubtedly consider it as lively as it is preposterous, a real find; whether you would stay tuned for an hour and three quarters is another matter. On the big screen, it's worth recommending to anyone who won't mind a movie that looks as though it costs less than his or her ticket. And, for archivists with an interest in the all-time worsts, here is a "Star Wars" knockoff that looks less like the original than most television commercials for new cars. Here is a tale of intergalactic intrigue that revolves around magical walnuts. Here is a real contender."Message From Space" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It is no more violent than "Star Wars," which also carried a PG rating. And its action scenes are a good deal more confusing.

title: Vote on BusStop Shelter Franchise By Estimate Board Put Off 4 Days
description: The Board of Estimate yesterday postponed until Monday a vote on the controversial busstop shelter franchise after Mayor Koch said that negotiations on the proposed contract were not yet complete.

title: Concern Helped By a Joint Effort To Stay in State
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 16 In a novel bit of intergovernmental cooperation, officials of New York City, Westchester County and Yonkers announced today that they had worked together to keep a business from moving out of the state.

title: City Ballet: Rare Farrell
description: IT was ladies night at the New York City Ballet on Wednesday, with a debut by Heather Watts and a rare appearance by Suzanne Farrell in George Balanchine's bit of Gershwiniana, Who Cares?

title: Mina P. Shaughnessy, 54, Expert In Remedial Writing at City U.
description: Mina P. Shaughnessy, an associate dean of the City University and an expert on remedial writing instruction for underprepared college students, died yesterday of cancer in her Manhattan apartment. She was 54 years old.

title: Seaboard and Chessie to Merge
description: Seaboard Coast Line Industries and the Chessie System, which operate two of the country's larger railroads, announced yesterday the approval of merger plan that would create the largest rail line in the United States.

title: Visiting Fossils  the Oldest. Residents of the City
description: Passersby and security guards were giving Sidney Horenstein puzzled looks the other day. They wanted to know what this man in the trenchcoat was doing, staring at a wall in the lobby of the office tower at No. 2 Broadway in Lower Manhattan.

title: Biracial Government in Rhodesia Postpones Elections Four Months
description: SALISBURY. Rhodesia. Nov. 16 The beginning of blackmajority rule in Rhodesia was put off tonight for four months  from Dec. 31 to next April.

title: Concert: Musica Sacra
description: MUSICA SACRA, which is conducted by Richard Westenburg, opened its 197879 season at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday night with what was surely intended to be a dazzling sendoff. The work of the evening was Verdi's spectacular Requiem, and the Musica Sacra chorus was joined by a large orchestra and four soloists Johanna Meier,. soprano; Katherine Ciesinski, mezzosoprano; Leo Goeke, tenor, and Malcolm Smith, bass.

title: TeenAge Peer Pressure: Often a Positive Influence
description: Peer pressure: To parents of teenagers, the phrase has ominous connotations. They envision adolescents irresistibly tempting one another to smoke marijuana or take stronger narcotics, drink liquor, become sexually active, hang out on street corners.

title: Japan's Payments Surplus Off
description: TOKYO, Nov. 16  Japan's currentaccount surplus in October shrank sharply to $400 million from September's $1.87 billion, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Music Hall's Prospects Not Certain Past April
description: The financial melodrama of Radio City Music Hall appeared yesterday to offer no certain denouement beyond a commitment to the traditional movieandstage format through the next Easter Show and the end of next April.

title: Modern Museum Celebrates Mickey
description: Here's to a character who's been superstar for half a century and only gotten sweeter, who's always worn the same unassuming garb and simple smile. Here's to a guy who made the big time but always kept the old friends and never deserted the gal who stood by him in his spaghetti days. Here's to an actor who's 50 years old but hasn't lost his hair, his teeth, or his recognition factor.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Coffee futures continued to slide yesterday on news that a Central American coffee producer has abandoned minimum export prices, destroying trader confidence in producing nations ability to maintain a floor under prices

title: Restaurants
description: WITH Thanksgiving just a week away, serious eaters might well feel an extra measure of gratitude this year for the arrival of Le Chantilly, the sixmonthold French restaurant that has enjoyed a welldeserved success almost from the day it opened.

title: U.S. PHOTO FLIGHTS RESUME OVER CUBA
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  The Carter Administration, concerned over the presence of advanced Soviet military aircraft in Cuba, has resumed photo reconnaissance flights over the island, Government officials said today.

title: Associated Press
description: WORKER'S BODY FOUND IN HOTEL RUBBLE: In Joplin, Mo., workers remove body of Frederick C. Coe 3d from wreckage of the Connors Hotel, which collapsedSaturday trapping three men. One, Alfred Summers, was found alive. The others were found dead yesterday; reportedly, they died instantly when the building collapsed.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter warned that a deep recession or depression might ensue if his antiinflation policy fails. But the President said did not anticipate a recession or depression, as he and other Administration officials spent much of the day selling the antiinflation program. [Page A1.]

title: G.O.P. Seeks Softer Juvenile Law
description: A leading Republican state legislator on criminaljustice matters called yesterday for a fundamental change in the state's new juvenilejustice law to prevent many teenagers from being treated initially as adults in the criminal courts.

title: CALIFORNIA STALLED ON VAST WATER JOB
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16  One of the biggest water projects in history, a $7 billion program to divert more of northern California's surplus water to arid southern California, is aground on legislative shoals, a casualty of electionyear politics and sentiment against spending.

title: World News Briefs
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Nov. 16 (Reuters)  Rescue teams searched through the night at the site where an Icelandic Airlines plane crashed yesterday, killing more than 200 passengers.

title: Notes on People
description: The former White House aide Midge Costanza confirmed yesterday that she was considering an offer to join Governor Carey's administration. Calling the offer to represent New York State with Federal agencies very exciting, Miss Costanza said she didn't know whether she would accept. I want to make sure that I'll be effective, she said, adding that President Carter has encouraged me to take it.

title: Election Panel Rules Group's A id to crane Is Not a Political Gift
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  The Federal Election Commission ruled today that the American Conservative Union should not be held politically accountable for the money it spends in support of its chair. man, Representative Philip M. Crane, who also happens to be a candidate for the 1980 Republican Presidential nomina. tion.

title: Cosmos Are Beaten, 42, By an Argentine Side
description: MAR DEL PLATA, Argentina, Nov. 16 (AP)  Argentina's Boca Juniors capitalized on defensive errors to defeat the Cosmos, champions of the North American Soccer League, 42, to night in an exhibition.

title: Australia Spurs War on Drugs
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 16 (Reuters)  Australia announced today that was stepping up its antidrug operation in Southeast Asia by sending more federal agents to Jakarta. Bangkok and Kuala Lumpur.

title: Theater: Fathers vs. Sons
description: THOMAS BABE, author of Fathers and Sons at the Public Theater, is one of the most imaginative and indigenous of young American playwrights. In cornmon with Sam Shepard, he is intensely aware of our national myths and heroes. His Kid Champion exposed the emotional torment behind the glossy facade of the rock star. His A Prayer for My Daughter was a copsandcriminals play with a difference; the subject was not law but paternity, real and mythic.

title: Hofstra Lists Two Concerts for Weekend
description: Two musical events are scheduled this weekend at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I. The university's string quartet, composed of faculty members who are also professional musicians, will perform works by Mozart, Bartok and Schumann tonight at 8:30 in the John Cranford Adams Playhouse, South Campus.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: More than 400 craftsmen are bringing their handiwork to the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I., for the fourth annual Harvest Crafts Festival, opening tonight with a champagne reception. You can find items for as little as $3 or as much as $3,000. Besides exhibits, there will be continuous demonstrations of pottery, printmaking, weaving, leatherwork and more. Hours: 6 to 10 P.M. tonight; 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. tomorrow, and 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. on Sunday. Admission is $2.75. From New York City, take the Long Island Expressway to the Meadowbrook Parkway and follow the signs. Information: (516) 3251331.

title: The New York Times/Barton Silverman
description: DOG'S BEST FRIEND: An unidentified Sanitation Department worker rescuing a dog from a fire in a vacant building yesterday at 468 Madison Street Brooklyn. Safely outside, man and dog went their separate ways.

title: The News Considering Putting Out A SingleEdition Afternoon Paper
description: New York may be getting a new afternoon newspaper. The Daily News, which has been thinking about this on and off for 1 the last 10 years, is once again giving serious consideration to putting out an afternoon daily that would contain closing stock prices and be out in time for the bulk of commuters to read on their way home.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Sonata No. 4 in A for Flute. Cello, and Harpsichord, Vivaldi; Pavane pour une infante defunte, Ravel; La Scala di Seta, Overture, Rossini; Prelude and Fugue No. 3 in B minor. Bach; Zigeunerweisen, Sarasate; Danse de la Chevre, Honegger; Trumpet Tune and Air for Organ, Clarke.

description: BASKETBALL

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. on Economic and Social Council elections and cooperation with the Organization of African Unity.

title: GoingPrivate Warning
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  The Securities and Exchange Commission warned companies today to exercise meticulous care in disclosing all significant facts  in! :uding the purpose  in transactions in which they are transformed from public to private concerns.

title: China, in a Downgrading of Mao, Attacks the Cultural Revolution
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 16  In an intensification of the campaign to downgrade the late Mao Tsetung and undermine the power of officials associated with him, China has declared that a celebrated essay he used to launch the Cultural Revolution was actually counterrevolutionary.

title: Federal Reserve
description: Rrevised over $100,000  seasonally adjusted

description: LEVENEMarie S. We deeply mourn the passing of the lovely mother of Rhoda Sono and Teddi Winograd. The Errployees of Teddi of California.

title: Javits Warns Moscow Its Rights Policy Hurts Scientific Exchanges
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 16  Senator Jacob K. Javits said today that he had told Soviet officials that human rights violations were hindering scientific exchanees.

title: Goldstein Poised to Dethrone Khan as No. 1 Squash Player
description: After a young amateur golfer named Francis Ouimet beat Harry Vardon and Ted Ray for the United States Open championship in 1913, he was credited with two achievements: he started the trend that ended British domination of golf, and, more important, he attracted hundreds of thousands of Americans to the game as participants.

title: Capital's Subway Opens 7.5 Miles to Maryland on Monday
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  Metro, the capital's multibilliondollar rapid rail system, will take another glide forward on Monday with the opening of 7.5mile section of its new Orange Line to suburban Maryland.

title: Buck White Bluegrass Group to Sing Twice
description: Buck White and the Down Home Folks, a bluegrass group from Tennessee made up of a father, his two daughters and a fourth musician, will give two performances this weekend.

title: Deaths
description: SENISONViolet Patricia. On November 16, 1978 of Patctmue, LI.. She was sportswear buyer for SwezeyNewins Dept Store, Patchogue. Beloved wife of Harry, loving mother of Richard, devoted daughter of Mrs Amelia Reyes, dear sister. of Albert Johnson, Douglas Johnson and Mrs Eileen Ward. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. Reposing at the Roland Funeral Horne, 500 New North Ocean Ave, Patchogue, L.I. Pray service SAM Saturday, interment Holy Sepulchre Cemetery. Coram. L.I. Visiting 24 and /.9PM Friday.

title: Ethiopia Said to Use Defoliants To Combat Guerrillas in Eritrea
description: ROME, Nov. 16 (Reuters)  Ethiopia, with the participation of Soviet and Cuban forces, is launching a scorched earth policy with defoliant sprays in new offensive in Eritrea, an Eritrean guerrilla leader said today.

title: Guns and Butter, Guns and Guns
description: President Carter is unequivocal about defense spending this season: There's no way that I can cut down the ability of our nation to defend itself, he says. Our security obviously comes first. The question is, how will it be paid for. The old dilemma of guns and butter has generally been resolved by finding money for both. But this year, the need to hold back inflation forces a choice. To judge from the defense outlays the White House is now talking about, Mr. Carter has chosen guns; that means no increase, probably even decrease, in spending for civilian programs.

title: 9 Youths Accused in Harassment Of Black Family Moving to City
description: Nine white youths, 13 to 15 years old, were arrested yesterday and accused of dumping garbage at the prospective home of a black family that has been harassed over its intention to move to City Island, the nautically picturesque sliver of the Bronx that separates Eastchester Bay and Long Island Sound.

title: Antiques in Fort Lee
description: More than 50 antiques dealers will exhibit their wares Sunday at an antiques and collectibles show sponsored by the Knights of Pythias at Fort Lee High School on Lemoine Avenue in Fort Lee, N.J. Proceeds from the show, which will feature jewelery, furniture, glass, silver, porcelain and other items, will benefit charities of the Lodge of the Palisades 178. Hours are 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission is $1. Information: (914) 3578410 or (201) 5293896.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar, drawing strength from tough comments by President Carter on the inflation fight, continued to rise in markets around the world yesterday, while the price of gold fell nearly $10 to its lowest level in several months.

title: The Vamp Look In Lingerie
description: It just won't do, nowadays, to go to bed in a granny nightgown or an elongated Tshirt like the one Liv Ullmann wore in Scenes from a Marriage. (We suspect that dreary garment contributed to the breakup of the marriage.) Fashion is from the skin out and since what's being worn in public is more blatantly sexy than it has been in years, it's no wonder that designers are going all out to make a woman even more alluring in the boudoir.

title: Market Up Modestly on Carter Assurances
description: Spurred by assurances from President Carter over the economy's future, the stock market registered a moderate advance yesterday.

title: A Fanfare for Franz Schubert Sounds in New York
description: HISTORIANS are unimaginative drudges with card catalogues for hearts and souls of congealed library paste. How else do you account for the fact that every reference book you open asserts that Franz Schubert is dead? There is even general agreement among the experts on the time and cause of death: 150 years ago this Sunday at 3 in the afternoon, of typhoid fever. But pay no attention. The man has never been more alive than right now, and this weekend should prove it even to a musicologist. He is even taking part in couple of marathons.

title: Monroe's Magic Still Working; He Sparks 9793 Knick Victory; Knicks Keep Rallying; Important Thing Is We Won; KNICKS (97); CLEVELAND (93)
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Nov. 16  Earl Monroe's old magic turned the New York Knicks around tonight in the Coliseum lust when they needed it most.

title: Wholesale Heroin Setup Is Charged
description: Robert Stepeney, described by law enforcement authorities as one of the top narcotics dealers in New York City, was charged yesterday with heading an organization that distributed large amounts of heroin and cocaine.

title: Key Rates
description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether manes

title: Fair at Plymouth Church
description: A Yankee Fair and Antiques Show will be held this weekend at the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, 75 Hicks Street, Brooklyn (between Orange and Cranberry Streets). Hours for the fair, a tradition at the church for 50 years, are 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. today and II A.M. to 3 P.M. tomorrow; the antiques show will also begin at 11 A.M. and go on until 10 P.M. today and 5 P.M. tomorrow. Admission to the fair is free; tickets for the antiques show are $2.50. Information: MA 44743.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Last April 10 a passel of bigwigs stood by smiling while the first Americanbuilt Volkswagen rolled off an assembly line at New Stanton, Pa. A little more than five weeks later, Volkswagen Manufacturing of America had its first strike. The first event was the baptism, one auto industry observer said the other day, and the second was the confirmation.

title: Offer of Supplies Requires That They Leave Area
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Nov. 16  More than 2,500 Vietnamese refugees aboard a decrepit freighter anchored off the coast here refused an offer today to allow their ship to be resupplied because it was part of a Malaysian ultimatum. Malaysia said that it would resupply tne ship, which is critically short of water and medicine, only if its passengersaccept a Malaysian refusal to grant them temporary asylum and leave its waters.

title: Deaths
description: ADLERMoses J. (Moe), ofSriioklyn,beloved husband of Tess, devoted father of Judith Sachs and Nancy Harris, dear fatherInlaw of Ned Sachs and Norman Harris, loving grandfather of Howard and Randy Sachs. Steven and Michael Harris. Funeral services from Westminster Chacel, Coney Island Ave. and Ave. H, Brooklyn, 1 PM, Friday, November 17. Interment Mt. Hebron Cemetery. Contributions to Cancer Care, Park Ave., N.Y., would be appreciated.

title: Josephson Acquires 8.6% of Harcourt Brace
description: Marvin Josephson Associates, Inc., which operates one of the largest talent agencies in the United States and is active in other fields of entertainment, announced yesterday that it had acquired 8.6 percent of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., a major publisher of books and magazines that is more than 10 times its size.

title: Carter to Install General As Arms Control Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UPI) President Carter announced today that he would install retired Lieut. Gen. George Seignious as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency as of Dec. 1, without waiting for Senate confirmation.

title: News Summary
description: Egypt informed the United States and Israel of its latest views on linking the projected EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty to the future of Palestinians in the West Bank of the Jordan and the Gaza Strip. The acting head of Israel's negotiators, Ezer Weizman, told reporters Cairo's plans provided no reason for pessimism, adding I hope and believe they should not be stumbling blocks. [Page Al, Column 1.]

title: Theodore Fishberg, 93; A Philharmonic Violist
description: Theodore Fishberg, a former viola player with the New York Philharmonic orchestra and a member of a family that at one time had six members playing in that orchestra, died yesterday in Miami Beach at the Royal Glades nursing home. He was 93 years old. He had lived in the Blackstone Hotel in Miami Beach.

title: WASHINGTON The Present Danger
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  You can get a good tough debate in Washington these days about almost anything except cutting the Pentagon budget. Even in the present war or skirmish against inflation here, the Defense Department is comparatively immune to the cries for austerity and frugality from the White House.

title: Tim Gullikson Ousts Gerulaitis
description: LONDON, Nov. 16 (UPI)  Tim Gullikson, reeling off six games in succession, won a seesaw battle against fellow American Vitas Gerulaitis today, which eliminated the topseeded player in the second round of a $175,000 Grand Prix tennis championship.

title: Hilton Splits Stock 2for1
description: Reflecting the profitspurring success of hotel and Las Vegas casino. operations, directors of the Hilton Hotels Corporation yesterday authorized a 2for1 stock split and increased the cash dividend on the common stock for the second time this year.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 16  PPG Industries announced today that it would terminate operations at its wholly owned chemical complex at Guayanilla, P.R., and at the Penuelas, P.R., facility of the Puerto Rico Olefins Company.

title: Estimate Board Votes South Bronx Housing Project
description: After five hours of impassioned pleas for the project by community spokesmen and the administration of Mayor Koch, the Board of Estimate gave final approval last night to the first housing construction planned under the ambitious South Bronx revival program.

title: At the Movies
description: I DIDN'T quite know what to think when I saw it for the first time, said Brooke Adams. I kept asking myself: What happened to that scene? How could he have cut it there? It wasn't so much that I was disappointed. I just felt strangely unrelated to it, and I think Richard Gere felt the same way I did.

title: Around the Nation
description: NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 16 The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson told 8,000 high school students here today that to do less than our best is a sin.

title: Europeans Ask Pledge From U.S.
description: GENEVA, NOV. 16  As the price for trying to wrap up the Tokyo Round of trade negotiations by the end of the year, Western Europe demanded fresh assurances today from the Carter Administration that it would be able to continue exporting subsidized goods to the United States freely next year.

title: F.C.C. Is Petitioned to Set Aside Frequencies for Indian Stations
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  A coalition of American Indian and national church groups petitioned the Federal Communications Commission today to set aside radio and television frequencies for the use of Indian reservations.

title: Rodgers Dancers Benefit
description: The Rod Rodgers Dance Company will give a benefit performance tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. at the Brandeis High School Auditorium, 195 West 84th Street. Proceeds will aid the DeWitt ElementaryJunior High School, a private school at 150 First Avenue. Tickets, taxdeductible, are $10, ($5 for students.) Information: 6771414 dr 9247560. 1

title: The
description: The Federal Government obtained eviction notices against the 20 squatters who disregarded a Nov. 15 deadline to turn over their homes on the Fire Island National Seashore to the Government. The notices authorize the Government to seize the properties, and park rangers are expected to put locks on the squatters homes this weekend. Once that is done anyone entering faces a charges of trespassing on Government property.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Corporate demand for bank loans expanded strongly in early November. and banks moved aggressively to get deposits to back them, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday. Companies also borrowed heavily in the commercialpaper market; volume there grew by the largest amount in almost four years.

title: JetsPatriots Draws Rare Sellout to Shea
description: Too much pro football on television? That will not be the case on Sunday as only two games are to be broadcast locally and and both kick off at the same time. The Eagles play the Giants (Channel 2) at Giants Stadium and the Patriots meet the Jets (Channel 4) at Shea Stadium with both kickoffs at P.M.

title: Steel Companies Say Dissident Haulers Fail To Disrupt Shipments
description: Dissident truckers have failed in weeklong attempt to disrupt steel hauling across the Middle West, steel companies reported yesterday.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: A large mass of clouds over the Midwest is part of a developing storm system centered Arkansas. The sharp line of clouds from southern Texas to Arkansas is a coldfront. Clouds are also sweeping across the Middle Atlantic States. Most of the Southeast clear. In the West, broken fair weather clouds are over the Rockies. Showers are moving into the Northwest

title: Germanys Sign Major Travel Pact
description: EAST BERLIN, Nov. 16  West Germany agreed today to pay East Germany a formidable political price of more than $3 billion over the next 10, years under major traffic accord aimed at improving the lot of West Berlin and at reaching longterm stability in the relations between the two countries.

title: Bloomingdale's to Pay $50, 000 in Settlement Of Credit Bias Chatie
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  Bloomingdale's department store chain agreed today to pay $50,000 in civil penalties for alleged discrimination against women in its evaluation of credit applications.

title: Freddy Cole Comes Of Age on Keyboard
description: The Cole Nobody Knows is not, as one might suspect, some unexplored aspect of Cole Porter. It is the tag line that Freddy Cole, a pianist and singer who is playing with his trio at Michael's Pub through the end of the month, has chosen to apply to himself.

title: Jazz: Slide Hampton Five
description: SLIDE HAMPTON, the lefthanded jazz trombonist, is leading a quintet at the Village Vanguard through Sunday that manages to combine the openness and fluidity of a small group with a suggestion Of the harmonic colors and tonal richness of a large ensemble.

title: H. A. L. Craig, at 57; Writer and Dramatist
description: H.A.L. Craig, a writer amd dramatist who had been living in Rome for the last eight years, died there on Oc. 24, at the Clinica Villa Carla, of lung cancer. He was 57 years old.

title: More Than Merely Power: II
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass.We live in an era of titillation with power and deep yearning for leadership.

title: 13 Suspended In Malingering, Cooping Cases
description: Thirteen police officers were sus.. pended from duty without pay yesterday  seven after being convicted of abusing sickleave regulations and six for reportedly spending up to half their tours of duty parked in a wooded area in their radio cars when they should have been patrolling the streets.

title: Dollar Resumes Rise in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 17 (AP) The dollar gained about 2 yen in fairly active early trading in Tokyo today. The American currency opened at 193 yen, up from Thursday's close of 191.35, and climbed as high as 193.50 yen.

title: Oil Executive Refuses Offer to Head Kennecott
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation appeared yesterday to have been turned down at the last minute by a prominent oil executive it had picked to succeed Frank R. Milliken as its chief executive officer.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4)Dance, Dance, Dance

title: Xerox Is Entering Telecommunications
description: The Xerox Corporation is entering the telecommunications business.

title: The Pop Life
description: STEVE REICH'S Music'for 18 Musicians is a remarkable piece of work, and it may be hoped that its new recording on the ECM label will win it and Mr. Reich's music in general a wider audience than before. This is a record that should appeal to lovers of trance music, to use Robert Palmer's apt term for the sort of dappled, structurally rigorous, hypnotic music composed by Mr. Reich, Terry Riley and Philip Glass. But Mr. Reich has been winning admirers steadily from more conservative classical devotees through his recordings on the Columbia, Angel and Deutsche Grammophon classical labels. And now, with ECM, he may well reach out to the progressive jazz and artrock enthusiasts,too.

title: Events and Openings,
description: MESSAGE FROM OUTER SPACE, directed by Kinii Fukasaku; starring Vic Morrow and Sonny Chiba, at Loew's State II and 86th Street East.

title: The Disaster Game
description: LONDONWhen a natural disaster happens in the third world, the victims collapse into chaos and apathy in the face of fate.

title: Z. THEODORE LOW
description: Z. Theodore Low, for nearly 50 years managing partner in the investment firm of Bear, Stearns & Company, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 700 Park Avenue.

title: Danbury Tax Revolt May Be Lagging
description: DANBURY, Conn., Nov. 16  Despite a plea for a boycott by a taxcutting association that won a referendum on a rate cut last July, hundreds of residents here are paying their tax bills early and at the higher rate, which supposedly had been rejected.

title: The Art of Being Infuriating, And Other Childhood Fun
description: No, Delia Ephron was not the biggest brat in the world. Her new book, How to Eat Like a Child, And Other Lessons in Not Being a Grownup, just makes it sound that way. She was, she insists, the kid in school who was a goodygoody; you know  the teacher's pet.

title: Quiet Egyptian on Peace Mission
description: CAIRO, Nov. 16  A pair of American journalists who were granted an interview with President Anwar elSadat last winter became aware toward the end of the twohour session of the presence of a ruggedlooking Egyptian with shortcropped hair, seated to one side.

title: U.S. Rebukes Vietnam For Action on Refugees
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  The Carter Administration sharply rebuked Vietnam today for virtually forcing tens of thousands of its nationals, mostly ethnic Chinese, to flee in recent months and requiring many of them to pay as much as $2,000 to buy their way out.

title: IRANIAN NAMES FOUR HE SAYS TOOK GIFTS
description: LONDON Nov. 16  A former aide to the Shah of Iran, who defected to Britain two weeks ago, said in an interview today that the Iranian Government had given substantial gifts to a number of Western reporters in return for laudatory articles about the Shah's troubled regime.

title: Ethereal Dancers Court Muses. in Brooklyn
description: The stage will be awash with a silken rainbow of dancers moving through colored lights on Sunday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Alwin Nikolais in a romantic mood? No. But the Eurythmeum Stuttgart will be performing something nearly as exotic in its first New York presentation of the rarely seen eurythmic dance.

title: Bridge:
description: DENVER, Nov. 16  The Fall National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League, beginning here tomorrow, will be high in quality but quantitatively an anticlimax.

title: Art: Delicate Kites Of Richard Smith
description: AS of 20 years ago, Richard Smith was spotted at once as one of the most gifted painters whom England has produced since World War 11. He has never lost that 'status, and there are contented collectors all over Europe and in both the Americas who can confirm it. But he is not by nature a showman, and his work in recent years has become more and more weightless and incorporeal. People suppose  however irrationally  that a painting that looks like a kite and hangs from the ceiling is not as serious as a painting that comes in a big gold frame and hangs on the wall. Furthermore, Mr. Smith's works are hard to reproduce since they depend both on a particularly precise and delicate sense of color and on a physical structure, part painting and part relief, that must be investigated the way we investigate a bird's nest. The work has, literally, to be seen to be believed; and it has not been properly seen in New York for some time, even though the Museum of Modern Art does from time to time show a shaped canvas that is one of Mr. Smith's more forthright achievements.

title: 16,000 More Languishing on Island Off the Coast
description: PULAU BIDONG, Malaysia, Nov. 15  Approaching this island by fishing boat from the mainland port of Kuala Trengganu, about 30 miles across the South China Sea, one sees visions of tropical paradise.

title: BankAmerica Doing Well
description: The BankAmerica Corporation is experiencing an excellent year better than we expected even a quarter or two ago, A. W. Clausen, president of the nation's largest bank, said yesterday in San Francisco. The company's thirdquarter and ninemonth operating earnings rose 3.3.4 percent and 28 percent, respectively, and showed, by far, the greatest increase in the history of the company, he noted.

title: Music: De Larrocha, Schubert and Mehta
description: THE BIG work on last night's New York Philharmonic program was the Schubert Ninth Symphony, which Zubin Mehta conducted as part of his ongoing Schubert series. Not that the Schubert Ninth would not normally have come our way in any event. In recent years it has become a favorite war horse,and every conductor feels that he has to measure himself against the work and its other interpreters.

title: EARNINGS
description: The F. W. Woolworth Company, the giant variety store chain, yesterday reported a 95 percent rise in thirdquarter profits, and more than doubled earnings for the nine months ended Oct. 31.

title: PRESIDENT EXPECTS HIS INFLATION PLAN TO BAR DEPRESSION
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  President Carter, attempting to sell his antiinflation program on several fronts, today raised the specter of depression but then dismissed it by insisting that his program would succeed.

title: O'Neill Sees Congress Going Along With Carter Effort to Trim Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., said today that unless there was a recession next year he expected the new House to cooperate with President Carter's efforts to trim the Federal budget and fight inflation,

title: Puppet Show at Museum
description: The World's Mightiest Puppet Show, presented by the David Rohn Puppets, can be seen tomorrow at 1:30 P.M. at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street. All tickets are $1; children younger than must be accompanied by a parent. Information: 5341672.

title: Rangers Send Polis To New Haven Farm
description: The Rangers assigned Greg Polis, left wing, to their New Haven affiliate in the American Hockey League yesterday.

title: Music: Torontonians Play Prokofiev
description: THE Toronto Symphony is getting around these days under the leadership of Andrew Davis, the 34yearold English conductor who took over the Canadian orchestra in 1975. Recently it added the People's Republic of China to its tour roster, which is going pretty far afield. This suggests that the Toronto Symphony is probably worth hearing, the truth of which was borne out by the concert it gave at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night on an Eastern seaboard swing that includes a Kennedy Center concert in Washington tonight and one at Brooklyn College tomorrow night.

title: Keep Mr. Berle on the Job
description: We don't know why word is circulating that Governor Carey plans to fire his environmental commissioner, Peter A. A. Berle, but if true, such action would be an injustice to Mr. Berle and a disservice to the state.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 26 (AP) Graham Marsh of Australia carded fiveunderpar 67 today to take a twostroke lead over a countryman, Bruce Devlin, after one round of the Australian open golf championship.

title: Estimate Board Votes A Massage Parlor Ban
description: The New York City Board of Estimate unanimously approved a zoning amendment yesterday that would prohibit establishment of new adult massage parlors throughout the city and help close existing ones.

title: U.S. Plan to Relax Pay Guide Is Denied
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  Ranking Administration officials said today that President Carter had no intention of relaxing his wage guideline either to secure compliance with his antiinflation program or to avoid labor unrest.

title: Comedy Hit in London Will Open in New York
description: Once a Catholic, a prizewinning comedy that is currently a hit in London, is scheduled to open in New York at the Brooks Atkinson Theater in midFebruary.

title: AUDRY T. DELANY
description: Audry T. Delany,retired Bronx social welfare executive, died Tuesday in the New Sans Souci Nursing Home in Yonkers. She was 74 years old.

title: Five Indicted in Fraud Involving $1.5 Million In Federal Contracts
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 16  A Federal grand jury returned a 23count indictment today charging five men with using the secrecy of a naval intelligence research laboratory to mask a systematic fraud against the Government involving $1.5 million in contracts.

title: Broadway
description: IT has not been a terrific season; there seems be general agreement so far that it has even been a dreary one. But hope springs, new projects are born, and early each season everyone always says that things are awful, anyway. No matter, there is the promise of better times to come, and Broadway has always lived on promise. There is, for example, Bedroom Farce by Alan Ayckbourn.

title: Not by Guideposts Alone
description: Despite the developing controversy over President Carter's voluntary guideposts for wages and prices, the nation should not lose sight of their potential value. Some major unions are balking at the proposed restraints on their wages and benefits. Businessmen are alarmed by the complexity of the Government's monitoring of their prices. Economists dwell on the past failure of controls and the unfairness of voluntarism. All these complaints have merit, but not enough.

title: Uganda Calls War Over, Tanzania Reports Fighting
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 16 (Reuters) Uganda said today that its twoweek border war with Tanzania ended with an orderly withdrawal of its forces, but Tanzania said its troops were driving the Ugandans off their soil.

title: Regents Propose Wider Eligibility For Student Aid
description: The New York State Board of Regents proposed yesterday to extend eligibility for awards under the Tuition Assistance Program to parttime as well as fulltime college students. The Regents said the move was necessary to prepare for an expected decline in the number of fulltime students in the next decade.

title: Central Park Zoo Seeks Very Special Seal
description: The Central Park Zoo is engaged in desperate, nationwide search for a preAct seal.

title: ExGolf Champion Dies
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 16  Richard D. Chapman, who won both the United States and British Amateur golf championships in his three decades of competitive play, died yesterday at his home in nearby Rancho Santa Fe. He was 67 years old.

title: Editor Seeking Political Post Embroils Duluth Papers in Legal Battle
description: DULUTH, Minn., Nov. 15  This city's major newspapers, The Herald and The News Tribune, are caught in an apparent conflict between rules of ethics that are interpreted as barring employees from seeking political office and a state statute against inducing a person not to seek political office.

title: Everybody Roots for China's Mr. Mu
description: He's more incredible than inscrutable. His name is Mu Tiehchu but he's known as Mr. Mu for short; for tall really  the tallest basketball player on the planet. He appears to be about 7 feet.6 inches, almost a foot taller than any of his teammates on the touring People's Republic of China team that will oppose Rutgers

title: Art People
description: HE speaks of her as Miss 0'Keeffe, yet Juan Hamilton, at 33. is Georgia O'Keeffe's close companion  so close, in fact, that rumors of marriage between him and the 91yearold painter will not be quashed. Last year. among friends, Miss O'Keeffe concurred with a smile when Mr. Hamilton teasingly suggested that as a woman she had a right to do what male painters had done through history: marry a partner decades younger than herself. But, pressed on the question in New York the other day. Mr. Hamilton smiled sweetly and came up with a swift no comment.

title: Kennedy's Criticism Angers Bell
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  In an extraordinary exchange of letters, Senator Edward M. Kennedy has asked the Federal Trade Commission to investigate a proposed merger approved by Attorney General Griffin B. Bell, and Mr. Bell has taken exception to the request in strong language.

title: F.B.I. TAPE HEARD AT HOUSTON TRIAL
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 16  Jurors wearing headphones and watching television monitors saw for the first time a videotape and tape recording of T. Cullen Davis, Texas industrialist, allegedly paying Charles David McCrory $25,000 for having a district judge murdered.

title: Palmer Seeks Racing License
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 16 (AP) Arnold Palmer has applied for a license to race trotters in Kentucky, the Kentucky Harness Racing Commission said today. The deputy commissioner,

title: Panel Convinced Bounty Induced Ray to Kill King
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  After all the witnesses have been heard and all the evidence has been analyzed, the House Select Committee on Assassinations is expected to conclude that James Earl Raykilled the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. for money, according to numerous sources who are close to the panel's investigation.

title: Rangers Feasting On the Big Apple
description: It was past midnight and Sonny Werblin still had his dream..

title: IRAN'S TROOPS CLASH WITH DEMONSTRATORS
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 16  Troops clashed with antiShah demonstrators in several areas today, and oil production showed only a modest gain because of persistent labor problems.

title: J. KENDRICK NOBLE, EXPUBLISHER, DIES
description: J. Kendrick Noble Sr., publisher and aviator, died Wednesday after a long illness in Austin, Tex. He was 82 years old.

title: Vengeance Is Suggested in Blaze That Killed 7 in the South Bronx
description: A fire in the South Bronx last week in which seven people died may have been set intentionally out of vengeance by two 14yearold boys, the Bronx District Attorney's office said yesterday.

description: WELLSTRAND INC., 350 Firth Ave., N.Y. Liabilities, $19,088,000; assets, S17,438,0)0. If Is a distributor yarn and fabrics. Irwin Meltzer and Michael Trachtenberg are owners of 50 percent each of the common stock. Arthur Fettner is vice president in charge of fiHence. Reiml, a corporation from Panama: Dan F Ilex. a corporation from Denmark; YarnTex W.E.S.Strand Inc., and Wescof Fabrics Inc. all have voting securities.

title: WNJUTV Gets Approval For OvertheAir PayTV
description: WNJUTV, a predominantly Spanishlanguage television station in Linden, N.J., has been granted permission by the Federal Communications Commission to become an overtheair paytelevision station.

title: Japan Steps Up Car Exports to Germany
description: BONN  Japan's auto makers have caused concern among West Germany's auto makers by doubling their sales in the West German market in two years.

description: IT is probably fair to assume that thousands of small investors are spending more money to finance their margin accounts than they are spending for, say, fuel oil to heat their homes.

title: Carson's Motivation: Eagles Bill Bergey
description: EAST RUTHERFORD. N.J., Nov. 16  It was meant as a compliment, one young pro to an allpro. I would like to become, said the Giants young pro, Harry Carson, the black Bill Bergey.

title: Where and When to Celebrate Schubert
description: Schubert festivities begin this weekend with a piano recital by Andre Watts tumor. row at 8 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall in Lincoln Center. Baritone for the Winterreise is Bernard Kntysen. Tickets. $9, at the box office (3621911). Also at 8. tomorrow. Ralph Kirshbaum, cellist, and Jet frey gel, pianist, play the Schubert Sonata in A minor and works by Rachmaninalf, Bach and Debussy at the 92d Street. Y.M.Y W.ILA. on Lexington Avenue. Tickets, $5. itl a nd $7.50 (4274000).

title: About Real Estate Apartment Demand Expands Upper West Side Borders
description: Two years ago one out of every five to seven apartment hunters who walked through the door at Alpha Equities on West 72d Street looking for help in finding an apartment actually rented an apartment through the agency. Now, says Warren Pearl, one of the principals of the firm, only one of 25 to 30 can be satisfied.

title: Arrows Sign Messing
description: The Major Indoor Soccer League took a page from the North American Soccer League's book and a major step toward credibility yesterday.

title: Levich Granted Soviet Exit Visa; Scientist to Leave Within Month
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 16  Veniamin G. Levich, a Soviet Jewish scientist who had been denied permission to emigrate for the last six years, said today that he had been granted a visa and would try to leave within a month.

title: Misses Ruzici, Wade Win
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif., Nov. 16 (AP)  Virginia Ruzici and Virginia. Wade used different routes tonight to reach the singles semifinals of a $250,000 roundrobin tournament at Mission Hills Country Club.

title: IN THE NATION Conflicting Realities
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia  Just before an Air Rhodesia jet landed in Salisbury early one recent evening, all the cabin lights were turned out as precaution against guerrilla attacks. As I sat a little nervously in the dark, journalist's phrase passed through my mind:

title: Advertising
description: TED BATES & COMPANY has a new client  Neighborhood Realty Group, U.S.A.,  that helped create. It also owns a small piece of the action, something it can't say about any other client.

title: ExDirector Sees Growth Periled In Meadowlands
description: SECAUCUS, N.J., Nov. 16 The outgoing executive director of the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission, William D. McDowell, voiced concern today that longterm and persistent local opposition to new housing in the region could doom plans to have 125,000 new residents in the Meadowlands by the year 2000.

title: A HIGH U.S. OFFICIAL SET TO VISIT ANGOLA
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  Richard M. Moose Jr., Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, will fly to Angola over the weekend for talks next week with officials of the Marxist Government of President Agostinho Neto, Administration officials said today.

title: The City
description: The New York City Board of Health yesterday changed the time that milk may be sold after pasteurization from three to four days.

title: Art: New Realisr Writ Large by Leslie
description: AMONG the socalled second generation painters of the New York School, none has defected more completely from the esthetic tenets of the Abstract Expressionist style than Alfred Leslie. Once a true believer in the improvisatory gestures of lyrical abstraction,

title: For Children
description: ST. LUKE'S SCHOOL CHRISTMAS FAIR, a twoday event, from 5 to 10 P.M. on Friday, and from noon to 5 P.M. on Saturday. at the school, 487 Hurt. son Street, Greenwich Village, with handmade gilts, clown makeup, plants, a treasure chest, and an art gallery. Events will include games and prizes on Saturday. and a disco on Friday night. A dinner will be available on Friday and a lunch will be served on Saturday; there will be food stalls on both days. Admission: children under 12, tree; adults, 50 cents. Information: 974.5960.

title: United Pess International
description: ELUSIVE DISK: Flyers Bernie Parent swiping in vain at puck shot Hawks Don Murray, lower right, as Rick Lapointe attempted to defend during the first period at Philadelphia last night. Chicago won game, 43.

title: Scenes From Ingmar Bergman's Life: Imitation of His Art
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 12  When Ingmar Bergman returned to Stockholm this autumn to begin rehearsals on the stage where he was arrested for tax fraud in 1976, the director seemed to be exorcising two years of humiliation and rage.

title: Art: Willi Baumeister Rediscovered
description: BECAUSE the 20th century has prized individualism so highly, the individuals writing (and making) its history have frequently cut corners. Figures adjudged great have too easily been seen as the originators of the ideas they had only given momentum to and which were probably inevitable anyway. An artist as crucial to abstraction as Wassily Kandinsky, for example, did not need the credit for inventing it  a laurel that has now been withdrawn by cooler scholarly heads. Though this kind of mythmaking has probably not lost the world any geniuses, it has, as current revisionism is showing, caused a certain warp in the historical perspective. It has also led to many artists of substance getting trampled in the scramble for firstness.

title: ACREAGE IN ALASKA IS SET ASIDE BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  Interior Secretary Cecil D. Andrus today used executive authority under a 1906 act to prohibit temporarily any commercial development on some 110 million acres of Alaska wilderness  almost 30 percent of the nation's largest state. The acreage would more than double the size of the entire national park and wildlife refuge system in the United States.

title: Lotus to Work on Car
description: DETROIT, Nov. 16 (AP)  The sports car being developed by John Z. DeLorean, a former executive of the General Motors Corporation, will be partly engineered by Lotus Cars Ltd. of Britain, it was announced today. Lotus, which builds sports and racing cars, is studying prototypes of the DMC12, a $15,000 sports car to be built near Belfast, Northern Ireland.

title: CBS and NBC Vie for 2d Place
description: ABCTV's preeminence in the audiencepopularity ratings for the third season in a row has sent program executives of NBCTV and CBSTV back to the drawing boards this week to plan extensive renovation of their primetime schedules in January. But the efforts of each will be to establish a claim to second place in the competition, because there is virtually no chance of overtaking or even catching up with ABC.

title: Letters
description: A Nov. 9 letter from Alfred C. Neal, respected past president of the Committee for Economic Development, recommended that the Government introduce selective credit controls in its fight on inflation. According to Neal, monetary and fiscal policies, supplemented by voluntary wage and price standards, will not dampen inflation. In particular, they need to be backed by controls over extension of consumer credit and mortgage credit for housing if they are to be effective.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a tranmission error, Washington dispatch in The Times Wednesday said an assessment had been made of Vietnamese assets frozen in the United States. No such survey has been conducted.

title: Miller Says Nation Can Miss Slump
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  The Federal Reserve chairman, G. William Miller, said today that a recession could probably be avoided next year, even though the Administration's goal for a limit on inflation is likely to be exceeded by as much as one percentage point.

title: Bishops Back Palestinian Home
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) America's Roman Catholic bishops called today for a comprehensive Middle East peace settlement that would assure the Palestinians a homeland of their own while preserving Israeli sovereignty within secure borders.

title: Madrid Judge Is Slain; Held Dissident Trials Under Franco Regime
description: MADRID, Nov. 16 (AP)  Two men on motorbikes rode up to a judge outside his home here today and shot him dead in an apparent revenge killing for his imprisonment of dissidents under Francisco Franco.

title: Guggenheim Unveils Surrealist City Views
description: THE visionary city has preoccupied architects throughout history, and no less in our own time  from Frank Lloyd Wright's Broadacres to Le Corbusier's Ville Radieuse, architectural mind., have struggled to create a new model for urban reality. Most idealized.ities have differed from real ones in their obsession with order, with neatness, with stylistic purity  things that instantly put them at odds with reality, and which seem to mark them as nothing more than architects dream visions.

title: Business and the Law
description: LOTS of businessmen don't think much of the way lawyers think. The expression thinking like a lawyer is not often meant to be a compliment. When executives use it, they usually mean that lawyers are nitpickers who talk too much, are only too eager to assume a combative posture, and are reticent about weighing the risks and rewards their decisions.

title: Ballet: Choura, a Premiere by Arpin
description: THE Joffrey Ballet called its final premiere of the season, presented Wednesday night at the City Center 55th Street Theater. Choura.

title: Peace Talks Raise Hope of Egyptians for Better Life
description: CAIRO, Nov. 16  Saad Mohammed Saleh, a telephone repairman, labored over a worn cable protruding from one of Cairo's dusty streets. Why do you think we have had problems with our telephones? he asked. Because of poverty and corruption that arc the results of wars. I know that when peace comes,I will not have to worry about fixing the telephone wires.

title: GOV. BROWN FACING DECISION ON BUDGET
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16  With an impresSive reelection victory behind him, Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. has begun to put himself into position for making significant changes in California's government, including deep cuts in spending.

title: SHIPPING/MAILS
description: DORIC (Home). Left San Juan Nov. 14; due 8 A.M. et W. SSW. Street.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, NOV. 17, 1978

title: New Regime Moving Afghanistan Deeper Into Orbit of Soviet Union
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 15  The new Government of this remote Central Asian country, in its first six months in office, has moved clearly and decisively and, some say, irreversibly  into the orbit of the Soviet Union.

title: Indian Dock Workers Strike
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 17 (Reuters) About 100,000 dock workers went on strike today and union leaders said India's major ports, Bombay, Calcutta and Madras, were paralyzed. However, port officials said that enough workers had shown up in Calcutta and Madras to enable the docks to continue to operate.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: United Press International

title: Islanders Defeat Capitals
description: LANDOVER, Md., Nov. 17  The Washington Capitals started aggressively against the Islanders tonight and had a 20 lead halfway through the game. But an upset was not in the offing  a victory by the Capitals would have been their first over the New Yorkers in the 21 games they have played  as the Islanders accounted for the rest of the scoring to gain a 42 triumph.

title: POLL DROPS PAPER AFTER DATA CHANGE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  A polling company that carried out preelection surveys for The Minneapolis Tribune has parted ways with the newspaper, charging that its data were significantly altered when the polls were published.

title: Replacing That Bargain-Basement Image
description: Until two years ago, when most people thought of Macy's they thought of the Thanksgiving Day parade and the bargain basement. Then The Cellar

title: Market Up For 3d Day In a Row
description: The increasing strength of the dollar in foreign exchange markets helped the stock market register its third consecutive gain yesterday in moderate trading.

title: Suspects in Fatal Fire Get Threats
description: Tight security was instituted at a Bronx courtroom yesterday following ominous telephone calls regarding two I4-year-old youths after a seventh victim died from a fire they are accused of setting.

title: Jersey's AntiSmog Effort Praised by U.S. as Model
description: TRENTON, Nov. 17 A high official of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency had words of praise today for New Jersey's efforts to reduce automobile fumes and, while warning there was still a long way to go, said Washington was no longer threatening to order the state to curtail auto traffic and industrial expansion.

title: Over $30,000 Repaid By Teller of Fortunes To 3 Elderly Women
description: Three elderly women who gave a 21yearold gypsy fortune teller more than $30,000 in cash have got their money back, and the fortune teller pleaded guilty yesterday to grand larceny in State Supreme Court in Manhattan

title: Pillers, Dierking Listed As Likely Starters by Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 17  Lawrence Pillers, the New York Jets defensive end who suffered a hip pointer in Wednesday's practice, did not work out with the team today but is listed as a probable starter for Sunday's game against the New England Patriots in Shea Stadium. Gregg Robinson, a rookie from Dartmouth, is Pillers's backup.

title: Joffrey Ballet Performs Jerome Robbins's Moves
description: A girl suddenly breaks rank to tear across the stage. A boy crosses his arms. Another boy falls. Three girls bow slowly. Of such simple gestures is Jerome Robbins's ballet Moves made. But the work, seen at the City

title: Somoza Turns to U.S. Backers
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 17 President Anastasio Somoza Debayle turned today to his two strongest supporters in the United States Congress for help in generating foreign support for his proposals to settle Nicaragua's bloody internal conflict.

title: VANCE LAUDS EGYPT ON NEW PEACE IDEAS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that Egypt's latest ideas on linking the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty to the solution of the Palestinian problem were constructive and that the United States was awaiting Israel's response.

title: Deaths
description: SHAPIRDMartin, passed away November 16. He is retired postmaster Ira Brooklyn New York. Dear husband of Angela of Scottsdale Arizona. Brother of Mrs. Cle Cohen and Miss Ida Shapiro, both of Brooklyn. Funeral services 11 AM Monday in Whitney and Murphy Arcadia Funeral Home Chapel. Interment Greenwood Memorial Park, Phoenix Arizona 3PEK TOR Victeria.
