title: The Region
description: WEST MILFORD, N.J. (AP) A 95foothigh windmill was hooked into the electrical system of West Milford High School, ready to supply 2,000 watts an hour when needed. The $6,500 windpowered generator is expected to pay for itself within 10 years, and also will be used in two courses designed to teach students about energy and conservation.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: International

title: TV: _NBC's 4Part Series On Bible's Greatest Heroes
description: Cecil B. De Mille and the other Hollywood titans invariably cheapened the Bible when they made movies about it, but at least they spared no expense. Greatest Heroes of the Bible, which will be seen on four successive nights, starting tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. on NBCTV is cheap all the way through. _

title: VERNON S. JONES
description: Vernon Sims Jones, a former admiralty trial lawyer who retired in .1966 after more than 45 years of practice in New York, died Thursday in Mobile, Ala. He was 84 years old and formerly lived in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: Sambo's Under Fire Over Name
description: RAYNHAM, Mass., Nov. 17  It has been almost 80 years since the English children's story Little Black Sambo first lulled children to sleep, but the tale about a boy who watched tigers turn to butter is tripping up Sambo's, the national restaurant chain, as it pushes to establish itself among the leading familystyle restaurants in the Northeast.

title: Deaths
description: JOHNSON--Ethel Thornblade, widow of the late 0. Rudolph. Beloved mother of Barbara and Richard, loving grandmother of Thomas and Frances, dear mother-In-law of Ernest. There will be a gathering of family and friends at her home. 860 United Nations Plaza on Sunday from 12 to 3PM. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to the Com-

title: In a Sea of Rain, an Island of Free Enterprise
description: As a driving rain produced its usual blossoming of the itinerant umbrella trade, a woman set up shop yesterday at Lexington Avenue and 59th Street. Dressed in a hooded slicker- a brisk business precluded holding an umbrella herself  this wetweather merchant sold her stock pedestrians who either were caught unprepared by the storm, or simply couldn't pass up a good buy. Rain clouds and umbrella peddlers should be gone by this afternoon.

title: Corporate Earnings Reported
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New Vat Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) over-thecounter.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: United Press International

title: White House, Yielding
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  The Carter Administration retreated publicly today from a decision it made privately last summer that no one could see the full data relied on to support a White House assertion that the 1978 coal miners strike, if undeterred, would cause widespread industrial unemployment.

title: Books of The Times The Psychoanalytic Tango
description: Psychoanalysis appeared in France at about the same time that the tango did. Both were rejected as morally shocking and foreign to the French character. How could anyone teach a Frenchman savoir vivre? Bourgeois life was as much a monument as Chartres Cathedral.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON THE Bell System has an electronic blackboard by which handwritten messages and drawings can be transmitted over telephone lines for instant display. It is used by universities to give lessons In distant classrooms and by industry for such purposes as communication between engineers and factories.

title: Soviet Ships Stir Turkish Anger
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 17 (AP)Riot policemen and troops guarded the Soviet consulate here today after youths ransacked its display windows to protest against the visit of two Soviet warships to this NATO country. The cruiser Dzerzhinsky and the destroyer Rezhitleny, both carrying guided missies, are the first Russian naval vessels to officially call on Turkey since 1938.

title: 29 INDICTED BY U.S. IN CHICAGO AGENCY
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 17  A Federal grand jury here has returned indictments against 29 inspectors and supervisors in the city Building Department's Bureau of Electrical Inspection who are accused of extortion and of taking kickbacks from contractors as a condition of issuing work permits or of certifying completed work.

title: Pan Am Plans Shuttle
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  Pan American World Airways disclosed plans today for a shuttle service between Washington and the New York area at a peakhour oneway fare of $37, if its application to absorb National Airlines is approved.

title: Princeton Takes Sculpture Rejected at Kent State
description: A work by the sculptor George Segal commemorating the 1970 slaying of four students at Kent State University has been accepted by Princeton University after its rejection by the Kent State University board as inappropriate.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: While Refugees Wait Off Malaysian Coast, Talks Remain at Impasse
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Nov. 17  While the freighter Hai Hong, loaded with more than 2,500 refugees from Vietnam, remained off Port Kiang near here, critically short of water and medicine, negotiations on the fate of the refugees remained at an impasse.

title: Felicity on Eastern Parkway
description: Six months ago, we related what we called a New York City parable about Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn. The blacks who live to the north of it and the Orthodox Jews to the south are not exactly buddies, but they did agree that Eastern Parkway, designed by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vawc to permit people to sit outdoors and enjoy the shade of trees, should be named a landmark. That would prevent the grand drive from being turned into an expressway. Both black and white community boards voted to ask the Landmarks Preservation Commission to consent.

title: Cosmos Are Beaten, 42, By an Argentine Side
description: MAR DEL PLATA, Argentina, Nov. 17 (AP)  Argentina's Boca Juniors capitalized on defensive errors to defeat the Cosmos, champions of the North American Soccer League, 42, last night in an exhibition.

title: Janie FrickeCoun try Songs Full of Spunk
description: A year ago, hardly anyone had heard of Janie Fricke (as in picky). To be reasonable, not that many people have heard of her now. But at least in the world of country music she has become a name to reckon with. On Thursday sne and tier band got up at some ungodly hour to rehearse for and appear on NBCTV's Today show. Then she stayed awake all day and did two shows at the Lone Star Cafe in the late evening, the first of which was broadcast on WHN radio. A busy day, and at the second show Miss Fricke was still full of goodnatured spunk and still had a voice left to sing with.

title: News Summary
description: Afghanistan's new Government has moved decisively, some say irreversibly, into the Soviet orbit. Its rhetoric has become stridently Marxist, its foreign policy rigorously anti-imperialist. Even the national flag has been changed to resemble the Soviet Union's. Our fraternal and friendly ties with the Socialist camp are developing and expanding in a remarkable manner, Prime Minister Noor Mohammed Taraki said in an interview. [Page I, Columns 45. ]

title: Sinyaysky, on Art
description: The Russian writer Andrei D. Sinyaysky, who since 1973 has lived in selfexile in Paris. received on Thursday the $12,500 Bennett Award given biennially by The Hudson Review, a New Yorkbased quarterly, to a writer of significant achievement whose work has not received the full recognition deserves. Mr. Sinyaysky is author, among other works, of A Voice From the Chorus, based on letters sent to his wife from a labor camp where he spent six years after a trial on charges of antiSoviet activities that followed publication in the West of his writings under the pseudonym Abram Tertz. He was imprisoned in 1966, released in 1971 and given an exit visa in 1973. Following are excerpts from his acceptance speech here, translated, from the Russian, by Barry Rubin.

title: Iran's Affluent, Indebted to Shah, Give Him Little Support in Crisis
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 17  As Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi struggles to maintain his rule against an opposition alliance of conservative Islamic clergymen, radicalized students, workers and bazaar merchants, he has received few tangible expressions of support from the people who owe him the most  the middle and upper classes that have reaped the lion's share of oil nrnfitc

title: Canadian Retail Deal Stirs Battle
description: A major takeover battle erupted yesterday in Canada with announcement by the Hudson's Bay Company that it planned to make an offer for all the shares of Simpsons Ltd., Canada's fourthlareest retail chain.

title: Florida's Defeat of Gambling Seen as Measure of Maturity
description: MIAMI, Nov. 17  The defeat of casino gambling in Miami Beach, rather than being a setback for the Florida economy, is being hailed as a sionni of the state's coming of ace.

title: Celtics, With New Dedication, Start to Regroup Under Cowens
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Her Child Dies in Fire
description: Mrs. Marino Fernandez of 8 Rivington Street being comforted by a police officer and a fireman after learning that her son Anthony, 2, died in an early morning fire. Another two-year-old, Thomas Rodriguez, also perished in the blaze.

title: 70 Accused of Collecting Unearned $250,000
description: City's Hospitals Warned to Stop Doctors Frauds

title: Sparky Lyle Has His Say
description: The baseball season is a long way off, but Sparky Lyle has already started throwing sliders at the Yankees.

title: Associated Press
description: OUT OF HIS ELEMENT: Gerry Cheevers blocking Jean Pronovost of the Flames as the Boston goalie cleared puck during a Flames power play in first period last night at Atlanta. Bruins won, 62.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: The City
description: Students at Public School 98 have begun wearing coats in their classrooms as they await the long delayed emergency repair of more than 100 windows broken during an explosion a month ago.

title: S.I. Rabbi Gets a Year In SchoolLunch Fraud
description: A Staten Island rabbi was sentenced yesterday to a year and a day in prison following his conviction on charges of filing fraudulant claims totaling more than $20,000 in connection with a Federal summer for schoolchildren.

title: Audit Disputes L.I.R.R. OnTime Records
description: Many commuter trains on the Long Island Rail Road ran faster 75 years ago than they do now, the New York State Comptroller's office reported yesterday.

title: 2 More Officers Facing Charges Of Improprieties
description: Two more police officers, both assigned to foot patrol in the Times Square area, are facing departmental trials for being off their posts, and authorities voiced concern yesterday that the problem of cooping by police officers appeared to be growing serious again.

title: Defense in Texas Trial Cross-Examines a Star Witness
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 17  Attorneys for T. Cullen Davis, who are expected to argue that the murder-for-hire charges against their client are a result of a frameup, took their first apparent steps in that direction today.

title: Westchester Considers 2d Airport, Possibly on Hudson
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 17  A second airport in Westchester County  possibly on a peninsula in the Hudson River known as Croton Point Park  is under review by the county's Airport Advisory Board, which is considering recommending that the county's Board of Legislators undertake a feasibility study of such a facility.

title: FRANCIS X. O'BRIEN, RETIRED JURIST, 73
description: Former Judge Francis X. O'Brien of Criminal Court, who was involved in the controversial acquittal of another judge's son, Gareth Martinis, in 1963, died yesterday of Parkinson's disease at his home in the Fordham section of the Bronx. He was 73 years old.

title: 3 Children and Mother Slain
description: A Queens man called 911 last night and reported to the police that he had killed his wife and three children. Investigating officers arrested the man, Winston Evans, after they found his wife, Marrilene, 30 years old and chit- dren Michelle, 10; Warren, 8, and Ameyo- a girl 6 all dead, possibly of strangulation, at the family home 8967 210 Street in the Hollis section of Queens.

title: Jersey Moves to Raise Tuition Rates in State Colleges
description: TRENTON, Nov. 17  The State Board of Higher Education today adopted a tuition policy for statefinanced colleges and universities that will lead eventually to undergraduate students paying 30 percent of the cost of their education and to graduate students and nonresident undergraduates paying 45 percent.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: OBSERVER
description: Outside the window at this very moment a man is parking a 20foot car in a 19foot space. He has been working at it for 10 minutes. It is a classic illustration of the New York temperament.

title: Woman Sentenced to 10 Years
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Nov. 17 (AP)  A 38yearold woman from Nashville was sentenced today to 10 years in prison and fined $10,000 for importing $14.3 million worth of cocaine into Puerto Rico. The wom.am_Betty J. Inman, was also sentenced to serve six months in jail for importing $65,000 in undeclared cash and to two years in prison for bringing in 163 items of undeclared jewelry from Caracas, Venezuela. The prison tearms are to be served concurrently.

title: Fidelity Bank Plans Changes
description: The Fidelity Bank of Philadelphia announced yesterday a move to consolidate its holdings in France. Under an agreement in principle, its wholly owned subsidiary, Fidelity BankFrance S.A., is to be acquired by the Banque de In MediterraneeFrance S.A., of which Fidelity of Philadelphia owns 22.6 percent. The bank said it expected the acquisition to be accomplished by the end of the year.

title: Another Exchange Merger Bid
description: In the latest round of merger proposals among exchanges, the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange proposed a merger yesterday with the New York Cocoa Exchange, which is also being courted by the Amex Commodity Exchange, a unit of the American Stock Exchange.

title: Letter On Indira Gandhi
description: To the Editor:

title: Human Rights Panel Charges Nicaragua Victimized Population
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  The InterAmerican Commission on Human Rights accused the Nicaraguan Government today of flagrant, persistent abuses of human rights, including summary executions, torture, arbitrary detention, indiscriminate bombing of unarmed civilians and obstructing the humanitarian efforts of the Red Cross.

title: Palette of Bright Metals Colors Artist's Jewelry
description: Seated in her cluttered SoHo loft studio, surrounded by her paintings and the tools of her trade, Marci Zelmanoff discussed the direction her jewelry has taken over the past two years, a rich period of creativity culminating in a onewoman show, Works in Metal: 197678, at the Aaron Farber Gallery, 666 Fifth Avenue, through next Saturday.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week.

title: Doctor, 76, Kills Wife, Then Self With a Shotgun
description: An elderly doctor killed his wife of 34 years with two shotgun blasts to the head and then took his own life in their East Side duplex cooperative apartment early yesterday mornine the police said.

title: CLARIFICATION
description: A picture in Metropolitan Report on Thursday, accompanying an article about violations of New York's genericdrug act, showed the Worth Pharmacy in the Bronx. Worth complies with the law, as evidenced by the list of drugs and prices visible in the picture; The Times did not intend to imply otherwise.

title: Pittston Makes Final Bid
description: The Pittston Company, a diversified concern with extensive coal interests, announced yesterday a second and final extension of its cash tender offer to purchase any and all of the publicly held shares of Brink's Inc. common stock to 5 P.M. next Wednesday. Before the offer, Pittston owned about 86 percent of Brink's common stock. Brink's is the armored car subsidiary of Pittston.

title: FRANCE LAUX
description: EUREKA, Mo., Nov. 17 (UPI)France Laux, who broadcast baseball games for the St. Louis Cardinals during the days of the Gashouse Gang, died of heart disease at a nursing home yesterday. He was 80 years old.

title: World News Briefs
description: COPEHAG EN, Denmark, Nov. 17 (AP)  The Danish Parliament voted today to grant Greenlanders home rule on their 890,000-square-mile island, the world's largest.

title: Business Records
description: FRIDAY, NOV. 17, 1978

title: Victims of Urban Revival
description: For years, urbanists have bemoaned the flight of young couples to the suburbs. They have urged steps to reverse that flight in the belief that the only true hope for urban revival rests in the vitality  and tax dollars  of new middleclass families. Well, now there is movement back, still barely more than a trickle, but pviripni in many cities. Youn2 people who two decades ago would have settled in a Levittown, are gravitating toward neighborhoods like New York City's Soho or Brooklyn Heights. The urbanists should be delighted, but they are not; the new movement exacts a price.

title: Mayor to Give Arts Awnrds to 20
description: A score 01 New York's finest, in arts and culture, will be anointed in an Egyptian temple in municipal ceremonies Monday evening, Nov. 27.

title: Hayes Paces Bullets In 14394 Rout of Nets
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Nov. 17  The Washington Bullets ground out a relentless 14394 victory over the New Jersey Nets tonight  a triumph that made the losers appear almost like a junior varsity squad.

title: Ivy League Race to End Today In Typically Scrambled Fashion
description: While Penn State, the No. I college team in the nation, is idle today, waiting to see if it goes to the Orange Bowl, and other teams seek bids to bigmoney bowl games, the Ivy Leaguers, who scorn such postseason madness, will finish another of their typically wild and surnrising seasons.

title: Citibank Lifts Prime Rate to 11%
description: Citibank raised its prime rate on corporate loans yesterday to 11 percent from 10% percent, joining five other major banks that had posted that figure earlier this week, and the higher rate quickly became almost industry. wide.

title: Claude Dauphin Dies in Paris; Stage and Film Actor Was 75
description: PARIS, Nov. 17  Claude Dauphin, the internationally known French film and stage actor, died last night at the age of 75. The cause of death was given as an intestinal occlusion. American audiences saw him most recently as the aged doctor with Simone Signoret in the French movie Madame Rosa.

title: Shaheen Gets Refinery Aid
description: John M. Shaheen, president of the Shaheen Natural Resources Company, got some encouragement from the government of Newfoundland yesterday in his struggle to regain control over a bankrupt refinery at Come-by-Chance, Newfoundland.

title: Egypt Seeks to Deny Charge of Hardening Terms
description: CAIRO, Nov. 17  The authoritative Cairo paper Al Ahram said today that Egypt, seeking to rebut charges that it had hardened its position in peace talks with Israel, had agreed with the United States that local elections in the West Bank of the Jordan be held a year after an EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty was signed, but had asked that the period for Gaza be limited to six months.

title: Regents Ask State to Add $246 Million in School Aid
description: The New York State Board of Regents has asked the State Legislature to increase aid to local school districts by $246 million, or about 8 percent, for the 197980 school year. If this happens, New York City would get an increase of $83 million  about 10 percent  but aid would decrease in some parts of the state, especially in wealthy suburban areas.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Music

title: World Gold
description: FRIDAY, NOV 11, 1978

title: Guilty in British Secrecy Trial
description: LONDON, Nov. 17A former army intelligence corporal and two journalists were convicted today of violating the Official Secrets Act. In effect, the court placed all three on probation.

title: Gas Law: Will It Help or Hurt?; Effect on U.S. Energy Picture Is Uncertain
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 17  If the Brooklyn Union Gas Company is right, the natural gas provisions of the new National Energy Act will at last guarantee an abundant supply of heating and cooking gas for 1.1 million customers in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island, at very little more money than they would pay otherwise.

title: A FoodStamp Ban Raises Froth
description: The Department of Agriculture was accused yesterday of being arbitrary and capricious in deciding that beer and soft drinks were less important to the general welfare and not more nutritive than foods approved for purchase for food stamps.

title: Around the Nation
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 17 (AP)  A suburban Pittsburgh water authority continued to fluoridate its water today, despite a judge's order to stop adding the chemical because he was persuaded it may cause cancer.

title: Circulation Low, Viva Magazine to Halt in January
description: Troubled by faltering circulation, Viva magazine, a five-year-old monthly aimed at sophisticated career women, announced yesterday that it would cease publication with its January issue.

title: The Land of the Free Agent
description: The most glamorized and least understood person in professional sports is the free agent. To become one, an athlete must first quit his job and then go it alone in the auction market. Some become rich, some become unemployed.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LIFE AND TIME 50 years ago, in a spectacularly large business move from Broadway, the New York Life Insurance Company shifted its headquarters to a formidable new office tower at 51 Madison Avenue, between 26th and 27th Streets. Over the years, the 34story structure has stood fast in a changing area dominated by the adjacent Madison Square, once the social center of Manhattan and now a park. A new anniversary exhibition of pictures covering the history of the section has just opened in New York Life's 400foot main arcade, the design of which was patterned after the nave of England's Salisbury Cathedral.

title: Nicklaus Leads on 66
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 17 (UP1)  Jack Nicklaus shook off a nagging shoulder injury and carded a courserecord six-under-par 60 today, gaining a fourstroke lead after the second round of the $250,000 Australian open.

title: Balancing Secrets and Rights
description: The defendant, charged with bribing a foreign official, is about to go on trial. He wants to persuade the jury that an American intelligence agency condoned or induced the crime. So he proposes to offer evidence that might compromise state secrets, and subpoenas it from the Government. The Government faces a dilem- ma. If it produces the material, it will jeopardize the secrets. But if it does not and the material is relevant, that will surely jeopardize the defendant's right to a fair trial.

title: McEnroe Advances In England
description: WEMBLEY, England, Nov. 17 (AP) John McEnroe advanced to the semifinals of a $175,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament today and was then treated by a doctor for a high temperature and suspected tonsilitis. Dick Stockton, Tim Gullikson and Arthur Ashe also advanced, putting four Americans into the semifinals in pursuit of the $36,400 first prize.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Growing confidence in the United States dollar and potentially larger gold supplies shattered recent commodity price trends this week as silver and livestock prices rose while gold and most grain prices fell.

title: W.T.T. Surveying Franchises
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 17 (AP) World Team Tennis, currently a twoteam league commissioned a marketing consulting firm today to help evaluate applications for franchises. Commissioner Butch Buchholz said that the league plans to announce the first group of new franchises within two weeks. The Golden Gaters and Phoenix Racquets are the only surviving teams of the 10 that operated last season.

title: Plop, Plop, Fizz, Fizz, For Olympics in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 17  The Soviet Union, acknowledging the effects of local cuisine on foreign tourists,said today it would provide plentiful sup.. plies of AlkaSelt3er during the 19S0 Olympic Games.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions on page 18.

title: Coach Cowens Aids Victory in His Debut
description: BOSTON, Nov. 17 (AP)The Boston Celtics, returning to their old racehorse style in Dave Cowens's debut as playercoach, snapped a sixgame losing streak tonight with a 120118 Nhtional Basketball Association victory over the Denver Nuggets.

title: ISRAELIS PREPARING . KEY PEACE DECISIONS
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 17  Defense Minister Ezer Weizman, one of Israel's top negotiators at the Washington peace talks with Egypt, returned home today for a crucial Cabinet meeting Sunday.

title: About New York
description: The lonely lawman infiltrating the cabals of the bad guys; the villains putting a tail on our hero who has had a contract put out on him and has scorned enticing bribes. All this is old hat to us television viewers and thrillnovel readers. This is the stuff that light summer fiction is made of., as well as bigname movies. What does come as a surprise is to meet a fellow who does exactly that sort of a thing for living.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 17 (AP)  The P.R. Mallory Company, the maker of Duracell batteries and other products, today agreed to a $250 million merger with Dart Industries.

description: Mortimer Landsberg, a retired stock broker and former chairman of the American Stock Exchange, has died in Del Ray Beach, Fla. He was 89 years old.

title: You Could Look It Up
description: ROANOKE, Va.Football is a fantasy anyway, the American male's gaudiest and goriest, but when I muse on gridiron glory, as now and then I do, it is to dream not of being a Viking, Ram or Redskin, like normal men, but of beingonce again a Raven.

description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation, battling an appeals court order that it conduct a new election of directors, asked the court yesterday to delay the order so that the company could appeal it to the United States Supreme Court.

title: E.F. Hutton Is Accused By S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused E.F. Hutton & Company, one of Wall Street's most prestigious brokerage firms, of having aided the manipulation of the price of Rapid American common stock on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Prudential Group Action
description: The Prudential Group Inc. has been advised by the American Stock Exchange that the exchange is filing an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission to remove the company's stock from listing because the company is below the Amex guidelines for continued listing as a result of its record of losses. Since Prudential is considering transferring its shares to NASDAQ, however, the Amex has agreed to allow trading in Prudential to continue for the interim period.

title: Sports News Briefs

title: AntiInflation Guides For HealthCare Costs To Be Published Soon
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  The Carter Administration will soon publish specific antiinflation guidelines for the health industry, which has been a major factor in soaring prices, Administration officials disclosed today.

title: Postal Contract Goes to I.T.T.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  The United States Postal Service today took another step toward entry into electronic communications by awarding 188,550 contract to I.T.T. World Communications to provide international links for a test program.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP)  The Federal Reserve Board today proposed prices that it wants to charge banks for the checkclearing services it provides.

description: Exactly a year ago today, 20,000 people most of them women  gathered in Houston for the historic first National Women's Conference. For the next four days, this rainbow of women, as they came to be called because of their racial and economic diversity, met, talked, argued, demonstrated and compromised.

title: British Lawmaker Wants Nixon Banned as an Undesirable Alien
description: LONDON, Nov. 17 (AP)  A British lawmaker said today that former President Richard M. Nixon should be banned from Britain as an undesirable alien.

title: Samuel S. Stevens, 77, Inventor Of Paper-Manufacturing Devices
description: Samuel S. Stevens, inventor and paper manufacturer, died Tuesday of cancer at his home in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 77 years old.

title: Jack Levine Paintings At the Jewish Museum
description: When the Jewish Museum was installing the large retrospective honoring Jack Levine, he prowled the halls. Short of drowning, how often does one's life pass before one's eyes?

title: INDUSTRIAL NATIONS GIVE BACKING TO U.S. ON ECONOMIC MOVES
description: PARIS, Nov. 17  Despite fears that economic growth in the United States may be curtailed and that a recession is possible in 1979, members of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development overwhelmingly endorsed the Carter Administration's recent moves to curb inflation and support the I dollar.

title: Associated Press
description: HARBINGER OF YULETIDE: A 75foot Norway spruce being lifted into position over the iceskating rink at Rockefeller Center yesterday. The center's 1978 Christmas tree will be lighted Dec. 4.

title: Profits Up 18%, Survey Says
description: The nation's major corporations reported profit increases of 18 percent for the third quarter, and 13 percent for the first nine months of this yeargains that are not expected to be matched in 1979, a Citibank survey reoorted yesterday.

title: U.S. Will Accept Refugees but Not From Freighter
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  The Carter Administration offered today to admit to this country up to 2,500 additional boat refugees from Vietnam who are stranded in Malaysia while it tries to persuade the Malaysian Government to grant safe haven to that same number of refugees aboard the freighter Hai Hong.

title: British Inflation Rate
description: LONDON, Nov. 17 (AP)  Britain recorded an annual inflation rate of 7.8 percent in October, unchanged from September, the Department of Employment announced today. It was the seventh successive month that the retail price index has remained at or below 8 percent, in line with Labor Gov- ernment predictions that the inflation raid would stay around 8 percent the rest of this year. Prices Secretary Roy Hattersley warned that inflation was hound to go up in the corning year trade unions persisted in demanding wage settlements in excess of the Government's 5 percent wage guidelines for the year that began Aug. 1.

title: Ulster Situation Is Quieter, But Calm Is Only on Surface
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 15  The chief voice of moderation in Northern Ireland's Roman Catholic minority has hardened its position on British withdrawal from Ireland and aroused strong new debate on the province's political future.

title: O'Grady Stops Harris
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 17 (AP Sean O'Grady defeated Freddie Harris in their junior welterweight bout last night when Harris was unable to continue in the seventh round because his eye was swollen shut. O'Grady's wonlost record is now 591 with 54 knockouts. Harris is 2711.

title: Soviet Tested a Neutron Weapon, Brezhnev Tells Group of Senators
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 17  Leonid 1. Brezhnev told 12 visiting United States senators today that the Soviet Union had tested a neutron weapon many years ago but had never put it into production.

title: Bridge:
description: DENVER, Nov. 17  There are four defending champions, double the usual number, in the national mixed pairs, which began here this afternoon with an entry of 498 pairs.

title: Conflict With Hanoi Spurs Peking Moves to End Isolation
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 17  The tour of Southeast Asia by the senior Chinese Deputy Prime Minister, Teng Hsiaoping, which ended Tuesday on a subdued note in Singapore, underscores the problems Chinese foreign policy faces.

title: Blitzstein's Regina

title: Group at Berkeley, Attacking University's Management of 2 Atom Weapons Labs, Urges Peaceful Uses
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 17  The University of California is facing internal criticism for its management of the laboratories at Livermore, Calif., and Los Alamos, N.M., where the nation's nuclear weapons are designed.

title: Housing Pace Firm In October
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP)  New housing construction continued at strong pace in October despite rising prices and interest rates, the Commerce Department said today.

title: The Office of the Citizen
description: Felix Frankfurter used to say that the highest office in a democracy was the office of citizen. That principle is celebrated in an unusual award given every, three years in the name of one of its great practitioners: the late Grenville Clark, a patrician New York lawyer who devoted much of his life to public causes, notably world peace and civil rights.

title: Another SlowMoving Saga of the L(ate). I. R. R.
description: The schedule for the 6:24 A.M. Long Island Rail Road train from Speonh says that passengers, after changing at Jamaica, will get to Pennsylvania Station at 8:35. On Thursday, they arrived at 9:58.

title: Ashford and Simpson Open At the Palace as Sony Team
description: Nickols Ashford and Valerie Simpson are from New York City, and they could not have asked for a hometown cheering section more vocal and enthusiastic than the audience at their Palace Theater opening Thursday night. A woman somewhere in the back sang gospel obbligatos, others bantered freely with Mr. Ashford and just about everybody clapped, whistled and jumped up and down. It may have been the opening of a fournight run on Broadway, a first for Ashford and Simpson, but the atmosphere was informal, communal, like a neighborhood church service.

title: Alaska Officials Irked by Order Barring U.S. Land Development
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  Alaskan officials today bitterly criticized an administrative order signed last night by Cecil D. Andrus, the Secretary of the Interior, blocking for as long as three years all state and private development on more than 110 million acres of Federal lands in the state.

title: Margaret Mead's Zest Is Recalled at Columbia Rite
description: Dr. Margaret Mead's spiritual as well as scientific zeal was recalled yesterday in a memorial service at Columbia University. She had, it was said, a restless drive to explore the most profound truths about how people develop and grow and sustain meaning.

title: U.S. Gives Europeans Assurance
description: GENEVA, Nov. 17  The Carter Administration assured Western Europe today that it could resolve the impasse that threatens the tradeliberalizing negotiations under way here and that may push the world into increased protectionism.

I never saw any MexicanAmericans, Mr. Amaparan recalled recently. I didn't relate to it. I just thought, there go the firemen.

title: Iranian Army Parades in Teheran

The Public Service Commission said yesterday that Continental would pay $52.1 million for the acquisition.

title: ExConvict Is Charged In Policeman's Shooting
description: A 29-year-old Bronx man released from prison last month after serving 10 years for manslaughter was arrested yesterday afternoon on charges of shooting a police officer in the neck in a servicestation robbery, the police said.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING The Pitfalls of Buying a House
description: FOR Ava Friedman, it's been long, long time from May to November. On May 13, Miss Friedman and her thenfianc saw a house in the Morris County community of Flanders, and she immediately put down a $500 deposit.

title: 2 French Painters at National Gallery
description: WASHINGTON  The good news from the National Gallery of Art is that the original West Building, to which we all owe so much, is once again in the business of mounting temporary exhibitions. Since the new East Wing was opened earlier this year to the sound of more trumpets than were needed to bring down the walls of Jericho, there has undeniably been a look of marmoreal forlornness about the West Building. It's ridiculous  the West Building still houses one of the world's greatest collections of painting  but people have got so conditioned to novelty that they judge museums more by what comes and goes than by what sits there all the time.

title: House Committee Rescues A Mural by Rockwell Kent
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18  Hidden behind a dry wall for more than a decade, large mural by the late Rockwell Kent has been rescued from oblivion by House committee.

title: Miss Spiess Will Be Bride Of Roy J. Jones Jr. in July
description: Dr. and Mrs. Walter C. Spiess Jr. of Lloyd Harbor in Huntington, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Louise Spiess, to Roy James Jones Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jones of Huntington. The wedding is planned for next July.

title: Playing Out Options at City Hall
description: The Region

title: Whose Dream?
description: BROOKLINE, Mass.  I have Ph.D. from a major West Coast university in a timehonored field of humanistic studies. I taught for five years after receiving my degree at major East Coast university. I was the first woman to be hired in a regular position in my department. I did not receive tenure. In i.he past three years I have been unemployed or marginally employed. I have averaged an annual earned income of $6,700 after 10 years of graduate study and almost as many years of teaching experience. I am selfsupporting. I have reared one child and contributed as much as I could to her college education, completed this year. My younger child will graduate from high school in five years. I am currently unemployed, despite seven months of correspondence with 15 different institutions. I am said to be ineligible for unemployment compensation because I have a contract to teach in the spring term (for $7,000). I'm grateful to have that.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE State Legislature, which has met spasmodically during the year, is about to call it quits for 1978. It will meet tomorrow and perhaps twice in December; however, unless ,.he cities can bring enough pressure to persuade the. Legislature to appropriate some extra money to help tide them over, nothing of great importance is expected to. emerge.

description: When Thomas and Sharon Kowalchuk went house hunting last February, never crossed their minds that they were hedding for a financial shock.

description: IF YOU move into Mountain Lakes  in fact, even if you already live in Mountain Lakes  by far the best way to get acquainted with your neighbors, new or old, is to begin eating.

The disease center said that four cases of Russian flu had been confirmed in Texas.

title: Inflation Saga: Great Exhortations
description: The hardselling of President Carter's antiinflation policy began in earnest last week, with the White House prophesying depression around the corner if the program's wageprice guidelines are not adhered to.

description: HOUSTON, Nov. 18 (AP)  Rick Barry tallied a seasonhigh 38 points and Mike Dunleavy added 22 to lead the Houston Rockets to a 126120 triumph over the San Antonio Spurs tonight.

title: CAMERA
description: Camera owners who may not have taken a picture in months will almost always take their cameras out for some picturetaking ses sions during the coming holiday season. Regardless of whether they are taking pictures of a family gathering, the turkey being carved, or ;the highlights of a late fall or winter :vacation trip, all too often the results ;are disappointingly poor  either be:cause the camera was not properly .taken care of and prepared, or be:cause the photographer was not familiar with some basic techniques that could bring life to the pictures.

description: Runaway interest :rates, inflation and the specter of recession all help to explain the apocalyptic view that many investors are taking of. the stock market, but there may be a, fourth horseman in the scenario, toothe Revenue Act of 1978.

title: Teacher Indicted in Bribery Case
description: A Staten Island school teacher, Berardino De Santis, has been indicted in Manhattan on a Federal bribery charge. He was accused of paving a $1,500 bribe to a loss-verifier for ate Small Business Administration to obtain a disaster loan. Mr. De Santis, who lives at 184 Arnold Street, is a general contractor as well as a teacher at McKee Vocational High School.

description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 18 (AP) Paul McDonald threw two touchdown passes in the second period and Charles White became Southern California's career leader in rushing today, carrying the Trojans to a 1710 victory over the University of California, Los Angeles, and a spot in the Rose Bowl New Year's Day.

title: Old Man and Nun
description: MUNICH, West Germany (AP)  If your car stalls on a German highway, you're most likely to be helped if you're an elderly man or a nun, the German magazine Quick says.

title: Ellen Joan Greene Engaged
description: The engagement of Ellen Joan Green e to Ira Seth Friedberg has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Greene of Passaic. N.J. Mr. Friedberg is a son of Mrs. Julius Fenster, also of Passaic, and the late Robert Friedberg. A winter wedding is planned.

title: BORDENTOWN FIGHTS TOXIC-WASTE DUMP
description: BORDENTOWN TOWNSHIP, N.J., Nov. 18  While 50 high school students stood chanting in a chilly rain outside the regional high school here last night, an acrid public hearing was held inside on a problem that is spreading in communities such as this across the nation  what to do with toxic chemical wastes.

description: WHATEVER happened to motherhood? In the nottoodistant past, when my interest in local government evolved from theory and philosophy to direct action, the one goal upon which every political figure and average citizen could agree was that help when needed  be offered to our senior citizens.

title: A Clean
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 18  In the interest of preserving documents, the new home of Florida's archives is extraordinarily clean and climatecontiolled. And many of the people who work there have reported symptoms of a mysterious sickness.

The doctor asks this question throughout his remarkable book and invariably answers it affirmatively. Not with totally blind enthusiasm, however. He is opposed to

title: PANELS IN CONGRESS TO GET NEW HEADS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18  As a result of retirements and the recent election, number of important committee changes will take place when the 96th Congress convenes on Jan. 15.

title: 20 Cities In Competition For AllAmerican
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 18 (UPI) The last of 20 cities seeking designation as an AllAmerican community have finished asserting their claims to the title here before a 12member jury of the National Municipal League.

description: JERUSALEM  Before the 1973 war, Israel was minor arms merchant with sales averaging $60 million year in a market dominated by the United States, the Soviet Union, France and Britain. Since then, Israel's military merchandise for sale has increased by at least six times, with sales this year estimated at $400 million.

title: Lake Placid Pretends To Play It Cool

This spirit tinges all the winter sports with excitement: on the ski slopes on Whiteface, which has the greatest vertical drop in the East (3,178 feet); on the only bobsled run in North America, and the only one in the world to accept noncrew passengers; on the crosscountry ski trails, skating rinks, snowmobile routes, sleigh rides, dogsled tours and toboggan slides.,

For the stitched exercises in lettering, numbers and pictorial motifs that young girls from to 18 years of age executed in the 18th and 19th centuries, have only recPntly become widely collected. And in that period, such designs which had for decades sparked the packaging of Whitman's chodolates, became part of the permanent collection of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, lhe gift in 1969 of the Whitman's Chocolates Division of Pet Incorporated. Several of the more than 500 needlework selections in that assemblage are always on view at the museum, and a selection of the rest are part of a show that has been traveling to museums and historical societies around the country.

title: Ohio State 21
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. 18 (UPI)  Ricky Johnson, a substitute tailback, broke loose for a 96yard touchdown run in the final period today to give Ohio State a 2118 triumph over Indiana and set up a Big Ten Conference showdown with Michigan next Saturday for the league championship.

title: Backing of Unit's Right to Fund Antiunion Lawsuits Is Set Aside
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP)  A Federal appeals court has set aside a lower court ruling that had upheld the right of an antiunion group to finance lawsuits filed against unions by dissident members.

It wouldn't matter, if it was just plain old Bob and Ed and Peter and Dick and Pat and Tom. but in each case it was a highly regarded professional pollster advising an incumbent United States Senator on this month's election.

title: Xerox's Turn

The goal: a highspeed, satellite- based communications network that Xerox would build and operate to serve business clients. It is the same market that the American Telegraph and Telephone Company and the International Business Machines Corporation have taken a bead on.

title: TV VIEW
description: Earlier this year, the only production on CBS to receive a Peabody Award was Camera Three, longrunning series nestled in the out-of-the-way slot of 11 o'clock on Sunday morning. The award's citation read, in part: When network television programming was in its infancy, CBS decided soonsor a halfhour weekly series devoted to culture. The re- suit was an experiment in serious television called Camera Three. Its single goal  to explore the marketplace of ideas  is still being pursued. . . . Camera Three has vigorously explored the arts world with such sustained interest over the years that a retrospective of shows could provide a most fascinating glimpse into the best of our cultural life. Its consistently high quality fare has won a remarkably loyal audi, ence.

title: Should More People Have a Voice in TV?
description: To persons wishing to have their specialinterest programs, concerns, advertising, ideologies and candidacies disseminated through television, the medium is becoming increasingly frustrating. Some major program suppliers in Hollywood, as well as independent producers, argue that with only three commercial networks, the marketplace is too restricted, and that public television, with its limited financial resources, does little to expand the field. Interest grotips complain that there is a lack of genuine diversity of viewpoints and that extreme and perhaps unpopular viewpoints rarely get an airing. Political figures, particularly minorparty candidates, contend there Is seldom a sufficient forum afforded them. And members of the general public, in letters and telephone calls to stations, often cite the lack of opportunity to talk back and have their opinions

title: Fighting Inflation
description: WASHINGTON  When President Carter met last week with business leaders to urge their cooperation in the Administration's newly intensified drive to combat inflation, the emphasis was on private sector prices. But the Administration also recognizes the

title: PEOPLE
description: Although he declined to give any specifics, Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland said he had the feeling the Chinese are in a shopping mood. After a 10day trip to China, he told reporters in Hong Kong last week that China probably would become an increasingly bigger buyer of grain from the United States. He said he had assured the Chinese that the U.S. would be dependable suppliers. The trip also resulted in an agreement on scientific and technical exchanges with China.

title: China Moves To Keep Them Happy Down On the Farm
description: HONG KONG Chinese agriculture has begun what appears to be its most extensive change since Mao Tsetung established the people's communes 20 years ago. As part of an urgent effort to raise stagnating farm output, Peking's leaders have reversed Mao's policies to offer China's 700 million peasants greater material incentives plus greater freedom from state control.

description: To paraphrase an old Chinese saying, the path to an Olympic gold medal in basketball starts with a single dribble.

The director of the laboratory, Richard Petluck, gave up his job as an elsmentaryschool teacher four years ago, when he moved to Israel and turned his hobby, guns, into his vocation.

title: Other Ideas &
description: Monks at St. Makarios monastery in Egypt's Western Desert say they may have found the bones of John the Baptist, whose relics are said in some ancient manuscripts to have been translated to the vicinity. In 1976, 19 bodies were found in a forgotten cave under a chapel, but there were only 13 skulls, leading to the surmise ttat the leftover could be John, who was beheaded at the order of King Herod. Monks said the find was kept secret to prevent a rush of pilgrims from interfering with restoration, but at last it leaked. If the remains are really John's, the find should gratify Egypt's President Anwar elSadat while discomfiting Syria's President Hafez alAssad; John is also a saint to Islam, and until now was supposed to be buried in the Great Mosque at Damascus.

title: Casino Gambling Is Favored in Poll
description: LONG ISLANDERS are worried about the future of their communities; overwhelmingly want tax relief and would welcome innovations such as casino gambling that niight bring new revenue to the areas, a New York Times suburban poll shows. At the same time, the poll shows them to be,apposed, 2 to 1, to construction of additional nuclear power plants.

description: SONNY'S PLACE, an attractive clubbar at 3603 Merrick Road in Seaford, features live jazz seven nights a week. When Sonny Meyerowitz, a longtime jazz fan, bought the establishment six years ago, few considered it suitable for live music, nor did many believe that any club could survive outside New York City with an alljazz policy.

title: The New York Times/ Roger W. Strong
description: TRIALS OF A SIDEWALK VENDOR: An outdoor watch salesman was evicted from spot on 42rd Street after local merchant's complaint. As policeman gave order, customers still browsed and vendor packed for new location.

title: POISONOUS FALLOUT FROM THE WAR ON MARIJUANA
description: Daryl Dodson, then a $125aweek intern on the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, first heard that the Mexican Government was spraying a lungseeking poison on illegal marijuana fields in February 1977. He did not believe it. Keith Stroup, director of the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws (NORML), first heard about aerial spraying of the Mexican marijuana fields with this lethal herbicide  paraquat  a few months earlier. He, too, did not believe it. But both Dodson and Stroup were curious about the stories that a reporter, Craig Copetas, was filing in High Times magazine about the use of paraquat in the MexicanAmerican war against marijuana, and both of them did something about it. Dodson's research began a Senate subcommittee investigation that led, finally, to Government testing of contaminated Mexican marijuana. Keith Stroup added paraquat to his 1977 lobbying agenda, and took his list to the basement office where Dr. Peter Bourne, an old friend, had just started working as the director of the White House Office of Drug Abuse Policy. Dr. Bourne also did not stories.

title: Agency Offices Stir Controversy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI)  With the completion this year of the new Federal Home Loan Bank Board building a block from the White House, controversy has arisen because the operator of the employee cafeteria has turned it into a discotheque each evenine.

description: BOSTON, Nov. 18 (AP)  The tall ships whose parade into Boston Harbor two years ago brought back the glories of the age of sail are coming back to help the city celebrate its 350th birthday in 1980.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Arguing that Nome, Alaska, had one of the highest alcohol consumption rates in the world  four gallons a year for every resident over the age of 15 a local group succeeded early this year in getting a proposition on the ballot to ban the sale of liquor. The leader of the drive, the Rev. John Shaffer, a minister to both Presbyterians and Methodists in Nome, said alcohol was causing serious health and crime problems.

description: MANSFIELD, Ohio, Nov. 18  A string of grand jury investigations and the indictments of three sheriffs in the last month have initiated a broad challenge to the integrity and possibly the authority of Ohio's principal law enforcers.

title: How to Go Nuts With the Squirrels
description: YOU don't have to be a true birder to like birds. Getting up at daybreak and tramping through woods or swamps to peer through binoculars at some rara avis flying high in the sky is my idea of nothing to do. But I get a kick out of the birds in my own backyard. So when the first autumn breeze Wows, the regulars start lining up on branches and railings near the house to give me a squawking reminder: Get out the feeders.

title: ART VIEW
description: The modernist art produced in Russia in the years just before and after the Revolution of 1917 has long been a matter of special interest to connoisseurs of avantgarde art in the West, and this interest has never been higher than it is at the present moment. Museum curators on both sides of the Atlantic long to procure precious loans from the Soviet state museums for a definitive exhibition of the subject, but they have been regularly defeated by the Soviet bureaucracy from realizing this goal. Official policy in the Soviet Union still withholds assent from these amazing productions of 60 or more years ago, and no fullscale survey of the Russian avantgarde can be mounted without access to the collections that continue to repose in the storerooms of the Soviet museums. From time to time a few pictures are released for some special occasion abroad, but the bulk of the work remains beyond the reach of Western museum officials.

title: SHOP TALK Stony Brook's Finds
description: STONY BROOK'S Main Street shopping center is a great place to do your day-to-day shopping. It is also a good place to go if you are looking for slightly offbeat gifts. And if you make shopping a family affair. on Saturday with a few avid nonshoppers in tow, it's ideal. The location, on a hill just off the shores of Long Island Sound, offers a spectacular view of the wetlands and the harbor area. The Brookhaven Yacht Basin at the base of the hill is a popular fishing spot for entire families.

title: Attica Hanging Ruled a Suicide
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 17 (AP)  The hanging death last week of a 25yearold Attica prison inmate from Staten Island has officially been ruled a suicide despite charges by some prisoners that the man had been murdered by guards. Doris Beitz, head clerk at the prison, said yesterday that the death certificate for the inmate, Edward Negron, listed suicide as the.cause of death. Mr. Negron, serving an eightyear term for manslaughter, was found last Thursday night hanging from bedsheets in an isolation cell where he had been put after he allegedly became unruly and lunged at a guard.

description: TRADITIONALLY, we describe our government as the world's greatest democracy, but strictly speaking, we are not democracy, of course, but a republic. .'Our laws are made not by the people di::rectly, but by elected representatives, :Dur history includes the ever-expand: big right to vote, to speak freely, to :choose public officials, but that's al;.most as far as the constitutional sys:lem has allowed us to go. Now some. ,;thing is happening. Americana are I clearly feeling less in control of their: political and economic destinies, and :tile sleeping giant of unrest is stirring..  We may never be the same again.

title: DINING OUT
description: EVEN longtime Westchester residents may not be familiar with the sparsely populated back country in which The Red Schoolhouse is situated. Certainly the onetime schoolhouse would have served a wide area when it was first built late in the 19th century. It is easy to imag- Me the large room with oldfashioned desks, the young scholars daydreaming as they gazed out across the meadow into the woods. Now, though some 15 candlelit tables are fitted neatly into the otherwise unchanged space, daydreaming still comes easily. Our daydream was one we've had before: We would discover that unknown but perfect little restaurant.

title: Raid From Costa Rica  Reported by Nicaragua
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 18 (AP)  A spokesman for the National Guard said today that a brigade of Venezuelan, Panamanian, Mexican and Costa Rican guerrillas had crossed the border from Costa Rica and had been repulsed.

title: A Suit by Handicapped Accuses the U.S. of Bias
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI)Charging the Federal Government with discriminating against its own handicapped employees, the National Association of the Deaf filed a class action suit today challenging a Civil Service policy that denies many of the employees job security.

title: The Employee as Volunteer, With Company Support
description: WASHINGTON  An employee of the Xerox Corporation is working at the Jacques Cousteau Society, setting up a public relations campaign to save the whales. At the Allstate Insurance Com- pany in Chicago, workers take five minutes a day to call a sick or housebound person referred by a social agency. A group from the Reynolds Metals Company in Richmond published and sold a cookbook that raised $5,000 for the local Boys Club.

title: Celebrating Lizst and Schubert
description: IS it my imagination, or has there been an explosion of concert activity in Connecticut? This Sunday, for instance, you can take your pick fsomjin array of musical attractions, including such brehestral events as the Greenwich Philharmonia (4 P.M., at the Greenwich .High scnoot), Norwalk Youth'Sympliony (3 P.M., old Norwalk High School), Manchester Civic. Orchestra (4 P.M., Center Middle School in Vernon) and Hamden Symphony (3 P.M., Alunini Hall of Quinnipiac College).

description: The marriage of Jennifer Lynn Cook, a certified public accountant, to Michael G. Dolan, a lawyer, took place yesterday in the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Donald Sakano performed the ceremony.

title: 98 G.E. Workers to Be Laid Off
description: WAYNESBORO, Va., Nov. 18 (AP) The General Electric Company has announced that 98 employees here will be laid off Nov. 29, the day after Thanksgiving. The layoffs are related to the company's failure to meet sales projections for terminet printers, according to a company spokesman. The company said it does not intend to lay off any more workers this year.

title: Terrorists in El Salvador Bomb Electric Plant and Restaurant
description: SAN SALVADOR, Nov. 18. (UPI)Marxist terrorists blew up a Government electric plant last night, blacking out large sections of San Salvador, and bombed a restaurant in another city in El Salvador, according to the police.

description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 18  The chairman of the Power Authority of the State of New York and the Westchester County Executive clashed late this week over whether cheap electricity from the state authority would be available to the county should it succeed in taking over Consolidated Edison's distribution network.

title: Critical Maneuver for Pioneer
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Nov. 18 (UPI)  Ground controllers guiding Pioneer Venus 2 toward Venus are prepared to release three more instrument probes tomorrow night in a critical manuever leading to a Dec. 9 descent into the veiled planet's thick, hot blanket of gases.

title: Fashion
description: Furs have been dyed many shades, but never until this season have so many been dipped, tipped or brushed with the glow of green. The effect is unexpected, flattering and surprisingly versatile because the shadings, anywhere from emerald to olive, are subtly done. Now a greenglinted fur is as adaptable as one of basic brown.

title: New York City Seeks To Be Host to G.O.P. For 1980 Convention
description: A belated bid to attract the 1980 Republican National Convention to New York City was initiated yesterday, but it appeared to have only a slim chance of success.

title: Karen A. Kenney To Be June Bride Of R. D. Dickson
description: Mr. and Mrs. John S. Kenney of Floral Park, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Anne Kenney, to Raymond Dykema Dickson, son of Mrs. James G. McGuire of Carefree, Ariz., and the late Dr. Laurie C. Dickson of Grosse Pointe, Mich. A wedding next June is planned.

title: Penn State in Sugar Bowl; Oklahoma Goes to Orange

title: Young Man's Progress
description: THE 1920's and 1930's in England have now begun to be regarded as a romantic literary period, when any day one might have seen Orwell plain, teasing his old friend Connolly at Bedford Square, watched Lady Ottoline Morrell sweeping a Bloomsbury pavement with the skirts of her Elizabethan forthingale, or sighted Lytton Strachey stroking his russet beard while he observed a handsome passerby.

title: Indian Tribe in Arizona Protests Removal of Two Catholic Priests
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 17 (AP)  Papago Indians, upset by the removal of two reservation priests, have asked the Roman Catholic Church to return the buildings and the Indian land on which they stand.

title: Changing South Africa's Rear Guard
description: Ever since the National Party of South Africa came to power 30 years ago, it has followed deplorable and myopic policies and tried to maintain them rigidly. But in its rear guard resistance to fundamental change, it has been forced to abandon more than a few trenches. Now there has been a changing of the rear guard.

title: A MONSTER

title: School District on L.I. Excels in Reading and Math

When the New York State Education Department released the test scores of its annual .statewide Pupil Evaluation Program, educators in the William Floyd School District had one additional piece of evidence to illustrate something they already knew: that pupils here were doing exceptionally well in their reading and math and that both skills were improving every year.

title: GARDENING Wild With Tradition
description: DON'T be surprised when walking near wetlands along the Long Island Sound or in woodland in Westchester County's back country it you come along a boggy area and find a plant with fruit that looks very much like the old familiar Thanksgiving Day cranberry. All of New England is home to the cranberry, and, if it were not for the suburbinization of the land, there would be a lot more cranberries found in the wild.

title: Pollock's Beginnings On View at Yale
description: WHILE compiling their fourvolume catalogue of the works of Jackson Pollock, Francis V. O'Connor and Eugene V. Thaw came upon a number of hitherto unknown or very obscure pieces. These discoveries com- prise Jackson Pollock: NewFound Works, a show at the Yale University Art Gallery that celebrates the university's publication of the catalogue.

title: Lucy Fowlkes Is Betrothed To a Surgeon

title: Maryland Stops Clemson, 2824
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Nov. 18 (AP)  Steve Fuller's touchdown pass plays of 87 and 62 yards twice rallied Clemson from 7point thirdquarter deficits and the 12thranked Tigers beat 11thranked Maryland, 28.24, today on Lester Brown's 5yard fourthperiod run.

title: Riction Roundup
description: The time, as they say in those solemn and portentous prefaces that roll up toward the top of our movie screens, is 1890. The place is the Pine Ridge Reservation in the Badlands of South

title: Setting up Camp in the Soviet Union
description: I fully believed I would fall in love with the Soviet Union. I was going to ignore politics, polemics and propaganda for a month; ignore the myriad warnings issued by family and friends; and do just what Intourist, the official Soviet travel bureau said it encouraged: drive through the country in my own car, camping. An easy matter, as long as I planned the entire route and booked each night two months in advance through Intourist. I fully believed that by avoiding the typical hotel-and-bus routine, I would be able to meet the Soviet people on their own ground, and be able to learn about them and have them learn about me. fully believed all of this.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Sometimes the only way to find out what's happening in the national soul is to read Variety, the showbusiness weekly. Variety wastes little time predicting trends; it's too busy reporting events, mostly in terms of business, which, as every good trade paper knows, has been the one true art this nation since its founding. If you happened to see the Nov. 8 issue of Variety, you might have been startled to reaa that in October, which was an unusually big month for movies in this country, two films accounted for 23 percent all the money spent at theater box offices. The films: National Lampoon's Animal House and Cheech Marin and Tommy Chong's Up in Smoke.

title: Retarded Woman Gets Damages
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 (AP)  A mentally retarded woman has been awarded $1.5 million in damages in Federal court from Coatesville Hospital because it did not have an oxygen tank in the delivery room when she was born there almost 22 years ago. Vickie Bostic, who now lives in Elkton, Md., was granted the damages yesterday.

title: J.W. Hubbell Jr. Weds Miss Hart
description: In the Brick Presbyterian Church yesterday afternoon, Gwynn MacColl Hart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert, Edward Hart Jr. of New York, was married to John William Hubbell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hubbell of Rye, N.Y., and Casteleros, France. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Richard Cosnotti. A reception was held at the Union Club.

title: Suburban Poll: Ties That Bind
description: WESTCHESTER residents are demanding but more interested in their communities and their neighhors than those in other suburbs. They are better educated than most, better represented in the highest income brackets but a bit uncertain, nevertheless, about their future. They are angrier than anyone about taxes but surprisingly confident in their commuter railroads, and quite pleased, apparently, with county government, especially when compared with their view of local government. They like New York City and use it.

title: Nuns Unlikely to Heed Pope's Advice on Garb
description: American nuns who gave up their traditional habits in favor of more modern and casual garb may be reluctant to go back to the old ways, despite Pope John Paul II's recommendations.

title: Four Days of Four Lives
description: DIANE JOHNSON is prolific and accomplished writer, best known until now for Lesser : Lives (1972), a biography of Mary Ellen Peacock Meredith, and for The Shadow Knows (1979). The latter is an ambitious pseudosuspense , novel

title: POLISH COMMUNISTS EDGY ON PAPAL VISIT
description: WARSAW, Nov. 14  The Communist leadership here appears resigned to the prospect of a visit by Pope John Paul II to his homeland, but it hardly conceals its lack of enthusiasm and would, at the least, want him to stay away from Warsaw.

title: Massachusetts Town Is Seeking Funds to Save Its Water Supply
description: PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Nov. 18 Provincetown, hardpressed by debt, rising taxes and inflation, has voted to borrow $460,000 in an effort to resolve its water crisis. The money will be used for process designed to clean up its water supply, to pay for an emergency well drilled last summer and to seek new sources of water.

title: LETTER TO THE EDITOR
description: This evening I read more about projected defense spending of over $130 billion in 1980. I wonder why there is so much emphasis on military spending and just why we need to devote so much energy to defensive security. Is it that we feel threatened from the outside or from ourselves?

title: BEATING 'sWORDS
description: North and south of the Imperial Highway near the Los Angeles airport, the giant complex of Rockwell International factories and offices encloses an area of 4.2 million square feet. Commanding hall that space, the two main buildings are a hive of laboratories, wind tunnels, machine shops, assembly areas and warehouses  the largest of the two plants built around an unobstructed central area big enough for a football field. The whole is an impressive manifestation of American industrial ingenuity and might. And, today, it is the scene of an economic disaster.

description: Neil Sedaka and Howard Greenfield were perhaps the most facile of the songwriting teams that churned out teenage pop music from the vicinity of the Brill Building on Broadway during the late 50's and early 60's. Their songs were never as moving as the best work of Gerry Goff in and Carole King, never as witty and mordant as the playlets of Jerry Leiber and Mike Stoller, never as streetcorner noble as the confections of Mort Schuman and Doc Pomus.

title: INVENTING A LANDSCAPE
description: The move away from tradition (right) has led to apartment buildings like these in Creteil (left), designed by architect Gerard Grandval. The leafshaped balconies of the artichokelike towers were meant to be painted green and purple, with hanging gardens. But they were left gray. The hope was that new forms would create new sensibilities among tenants. The buildings have not proved

title: Architecture Cold Comfort The New French Towns
description: The future has come to France, and it happened in just 10 years. In the decade from 1945 to 1975, officials of the French national government and the Paris region planned and built five new towns and restructured and expanded half a dozen older suburbs within a 20mile radius of Paris. In so doing, they radically altered the image and actuality of the French way of life for an anticipated 600,000 to one million people. The job was done cooly and systematically, with the impeccable logic that characterizes the operation of the French intellect at its best.

title: Georgia Settles fora 2222 Tie
description: AUBURN, Ala., Nov. 18 (UPI) Willie McClendon scored on a 1yard plunge late in the fourth quarter today but eighthranked Georgia kicked an extra point instead of going for a 2point conversion and settled for a 2222 tie with Auburn.

title: On High in Spain: The Contrast Is Sharp
description: Winding up the highest road in Europe, with our skis strapped to the roof of our station wagon, we were dazzled, and a bit unsettled, by visions of spring in winter: apple and orange blossoms in flower at 4,000 feet. Could there be snow lust beyond?

title: Deaths
description: BUTLER--Harold F. Of Short Hills, N.J. On Friday November 17, 1978. Husband of Miriam Meyer Butler. Father of Mrs. Miriam B. Dayhoff, Mrs. Virginia B. Lohse and Miss, Constance M. Butler. Brother of Mrs. Frances Pangburn. Also sur vived by 6 grandchildren and 3 great grandchildren. Funeral Service at Christ Church, 66 Highland Ave., Short Hills, N.J. on Monday, November 20 at 10 AM. Relatives and friends are invited to attend. Interment Centre Hall, Pa. Please omit flowers.

title: Rabbi Loses Libel Suit
description: BOSTON, Nov. 18 (AP)  A Providence, R.I., rabbi has been ordered to pay $85,000 to the founder of a Boston black arts center he allegedly accused of preaching hatred of Jews. A Suffolk Superior Court jury yesterday found in favor of Elma Lewis, director of the National Center of AfroAmerican Artists, ordering Rabbi Marvin S. Antleman to pay a $62,000 judgement, plus interest, in the libel suit.

title: Women's Colleges Regain Appeal
description: TOWSON, Md., Nov. 17  Seven students have spent the entire semester in the infirmary at Goucher College, and the institution's officials see this as a symptom of Goucher's good health.

description: Uniroyal Inc.'s latest ad campaign cites the successes of its research and development staff as evidence of the industrial giant's urge to discover.

title: Control of Ulster County's Voles Creates Environmental Dilemma
description: ALBANY, Nov. 18  The pine vole; a tiny underground rodent that gnaws at the bark of apple trees, has chewed its way into a controversy between the State Department of Environmental Conservation and an array of the Agricultural Establishment of New York State.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Rhodesia: The Urgency
description: LONDONThe decision the other day by the Rhodesian regime to put off elections for majority rule until April 1979 comes as no surprise. With about twothirds of the country already under martial law (and with new bits being added almost weekly), there is no way in which proper elections can be organized by Prime Minister Ian D. Smith and his black colleagues committed to achieving an internal settlement.

title: Deaths
description: WEISSAnna, dearest wife of the late Jack, beloved mother of Eleanor and Albert Kirschenbaume adored grandmother of Howard and Diane, Stuart and Janice, loving great grandmother of Justin, Jennifer, and Storm, and cherished sister, Services Monday, 1PM, at Kirschen. baums, Coney Island Ave. at Ave. H, Brooklyn.

title: Delaware 38, Colgate 29

title: Racing the Downhill Dollar
description: The Alps tend to humble humans, give you a bit of perspective on your own true diminished self. SurelY, this is never more clear to an American than the first time he confronts the real state of the United States dollar on a Swiss mountainside. It happened to me in one of those little huts tucked along the edges of ski runs, where the best highaltitude meals in the world are served.

title: DINING OUT A Sure, Bet Near Atlantic City
description: THE odds in your favor might not be too good at the gambling tables in Atlantic City, but there is one sure bet in nearby Margate. you put your money down at the Captain's Galley, a freshfish restaurant attached to the Margate Fishery, you will get fresh fish.

title: When a President Prescribes Pain
description: If we hear him right, President Carter has reached a fateful decision to turn his politics inside out. Instead of completing the agenda of liberal spending in a financially responsible way, as he set out to do two years ago, he intends now to sacrifice that goal to rescue an enfeebled economy from a decade of inflation and stagnation. Besides deferring new health, welfare and urban programs, he intends to cut existing programs. Instead of satisfying the coalition that has sustained Democratic Presidents since Franklin Roosevelt, he proposes to tame that hungry beast as Republican Presidents since Eisenhower never could.

title: Has Success Spoiled Islanders?
description: They are mostly married, home-owning suburbanites and earn an average of $75,000 each. Once, they were in the lowest class. Now, they are Establishment.

description: Newark, with a population of about 375,000, is New Jerseys biggest city and perhaps the one most severely affected by the combination of state budget restrictions and loss of Federal aid.
