description: IN an age in which autobiography so often means Telling All  childhood traumas, early sex encounters, broken marriages, psychoanalytic soulsearching  Alan Jay Lerner's The Street Where Live comes as something of a surprise. Mr. Lerner will have none of the confessional approach; he clearly a civilized, attractively modest, gentlemanly

title: Turner Purchases Two Cup Yachts
description: Ted Turner is rocking the boat again. But this time it's his own. The flamboyant defender of the America's Cup and the owner of the Atlanta Braves and Hawks has plunked down something in excess of $500,000 to buy the 12Meter yachts Courageous and Independence.

title: Wreck of Ship in Lake Champlain May Date to the Last Century
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 18 (AP) The wreck of a marblecarrying ship found on the muddy bottom of Lake Champlain may date to the 19th century, according to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: CoAuthor Says Proposition 13 Is No Panacea for Rest of Nation
description: NASHVILLE, Nov. 18  Paul Gann, the coauthor of Proposition 13, today said the California measure was inappropriate for the rest of the country. Mr. Gann joined antitax forces meeting here to work on a Constitutional amendment that would limit Federal svendine.

title: Milwaukee Women's Crime High
description: MILWAUKEE, Nov. 18 (UPI)  Law Enforcement Assistance Administration statistics show that. Milwaukee women are more likely to be victims of violent crimes involving injuries than women in several other Cities, including New York.

title: Melanie E. Vosburgh Affianced
description: Dr. and Mrs. Donald R. Vosburgh of Oneonta, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Melanie Eve Vosburgh, to Thomas Edward Anthony, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Anthony of Radnor, Pa. The wedding is planned for August. The future bride is a senior at the S.I. Newhouse School of Public Communications of Syracuse University. Her fianc is assistant news diretor at radio station WDOS in Oneonta.

title: Jill Lisa Feller Plans Wedding
description: Cantor Irving S. Feller of Adath Israel Congregation in Trenton, and Mrs. Feller, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jill Lisa Feller, to Louis A. Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elwin Davis of University Heights, Ohio. The couple, students at the University of Indiana, are graduates of Case Western Reserve University. wedding next May is planned.

title: HsuehTung Chen and Dancers In 6 Works at Schimmel Center
description: One cannot fault the dances of HsuehTung Chen for their good taste, craft and the for the most part delicate choreographic sensibility they reveal. But the six works performed at Pace University's Schimmel Center on Friday by HsuehTung Chen and Dancers suffered from a distinct lack of dynamic variety and daring.

title: Japan Is Spurring Defense Programs and Strengthening Military Links With the West
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18  After years of curbing its defense expenses and its military ties abroad, Japan is quietly accelerating defense programs, stepping up military purchases in the United States and strengthening defense links to Western nations.

title: Symphony Director Is Never Disconcerted
description: ONE day last spring, a boyishlooking 25-year-old with 17 years of acting, singing and theatrical administrative experierice was scanning job openings in the newsletter of the American Symphony Orchestra League. At the time, the young man, Thomas J. Parker, was administrative assistant to the executive director of the Detroit Symphony.

title: Major Quake Called a Possibility For Ramapo Fault in New Jersey
description: MAHWAH, N.J., Nov. 18 (AP)  Local officials who called Columbia University's geological observatory after a small earthquake here have been told that New Jersey has a major fault that could cause another earthquake any time  possibly a serious one.

title: Miss Thorpe, Florist, Bride
description: Patricia A. Thorpe and Harold L. Stults Jr..were married yesterday in St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Gerald deScenzo, assisted by the Rev. Carl Flemister of the American Baptist Church.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: ONEquarter of the population of the United States read 10 books or more during the past six months. Thirty percent read one to nine books during that period. Thirtynine percent read newspapers and magazines but nary a book. The rest read nothing at all.

title: Cold Spring Harbor String at 26
description: Cold Spring Harbor registered its 26th consecutive regularseason victory yesterday when it routed Roosevelt, 280, to capture the Conference IVB championship and send it into the title playoff against Elmont, the Divion A winner. The game will be Friday at Post College, Brookville.

title: 50,000 Lose Jobless Benefits
description: ALBANY, Nov. 17 (UPI)  About 50,000 people lost unemployment benefits in the week ended Nov. 3 as a Federal extendedbenefits program ended because overall tmemolovment was down. The total claiming unemployment insurance benefits dropped from 304,013 in the previous week to 253,094, with most of the decline caused by the cutoff of the special program, the department said yesterday.

title: 5th Avenue Shoppers Scatter as Policemen Chase Holdup Suspect

title: Koch Sends in New Budget System to Tackle Gap
description: Mayor Koch has implemented a new budget-making process as he begins to wrestle with the immediate problem of closing an estimated $438 million budget gap for fiscal 1980, which begins next July The city's existing budgeting  and financialmanagement systems are inadequate to this task, the Mayor said the other day in explaining the reasons for the new process. The budget process is fragmented and does not operate according to an orderly predetermined schedule. In the recent past, the city has been forced to rely on a series of ad hoc budgetreduction analyses performed, in the main, by the Office of ManagementBudget to live within constraints of the financial plan. Because of the limitations of time, the budget process has been too centralized. The role of agency heads and program managers in budget formulation has been far too limited,

title: Arthritis Victim Shot to Death

George W. Hoffman was sent to a hospital for psychiatric observation after his arrest. His wife, Helen Hoffman, 79, was shot three times in the head with a .32caliber pistol while she slept, the police said.

title: The Region
description: MINEOLA, L.I. (UPI)  Aaron Mays, 15 years old, of Freeport, L.I. the first juvenile on Long Island to be treated as an adult offender under new state law, has been allowed to plead guilty to a reduced charge in the robbery of an elderly Hempstead couple on Oct. 4. Originally charged with seconddegree robbery and first-degree burglary, he was permitted to plead to attempted seconddegree robbery, which carries a maximum prison term of seven years. Had he been treated as a juvenile, the maximum penalty would have been 18 months. He is to be sentenced Dec. 19.

title: The Choice: Heat or Money

It read: It's 72 degrees in here. One worker found a piece of cardboard, scribbled on it and held it up for the office occupant. It read: It's $15 an hour out here.

Fragrance permeates detergents, toilet paper, room sprays, even artificial flowers. Cars smell new because they've been sprayed to smell that way and American men and women smell better than ever before because they're using vast amounts of new colognes and perfumes that have recently been developed in this country.

title: Accused Ex-Policeman Dies
description: LOWELL, Mass., Nov. 18 (AP)  A former policeman accused of killing Lowell policeman in a drug store holdup died today from wounds suffered while fleeing from the police, hospital officials said. James J. Shanahan, 29 years old, until recently a member of a 10member police force headed by his father in the town of Groveland, died at Lowell General Hospital, the officials said. Mr. Shanahan was accused of killing Patrolman Christos Rouses, 53, in an exchange of gunfire yesterday.

title: Headliners

After enduring more than a year of such rumors, the White House has spoken: James Earl Carter 3d, better known as Chip Carter and his wife Caron have separated after five years of marriage. In the summer of 1977, the President's son moved out of the White House and went to Plains, Ga., leaving his wife and their son behind. Now he's back but Caron Carter has returned to Georgia. The White House announcement said Mr. Carter will continue in his job with the Democratic National Committee.

title: THE NEW FACE OF SPANISH COMMUNISM
description: MADRID. Surprisingly strong and melodious, La Pasionaria's 82yearold voice suddenly opened in song, an old revolutionary song that floated across the smokefilled convention hall and silenced a thousand Communist delegates waiting for a broken computer to be fixed and give them the voting results for the new central committee. The mainly youthful delegates to the Ninth Party Congress exploded in applause when the living icon of Spanish Communism  a Stalinist maybe, but beloved Stalinist  warbled to the end of her song, returned to the dais, her long milky fingers stretched across her =creased forehead. Dolores Ibarurri watched as another generation of Communists, impatient with waiting for the tallies, put on an impromptu amateur hour: rhymed Aragonese jotas, some sung in praise of the party; a few dirty jokes; a funny imitation of Santiago Carrillo's windy oratory; a stringy Valerian's song, in Catalan, whose longlive refrain struck some as a bit irreverent for a congress that had just abandoned Leninism as a guiding tenet: Visca Lenin! Visca Marx! Visca Liberia!! Finally, a jovial Basque took the microphone and got the whole congress to hum along to a boisterous tune which ended with everyone throwing spare articles of clothing and copies of the party's 15 theses toward the high ceiling of the Melia Castilla Hotel. It may have crossed lbarurri's mind that it was just as well the fraternal Soviet comrades had excused themselves before the break; even she seemed shocked at some of the jokes, which certainly wouldn't have been retailed during the cold, despairing years of

title: A Plan That Will Have No Real Impact
description: It is difficult to see how President Carter's new wage and price standards will have any real impact on next year's inflation rate. The other ele- ments of the Administration's antiinflation program  fiscal and monetary restraints, efforts to minimize the costs of Government regulation, stiffer opposition to special interest groups demands for trade protection, price supports and their avowed intent to reduce the budget deficit and the like could make a significant difference the Administration, the Federal Reserve Board and the Congress follow through on them. But the standards themselves aren't prompting any revisions in our company's Consumer Price Index forecast for 1979.

title: The Theater Audience: A House Divided

Contemporary America constitutes not one but many nations, each with its own political ambitions, its own language, gestures and symbols, its own hunger for cultural recognition. How can a single theater hope develop a body of plays and productions that transcend these national divisions and appeal to a general American public?

title: On the Block: The Saga of a nee Proud Ship
description: Some old ships, like old soldiers, never die; they just fade away. Take, for example, the America, the once proud flagship of the United States Line. She was christened in 1939 by Eleanor Roosevelt and, when first placed in service at the outbreak of World War II, carried passengers on voyages to socalled safe zones in the Caribbean and to California before being commissioned as a troop ship and renamed the West Point. During her war duty she sailed all the world's oceans and in 1946 was returned to the United States Lines for whom she sailed in transAtlantic service over an 18year period.

title: Is It Safe to Drink the Water? How Ships Make Sure

James Rodgers, an assistant professor at the University of Florida Water Research Center, had been commissioned by Holland America Cruises to oversee the purity of the ship's water during a watersystem overhaul. title: What's Doing in NEW ZEALAND
description: THE SCENE  Smartaleck pilots sometimes announce on the intercom as they approach the New Zealand coast: Ladies and gentlemen, we are now nearing New Zealand. Set your watches back 50 years. New Zealand- ers, looking at the present state of the world, are inclined to retort: So, is that bad? It is true that no one would to New Zealand for sophisticated night life or high living. Visitors are inclined to find things rather quaintly oldfashioned, the pace of life leisurely, the people naively willing to waste time being friendly. There is little smog, even in the cities, the air is still crystal clear, and the absence of slums,- freedom from class distinctions and equable climate ornament a country of great natural beauty. It is a sportsman's paradise, whether the sport is hunting, fishing, golf, yachting, skiing, horse racing, or the local fetishes rigby football and cricket.

title: URBANITY AND MODERNITY
description: The distance from Paris (above) to Creteil (below) is about five miles, but it may as well be a trip to the moon. Paris is the product of the rational refinement of centuries of a magnificent architectural and urban tradition. But this tradition finds no reflection in the Paris region's new towns. Parisian neighborhoods combine housing, shops, offices, administration, entertainment and the arts in a vital, organic mix. Creteil's residential neigborhowls, like the Quartier de le. 1laye aux Moines shown here, are designed by several architects to avoid monotony, but unlike Paris's natural variety, their differences are cosmetic. Creteil has open space and a pattern of changing ground levels; Paris has streets that serve as conduits of activity and are alive with constant use. Paris puts it all together for a synthesis of art and life that is still missing from the

title: Heating Oil Prices Take a Sudden, Unexpected Jump

After a few minutes, Brown picked out three kidsyou, you and you and told them to throw some more until he said to a blond kid, You're my quarterback.

title: Simon Gray Explores The Roots of Atrocity
description: In his bestknown and most successful plays, Simon Gray has probed for the nerveendings that animate the world of the middleclass London intelligentsia. The hero  or antinero  or ms rata nit plumy is a sardonic university professor sulkily treading the murky waters of his own emotional disarray. Otherwise Engaged, which won the New York Drama Critics Circle award as the best play of the 197677 season, introduced us to Simon Hench, a brilliant but determinedly disengaged young publisher whose life is a closed book even to his wife.

title: By Comparison, U.S. Tax Rate Looks Not So Bad
description: Taxpayers in the United States may be rumbling about revolt, but in fact they have it better than citizens of almost every other industrial country in the world. This is one of the findings of an annual report on comparable international tax levels released by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. The analysis shows that the total tax revenues collected in the United States in 1976 represented 29.29 percent of gross domestic product, lower than every other industrial country with the exception of Japan.

title: Doobie Brothers Rockers Bring Barroom Eclecticism to a Club
description: The Doobie Brothers, wno ended a twonight engagement at the Palladium on Friday, have had their. moments of popularity, and it should be reported  especially because artists love to have such facts taken note of that their Friday audience seemed to enjoy them enthusiastically. But their music didn't seem very gripping.

description: BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 18 (UPI)Between a Mississippi River levee and the tracks of the Illinois Central, Federal scientists are trying to breed the ideal honeybee.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Atlantic City is a mess. It is not even faltering, phoenixlike, from the ashes of its cataclysmic decline to a new and glorious future as the gaming resort of the 1980's; it is rushing off relentlessly in all the wrong directions. It seems determined to use legalized gambling to get just another flashy, jerrybuilt strip, that will have no advantage in planning, character or quality over airy other flashy, jerrybuilt strip. The state of New lersey, in its anxiety become the Las Vegas of the East, is missing the chance create a winning ticket. The future is being thrown away through ignorance, inertia and wrongheadedness, and the failure to capitalize on those things that once made Atlantic City a great resort  a superb site, a distinctive style, and genuine substance.

title: Spanish Military Court Sentences Civilian Who Insulted Flag in Skit
description: MADRID, Nov. 18  Spanish military justice has taken what may well be its last outraged swipe at a civilian who has offended the army. An 18yearold Basque actor has been sentenced to one year in prison for insulting the flag.

title: Dorothy Hines Is Betrothed

Hines of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Quogue, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dorothy Hope Hines, to Daniel Francis McCartney, son of Mr. and Mrs. George McCartney of Elmhurst, Queens. A March 17 wedding is planned. The future bride teaches second grade at the Buckley School, where her fianc is a physical education teacher. Miss Hines's father is a vice president of the Bankers Trust Company.

title: Are We Attuned To Borodin Today?
description: Just a few years ago the works of the nationalist Russian composers of the late 19th century seemed to play a far larger part in American orchestral repertories than they do today. This was partly because of the presence of such real or imagined Russian-Oriental-exotic conductors on our podiums as Serge Koussevitzky and Leopold Stokowski. But it was also because, given the shifting tides of fashion, these vibrant and lavishly colored symphonies and tone poems sounded fresher and more vital than they do to modern ears.

title: Margaret Mead Remembered
description: LOS ANGELES  The reaction of the anthropologists gathered here for their annual convention was pretty uniform. On the first day of the conference, Margaret Mead, with her usual flair for the dramatic, died, and the feelings of all were summed up by one young anthropologist who had never known her personally  Anthropology without Margaret Mead  unthinkable.

title: IN BRIEF
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy last week took the unusual step of asking the Federal Trade Commission to investigate the proposed acquisition of the Lykes Corporation by the LTV Corporation. The merger was approved this summer by Attorney General Griffin Bell, who opposed Senator Kennedy's request. At issue: a ruling that gave Lykes failing company status entitling it to special consideration.... The Justice Department went to court to block efforts by United Technologies to buy a controlling interest in the Carrier Corporation. Carrier, a leading manufacturer of heating and cooling devices, itself has filed suit to block the acquisition, claiming that United's $28ashare offer for Carrier common stock was inadequate. The Justice Department says the acquisition would restrict competition. . . . Marvin Josephson Associates Inc., one of the country's largest talent agencies, acquired 8.8 percent of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., a major publisher. Josephson, with earnings of $4.1 million last year, is dwarfed by Harcourt, whose earnings.reached $18.2 million.

What's more, most companies, even those that are less-than-prime credit risks, say they expect no problems obtaining funds.

title: The Bell System's Mr. Brown

Brown, the president, to the chairmanship of the company, Mr. Brown, John D. deButts, the current chairman, and two other top officers were waiting outside the boardroom while the vote was being cast. Once it had been cast, Frank Hut- son, the company secretary, hurried out to summon them back.

title: Thanksgivings Past: The Loved, the Forgettable, the Forgotten
description: It is not mere chance, of course, that Thanksgiving feasts are those best remembered in America. They are strictly secular affairs, with the turkey and all it represents, and the bird simply has more character than an Easter ham. And. Door Christmas, there is no traditional main course be it beast or fowl  traditional to the holiday. Old Charles Dickens did his share, of course, in relating the Christmas goose to the feast day, but the goose is, in America, at any rate, one of the scarcer of God's winged creatures to find on the market.

title: Edward Kosner of Newsweek Weds Julie Baumgold, Writer

title: Federal Overtime to Be Checked
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP)  James T. McIntyre Jr., director of the Office of Management and Budget, said today that his staff would closely monitor the use of overtime pay for Federal workers. He noted that an increasing number of cases concerning questionable overtime use have come to light in recent weeks. Mr. McIntyre asked department and agency heads to be certain that the use of overtime is justified in terms of prudent and efficient management.

title: Deaths

title: Saudis to Seek Oil Price Freeze, But Hint OPEC Will Not Agree
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 19  Saudi Arabia intends to go into the crucial Dec. 16 pricesetting meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries seeking a freeze for the third straight year, the Saudi Oil Minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, said today. He also suggested strongly, however, that the effort might not succeed.

title: Kenya Survives Its LongFeared Transfer of Power

Rabbi Yaacov Hilsenrath performed the ceremony.

description: Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi firmly believes that the Central Intelligence Agency began a dirty tricks operation 15 years ago to make contact with dissidents in Iran so the United States would have influence with anyone who managed to overthrow him, Time magazine reports in its current issue.

description: SHRUB OAK, N.Y.  Does it bother me? Terri Bensky, a junior at Lakeland High School said when asked recently how she felt about receiving failing grades of 50 last November for courses in which she normally brings home grades of 85 or better.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) Americans are vacating the big cities, according to figures released yesterday by the Census Bureau. Between 1970 and 1976, 18 of the nation's 25 most populous cities lost residents, the figures show.

title: California Fights River's Flow of Mexican Wastes
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19  On a map, the New River starts about 20 miles south of the Mexican border and meanders northward for 75 miles to California's inland Salton Sea, looking like any other modest stream. In reality the New River has a noteworthy distinction.

description: When Bruce Donaghy arrived at the starting line for the John F. Kennedy Memorial bicycle race in Central Park yesterday, he needed few introductions.

description: The green paint is cracked and peeling on the sign that reads, O'Grady's Eire Bar, on Roosevelt Avenue in Jackson Heights, Queens.

description: New York City does not now intend nor does it have the resources to complete the longplanned 14.3mile Second Avenue subway, State Comptroller Arthur Levitt declared yesterday.

title: Iran Frees 210 Political Prisoners, And Shah Renews Election Pledge
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 19  The Iranian Government today released 210 political prisoners, and Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi renewed his pledge of two weeks ago to hold free elections next June and bring an end to the military rule he imposed on the country.

title: China in Favor Of Borrowing
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 19 (Reuters) China's Vice Premier, Li Hsiennien, has told a group of Congressmen from the United States that China would accept foreign loans if its sovereignty was not harmed.

title: Benefits of the Destructive
description: Primaries are supposed to be bad for politicians. They tend to be like family fights, leaving a party and a candidate, even if he wins, bloodied, financially broke, disorganized and vulnerable to his generalelection opponent. That's the conventional wisdom.

title: New Koch Aides Seek Remedies To Harlem Youth's Loss of Faith
description: It is a long way from City Hall to Edgecombe Avenue near 155th Street in northern Harlem. Yet, virtually all politically involved blacks in the city argue that Mayor Koch's reach must extend that far and to similar places in Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens if he is to govern this city effectively.

title: Wider Pay Disclosure Is Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  Warning that the lives of American executives abroad might be placed in jeopardy, many corporations have vigorously opposed a Securities and Exchange Commission proposal to require more top executives to disclose how much they are paid in salaries and the fringe benefits known as perks.

title: Talks Are Starting in India to End Dockers
description: NEW DELHI. Nov. 19 (Reuters) Talks began today aimed at ending India's nationwide dock strike, which has nearly paralyzed six of the country's ten major ports.

title: Sex Bias Inquiry Seeks to Alleviate Tense Situation at Health Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  Ann Brown, who has a Ph.D. in pharmacology, joined the National Institutes of Health in 1962 as a research assistant. Twelve years later, after filing a formal charge of sex discrimination, Dr. Brown got her first promotion.

description: International

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  The Carter Administration plans to ask Congress next year to revise the increasingly costly program of Social Security disability benefits in ways that could save more than $2 billion a year by the middle 1980's.

description: ATLANTA, Nov. 19 (UPI)  The firs! cases of Russian flu of the 197879 season have been reported in Texas, and influenza experts at the national Center for Disease Control say that other states should expect outbreaks of the flu.

title: Music: Watts and Kruysen Offer Schubert Lieder
description: ANDRE WATTS continued his Celebration of Schubert series Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall with the first of his collaborative concerts. In this case, the collaborator was Bernard Kruysen, in the first of two programs devoted to Schubert's songs. On Saturday it was Winterreise; on Dec. 6 the two men will return for Die Schone Miillerin and other lieder.

title: Merely Shot In the Head
description: 0NE of the few good reasons 1 can think of for run. ning 26 miles would be to escape being shot in the head. But Dennis Rainear, 28 years old, of Midland, Mich., runs such distances for his own gratification. And when somebody did shoot him in the head, after 10 miles on Nov. 4. he kept on runnine.

title: Boos, Bookies, the Spread: Pro Football Wagering
description: TOWARD the end of a game between the Giants and the Dallas Cowboys earlier this season, a significant segment of the crowd remaining in Giants Stadium booed when Roger Staubach took the football and lay down on the turf for each of the Cowboys final two plays.

title: TV: A Rock Special From Bobby Vinton
description: BOBBY VINTON'S Rock n Rollers, which for some reason is preempting regular programming from 8 to 9 tonight on Channel 2, is a $19.95 knockoff of Grease. At the same time, it is a kind of advertisement for the multimillion dollar film. Grease is mentioned frequently, and three members of the cast of that film Stockard Channing, Eve Arden and Susan Bucknerare featured.

title: Dolls That Are Not for Playing
description: A doll is not necessarily a toy. While children have always played with dolls of some sort, no matter how crude, dolls have, through the ages, also been used as sacred objects, as ceremonial offerings and as amulets. Take, for example, fetish dolls, voodoo dolls and the Kachina dolls of the American Indians.

title: How to Help Minority Business
description: It's open season in Washington on Government fraud and abuse. First it was Medicare and CETA, the recession job program; then the General Services Administration, and now the Small Business Administration's setaside program, which distributes Federal contracts to minority entrepreneurs on a non-competitive basis. Allegations of sloppiness and outright fraud in the handling of S.B.A. loans to contractors have cast a cloud over the entire program. It is an inherited cloud from the Nixon and Ford years, but the Carter Administration has to share the blame for failing to give S.B.A. the necessary supervisory staff.

title: Pope Meets Rebel French Prelate
description: ROME, Nov. 19 (Reuters)  Pope John Paul 11, in an unexpected gesture aimed at church unity, has met Marcel Lefebvre, theFrench rebel Archbishop whose traditionalist movement has challenged Vatican authority for the past three years.

title: Kings Beat Nets, 114100
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov.19 (AP) Bob Nash scored 22 points, and New Jersey was called for seven technical fouls as the Kansas City Kings defeated the Nets, 114100, last night.

description: The new Dunhill Shop in Bloomingdale's has, or soon will have, the following items, most of them for sale.

title: Bridge:
description: DENVER, Nov. 19  The first major event of the North American Championships ended here last night in a victory for two New York experts. The mixedpair title went to Gail Moss, who won the World Women's Team championship five months ago in New Orleans, and Ahmed Hussein, a former member of the Egyptian national team.

title: 2 Women Die in Crash With Husbands
description: KIRBYVILLE, Tex., Nov. 19 (AP) Two women from the southeast Texas community of Call were killed yesterday when the car in which they were riding collided headon with a vehicle carrying their husbands, the authorities said. The men were not injured.

title: KEY AIRLIFT FORCE MAY LOSE ITS PUNCH
description: SCOTT AIR FORCE BASE, III.  The future effectiveness of the Military Airlift Command, the key to United States mobility in a war or other crisis, is endangered by two critical deficiencies.

title: Citing Repressive Policies in Chile, A.F.L.C.I.O. May Join in Boycott
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 19  Chile's military regime is facing the threat of an imminent boycott by United States and European unions against trade in Chilean goods as a sanction for repression of labor rights here.

title: Moscow Frees Convicted Spy
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 19 (AP)  Soviet authorities today allowed a Ukranianborn businessman who worked for a British electronics company to leave the country after spending 10 years in labor camps. Nikolai Sharygin, 52 years old, Who lett the Soviet Union as a teenager, was arrested on a business trip here in 1968 and sentenced to prison on treason charges.

title: Carter Answers Soviet on Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  President Carter moved quickly today to rebut a warning from Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, against any American interference in Iran.

title: Rose Vella Is Bride of Ely Jacques Kahn 3d
description: Rose Mary Vella, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Vella of Livonia. Mich., was married yesterday afternoon to Ely Jacques Kahn 3d, son of E. J. Kahn Jr. and Virginia Rice Kahn. The ceremony was performed in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More by the Rev. Gerard Di Senso.

title: Bond Report
description: For vreek ended November 17,1918 UTILITY BONDS

title: A Reporter's Notebook: Bidding Adieu to a Decent
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  James M. Fallows, the 29-year-old Rhodes Scholar who has served as Jimmy Carter's chief speechwriter for the last two and a half years, is leaving the White House this week to return to magazine writing. He will be the Washington correspondent for The Atlantic Monthly.

title: HanukkahLight Dispute On 72d St. Waits a Ruling
description: When the merchants of West 72d Street strung Christmas decorations across their throughfare last month, the synagogue around the corner decided that it would be nice to have a Hanukkah menorah on the block as well.

title: Corning Sells Plant
description: The Corning Glass Works has signed a definitive agreement with the Weyerhaeuser Company for the sale of Corning's Riverside, N.Y., shipping-container plant to Weyerhaeuser for cash, the companies announced jointly. The amount was not disclosed. The plant, which produces corrugated containers, employs 140 people.

title: The Region
description: FLEMINGTON, N.J.  Five Ku Klux Klan members in whitehooded robes marched in front of the Hunterdon County Courthouse distributing leaflets and carrying placards reading Gas the Communist Jews. The group intermittently pulled out a flag bearing the Star of David and stamped their feet on it.

title: The Editorial Notebook Cambodia and America's Conscience
description: The brutal record of the Khmer Rouge regime in Cambodia is being used by some supporters of the Vietnam War in a renewed attack on the peace movement of the time. The for- mer hawks contend that the oppression in what is now known as Democratic Kampuchea, and to a lesser degree in Vietnam, should weigh on the conscience of former doves: those who forced our withdrawal must bear major responsibility for the present afflictions of the peoples of Southeast Asia,

title: Beethoven: His Score for Goethe Play
description: BEETHOVEN's incidental music for Goethe's Egmont was presented in concert form Sunday afternoon at Hunter College by the Beethoven Society. Like a similar performance a year ago at the 92d St. Y.M.Y.W.H.A., it left the impression that this proud, fiery score, which runs well over half an hour, deserves to be heard in conjunction with full staging of Goethe's play. It is topdrawer Beethoven, far too good to go to waste.

title: 20 Seconds Left As Eagles Win
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 19  One of the simplest plays in football, a handoff to the fullback, was messed up by the Giants today and, with 20 seconds remaining, Herm Edwards of Philadelphia ran the ensuing fumble 26 yards for a touchdown to give the Eagles an unbelievable 1917 victory.

title: Universal Container Proxy Feud
description: Bitter fights with the management of the Universal Container Corporation of Linden, N. J., are nothing new to Arthur J. Horwitz.

title: 13 Hurt in Philippine Air Mishap
description: MANILA, The Philippines, Nov. 19 (AP)  The front landing gear of Philippines Airlines domestic jetliner collapsed on landing here this morning, injuring 13 passengers, an airline spokesman said. The plane, a BAC111 with 91 passengers and a crew of five, had returned to Manila airport soon after takeoff after the pilot determined the front landing gear had failed to lock in place.

title: Mahagonnyls Staged at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 18  Under the artistic direction of Robert Brustein, the Yale Repertory Theater has been a leader in reviving the plays of Bertolt Brecht, particularly the musicals that he wrote in collaboration with Kurt Weill. One BrechtWeill epic,The Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny, has been a special favorite with the Yale company. In 1971 there was The Little Mahagonny, a brief song cycle. Then in 1974 Yale offered the entire opera, staged with a full orchestra and chorus in collalxration with the Yale School of Music.

title: Emotional Violence Is Subtle, But It Can Destroy Relationships
description: A group of woman psychotherapists, who believe that more and more couples are inflicting subtle forms of violence on each other, held a seminar on the subject Saturday, and almost 200 people showed up. Most of them were women.

title: 4 Die as Bomb Explodes on Israeli Bus
description: JERUSALEM, Nov.19  A terrorist bomb exploded on a packed bus carrying tourists and Israelis through the occupied West Bank today, killing four persons and wounding forty.

title: A New Piece By M. M. Cotel Is Performed
description: IT IS not often that a weekend con ference devoted to religious and political issues happens to introduce a new musical composition. But that is what the Leadership Assembly of the Greater New York Conference on Soviet Jewry did Saturday night at Temple B'nai Jeshuran, 270 West 89th Street, and the result was a credit to everyone involved.

title: Susan A. Schlotterbeck Is Bride of Glenn Pfeiffer
description: Our Saviour's Lutheran Church in Fairfield, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Susan Anne Schlotterbeck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter A. Schlotterbeck of Fairfield, to Glenn Melvin Pfeiffer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harley Pfeiffer of Grand Haven, Mich. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Richard Lindgren.

title: Advertising
description: JUST about a year ago it looked as if Playboy Enterprises had come up with an interesting way of enlarging its magazine empire  lending fledgling publishers startup money in return for an option to buy a majority. The first venture, of what at the time was expected to be a series, was the International Review of Food and Wine.

title: Pop: Carole King at Palladium
description: I WILL always want you for my sweetheart, Neil Sedaka chirped 19 years ago in tribute to Carole King, no matter what you do. And that sums up the attitude of the adulatory audience at the Palladium when Miss King performed there on Saturday night. (Coincidentally, Mr. Sedaka played at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday.) It scarcely mattered that Miss King, one of the greatest pop songwriters of the 1960's and among the most popular performers of the early 70's, has not recorded an especially memorable song for several years, because her show was largely given over to her classic compositions.

title: Boy Dies When Can of Gasoline Ignites After Spilling on Heater
description: A 10-year-old boy was fatally burned in the office of a Brooklyn service station yesterday morning when a can of gasoline spilled accidentally, ignited on contact with an electric heater and engulfed him in flames the police mooned.

title: Commodities
description: DESPITE the sharply downward trend in the price of gold thus far this month, Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. has come round to the belief that more and more Americans will continue to invest part of their savings in the metal as a hedge against inflation and general economic uncertainty.

title: Dispute Over Admissible Evidence Finds a New Target: Voiceprints
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  The issue or what standard to apply in admitting scientific evidence in court proceedings, a subject of debate for more than 50 years, has been further obscured in recent months by conflicting Federal and state court decisions.

title: Young Leaving Today On Africa Trip to Win Support for U.S. Aims
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 19 Andrew Young will leave tomorrow for Africa hoping to elicit support from leaders whose backing is critical for the success of United States diplomatic efforts regarding southern Africa.

title: ABROAD AT HOME Israel And Egypt
description: BOSTON, Nov. 19  The year since Anwar Sadat went to Jerusalem has been a rollercoaster of hope and disappointment. After the exhilaration of the visit came months of diplomatic stalemate. camp David seemed to assure agreement between Israel and Egypt. Then, in the last few weeks, that prospect has flickered.

title: Peru Completes $2 Billion Refinancing Package
description: LIMA, Nov. 19  Peru's financial authorities have completed what they describe as a 32 billion package of loan and refinancing operations with foreign banks and governments that they hope will enable them to stabilize and turn around an economy that until few months ago was in the worst crisis in its history.

title: Bobby Allison Takes 500Mile Race
description: ONTARIO, Calif., Nov. 19 (AP) Bobby Allison scraped the wall 20 miles from the finish today but managed a 1.78micond victory over Cale Yarborough ill the $185,000 Los Angeles Times 500, the final race of the Grand National stock car season.

title: Ralph Kirshbaum in Cello Recital
description: SINCE his New York recital debut nearly three years ago, Ralph Kirshbaum has been pursuing what appears to be a busy and prosperous career in Europe and London, the city where he has now taken up residence. Saturday night the cellist from Texas returned to New York, very much a seasoned musician, for a recital at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A.

title: Deaths
description: SIMONEJoseph N., beloved husband of Gloria, devoted father of Peter, loving brother of Evelyn Owen, John. Alfred and Violet Genorese and Carolyn Hamid. Reposing at Cobble Hill Chapels, 171 Court St, Brooklyn. Funeral Tuesday. 10AM Mass at Our Lady of Lebanon (Remsen and Henry Streets). Interment Calvary Cemetery. Visiting 2 to 5, 7 to 10PM.

title: New York Drafts Welfare Budget
description: A New York State budget request for $7,551,141,000 for welfare, Medicaid, social services and administration has been drafted by the State Department of Social Services, up 4.2 percent from current spending and 12.6 percent higher than a year ago.

title: I'll Miss The Mill
description: There's no more weaving. There are no more old looms any more. Everything today is modern. I don't know how to explain it, but you're connected with the machinery. It's a part of you; it's your life. I love the mills, I love to work, I loved being a battery hand. I always liked it. I used to complain a lot, but if I had my choice, I would stay here until I retired. And three quarters of the people here would have stayed here for life. The bosses never bothered you if you did your work. They didn't care if you went for a break. They were never on your back, saying, Now we've got to get this done. We. all worked together as one. Everybody had their work to do, everybody knew what to do, and they did it. There were no fights, no bickering. It was a good life.

title: As the Clouds Descend, So Do Delaware's Duck Hunters
description: BOMBAY HOOK, Del., Nov. 18 You hunt yesterday?

title: When Peace Is at Hand
description: As Henry Kissinger discovered in closing his big deal on Vietnam, an announcement that peace is at hand usually produces a lot of slippery fingers. So it is in the Middle East today. Frightened Israelis and fretting Egyptians are clawing over the compromises of Camp David as if the agreement posed a greater threat than the impasse of only a year ago. According to President Carter, the negotiators are now quarreling over the height of permissible observation towers and losing sight of the human dimensions of their pending accord; they are haggling over days in the schedule of troop withdrawals at the risk of losing a magic moment in time.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Eugene Onegin, Waltz, Tchaikovsky; La Cathedrale engloutie, Debussy; 6th Sonata for Recorder and Strings, Rebel; Three Fantastic Dances, Shostakovich; Suite in E minor: Allemande and Bourree, Bach; A Midsummer Night's Dream, Scherzo, Mendelssohn.

title: Rating Foods for Health
description: The approach of Thanksgiving, season of gorging, reminds us how little we know about nutrition. The Federal Government has tried for 50 years to make sure that Americans get all the proteins, minerals, vitamins and other nutrients they need. But little research has focused on the newer health problems caused by our overabundant diet.

title: RYAN WAS A FRIEND OF DISADVANTAGED
description: In 22 years of public office, Leo Joseph Ryan, the 53-year-old Congressman who was killed in Guyana Saturday, had developed a reputation as an independentminded reformer and a personal investigator of trouble spots.

title: Bowl Pairings
description: GARDEN STATE BOWL, Dec. 16

title: BEGIN REJECTS PLAN FOR LINK IN TREATY TO THE PALESTINIANS
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 19  Prime Minister Menachem Begin, arriving at his Herut Party headquarters under a barrage of eggs thrown by disenchanted supporters, said tonight that he would ask the Israeli

title: Dividends
description: Cartel listnt sr herkilert meetings for week follows

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 20, 1978

title: TV: The Immigrants, Another Formula
description: THE IMMIGRANTS, on WPIX/Channel II tonight and tomorrow at 8, comes off the curious programming line called Operation Prime Time.

title: ESSAY The Airport World
description: EVERYWHERE INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT  The President of American Airlines has just informed the Mayor of New York that his company is doing what it does best: taking off. Announcement of the airline's plans to move its headquarters from the center of Manhattan to the Orwellian airport complex somewhere between Dallas and Fort Worth came as a shock to New York's commercial hopes.

title: Caribbean Air Crash Kills 15
description: POINTE-A-PITRE, Guadeloupe, Nov. 19 (UPI)  A small Air Guadeloupe airliner crashed yesterday on a 20mile flight from Guadeloupe to the holiday island of MarieGalante. Fifteen people were killed and five were rescued, all with iniuries. An airline spokesman said the plane went down in a thunderstorm mile and a quarter from its destination. They said all the passengers were residents of the two Frenchowned islands, situated in the Caribbean about midway between Puerto Rico and Venezuela.

title: Putnam to Be N.A.S.D. Head
description: Stephen Putnam, president of F.L. Putnam & Company, was elected 1979 chairman of the board of governors of the National Association of Securities Dealers. John A. Wing of the Becker Securities Corporation, Chicago, was elected vice chairman of the association's 27member board. A former Georgia Congressman, Williamson S. Stuckey Jr., was named a governor at large. The N.A.S.D. regulates the overthecounter stock market.

title: CUNY Aides Criticized As Inactive on Asbestos
description: The New York Public Interest Research Group charged over the weekend that the City University of New York has not done enough to eliminate asbestos sites posing a health hazard from dangerous levels of the material, which has been found to cause cancer.

title: Georgia O'Keeffe Is Involved in 2 Suits Linked to Agent Fees on Her Paintings
description: While Georgia O'Keeffe savors the tranquillity of life in tiny Abiquiu, N.M., still pursuing at age 91 the art that has brought her worldwide fame, legal battles involving her are being waged in two courts here in Manhattan.

title: Crewman Survives 12Mile Swim
description: NEW SMYRNA BEACH, Fla., Nov. 19 (AP)  A 21-year-old fishing boat crewman crawled out of the Atlantic Ocean yesterday after an allnight, 12mile swim that began when waves tossed him from the boat. Peter Knopp, skipper and part owner of the 44foot trawler, said that Jimmy Lear of Daytona Beach, Fla., told him that he had managed to get to beachside house after the swim and call police.

title: Design for New Theater Picked in Provincetown
description: PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Nov. 19 The design of a new theater here that is to become the nation's first major center for the study of Eugene ONeill and his plays was announced today after an unusual architectural competition conducted in public for eight days.

title: Patriots Gain 1917 Victory
description: The 1978 comeback of Richard Todd as the New York Jets No. 1 quarterback is over. It ended threefourths of the way through the Jets 1917 loss to the New England Patriots yesterday at Shea Stadium.

title: Music: Ashkenazy Leads And Is the Piano Soloist
description: VLADIMIR ASHKENAZY continues to pursue his conducting career, and yesterday afternoon he appeared with the English Chamber Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall as both piano soloist and conductor of a fullscale (chamber) orchestral program.

title: Dollar Climbs Against Yen
description: TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 20(Reuters)  the recovery of the dollar gained momentum today on the Tokyo foreignexchange market when the currency rose to 195.60 yen, its highest level in nearly four months.

title: I Class Up A Joint
description: I've never worked a daY in my life. If I did it would probably ruin my career, which at the moment is something of a cross between a butterfly and a lap dog. I never went to high school either.

title: Roaches on M.T.A. Buses Driving the Riders Buggy
description: Fifteen or 20 passengers got off the Madison Avenue bus at 57th Street the other day, brushing themselves off, removing their coats, swinging their arms and slapping themselves, while passersby looked on in perplexity.

title: Carillon to Add A Happy Note At Show Times
description: A new sound of music came to Broadway and the Times Square area yesterday as St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church  long the home of the Actor's Chapel  dedicated a carillon that will salute curtaintime every evening and matinee snow time with There's No Business Like Show Business. The new electronic bells of St. Malachy's, at 239 West 49th Street, will also chime regularly every quarterhour and play the Angelus three times a day.

title: Stable or Higher Prices Possible in Bond Market
description: Bond prices, buoyed by greater stability of the dollar in foreign-exchange trading and the Federal Reserve's apparent decision to hold the Federal funds rate close to 93% percent for a while, made fairly goodsized gains last week. Yields on Government bonds posted their largest declines since August.

title: City's Roadway Works Restricted for Holidays
description: Work on New York City's roadways and sidewalks will be restricted throughout the coming holiday season under regulations issued yesterday by Transportation Commissioner Anthony R. Ameruso.

title: Arizona State Named Foe For Rutgers in New Bowl
description: Arizona State, a new member of the Pacific 10 Conference but an old hand at football bowls, accepted a bid yesterday to one of the two new bowl games. The Sun Devils agreed to play Rutgers in the first Garden State Bowl game at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, NJ.. Dec. 16.

title: How W.T.T. Became World Teamless Tennis
description: THE league that brought you colorcoded courts and a new concept of tennis has all but ceased to exist. World Team Tennis has come to this: two courts, two franchises and very few players.

title: STEVEN S. CARDNER, FED OFFICIAL, DEAD
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  Steven S. Gardner, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, died of cancer at his home here today after a long illness. He was 56 years old.

title: Outdoors
description: NOW that true November weather has arrived, Long Island hunters will once again be inspired to follow their sport in one of the nations classical waterfowl regions.

title: Rear Column,
description: IN Rear Column, Simon Gray has drawn upon an episode in the later career of the African explorer Henry Morton Stanley to construct an absorbing play about human disintegration under pressure.

title: Khan Is Victor In Squash Match
description: Sharif Khan of Toronto, the ninetime North American open champion, defeated Stu Goldstein of New York, 159, 1648, 1512, 154, in the final of a $15,000 squash tournament at the Uptown Rac, (met Club yesterday. First prize was $2,500. Goldstein won $1,500. More than 400 people, in men's, women's and junior divisions, competed in the threeday tournament.

title: Education Boards See Levittown As a Model for Resisting Strikes
description: LEVITTOWN, L.I.  The outcome of the teachers strike here  an outcome that gave the teachers virtually nothing they had sought  is being interpreted by school boards elsewhere as a sign that a strong board, intent on holding down costs, can succeed even in the face of a determined union.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SAYS IT IS GETTING ARMS
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 19 Prime Minister P.W. Botha, rejecting United Nations pressures for black majority rule in SouthWest Africa has said that the oil embargo favored by some African nations will have no more impact on South Africa than the weapons embargo does that is already in force.

title: Smoke From Blaze in Room Kills A Resident of Hebrew Home, 86,
description: An elderly resident in the Hebrew Home for the Aged in the Riverdale section of the Bronx was killed by smoke inhalation from a small blaze in his room at the home at 5901 Palisades Avenue.

title: James. Edward Noftingham Jr., Jazz and RadioTV Trumpeter
description: James Edward Nottingham Jr., a trumpeter whose work ranged across the music scene from 52d Street jazz clubs of the late 1940's to more recent appearances with television network staff orchestras, died Thursday at Brooklyn Veteran's Hospital at the age of 53. He lived at 447 Fourth Kings Walk in Brooklyn.

title: Issue and Debate Government's Regulation of Commerce on Sundays
description: NEW HAVEN  After the laws of the New Haven Colony were printed and bound on blue paper in 1650, they became known as blue laws and over three centunes, the term has come to mean any law that attempts to regulate work or in dustry on Sundays.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Dip Sharply
description: Though most shortterm interest rates climbed last week and banks set minimum rate of 11 percent on corporate loans, rates on United States Treasury bills dropped sharply, and that is sad news for depositors who want to buy sixmonth savings certificates.

title: Cowboys Rout Saints, 277
description: The Dallas Cowboys took their customary 15minute nap during the first quarter of their game against the New Orleans Saints in Irving, Tex., yesterday, but they then awoke to play their best brand of football and routed the Saints, 277.

title: After 59 Years, Maclean's Becomes Canada's Own News Magazine
description: TORONTO, Nov. 19  In October 1919, Lieut. Col. John B. Maclean wrote a memo announcing to his monthly magazine's staff: The ultimate aim is to develop Maclean's into a Canadian national weekly.

title: Max Factor's Chief Is a Revlon Product
description: Max Factor & Company, the cosmetics concern, has turned to Revlon, its highclass competitor, for its new president and chief executive officer. It named Dale Ratliff, one of Revlon's ranking sales executives, to succeed Sam Kalish, who resigned as Max Factor's top executive last July 1.

title: Education Gains Fail To Help Women Win Jobs, Study Maintains
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP)  A white man who dropped out of high school made more money on the average in 1976 than a white woman with a college degree, according to a private study of Labor Department figures.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Did Al (Bummy) Davis ever fight Bob Montgomery? If he did, who won?

title: Staff of a Defeated Congressman Seeks to Sell Services as Package
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) Several Capitol Hill employees, bucking the axiom that sudden unemployment goes with politicals, are trying to sell their services as a team to a Congressional newcomer.

title: SADAT IS DESCRIBED AS HOPEFUL ON PACT
description: CAIRO, Nov. 19  One year after he stepped off an airplane in Jerusalem and embarked on his historic peace mission, President Anwar elSadat was described today by a prominent American visitor as still upbeat in his hopes for a Middle East peace settlement.

title: Marc Silverman in a Piano Debut
description: MARC SILVERMAN'S New York recital debut Saturday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall was more than auspicious. At 26, he plays the piano with exceptional authority and impeccable taste, and he doesn't miss notes.

title: The City
description: An alleged gambling operation that masqueraded as a taxconsulting service but, according to the police, handled $1 million a week in telephone bets on sporting events was shut down yesterday in a police raid at an East Side apartment. Five men were arrested and large quantities of purported gambling records and paraphernalia were seized.

title: CIVIL SERVICE PLAN SOON TO TAKE SHAPE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  At midnight Dec. 31, the 95-year-old Civil Service Commission will cease to exist. It will be replaced, one second later, by three new agencies, a result of a battle by President Carter for what he termed the centerpiece of his efforts to improve the efficiency of the Civil Service.

title: 2 Convicted Top Officers Resign Posts at Fruehauf
description: The top two officers of the Fruehauf Corporation, who were convicted in 1975 of defrauding the Government of $12.3 million in excise taxes, resigned last week. William E. Grace, chairman, and Robert D. Rowan, president and chief executive officer, submitted their resignations to the company's board two weeks after the United States Supreme Court refused to grant a hearing on an appeal of their convictions.

title: U.S. and Japan In Energy Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP)  The United States and Japan have tentatively agreed on a $10 billion cooperative program to find alternative energy resources, with initial emphasis on fusion energy and coal conversion. An

title: BILL H. THOMPSON
description: PARIS, Tex., Nov. 19 (AP)  Bill H. Thompson, an executive of the Texas Power and Light Company and former managing editor of The Paris News, died Friday night when his car was struck headon by a pickup truck near Honey Grove, about 20 miles east of this north Texas city.

title: Columbus Enjoying a Quiet Prosperity as Its Sister Cities in Ohio Decline
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 18  After all that has been said about the decline of the nation's industrial crescent, this central Ohio city is an exception.

title: McEnroe Wins
description: WEMBLEY, England, Nov. 19 (AP)  John McEnroe battled for 33/4 hours today to overcome a fellow American, Tim Gullikson, 67, 64, 76, 62, in the final of a Grand Prix tennis tournament.

title: Hanoi Says Peking Is Attempting To Start New Exodus of Chinese
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 19 (Reuters) Vietnam accused China today of trying to start another mass exodus of ethnic Chinese, charging that the attempt was a bid to undermine Vietnam's sovereignty and security.

title: Stein Study Says M. T A. Invests Millions Abroad
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is putting millions of dollars into Swiss banks and such places as Walla Walla, Wash., instead of using the money to help New York's economy, Andrew J. Stein, the Manhattan Borough President, said yesterday.

title: Deaths
description: BAUMOHL.Samuel Peter Beloved husband of Ruth devoted father of Michael & Pat Starke adored grandfather of Amy. Stephen & Nicola. Services Monday. November 20, 12:15PM at The Riverside, 76 St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Rikers Inmate Stabbed to Death By Another With Makeshift Knife
description: A 35-year-old prisoner was stabbed to death yesterday by another prisoner with a sharpened spoon, authorities said. Both men had been in a special section of the House of Detention for Men on Bikers Island, where they had been undergoing mental observation.

title: Fleming Wins Race
description: Tom Fleming of the New York Athletic Club was the individual winner and the Greenville (S.C.) Track Club captured the team title in the Road Runners Club of America National 15kilometer crosscountry championships today

title: A President in the Shadow of a Legend
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 19  Have you seen an African fig tree? Its branches are wide so that it blocks the sun and nothing can grow beneath it. But when it is cut down, the sunlight comes in and then a new tree can

title: Profits Taste Sweet At French Food Fair
description: PARIS, Nov. 19  Amid caviar from Bulgaria, oyster extract from Japan and snails from Turkey, the 25,000 buyers and importers who mingled, dickered and tasted seemed mainly hungry for the American market at Salon Internationalde l'Alimentation, the mammoth food trade show that ran here all week.

title: Concert Piano: Lili Kraus
description: ASCHUBERT anniversary without a concert by LIB Kraus would be as unthinkable as a Mozart anniversary without a concert by Lili Kraus. The pianist has become so closely identified with these two composers, playing their music and speaking of them with such passionate commitment, that one sometimes feels she must have known both personally.

title: 3d NATO Satellite Sent Up
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla, Nov. 19 (AP)  A North Atlantic Treaty Organization 3C communications satellite was lofted last night, joining two similar spacecraft already in orbit. The satellites are designed to improve communications among the 15nation NATO alliance.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Week ended Nov. 17, 1978

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON BIG changes are coming for Senate and House committees as a result of the midterm national election. The arrival of a large contingent of new House members and the secondlargest number of new Senators in history will bring a shift in the balance of power on key committees. In almost all cases, it will be to the right.

title: World News Briefs
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 19 (Reuters)  An Indian Air Force transport plane crashed on a mountain airfield near the Chinese border today, killing all 77 persons aboard. One man on the ground was also killed.

title: Todd's Call: Was It Right?
description: WITH the new pain searing the same left shoulder, Richard Todd got up slowly. In a third-and-16 situation at the New York Jets 16yard line, he had called a quarterback draw  a dangerous play for a man of iron, a reckless play for a man who had missed seven games with a fractured collarbone. He had hurried for a 7yard gain but then he was tackled and jarred by two New England Patriot linebackers, Rod Shoate and Steve Nelson, and he got up slowly. At the sideline, he motioned to Dr. James Nicholas, the Jets orthopedist, and they went under Shea Stadium to the Xray room. By the time Richard Todd returned to the sideline, his understudy, Matt Robinson, had collaborated with Wesley Walker for a 56yard touchdown play that put the Jets ahead, 1716, in a game they would eventually lose, 1917. Now, midway in the final quarter, Matt Robinson was standing at the sideline when Richard Todd walked over to him.

title: Ennis
description: BURNS--Allaryse Sudour, Of 114 E. 71 St, NYC,on November 18. Beloved mother of Jeanne, and Robert. Loy ing grandmother of Jennifer, Eric. and Susanne Kent. Services to be announced.

title: East Brunswick Finds Easy Way To Sell Its Notes
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 19 Municipalities big and small are finding it troublesome to sell bonds for civic projects, but not East Brunswick. It took merely four days last September to sell out a $529,000 bond issue, which will finance a garage for the township.

title: Notes on People
description: College Chancellor Paying Dividends at State University

title: Deaths in Guyana Threaten Sect's California Organization
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 19  The powerful politicalreligious organization that the Rev. Jim Jones built as the People's Temple seemed today to be in danger of breaking apart in the aftermath of five murders at the airstrip that serves the group's agricultural colony at Jonestown, Guyana.

title: Carters Hear Amy and 34 Others Play Violins at Children's Recital
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) President and Mrs. Carter, after returning from Camp David this afternoon, listened to their daughter, Amy, and 34 other children perform at a violin recital in a suburban church.

title: Lennie Tristano, at 59 Pianist Was Innovator In the Cool Jazz

Apart from the damage they suffered in the standings, the Redskins showed that they were in trouble as the 16game National Football League season ground on.

title: NICARAGUANS FLEE THREAT OF FIGHTING

But more than half the houses stand empty, the occupants having fled in anticipation of a new insurrection against President Anastasio Somoza Debayle.

The police said that Alonzo Holland, 7 years old, and his brother, Tyrone, 4, who were sleeping when the fire broke out, were pronounced dead of smoke inhalation at area hospitals.
