Witnesses said that one resident had escaped by jumping out window and another had climbed out window and down a tree. The 97-year-old hotel had been occupied in recent years by retired, elderly and lowincome people. The cause of the fire is not known.

title: U.S. Boxers Defeat England
description: LONDON, Nov. 20 (AP)  Alex Ramos, a middleweight from New York City, led an amateur boxing team from the United States to a 53 victory over England tonight.

title: Grand Jury Studying Alleged Talks By Carter Aides of a Fix
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 20  A Federal grand jury has begun an investigation here of whether there is any substance to an allegation that aides of President Carter discussed halting extradition proceedings against Robert L. Vesco, the financier, in exchange for a share of $10 million in stock according to Federal sources.

title: Begin to Ask Cabinet to Approve Treaty Draft It Rejected 2 Weeks Ago
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 20  Prime Minister Menachem Begin is planning to ask the Israeli Cabinet tomorrow to approve a draft of a peace treaty with Egypt that the ministers balked at two weeks ago.

title: Around the Nation
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov 20 (AP)  Parents abuse nearly two million children each year, according to a study released today at a conference on the subject. Those who conducted the study, which was commissioned by the National Institutes of Mental Health, reported that the scope of the problem to he double previous Government estimates.

title: Piano: Sylvia Zaremba Plays First of 3 Recitals
description: SYLVIA ZAREMBA, a onetime child prodigy pianist who has enjbyed considerable success for several decades as an adult, gave a technically impressive performance in the first of three recitals that she will be nresentine this season in

title: Sect Leader's Lawyers Relish Radical Images But Have Differences
description: Each man has been involved for many years in some of the most sensational controversies in the United States. Each has been called a radical and relished the reputation, but each has also been called a publicity hound, even an opportunist.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: Demolition Blast Fells Wrecked Hotel's Wing
description: JOPLIN, Mo., Nov. 20 (AP)  Demolition workers have dynamited, the wing of the Connor Hotel that remained standing after the main section collapsed last week and killed two workmen.

title: Carter Weighs Cuts in Pay Increases for Half a Million
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 20  President Carter is considering asking Congress to overhaul the Federal pay system in order to reduce future increases for more than a half million workers, White House officials said today.

title: Unwords and Policy
description: WASHINGTONYears ago Disraeli, in one of the novels, remarked that Few ideas are correct ones, and none can ascertain which they are. But it is with words we govern men. There can be no doubt that words are important in government and they are especially so in the delicate area of foreign policy negotiations. It is for this reason that I have been troubled by what appears to me to be the undisciplined use of language with which American spokesmen and principal officers of the government have addressed themselves to certain foreign policy problems.

title: 2 Peking Wall Posters Raise New Questions On the Status of Hua
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 20  Two wall posters calling for a full public investigation into the suppression and coverup of the major antiGovernment demonstration in Peking in 1976 appeared in the Chinese capital today, raising questions about the status of Hua Kuofeng, Chairman of the Chinese Communist Party.

title: Last Satellites Released In Space Shot to Venus
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov 20 (Reuters)  A United States spacecraft 5.8 million miles from Venus released its last three passenger satellites today as part of study of the planet's atmosphere, space officials said here.

title: Rep. Diggs Is Sentenced to 3 Years Over Kickbacks From Employees
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 Representative Charles C. Diggs Jr., the senior black member of Congress, who was overwhelmingly reelected two weeks ago, was sentenced today to three years in prison on charges of mail fraud and making false statements.

title: Thin Line in the Jungle
description: Thin Line in the Jungle

title: Three States Suing U.S. To Overturn Law on Gas
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 20 (AP) Charging regional discrimination and a Federal violation of states ights, Oklahoma, Texas and Louisiana filed suit today seeking to overturn the Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978, a key part of President Carter's energy legislation.

title: Board Backs Koch Plan on State Financing for City
description: Bowing to a request by Mayor Koch, the Board of Higher Education yesterday endorsed a proposal to transfer the total operating and capital costs of the City University's fouryear colleges to New York State, but based this support on an insistence that the independence of the 18unit institution be continued.

title: Jersey Hearing on AntiHomosexual Bill Disrupted
description: TRENTON, Nov. 20  A State Senate hearing on a proposal to make homosexual acts a crime in New Jersey  instead of decriminalizing them, which would happen next September under a recently passed measure  was disrupted today by an elderly woman who called hot-nosextiality a sin.

title: U.N. 4ides Will Interview efugees on Ship ff Malaysia
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Nov. 20  The Malaysian Government, which has withdrawn its threat to force a freighter with 2,500 Vietnamese aboard to leave Malasyian waters, has granted United Nations officials permission to begin interviewinu the refugees tomorrow.

title: On Cambodia: But, Yet
description: CHICAGOEveryone knows about the war waged by the United States in Cambodia from 1970 to 1975. But very few people know about or understand the war that it is waging today against that country, which now calls itself Democratic Kampuchea. The war is being fought on many fronts. But it is mainly a propaganda war, a con-

title: Deaths
description: LABERSelma G.. beloved wife of the late Henry. Devoted mother of Austin. Dear sister of George Geller. Cherished grandmother of Abigail. Pam and Emily. Loving mother-inlaw of Jeri. Services Wednesday, November 22nd, 12:15pm, The Riverside 76th St P. Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The American Cancer Society

title: Koch Reported to Want Hospitals Chief to Resign
description: New York City officials said yesterday that Mayor Koch was preparing to ask for the resignation of Joseph T. Lynaugh as president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, the semiautonomous city agency that spends $1 billion a year to operate the 18 municipal hospitals.

title: Mrs. Kreps Going Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP)  Secretary of Commerce Juanita M. Kreps will travel to New Delhi next week to try to strengthen trade relations with India, it was announced today. Mrs. Kreps will also travel to Moscow, where she will join Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal in attempts to improve commercial relations with the Soviet Union.

title: State Dept. Says It Told Ryan of Mission's Peril
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  The State Department said today that it had told Representative Leo J. Ryan before his trip that Jim Jones's People's Temple community had armed guards and that was situated in an area with few police.

title: Cut in Hospital Beds Sought
description: New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation announced yesterday that it had asked the state for permission to eliminate 156 beds at Harlem Hospital Center. This would result in a 16 percent reduction in the current total of 971 beds. Officials also said a 65bed reduction was planned for Queens General Hospital, reducing the total there from 750 to 695.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Mixed
description: Yields were mixed on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and 182day maturities.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 1978

title: Working Windjammer Again Graces the Harbor
description: For the first time in 42 years, a coinmercial sailing ship will depart from New York Hart)or. The Berta of Ibiza, her 10 crew members and a 60,000pound cargo of Vaseline. Qtips, talc and empty bottles, was scheduled to leave at dawn this morning from Pier 6 at the foot of Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn. Destination: Trinidad.

title: The Three U.S. Newsmen Slain in Guyana Ambush
description: An awardwinning correspondent for NBC News since 1975, 42-year-old Don Harris had a career in television that spanned more than 20 years and embraced a wide range of assignments as a reporter, newscaster, producer, weatherman and program director.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Climbs Overseas, Then Eases in New York
description: By The Associated Press

title: Keeping Faith With the Boat People
description: The Carter Administration's offer to take an additional 2,500 Indochina boat people out of Malaysian transit camps should persuade Kuala Lumpur to grant safe haven to the 2,500 aboard the freighter Hai Hong. But this latest crisis dramatizes a new Vietnam refugee problem, far larger than any since the American departure from Saigon.

title: Soviet and Ethiopia Sign Accord Solidifying Ties in Horn of Africa
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 20  The Soviet Union today solidified its relatidnship with Ethiopia by signing a treaty of friendship and cooperation that is expected to maintain or increase Soviet military involvement in the Horn of Africa.

title: Israel Asks Germans Not to Use Statute of Limitations for Nazis
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 20  The Israeli Parliament appealed to the West German Government and the Bundestag today not to apply its statute of limitations to Nazi war criminals.

title: Austria Marks Anniversary Of Schubert
description: VIENNA, Nov. 20  Austria observed the 150th anniversary of Franz Schubert's death yesterday with official ceremonies and a series of concerts, particularly in Vienna.

title: Plan for Airborne Missiles to Land Before Firing Arouses U.S. Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  A White House scientific panel has urged the Carter Administration to adopt a multibilliondollar plan involving the deployment of hundreds of missiles on airplanes that would, in the event of attack, land at airst rios to fire the weatxms.

title: Soccer Makes Columbia a Winner
description: For the first time in more than a decade, the loudest noise at Baker Field did not come from the nearby I RT elevated train. This time it came from Columbia soccer fans and players at the conclusion of Saturday afternoon's Ivy League title game against Brown.

title: Books: Should Opera Attempt To Teach Its Modern Audience?
description: YOU might wonder before reading this book what Becket's Godot has to do with opera in the 20th century. After reading it, you still might wonder, for the au thor's prose style is so entwined in mannerism and his logic so opaque that whatever points he has to make can be difficult to discern.

title: Sports Today
description: Kneks vs. Do Derout Pistorns Madvion tiquar Garden, 7:10 P.M. (TelevisionChannel E, cable, 7:30 P.M.)(RadioWNEW, 7:30 P.M.)

title: Colts
description: Following the 21point trouncing of his team last Sunday, the owner of the Baltimore Colts, Robert (Tiger) Irsay, had another temper tantrum, which has become an almost weekly event. Speaking to several reporters Irsay announced that at the end of the season he would dismiss all the team's assistant coaches, an act usually beyond the province of owners. Coaches hire and fire their own assistants, but in Baltimore, acquiring the club for $19 million six years ago appears to have given Irsay the privilege of expressing his considerable feelings.

title: Talking Business
description: with Andrews of the Purchasing Association

title: The Region
description: HARTFORD  Potentially danger. ous amounts of chemical pollutants have been found in six drinking walls in the town of Canton, according to the State Department of Health, and I he owners of the wells have been told to stop using them. Dr. Douglas S. Lloyd, the department commissioner, issued statement today saying that there was no immediate acute risk to healthbut that the department and the State Department of Environmental Protection were conducting further tests in Canton, a rural area with a population of 7,200.

title: A.B. Dick's Acquisition Proposed
description: The A. B. Dick Company, the 9-1-year old Chicago producer of business machines, and the General Electric Company of London, announced yesterday that their boards had agreed in principle to the acquisition of A.B. Dick by the British company for $103 million in cash.

title: Tape Shows Coast Jet Lost Sight Of Small Plane Before the Crash
description: Government investigators made public yesterday transcripts of cockpit recordings showing doubts raised among an airliner's crew about the position of a small plane just before the two craft collided over San Diego Sept. 25.

title: Two Students Die in Auto Crash
description: PORTSMOUTH, R.I., Nov. 20 (AP) Two students at Roger Williams College died in a car accident on East Main Road late Saturday. The state police identified them as John T. Livieri, 18 years old, of Woodbridge, Conn., and Stephen Vass, 18, of Bridgeport, Conn. The police said that the students car went out of control and struck a utility pole.

title: Costumes of Ballets Ruses in Gala Show
description: The Rusana are back. Not princes and Peant who turned the Costume thy Metropliton Mosconi if ?? two years redone, the original design being encased in a protective covering.

title: Corporate Earnings Are Reported for the Quarter
description: AODRESSO-MULTIGRAPH (N)

title: Koch Drops Objection to Contract For Franchise to Build Bus Shelters
description: Mayor Koch yesterday withdrew his final objection to granting the multimilliondollar busshelter franchise to the Convenience Safety Corporation, clearing the way for the contract to be awarded by the Board of Estimate tomorrow.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, Nov. 20, 1978

title: About Education
description: THE mathematicians shall inherit the earth, and a little calculator shall lead them. That seems to be the essence of a message to students, parents and mathematics teachers from Prof. Bruce R. Vogeli, chairman of the Department of Mathematics, Statistics and Computing in Education at Teachers College, Columbia University.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, NOV. 20, 1978

title: Fun and Sham With Broadway Scenery
description: ISUDDENLY see that I shall have to revise my prejudices  somewhat. For some years now I've steadily inveighed against the stage's rather pitiful habit of attempting to ape the scenic splendors, and the speed, of film. Once film, with its casual power of showing audiences everything from towering infernos to ships turning turtle in midocean, had become the theater's principal rival, the theater tried fighting back on a metoo basis.

title: GOING OLJT Guide
description: EARLY REMINDER A midday ceremony by the Salvation Army at 12:30 P.M. in Rockefeller Center, with a cheerful earful of Christmas music. will urge New Yorkers to remember the needy during the incoming season.

title: School War Holdout
description: The great school war over decentralization ended a decade ago, but somebody evidently forgot to tell Harlem's Community School Board 5. It continues to do battle with its district superintendent, with Schools Chancellor Frank Macchiarola, with the press and, not least, with its own children. In the most recent episode of this tragicomedy, the board fired Superintendent William Hall for the fifth time since July, even locking him out of his office, only to have him reinstated again by the Chancellor. Enough is enough.

title: SADAT SEEMS BITTER AT ARAB MODERATES
description: CAIRO, Nov. 20  As the first anniversary of his speech before the Israeli Knesset passes, President Anwar elSadat is said to have become embittered by the lack of moderate Arab support for his peace efforts and fearful of being trapped in a separate peace agreement with Israel.

title: Reopening of Bazaars In Iran Is Called Step Back to Normal Life
description: HEHERAN Iran, Nov. 20 The great bazaar of Teheran, a hotbed of the revolt against the Shah, reopemil for Inv:loess today titer hello! shot down for nearly 10 (lays hv a strike.

title: Istanbul Ferry Hijacked
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 20 (AP) Armed youths, said to be leftists, hi. jacked a ferry carrying about 750 corn. miners from the European side of Wan. Mil In the Asian side today and ordered the captain to cniise in the Eicksponts until authorities listened to their demands, which were not reported.

title: Trial in Girl Scout Slayings Is Delayed by Allegations of a Book Deal
description: PRYOR, Okla., Nov. 20  The murder trial of Gene Leroy Hart, charged with the sex slayings of three Girl Scouts June 13, 1977, has been delayed indefinitely. Defense attorneys charged in a pretrial hearing that the prosecuting attorney had handed out confidential documents.

title: Music: Chamber Version of l'Histoire du Soldat
description: AS a feature of its first anniversary season, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is reprising its audience's favorite pieces from the first decade of concerts. Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, the chosen work was Stravinsky's L'Histoire du Soldat, in a cleverly arranged version conducted by Michael Tilson Thomas.

title: Searchlights in Kabul: A Symbol of New Repression
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 15 Every night, as the first truckloads of wellarmed soldiers rumble out across this andent capital to begin enforcing the military curfew, two or three powerful searchlights come on, surveying the city and the rocky brown mountains that surround it.

title: British Court Hears Liberal Leader Conspired to Murder Alleged Lover
description: LONDON, Nov. 20  Jeremy Thorpe, the former leader of the Liberal Party, was quoted today as having said several times that the only way to silence Norman Scott, who maintained he had had homosexual relationship with him, would be to murder him.

title: IRA S. ROBBINS DIES, HOUSING EXPERT, 78
description: Ira S. Robbins, a pioneer in the field of public housing during the 1930's and 40's, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital of complications after an operation. Mr. Robbins was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Defectors From Sect Depict Its Rehearsals for Suicide
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 20  has mass suicide drills, where he tells all the people, hundreds of people, to drink a certain drink, and he says, That's fatal, you're all going to die in 45 minutes, want to see how you feel about dying for socialism.

title: Kerkorian to Seek 20% of Columbia
description: Kirk Kerkorian, owner of 48 percent of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc., the giant motion picture, hotel and casino company, disclosed yesterday that he would shortly offer to purchase 1.75 million shares, or about 20 percent, of Columbia Pictures Industries, for $24 a share.

title: Giants Oust Gibson A Day After Bungle
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 20  Bob Gibson, the Giants offensive coordinator, who called the disastrous play on which a victory was fumbled away yesterday, was dismissed today.

title: Sadat Offers to Meet Begin
description: PARIS, Nov. 20  President Anwar ell elSadat said in a broadcast on French television tonight that he would be glad to meet with Israeli Prime Minister Mena1 chem Begin anywhere, including Cairo, to overcome continued obstacles to peace treaty.

title: Roosevelt High Captures P.S.A.L. Soccer Title, 20
description: Theodore Roosevelt High School defeated South Shore of Brooklyn, 20, at Midwood Field Sunday for the Public Schools Athletic League soccer championship. The Bronx team scored its first goal on a header by Carlos Panchana, the center halfback, in the first half. Jim Selimoski, a wing, added the other goal late in the game. Joe Reale, Roosevelt's goalkeeper, recorded his 11th shutout of the year.

title: EARNINGS Marshall Field Profit Up By 10.4% in 3d Quarter
description: Marshall Field & Company, Chicago's leading department store chain, reported yesterday a profit increase of 10.1 percent for its third fiscal quarter ended Oct. 28.

title: Work at Olympics Site Races Fall Sun
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Nov. 17 The unusually warm autumn here has let construction for the 1980 Winter Olympics go on at a furious clip. Some sites are finished already, and two projects  new ski jumps and hockey rinks delayed last year by the bankruptcy of their steel suppliers are moving back onto schedule.

title: Red Sox Reflect
description: Haywood Sullivan, the man who runs the Boston Red Sox, sits in his office in Fenway Park these days, remembers how his team blew a I4game lead to the New York Yankees and confesses: I sit and stare, but I haven't come up with the answer vet.

title: Little Attention Paid to Warnings by Sect's Leader
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20 Few here paid attention earlier this year when relatives of people living in Jonestown, a jungle settlement in Guyana, distributed summary of human rights violations.

title: Anguished Mother Tells How Fear Controlled Cult
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20  The first time Wanda Johnson met the Rev. Jim Jones was in 1967 when the newly arrived minister was teaching adult education classes at Ukiah High School in California.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Returns to Indian Parliament and Is Booed by Her Foes
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 20  As the Indian Parliament opened a fiveweek winter session today, the governing Janata Party was confronted with the formidable presence of former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi inside the house and about 100,000 tradeunion demontrators outside.

title: Horner of Braves Top Rookie
description: Bob Horner, the Atlanta Braves slugging third baseman, was named National League rookie of the year by the Baseball Writers Association of America yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Opera Returns Luisa Miller
description: IT IS impossible not to (eel affertion for an opera in which the villain, a particularly slithery character, is named Worm. 13tit that is not all'that can he said for Verdi's Luisa Miller. which the Metropolitan Opera brought back into its repertory last night  for the first time since the 197172 season. One of the less- er, but not uninteresting works of Verdi's middle, period, Luisa Miller never quite works on the composer's highest level, which seems to baffle and confuse sometime operagoers. And yet it can provide an absorbing experience to anyone who listens with an inner ear tuned to Verdi's earlier and subsequent work.

title: Moscow Beams Harmed No One, Study Indicates
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UPI)  Medical researchers found no evidence that radiation beamed at the United States Embassy in Moscow caused health problems for Americans living in the building, according to a report issued today by the State Department.

title: Todd Is Again Focus Of the Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 20  The question hanging over the New York Jets camp today in the wake of the reinjury to Richard Todd's collarbone was the current situation of the Jets quarterkks.

title: The City
description: Senator Birch Bayh, Indiana Demo. crat, said he planned to hold a hearing next year to consider ways to protect a reporter's confidential notes in cases similar to that of M. A. Farber, the reporter for The New York Times who was jailed last summer after refusing tosubmit his files to the judge in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich in Bergen County, N.J.

title: Honor Code Challenged in Expulsion
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 20  A law student expelled from the University of Virginia announced today that he would seek to challenge the school's honor system in Federal court over his dismissal last May, two days before he was to graduate.

title: Giorgio de Chirico Dies; A Top Modernist Painter
description: Giorgio de Chirico, the painter, died of a heart attack yesterday in Rome, where he made his home lie was 90 yea us old.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 (AP) The state Supreme Court has reinstated a $125,000 award to a woman hit by a baseball during a Pittsburgh Pirates baseball game on the opening day of Three Rivers Stadium more than eight years ago.

title: Cubans Mobilize Over U.S. Fleet
description: HAVANA, Nov. 20 (Reuters)  Cuba put its defense forces on alert last week as a large American fleet apparently approached Cuban waters, reliable Cuban Government sources said today.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Theater: Serban's Workshop Master and Margarita
description: BULGAKOV'S The Master and Margarita'. is a soaring, dazzling novel; an extraordinary fusion of wildly disparate elements. It is a concerto played simultaneously on the organ, the bagpipes and a pennywhistle, while someone sets off fireworks between the players feet.

title: Sugar Suits Settled
description: The Ingredient Technology Corporation and the United Brands Company announced yesterday (hat they had jointly agreed to settle certain class action suits alleging violations of the antitrust laws in the sale of refined sugar in the eastern United States. Ingredient Technology has agreed to pay r2.26 million and United Brands has agreed to pay $362,500.

title: Bridge:
description: DENVER, Nov. 20  An unusual double seemed in the cards when the lifemaster women's pair championship went into its final stage at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here this afternoon.

title: COMPANY NEWS Joseph son Accused By arcourt Brace
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., a major publisher of books and maga-

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Economy

title: Minister in Georgia Is Convicted Of VoteBuying in Primary Races
description: ALBANY, Ga., Nov. 20 (AP)  The Rev. Clennon King, the black minister who tried to integrate President Carter's church in Plains, Ga., two years ago, was convicted today of votebuying.

title: Montreal and Edmonton To Play in Grey Cup Final
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 20 (UPI)  The Montreal Alouettes beat the Ottawa Rough Riders, 2116', yesterday and will meet the Edmonton Eskimos in the Grey Cup final next Sunday in the Canadian Football League.

title: Lasker Awards Given to
description: The 1978 Albert Lasker Awards in medicine were announced yesterday, with honors going to three scientists who developed important new vaccines and to three others whose discoveries opened a whole new realm of research in brain chemistry.

title: Deaths
description: WERTHEIMERVal. The Officers and Members of The Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union mourn the untimely passing of our collegue and friend, VicePresident Val Wertheimer. A longtime Officer of the Union, he served in many important posts with a rare devotion and distinction. Val Wertheimer was One of those totally trustworthy men whose Integrity shone forth like a beacon in the darkness that eternally strives to overcome us. No matter how black the situation seemed. Val's sunny demeanor convinced us that the sun would rise tornmorrow and that good would conquer evil His impressive efforts on behalf of his fellows in addition to his work for the Union, Include the cooperative movement, leadership in consumers and community groups, and The Amalgamated Bank of New York. An Honors Graduate of Columbia University Law School, he came to work for the Amalgamated in 1946 and rose to be Assistant Secretary Treasurer before being elected a VicePresident In 1966. Those of us who were fortunate enough to be as SoCiated with Val over the years are grateful for the privilege of having known a man who gave so much of himself so unstintingly and so cheerfully to his Union and to the cause of workers everywhere. To his wife of 32 years. Barbara, and to les son and daughter, we offer our deepest condolences. May his family take comfort from his lifetime of noble

title: Control of Poverty Funds Is Focus of Raucous Hearing
description: A raucous public hearing that ended abruptly with angry members of the audience storming the stage and forcing a city commissioner to flee under police protection has pointed up the difficulty faced by Mayor Koch in his effort to wrest control of the $35-million-a-year antipoverty program from the community groups that have run it for the last decade.

title: CREDIT MARKETS 2Year U.S. Notes Sold At 9.36%
description: The Treasury sold twoyear notes yesterday at an average yield of 9.36 percent, the highest rate for these intermediatematurity securities since the Federal Government began offering them to investors at regular intervals in 1974.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Just A School
description: URBANA, IllinoisWhat are schools for? They are undoubtedly intended to contribute to a child's academic and occupational success. But more than this is at stake in schools: They also help communities to survive. Note the lament, heard often these days: If our school is closed, our community will die.'At least this is the perception of people in small towns and relatively stable city neighborhoods where no other agency serves so effectively as a nucleus.

title: Hearings on L.I. Nuclear Plants
description: Another set of hearings was ordered yesterday to determine whether two proposed nuclear power plants should be built on eastern Long Island in view of reduction in projected electricity demands.

title: Stocks Waver as Dollar And Indicators Weaken
description: Weakness in the dollar abroad and some bearish economic news caused the stock market to end mixed yesterday after four consecutive sessions of advances.

title: Son Depicts Leader of Cult As a Fanatic and Paranoid
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Nov. 21 Jim Jones, the cult leader who died along with 908 of his American followers in a mass suicide rite in the Guyanese jungle, was described by his surviving son today as a fanatic in ill health who had turned paranoid in recent years.

title: Ernst Sued In Merger
description: Former stockholders of L.K. Cornstock & Co. sued E.C. Ernst Inc. in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday in an effort to cancel a merger agreement involving the twc companies.

title: WASHINGTON Thanks For What?
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21  You could hardly notice it from the mood of the nation this Thanksgiving Eve, but even so there are some reasons for giving thanks:

title: Business Reports Getting Costlier
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) Businesses spend more than 69 million hours  and ;1 billion annually filling out reports required by the Federal Government, a Congressional investigatory agency reported today.

title: GRAVES TEAM ON WAY
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Nov. 21Guyanese troops and policemen hunted in the jungle today for up to 500 members of a California cult who were believed to be missing for a third day after more than 400 others joined their leader in a mass suicide Saturday night.

title: Wine Talk
description: THE late French comedian Fernandel had one of the most expressive faces in films. Someone once put together a book of Fernandel photographs, purporting to show him answering questions just with his face. One of the questions was, And what do you think of American champagne? His expression was an unforgettable mixture of pain, disdain and embarrassment such as only a Frenchman could achieve.

title: One Case of Typhoid Discovered Another Suspected in Brooklyn
description: One confirmed case and one suspected case of typhoid fever in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn were reported yesterday by Dr. Reinaldo A. Ferrer,.. the city's Health Commissioner.

title: Economic Scene
description: MILLIONS of Americans who thought they were going to be able to retire at age 65 or earlier can expect to work several years longer as a result of two fundamental national trends. One is the aging of the United States population  a consequence of the slowdown of population growth. The other is inflation, which slashes the value of private pensions and savings.

title: Glorious Game: Coveted Dishes For Late Fall
description: JUST before the game season, a note arrived on my desk from Berton Roueche, a neighbor author, best known for his New Yorker essays, many pertaining to food or medicine. In it, he cluded a quotation from Sydney Smith, a 19thcentury clergyman most often referred to as English writer and wit. On that occasion, Smith had written a friend: Your grouse are come by today's mail, but I suppose they will come tomorrow. Even the rumor of grouse is agreeable. It is lost to history as to whether those birds ever did arrive and, if so, in what condition, but it is convenient at this season to turn Smith's words to my own good purpose and say that even the rumor of game is agreeable.

title: CLEVELAND'S MAYOR ENDS A 5WEEK REST
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 21  Faced with list of prospective troubles ranging from fiscal default to disastrous snowstorms, Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich formally returned to work yesterday, ending a fiveweek absence from City Hall. He had been ordered by his physicians to get some rest because of what was reported to be an ulcer attack.

title: Arafat Accepts U.N. Peace Force If Palestinian State Is Established
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 21  Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, has said that if a Palestinian state could be formed he would agree to the stationing of United Nations peacekeeping troops inside the new nation and on its borders as a reliable security guarantee.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Most large corporations spend millions devising strategies for growth. But Selwyn Cain, president and owner of a $4 million paperbox manufacturing operation, stumbled accidentally upon a good blueprint for expansion.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: The New York Times/Teresa Zabala
description: MUSIC FOR THE HOLIDAYS: Robert C. Byrd, Senate majority leader, presenting President Carter with autographed album in the Oval Office yesterday. The Senator, who doubles as a bluegrass fiddler, advised the President to tell Amy. who is studying violin. to stick to classical music..

title: The SoulWarmer For Frosty Days
description: ALL the vases are full. The mistress keeps kasha in them, a housemaid explains to a flowerbearing visitor in Isaac Bashevis Singer's latest novel, Shosha.

title: Food Stamp Curb Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP)Family wage earners who quit their jobs without good cause would not be eligible for Government food stamps for two months under a proposal announced today by the Agriculture Department. The proposal will be open for public comment until Dec. 21. Comments may be sent to Nancy Snyder, Food and Nutrition Service, Agriculture Department, Washington, D.C. 20250.

title: Music: Willy Joe Shaver

title: TaxFree Note Rates Hold Level
description: Interest rates on taxexempt notes guaranteed by the Federal Government held steady yesterday in a sale of shortterm securities to finance urbanrenewal projects.

title: Social Security Agency Sought Investigation of Cult in Guyana
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21  Twice within the past year the Social Security Administration asked the State Department to determine whether Americans at the Jonestown jungle commune in Guyana were being forced to turn their Social Security benefits over to the People's Temple, Social Security officials disclosed tonight.

title: Third Botulism Case Confirmed
description: DENVER, Nov. 21 (AP)  A hospitalized 30-year-old man is the third person to be confirmed as suffering from botulism after eating at a restaurant near Denver, the Colorado Department of Health reports. Two other cases have been con- firmed by the National Center for Disease Control in Atlanta and tests are under way to determine if a fourth suspected case, that of a 27-year-old man, also involves the deadly form of food poisoning. A department spokesmansaid all four, none of whom were identified, are in stable condition at hospitals in Denver and Longmont.

title: November 22
description: The New Frontier: for the first time in a generation Washington became a magnet for the young. Adlai Stevenson had brought intellectual respectability to politics. Now John Kennedy brought energy as well, and young people were drawn to it. They spent week- ends driving TR3's or tossing the old football around; and long work weeks wrestling with persistent problems whose solution, they were sure, required only dedication. They soon came to make jokes about their vigah, but still gave the sense that the most intractable problem would yield if only ten smart people would get together around a table and stay up all night. For a time, the entire country shared such confidence.

title: Danny Ruvolo, 22, in Car Crash; Danced in Chorus Line,
description: Danny Ruvolo, who was a dancer for 17 of his 22 years and who was to have made his movie debut in Bob Fosse's All That Jazz, was killed Friday in an automobile accident on the Grand Central Parkway. His family home was in East Rockaway. L. I.

title: Advertising
description: A Play On Names By Subaru

title: As I Was Saying a While Back
description: The frank yet graceful use of I distinguishes a good writer from a bad column, Ambrose Bierce wrote. The latter carries it with the manner of a thief trying to cloak his loot.

title: Walter J. McGraw 2d; A Writer and Director Of Programs for Radio
description: Walter John McGraw 2d, a writer, director and producer best known for his work in radio, died Saturday at New York Hospital. Mr. McGraw was 59 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Topics Pols Apart
description: We take our intellectual progress where we find it. When Khrushchev toppled Stalin, he contributed to the lore of tyranny the admirable theory that one man's necessary brutality inevitably turns into everyman's intolerable nightmare. No one would ever again be given Stalin's powers of life and death for the simple reason that the other leaders of the Soviet Union preferred to sleep soundly.

title: U.S. Striving to Keep Mideast Talks Alive
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 The United States sought today to keep the EgyptianIsraeli peace talks alive after the Israeli Cabinet's rejection of a key Egyptian proposal for linking the projected peace treaty to a timetable for solving the Palestinian problems.

title: Six U.S. Senators, in Bucharest, Meet With High Rumanian Aides
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 21 (UPI)  A group of six United States senators led by Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, met today with high officials of the Rumanian Foreign Ministry and the Ministry of Foreign Trade.

title: Iran Reported as Neutral On OPEC OilPrice Rise
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 21  Iran, by tradition one of the most aggressive producers in seeking oilprice nses, has decided not to play a ieading role in next month's pricesetting by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, according to American officials.

title: ...to Love (and Cook) Kasha
description: Although buckwheat groats can be boiled in water with salt, with or without a lump of butter, they develop very little flavor this way. It is far better to follow the method described on the Wolff's box, a standard preparation similar to making a pilaf or risotto.

title: MILLARD E. HOOKER
description: Millard E. Hooker, director of business planning for the RCA Corporation's Hertz Division, died yesterday at the Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center. He was 53 years old and lived in Scotch Plains, N.J.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: PRICK UP YOUR EARS: The Biography of Joe Orton. By John Lahr. 302 pages. Illustrated. Knopf. $15.

title: John Curry's kedancing
description: JOHN CURRY is a fabulous ice skater who looks and moves like a dancer. Everybody should see him, and now they can-at the Felt Forum, where a show called John Curry's Icedancing opened last night for a run through Dec. 3.

title: JobRelated Injuries Rise Slightly Despite Safety and Health Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 The number of jobrelated injuries andillnesses suffered by American workers was virtually unchanged in 1977, the Labor Department reported today, despite steppedup Federal efforts to protect worker safety and health.

title: The Stakes in Atlantic City
description: No one promised that legalized gambling would make Atlantic City a rose garden, but New Jersey might have aimed higher than a bad copy of Las Vegas. There are serious problems of relocating the poor and elderly, compounded by realestate speculation and political hustling. Last on the list of nubile concerns the kind of city the new gold rush will produce. Bad enough that there are no standards, oversight or review to control planning, design and construction. Worse still is an abdication of responsiblity by state authorities whose job it is to hold the line.

title: New Article in Peking Paper Is Seen as Attack on Leaders
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 21 A new article calling for steps to prevent the emergence of a Khrushchev in China has added further ominous overtones to the growing political debate in Peking.

title: Guitar: Yepes Plays Sor
description: rERNANDO SOR was referred to in his time as the Beethoven of the guitar and the Racine of the guitar. A 20thcentury writer has downgraded the guitaristcomposer-teacher-theoretician who was a contemporary of Schubert and Beethoven to the Czerny of the guitar. The latter epithet may have gone too far  Sor's music remains in the repertory of every respectable classical guitarist, which is not true of Czerny and today's piano recitalists. But it is also fair to say that Sor's music is long on charm and short on depth.

title: Technology
description: DON'T look now, but another gold rush may be on the way. With gold selling around $200 an ounce, the combination of new techniques and portable mining equipment is starting to make previously uneconomical gold deposits attractive to both small groups of miners and large mining companies alike.

title: C.I.A. Memo Author Honored For His Crafty Use of Language
description: The Doublespeak Award for 1978, which is intended to memorialize duplicitous language, even lies, will be granted tomorrow to the author of Central Intelligence Agency memorandum entitled AgencyAcademic Relations.

title: Best Buys
description: THE 1979 forecast for consumers remains bleak. While it has already been reported that nationally, food costs are expected to rise a full 10 percent in 1978, the local picture is even more grim.

title: Holiday Messages by Phone
description: NEWARK, Nov. 21 (UPI)  Starting tomorrow, New Jersey youngsters can place telephone calls to Mr. and Mrs. Santa Claus and hear recorded Christmas stories. The New Jersey Bell Tele- pnone Company provides the recordings. charging 10 cents a call to 9363636, which will have 38 separate messages between now and Christmas Day. There will also be an eightday program on Hanukkah: The Festival of Lights starting Dec. 24; that number is 9367373.

title: Suffolk County Is Suing Lilco Over Smoke Emissions
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Nov. 21The Suffolk County District Attorney filed criminal charges against the Long Island Lighting Company today, accusing it of having allowed heavy smoke to pour from its Northport generating plant, the most modern in its system.

title: French Threaten to Delay TradeLiberalizing Pact
description: BRUSSELS, Nov.21  France threatened tonight to block other Western European nations from concluding a new tradeliberalizing agreement with the United States until the incoming Congress gives President Carter authority next year to suspend punitive import duties now threatening some $400 million worth of European exports to America.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, NOV. 21, 1978

title: No F.T.C. Study for LTV Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21  The five members of the Federal Trade Commission rebuffed today a request by Senator Edward M. Kennedy that the commission investigate a proposed industrial merger that has been approved by Attorney General Griffin B. Bell.

title: North Carolinians Buy First Legal Drinks Since 08
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Nov. 21 (AP)A 23-year-old waiter sipped a $1.50 Bloody Mary at a restaurant this morning, apparently becoming the first person to buy a mixed drink legally in North Carolina in 70 years.

title: Associated Press
description: Officer Herbert Lazewski of Buffalo police giving mouth-to-mouth resusitation to three-year-old child overcome in an apartment fire on Monday. All forts to revive the child after firefighters brought him from blaze failed.

title: Quebec Business Flight Ebbs
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 21  Two yeats after the provincial election of the nationalist Parti Queebeeois, much of the early panic has died down among businessmen fearful of Quebec's separation from Canada. But a strong air of caution and concern remains here.

title: CARTER TAX VALUES DOUBLED IN GEORGIA
description: AMERICUS, Ga., Nov. 21  Local tax officials have more than doubled their original appraised value of improvements made in 1975 and 1976 to President Carter's peanut business, resulting in $3,556.23 in additional property taxes and penalties, which the Carter family has agreed to pay.

title: Emptied Niagara Neighborhood Now Looks Like a Disaster Area
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Nov. 19Fourteen weeks after the Love Canal neighborhood was declared a disaster area it has finally begun to look like one.

title: Boy, 15, Draws Up to 10 Years In Slaying Case
description: The first juvenile offender in New York State to be convicted and sentenced as an adult was ordered to prison yesterday for three and onethird to 10 years, following his plea of guilty to a charge of manslaughter in the killing of his uncle. As youthful offender the defendant, I5year old Barry Jones, would have faced a maximum of 18 months in custody.

title: Early Retirement Trend Holding
description: Inflation, together with the abolition of mandatory retirement at the age of 65, may cause some older Americans to remain in their jobs next year. But there is no sign of an immediate social revolution or a reversal in the current strong trend to earlier retirement.

title: Real Estate
description: AS George Klein tells it, he was walking on Park Avenue one morning last year, took a look at the turn-of-the-century property on the southeast corner of 59th Street and decided then and there to find out whether the site could be purchased for an office building.

title: When Adults Are Turkeys
description: The Macy's Parade

title: It's Beginning to Look a Lot Like Christmas
description: Although there's barely a chill in the air, and nary a frost on the ground, signs are abounding in New York that the holidays are really coming. In Rockefeller Center, above, Bill Abbate had hands full trimming the largest tree around. And in a cluded warehouse across the Hudson, left, Santa's reindeer were being spruced for Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade. The Salvation Army sounded a tuneful Christmas Kettle Kickoff in concert with Bronx Citadel Corps Junior Songsters.

title: Emery Succeeds To Duryea's Job As Albany Chief
description: ALBANY, Nov. 21  James L. Emery of Geneseo was named today to succeed Perry B. Duryea as the Assembly's minority leader, snatching the post from Dominick L. DiCarlo of Brooklyn, who was the frontrunner and is currently dpnuty minority leader.

title: Big Milk Coop Is Recapitalized
description: Dairylea, the Northeast's largest farm-to-consumer milk cooperative, has successfully completed a major recapitalization that has put $20 million of members' equity into the organization. Clyde E. Rutherford, Dairylea's president announced yesterday.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Is Charged By Assembly Committee
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 21  A Parliamentary committee charged former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today with contempt of Parliament and a serious breach of privilege as a result of her efforts to protect the business interests of her son while she was in power.

title: U.N. Asks Americans Not to Give Traffic Tickets to Its Delegates
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 21 The United Nations has asked United States authorities not to issue traffic summonses to delegates and other diplomats accredited to the world body, but it also urged the diplomats to obey traffic laws.

title: Reds Conclude Tour
description: HAMAMATSU, Japan, Nov. 21 (AP)  The Cincinnati Reds concluded their 17game exhibition tour of Japan by scoring their 12th straight victory, a 32 triumph today over the Yomiuri Giants. The Reds had 14 victories, two losses and one tie on the tour, after George Foster knocked in what proved to be the winning run in the sixth inning of the final game. Tom Hume recorded his fifth victory of the tour.

title: The Gospel of Beauty, According to Lola
description: Just in time to rouge the cheeks of pallid winter, to set the bosoms of sober feminists heaving with righteous ire, to tweak the vanity of duplicitous swains, and to set most people choking with laughter, The Ecco Press of 1 West 30th Street has issued a rare volume.

title: New York State Lists 20 Old Dumps Filled With Perilous Wastes
description: New York State has listed 20 sites that are of major concern because of hazardous waste dumped into the ground in the past. Of the sites, all of which are upstate, 10 are in Niagara County, including the Love Canal disaster area.

title: St. Francis Tops Lions in Soccer Final
description: When the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer berths were awarded two weeks ago, St. Francis College of Brooklyn was told to be thankful for having received the last bid in the fourteam New York regional tournament.

title: Avon Plans to Take Over Tiffany for $104 Million
description: Cosmetics Concern Seeking to Diversify

title: G.M. Chief Optimistic On Sales
description: Thomas A. Murphy, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, said yesterday that a cut in the company's yearend dividend had been misinterpreted by Wall Street as a sign that we lack confidence in the sales outlook for the automotive industry. The dividend announcement on Nov. 6 was followed by a sharp drop in the stock market the next day.

title: Nonsmokers Try To Clear the Air
description: ALOS ANGELES businessman asked the airline agent to give him a seat as far as possible from the smoking sections because smoke makes me cough. woman asked the headwaiter at an elegant New York restaurant to please tell the gentlemen at the next table to put out their cigarettes or move to a different table. The smoke, she said, irritated her eyes and throat and was ruining her dinner.

title: When You're All Alone on Thanksgiving
description: Thanksgiving, this most American of public holidays is not about food at all, but about spending a day in the company of others. Among the many recipes for food then, we offer here a recipe, meaning a prescription or remedy, for spending The Day alone.

title: Knicks Rolling On; Nets Routed, 140118
description: The only thing the Knicks 'shot was the breeze in the first half of their game with the Detroit Pistons last night at Maeison Square Garden. They scored only 32 points, the lowest firsthalf total in the National Basketball Association this season.

title: U.S. to Get LowSulfur Chinese Oil
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 21  The Coastal States Gas Corporation announced here today that it had signed an agreement to become the first United States oil company to import crude oil from China since the Communist regime came to power.

title: Cult Chief's Beginnings In Indianapolis Recalled
description: NYACK, N.Y., Nov. 21 As a young churchman in Indianapolis the Rev. Jim Jones was an obviously intelligent, eager, concerned person of great initiative who lived simply, organized soup kitchens and nursing homes, and helped minorities, a former church leader recalled today.

title: Less CarDealer Optimism
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI) Newcar dealers profit expectations for the next year continued to decline for the second quarterly survey period, the National Automobile Dealers Association reported today. The N.A.D.A. index of dealerprofit expectations, measured last month, was 90  or 18 points lower than in July. The index was 6 points below the October 1977 index, which was the lowest level in more than two years. N.A.D.A. said the decline in optimism most likely resulted from fear that newcar sales would be down in 1979 because of a slowing economy and tight money.

title: Q&A
description: Q. You have said that you do not ap prove of preparing salad dressing containing chopped garlic in advance because in a short while, a day or so later, the garlic does not taste fresh. Would you sanction keeping chopped garlic in the refrigerator for a day or longer?

title: Colorado Trial Reflects Antinuclear Drive
description: GOLDEN, COLO., Nov. 21 A curious trial here, conducted so far without a jury, focuses attention on the growing and increasingly successful antinuclear movement in this country.

title: Japanese Airline Is Struck
description: TOKYO, Nov. 21 (Reuters)  Japanese flight attendants grounded more than 100 flights today and threatened more walkouts if Japan Air Lines does not end the sleeper service introduced on long-distance flights five months ago. Men pas- sengers are sometimes partly undressed when drinks are delivered, complained one woman attendant, adding, At other times I. must face intimate couples in bed. The attendants also argue that wouldbe hijackers might use the bunks to prepare for attacks.

title: Film: 'Same Time':Trysting Annually
description: THERE'S a big stumbling block in Bernard Slade's play "Same Time, Next Year," and the movie version trips and goes flying. What keeps these two lovers  who meet accidentally in a romantic little inn and then keep on meeting there, one night annually, for 20-odd years  eternally interested in each other? How do they manage to stay so gaga and still live peacefully with their spouses? How do they forget each other so conveniently when each anniversary tryst is over? At the best, this premise is full of terribly sad implications for the characters and their everyday lives. At worst, it stops an audience dead by calling constant attention to the play's falseness.If "Same Time. Next Year," which opens today at Cinema I, were a success as a comedy, this patently phony pretext wouldn't necessarily hurt; indeed; its very outlandishness might become part of the joke. But Mr. Slade's screenplay isn't often funny, and it's full of momentous events that can't be laughed away.During the half-dozen encounters that make up the story, there are a birth, some deaths, two guilty consciences and countless marital problems to be contended with. For instance, when we see them in 1966, George (Alan Alda) is a straitlaced businessman, and Doris (Ellen Burstyn) a very premature hippie. They have begun to have a domestic quarrel about Barry Goldwater when George blurts out that his son was killed in Vietnam; this is supposed to both melt Doris (it does) and explain the drastic change in George. It's hard to say which is more noxious, Mr. Slade's wringing a cheap tear out of his audience or his burdening a cardboard character with real grief.As directed by Robert Mulligan, who has careened about 180 degrees away from his last film, the screamy and high-strung "Bloodbrothers," "Same Time, Next Year" is both less and more than it could have been. By moving the action outdoors once in a while, or into the inn's restaurant, Mr. Mulligan loses the element of claustrophobia that might have taken an audience's mind off the screenplay's troubles. But he substitutes the serenity of a California coastal setting, and gives the film a visual glamour that is mercifully distracting. Mr. Mulligan seems to have been more interested in sprucing up the material than in preserving its absolute integrity, and under the circumstances, his approach makes sense.What sells "Same Time, Next Year" on stage, and what keeps the movie halfway afloat, is the chance it gives George and Doris to change with the times. Not much happens to George, relatively speaking. He evolves from young Lothario to stodgy executive to know-it-all analysand, and always stays something of a straight man to Doris. She, on the other hand, changes from ingenue to sexpot to pregnant frump to successful businesswoman with a logic that has more to do with costuming than with character. These shifts have such slight bearing on one another that the story becomes little more than a series of blackout sketches. But the scenes' very incongruity is funnier than any one episode is individually, and clearly the actors have a lot to play with.Mr. Alda isn't terribly playful, and he reads every line as if it were part of a joke, which only accentuates the flatness of the script. Miss Burstyn, on the other hand, is the eternal coquette, even when  in the latter part of the film  she begins looking like Betty Ford. Her gestures vary absolutely from scene to scene, yet she brings so much sweetness to Doris's various incarnations that the character very nearly comes to life. Miss Burstyn never tries to make sense of the role, and she often undercuts what little sense there is; her 24-year-old Doris, for instance, is so demure it's impossible to believe she ever succumbed to George's charms in the first place. But she gives the role a warmth and grace that become quite an adequate substitute for reason."Same Time, Next Year" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested") thanks to the intimations of tawdriness in the characters' annual hotel-room reunions.

title: Bride:
description: DENVER, Nov. 21  For the second time in three days at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals, one of New York's quintet of women world champions collected maior title here last night Monday.

title: Explaining the Mass Suicides: Fanaticism and Fear
description: Psychological experts stressed two main themes yesterday in trying to explain the mass suicide in Guyana.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: ONE of the most convenient and often quoted remarks about food is lzaak Walton's borrowed line about strawberries: Doubtless God could have made a better berry, but doubtless God never did. it is a line that can often be turned to one's own use, and that is the way I feel about fresh scallops while still in season. Doubtless nature could have made a better bivalve, but doubtless nature never did.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: OMAHA, Nov. 21(AP)  ConAgra Inc. took its battle with Cargill Inc. for control of a Kansas beef packer to court today, asking a Federal District Court judge to block Cargills takeover offer for the MBPXL Corporation.

title: Cult Doctor, Tied to Poisonings, Had Been Dedicated to the Poor
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 21  Dr. Lawrence Schacht, the physician and former Houston resident who reportedly prepared and served the cyanidelaced punch with which hundreds of members of the People's Temple killed themselves, was described by associates today as an intense and dedicated young man with an impressive concern for the poor.

title: Iranian Army Operating Power Plant After Strike
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 21 (AP)  The army took over operation of the Shahryar power station west of here today after a walkout by 2,000 workers. In Teheran, troops fired at demonstrators opposed to the Shah yesterday, killing one person and wounding 20.

title: Notes on People
description: Judge at 63 Swearing In Looks Back in Candor

title: Castro Says His Regime Plans To Free 3,000 Political Prisoners
description: HAVANA, Wednesday, Nov. 22 (Reuters)  President Fidel Castro of Cuba announced today that his Government would free some 3,000 political prisoners  about 80 per cent of those remaining on the island.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yeaterday's Weather at 1 P.M. Notional Ciciania and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

description: HE has been reading Wrinkles, a new novel by Charles Simmons in which a man with no name remembers the past, breaks the fingers of the present, and imagines the future in paragraph after paragraph of prose so lim-

title: The Region
description: WHITE PLAINS  A new head of Westchester County's problemridden CETA (Comprehensive Employment and Training Act) program was announced by County Executive Alfred B. DelBello. He is Louis W. Jones 3d, the county's equal employment opportunity coordinator.

description: Korchnoi Bounces Back, Rising to New Heights

title: United Press International
description: AMBUSH IN SAN ANTONIO: Police in Alamo Heights, Tex., examining bullet holes In car belonging to James Kerr, 38, an assistant U.S. Attorney. Mr. Kerr said two men wearing black gloves fired at his car with a shotgun and rifle but missed him. The veteran prosecutor has most recently been involved in a case involving cocaine smuggling from South America.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: THE fashionable peasants have gone back to the Russian steppes and look what's playing now: a retrospective of Hollywood in the 90's and Lili Marlene waiting under the street lama. Obvi- ously, if you're going to paint your mouth wine red and teeter on skyhigh sandals, you'll need to be hatted, befurred and blinding with glitter. Out of the avalanche of fashion bits and pieces, we've garnered some of the things you must have if you're to be in the fashion stream.

title: Rams Sign Contracts With Anaheim
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Nov. 21 (AP)The Los Angeles Rams owner, Carroll Rosenbloom, and Anaheim city officials signed contracts today that assured the move of the National Football League team to Anaheim Stadium in 1980.

title: Leading British Lawyer Linked To Thorpe Case by Former M.P.
description: LONDON. Nov. 21  Another prominent name was linked today with_the dramatic case of Jeremy Thorpe., the former Liberal Party leader whornas been charged with conspiracy and incitement. to murder.

title: TV.
description: LONG a guest and frequently a substitute host, most notably for Johnny Carson, Steve Martin stars in his own television special tonight  A Wild and Crazy Guy on NBC at 10 o'clock.

title: Market Place
description: LAST summer, the Southern Pacific Company began acquiring shares of Seaboard Coast Line Industries with the idea of eventually acquiring the railroad.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Cairo, Cairo, Cairo
description: There is a multifaceted struggle between President Anwar alSadat and his Arab rivals. The one we hear of the most is over the issue of war and peace with Israel. Two others are deeper. cultural struggles: One is a struggle for and over Cairo itself --- the last real city in the Arab world; the other is between cosmopolitan Cairo's interpretation of the world and the more fundamentalist, sheltered outlooks of Arab deserts and provincial towns.

title: Wilmington Teachers End Strike With Approval of ThreeYear Pact
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 21  A fiveweekold strike by public school teachers here, a side effect of the introduction this fall of one of the most ambitious desegregation plans in the nation, ended this afternoon with approval of the threeyear contract.

title: A Noble Steed's Son Draws Ignoble Price
description: Three summers ago, if his owners had decided to put him into the Saratoga Yearling Sales, he could have brought $500,000. Maybe even a million.

title: MSI Data Settlement
description: The NISI Data Corporation said it would distribute to its shareholders all 300,000 shares of the common stock of the Western Digital Corporation it recently received in settlement of a damage claim against Western Digital. The Western Digital stock will be distributed on a pro rata basis between Jan. 1 and March 31, the company said.

title: A Survivor Who Hid In a Treetop All Night Tells of the Shootings
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov 21  Last Saturday James Cobb Jr.'s two sisters were pulled away from him as they walked through the streets of Jonestown, Guyana

title: Connors Defeats Austin
description: KOBE, Japan, Nov. 21 (AP)Jimmy Connors, the United States Open champion, beat a fellow American, John Austin, 61, 60, today in $125,000 international tennis tournament. Connors will meet the victor of tomorrow's firstround game between Ken Rosewall of Australia and Pat Dupre of the United States in the semifina lc in Tnkvo Saturday.

title: Parents and Children and the Debts of Love
description: GOD forbid, in the current view, that parents should make claims on children. To understand the bill of goods in the terms it is now being merchandised, children are not liable to parents for moral and emotional debts. There are no debts, period. No one owes anyone anytning  tor the new view is egalitarian on this score, too: obligation and expectations had better not be traveling either direction. And mostly they don't any more.

title: Robinson Scores 51
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 21  The pinpoint accuracy of Leonard (Truck) Robinson and his careerhigh 51 points enabled the ailing New Orleans Jazz to crush a faltering New Jersey Nets team, 140118, tonight before 6,177 spectators in the cavernous Superdome.

title: Price Increase By OPEC Seen
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 21 (AP)  The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will approve a prudent increase in oil prices when it meets next month in Abu Dhabi, according to President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela.

title: Battery Project Is Resumed As U.S.Approval Is Awaited
description: After a 17month halt because of severe financial problems, work has resumed on Battery Park City, the $1.5 billion new town of apartment and office buildings envisioned for the Hudson River shore of lower Manhattan.

title: Deputy Chief of Police Convicted in Baltimore
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 21 (AP)  Lieut. Col. James H. Watkins, the city's suspended deputy police chief, was convicted today of malfeasance and nonfeasance in connection with an investigation of drug trafficking in the city.

title: Yankees to Announce Signing Of John, Star Southpaw, Today
description: For the second time in three years, pitcher who beat the Yankees in the first game of the World Series is about to defect to them. The Yankees have scheduled a news conference for 11 A.M. today at which they will announce the signing of Tommy John.

title: Social Worker Robbed And Killed Client, 68, An Indictment Asserts
description: A 29-year-old social worker has been indicted on charges of murdering his 68yearold client after persuading her to withdraw her life savings of $13,000 from a bank, Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, announced yesterday.

title: GREAT LAKES PACT TO BE SIGNED TODAY
description: The United States and Canada are to make yet another effort today to speed the lagging cleanup of the Great Lakes, which has been under way, at least on paper, for more than half a century.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: ON a Saturday evening, writes Stella Hershag, a young couple got on a Fifth Avenue bus, unaware that the fare after P.M. was half, The man dropped four quarters in the bus before the driver could stop him.

title: The New York Times
description: Children from St. Joseph's school gathered around artist's rendering of home for families of children who being treated for cancer. St. Joseph's, the former owner of the house, helped raise money for the renovation.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 22, 1978

title: Phone Rate Differential Assailed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21  The Federal Communications Commission today ordered the American Telephone and Telegraph Company either to justify its policy of offering longdistance service to big corporations at lower rates than to other customers or to eliminate the differential.

title: The City
description: The Department of Parks and Recreation yesterday granted a West Side synagogue permission to build a 13foot Hanukkah menorah on park property despite the recommendation of a community planning board that the application be denied on churchstate grounds.

title: Jets Place Todd On Injured List
description: Richard Todd's season ended officially yesterday when he was taken off the roster of the Jets to make room for another player.

title: Project Still Accepting Applications for Rental
description: Although 3,800 applications have received for the 1,639 apartments in the first six Battery Park City buildings (three more apartments would be for staff), officials say more applications are welcome. Based on experience, the project expects to rent one apartment for each four applications received, an official said.

title: John D. Roche, Who Was Creator Of Landmark Hollywood Sign, 82
description: HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 21 (UPI) Nearly one week after the new Hollywood sign was unveiled, the creator of the old landmark died. John D. Roche, an advertising executive died Friday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 82 years old.

title: Manhattan Police Initiate Central Booking System
description: The young man looked dazed, as if the lights had suddenly been turned on while he was asleep. Dozens of police officers and civilian police employees  men and women who had seen hundreds of arrests  were looking at him as if he were the first defendant they had ever Seen.

title: Postal Service Is Beginning Tests Of Electronic Mail Transmission
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP)  The Postal Service said today that it was beginning to test transmission of mail by electronic impulses and satellites and that such a system could be in use as soon as three years from now.

title: EuropeChina Trade Booming
description: GENEVA, Nov. 21  China has become much the most dynamic market for Western Europe's exports over the last year, according to a staff study of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

title: TollFree Calls On Inflation End
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 21 (UPI)  Beginning today, Government information about President Carter's antiinflation program will no longer be free of telephone charges.

title: Campbell Shv About His Feats
description: Earl Campbell's tremendous per formance in Houston's 3530 victory over Miami in the Astrodome Monday night brought the gifted rookie from Texas close to some records he says are of no interest to him.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Trading in precious metals was extremely hesitant yesterday as the market awaited the results of the Treasury's auction of 750,000 ounces of gold bullion. Well after the close, the Treasury announced that the average price realized was $199.05 an ounce, or only 25 cents below the second and final bullion fixing in London.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the crossword puzzle of Nov. 11, the clue for 12 across was Late U.S. poet, and the answer, published Nov. 13, was Shapiro. The American poet Karl Shapiro is alive and well, in Davis, Calif

title: Koch Is Seeking Lynaugh Ouster From City Post
description: Mayor Koch asked Joseph T. Lynaugh yesterday to resign his $65,000-a-year post as president of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, the $1 billion semiautonomous city agency that manages the city's 18 municipal hospitals

title: Workfare Order In City in Jersey Voided by Court
description: TRENTON, Nov. 21  This city's socalled workfare program, under which ablebodied adults were required to work in return for welfare grants, was ruled illegal today in State Superior Court.

title: Republic Steel Raises Dividend
description: The Republic Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it was raising its quarterly dividend from 40 cents to 45 cents a share. It also declared a special dividend of 55 cents a share.

title: Letters Extolling Jones Typify Common Washington Practice
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21  I don't remember anything about him. He was lust a person.

title: Tunisian Leader Will Visit U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP)  Prime Minister Hedi Nouira of Tunisia will visit the United States starting Nov. 29 to confer with President Carter and senior officials, the White House announced today.

title: Effects of Soviet Rays Discounted
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 21  Abnormally high white blood cell counts in people who have served in the American Embassy here have nothing to do with microwave radiation that has been beamed at the building for 18 years, according to a study by a consultant for the State Department.

title: Merrill Unit in Acquisition
description: A definitive agreement has been reached for the acquisition by a subsidiary of Merrill Lynch & Company of certain subsidiaries of the Huntoon Paige Holding Corporation, a mortgage banking firm, for $15 million. The subsidiaries to be acquired are the United First Mortgage Corporation of San Diego and Huntoon Paige Associates of New York.
