description: Morning

title: Corporate Earnings Reported
description: For periods as shown. (N) mdi Cates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) overthe counter.

title: Tests Widened on Water Found Tainted in Canton
description: CANTON, Conn., Nov. 21  Health officials today expanded watersampling efforts aimed at learning how many residents and workers hero have been affected by drinking water contaminated with industrial chemicals known to cause cancer in animals.

title: 24c Inverted Stamp Bought for $100,000
description: The $100,000 sale of a 24cent inverted airmail stamp at auction at Sotheby Parke Bernet has set a world record for the sale of a United States postage stamp, according to a spokesman for the auction house.

title: Stage: Marshall and Miss Stapleton in Gin Game
description: WHEN Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy brought The Gin Game to New York a year ago, their work was so supple and gleaming, full of such mounting ferocity, that it was difficult to disentangle the play from the performance.

title: Cowboys Close Door To Their Locker Room
description: DALLAS, Nov. 21 (AP) The Dallas Cowboys announced today a new postgame interview policy, which permanently..closes the their locker room to press representatives  a first in the National Football League  because of the womanreporter issue.

title: DEATHS
description: BASSELLMax. The Chaplin A.D. GoodeBen Goldman Ledge, Bnai Brith, sorrowfully announces the recent death of one of our founding members who passed away on Oct. 4, 1978 at the age of 95 In Ft. Leuderdale, Fla.

title: 7 Dead in British Mine Accident
description: DONCASTER, England, Nov. 21 (AP)  Part of a train carrying miners to the surface of a coal pit derailed half a mile underground early today, killing 7 men and injuring 19. A spokesman for the National Coal Board said about 70 men from the night shift were riding the train when the last two of the four cars derailed. was the first major British mining accident since 1973.

title: Music: Big Band Songs
description: THE Salute to Great American Song Writers series at the Atrium of the Citicorp Center, which was inspired by Alec Wilder's book American Popular Song, has, in its 14th week, finally gotten around to Mr. Wilder himself as song writer to be saluted. However, the program that Mary Mayo is giving in the Atrium through tomorrow from 6 to 8 P.M. is concerned as much with Mr. Wilder's book and the many song writers discussed in it as it is with Mr Wilder.

title: Met Sings Luisa Miller
description: IT IS impossible not to feel affection for an opera in which the villain, a particularly slithery character, is named Wurm. But that is not all that can be said for Verdi's Luisa Miller, which the Metro- politan opera nrougnt DaCK IMO ITS repertory Monday night for the first time since the 197172 season. One of the lesser, but not uninteresting operas of Verdi's middle period, Luisa Miller never quite works on the composer's highest level, which seems to baffle and disturb sometime operagoers. And yet it can provide an absorbing experience to anyone who listens with an inner ear tuned to Verdi's earlier and subsequent work.

title: Short Interest on Big Board Falls 1.8 Million Shares
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest fell 1.8 million shares to 39.5 million shares in the month ended Nov. 15. The short interest for the yearearlier level totaled 33.3 million shares.

title: Bache Group's Net Up to $5.4 Million for Quarter
description: The Bache Group Inc., parent of the brokerage and investmentbanking firm of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields, announced yesterday that its earnings fair the firct ficral nuarter ended Oct. ;IL were $5.4 million, or 74 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $1.6 million in the comparable period of 1977. Revenues rose 65 percent to $109.8 million from $66.4 million.

title: THEODORE KAUFMAN
description: Theodore Kaufman, who had headed the Park Row News Service in Manhattan since he founded it in 1926 until his retirement last April, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 78 years old.

title: The New Yort Times/John Soromaroc
description: A Slice of Life in East Harlem:

title: Massachusetts Is Now Finding a Bit of Mystery in Its New Governor
description: BOSTON, Nov. 21  What sort of Gov. ernorthe voters elected here earlier this month is something of a deepening mystery as Edward J. King's transition team begins the work of transforming a political upheaval into a government.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: SOMETHING INDEED On a recent night of pelting rain, with pedestrians scarce on midtown streets, the Cafe Reginette and its new house musician, Jorge Rios, were a delightful surprise. Even on a dry evening, it would he hard to find a more relaxing and compactly beautiful cocktail and dining lounge with music to match among the newer East Side soots.

title: F.B.I. Is Investigating Jones Plot, Using Statute on Assassinations
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 21  The Justice Department has opened an investigation of whether there was a conspiracy to murder Representative Leo Ryan of California a department spokesman said today.

title: A Correction
description: In The Living Section last week, the eighth step was inadvertently omitted from the recipe for roast turkey:

title: People in Sports .
description: Path Shriver:the 16-year-old schoolgirl who reached the final of the United States Open tennis championship in September, was one of four athletes designated rookies of the year by Tennis and Golf Digest magazines. The others were JoseLuis Clerc of Argentina, who reached the final of five grandprix tennis tournaments; Pat McGowan, who won $47,091 in his first year on the PGA Tour, and Janet Anderson, winner of $11,959 on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour.

title: Industry Official Sees A Compromise Drug Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21  A bill that would make major changes in the regu lation of drugs, which became stallec in the legislative process in the outgoing Congress, may be enacted in re vised form next year, C. Joseph Stetler president of the Pharmaceutical Manu facturers Association, said today.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: International

title: Carey Expected To Name 2 Soon To M.A.C. Posts
description: George D. Gould, president of the Madison Fund, will be named chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, and Marilyn F. Friedman, a 33-year-old lawyer, will become executive director as the corporation moves into its new phase as overseer of New York City's fouryear financing plan.

title: Judge Gets Chase SexBias Pact
description: A $1.8 million settlement of a sex-discrimination suit against the Chase Manhattan Bank was submitted yesterday for court approval.

title: Newark Policemen, Facing Layoffs In Financial Crisis, Appeal to Fear
description: NEWARK, Nov. 21 Policemen facing layoffs on Jan. 1 handed out flyers to passersby today, warning them to leave. the city before dark, to keep their car doors locked and if attacked, scream loud!

title: SearsQuarterly Net 4.5% Higher Despite &les Dip
description: Sears, Roebuck & Co. net income rose 4.5 percent in the third fiscal quarter despite a 1.9 percent dip in sales and a sharp rise in interest costs and other expendituies, the world's largest retailer of general merchandise reported vesterday.

title: Making a Deal With the Truckers
description: President Carter's winter offensive against inflation is aimed largely at winning labor's moderation in upcoming wage contracts, especially in trucking. And this poses a dilemma for the Administration: Gaining the cooperation of the Teamsters may require scrapping plans to make the trucking industry more competitive through deregulation.

title: SmallBusiness Agency Head Concedes Minority Aid Program Is Abused
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21  A. Vernon Weaver, the head of the Small Business Administration, conceded at a Senate hearing today that his agency's program to aid minorities was abused and badly managed. But he defended the program as a cornerstone in the Carter Administration's efforts to support and expand minority business and vowed to end abuses.

title: From Russia, With BBC
description: ALONGFORGOTTEN footnote to the history of the Soviet cinema provides the basis for Thank You Comrades, a BBC production that will be shown from 9 to 10 tonight on Channel 13. In 1918, shortly after watching Charlie Chaplin film in which the tophatted Mack Swain was once again tripped up by the Little Tramp, Lenin, we are told, declared, All the arts are important to us, but the most important is the cinema.

title: Ruth M. White Dies; Former Stage Actress Was Writer's Widow
description: A funeral service was held yesterday in Saranac Lake, N. Y., for Ruth Morris White, a writer, former actress and the widow of William Chapman White, author and a columnist for The New York Herald Tribune in the 1950's. Mrs. White died last Thursday at the Longevity Center of Florida in Bal Harbour at the age of 76.

title: 80 Million Saw TV Pearl
description: Pearl, an extended made-for-television movie that unfolded over three successive evenings on ABCTV last week, scored the highest audiencepopularity ratings of the season for a limitedrun series, averaging 45 percent of the audience for the entire MX hours of the telecast.

title: CHARLES H. LIPSETT
description: Charles H. I.ipsett, a retired publisher of industrial and trade journals, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. lie was 95 years old. Mr. Lipsctt was head of the Atlas Publishing Company of New York, now defunct.

title: Europeans See Steadier Dollar
description: LONDON, Nov. 21 European bankers, including even the hard-to-please Swiss, seem to have concluded that will be quite a while before they can again buy dollars as cheaply as in the last few days of October.

title: Around the Nation
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa, Nov. 21 (AP)The Democrats, for now, retain control of the Pennsylvania House following an official recount in a deadlocked race that had tied the House's political balance.

title: Islanders Romp, 71; Trottier: 3
description: DENVER, Nov. 21 (AP)  Bryan Trottier scored a threegoal hat trick, including two goals in the first period, as the New York Islanders muted Colorado, 71, in a National Hockey League game tonight.

title: NADER GROUP URGES U.S. BAN ON DARVON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21  The Health Research Group asked the Federal Government today either to ban the pain-killing drag Darvon or to limit its sales on the ground that its flagrant abuse was killing more than 1,000 Americans yearly and in some areas causing more deaths than heroin and morphine did.

title: 3d Quarter Had 7.1% Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP)  The inflation rate stood at 7.1 percent while the economy continued to grow moderately in the third quarter, according to revised figures released by the Government said today.

title: Coast Tests Variable Mortgages
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 21  The variablerate home mortgage where the homeowner's monthly payment rises or falls with current interest ntles is takine root in California.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 21 (UPI)  The Gold Glove Award winners for 1978 include two members of the New York Yankees and four Philadelphia Phihies.

title: ISRAELIS BACK PACT AS PROPOSED BY U.S, REJECT A TIMETABLE
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 21  The Israeli Cabinet gave nearly unanimous approval today to a United Statessponsored draft for a peace treaty between Israel and Egypt, but it rejected Egypt's demands that a treaty be linked to a timetable for Palestinian autonomy on the West Bank of the Jordan and in the Gaza Strip.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: CameronBrown Investment Group, a Raleigh, N.C.based real estate investment trust, has named Robert Stiller managing trustee. Mr. Stiller replaces W.J. Smith Jr., who was also president and who resigned last week. There will be no president, the company reported.

title: EARNINGS Macy's Earnings Up 9.4% To FirstQuarter Record
description: In line with the higher profits of most other departmentstore chains in the October quarter, R.H. Macy & Company reported yesterday a 9.4 percent increase in net income for its first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 28.

title: World News Briefs
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Nov. 21 (Reuters)  Costa Rica has broken diplomatic relations with Nicaragua, President Rodrigo Carazo Odio announced tonight, shortly after both countries reported casualties in a border clash.

title: Film: 'Movie Movie' Satirizes 30's Styles:Hollywood Flimflam
description: "THESE hands," says Joey Popchik, the delivery boy who wants to become a lawyer, "are for reading books." But fate and the Great American Depression interfere. Joey's kid sister, Angie, is going blind. "It's okay, Joey." Angie says, "I've seen a lot already. I'll remember."The only way Angie can be cured is to go to Vienna for an operation that will cost $25,000, which comes to approximately $12,500 an eye, as one observer carefully calculates. Where to get the money? Joey must put aside his books and become a prizefighter. Thus begins the event-crammed, dopily heroic plot of "Dynamite Hands," the first half of Stanley Donen's sweet, hilarious, very witty recollection of the sort of movie programs that came off the Hollywood assembly lines in the 1930's.In addition to "Dynamite Hands," "Movie Movie" includes a breathless trailer for a movie about World War I flying aces, "Zero Hour," "war at its best!" and, as the top feature on the program, "Baxter's Beauties of 1933," a full-color  "Dynamite Hands" is in black-and white  triumphantly nutty backstage musical that Warner Baxter, Ruby Keeler, Dick Powell and Ginger Rogers might well have made. Instead, we have the great good fortune to have George C. Scott, Trish Van Devere, Art Carney, Red Buttons, Eli Wallach, Barry Bostwick and Rebecca York. These actors, many of whom also appear in "Dynamite Hands," represent one of the happiest poolings of resources since Balaban met Katz."Movie Movie," opening today at the Sutton Theater, was written by Larry Gelbart, who was responsible for "Sly Fox," Mr. Scott's most recent Broadway hit, and Sheldon Keller. It seems so effortlessly funny that I suspect that the real intelligence and discipline that guide the project will be overlooked.Mr. Gelbart and Mr. Keller not only appreciate the comic uses of the mixed metaphor  one that is driven into the ground to the bursting point  but, more importantly, they have recreated the efficiency and manic, upbeat innocence of those Depression pictures. This has to do with more than screen styles  wacky montages and attention-getting wipes and fades, which anyone can imitate.The movie's spirits are high even when its eyes are filled with tears. The film makers genuinely like their models. When Joey Popchik says, "How do you get two cents back on a heart," after he realizes he's been played for a sucker by a hardboiled nightclub singer, the writers are recollecting movie manners to which we still respond. People in 30's movies never talked quite this fruitily so consistently. The point is that this is the way we enjoy remembering them, to remind us, perhaps wrongly, that we've grown up.Mr. Donen's production is his most buoyant film since "Singin" in the Rain," and goes a long way toward erasing the memory of things like "Lucky Lady," "The Little Prince" and "Staircase." For the most part, the timing is as precisely right as in one of those rare Broadway musicals in which everything works perfectly. Nothing is held too long. When we anticipate a gag, it is funnier simply because we do anticipate it, and then it is frequently topped.The performers are marvelous. Mr. Bostwick (of Broadway's "The Robber Bridegroom") is a standout as the mild-mannered bookkeeper who, in the nick of time, turns out to be a singer, dancer and composer of hit songs in "Baxter's Beauties." Miss York is most comically earnest in the Ruby Keeler role in the same film, with terrific support from Barbara Harris, who plays the Ginger Rogers-Glenda Farrell part.The newcomers who light up "Dynamite Hands" include Harry Hamlin, in the William Holden-John Garfield role; Ann Reinking as "Troubles" Moran, the nightclub singer with the rhinestone heart, and Kathleen Beller, as the poor girl with the mysterious eyesight problems. Messrs. Carney, Wallach and Buttons show up in each film, as well as in the "Zero Hour" trailer. They appear to have had a picnic, which they share.Mr. Scott and Miss Van Devere are superb in both "Dynamite Hands" and "Baxter's Beauties." In the first, she is Joey Popchik's bespectacled librarian-sweetheart, only temporarily eclipsed by the acquisitive "Troubles" Moran, and in the second, she's the big Broadway actress whose drinking problem allows the chorus girl to become an overnight star. It's high praise to say Miss Van Devere is as funny and appealing as she was in "Where's Poppa?"Mr. Scott is such a powerful actor that it's always a surprise he can be so wickedly funny when he puts his mind to it. It's more than a physical transformation, which anyone can accomplish with a bit of makeup. There's a change in his center of gravity. As "Gloves" Malloy, the trainer who grooms Joey Popchik for the title bout, he is a model for all slightly too colorful, unbearably wise and sentimental old character actors. In "Baxter's Beauties" he is the grandly stylish "Spats" Baxter, the legendary Broadway producer whose only real problem is that he has been struck down by something called Spencer's Disease, another mysterious ailment without many symptoms, but which seems to strike people in show business quite regularly. All of which is why "Spats" has to get his last show on in a hurry and make sure that it's a hit.The appearance of "Movie Movie" at this point in a dreary season restores my confidence in the joys to be had from Hollywood flimflamming at its elegant best."Movie Movie," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains a couple of benignly funny double entendres that are probably out of the reach of any child who could be shocked by them.

title: Police to Donate Raise To Aid 5 Killed by Gas
description: RUSH SPRINGS, Okla., Nov. 21 (AP)  After getting the raises they had sought for a long time, this town's three police officers have decided to donate the first month's increase to stricken family.

title: Careers
description: WHEN businessmen talk to college undergraduates, all too often they speak in highflown generalizations about their companies wanting to hire only graduates with top academic records, bubbling with enthusiasm, endowed with highest integrity and devoted to the profit motive.

title: Events Today
description: Films

title: Manhattanite Gets 25Year Term For Murder and Dismemberment
description: CATSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 21 (AP)Dominic Grimaldi, 23 years old, of Manhattan was sentenced to a maximum term of 25 years to life in prison today for the murder a year ago of a 17-year-old New York City resident.

title: Racing Owners Threatening To Drop USAC
description: The men who own the cars that turn Indianapolis into the world capital of speed every Memorial Day weekend are threatening to leave the United StatesAuto Club, which sanctions the Indianapolis 500 and the other races in the series, to hold their own events in 1979. However, both sides were hopeful of a settlement before racing resumes in March.

title: Sadat Recalling Chief Negotiator In Apparent Show of Displeasure
description: CAIRO, Nov. 21  Egypt announced today that it was recalling its chief negotiator from Washington in an apparent expression of displeasure over Israel's refusal to incorporate a timetable for Palestinian selfrule into an Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty.

title: Cult Massacre Books Rushed
description: Bantam Books and Berkley Books are rushing original paperbacks into print on the People's Temple Cult and the massacre in Guyana. Both New York publishers expect their books to hit the racks on Dec. 3.

title: G.O.P. Still Hopes to Control Pennsylvania House
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 22  Shortly before midnight last election night, Nov. 7, the Democratic State Representative from this area learned that he had received 8,551 votes in his attempt to win third twoyear term. At the same time,

title: Goodrich Cuts Stake In Japanese Concern
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company announced it had reduced its interest in the Yokohama Rubber Company to just under 20 percent from 24.6 percent, for a net gain of about 11.6 million. The company said it had sold that interest to Japanese investors. Yokohama makes tires, industrial rubber and aeronautical products.

title: Backgammon:
description: Barclay Cooke, a veteran of 30 years of competition over the backgammon board, has long been considered one of the world's best players. With his enthusiasm, he has done much  to enhance the stature of the game and has always endeavored to keep it on a high level. In addition to his playing, he is also known to the backgammon world as a teacher and a writer.

title: Prosecutor, Criticized on Book Contract, Withdraws From Girl Scout Slayings Case
description: PRYOR, Okla., Nov. 22  The chief prosecutor in the case of Gene Leroy Hart, who is charged in the murders of three Girl Scouts last year, withdrew from the case today, citing physical and mental pressures placed on him by Mr. Hart's lawyers.

title: Assise Presc
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy at the grave of President John F. Kennedy at Arlington National Cemetery yesterday. The President was assassinated 15 years ago Wednesday, in Dallas.

title: Women's Leaders Cancel Meeting With President
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22  A group of women's leaders canceled a scheduled meeting today with President Carter, protesting that the 15minute period he had alloted them was insufficient for the discussion they had in mind.

title: The Art Of Receiving Your Guests
description: REALLY, you know, not everyone is terrified. Just because you curl up in the fetal position at the thought of 12 people for dinner  let alone 20; while the notion of 40 sends you to the floor  believe it or not, there are oeonle who actually like to entertain.

description: BEFORE he mailed the invitations for his Christmas party. Larry Nicks decided that there should be music in the air. So he called the Manhattan School of Music and hired a trio of student instrumentalists.

title: PRESIDENT CRITICIZES INTELLIGENCE EFFORT ON CRISIS PREDICTION
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22  President Carter, in a handwritten memorandum to his top advisers on national security, has complained about the ability of the Administration's intelligence branches to forecast foreign political developments, such as the recent turmoil in Iran.

title: U.S. Shoe Sales And Profits Up
description: The U. S. Shoe Corporation, manufacturers, importers, and retailers of footwear, reported yesterday increases of 32.8 percent in profits and 17 percent in sales for the first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 28.

title: Executive Disclosure Is Widened
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22  The Securities and Exchange Commission ruled today that more top corporate executives must disclose how much they are paid in salaries and perquisites.

title: Nets Awarded Protest In Nov. 8 Loss to 76ers
description: Larry O'Brien, the National Basketball Association commissioner, yesterday upheld the New Jersey Nets protest of their Nov. 8 double overtime loss to Philadelphia in which Bernard King and Kevin Loughery, the Nets coach, were assessed three technical fouls each.

description: STEPHANIE JUTT, a flutist who appeared Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, is certainly keeping busy. Aside from appearing with various orchestras, including the New York City Opera orchestra in Washington and the New York Philharmonic, sne mane ner sow New York debut last year and will give another solo recital in February at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A.

title: Moon's Church Files Suit Against Regents, Charging Charter Bias
description: Charging that their constitutional and civil rights had been violated, members of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Theological Church have brought a $28 million damage suit against the New York State Board of Regents for having denied a provisional charter to the church's Dutchess County seminary.

title: Midwest Republicans Survey Gains and See Better Times
description: KNOXVILLE, Iowa, Nov. 20 Marvin Gilliland stood in his shirtsleeves in the window of an empty corner store on Knoxville's city square, cheerfully scrubbing away the amateurish drawings of sassylooking elephants that had adorned the first Republican campaign headquarters established here in recent memory.

title: Religious Revival Is Sweeping Across the World of Islam
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 22  In Iran, 2,500-year-old monarchy, backed by the most powerful military force in Central Asia and a surfeit of oil riches, is staggered by a loosely organized, unarmed opposition led by conservative Islamic clergymen.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: WELDON H. STEINER COLUMBIA, Mo., Nov. 22 (UPI) Weldon H. Steiner, publisher and owner of The Vandalia Leader and president of the Missouri Press Association, died last night at Boone County Hospital. He was 55 years old. He was district secretary to Representative William L. Hungate, Democrat of Missouri, from 1964 until Mr. Hungate's retirement in 1977.

title: ExPoliceman Seized With Dynamite Sticks On an East Side Roof
description: A dismissed New York City police officer was arrested yesterday on charges of possession of explosives and incendia ry material.

Mr. Feldman has not exactly conformed to the Northeast academic musical orthodoxy in the course of his compositional career; he's been a bit too Cageian and intuitively experimental for that.

description: MEMPHIS, Nov. 22  In the credit house where he researches his conspiracy theories on the assassinations of the 1960's, Mark Lane was spinning out another conspiracy scenario today  that the People's Temple mass suicide in Guyana was the first step of a master plan that, Jinancea wan a Ltu million secret fund, could bring even more murders of American public officials and defectors from the cult founded by the Rev. Jim Jones.

title: Tigers

description: IT is unusual to run across a pairing of first recordings of works by great composers of the past, but here they are on this disk. Wagner's Das Liebesmahl der Apostel is a relatively early one, whereas Bruckner's Helgoland is the last work he completed.

title: Borden Monopoly Found
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission ruled today that Borden Inc. had unlawfully maintained monopoly power in the processed lemon juice market. But the commission stopped short of letting competitors use the company's ReaLemon name.

title: New York Shortchanged on U.S. Aid, Rep. Green Says
description: New York City is faring poorly in corn peting for Federal money under the $40( million Urban Development Action Grani program, Representative S. William Green said yesterday. Mr. Green, the city's only Republican Representative blamed the Carter Administration foi shortchanging the city.

title: Norwalk Trying A Bus Network At a Fiscal Loss
description: NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 22  I'm dying to try this, said Mary Callahan as she climbed aboard a bus in Norwalk for the first time in 15 years.

title: Books of The Times
description: PHILIP RAHV was quite right in leaving out most of his political essays from his three collections of criticism. These essays weren't very good, and he probably knew it. They were, of course,

title: Weeden Agrees On Merger
description: Financially troubled Weeden & Company, once the nation's leading thirdmarket securities firm, and Moseley, Hallgarten & Estabrook, an oldline, profitable, Bostonbased brokerage and investment banking concern, announced an agreement yesterday to merge. The announcement marks Weeden's second effort to associate with another securities corporation in three months.

title: Trial Shift Asked in Option Case
description: BOSTON, Nov. 22 (AP)  Alan Abrahams, who is accused of using commodity options to swindle investors of millions of dollars, asked a Federal judge today to move his trial to Texas.

title: Defecting Iranian Critic Is Now Target
description: LONDON, Nov. 22 In less than three weeks in London, Siamak Zand, a 37yearold Iranian, has attracted a lot of attention for a man previously unknown (wen to many specialists on his country.

title: Fire Damages Insurance Office
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 (UPI)  Offices of the Reliance Insurance Company were extensively damaged early today when fire swept through the 15th floor of a 22story downtown office building.

title: SADAT TELLS CARTER TALKS WILL CONTINUE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22  President Anwar elSadat assured the United States today that Egypt would continue peace talks with Israel. The assurance came after Israel's rejection of an Egyptian demand that a peace treaty be linked to timetable for solving the Palestinian issue.

title: The City
description: Mayor Meets Briefly With Hospitals Chief

title: Sound
description: IDO NOT normally devote much space to the discussion of specific products except to illustrate general design principle or report a significant innovation.. But in the case of speakers, I decided to bypass this rule, because the character of speaker cannot be adequately described in terms of its technical specifications. Only discursive comment, necessarily personal, can convey something of the speaker's sonic personality and give you some inkling as to whether you might be interested in hearing a particular model yourself.

title: Dance: Pennsylvania Ballet Presents `Coppelia
description: THE Pennsylvania Ballet has wished us a very merry Coppelia this holiday season. This year, its regular fall season at the Brookyn Academy of Music turns out to be a full week, through Sunday afternoon, of ballet's best known comedy classic.

title: Turkey: Engineered Product
description: The turkey that graces your table today is as different from the bird your grandfather brought home as a Ford compact is from a Model T.

title: Ballroom: New Face
description: ADOMI DE CESARE, a Ht darkhaired woman who ha., appeared in Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway productions of Charles Ludlam's Ridiculous Thea. for, at El Coyote, the Public Theater and the Theater for the New City, is making a tentative and uncertain entry into cabaret this week at the Ballroom.

title: GARDENING
description: ALONG time ago I had a spider plant that absolutely refused to send out those long, dangling runners full of new little plants that one always sees on the plants at someone else's house. I tried everything: changing the light, fertilizing, misting three times a day, talking to it. Nothing worked. I had one large, evergrowing, recalcitrant, runnerless spider plant.

title: Markets Closed
description: All stock exchanges, banks, commodity markets and most businesses in the United States are closed today for Thanksgiving Day. Tomorrow will be a normal business day for stock exchanges. banks and all commodity markets except for the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, which will be closed for the day for renovation work. Many businesses are also expected to be closed.

title: Castro Would Free 3,000
description: HAVANA, Nov. 22 (Reuters)  President Fidel Castro of Cuba, who announced early today that his Government would free some 3,000 political prisoners, stipulated that the United States would have to accept those prisoners who wanted to so there.

title: Tiffany's Stock Rises 163/4 Points
description: Walter Hoving, the 81year old chairman of Tiffany & Company, was in an obviously jubilant mood yesterday, savoring the merger package he had sprung on Wall Street the day before and watching his stock almost double in price.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Simpsons to Fight Hudson's Bay Bid
description: TORONTO, Nov. 22  Simpsons Ltd., the nationwide department store chain, indicated here today that would fight an attempted takeover by the Hudsen's Ray Comeany.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday incorrectly characterized the importance of residential mortgages to the commercial banking industry. Residential mortgage loans constitute a relatively inconsequential part of the overall business of commercial banks.

title: Hers
description: Abigail McCarthy

title: ESSAY Adm. Turner's Failures
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22  In a handwritten note dated Nov. 11 to Cy, Zbig and Stan, President Carter wrote: I am dissatisfied with the quality of political intelligence. The President icily directed Secretary of State Cy Vance, National Security Ad- viser Zbigniew Brzezinski and Direc- tor of Central Intelligence Stansfield Turner to correct the situation.

title: U.S. PLEDGES EFFORT TO SPEED THE ENTRY OF CUBAN PRISONERS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22  The United States promised today to try to speed the process for admitting Cubans after President Fidel Castro announced his intention to let thousands of political prisoners leave the country.

title: Schuss Time to Hit the Slopes
description: Because subfreezing weather in recent days has enabled some snowmaking machines to work round the clock, 10 ski areas will be open today.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Theater

title: ETHNIC GROUPS SPLIT ON SOCIAL QUESTIONS
description: Blacks and Hispanics, two cohesive voting groups, heavily supported Demo cratic candidates in this month's Congressional elections and also shared traditionally liberal positions on economic issues. But the two groups disagreed sharply on some social issues.

title: Blenheim Rotunda Study Is Sought
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 22  The National Trust for Historic Preservation offered today to pay up to $10,000 to help finance an independent study of the economic feasiblity of preserving the historic Blenheim Hotel rotunda and making it part of a new casino hotel complex.

title: The Region
description: NEWARK (UPI)  Lucille Puryear, former head of the United Community Corporation of Newark, New Jersey's largest antipoverty agency, was convicted of having accepted $.33,000 in cash payoffs in exchange for awarding Federal contracts.NORTH HAVEN, Conn. (AP)  Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Connecticut filed rate increases and revisions in its Century contract that would total $10 million for 442,550 subscribers. The Century contract assures subscribers of full payment of a participating doctor's charges for covered medicalsurgical services.HARRIMAN, N.Y. (AP)  The Palisades Interstate Park's hiking trails, closed since Nov. 3 because of fire danger caused by dry weather, were reoponed. Nash Castro, the park's general manager, said that recent precipitation had lessened the danger and that prospects for further precipitation look very promising.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 23, 1978

title: 36 Debutantes Bow at Plaza
description: Thirtysix young women of college age, all provisional members of the Junior League of New York Inc., were honored last night at the league's 30th annual ball at the Plaza Hotel. The women were presented to Mrs. E. Ward Smith, the league's president, and to Mrs. James O'Neil, chairman of the ball committee. Proceeds will benefit the league's community service trust fund,

title: Iranian Parliament Backs Regime; 3 Hurt in Clash in Teheran Bazaar
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 22  The military Government received an expected strong vote of confidence in Parliament today while the Shah's opponents mounted their pressure on him to resign.

title: Francis Lauro, 60, a. Broker, Dies
description: Francis G. Laura, a stockbroker with a distinguished flying record in World War II, died Tuesday in Mercy Hospital, Rockville Centre, L.I., after a long illness. He was 60 years old and a partner in the Wall Street brokerage concern of Phelan, Silver, Vesce, Barry & Company.

title: Temple U. Appoints Dean
description: PHILADELPHIA. Nov. 22 (AP) Temple University has announced the appointment of George W. Wheeler, 53 years old, as dean of its College of Liberal Arts. He is now dean of the division of natural and social sciences at Lehman College of the City University of New York. He will assume his new duties at Temple in February.

title: INVESTIGATORS SEIZE TAPES AT SYNANON
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 22  District Attorney John Van de Kamp announced today that investigators from his office, in a raid on a remote ranch of the Synanon oreanization 150 miles north of Los

title: Rose Cites Big Offer
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 22 (UPI)  Pete Rose, arriving home today from a monthlong tour of Japan with the Cincinnati Reds, said virtually all 12 teams that had diafted him as a free agent had shown great interest in signing him. He said the Atlanta Braves owner, Ted Turner, had offered him a tremendous contract.

title: Jones Used BibleThumping And Politics of Brotherhood
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22  The middleaged black woman always wore plain dark suit and a small hat and she used to stand, day in and day out, month after month, on one of the main streets here soliciting funds for the People's Temple.

title: Doctor Searches Jonestown for His Mother
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Nov. 22 Most days, Robert C. Lowery is a surgery resident at Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn. Today he is a son in search of his mother. He is believed to be the

title: MixedMarriage Gains Are Found
description: Tolerance among Americans for interracial and interfaith marriages has substantially increased over the last decade, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Ballet: Joffrey Performs Arpino's Kettantanz
description: GERALD ARPINO'S ballets are not to everyone's taste. A recent pelting of the stage with candy during an Arpino ballet could serve, perhaps, as the most succinct of critical comments among the naysavers. The fact remains, however, that the Joffrey Ballet's resident choreographer is a man for all seasons who can be depended upon to produce regularly and to entertain, neither of which is a small teat.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Abbott Laboratories, Chicago, has named Thomas R. Hodgson a division vice president and general manager of the hospital products division, replacing Daniel E. Gill, who resigned.

title: Few Schools Use U.S. Breakfast Plan, Study Finds
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22  Eight mil lion American schoolchildren begin classes hungry or poorly fed each morning, according to a study issued today, despite a 12-year-old federally subsidized program that offers nutritrional breakfasts to any public or nonprofit school at little or no cost.

title: Has Forced Evolution Improved the Turkey? It's a Question of Taste
description: The broadbreasted turkeys that will grace untold millions of dinner tables today are direct descendants of the wild turkeys the Indians contributed to the Pilgrims in Plymouth. Mass., on the first Thanksgiving Day in 1623.

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL

title: Former Oakland Aide Admits Embezzlement
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 22 (AP) The former manpower director of Oakland, Juan Lopez, pleaded guilty today to charges of embezzling more than $30,000 in public funds by falsifying records and forging a former employee's signature. Mr. Lopez, who was ar-

title: I.T.T. Unit Wins Contract
description: A $1.3 million contract to supply a public telephone exchange for the city of Leningrad was announced yesterday by a Finnish subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: Pressure Builds Against Airline Planning Move
description: Appeals to boycott American Airlines  some serious and some facetious continued to be voiced yesterday by New Yorkers who were miffed over the airline's decision to move its corporate headquarters from Manhattan to the DallasFort Worth Airport.

title: Mime Unit in False Promises
description: THE San Francisco Mime Troupe, America's longestrunning and most outspoken political theater, is back in New York for the first time in four years, for a week's engagement at the Entermedia Theater. Once again, this company is baring its anger, animosity and rollicking sense of humor.

title: Help for the Wilmington 10
description: The Justice Department's entry into the Wilming- ton 10 case gives hope for a fair resolution of that tan- gled controversy. The case involves nine black men and one white woman convicted in North Carolina in 1972 on charges of firebombing a store and shooting at policemen during a racial disturbance. The devart- ment's Civil Rights Division is asking to participate in habeas corpus proceedings before a Federal court in Raleigh, on the basis of new evidence which seems to support the defense claim that the trial was unfair.

title: Second Helping to Provide Fans With a 6Hour Feast of Football
description: DENVER (84) at DETROIT (48) Broncos next game is the big one, at Oakland. Defense has been tight lately, 10 points allowed in last two games, as 1977 starters are intact and healthy. Craig Morton has eased quarterback unrest with two strong outings. Lions will pass and pass. Betting line: Denver by 4 points.

title: Coffee for a Crowd
description: HATEVER else may be open to question when you make party arrangements, the One certain fact is that it will all end with coffee  the one for the road that is as much an esthetic windup as it is a safety factor for those who must drive after hours of drinking. And because you want every guest's last impression to be a pleasant one, good coffee is as essential to the party as the right wine and the best foods.

title: Party Pitfall: Who Sits Where?
description: FORGET cleaning the house, forget the guest towels, forget replacing the mushy bar of soap, forget spreading the beauty mud on the wrinkles. Piffling matters, all of them.

title: Doing Everything,
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22  The Carter Administration is doing everything can to help search for missing Americans in the jungle around the Guyana commune, official spokesmen said today, despite a note of skepticism about estimates that hundreds of members might have escaped the mass suicide last weekend.

title: Jazz: Jones, Harrell Band
description: THE latest big band to try to find a foothold in that particularly slippery area of jazz is an llpiece group jointly led by Sam Jones, a bassist, and Tom Harrell, a trumpeter. The band made its debut last June at Gulliver's in West Paterson, N.J., came into New York at the Village Vanguard in September during the newspaper strike, and is now back at the Vanguard playing a series of Monday nights while the Thad JonesMel Lewis Band is out of town.

title: Same Old Invitations? Change the Script
description: SPECIAL parties deserve special invitations, and none are quite as special as those handlettered by a calligrapher. It is like sponsoring your own limited edition of work of art (in more ways than one calligraphy is expensive).

title: Marie McCabe Wed to Professor
description: Marie Hyde McCabe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Wilfred Hyde of Putnam Valley, N.Y., and Donald MacInnis, son of Mrs. Albert Garland MacInnis of New York and the late Mr. MacInnis, were married yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Eugene E. Lau- bach performed the ceremony in the Riverside Church. He was sisted by the Rev. Dr. Edwin O. Kennedy.

title: Threatener Held Incompetent
description: DALLAS, Nov. 22 (UPI)  A Federal judge has ruled that a New York man charged with threatening the life of President Carter in a call to the Federal Bureau of Investigation on Sept. 18 is not

title: Festive Flowers
description: IT wasn't all that long ago that the stylish florists told you that if you didn't put your flowers in baskets, you might as well move to Moose Jaw. And now, would you believe it, those very same florists are telling you that baskets are for waste paper, laundry, the baby, the dog  anything but flowers. Tempus fugit.

title: THOMAS M. BUCKNER
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 22 (AP) Thomas M. Buckner, president and general manager of the Lexington HeraldLeader Company, died today in St. Joseph Hospital, three weeks after suffering a brain hemorrhage. He was 41 years old.

title: Matt Robinson, Boy Next Door, Soothes Jet Family
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 22  Once, it would have been a time for handwringing. The coaches would walk around kicking the dirt and the players would look as if they had lost their best friend.

title: Airline That Pays. Passengers to Fly
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board today approved the ultimate in low, air fares  the airline pays the passenger to fly.

title: Study Sees Higher Prices If Gasoline Controls Go
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 22 (UPI) Energy Department officials said today that a new study shows removal of gasoline price controls, a step the Administration is expected to propose early next year, could drive pump prices up by 3 or 4 cents a gallon.

title: Arabs Buy U.S. Airline Stocks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP)  Abu Dhabi, a small but rich Middle East oil nation, has acquired substantial holdings in United States airlines and an air freight company, a Senate subcommittee disclosed today.

title: Around the Nation
description: Massachusetts Man Guilty In Homosexual Beating

title: Lawyer Says the Leader of Cult Had Lost His Reason
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22  The Rev, Jim Jones was described today as having lost his reason by Charles Garry, one of his lawyers and once one of the strongest supporters of the People's Temple, the cult group led by Mr. Jones.

title: Wedding Camels At the Film Forum
description: AFEW days before the ceremony, the bride is all smiles, but, at the wedding she's a nervous wreck. The women wear much too much jewelry. The bride's mother has worn herself out sewing the bridal outfit and gossiping about what others wore at other weddings, while the father of the bride has kept an eagle eye on the gifts. An aunt has been in charge of the hospitality extended to the new inlaws, and she has plotted this with vengeance. When a hostess wows her guests, the aunt explains, They say, She is good  let us marry her daughter so we'll always be treated like this.

title: Crime Index Drops in New York State
description: The number of serious crimes reported to the police in New York State declined last year, the first such decrease in five years, according to a report released yesterday by the State Division of Criminal Justice Services.

title: Social Security Announces Rise In Pay Ceiling for Retired People
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP)  People who retire before the age of 65 will be able to earn up to $3,480 next year without losing any Social Security benefits. That is an increase of $240 from 1978.

title: U.S. Cites Illinois in Billing for Ineligible Abortions
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP)  Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, accused Illinois today of improperly billing the Federal Government for some 12,600 abortions that were not eligible for Federal financing.

title: Q & A
description: (Q) There is a crack in my living room ceiling that runs almost the entire length; I have cleaned it out and filled it every summer for the last eight or 10 years. I have used both patching plaster and spackling compound, but by the middle of the next heating season the crack returns. I have thought of using a latex caulking. What do you recommend?  W.A.

title: Yanks Sign Tohn for $14 Million
description: When Tommy John was traded by the Chicago White Sox to the Los Angeles Dodgers in 1971, he viewed the move as going from a Chevrolet to a Cadillac. In signing with the Yankees as a free agent yesterday, he said he was going from a Cadillac to a RollsRoyce. The Rolls, however, nearly suffered a flat tire.

title: Durables Orders Up 6.3% in October
description: WASHINGTON Nov. 2' (Al')  Sustained demand for airplanes and ships led to a 6.3 percent increase in orders for durablegoods products in October, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Alaska Issue Yields Up to 7%
description: The Alaska Housing Finance Corporation sold $44 million of upper-mediurngrade, taxexempt bonds yesterday at prices giving investors yields as high as 714 percent. The securities sold quickly.

title: Officials Now Say Notes To Jones May Be Fraud
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22  Searches of office files around Washington have yielded few copies of letters allegedly written to Jim Jones, the cult leader, by prominent public figures, and some officials are starting to wonder whether they were victimized by deception.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: Snurre American PoIrnInum Inslitote

title: Route List Is Revised By C.A.B.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP)  The Civil Aeronautics Board said today that it had made errors in awarding 248 air routes earlier this month. The regulatory agency announced several changes affecting eight airlines.

title: 2Cent Rise in Milk Price Forecast
description: The milk industry says there may be a rise in the price of milk to meet expected increases in labor costs.

title: EGYPT SAYS SETBACK WON'T AFFECT TALKS
description: CAIRO, Nov. 22  As its chief negotiator at the Washington peace talks headed home for consultations, Egypt looked to the United States today to help break the latest deadlock with Israel over guarantees for establishing Palestinian home lute on the occupied West Bank of the Jordan and in the Gaza Strip.

title: PEKING REGION GETS NEW POLITICAL HEAD
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 22  A new chief political commissar has been named for the critical Peking military region, it was disclosed today, in a move that may be related to the growing political debate in China.

title: 5 Serbs Accused Of Plot to Bomb Chicago Offices
description: U.S. Reports Tapes Relate Other Terrorist Acts

title: London Train Engineers Strike
description: London, Nov. 22 (Reuters)  Thousands of London commuters were delayed today by a strike of train engineers resulting from a dispute over bonus payments. The strike, by more than 700 engineers from 10 depots, is the first of series threatened every Wednesday until Christmas.

title: Talking Business with Darby of the F.C.C.
description: WASHINGTON

title: Cut in Jersey SchoolAid Rise Is Voted
description: TRENTON, Nov. 22 The New Jersey Legislature today approved a new formula that will cut a proposed $130 million increase in state aid to public schools by $22 million, with most of the cuts affecting wealthier suburban districts.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP)  The Federal Trade Commission today challenged the merger of the Grand Union Company and Colonial Stores, two major East Coast supermarket chains.

title: S.E.C. Official in Limbo A Center of Controversy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21  John R. Evans does not look like a man in limbo. The only sign of strain in his manner is a blue sheet of paper that he rolls into a circle and then unrolls, repeatedly.

title: Judge Warns Brooke on the Loss Of Properties and Pension Fund; CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 21 (AP) Senator Edward W. Brooke was threatened with the loss of his two remaining properties and his pension fund by a Middlesex Probate Court judge today and was given until Dec. Ito pay taxes on his Caribbean home and transfer the house to his former wife.
description: Judge Lawrence Perera told the Senator's lawyer that if Mr. Brooke did not pay the taxes and transfer the St. Martin home to his former wife, Remigia, by Dec. 1, the court would see that the taxes were paid.

title: For the Holiday: Crafts, Samplers and Myriad Mums
description: More than 175 exhibits of contemporary crafts and sculpture by New England and New Jersey craftsmen will be displayed in booths around the grandstands of the Meadowlands on Sunday.

title: Carey Names Paterson to Replace Cuomo in Post of Secretary of State
description: Governor Carey yesterday named Basil A. Paterson, New York City's Deputy Mayor for Labor Relations and Personnel, to be his new Secretary of State. Mr. Carey said the appointment was part or his commitment to make his an administration where blacks and Hispanics and women and all the wonderful diversity of New York have a place.

title: GOING OUT GUidoer
description: ECHOES With minimal fanfare, a new exhibition at Goethe House commemorating the 100th birthdays of four German writers: Alfred Dublin, Georg Kaiser, Erich Muhsam and Carl Steinheim. The display of letters, manuscripts, photographs and rare first editions is part of the institute's current cycle on German Expressionism. All of the late writers, belonging to the same age group, were direct or indirect victims of Nazi domination in their native land.

title: A 1,600Mile Crawl Fizzles at White House
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP)  A Baptist lay minister who said he had crawled 1,600 miles from Marshall, Tex., to Washington arrived at the White House gates today and was told that President Carter was too busy to see him.

title: Sears Accused on TV Imports
description: A Federal grand jury and various Government agencies are investigating allegations that Sears, Roebuck & Company violated tariff laws while importing television sets from Japan. The allegations include dumping (selling the TV sets in this country at lower prices than in Japan) and falsifying customs declarations.

title: Violence Charged by Both Sides In Rochdale Village Guard Strike
description: A bitter labormanagement confrontation at Rochdale Village in Jamaica, Queens, has inconvenienced the 25,000 residents and brought charges by both sides of acts of violence.

title: Notes on Pimple
description: The Ford Children: Tales Out of School

title: Time in Amber in the Midlands
description: been dealt a third blow by the arbitrary lowering of cattle prices. If allowed to seek a natural level the rising price might yet have let some cattlemen hane on.

title: Bridge:
description: DENVER, Nov. 22  News of the tragic events in Guyana had a special meaning for players at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here, who learned that Louis Gurvich, league president last year, flew to

title: Miss O'Brien Wed To William Corey
description: Elizabeth Sara O'Brien of New York was married yesterday in St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church to William Russell Corey. Msgr. George Lewis Smith performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Navratilova Wins
description: TOKYO, Nov. 22 (UPI)  Martina Navratilova routed Jeanne Evert, 60, 61, today in the first round of a $125,000 tennis tournament. An American, Pat Dupre, defeated Ken Rosewall of Australia, 63, 63, in a firstround men's singles match. In doubles, the American pair of Tracy Austin and Kathy May beat Virginia Ruzici of Rumania and Jeanne Evert, 64, 63.

title: UNESCO Endorses a Compromise That Calls for Free Press Coverage
description: PARIS, Nov. 22  The 146 member nations of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization gave unanimous endorsement today to a compromise declaration on world news coverage that eliminates all mention of government control of the news.

title: U.S. Trade With China Increases As Peking Acts to Lift Economy
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 22  Since the 19thcentury days of the Yankee clipper ships, Americans have dreamed of turning China's millions of people into customers. Their hope has never been realized, blocked by China's poverty, revolution and Mao Tsetung's ideology of selfdevelopment.

title: World Gold
description: WEDNESDAY. NOV. 22, 1978

title: China Shops for a Satellite system in U.S.
description: SMITHTOWN, L.I., Nov 21  The Chinese are in the market for, a domes. tic communications satellite system.

title: About Port Washington
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Nov. 22  The yellow school bus has Vinnie Clifton at the wheel and he steers it gently, as if back through time, watching all the gray heads seated two-bytwo in the rearview mirror and braking

title: Tally Suspending Mannesmann Talks
description: The Tally Corporation, a dataproc, essing concern, said that discussions with Mannesmann AG, a West German industrial concern, which has been trying to gain control of Tally, had been suspended indefinitely.

title: 11% Prime Possible At Citibank
description: While shortterm interest rates declined slightly yesterday, they nevertheless finished the banking week high enough to allow Citibank to raise its prime rate to 111/2 percent tomorrow if it decides to adhere strictly to the for- mula on which it bases that rate. Along with other major banks, it now has an 11 percent prime rate.

title: Protecting Alaska's Crown Jewels
description: A controversy over the future of Alaska's vast wilderness aroused strong emotions this year in and out of Congress. It also led to the utterance of a good deal of nonsense. It did not, regrettably, result in the legislation that is badly needed to end two decades of uncertainty over the allocation of land to competing interests. Such a law would permit the people of Alaska to get full title to land that is rightly theirs and to get on with the job of tapping its wealth. At the same time it would permit Federal guardians to protect those areas in which considerations of scenery, wildlife and recreation outweigh economic values.

title: Furnishing Your Party: Elegant Essentials
description: From a generous platter, to a simple wine glass, to a sturdy folding chair  these classic designs will make entertaining at home go smoothly.

title: Mother, 14, Abandons Child
description: ROCHESTER, Nov. 22 (AP)  Welfare officials have filed a petition of child neglect against a14-year-old girl they say admitted giving birth to a boy, then abandoned him last week. if the petition is granted, the Monroe County Social Serv- ices Department will be given supervision of the child, who is in Genesee Hospital, and will move him to a temporary foster home, said Susan Vinocour, an assistant district attorney.

title: L.I. Shuts 12 More Polluted Wells
description: GLEN COVE. L.I., Nov. 22  Long Island health officials have closed a dozen more wells in community water supply systems so far this year, raising to 98 the total number of wells shut down because of organic chemical pollution.

title: Deak Survives as A Bear
description: Nicholas L. Deak, head of Deak & Company, one of the nation's largest foreignexchange concerns, has survived the Great Depression, economic collapse overseas and the perils of moving money into and out of Nazi Ger- many when he served in the Office of Strategic Services during World War II.

title: U.S. Study Predicts Price Rises if Drugs Are Banned in Animal Feed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP)  An Agriculture Department study released today shows that if the Federal Government banned the use of drugs in feed to make animals grow faster, consumers would see food prices go up 1.2 percent more in the first year.

title: ISRAELI CALLS ACCORD NOT OPEN TO CHANGE
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 22  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan told senior Foreign Ministry officials today that the draft peace treaty Israel approved yesterday was a sealed package that should not be opened for amendment, and that Egypt should take it or leave it.

title: Gaming Stocks Star As Market Edges Up
description: Gambling issues and a handful of special situations including Tiffany & Company led the stock market higher yesterday in slow preholiday trading.

title: The Connecticut Yankees Drop Out of Soccer League
description: Joseph Raymond, president of the American Soccer League, announced yesterday that the Connecticut Yankees franchise has folded due to the current owners inablilitv to meet league obligations and failure to cornply with minimum league operating standards.

title: Women Ears Fellow Officers
description: Alfred Graves brushed nervously at the black gabardine jacket he had been wearing when he was arrested, studied its seams to make sure they had survived a scuffle and adjusted a gray silk scarf that still waved proudly from its breast pocket. He had iust been fingerprinted and now, waiting, he surveyed the bleak, dimly lighted room with indignation.

title: DeerHunter Is Killed
description: JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 22 (AP) Steven N. Johnson, 26 years old, of Bemis Point, was fatally shot yesterday in the back of the head by one of his five deerhunting companions, authorities said. A certificate of accidental death was issued, but authorities said their investigation was continuing.

title: Benefit for Sect Was Planned
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22 About 75 prominent city leaders and politicians recently endorsed a $25-a-plate dinner arranged as a benefit for the People's Temple medical program at the sect's mission in Guyana.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Braths

title: Fee for Information Phone Calls Barred by Agency in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 22  The Connecticut Public Utilities Control Authority narrowly rejected today the phone company's request that it be allowed to charge 20 cents for directory assistance, a service that the telephone company says will cost it $16 million to $32 million in the next five years.

title: Rangers Battle Leafs To 33 Split Decision
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 22 (AP)  Secondperiod goals by Clark Gillies and Gerry Hart, plus the goaltending of Glenn Resch sparked the New York Islanders to a 41 victory over the Minnesota North Stars tonight.

title: Home Improvement
description: Bernard Gladstone

title: Futures Link Explored
description: Four of New York's six commodity futures markets are exploring the feasibility of merging, the exchanges announced yesterdEg. The move came against a backdrop of soaring futures trading, almost daily rumors of merger moves between various exchanges and increasingly covetous glances at the New York commodity trade by the much larger and more aggressive Chicago markets.

title: Seoul Rebuffs Latest Try By U.S. to Curb Imports
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 22 South Korea has refused to accept an American demand for a drastic cut in its shipments of color television sets to the United States, sources close to negotiations on the issue said today.

title: Text of the UNESCO Compromise Declaration on a Free Flow of World News
description: PARIS, Nov. 22  Following is the text of UNESCOs declaration on news organizations as adopted unanimously today by the organization's 20th General Assembly:

title: Unpaid Chicago Parking Tickets May Cost Hertz, Avis $2 Million
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 22  Hertz and Avis will soon receive bills from the city for 200,000 unpaid parking tickets totaling about $2 million dollars.

title: Japan's Folk Art Tradition on Display
description: THE exposure New Yorkers have had to Japanese art and artifacts in recent seasons has focused primarily on the splendors that satisfied imperial taste. The Japanese swords, palace furniture, lavishly decorated screens, scrolls and theater robes, as well as the precious porcelains and utensils devised for the tea ceremony, are among the treasures that have been shown at, for the most part, Japan House Gallery, 333 East 97th Street.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: International

title: Helen Hayes Will Receive Allergy Foundation Award
description: Helen Hayes, who is starting her 73d year as an actress but who had to give up her stage career in 1971 because of an allergy to theater dust, will be honored at the Crystal Globe Award dinner next Tuesday.

title: U.S. Law to Discourage Redlining Termed Too Weak
description: As the New York State Legislature has struggled to a deadlock over ending redlining  the practice by which banks are said to deny mortgage money to decaying urban areas  the Federal Government has put into effect a series of regulations aimed at discouraging the banks from cutting off funds to inner city areas.

title: NEW & USEFUL
description: AnneMarie Schiro

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, NOV. 22, 1978

title: Peace Corps Director Said to Be Resigning
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP)  The Peace Corps director, Carolyn Payton, has decided to resign after 13 months in the oost agency officials said tonight.

title: Rubble and the Dead Mark Invaded Region of Tanzania
description: A small but majestic mission church looks down from a rocky hilltop. Its spire still stands, but the walls and roof have been pulverized by Ugandan artillery fire.

title: Gibson Is Called Deaf to Pleas on Police
description: NEWARK, Nov. 22  Members of the City Council charged today that Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson was determined to lay off 200 policemen on Jan. 1 beause of a budget crisis even if an alternative plan aimed at saving some of the jobs could be found.

title: Lerner Plays the Role Of Savior at Food Fair
description: There is a new leadership, direction and spirit at Food Fair. At least that's what Marvin Lerner, the company's newly appointed senior vice president and chief operating officer, is telling creditors and suppliers. Food Fair, a Philadelphiabased supermarket and discount store chain, has been operating under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act since Oct. 2.

title: ABROAD AT HOME The Human Element
description: BOSTON, Nov. 22  In the summer of 1964 an elderly pacifist, A. J. Muste, began walking for peace from Quebec to Guantanamo. The Johnson White House asked the Justice Department to get an injunction that would keep Muste, when he got to Florida, from boarding a boat for Cuba. The neces- sary authorization letter was presented to Attorney General Robert Kennedy.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Nov. 22 (AP)  The Winnipeg Jets announced today the signing of John Ferguson to a fiveyear contract as vice president and general manager of the World Hockey Association team, effective immediately.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: CLEMENT D. GILE Clement D. Gile, retired vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died Tuesday of cancer at the Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in Harrison, N.Y.

title: Nets Top Warriors By 10092
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Nov. 22  Injuries had shortened the New Jersey Nets bench to eight men, and a midnight flight from New Orleans last night had shortened their sleep. But led by Eric Money and Winford Boynes, the Nets beat the Golden State Warri- ors, 10092, tonight to end their losing streak at three before a crowd of 4,212 at Rutgers Athletic Center.

title: 2 Unusual Choral Works
description: LAST NIGHT in Avery Fisher Hall, Zuhin Mehta gathered unto himself a chorus and addressed himself and the New York Philharmonic to a pair of masterpieces  Schubert's Mass No. 5 in flat and the much shorter Te Deum by Anton Bruckner. Both works were more than welcome, their intrinsic merits aside. We don't normally get this material on symphony programs. There is a theory in some symphony circles that audiences grow restive during long choral works. And, besides, they cost a lot of money to put on: soloists, a chorus ...

title: 200 VIETNAMESE DIE OFF MALAYSIA COAST
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Nov. 22  About 200. refugees from Vietnam drowned today when the fishing boat on which they had escaped capsized after had been towed from the Malaysian shore by the police. More than 50 refugees on board survived.

title: Many Portuguese Report U.F.O.
description: LISBON. Nov. 22 (Reuters)  Portuguese newspapers today published photographs of what they said was an unidentified flying object that had appeared over Lisbon at sunset yesterday. An orange, cigarshaped, luminous object was reported by hundreds of persons in calls to newspapers and radio stations.

title: Letters
description: Function and Form

title: Letters: On Civil Defense
description: Nonsense or Need?

title: Movie Angling for an Accolade
description: T HE DEER HUNTER, Universal's $13million epic about the war in Vietnam, will drop into New York briefly in December  and then disppear for two months.

title: The Magic of a Holiday Party:  How to Pull It Out of the Hat
description: Drawing by Jo Teodorescu

title: Associated Press
description: MISHAP IN TEXAS: People living within a mile radius of Canyon, Tex., were evacuated yesterday after a freight train derailed and two tank cars carrying liquefied gas exploded. No one was hurt; the fire was allowed to burn itself out.

title: Kahn Hopeful On Wage Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) President Carter's chief inflation fighter said today that he hoped to see the first tapering off in the wageprice spiral within nine months.

title: Accents & Images Gets a New Home
description: DESPITE the Les Must de Cartier and Mark Cross boutiques, Christopher McCall and Ron Prybycien insist they have not sold out to Madison Avenue. Their Accents & Images shop, in its sleek new home in a modern apartment building at Second Avenue and 54th Street, is still a neighborhood store, they say, just as much as the old store was in its brownstone at 972 Second Avenue.

title: 'star Wars
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 22  Many of the students who passed Thomas Eaton's eighthgrade reading class at Highlands School last week were puzzled by the activities in Room 109.

title: Brawler Slain in Fight With Police
description: A Brooklyn man's boisterous celebration of his 25th birthday on Tuesday night in midtown Manhattan ended in his death in a fight with two plainclothes policemen.

title: Miss Faircloth Becomes Bride
description: Charlotte P. H. Faircloth and J. Sinclair Armstrong, both of New York, were married yesterday morning. Surrogate Millard L. Midonick performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: A Small Thanks to the Yankees
description: In order of importance on Thanksgiving Day, sports is cranberry sauce. It's nice if you like it. If not, you can enjoy your dinner without it. But for New Yorkers who like sports, it's time to say thanks to the Yankees front office for being what every front office should be  relentless in trying to better its team. Club owners always talk about how they ex- pect their players to give 110 percent, but sometimes those same club owners don't give 50 percent. They're not willing to spend the money or the time it takes to assemble the best possible players, managers and coacnes. But the Yankees are willing, and able. As the Yankees principal owner, George Steinbrenner has put every other sports franchise in New York on the spot to produce a winner. And for that, New York-

title: An Exercise in Puritanism
description: The Pilgrims who gathered 357 years ago at Plymouth, Mass., ate about onethird as much food as most Americans will consume at their Thanksgiving tables today. We wish we could believe that our typical 2,000calorie meal reflects a quantum increase in thankfulness  but with the economy in the doldrums, the Giants near the bottom of the Eastern Conference, and the price of No. 2 fuel oil on the rise again, that is plainly not the case.

title: Cult Operated Radio, Defying Rules of F.C.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov- 22  The People's Temple in San Francisco and its outpost in Guyana have communicated by ham radio in recent years rather than by telephone, provoking conflicts with the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Nevada Bank Stock Offering
description: The Nevada National Bancorporation, a Reno bankholding company with $400 million in assets, raised $10 million of equity capital yesterday by offering an unusual package of two preferred stocks  one convertible and the other with a sinking fund.

title: World News Briefs
description: MINEHEAD, England, Nov. 22 (Reuters)  Peter Bessell, the chief prosecution witness in the murder case against Jeremy Thorpe, the former leader of the Liberal Party, underwent a grueling crossexamination today by the politician's defense lawyer.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Nader Unit Assails Rule Letting Children Harvest Sprayed Crops
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UPI) Ralph Nader's health group charged today that thousands of children might suffer lifelong damage because the Labor Department was allowing them, for the first time ever, to harvest crops sprayed with cancercausing pesticides.

title: Mystery Is Intensifying in Guyana Over Those Who Fled Suicide Rite
description: TIMEHRI AIRPORT, Guyana, Nov. 22  The mystery of how many California cultists survived the mass suicide at their jungle camp increased today as a newly arrived United States military mission said its primary purpose was to recover the bodies of the dead.

title: Home Beat
description: Jane Geniesse

title: Party Hosts Can Rent Everything, Even Dance Floors
description: WNETHER your dinner party or disco dance flies or flops can depend on how well staffed and equipped the party is. In any event, you will certainly flop if you mix the drinks instead of mixing with the guests.

title: Ford Faces Pay Penalty In Britain
description: LONDON, Nov. 22  Accepting an offer more than three times as big as permitted under the Government's wage guidelines, workers at Britain's Ford Motor Company voted today to end their eightweek strike, which has cost $855 million in lost production.

title: The Perfect Guest
description: The socceess of It party, let us never forget, rests not on host alone Who then is the betted guest?

title: City Ballet Offers 4 Abstract Works
description: HOW times have changed. Not long ago, Tuesday night's program by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater might have distressed certain danceeoers.

title: New Yorker: Special Dividend
description: The New Yorker Magazine Inc. yesterday declared a special dividend of $1.75 a share and a regular dividend of 50 cents a share, both payable on Dec. 14.

title: TV: Ustinov Is Starring In The Thief of Baghdad
description: THERE'S still another version of The Thief of Baghdad available in movieland. The one I recall; quite fondly, from childhood featured an actor named Sabu. The new production, made for television and available on NBC tonight at 8 o'clock, stars Peter Ustinov and special effects by John Stears, an awardwinning film designer.

title: 'sarava,
description: Rehearsals have begun for Sarava, a musical adapted from Jorge Amado's novel, Dona Flor and Her Two Husbands. The story was also made into a Brazilian film that was wellreceived here.

title: State Dept. Encourage's Inquiries by Relatives
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UPI) The State Department announced today that it was increasing the size of its task force here to handle the large volume of phone calls from relatives and friends of victims of the events in Jonestown, Guyana.

title: Facelift for a Times Square Landmark
description: The New York Times/ Paul Hosefros

title: WASHINGTON Frank Church And State
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23  In the coming session of the Congressfrom next January through the Presidential election of 1980  the Carter Administration will have to deal with a transformed Senate Foreign Relations Committee on such critical issues as a strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union and some kind of compromise peace settlement in the Middle East.

title: Capital Plans for a New Convention Center
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23  The District of Columbia, already the thirdranked American city in volume of conventiongoers from out of town, has started preparations for a massive new center that is expected to attract hundreds of thousands more pleasurebent delegates and to revitalize one of the last remaining, areas of downtown decay.

title: Egypt Indicts Plane Buyers
description: CAIRO, Nov. 23 (AP)  Two former Egyptian Cabinet ministers and three top airline officials have been indicted in a bribery and negligence case involving the Boeing Company, District Attorney Anwar Sehli said today.

title: Walker's Play Is Pride of Jets
description: With the reinjury of Richard Todd, and only the tattered remains of a season to look forward to, there is little cause for good cheer in the Jets camp this week. One bright spot,however, the performance of Wesley Walker, the secondyear wide receiver.

title: Argentina Paralyzed By Inflation
description: BUENOS AIRES  The Sasetru Group, Argentina's biggest diversified conglomerate, expects to close its books on the 1978 fiscal year with no profit and has ordered a sharp cutback in investment projects now under way.

title: Nei
description: HIS stocking feet waggling on the floor in front of his chair. Richard Gere lolled in his suite in the Sherry Netherland Hotel on Fifth Avenue and said, quite matteroffactly. I could probably do anything I want in the theater now.

title: FRED HARRIS
description: Fred Harris, a theatrical agent, died Wednesday at his apartment on West 57th Street. He was 76 years old.

title: Reeling With Laughter At the Subplot Cabaret
description: The latest something funny in a long line of funnies in the intimate underground room at the American Place Theater, 111 West 46th Street (2470393), where humor with an American flavor has been a weekend staple for several seasons, gets its laugh on film. This is the first cinematic haha in the American Humorists Series. The offering this weekend is an hourand45minute reel of drollery that embraces humor from its most rustic to its most rugged.

title: Huntsville Firemen Back on Job
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Nov. 23 (AP) Union firefighters began returning to work early today, signaling the end of sixday strike by the police and the firefighters. An agreement to end the strike was reached overnight after the City Council approved new proposals on grievance procedures, seniority rules, sick leave, incentive programs and overtime pay. Firefighters began signing duty rosters this morning, officials said, and striking police officers were expected to return to work later in the day.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. on apartheid

title: Cosmos Buy Brazilian
description: RIO DE JANE! RU, Nov. 23 (UPI)  The Cosmos have purchased the top Brazilian left back, Francisco Das Chagas Marinho, from Rio de Janeiro's Fluminense club for $300,000, it was reported here today.

title: Bridge:
description: DENVER, Nov.23  One of the world's greatest pairs held a substantial lead going into the final two sessions of the blue ribbon pair championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here this afternoon.

title: Music: Vasary's Piano Fantasies
description: THE programs of many pianists read as if they had been picked out of a hat, and a shallow hat, at that. But Tamas Vasary put together a recital at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. on Wednesday night that had not only genuine substance, but thematic logic as well. The Hungarian musician built the evening out of four pieces labeled as fantasies and he played them with considerable imagination.

title: The City
description: A dismissed New York City police officer who was arrested Wednesday on charges of possessing explosives and incendiary material was arraigned yesterday at Manhattan night court and then held at Rikers Island in lieu of $75,000 bail.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Down in Europe; Gold Inches Above $201
