description: GREENVILLE, Miss., Nov. 20  It's got so you don't have to be a fool or patriot to run as a Republican, said Clarke Reed, the Republican national committeeman, as he talked with exuberance of victories won and victories yet to come in a state where the oncethriving yellowdog Democrat is all but extinct.

title: Mountain Dew Opens Negro Ensemble Season
description: The Negro Ensemble Company's 12th season will begin Dec. 6 with the production of Nevis Mountain Dew, written by Steve Carter and directed by Horacena J. Taylor. Mr. Carter, director of the company's playwrights workshop, wrote Eden, which was presented by the troupe in 1976.

title: Spain Expects Tourism To Set Record for 1978
description: MADRID, Nov. 22Spain is heading for a record year in tourism that marks the end of a fouryear slump in a vital sector of the economy that generates more foreign exchange earnings than anv other.

title: Penn State Defeats Stubborn Pitt, 1710
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Nov. 24 Penn State managed to retain its ranking as the No. 1 college football team in the nation today and extend its winning streak to 19 straight games when it staged a thrilling fourthquarter rally to beat Pittsburgh. 1710.

title: Stocks Up Despite Rate Rise
description: Stock prices advanced yesterday despite an increase to 11 percent in the prime lending rate, the loftiest level in more than four years, by most major banks. Citibank, the largest commercial bank in New York, set the pace with a halfpoint increase announced just before trading opened on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Advances, Helped By Rise in Prime Rate
description: The dollar rose against foreign currencies in slow trading on the world's foreign exchange markets yesterday, in part on news that most American banks had increased their prime lending rate onehalf point to 11 percent.

title: Japan's Trade Curbs Irk Americans There
description: TOKYO, Nov. 24  The price of the not very large muskmelon at an autumn bargain sale in a store in Tokyo office building was $129. There were other healthylooking melons ranged on the shelf alongside at $112, $97 and $81. They were all roughly the same size.

title: TV: Soviet Union's Unknown War With Germany
description: The RussianGerman War of 194145, waged by two despotisms that cared as little about the lives of their own subjects as they did about those of their enemies, was mankind's bloodiest conflict. It is generally accepted that something like 10 million troops and 20 million civilians perished in it, and that close to 90 percent of them were Russian.

title: OBSERVER
description: Since the 1960's we have come to regard the freak as the characteristic human aberration of our time. Now the macabre events in Guyana raise the question of whether the freak is being replaced by the zombie.

title: Christmas Shopping Season Begins in Earnest
description: The day after Thanksgiving brought its traditional throng of shoppers to the city's department stores yesterday as thousands of gift givers sought to get an early start on their season's purchases. Some, however, chose to use the occasion for inspiration in compiling their lists for Santa.

title: Citibank Report Denies Foreign Tax Violations
description: Citibank denied yesterday that it had violated foreign exchange and tax regulations as a former employee had charged last July.

title: Nets Beat Jazz by 103100
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Nov. 24  The screams, shouts and machinations of Coach Kevin Loughery of the Nets won a game for New Jersey tonight, 103100, from the Neu, Orleans Jazz.

title: Lee Bows in Table Tennis
description: NORRKOPING, Sweden, Nov. 24 (AP)  DalJoon Lee of the United States was eliminated in the men's singles of the Scandinavian open table tennis championships today. Nicky Jarvis of Britain beat Lee, of Columbus, Ohio, 2113, 2117, 1421, 2115, in a firstround match. Lee was the only American player entered.

title: France Sentences 4 Americans Convicted in Hijacking of Airliner
description: PARIS, Nov. 24 (AP)  A group of black Americans was sentenced to prison today by a French judge in an airline hijacking case.

title: RAIL INDUSTRY CUTS FREIGHTRATE RISE AFTER U.S. REQUEST
description: The Association of American Railroads, after two weeks of intensive bargaining with the Council on Wage and Price Stability, said yesterday that the railroad industry would trim its proposed freightrate increase to 7 percent from 8.1 percent to comply with the Administration's price guidelines.

title: More Apartheid, or Less, Is Issue in Transvaal Voting
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 24The governing National Party will meet this weekend to make a decision that could fundamentally affect the future of apartheid  whether it will evolve to. ward greater rights for blacks, or be reinforced in a way that worsens existing racial tensions.

title: Finn Captures Auto Rally
description: LONDON, Nov. 24 (AP)  Hannu Mikkola of Finland was confirmed today as the winner of the LombardRAC auto rally. Mikkola, who led the Ford team to a 1,2,3 sweep in yesterday's event, clinched the series championship with the victory.

title: Refugee Deaths Tied to Ethnic Ire
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Nov. 29  A senior Malaysian official said today that the drowning of about 200 Vietnamese refugees two days ago was an indirect result of the negative, probably antiChinese, feelings aroused on Malaysia's east coast by the dramatically swelling stream of refugees.

title: Letter: On Nicaragua
description: To the Editor: The conclusions of your Nov. 21 editorial (The Nicaraguan Exception) correspond with those reached by an ecumenical delegation of North American church leaders who visited Nicaragua recently.

title: Giants Regain Spirit and Hope to Retain Coach
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 29  The Fumble is irretrievably gone, like the season that could have been, but the Giants have recovered their spirit at least. Now they would like to retain their coach.

title: New York Ethics Unit Saw Wetv Document In BusShelter Inquiry
description: More confusion was added to the controversy over a New York City busshelter contract yesterday with the disclosure that the Board of Ethics had already considered and discounted one of two new documents that led the Commissioner of Investigation to reopen the inquiry this week into the role of a former city official.

title: Conflicting Versions of Iran Army's Clash With Dissidents Illustrate Elusiveness of Truth in Long Crisis
description: SHIRAZ, Iran, Nov. 23A brilliant autumn sun flushed the dunbrown mountain ridges surrounding the city, the wind swayed the raucous whitebacked crows perched on a redleafed maple, and at the foot of the tree a Moslem priest stood before a crowd of somber youths to deliver a funeral oration for one of the antiGovernment demonstrators killed in a confrontation with soldiers on Sunday.

title: 2 Officers Describe Horror of Guyana Death Scene
description: TIMEHRI AIRPORT, Guyana, Nov. 24  I expected it to be bad, the warrant officer was saying. But I've been in Vietnam two years, and I've never seen anything like that. And I hope I never do aeain.

title: COMMODITIES Futures Show Strength In Wheat and Soybeans
description: Futures contracts for wheat and soybeans turned in a strong and active showing yesterday, despite the fact that Thursday was Thanksgiving and many commodity traders and speculators presumably made it a fourday weekend, taking yesterday off.

title: Belgium to Nationalize Ailing Steel Industry
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 24  The Belgian Government, following in France's footsteps, unveiled a plan today to take control of the country's ailing steel industry and slim it to more competitive size at a cost of up to $2 billion and the loss of 15,000 jobs.

title: Your Money
description: WHEN Peter Andrew, a freelance photographer who lives in Bergenfield, N.J., turned 25 the other day, one of the first things he did was telephone the agent who handles his automobile insurance.

title: White House Endorses French Sale Of a Nuclear Power Plant to China
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24  The Carter Administration has approved a request by France to sell an Americandesigned nuclear power plant to China, Government officials said today. They said the approval was contingent on France's obtaining assurances from Peking that the plant would be used for peaceful purnocnc.

title: U.S. Says Incorrect Toll of Dead Reflects a Hasty Police Estimate
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24  The State Department, pressed to account for the abrupt increase in the count of the bodies at the People's Temple commune in Guyana from about 400 to nearly 800, said today that the orginal figure had been only a rough, preliminary estimate by the Guyanese troops and policemen when they first entered the Jonestown area last weekend.

title: $330,000 Awarded in Air Crash
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24 (AP)  The five children of a woman who perished in the crash of a Pan American Airlines jet in Pago Pago four years ago have been awarded damages of $330,000. The damage award. to the Children of Barbara Giles came Tuesday after a twoday trial and one month after four survivors of the crash were awarded $400,000.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a report in The Times on Nov. 19, Attorney General Griffin B. Bell was quoted as saying that he intended to examine each case of former Cuban political prisoners seeking entry into this country to prevent admission of Communists, terrorists, and criminals. A Justice Department spokesman said later that Mr. sell had acutally said that his scrutiny was intended to exclude spies, terrorists and common criminals.

title: Bride to Open Met's Radio Season
description: A new production of Smetana's The Bartered Bride, with Teresa Stratas, Nicolai Gedda and Jon Vickers singing the lead roles, will begin the 197879 season of live radio broadcasts from the Metropolitan Opera on Dec.2

title: Janet Hafner and J.M. Biltchik Marry in Ridgefield Ceremony
description: Janet E. Hafner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Hafner of Delray Beach, Fla., and Lake Placid, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Jonathan M. Biltchik, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Biltchik of Chappaqua, N.Y. Justice of the Peace Nicholas Thieman performed the ceremony in the Elms Inn in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: Testing the Mayor on Race
description: The relationship between Mayor Koch and the city's black community was bound to be uneasy, even before the rise in tension in Crown Heights. For the first time since 1953, the Manhattan borough president was not black, so there was no minority representative on the Board of Estimate. The city's straitened circumstances reduced the patronage available to black supporters of the Mayor. Blanche Bernstein, the Commissioner of Human Resources, became a focus of minority discontent because fewer blacks held top positions in her agency than in the previous administration, and she was accused of being insensitive to the needs of the poor.

title: The City
description: A young man and woman were forced out of an automobile and shot to death in a wooded area near Orchard Beach in the Northeast Bronx yesterday afternoon by two men who, witnesses said, fled in a latemodel Cadillac.

title: U.S. Agrees to Share Cleanup Cost At Defunct Nuclear Center Upstate
description: James L. Larocca, New York State's Energy Commissioner, said yesterday that the Federal Government had now acknowledged for the first time that would play a major role in cleaning up what remains of a vast upstate nuclear fuel reprocessing center that failed.

title: Synthetic Gas Unit Closing
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP)  The Department of Energy announced today that it would shut down its experimental plant for converting coal into synthetic gas next month because Congress did not provide enough funds to keep it operating. The pilot plant, at Bruceton, Pa., near Pittsburgh, was built at a cost of $17 million and began operating in July 1976 to test a procesf, for converting 72 tons of coal daily into 1.2 million cubic feet of methane gas as a possible substitute for natural gas.

title: Brass Patrol as Police Take Test
description: Twelve hundred fewer police officers were on duty yesterday as 19,900 members of the New York City forceabout 70 percent of the total took a Civil Service examination for sergeant. More than a thousand sergeants and lieutenants had to be assigned to patrol duties to replace the test takers.

title: Radio
description: 69, WQXR. Piano Concerto. in, minor, Viotti ; Suite from Isse, De stouches; Overtue from Der Vier. jahrige Posten, Schubert; Sere. nade in C for Strings, Tchaikov. sky; Suite of English Folk Songs, Vaughan Williams; Overture from La Dame Blanche, Boieldiau; Flute Concerto in C, Gianella.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: DETROIT, Nov. 24 (AP)  Plans to establish a major new auto battery manufacturing plant in France were announced today by the General Motors Corporation.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MANILA, Nov. 24 (AP)  Peter Feigl of Austria upset secondseeded Tom Gorman, 62, 62, in a quarterfinal match of the $75,000 Philippine International Grand Prix tennis tournament today.

title: Liberal Party Patron Says Donations Were Diverted to Thorpe's Use
description: LONDON, Nov. 24  A wealthy businessman MI described himself as the biggest supporter the Liberal Party has ever had financially testified today that two donations he made to the party had been channeled to Jeremy Thorpe, who was then its leader.

title: Books: Alan Jay Lerner Is Lyrical Without Music
description: In a time when gossip can masquerade as literature, what a pleasure it is to encounter in print such an urbane and intelligent writer asAlan Jay Lerner. Mr. Lerner is, of cdurse, the lyricist and author of the musicals My Fair Lady, Gigi and Camelot, and the same impeccable touch that he has when matching words to music is evident in his first book, The Street Where I Live. This is the story of his three greatest successes, although his other triumphs and his failures are mentioned in passing, which means that this is less an autobiography than a judicious guide to the intricacies of a popular'art form. Anyone with doubts about lyric writing as an art form need only look up Mr. Lerner's lyrics, printed in the back of the book. They can stand alone as verse and also, as we read them, they spring into music.

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 24 (AP) Vietnam's armed forces have stepped up ground and air attacks, into Cambodia, flying as many as 40 combat missions daily into the neighboring country, authoritative sources here said today.

title: Dr. James R. Kinney, Urban Veterinarian And Author, Was 76
description: Dr. James Roser Kinney, a New York City veterinarian, died Thursday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx after a long ness. He was 76 years old and lived at 575 Park Avenue in Manhattan.

title: Witness Tells How Cult Members Went to Deaths
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Nov. 24 (UPI) A witness at the mass suicide and killings at Jonestown on Saturday recalled here today that only one member of the People's Temple had objected when the cultists were told by their leader that all must die.

title: U.S. Action On Sugar Price
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) The Agriculture Department moved today to bolster sugar prices by keeping some of the1977 crop off the market.

title: Army Faction Expels Air Force In Bolivia's 5th Coup in 14 Years
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 24 (AP)  The Army toppled the fourmonthold Government of Gen. Juan Pereda AsbUn in a bloodless coup today and promised prompt elections to return the people to their rights and liberties.

title: Talks Fail On Wheat In Geneva
description: GENEVA, Nov. 24 (AP)  Negotiations between the world's principal grainproducing and graintrading nations for an international wheat agreement broke down in Geneva today, largely because of United StatesEuropean differences on prices and the size of world reserve stocks.

title: Botswana Denies Barring Return Of Blacks to Homes in Rhodesia
description: GABERONE, Botswana, Nov. 24 (Reuters)  Botswana denied today charge by Rhodesia that its police were preventing hundreds of blacks who fled guerrilla warfare from returning home A statement from the office of the President, Sir Seretse Khama, said Rhodesia had made the accusation because its attempts to lure the refugees back to Rhodesia were a complete fiasco.

title: New Air Route Awarded
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP)  An administrative law judge of the CivilAeronautics Board has awarded Allegheny Airlines a new route between St. Louis and the San Francisco Bay area. In doina so, the judge, Stephen J. Gross, said that American Airlines and Eastern Airlines would get the routes instead if Allegheny failed to provide lowfare service. T.W.A. is now the only airline holding nonstop authority between St. Louis and San Francisco.

title: Catherine O'Hearn Bride Of Michael Damian Ryan
description: Catherine Lee O'Hearn, daughter of Terry O'Hearn and Theodore David O'Hearn of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Michael Damian Ryan, son of Dr. and Mrs. John D. Ryan of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Melvin Hawthorne performed the ceremony at the Church Center of the United Nations.

title: News Summary
description: Nearly twice as many People's Temple members died in their jungle commune than had been initially reported by the Guyanese Government, United States officials said. It now appears that there be may be as many as 780 bodies, American aides in Guyana said in a terse statement that left many questions unanswered. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: L.I. Greenbelt Offers a View Still Pristine
description: The couple did not look much like hikers. He was wearing slacks and a leatherbrimmed hat. She had on a lightcolored pantsuit and street shoes.

title: China's Boom Is Europe's Boon
description: BONN, Nov. 24  Swissair, one of the few European airlines with direct flights to Peking, says its flights from Zurich are booked two weeks ahead. A recent telephone caller was unable to reach most toplevel personnel at %Vest's Germany's Dresdner Bank. They've all gone to China, a spokesman said.

title: Forgings Orders Rise
description: Forgings orders at independent shops in October climbed 28 percent, to $250.7 million, from $196.5 million the year before, the Forging Industry Association announced yesterday. The group said, however, that orders had dropped 18 percent, from $304.2 million in September. Bookings for the first 10 months climbed 47 percent, to $2.39 billion, from $1.63 billion in the similar period last year.

title: E.E.C. Group To Visit U.S.
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 24 (AP)  A European Common Market delegation headed by Wilhelm Haferkamp, External Affairs Commissioner, will visit Washington next week for talks on economic ties, energy, thirdworld development and the world'trade and tariff talks, the Common Market announced today.

title: Jacques Bergier, at 66; French Science Writer And a Resistance Chief
description: PARIS, Nov. 24  Jacques Bergier, who headed one of France's most efficient secret resistance networks during World War II, died here last night of cerebral hemorrhage. He was 66 years old.

title: Dr. Payton, Under Pressure, Resigns as Director of Peace Corps
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24  Citing unresolvable differences of policy between Carolyn R. Payton, the director of the Peace Corps, and her immddiate supervisor, President Carter tonight accepted Dr. Payton's resignation.

title: 4 Yards to Glory in the Gloom
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Nov: 24  Joe Paterno wanted to know exactly how many yards his Penn State team needed for a first down. Four yards, somebody was shouting. One yard, another yelled. Two yards, somebody else said. Two yards was the correct distance, but Joe Paterno didn't know that yet.

title: Opera: Miss Crespin Is Back
description: Regine Crespin, absent from the Metropolitan Opera last season, returned to the company Thursday night in the title role of Carmen. Bizet's sultry gypsy is not the kind of part one would ordinarily associate with such a stately, statuesque singer, but Miss Crespin, as she demonstiated when she first sang Carmen in New York three years ago, has devised a fascinatingly original interpretation that works wonderfully well for her.

title: U.S. Says Most Cult Complaints Did Not Warrant Formal Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  The Justice Department has formally investigated only about 300 of the 400 to 500 complaints of brainwashing, threats of extortion or physical restraint by religious cults that it has received in the last three years, a department spokesman said today.

title: Labor Dept. Revising Public Jobs Programs After Abuse Is Found
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24  Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall, believing that mismanagement, inefficiency and indifference are threatening the longterm credibility of the Government's public jobs programs, is undertaking major revisions in the Labor Department's Employment and Training; dminist ration, icesay.

title: White House Appoints New Chief Speechwriter
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) President Carter is shaking up his speechwriting staff, and Bernard Aronson, a speechwriter for Vice President Mondale, will be the new executive speechwriter, according to a White House spokesman.

title: Kate Harrington, Actress, at 74
description: Kate Harrington, who acted on stage, in films and on television, died Thursday in Beth Israel Hospital. She suffered stroke last year. A resident of Manhattan, she would have been 75 years old Dec. 8.

title: 11% Prime Is Set, Up HalfPoint
description: The cost of money moved sharply higher yesterday as Citibank and most other major banks raised their prime lending rate to 11 percent from 11 percent in the 14th increase in the basic interest rate so far this year.

title: Sears Plans To Buy Its Stock
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company announced yesterday that it plans to buy up to 10 million of its outstanding common shares on the open market, or approximately 3 percent of the 322 million shares outstanding as of Oct. 31. There is no time limit on the nlan.

title: On East 67th Street, an Injunction Against the World
description: Numerous demonstrations protesting the recent trials of the Russian dissidents have been held at the Soviet mission to the United Nations, situated on East 67th Street.

title: Doctor Fails in Search For His Mother's Body At Guyana Settlement
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Nov. 24 The short, unhappy odyssey of Robert C. Lowery has ended, inconclusively.

title: Boeing Thrives on New Orders
description: SEATTLEThe bonanza at the Boeing Company  orders in 1978 for nearly 900 aircraft at a delivery cost of more than $9 billion  has made the giant aircraft producer here as fat as one of its widebodied lets.

title: THOMAS STEEL
description: Thomas Steel, a mechanical engineer, died Thursday of a heart attack at his son's home in Flushing, Queens. He was 80 years old.

title: The Region
description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecticut, is changing press secretaries, prompting speculation that he may actively seek his party's Presidential nomination starting next year.

title: Flyers Hand Stars Sixth Straight Loss
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 (AP) Mel Bridgman scored the tiebreaking goal with 5 minutes 35 seconds left in the second period and the Philadelphia Flyers recorded a 43 National Hockey League victory over the Minnesota North Stars this afternoon.

title: Business Records
description: Petition Flied By: WILLIAM CASTNER, 73 Sycamore Corners, New Wind. sor, N.Y. Liabilities, 512,984Orion 14,968. ROCHELLE CASTNER, 3873 Orn Ave., the Bronx. LI. abilities, $13,044; assets.

title: Volkswagen Talks Fail
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany, Nov. 24 (UPI)  Volkswagen announced today that its talks aimed at a diversification move with the NixdorfComputer AG had ended with no agreement.

title: 76ers 134, Clippers 120
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 (AP) Julius Erving scored 30 points as the Philadelphia 76ers broke a twogame losing streak and defeated the San Diego Clippers, 134120, tonight.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) York cafes stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Foreigner, Megalith Rockers, Purveys HeavyMetal Power
description: Foreigner, a megalith of a rock group, made its New York debut at Madison Square Garden on Thanksgiving Evening. TheSe days, it ordinarily takes several years to achieve pop superstardom. But Foreigner, a conglomerate of six British and American journeymen incorporated just two years ago, reaped windfall profits with its very first release.

title: Gains Reported In Japan Talks
description: TOKYO, Nov. 24 (AP)  A Japanese Government source said today that Japanese and United States trade negotiators in Geneva had basically agreed to increase Japan's import of oranges, grapefruit juice and beef from the United States, the Asahi Shimbun newspaper reported.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Railroads agreed to trim their requested rate increase to 7 percent from 8.1 percent following two weeks of intensive negotiations with the Council on Wage and Price Stability. The council said the crease appeared to be within the Carter Administration's voluntary guideline, and Transportation Secretary Brock Adams said the decision should be a model for the rest of American industry. [Page 1.]

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON AN employee of the RCA Corporation in Florida has invented mechanism to remove warning lights automatically from the cable tethers of research balloons. Julie K. Randolph was granted patent 9,126,850 this week. assigning it to RCA.

title: Treatments for the WouldBe Sybarite
description: What with a perfume called Me! and forthcoming magazine named Self, sybaritism seems to be the mood of our times. touch of it never hurt anyone. Being good to oneself sometimes makes us nicer to others.

title: SIIMULIK GOLDSTEIN, YIDDISH STAGE STAR
description: Comedian, 70, was in Folksbiene Production of The Inheritors Shmuel Goldstein, a comedian of the Yiddish stage, died Thursday of a heart attack. He was 70 years old.

title: U.S. Agency on Job Safety and Health Discards 928 Nuisance Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP)  The Government's watchdog over safety in the workplace is dropping many rules that employers have found onerous, such as those about how to design the proper toilet seat or how to choose a tool belt.

title: Bonn Votes Stimulus To Aid U.S.
description: BONN, Nov. 29 (UPI)  The West German Parliament approved today $7.8 billion program to stimulate the economy and keep a promise Chancellor Helmut Schmidt made to President Carter at the economic summit meeting here in July.

title: Reserve Pushes Interest Rates Higher
description: In the first tightening move since its policysetting Open Market Committee met Tuesday, the Federal Reserve yesterday nudged interest rates higher, causing a sharp drop in prices in the bond market.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WHILE YOU'RE THERE A new, fiveday art exhibition will open tomorrow at the United Nations Plaza Hotel, 44th Street west of First Avenue, where the public is invited to view works in oil and blackandwhite graphics by Thomas Schmitz, a young West German artist. The display, a departure for the hotel, will be in the secondfloor U Thant Room. Hours through Thursday are 11 A.M. to 7 P.M., with no admission charge.

title: Old Jewelry Attracts New Fans  Investors
description: It's more esthetically attractive than pork belly futures, more fiscally secure than stocks, probably more profitable than a savings account, less expensive than most real estate and less vulnerable to theft than large diamonds. And, in widening circles, antique jewelry carries an impressive amount of cachet.

title: St. John's Five Triumphs; Wagner Stuns Alabama
description: Reggie Carter's layup with 12 seconds remaining gave St. John's University a 7270 victory last night over American University in the opening round of the fourth annual Joe Lapchick Memorial basketball tournament at St. John's.

title: ZAMBIAN PESSIMISTIC ABOUT PEACE MOVE
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Nov. 24 (Reuters) 1  President Kenneth D. Kaunda deliv1 ered a rebuff in advance today to planned BritishAmerican efforts to set up a conference of all parties involved in the Rhodesian dispute, saying such talks would achieve nothine constructive.

title: Disobeying a Good Drug Law
description: A New York State law to cut drug costs to consumers is being undermined by some physicians and pharmacists. Doctors are now required to indicate on special forms whether a specific brandname drug is necessary or whether the pharmacist should substitute cheaper equivalent. The laudable goal is to provide consumers the medicine they need at reasonable cost.

title: Instrument Landing Is Victor in Remsen
description: When the Eclipse Award ballots are counted to decide this season's champion 2yearold colt, Instrument Landing won't be among the top three votegetters.

title: Even Now, SecondTier Stocks Have Their Advocates
description: When the stock market plunged in October, smaller company stocks the secondtier issues traded for the most part on the American Stock Exchange and overthecounter  fell twice as hard as their bigger, betterknown cousins. The Federal Expresses and Paradynes that in recent years moved up so smartly past the Kodaks and Union Carbides rushed even faster past them on the way down.

title: AROUND THE Garden; Mulch? Not Now; This Week
description: Last call to plant bulbs. Pot cuttings of impatiens, geraniums and begonias rooted from summer border flowers. Clean and store the lawn mower. Clean and store tools that will not be used until spring.

title: Popularity of Soaring Takes Off
description: HAWKS!  came the cry echoing over a quiet meadow north of Waterbury. recently  an area used these days as the gliderport for the Connecticut Soaring Center. Suddenly the giant birds could be seen flapnine their wines 20 feet above the treetops, swirling skywards in a upward current of warm air known to the fliers as a thermal.

title: Jane Ferguson Wed To Paul J. Ritzman
description: Jane Gardiner Ferguson, daughter of Marian Merrill Ferguson of Avon, Conn., and the late Samuel Ferguson Jr., was married yesterday to Paul Jonathan Ritzman, son of Dr. and Mrs.Thomas A. Ritzman of Hopkinton, N.H. The Rev. Nigel Andrews performed the ceremony at the Trinity Episcopal Church in Concord, Mass.

title: Grant's Galena: An Illinois Town That Time Forgot
description: Galena is known as the town time forgot. While most places its size  4,000 people, give or take a few  have evolved into faceless neon and plastic franchise towns, no different from the last place back down the road, Galena has been so remarkably unchanged it almost as if it had been buried for hundred years beneath the same kind of volcanic ash that has preserved Pompeii and Herculaneum.

title: Horse Breeding: Does Racing Face Another Scandal?
description: A massive bloodtyping program designed to spot false pedigrees has been accelerated by The Jockey Club as a result of several equine paternity suits and reports of other possible breeding deceptions. The program is designed to halt or prevent what some of horse racing's top leaders fear could become another major scandal: fraud on the breeding farm.

title: Vance Says Ties With Russians Have Improved
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance says that relations with the Soviet Union are improving and there is still a possibility of a strategic arms limitation treaty this year.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Has any composer dominated his country as Giuseppe Verdi did? Between the death of Donizetti in 1848 and the emergence of Ponchielli in the 1870's there was, in effect, only one composer Italy who counted. It is true that Boito had composed Mefistofele in 1868, but he was a oneopera  indeed, a onecomposition  man, and he is as famous for his librettos of Verdi's Otello and Falstaff he is for his opera, and perhaps even more so. Take 1869.

title: Nixon Leaves for European Tour, His First Trip Abroad Since 1976
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon left yesterday on his first visit to Europe since resigning the Presidency four years ago. The trip is also his first international Tourney since visiting China in 1976.

title: New CETA Chief Moves Cautiously
description: WHITE PLAINS THE MAN destined to assume one of the county's hottest administrative seatsheading the $35 million local program the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act  appears to be moving cautiously into his new role.

title: Jets Play Dolphins With Eyes on the Past
description: MIAMI, Nov. 25  The last time the New York Jets swept two games from the Miami Dolphins in a season was the last time the Jets made the playoffs. That, of course, was in 1969, the season after the Jets victory in Super Bowl III over the Baltimore Colts.

title: From Priesthood To Law Deanship
description: BOTH my wife and I are New Yorkers, said Dr. John J. Regan. So for us it's ahomecominng.

title: Echoes and Portents
description: PMOLITICAL history often repeats itself, but rarely as fast as it has in Nassau County. Just a year ago, the Nassau Republican organization emerged from an unseemly and damaging battle between a County Executive, Ralph G. Caso, and the Nassau G.O.P. chairman, Joseph M. Margiotta.

title: Action Weighed in Fall at Tower
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP)  The Labor Department has asked the Justice Department to consider possible criminal action against the contractor for a giant cooling tower where scaffolding collapsed, sending 51 construction workers to their deaths, a Government source said today. The case involving ResearchCottrell Inc. of Bound Brook, N.J., the contractor for the cooling tower on Willow Island, W. Va., was referred to the Justice Department last week by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, the source said.

title: America's favorite Dolly, Carol Charming, plans to give the crew of Hello, Dolly a disco party full of and frivolity fOr Christmas..
description: Christmas is a time when almost everyone, in the spirit of the Three Wise Persons, thinks about giftsboth spiritual and the wrapped up kind. We asked some celebrity Santas to think about what they might have planned for a special friend or enemy this Christmas.

title: Recital: Alice Lindsay Arranges Compositions for Tier Own Viola
description: Alice Lindsay has been a busy violist in the New York area for some years now, as a solo recitalist and teacher as well as firstdesk player with the New Jersey Symphony, the Orchestral Society of Philadelphia and, presently, with the Chamber Symphony of New Jersey. On Friday night she gave a recital at Alice Tully Hall performing a pleasantly varied program devoted to her mellow, aristocratic instrument.

title: Jonestown Has
description: Had they died for a cause in which everyone could believe, they would have been called martyrs. But the members of the People's Temple shared a belief system that, though surely coherent and laudable to them, seems others tragically misguided and even psychotic.

title: A New World Population Estimate Has One Very Soft Spot
description: Washington  They seek out visitors to China paw through their handscrawled notes. They hang on provincial Chinese radio broadcasts for a shred information, a number here, a number there. One even has two anonymous informants, one of them with close contact to a Peking ministry.

title: Former Iran Press Aide Agrees to Take Lie Test
description: LONDON, Nov. 24  Siarnak Zand, a former press aide to the Shah of Iran, agreed today to take a lie detector test in response to a challenge from Arnaud de Borchgrave of Newsweek magazine.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: We couldn't remember how Here's That, Rainy Day goes, so Benny Goodman hummed a few bars over the phone, stopping to say, I'm a lousy singer. No matter. His voice is not the instrument people will be coming to hear Saturday night at 8:30 when the durable Mr. G. performs Weber's Concertina for Clarinet with the Bridgeport Symphony in the Klein Auditorium, at 910 Fairfield Ave. The King of Swing told us he has been practicing the Weber piece for about 25 years. I only get to rehearse with the orchestra the night before, you know, he said. The concert is in two parts  classical and pop, with no rock. I don't need it, and I don't think people expect me to play it, he said. Tickets are $3 to $9. For reservations, call 5760263.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: The Federal Reserve is estimated to have put more than $6 billion into the effort to defend the dollar since the Administration's rescue program was announced on Nov. 1, and the West German, Japanese and Swiss central banks on some days have spent even more than the Fed on bolstering the American currency. Judging from early reactions in the European money markets, the effort has been successful, at least temporarily.

title: Revisions Drafted for Civil Service System
description: TRENTON THE state's Civil Service system may undergo some major changes with regard to the preference now given to veterans of the armed forces.

title: Editors Choice
description: AMERICAN CAESAR: DOUGLAS MACARTHUR 1880IN14, by William Manchester. (Little, Brown & Co, $15.) Voluminous research; narrative sweep; Judicious ambivalence.

title: Two Soviet Craft Near Venus
description: MOSCOW, Nov 25 (Reuters)  Two Soviet space probes launched toward Venus last September are nearing the planet with all systems working, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency. The two craft, Venus 11 and Venus 12, now more than 600,000 miles apart, have been signaling back information on solar winds, cosmic rays and other space phenomena, Tass said. They are due to arrive at the planet in December to carry out further experiments.

title: ISAAC BASHEVIS SINGER TALKS ABOUT EVERYTHING
description: W hen 74yearold Isaac Bashevis Singer won the 1978 Nobel Prize in Literature, I visited him in his oldworld apartment on New York's Upper West Side. After receiving constant attention from the world's media, Mr. Singer was exhausted but quietly exuberant. His vivacious wife, Alma, felt that he should rest. But he preferred to talk.

title: 4 Found Dead in Mobile Home
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Nov. 24 (AP)  An Oakland County deputy sheriff, a woman and two of her children were found dead in a mobile home yesterday, apparently overcome by fumes from a furnace. A third child was recovering in a Pontiac hospital. Sheriff's deputies identified the victims as Deputy Robert Dehnke, 28 years old; Sharon Novotny, 32, and two of her children, Gary, 14, and Kevin, 9. The third child was 5monthold Jennifer.

title: Deaths
description: FLAHERTYCharles J., Sr. Beloved husband of Helen V. nee Mohr. devoted father of Charles, Jr.. John, Mary Ellen ToIan, and Kathleen Appolio. Fond brother of Patricia Connolly, John and James. Reposing at the Castle Hill Funeral Home. 152) Castle Hill Ave. Bronx after 7 P.M. Funeral Mass Our Lady of ASSUI110. tion R.C. Church, Monday, llam, In ferment St Raymond's Cemetery.

title: Moderation is the Message For New Right Campaigners
description: JACKSON, Miss.  Don't worry, he'll vote like a rightwing extremist when we need him, said a very conservative supporter of Mississippi's new Republican senator, Thad Cochran, who ran and has been portraying himself as a moderate  undecided, for example, about whether support a new strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union.

title: N.Y.C.L.U. Fights Curb on Soviet Mission Pickets
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union has filed a motion in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to overturn a sevenyearold injunction that prohibits picketing by more than 12 persons near the Soviet Mission to the United Nations.

title: Walking the Himalayas
description: PETER MATTH1ESSEN has made another of his epic trips for us  epic in the sense that he writes about them so much better than anybody else who has been undertaking journeys such as his in recent years. Though he also writes good novels, he has gone rafting on the Amazon, adventured in New Guinea, rattled through a substantial stretch of East Africa by souk lorry and Land Rover, chased sharks off the coast of Australia, and visited the Eskimos. Thus, among good writers, he is something of a throwback.

title: 4 US. Units Plan Fight On 24 Toxic Substances
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP)  Four Government agencies asserted today that they planned a joint attack on 24 toxic substances that pose health or environmental threats because of unsafe manufacture or handling.

title: 10cc, the British Rock Group, Gives a Concert at the Palladium
description: To judge by what is probably lOcc's bestknown American hit, I'm Not in Love, the band is some sort of Romanticized artrock ensemble of the synthesizer sort. But from its other big hit here, The Things We Do for Love, direct descendant of the Hollies and the Beatles by way of Wings might seem more like it. To judge from the group's Friday evening appearance at the Palladium, the latter description is the more accurate.

title: Sri Lanka Storm Dead Put at 500
description: MADRAS, India, Nov. 25 (AP)  A hurricane struck the southern Indian coast today after roaring across the island nation of Sri Lanka, where local newspapers reported that about 500 people had been killed.

title: Seton Hall Streak at 32 As Merklinger Excels
description: John Merklinger rushed for 241 yards and scored three touchdowns to lead Seton Hall past Essex Catholic, 230, yesterday at Schools Stadium, Newark. Seton Hall (100) extended New Jersey's longest current schoolboy unbeaten streak to 32.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: Representative Ronald A. Sarasin was back in Washington, arranging for the closing of his Congressional offices and the transition to a successor. State Senator Lewis B. Rome was back practicing law again in his hometown of Bloomfield.

title: Meyer Runs 29:35.9, Takes A.A.U. Title
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 25 (AP)  Greg Meyer of the Greater Boston Track Club held off the University of Oregon's National Collegiate champion, Alberto Salazar, to win the national Amateur Athletic Union men's individual crosscountry championship today.

title: DINING OUT
description: HARTFORD THIS seems to be the era of theme restaurants, with new ones opening in refurbished old firehouses, factories and railroad stations. On several occasions recently we dined in a bank vault in the recesses of the Connecticut Bank and Trust Building in Hartford. But instead of depositing money we were spending it at fact Min.

title: 6 Named to Unit for Retarded
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP)  President Carter has appointed six persons to the President's Commission on Mental Retardation. Named on Wednesday to terms expiring May 11, 1981, were Andrew I.T. Chand, Aiea, Hawaii; Herbert J. Cohen, New York City; Ruth W. Diggs, Norfolk, Va.; Shirley C. Miller, Atlanta; Edward J. Quilligan, Los Angeles, and Aileen A. Weiss, Columbia, S.C. Mr. Carter also appointed Thomas H. Wyman of Wayzata, Minn., to the Presidential Commission on World Hunger, and Wayne E. Glenn of Little Rock to the Advisory Committee for Trade Negotiations.

title: Property Owners in Atlantic City Finding They Have Midas Touch
description: ATLANTIC CITY (AP)  Ever since casino gambling was approved here two years ago, many local businessmen  either through sheer luck or shrewd business dealing have been striking it rich.

title: DINING OUT; Where Broiled Is Best; Merry Pedlar
description: TWO noteworthy features mark the Merry Pedlar in Floral Park. First and most important, the kitchen turns out fine, simple broiled dishes, and the ingredients are firstrate. An added bonus is the unpretentious, comfortable setting, decorated with tongueandgroove cedar paneling, hanging plants and wicker, giving a pleasantly contemporary feel.

title: Bernstein as Symphonist
description: Leonard Bernstein, eternal wunderkind, musical polymath and by some margin America's most widely celebrated classical music personality, reached the age of 60 last summer with a surprisingly modest amount of fanfare and media brouhaha. This appears to be a relatively quiet period of reflection and stocktaking for the composerconductor. As when he retired from the directorship of the New York Philharmonic in 1969, Mr. Bernstein has once again expressed a desire to curtail his diverse activities and to devote most of his energies in the future to serious composition, opera in particular.

title: Yiddish Is Alive and Well  Nu?
description: WHEN Isaac Bashevis Singer, this year's Nobel Prize winner in literature, speaks at Temple Emanuel in Great Neck on Thursday evening, he will undoubtedly feel more at ease than he generally does. This is because he will be speaking not only in English, but also in the language he writes in, Yiddish.

title: Researchers Find Sexuality Lags Among Women Taking Birth Pills
description: BOSTON, Nov. 25 (AP)  Women are most interested in sex when they are at their most fertile, researchers say, but those who take oral contraceptives lack heightened sexual desire.

title: Edward Finch Jr. Fianc of Pauline Swayze
description: The engagement of Pauline Hoefer Swayze of New York to Edward Ridley Finch Jr., a partner in the New York law firm of Finch & Schaefler, was announced last Tuesday at a reception given at Mr. Finch's home by Mr. and Mrs. Howard Ellis Cox, his brotherinlaw and sister.

title: Rutherford Curbs Vandalism in Parks
description: RUTHERFORD TEENAGE vandalism and vagrancy in three parks in this Bergen County borough have been virtually eliminated, thanks to evening patrols by a park ,ranger employed by the town's Recreation Department.

title: Susan Walker To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore G. Walker 3d of Woodbridge, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Carol Walker, to Michael MCKee Monahan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E, Monahan of Fort Myers, Fla.

title: ART VIEW
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. The city of Oslo, in midDecember, is an eerie place. The oppressive darkness, only briefly but spectacularly relieved by the midday sunrise and sunset in quick succession; the continual fall of the snow on the lamplit streets; the careful tread of pedestrians and the slow progress of vehicles looking as if they were making their way through the obscruity of a tunnel; the rhythm of a daily life pursued in an atmosphere of eternal night  all of this lends an air of both enchantment and depression to the place. For the visitor who arrives from a gentler climate, it seems quite incredible that life can be permanently lived under such dour circumstances. But then, as he quickly discovers, the natives are not exactly reconciled to it, either. In Oslo, they speak of Copenhagen as the south, rather as Parisians speak of the Riviera.

title: What's Doing in the BRITISH VIRGIN ISLANDS
description: NEVERNEVER LAND  The British Virgin Islands, an array of 40 to 50 (depending on the tides) islets, cays and oversize rocks in the Caribbean, are no larger in the aggregate than Martha's Vineyard and. beine small. they prefer to think small. Located 60 miles east of Puerto Rico with its clangorous gambling casinos, and 15 miles east of the bustling free port of St. Thomas in the United States Virgin Islands, the British Virgin Islands are kind of nevernever land, almost too good to be true, in the otherwise frenetic mainstream of Caribbean tourism.

title: Exotic Reggae Fills the House
description: REGGAE music, as been bubbling under in this country for several years now. Born in such Kingston. Jamaica. ghettos as French Town and blending the Africanbased pulse of Jamaican rhythms and a political spiritual message with the urgency of United States rhythm and blues, ref gae's current position in the contempt, rary marketplace is ambiguous. Show ing only intermittent signs of achieving widespread American acceptance as performed by its originators, it never theless retains a tenacious influence on a variety of popular music makers, including Paul Simon, Eric Clapton. Elvis Costello and the Rolling Stones.

title: Dingoes, Wagtails
description: Judith Wright is an Australian poet, author of 10 books of verse from which the present selection has been made. Assuming that American readers need help with work that conies out of an unfamiliar country, she provides an introduction telling us a bit about Australia, of where

title: Price of Sunday News Will Rise From 35 to 50 Cents Next Week
description: The price of the Sunday edition of The Daily News will be increased in the New York metropolitan area from 35 cents to 50 cents next Sunday.

title: Panel Fails to Reinstate SmokedOut Dispatcher
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Nov. 25 (AP)  Sandra Cahill had something to kick about when she refused to work in smokefilled room, but the city's Civil Service Board is not going to reinstate her as a fire department radio operator.

title: OPEC's Pricing Dilemma: How Much Is Too Much?
description: WASHINGTON  Meetings of the oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have much in common with the conclaves of cardinals in Rome to select a new pope: Both exude an aura of mystery, attract great speculation and frequently produce surprises. The upcoming gathering of the high priests of OPEC, on Dec. 16 in Abu Dhabi, shows no sign of being an exception.

title: Letting Hot Air Pay Off in Tax Credits
description: THIS winter's heating bills will be higher than last year's, but under the new National Energy Act, homeowners can save in the future and get advice on how to do it, and they can get some of their investment back now.

title: Denise Patton to Be Wed Dec. 22
description: Denise Louise Patton and John Augustine Chilton Hearst, alumni of the California Polytechnic University in San Luis Obispo, plan to be married Dec. 22.

title: APPLE CROP SAVED BY UNUSUAL CREWS
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Mich., Nov. 25 (UPI)  Because of a reduced influx of migrant workers, some Michigan apple growers have hired schoolchildren and mentally handicapped adults to harvest this year's record crop.

title: Terriers Ousted by Clemson
description: The dream of going to the National Collegiate soccer final tournament came to an end for St. Francis College of Brooklyn yesterday when Clemson scored four goals in the second half and eliminated the Terriers, 40.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Some of the most interesting architecture is the most ambiguous; the transitional period from about 1890 to World War I, never quite free of 19thcentury tradition while straining spectacularly after a new, 20thcentry vision, is full of genius and contradiction.

title: 2 NEW DEPARTMENTS IN CABINET STUDIED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2.5  By midDecember, President Carter is slated to receive preliminary proposals from his reorganization staff suggesting the replacement and expansion of two executive branch departments and possibly resultingin the dismantling of the Commerce Department, Administration officials said today.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS After A Treaty
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.The treaty that is now being negotiated between Egypt and Israel constitutes an intermediate solution of the Middle Eastern conflict. The Camp David documents are riddled with ambiguities that concern the Palestinian problem. They will have to be lifted in one of two ways.

title: No Autopsies Done on Victims, Leaving Cause of Deaths Unclear
description: One week after about 900 Americans died in Jonestown, Guyana, no autopsies have been performed by American doctors, according to officials at Dover Air Force Base, Del., where the badly decomposed bodies have been flown. The officials added that they did not know if d ny autopsies were performed in Guyana.

title: South Africans Reject U.N.'s Effort to Block Elections in Namibia
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 25 (AP)  South Africa has rejected a demand by the Security Council that it cancel elections it plans to hold without United Nations supervision in SouthWest Africa next month, Secretary General Kurt Waldheim reported today.

title: Miss Fackler Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harland Fackler of Pioneer, Ohio, have made known the engagement of their daughter, America Mary L. Fackler of New York, to Edward E. Sterling, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eduard Sterling of Ridgewood, Queens, and Kingston, N.Y. A winter weddine is planned.

title: ANTIQUES
description: WHATEVER calendar other shoppers may follow, the holiday giftbuying season begins for Connecticut collectors when the Christmas Antiques Bazaar opens in Old Greenwich. The 16th annual exhibit and sale will run from Friday througll Sunday.

title: French Was a Foreign Language
description: THE circumstances of Pierre JakezHlias birth were unfavorable. The doctor had to be called, and it was somewhat humiliating for my mother who felt she ought to have been able to give birth without the help of anyone but the  midwife. The baby came lustily into the world, but without nails. He won't be mean, prophesied one grandfa ther. The other, a more worldly sabotmaker, found in his grandson's unusual birth a portent of honor and glory.

title: Study Finds Rural Women Earn Less Than Urban Counterparts
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP)  Rural women who work outside the home are generally paid much less than their city counterparts, in part because they are willing to take lowerpaying jobs, according to a report by the Agriculture Department.

title: Radio
description: 7:308 A.M., WABC: Message of Israel.

title: Moscow Youth Paper Hails Mickey Mouse
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 25 (AP)  A Soviet youth newspaper today offered its salute to Mickey Mouse, the Walt Disney cartoon character who celebrated his 50th anniversary last week. unlike other movie stars, Mickey Mouse doesn't make any secret about his date of birth, said an article in the newspaper Moskovsky Komsomolets.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: All criticism is subjective, but when you start trying to pin down why one artist has mystery and another doesn't, you run the risk of pushing subectivity into absurdism. Be that as it may, Betty Woo, a Hong Kongborn, San Franciscobased pianist who made her New York debut last Sunday night, had many virtues as a technician and musician. But she lacked mystery.

title: Islanders Conquer Can ucks
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Nov.25 (UPI)  Five players scored goals tonight as the New York Islanders posted a 52 victory over the Vancouver Canucks. It was the Islanders fifth straight triumph on the road.

title: $83,673 Check Averts Auction Of Coast Town
description: BRIDGEVILLE, Calif., Nov. 24 businessman presented a check for $83,673, after a computer breakdown had delayed the foreclosure auction, and the church's town was apparently saved.

title: News Summary
description: Nearly 900 People's Temple members are now believed to have died in Guyana last weekend, United States officials said, and they indicated that the total might rise. They gave no explanation for the increase in.their estimate of nearly R00 dead, announced Friday. Combined with the number of Temple members known to have survived the mass deaths, the new figure exceeds the Guyanese Government's estimate that 915 temple followers had officially been registered. [Page 1, Column 6.)

title: Trials of Judicial Selection
description: What's the best way to pick a judge? We don't know, but there may be lessons in the current extensive flurry of attention to the subject, much of it in the name of merit selection. Indeed, that has become a fixture in the language, a phrase no judicial reformer or politician can do without.

title: ART
description: NEWARK GEOMETRIC abstraction must be one of the most forbidding terms in the annals of art. It is an expression that reduces art to a mathematical experience, as if were a theorem.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The 1979 edition of the Standard Catalog of World Coins has come up with 558 more coinissuing entities than there were in the 1977 volume  a total of 1,245, instead of 687. Strictly speaking we cannot call all these entries countries because the Catalog's Country Index also includes states, provinces, cities and even individual mints.

title: Gloria Lynn Veeder And Kenneth Bond Will Marry Jan. 20
description: Stuart Jay Veeder of Westbury, L.1., has announced the engagement of his sister, Gloria Lynn Veeder, to Kenneth Walter Bond of New York and Ausable Forks, N.Y., son of Dr. Daniel B. Bond and Mildred N. Bond of Eugene, Ore. The couple will be married Jan. 20 at the Brick Presbyterian Church.

title: Holocaust II!
description: They don't talk about extermination ovens or about freaky medical experiments or about lampshades fashioned from human skin. But the Cambodian refugees do talk about forced labor camps, about deportations, and about mass executions.

title: POLITICS A Matter of Life and Salary
description: ALFRED B. DELBELLO, the Democratic County Executive, told the Board of Legislators recently that his proposed $419 million budget for 1979 was another step in the county's progressive efforts to control costs while sustaining Westchester's quality of life.

title: The Region
description: The Health and Hospitals Corporation, a creation of former Mayor Lindsay and a burden to him and to two succeeding mayors, was giving Mayor Koch a migraine last week.

title: TV VIEW
description: In A Question of Love, tonight's ABC movie at 9, the subject is lesbianism. Clearly, television's sex bandwagon keeps rolling. As violent content is reduced, sexrelated content becomes the major alternative. It can indeed be infinitely preferable, but, this being American television (the European variety has long been more sophisticated in such matters) the new phenomenon tends to generate tremors of nervousness on both sides of the small screen.

title: INTERVIEW A Lesson Plan for Higher Education
description: A FEW weeks ago Howard Klebanoff found himself seated with a telephone in each hand and a visitor in front of his desk. One phone caller wanted to talk to the chairman of the State Board of Higher Education. The other wanted Governor urasso's campaign chairman. The visitor was a client waiting to talk with his lawyer.

title: Best Sellers
description: NONFICTION

title: IN BRIEF
description: Citibank led a troop of America's most powerful banks in a virtually unprecedented halfpoint jump in the prime lending rate to 11 percent, a level dangerously close to the 12 percent peak registered in mid1974. The banks that moved swiftly Friday to match Citibank's prime, which is the interest banks charge their most creditworthy corporate borrowers, included Morgan Guaranty, Chase Manhattan, Chemical, Banker's Trust, Continental Illinois and the Bank of New York.

title: Zambia's Ttivo Traditional Rail Outlets to Sea, Through Rhodesia and Zaire, Are Coming to Life Again
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Nov. 22  For landlocked Zambia, more than 1,000 miles from the nearest ocean port, the opening of a railroad line is a major event, full of promise but fraught with politics.

title: The Region
description: HARTFORD (AP)  The Connecticut Conference of Municipalities began an offensive yesterday to get more money for local governments in Gov. Ella T. Grasso's proposed state budget for next year.

title: Atlantic City: The Human Cost of Progress
description: ATLANTIC CITY AUREA SANTIAGO and her five children used to enjoy looking out the windows of their groundfloor apartment on south Vermont Avenue. Hispanic neighborhood. But not any more. Their absentee landlord, seph White, recently had the windows boarded up as part of his efforts to force the Santiagos and other occupants of the building to move.

title: Union Fight Could Cost the State Money
description: HARTFORD ELECTIONS to decide union representation among state employees this fall have seen three upsets and several serious challenges to the dominant union among the employees. The results may mean higher costs in new contracts early next year.

title: N.Y. State's Prison Chief Awaits Confirmation
description: Between the polities battles of the elections just past and the confirmation hearings Just ahead, Richard D. Hongisto is discovering that the primary occupation of an Acting New York State Corrections Commissioner is juggling.

title: Detective Work Is Urged To Reduce Ski Lawsuits
description: CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 25 (AP)  Ski slope operators could defend themselves better from getrichquick lawsuits they used police detective methods'to investigate skiing accidents, a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation says.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: An article in The New York Times on Nov. 9 explained the problems that Bordentown was having with the state because of the town's requirement that ablebodied welfare recipients work for the town a certain number of hours week.

title: Kennel Keeper Mauled by Lion
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 25 (AP) woman kennel keeper was reported in good condition today after undergoing treatment for severe cuts when she was mauled by a 300pound lion. The Jefferson County police said that the 4yearold lioness escaped from a pen at the Southland Animal Hospital yesterday and attacked Susan Franta, 29, of Louisville. She suffered severe cuts of the face and scalp. The animal was killed because tranquilizer gun could not be obtained.

title: The Enduring Art of Callas
description: s he was the Paganini of opera. She could create tension on the stage which reminded me of question once asked much in his voice, he said It's the fear in my voice. Callas always gave sense that perhaps she would not able to finish an aria. It was like watching Callas fighting against Callas, sort of bullfight in Which she finally killed the !monster and was acclaimed the victorious heroine of the moment. That sense of fight with herself created an enormous excitement in the theater.

title: Public Broadcasting Assailed on Race
description: Public broadcasting has been delinquent in meeting the needs of minorities in every aspect of management, employment, training, programming and decisionmaking, according to a detailed and voluminous report issued by a task force that spent 18 months examining the problem.

title: Peking's Poster Warriors Are Not Just Paper Tigers
description: HONG KONG  A crudely lettered poster on Peking's busy Changan Street last week proclaimed a startling message. From 1966 to 1976, it said, from the start of the Cultural Revolution to the death of Mao Tsetung, China was under a fascist regime and the only person who defended us ordinary people against the fascists was Chou Enlai.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: CHAPPAQUA  My Fair Lady, performed by Chappaqua Drama Group. Today at P.M. and 7:30 P.M. Horace Greeley High School, Roaring Brook Rd. 6668109.

title: Sadat Meets U.S. Senators
description: CAIRO, Nov. 25  Senator Henry M. Jackson, who, with six other Senators, conferred today with President Anwar elSadat, said later that he did not believe Egypt and Israel would agree on a peace treaty before the Nobel Peace Prizes are presented to Mr. Sadat and Prime Minister Menachem Begin on Dec. 10.

title: Columnist Mockridge Files Suit To Keep His Job With Syndicate
description: Morton Mockridge, the humor columnist, filed suit for damages yesterday, contending that he was illegally dismissed by ScrippsHoward Newspapers.

title: Stoppard and Pinter Open To Mixed British Reviews
description: LONDON  New plays by two of Britain's most celebrated contemporary playwrights, Harold Pinter and Tom Stoppard, have recently opened here to contrastive receptions.

title: Mayor Suozzi of Glen Cove Says He'll Seek New Term Next Year
description: GLEN COVE, L.I.  I want to prove that the new government charter is going to work and I want the chance to put it into effect, said Mayor Vincent A. Suozzi, announcing his intention to run for reelection a year ahead of time.

title: Girl, 13, Is Dead After Refusing Marrow Transplant From Sister
description: BOSTON, Nov. 25 (AP)  A teenager, who declined to have boric marrow transplanted from her sister because of religion and the possible danger to her sister, is dead.

title: Police 'sting Operations Found to Reduce Thefts
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UPI)  A Federal report says that crimes of theft appear to be falling as a result of the Government's widely heralded sting operations  bogus fencing rings set up to snare thieves.

title: Dingoes, W agtails
description: Judith Wright is an Australian poet, author of 10 hooks of verse from which the present selection has been made. Assuming that American readers need help with work that conies out of an unfamiliar country, she pros vides an introduction telling us a hit about Australia, of where

title: Barbara Joan Mayrsohn Bride of Stephen P. Taft
description: Barbara Joan Mayrsohn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Mayrsohn of Purchase, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Stephen Pike Taft, son of Dr. and Mrs. Nathaniel B. Taft of White Plains. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony at the Brae Burn Country Club.

title: Giants Progress Is Key Asset for McVay
description: After The Fumble, Joe Pisarcik needed a police escort through the Giants Stadium parking lot. Bob Gibson, the man who called the play, was dismissed the next day by the front office. Everywhere, people are laughing at the Giants, saying The Fumble is just symbolic of a franchise that has not been in the National Football League playoffs since 1963.

title: Documents Indicate Corps Misled Congress on Major Southern Canal
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 25  Thousands of confidential memorandums and other internal documents of the Army Corps of Engineers indicate a continuing practice of accounting manipulation, guesswork and misleading statements to Congress to justify construction of the $2 billion TennesseeTombigbed Waterway through Mississippi and Alabama.

title: Racial HardLiner Elected Party Head in Transvaal
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 25Prospects for an evolution toward wider rights for South African blacks dimmed today with the election of a hardline white supremacist, Andries P. Treurnicht, as leader of the governing National Party in populous Transvaal Province.

title: CARE FOR RETARDED IN DISPUTE ON COAST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 25  Every so often, while he is playing at the special nursery for retarded children where he lives, 12yearold Phillip Becker drops his toys, taps his chest and says, Stop that.

title: The First Lady Next Door
description: ONE day during her short reign as the 38th First Lady of this land, it befell Betty Blotimer Ford to christen a Bicentennial jet by cracking a bottle across its nose. I stuck my fingers into the stuff running down the plane, she recounts in The Times of My Life, and tasted it to see if it was really champagne. It was, but I suddenly thought, Oh oh, how undignified, old girl : you shouldn't have done that.

title: A Day for Rugby Ruffians Lures 400 to Randalls Island
description: This is a game for ruffians played by gentlemen, as opposed to soccer, which is a game for gentlemen played by ruffians, said Ed Lebow, the vice president of the host New York Rugby Club, yesterday, as more than 400 men and women gathered for their annual booting, tackling and passing jamboree on Randalls Island.

title: East German Children Receive Special Early Training in Music
description: LEIPZIG, East Germany In an effort along the lines of the sports program that brought East Germany more medals than the United States at the last Olympics, children in their first year of school here are being selected for special musical training aimed at developing performers of international stature.

title: Homosexual Acts: Are They Criminal?
description: TRENTON EFFORTS now under way to make homosexual acts a crime in New Jersey run counter to an emerging judicial philosophy that the bedroom is an area in which government should not meddle.

title: Deaths
description: APFELBAUMWilliam, on November 21, 1978, in his 138th year, beloved husband of Anna, adored by his daughters, Francine Ramon, Jacqueline Schwartz, Rhoda Lembeck, and his ten grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren.

title: POLITICS
description: IN politics, as in love, little things do mean a lot. Take the case of the Governor and the Town of Sterling and its new tractor.

title: The Third Generation Is Coming Up Fast
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Kaiser is a name that suits a dynasty of empire builders, and it seems apt for the third generation of company executives, 36yearold Edgar Fosburgh Kaiser Jr.

title: Michigan Topples Ohio State, 143; Goes to Rose Bowl Against U.S.C.
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 25  The largest crowd in the 56year history of Ohio Stadium, 88,358, most of them Ohio State rooters, waited and waited for something to happen today in the football game against Michigan. Not much happened, except that Michigan beat the Buckeyes, 143, in routine fashion.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Holism. You won't find it listed yet in your dictionary, but you're certain to hear a lot about it during the months to come. Holism  sometimes it's spelled wholism  is a way of life that its converts believe will enable them to maintain the health of the body, mind and spirit with minimal use of drugs, surgery or hardware. It's a compound of alternate activities, some new, some ancient, some native American, some alien, that became popular during the 70's yoga, accupuncture, homeopathy, herbal ism, hypnotism, biofeedback, massage, natural childbirth, med tation, dance and music therapy, to name a few. But holism, its advocates maintain, is a total greater than the sum of its parts.

title: At Stake Is Algeria's Future
description: PARIS The eclipse of Houari Boumediene, Algeria's steely 51yearold leader, suddenly revealed how completely he had concentrated power In his own hands and how fully Algeria's activist role in world affairs was a reflection of his own personality.

title: A Coin That Survived Wild West Is Caught in Washington Crossfire
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UPI) The silver coins emerged from the Old West of boom towns, gunfights and gambling halls. For almost a century they survived in dank basements, escaping the blast furnaces of World War I.

title: A Writer's Remains Are Restored to Peru
description: LIMA, Peru, Nov. 25  King Juan Carlos of Spain today restored to the people of Cuzco, the ancient imperial city of the Incas, an urn containing the ashes of Garcilaso de la Vega, a native son who became one of the great writers of the Spanish Conquest.

title: Con Ed's RefusetoEnergy Plan: Will the Dollars Make Sense?; NEWS ANALYSIS
description: WHITE PLAINS THE CONSOLIDATED EDISON proposal to aid the county in solving its solidwaste disposal problem is not a unique undertaking by a utility, but the financial and technical arrangements the utility is proposing differ significantly from those set forth by two utilities that pioneered in the use of refusederived energy.

title: ANTIQUES
description: The collecting of objects shaped by nature or made by man postdates the Garden of Eden, but probably not by much. The ancient Egyptians and Chinese were buried with collectibles, one way such antiquities survived wars and natural disasters and were there to be rediscovered when tombs were reopened.

title: Princeton Alumnus Assays Changes
description: PRINCETON A 1952 graduate of Princeton University reached a startling conclusion recently when he compared the course of study today with when he was an undergraduate.

title: 15YearOld Is Sentenced to Life For 2 Shooting Deaths in Florida
description: MIAMI, Nov. 24 (UPI)  A Circuit Court judge sentenced 15yearold Lester Enriquez to three consecutive life sentences today for the murders last Sept. 19 of a Florida highway patrolman and a tow truck driver.

title: The art of luring a man.; THE 01.1 MONEY MAN; THE LAWYER; THE DOCTOR; THE .13 BOARDROOM?; THE PROFESSOR; THE ARMY OFFICER
description: OK. So you've made it to the boardroom with your no frills suits and it's lonely at the top. If you've paid close attention to the dictates of John Molloy in his The Woman's Dress for Success Book, you may have found, as he so pointedly warns, that dressing to succeed in business and dressing to be sexually attractive are almost mutually exclusive. Alas, a choice between the bedroom and the boardroom.

title: The City
description: Friends of Animals, an animal welfare group, denounced as inhumane the city's plan to find a sea lion for the Central Park Zoo that had been taken into captivity before 1972. Under the Federal Marine Mammal Protection Act, only sea lions captured before that year may be purchased by the zoo. To obtain a sea lion captured later, the zoo would have to install an expensive pool filtration system that the Parks Commission says the city cannot afford.

title: Alex Van Riper Sets Nuptials for Dec. 31
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Austin Van Riper of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Alexandra Jay Van Riper to Peter Cameron Bulkley, son of Marilyn Bulkley of Irvine, Calif., and Roger Charles Bulkley of New Canaan, Conn.

title: U.S. OilLease Policy Leaves Questions
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25  Congress made important changes this year in the law that governs offshore oil drilling, and the Interior Department made a major policy change this month that could increase Government revenues from offshore fields. But important questions of national policy regarding the outer continental shelf remain unresolved.

title: CHILDREN'S BOORS
description: Odette is a baby bird, in a nest, in a tree, in Paris, in the spring. Out she falls, landing on the hat of an old man who plays his accordion in the Metro station. title: Sunday Observer
description: Once, while selling a book, I helped a man make sausage one morning on television in Baltimore. Afterward, he gave me a pound. It is the only profit I have ever realized from my excursions into television. They never sold a single txxik, if the publisher's royalty statements can be believed. In fact, I cut such a dim figure on the tube that the publisher pleaded with me to abandon it lest I infect his entire list with bankruptcy.

title: Coast Surfer Attacked by Shark; Wounded Hand Gets 50 Stitches
description: JUPITER, Fla.. Nov. 25 (UPI)  A 17yearold surfer suffered a severely lacerated hand that required 50 stitches when a shark attack him oft Jupiter beech, the authorities said today.

title: Carter Plans 2d Cut in Arms Sales
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25  The Carter Administration plans to reduce arms sales to nonallied nations for the second year in a row, according to Government officials, even though the White House has failed to get other exporters of military equipment to follow suit.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Cuba is the only country to have named its best brand of ice cream after a ballet. Coppelia ice cream, especially strawberry, is delicious. Ballet, in fact, seemed ominipresent during the week I spent in Havana during the sixth International Ballet Festival that closed after three weeks on Nov. 19.

title: Iran's Troubles End Boom Times for Foreign Companies

An American executive, asked recently whether Iran would continue to be the booming market it has been since 1973, replied, Oh no. It was too wild. too eood to be true.

title: Lincoln Hospital's Chaos Traced To Battle Conditions in Bronx
description: When Lincoln Hospital rose in the South Bronx two years ago, Phoenixlike in the surrounding rubble, political leaders described it as a magnificent, technically advanced, $250 million municipal gift to an impoverished population with severe medical problems.

description: STARKE, Fla., Nov. 24 (AP) 4 A 23yearold convict was stabbed to death and two other inmates were captured in an escape attempt yesterday at Florida State Prison, a prison spokesman said.

description: MELVILLE, L. I., Nov. 25  When you live next to the Long Island Expressway, you make concessions. According to one homeowner, you can even imagine that the traffic sounds like ocean waves.

title: Austerity in Valhalla: We Don't Want It to Happen Again
description: VALHALLA EACH day after classes at Valhalla High School, students could be seen milling around the school parking lot, listening radios and chatting. But more recently, students have begun to wander through the village looking for things to do. The picture has been disturbing to some residents who attribute the increase in loitering to the cancellation of sports and other extracurricular activities, a consequence the district's defeated budget, and they decided to do something about it.

title: F.B.I. IS CONCERNED ABOUT CRIME FILES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UPI)  A national police intelligence organization set up in 1956 to develop files on organized crime has been plagued for years by disclosures of material to the mob, according to files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Fusina: The Heisman Candidate With the No. 1 Supporting Cast
description: Joe Paterno, Penn State's head coach, has been on his soap box for so long telling the world what a fine quarterback he has that one might get the impression Chuck Fusina is the only reason the Niltany Lions have won 19 games in a row and are finally ranked No. I in the nation.

title: Television This Week
description: 5:15 P.M. (2) FESTIVAL OF LIVELY ARTS FOR YOUNG PEOPLE. A Special Day in the Year of the Child. A onehour special celebrating children throughout the world and featuring Samoan singers, Congolese dancers and the music of Maori natives of New Zealand and American Indians.

title: PEOPLE
description: In his first big managerial move at the Chrysler Corporation, Lee A. Iacocca last week named his close friend and former colleague, Harold K. Sperlich, as head of development for all new cars and trucks. Mr. Sperlich, 49 years old, left a top planning post at Ford to join Chrysler a year ago after a dispute with Henry Ford II, Mr. Iacocca's old boss. He replaces Richard A. Vining, 53, who will now work on the building of cars and trucks. Mr. Vining succeeds R.K. Brown, who remains in charge of sales and marketing. Mr. Sperlich's new title is group vice president for product development, and Mr. Vining and Mr. Brown remain executive vice presidents. All the moves were decided jointly by Mr. Iacocca and John J. Riccardo, the company chairman.

title: JOURNEY TO ESRIAL AND EGIPT
description: The habit of enmity dies hard and it may be true, as an Israeli acquaintance recently quipped, that a swift peace settlement would have been an insult to 30 years of conflict. Even now, when dinnerparty.

And the novel takes as its subject the hero or victim of another particularly American phenomenon, the world of Pentecostal religious fanaticism  smalltown revival meetings, healers, inspired local preachers.

title: How the Japanese Imports Are Faring
description: Seven Japanese companies compete in the American auto market.
