title: A NeverEnding Battle Over The Bronx River and Parkway

title: TeenAger Slain on Date Was a Suspect in 3 Murders
description: An 18yearold man, shot to death Saturday afternoon in the Northeast Bronx along with his 17yearold date, was named by the police yesterday as the alleged killer of two Bronx youths who was wanted also for questioning in yet another slaying two months ago in his own neighborhood in upper Manhattan.

title: ANTIEUROPE TREND MOUNTS IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Nov. 23  AntiEuropean feeling is building up again in Britain, the Common Market's most reluctant member, forcing Prime Minister James Callaghan to reappraise his position.

title: CHESS

title: THEATER Behind the Scenes At the Goodspeed
description: EAST HADDAM CONSIDERING that the Goodspeed Guild did not come into being until Jan. 23, 1975, one can only wonder at how the Goodspeed Opera House ever functioned without it.

description: THIS is the time of year when the shapes and sizes of trees in a home landscape become important. Flamboyant flower colors have faded. Only the green velvet of the lawn remains. Trees stand out in their elegance or ugliness, whatever the case may be.

title: SPORTS

And in her first year on the women's professional tennis tour, Caroline Stoll did go a long way: from 60th to 28th place on the computer rankings, 12th in the final Grand Prix standings, prize money in excess of $40,001.1 and four tournament titles.

description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25 He promised utopia and delivered death. And when warnings came of how it might end  and they came for more than year  almost no one listened.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: THE coming of cold weather marks the unwelcome arrival of steadily increasing fuel bills once more. Although there is not much the individual homeowner can do about the increasing cost of oil, gas and electricity, there are a number of steps that can be taken to reduce the amount of heating fuel consumed (heating accounts for the largest percentage of the annual energy requirements of most homes in this area).

title: Bulletin in Philadelphia Is Back To Normal as Press Strike Ends

description: LAFAYETTE THE prices are crazy. I don't know where it's all going. How can you sell low when you have to buv high?

title: City Schools Chancellor Looks Ahead And Back
description: Frank J. Macchiarola, now in his fifth month as chancellor of New York City's schools, is confronting many of the broad, seemingly insoluble problems that have plagued his predecessors: a decline in student performance, a high dropout and truancy rate. Last week, there were more immediate, but no less important ones: asbestos contamination, a failure by some officials to make sure that students rot required inoculations. In a recent interview with Marcia Chambers, who reports on education for The New York Times, the chancellor discussed some things he has learned about the nation's largest public school system and his plans for making it better. The following are excerpts from that inten,iew.

title: New Recourse forVictims of Domestic Violence
description: DOMESTIC violence  between husband and wife, parents and children, or members of the same family  is nothing new to police officers who have long responded, often reluctantly, to such assaults within the household. It is new to criminal prosecutors, however. Until recently, Family Court was the only recourse for victims of such violence. Now under new legislation, a victim has the right to choose between Family and Criminal Court, and it will be up to the police officers to explain the tlifference.

title: THE LIVELY ARTS
description: CHRISTMAS began in July for the Eglevsky Ballet, as it usually does, with the first open rehearsals to select children for the annual production of The Nutcracker, which the company will begin performing in a fourweek tour starting Friday.

description: Shortly after World War II, the Federal Government initiated a major housing program, known as Section 608, that resulted in the development of thousands of garden apartments. Chief Bob Baeten identified the two as Cecil McClure, owner of the boat and apparently from Tampa, and Mathew Cobb, whose home town was not known.

Kaiser built the Hoover, Bonneville and Grand Coulee Dams  turned out thousands of World War II ships and jeeps  founded a health plan that cares for 3.3 million Americans  manufactured missile and aircraft parts. Before his death in 1967, he had emblazoned his name on an international mOustrial empire that would encompass 230 companies and subsidiaries with 97,000 employees.

description: I have heard that sunflower seed hulls have a toxic substance that retards growth of other plants. We have quite a pile of hulls accumulating beneath our bird feeder and would like to use them as a mulch on our plants. Is this advisable? P.M., Waterbury, Conn.

title: MEN GUARDS LIMITED AT WOMEN'S PRISON
description: Restrictions on the use of male guards in a women's prison have been ordered by a Federal judge, in Manhattan who stressed the right of a prison inmate to some minimum of privacy.

title: The Ruling Liberal Democrats Must Choose Between Two Very Different Men

Depending on whether or not the incumbent conservative Prime Minister, Takeo Fukuda, is retained or a more progressive challenger replaces him, the outcome has deep implications for Japan and indeed all of Asia.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: Isaac Asimov, the prolific scientistwriter, is at work on a book describing all the possible ways the world might come to an end. And while he doesn't think any of them is likely to happen, apparently he isn't taking any chances: Hence, Requirement for Survival, the topic for his lecture tonight at the Plandome Forum. Touching on such issues as disarmament, world famine and overpopulation, he will speak at 7:30 P.M. at the North Shore Unitarian Church, Plandome Road, Manhasset, with the $4 admission earmarked for the Unitarian Universalist United Nations Office. 6276560.

title: Purchasers of Portable Air Tank Warned on Possible Explosions
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. (U (UPI)  The Consumer Product Safety Commission today warned consumers about 118,000 portable air tanks that might explode. Such tanks have been linked to numerous injuries and one death.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: An Emergency on the 8:14 From Florence; Plea for Help; Waiting at Bologna; 'should I go to Milan or get off at Bologna and wait? Did the train have a radio so we could get in touch with Florence? Would the police find Betty and send her on?
description: After three weeks last summer in the galleries of Europe, especially Florence, my wife and I decided to spend two days at Stresa on Lake Maggiore in northern Italy before our charter flight home. We chose the 9:10 A.M. train from Florence to Milan on Saturday morning. It was faster than the 8:14 and still gave us 90 minutes to switch to the Stresa train at Milan Central, that modern classical monument to Mussolini and his policy of running the trains on time.

title: New Evidence Is Hinted In Assassination Film
description: DALLAS, Nov. 25 (AP)  Greatly enlarged frames of movie film taken the day President John F. Kennedy was assassinated may show two persons in sixthfloor window of the Texas School Book Depository, a photo analyst hired by The Dallas Morning News said today.

title: Our Most Widespread Dramatic Art Is Our Most Unfree
description: 'F ame, an hourlong play that I have written expressly for television, will be shown Thursday evening at 10 on NBC. The event prompts two questions: How did I come to write a play for television? And why have established American playwrights just about ceased to write for the medium?

title: FILM VIEW
description: oney  there's too much of it being spent and not enough to go around. Because in times like these publicity claims, like everything else, tend to become inflated, filled with hot air, we shouldn't necessarily believe that the forthcoming Superman, based on the comic strip, actually cost $78,000,000, but even if it cost half that much, one must wonder whether or not something is wrong. Forget the art part; it seems bad business to make a film that has to become one of the biggest moneymakers of all time simply to show a small profit. Movies can't cure cancer or the common cold and, much of the time, they can't even cure boredom. What is going on?

title: Test Coal Converter Closing
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI)  The Energy Department said today that lack of money was forcing it to close an experimental plant at Bruceton, Pa., designed to test an advanced process for turning coal into cleanburning synthetic natural gas. The $17 million plant began operation in July 1976. At full operation, it could convert 72 tons of coal a day into 1.2 million cubic feet of methane gas.

title: DINING OUTLong on Taste, Short on Ambiance
description: WE have from time to time suggested that there are no ultimate truths where taste is concerned and that our star ratings should be taken only for what they are  one person's judgment. We have also suggested that restaurants may be of interest because of factors beyond the actual goodbetterbest quality of the food: unusual ambiance, specialized cuisine, attractive nriria and so forth.

title: Sports Today
description: A.A.U. national junior men's 8kilometer and Eastern Masters A.A.U. 10kilometer championships, at Van Cortlandt Park, Broadway and 244th Strreet, the Bronx, A.M. and 12:30 P.M., respectively.

title: Audrey Theresa Hoxter Bride
description: Audrey Theresa Hoxter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Curtis J. Hoxter of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married there yesterday in Temple Israel to Robert W. Strecker, son of Mrs. Marion Strecker of Melrose, Mass., and the late Wilbur Strecker. Rabbi Philip Bregman performed the ceremony.

title: The Old County Leader Isn't What He Used to Be
description: When he first took office, Mayor Koch had New York City's five Democratic county political leaders over for a Gracie Mansion breakfast every few weeks. At the first one, the Mayor  serving in an era of proclaimed municipal austerity and himself political product of the party's selfdescribed reform movement  admonished the leaders, Now remember I can't give you judges or jobs.

title: Other Ideas & Trends
description: Either the statistics are getting better or the parents are getting worse. A study commissioned by the National Institutes of Mental Health reports that the incidence of child abuse in the United States is twice as high as previously estimated. Some of the more cheerless statistics: nearly 4 percent of all children under age 17 are subject to abuse; parents under 30 are 62 percent more likely to beat their children than parents between 31 and 50; and black and white parents are equally likely to beat their children, but blacks are more likely to get caught at it.

title: Jersey to Test TV in a Courtroom
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court will open its doors to television cameras next month in a oneday experiment that will help determine whether trials will eventually be televised throughout the state.

title: F.A. Allen 3d Weds Helen Mills Watson
description: The marriage of Helen Mills Watson to Frank A. Allen 3d took place at the bride's home in New York yesterday. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church, minister of the Unitarian Church of All Souls, performed the ceremony.

title: THEATER Behind the Scenes
description: CONSIDERING that the Goodspeed Guild did not come into being until January 1975, one can only wonder at how the Goodspeed Opera House ever functioned without it.

title: Spooks: The Haunting of America.
description: Someone, somewhere, sometime did a piece on those people publishing companies hire specifically for their skill in distilling books down to a series of oneliners. They're the ones

title: WOLFF'S TEAM FIRST IN REISINGER BRIDGE
description: DENVER, Nov. 15 For North Ameri ca's top contract bridge stars, the tournament year approached its climax here this afternoon with 30 teams battling in the semifinal stage of the Reisinger boardamatch team championship, the concluding event of the American Contract Bridge League's fall nationals. The field will be cut Co 11 teams for the final tomorrow, and the winner will qualify for playoffs to determine the 1980 American world championship team.

title: Justice Dept. May Bring Charges In Scaffold Collapse Fatal to 51
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UPI)  The Justice Department said today that it was looking into a West Virginia scaffolding collapse that killed 51 workers to determine if criminal charges should be brought against a NeW Jersey company. The Labor Department yesterday forwarded its report on the April 27 tragedy to the Justice Department for possible action.

title: Long Island/ This Week
description: BALDWIN  Oils and watercolors by Natalie Palmer; silver jewelry by Adele Lawrence; through Thursday; Library, 2385 Grand Ave. For hours, 2236228.

title: Marinho to Add Flair To Roster of Cosmos
description: Francisco Marinho had been frequently on the agenda of the board of directors meetings of the Cosmos the last year or so. Now that he has been added to the team's galaxy of stars, the young Brazilian defender will probably be more often on the agenda because of his temperament and actions off the field. On the field, Marinho will be a matter of discussion and concern of every team in the North American Soccer League.

title: Elizabeth P. Barringer Fiance of John S. Clark
description: Mr. and Mrs. C. Minor Barringer of Chadds Ford, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Pratt Barringer, to John S. Clark, son of Alexander Clark of Cambridge, Mass., and Rockport, Me., and the late Mrs. Clark. A May wedding is planned.

title: CRIME
description: In the past, Michael Sinclair has dreamed up some wild ideas, notably in The Dollar Covenant. Scotland was owned  by the Americans. In his newest book, THE MASTERPLAYERS (Norton, $8.95), he sticks closer to the amenities of the espionage novel. But this is one of those quiet espionage novels, in which the hero is an amateur, manipulated by a woman and by forces that he can only dimly perceive.

title: Two Make Their Local Debuts With the Pennsylvania Ballet
description: A sure sign of a good ballet production is its ability to support cast changes. That point was proved again when Tamara Hadley and William DeGregory made their local debuts in the Pennsylvania Ballet's new Copp& lia Friday afternoon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Miss Klopman Becomes Bride Of C.R. Kelsey
description: Betsy Ellyn Klopman, daughter of Mr and Mrs. William Allen Klopman of Greensboro, N.C., and Quogue, L.I., was married in Greensboro yesterday to Charles Roland Kelsey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert John Kelsey of Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. Roland Jones performed the ceremony in St. Francis Episcopal Church. He was assisted by Suffragan Bishop Charles J. Child Jr. of the Episcopal Diocese of Atlanta.

title: Commuted Sentences
description: DURING the newspaper strike, train commuters who were compulsive readers had to fall back on books. Not being in the habit, many of them went to their local libraries and bookstores and picked up the first thing that came to hand. The results were interesting.

title: A alto in Finland
description: The Americans at the next table seemed disappointed. They had apparently just returned from a bus tour of Helsinki, or perhaps from a boat tour through the Finnish lake district. They were complaining about all the raw fish, about the language and about the lack of interesting buildings and things.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: I MY MOTHER/MY SELF, by Nancy Friday. (Dell, $2.50.) A discussion of the motherdaughter relationship.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: When industrialization got under way in the 17th century, food production soared, and that helped set off population explosion that has reverberated for 300 years. The echoes have included predictions of mass starvation and world chaos by the year 2000. Last week, however, the Census Bureau reported what one of its chief demographers called a major turning point in world history, a small but perceptible slowing in the growth rate of world population.

title: Israel. Publishes. Annex to Treaty Setting Normal Ties With Egypt
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 25  Details of how normal relations between Israel and Egypt are to be established were made public tonight when the Israeli Government published the annex to the draft of the proposed peace treaty between the two countries.

title: Rhode Island Is Baffled As Rare Birds Appear
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 25 (AP)  Some rare birds from as far away as South Africa have been. sighted in Rhode Island in the last two weeks, and birdwatchers are baffled by their appearance.

title: A Jockey Who Rides A RockandRoll Range
description: IF you went back to the time before cars and juke boxes, and used terms like disk jockey and rockandroll, people might guess you were referring to the rider of some strange kind of horse and the sensations he got while riding it. And if you were referring to meg Linn successful young WNEW disk jockey, whose passion for horseback riding on the trails in White Plains is matched only by her love for rockandroll music they would not be far from wrong.

title: Alligators May Be Endangered, But Their Smugglers Live Well
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UPI)  The breakup of an international alligator smuggling ring has disclosed that some of the smugglers were previously convicted of similar offenses and that illegal alligator exports are apparently profitable even when the smugglers are caught.

title: Oregon, Improvising Quartet, Gives Concert at Carnegie Hall
description: Oregon, an improvising quartet that has been together since the beginning of the decade, gave its first concert at Carnegie Hall Friday night, and one couldn't have asked for a better illustration of the possibilities and pitfalls of free improvisation. The group customarily strings together its preconceived compositions with entirely spontaneous dialogues, and it was these dialogues, some of them considerably longer than the tunes they connected, that provided many of the concert's high points and most of its lows.

title: World Flattens For Old Society Of Geographers
description: The American Geographical Society has helped explore places remote and forbidding  polar extremities, subterranean depths, jungles and deserts, even outer space. But nothing equals its melancholy adventure, now finally completed, from which there is no return.

title: Ellen M. Schneider Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Schneider of North Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen M. Schneider, to Dr. Gary S. Hitzig, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Hitzig of Deerfield Beach, Fla. An August wedding is planned. Miss Schneider attended C.W. Post College and graduated from Boston University. She is with the J. Walter Thompson Advertising Company in New York. Her fiance is chief resident in urologic surgery at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He is an alumnus of Brooklyn College and the Downstate Medical School in Brooklyn.

title: Shero Succeeding by Putting Rangers on the Defensive
description: Fog? What Fog? asks Sonny Werblin about Fred Shero's nickname.

title: No End Of Messiahs
description: LEONIA, N.J. We can expect more disasters like the People's Temple mass suicide in Guyana.

title: U.S. Is SecondRichest Country, New Survey Finds
description: WASHINGTON, NOv. 25 (AP)  Despite its world trade problems, the United States is second only to Kuwait as the world's wealthiest country, University of Pehnsylvania economists report.

title: Missing Diamonds Stir Search
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25 (UPI)  The police were looking for Leila White of Hollywood, who worked for a diamond broker and allegedly picked about 5180,000 worth of diamonds for him last week. The broker called the postal authorities Wednesday to report that the shipment of 1,140 diamonds had never arrived. A check disclosed that the woman apparently had signed for the four boxes of diamonds last Thursday and had not been seen since.

title: Phenomenology Has a New Star
description: The ascent of Pope John Paul II promises to touch off a new round of controversy among philosophers over the virtues of phenomenology, a field that enjoyed a heyday when championed by the likes of JeanPaul Sartre, the French existentialist, but considered by American scholars something of curiosity. John Paul is the author of Person and Action, a treatise on phenomenology published in 1969 and soon to be translated into English on the impetus of its author's newfound celebrity.

title: Houston and Texas Succumb in Upsets
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., Nov.25 (AP) James Hadnot snared a 2point conversion pass late in the fourth quarter to give Texas Tech a 2221 upset victory over Houston today in a Southwest Conference game.

title: Susan Smyth Sets Bridal for October
description: Susan Smyth, an assistant vice president with the Emigrant Savings Bank in New York, and James Michael Maloney, a vice president with the Pioneer National Title Insurance Company in Morristown, N. J., plan to be married next Oct. 20 in Tarrytown, N. Y.

title: Modern Western Art Shown in Peking
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 24  A British artist based in Hong Kong has held the first show ever staged in Peking of contemporary Western painting, attracting a small number of Chinese officials, painters and curious individuals.

title: Winthrop Reid Planning Bridal
description: The engagement of Winthrop Reid to Edward E. Burns Jr. of Rumson, N.J., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Fergus Reid of New York and York Harbor, Me., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Burns of Sodus Point, N.Y., and Sarasota, Fla.

title: Why the Wrong People Don't Get Invited to the Right Parties
description: There's something exciting, wonder ful and glamorous going on in New York every night of the year and, amazing though it may be, most of these events manage to stagger along without the exciting, wonderful and glamorous presence of most of us.

title: TRUANCY INCREASING IN THE CITY SCHOOLS
description: William P. Richardson, a Transit Authority patrolman who is part of New York City's truant squad, stopped stroller in Times Square the other day and said: Now, how old are you, son? And shouldn't you be in school?

title: J.R. Kell Weds Sara Thompson
description: Sara Chattin Thompson and John Russell Kell were married yesterday at Upper Bank House in. Media, Pa., by the Rev. W. Benjamin Holmes, an Episcopal priest. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wirt Lord Thompson Jr. of Media, graduated from Miss Porter's School and the University of Pennsylvania. Her husband, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Kell of Perkasie, Pa., an alumnus of Pennsylvania and the Temple University Law School. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Robert Wilson After Einstein
description: In November of 1976, Robert Wilson was king of avantgarde New York. His Einstein on the Beach had sold out the Metropolitan Opera twice, winning a measure of critical respect and popular attention unprecedented for a SoHo performance piece. To be fair, Einstein was a cocreation of Mr. Wilson and Philip.

title: Later TO THE EDITOR
description: I want to thank you for the Robert Jastrow story ("Have Astronomers Found God? June 25). It is, quite simply, the most exciting single article I have over read.

title: Louisa Greene Wed To Kevin McCall
description: St. Michael Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Louisa Aldrich Greene, daughter of Mrs., William Aldrich Greene of Greenwich and the late Mr. Greene, to Kevin McCall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Benton McCall 3d, also of Greenwich. The Rev. Thomas J. Guinan performed the ceremony.

title: FISHING
description: FISHING for striped bass along the East Coast has been in steady decline for several years. But the fall run of bass around Sandy Hook indicates that such angling is on the upswing.

description: I am typing this with one hand. My other hand, other arm and shoulder and, for that matter, half my body are encased in a plaster cast. I was a football player.

In New York, the firm of Serko & Simon runs an advertisement showing a sunrise with the legend, A new day has dawned for those seeking and providing legal services.

title: Polish Rumors About Gierek Fly
description: WARSAW, Nov. 18  Rumors are major Polish industry, but they are consumer items with a limited life span.

title: A National Theater In Search of Identity
description: The National Theater has just presented Betrayal, Harold Pinter's new play about adultery, which was coolly greeted by the critics. It was felt that although Mr. Pinter had abandoned his usual mystifying tactics, he had put nothing substantial in their place. The new work was directed by the chieftain of the National, Peter Hall, who regularly stages Mr. Pinter's plays in the icy, immobile style they have perfected together. The play is concerned, not for the first time in Mr. Pinter's case, with a triangular relationship  on this occasion husband, wife and wife's lover. But this time there are no ambiguities. Mr. Pinter fills us in on the details of the relationship by the simple means of presenting us with a series of flashbacks, taking us from the end of the affair to its beginning. But he tells us almost nothing about the individuals though with his usual economy he does delineate their social world of publishers, literary agents and middleclass cultural gossips  and thus prevents us from taking any great interest in them.

title: Tobi A. Solomon, a Teacher, Bride of Richard W. Halpern
description: Tobi Ava Solomon and Richard Walter Halpern were married yesterday evening in Temple Beth El in Swampscott, Mass., by Rabbi Ephraim Bennett.

title: Dana Seavfv
description: Q. Most of us think New Yorkers rake in more money than folks living in other parts of the country. Is that fact or fancy?

title: Atlantic Salmon Future Murky
description: Even as efforts to bring Atlantic salmon back to the rivers of New England are succeeding, the future of this most splendid of all food and game fishes remains in doubt.

title: G.O.P. Governors to Meet Today
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 25 (UPI)  The nation's 12 Republican governors and nine governorselect are scheduled to meet in Colonial Williamsburg tomorrow to attend the threeday winter meeting of the Republican Governors Association at the elegantlyrestored site of what was once Colonial Virginia's capital. The meeting will include working sessions on state government problems and political campaigning.

title: A Libretto for SALT
description: Observing the politics of SALT these days is like spending a night at the opera. Emotions are rising all around but it is virtually impossible to follow the story. The arms control treaty still lies hidden in the wings but expert factions have formed on stage. President Carter acts scared, throwing money around to appease the treaty's likely opponents and even threatening to call it an executive agreement to evade the Senate's twothirds majority rule. But he also talks serenely about the Russians strength and intentions as though only paranoids would worry about them. The Soviet leaders, meanwhile, boast to visiting senators that they well understand our ratification process while demonstrating precisely the opposite; they will not be much help.

title: Indian Remains From Dam Site To Be Reburied With Respect
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Nov. 25 (AP) The skeletal remains of Indians that were unearthed in construction of the Grand Coulee Dam nearly 40 years ago are finally going to be reburied.

title: George Wilson, 64
description: DETROIT, Nov. 25 (AP)  George Wilson, the last man to coach the Detroit Lions to a National Football League championship, died of a heart attack Thursday at Sinai Hospital in Detroit. He was 64 years old.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: MY friends in Los Angeles were talking about the Island, because they used to live there, and I still do. It was funny, the things they remembered.

title: A Friend of the Revolution
description: OF the three giant figures that loom up out of the darkness of the Russian Revolution, Trotsky's is the most dominant and most dramatic. His immense vitality was matched by his versatility. As a politician, his contribution to the cause of the Revolution  in 1905 and from 1917 to 1921  rivaled that of Lenin. Stalin defended him but was dwarfed by him. He was preeminent as an orator, a critical writer on a wide variety of themes, a historian and, above all, as a social and political thinker. Two books devoted to Trotsky's ideas have just appeared. Baruch Kneipaz has immersed himself in the vast corpus of Trotsky's writings, published and unpublished, and produced a long and erudite analysis of every aspect of his thought. Irving Howe, constricted within the limits of the Modern Masters series, has written an excellent short account that he calls a political essay. He has, as he explains, relied for a skeleton of facts on Isaac Deutscher's classic biography, and covered it with a running commentary on the issues that preoccupied Trotsky throughout his career.

title: Giants Need Paterno
description: The schedule did the Giants a favor. Instead of having to bear the boos at Giants Stadium today, they are in Buffalo, far from the reverberations of last Sunday's incredible 1917 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles on Joe Pisarcik's fumble that resulted in the sudden dismissal of Bob Gibson as offensive coordinator. Now the

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER Church With Tie to Press Freedom Will Get U.S. Aid
description: MOUNT VERNON EARLIER this month, President Carter signed a bill affecting 100 parks, rivers, trails and historic sites. The apparently routine action included a provision acceptIna donation of property located within the square of South Columbus Avenue, South Third Avenue, Edison Avenue and South Fulton Avenue in Mount Vernon, and it opened the way for the transfer of St. Paul's Church to the National Park Service.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: If it hadn't been for the gaggle of geese that James A. Michener saw feeding on grains of corn a few years 1'o in the Chesapeake Bay area, his now sweeping historical novel might he about the Muslim world, or the Caribbean. Instead, it is Chesapeake, which won out over the other two ideas that were cooking in his head, he said, because I felt an identity with those birds so overpowering that I knew I had found the leitmotif for my novel.

title: Nonviolent Provocation
description: DAVID J. GARROW, a graduate student in political science al Duke University, tells us in his preface that this work was begun as a tutorial paper and was then expanded into a senior honors thesis. It is a thorough and clearly written scholarly study of the 1965 directaction campaign in Selma, Ala., that resulted in passage of the Federal Voting Rights Act Die legal and political aspects are covered, as well as the civilrights movement.

title: ANTIQUES
description: ALTHOUGH some Long Island antiques dealers have complained that it is increasingly difficult to find Americana of quality and interest at affordable prices, a recent trip to several shops in Bridgehampton and Sag Harbor indicates that the supply of country furniture and folk art in the area is by no means exhausted. A wide variety of objects  many of them of Long Island origin, and ranging from scrimshaw to corner cupboards to decoys  can be found in these shops.

title: Albany Freshmen's Key Goal: Tax Relief
description: IF the central political concern of Long Island voters these days is the property tax, they needn't worry about their new State Assemblymen and Senators: Whatever their views on other issues and their political party affiliations, all seven new legislators say that propertytax relief will be their central worry in the next T poiclattire.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Tactical question. In a play, how many times can man whip a pistol from his holster, or even two pistols from two holsters if he's wellequipped, point the weapon or weapons straight at another fellow, announce that he's going to shoot the other fellow dead  and then not do it? Twice? Three times? Five times? Seven? Or did you give up hope after six?

title: Four Poets
description: Marge Piercy has published five novels and five books of poetry. The spirit most felt in this book is generous love, but 'love combined with scrutiny and even humor. Arranged

title: Subaru Marches to a Different Drummer, and Briskly
description: The big Japanese car sellers in America are seeing sales slip; Subaru sales are climbing  up by 20,000 units in the first 10 months from yearearlier sales of 66,000.

title: Emergency Funds: Count on Cash

Je suis absoluement &sole, Madame, the desk clerk said, with a suspicious glance at my American Express card, but we accept no cards. stared at him blankly. We will take your personal check, but naturally.

title: Golfing Victory By Park Officer. Creates a Furor
description: Last August, Michael Asheroff, deputy general manager of the Long Island Parks and Recreation Commission, played in a golf tournament on state park grounds that was cosponsored by the AnheuserBusch Company and the New York State Office of Parks and Recreation.

description: The Farmingdale High School football team capped its most successful season  unbeaten untied and unscored upon  by routing Sewanhaka of Floral Park, 320, yesterday for the Nassau Conference 1 championship at C.W. Post College.

title: Judge Drops One of Four Counts In Fiery a Collision of Ford Pinto
description: ELKHART, Ind., Nov. 25 (AP)Judge Charles Hughes of Elkhart Superior Court has dropped one of four criminal charges against the Ford Motor Company in a case involving the deaths of three women whose 1973 Pinto burst into flames after it was struck from behind.

title: Among the Graffiti,
description: WHEN I was attending Nassau Community College recently as a mature student, an unusual drama was being played out entirely within the ladiesroom. It provided sharply etched insight, for me, into what I had noticed in only the vaguest waythe attitude of most young people toward one another.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Today Molorsport Club of North Jersey fun rally: start at The Club House, Route 40 Westbound, Fairfield, N.J. Registration: 11 A.M.; first caroff noon.

title: Gorillas Don't Multiply Although TV Is Added
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 25 (UPI)  JeJe and Vanilla, Hermann Park Zoo's gorilla couple, have demanded and received longer televisionwatching hours, but so. far they have not snuggled up romantically with a late movie.

title: Inflation Fight Will Increase Pressures
description: WASHINGTON  If ever a Federal agency could called embattled, the Labor Department's Occupational Health and Safety Administration is it. Since it was established in 1970 to issue and enforce standards for safe and healthy workplaces, the agency has been forced to dig against business complaints about red tape and insupportable costs and labor charges that the manaate to protect workers was not being met. Now it is under attack from Carter Administration economists charged with reducing the cost of Federal regulation in general and enforcing the President's new wage and price standards in particular.

title: New Bible for Evangelicals Has Sold 1.2 Million Copies
description: The newest translation of the Bible, designed specifically for the booming evangelical Christian market, has sold 1.2 million copies just four weeks after publication, most of them even before the ink was on the paper.

title: It's not Leonia
description: BARCELONA WE LUNCH on our terrace overlooking this marvelous city, which has been called the Paris of the Mediterranean. My wife and I came here for one month to work and play. She came to study Spanish and use it in the marketplace, restaurants and shops. I came to ponder the wonders and mysteries of Antonio Gaudi, the great Catalonian architect.

title: The U.N. Plaza Seizes Prime Turf In Hotel Trade
description: For as long as anyone can remember, which is to say for the more than 30 years since the United Nations was plunked down in New York City, the Secretary of State would travel up from Washington each fall for the General Assembly session and set up camp in the Waldorf Astoria Hotel on Lexington Avenue.

title: Furchtbar! Schrecklich!
description: SHORTLY before 2 A.M. on Sunday, Aug. 13, 1961, sirens screamed down the deserted streets of East Berlin as squat tanks led military convoys to the 25mile border that separated the eastern part of the city from the west. Trucks of steelhelmeted Vopos (East Berlin policemen) took up positions at the main intersections. Troops unloaded wooden horses.

title: Service Roads Irk Homeowners Near Route 110
description: MELVILLE WHEN you live next to the Long Island Expressway, you make concessions. According to one homeowner, you can even imagine that the traffic sounds like ocean waves.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Nov. 25United Nations authorities, engaged in trying to restore stability in strifetorn southern Lebanon, are accusing Israel and Israelisupported Lebanese Christian militiamen of hampering their efforts and eroding the authority of the United Nations peacekeeping force.

title: Cartoon Art at Library
description: POUND RIDGE THE problem is that everyone here looks like they just stepped out of a New Yorker cartoon, one affluent matron said worriedlv. The context of her remark, a special exhibit at the Hiram Halle Memorial Library here of original cartoons and covers from The New Yorker magazine, couldn't have been more appropriate.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: HENRY JAMES, by Leon Edel. (Avon/Discus, vols., $2.95 each; boxed set, $14.75.) The life, mind, work and times of Henry James (18431916), expatriate American who became one of the leading contributors to the novel form. A richly detailed work, originally published between 1953 and 1972, that won both Pulitzer Prize and a National Book Award.

title: Hanna Lachert, Violinist, Plays A Varied Program of Sonatas

In recital Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, she offered a program of sonatas by Beethoven, Brahms and Hindemith, plus short works by Bartok and Szymanowski. It added up to a sensible program, and it was sensibly performed.

title: Jonestown Was a Model; Now It's Embarrassment

Guyana, Nov. 25Until the murders and suicides of last weekend in the northwestern hinterland of Guyana, the Jonestown communal settlement of the People's Temple had been considered by officials here to be a promising model project because of the many ways in which it seemed to fit so well into this complex country.

title: Carter's Mormon Award Becomes Women's Issue

The Rev. Lawrence McColl Horton performed the ceremony.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL

title: Correction
