description: Wanda Celeste Williams, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul T. Williams of Lawrenceville, N.J., was married in West Orange, N.J., yesterday to Mario L. Baeza, son of Alma Baeza of Verona, N.J., and the late Dr. Marco A. Baeza.

title: Girl, 9, First to Finish Coney Island Walk
description: It was just one year ago that Diane Romansky decided to become a cornpetitive walker.

title: STUDY FINDS DECLINE IN WORLD CROP SOIL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  Under the pressures of urban expansion, soil erosion and the encroachment of deserts, the world's supply of crop land is declining at an alarming rate, a new Worldwatch Institute study reports.

title: Penn State Takes Lambert Trophy
description: Penn State, undefeated and ranked No. 1 in the nation, won the Lambert Trophy a record 14th time yesterday for the oustanding performance by an Eastern major college football team this season.

title: The Best Games Electronics Can Produce
description: ONCE upon a time, playing a sports game entailed opening a board that simulated the arena, throwing some dice or spinning a spinner and then looking at a chart to see what had happened. A lot of luck and not much skill.

title: Nassau G.O.P. Feud Rings Familiar Note of Discord
description: New Yurk City's wild and wooly brand of politics has obviously been exported to Nassau County. In a scene reminiscent of past city administrations, the two top officeholders in the usually welldisciplined Nassau County Renublican organization.

title: United Press International
description: ACCEPTED IN CANADA: Vietnamese mother and child in Montreal after flight from refugee ship in Malaysia. Article on page A3. MONTREAL, Nov: 26  The first Vietnamese refugees to be accepted by the West from the Hai Hong, the freighter that for weeks could find no takers for its cargo of 2,500 people, arrived here late last night from Malaysia with expressions of gratitude for the Canadian Government.

title: Venezuela Seeks Loan
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 26 Venezuela's stateowned steel cornpany plans to raise $500 million through foreign loans over the next several months, bankers here said today.

title: Music: String Quartet At Noon Coffee Concert
description: IF art lovers can walk into museums and view the masters without charge, why shouldn't the same privilege be extended to music lovers? The reasons are. of course, the complex and costly mechanics of presenting live music. Even so, the Coffee Concerts at the Beacon Theater this year are trying out a noble experiment by offering music free to the public, with a voluntary contribution of any amount being accepted at the door.

title: Guyana Did Autopsies on Some Victims, U.S. Reports
description: DOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Del., Nov. 26  A State Department official said today that the department had received reports that autopsies had been done by Guyanese officials on an unspecified number of victims of the mass deaths in Jonestown, but that no autopsies were planned to be done at Dover, where 912 bodies have been flown.

title: The Region
description: Senator Clifford P. Case of New Jersey. who has steadfastly declined to step down in time to give Senatorelect Bill Bradley a seniority advantage in the new Congress, indicated yesterday that he might change his mind.

title: Jewish Bank Kept From Deal
description: PARIS, Nov. 26A prominent European investment bank has apparently become a victim of the Arab boycott, marking the first time in about three years that detailed allegations of discrimination against a Jewish bank by Arab interests have surfaced publicly in Europe.

title: U.S. Rules Harm Chrysler And A.M.C., Study Finds
description: DETROIT, Nov. 26  A Governmentsponsored study has concluded that Federal regulation of the automobile industry is causing economic hardship for the nation's two smallest car manufacturers and could threaten their survival in the event of a recession in the next seven years.

title: Nation's Military Services Are Facing a Severe Shortage of Doctors
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  Lieut. Col. James Rumbaugh, a 39yearold Army psychiatrist, earns about $47,000 a year. He says with a smile that many of his classmates at medical school are earning double that amount in civilian life.

title: Poland Combats Meat Shortage By Opening Commercial Shops
description: WARSAW  Long before the butcher shop opened at 7 A.M., customers had lined up outside, and less than four hours later, the sausages were all gone.

title: Bar Group Is Studying Allegations That Shea Withheld Information
description: The New York City Bar Association has begun an inquiry into allegations that William A. Shea, one of the city's most prominent lawyers, may have withheld damaging information on a former law partner who resigned as the city's General Services Commissioner last August and has since been indicted on Federal fraud charges.

title: Woman's Exchanze. 100 Years of Gentle Work
description: The New York Exchange for Woman's Work, an endearingly dowdy charity devoted to helping gentlewomen in reduced circumstances to become selfsupporting without losing their selfrespect, is celebrating its 100th anniversary this month. And, while its honor remains beyond reproach, the same cannot be said for the codfish balls.

title: Environmentalists Jubilant Over Mineral Springs Development Victory
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25  Conservationists are jubilant over their victory, in the final hours of the Congressional session, in one of the thorniest environmenal disputes in years  the battle over proposed mountain Disneyland in Mineral King Valley in the Sierra Nevada ranee.

title: Uranium: Australian Puzzle
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 26  The lonely traveler moving east from Darwin, capital of the Northern Territory, drives along a narrow ribbon of bitumen bisecting the sprawling wetlands of the region. After 120 miles he enters Arnnem Lana, an adoriginai reserve with spectacular waterfalls, rocky outcrops, thick foliage and crocodileinfested bayous.

title: Carters at Camp David Services
description: THURMONT, Md., Nov. 26 (UPI)President and Mrs. Carter attended special religious services today for the Camp David staff and their families. The Carters arranged the worship service at a helicopter hangar on the Marineoperated facility, a White House spokesman said.

title: Carol Simon Kalb Is Married
description: The marriage of Carol Simon Kalb of Roslyn, L.I., widow of Dr. Seymour Kalb, to Max Smedresman, a widowoi of Hollis Hills, Queens, took place at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, L.I., yesterday. Rabbi Robert S. Widom pr formed the ceremony. The bridegroom is vice president for business development of the Vitarine Company, a divi sign of West Chemical Products in Springfield Gardens, Queens. The bride formerly taught English in the New York City schools.

title: Woman In Coma 37 Years Dies; Was Cared for by Her Mother
description: HOLIDAY, Fla., Nov. 26 (AP) Elaine Esposito died in her mother's arms today, 37 years after the appendectomy from which she never awoke. Her coma was believed to be the longest on record. She was 43 years old.

title: R. Hawley Truax of New Yorker; Was Board Chairman and a Poet
description: R. liawley.Truax, a former cflairmAn of the board of The New Yorker magazine and one of its directors for 46 years, died of pnuemonia Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 89 years old and had been confined to his home at 175 East 79th Street in mnnthchv Arthritis.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME, Nov. 26 (UPI)  Pope John Paul II issued a worldwide appeal for religious freedom today. His voice trembling with emotion, the 5Syearold former Archbishop of Cracow, Poland, told crowd of more than 60,000 in St. Peter's Square that many Roman Catholics are persecuted because of their faith.

title: How Warplane Contracts Are Won
description: TORONTO, Nov. 26  The announcement last week that two finalists had been chosen in Canada's rigorous selection process for a manufacturer of new generation fighter aircraft marks the start of the last lap in a bitter, $2 billion competition involving the largest military procurement program in Canadian history. The winner is certain to be an American comnanv.

title: Cleveland Schools Test Calculators for Pupils
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 26 (UPI)  Pocket calculators are being tested in some schools here to see if they can increase students mathematics skills.

title: Making Democracy More Interesting
description: On Nov. 7, William H. Smith of Waukegan, Illinois, was elected auditor of Lake County. On the same day, by a referendum on the same ballot, the voters abolished the lob. That. to some people, illustrates the irresponisibility that results from lettinctb voters take the law into their own hands. They have done so since the turn of the century in one or more states, through the initiative, by which new laws are put on the ballot, and the referendum, by which old laws are overturned. Some students of politics have always mistrusted these devices, but never more than now, with enthusiasm for the initiative and referendum growing in a number of states, including New York. And in the wake of California's jolting vote on Proposition 13 to limit property taxes, concern over such direct democracy has turned into opposition. To our thinking, such opposition is wrong.

title: Administration Plans Severe Cuts In Proposals for Welfare Changes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  Severely curtailing his proposals for changing the welfare system, President Carter plans to ask Congress in January for a package that would increase Federal spending but by far less than he had once proposed.

title: Around the Nation
description: LOS ANGELES. Nov. 26 (UPI) man arrested in connection with the stabbings of two men on Skid Row may not be a suspect in the knife slayings of 10 other men in the downtown area, the police said today.

title: Commodities
description: NEVER before has the commodities futures industry witnessed so many merger meetings among the nation's 11 exchanges as it does today. Last Tuesday, for example, four of New York's six commodity exrhanees beean memer talks.

title: BOXING
description: A Parisian's odyssey leads him to a European title bout and victory, P. 5

title: Eskimos Capture Grey Cup
description: TOUONTO, Nov. 26 (UPI) The Edmonton Eskirnos, led by the passing of 35yearold Torn WilkirNon and the htcking of Dave Cutler, won the Cana. (h..in League Football championship io(lay by defeating the Montreal Alanetries in the Grey Cupture.

title: Soccer Rankings: Very Good, So Far
description: the committee in charge of Hie natiwial rankings in collegiate soccer trust have done something right this season. The first four selections; ached the semifinals of the National Lollegiate Athletic Association tournaANIL.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON FIVE big tests await the President's efforts trim the rising cost of regulation. In his Oct. antiinflation message, the President promised to redouble the Administration's efforts to reduce the inflationary impact of regulation. In some ways, that promise was a reaffirmation of earlier intentions.

title: Terry Sousek, a Lawyer, Marries Ann Goldweber
description: Ann Leslie Goldweber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Goldweber of Westbury, LI., was married yesterday to Terry Sousek, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Sousek of Gresham, Wis. State Supreme Court Judge Louis Grossman performed the ceremony in the Recency Hotel.

title: Outdoors: A Deerslayer Goes Forth
description: EQUIPPED with muzzleloading rifle, six greased 58caliber Minie balls, powder horn and percussion caps, I said goodbye to my companions and began my ascent of a mountain in Quest of a deer.

title: Ballet: John Butler's After Eden
description: JOHN BUTLER's After Eden, which the Joffrey Ballet revived at the City Center, is a ballet that never makes quiteenough sense.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: it is time to examine how far institti. tional racism is playing its deadly role in the lives of children charged as violent juveniles.

title: Patricia Craig Sings Title Role In Bartered Bride at the Met
description: PATRICIA CRAIG has been the cover for Theresa Straws during this season's new production at the Metropolitan Opera of Smetana's The Bartered Bride, and Saturday night sne got ner one and only official chance to sing the title role. It was her company debut, and she's scheduled to appear later this season as the First Lady in The Magic Flute.

title: Sect Lawyer Explains Role In Custody Fight Over Boy
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26  For Charles Garry, the mystery of his late client, the Rev. Jim Jones, is no mystery at all. Ile sees the People's Temple founder as a clever dictator whose mind gave way to paranoia when he felt he was on the verge of exposure.

title: South African Arrives For U.N. Negotiations On SouthWest Africa
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 26Diplomatic efforts to obtain indepen dence for SouthWest Africa moved to an important negotiating stage with the arrival here today of Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha of South Africa.

title: I Never Once Thought He Was Crazy'
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Nov. 26It may sound funny, said Tim Carter as he slumped, bonetired in both body and mind, in a chair on a breezeswept veranda of an ancient colonial hotel and reflected today on the Rev. Jim Jones, but I never once thought he was crazy until I saw my wife and 15monthold son dying of convulsions last Saturday.

title: Annual U.S. Wine Consumption Up From 4 to 7 Quarts a Person
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI) Americans now drink an average of about seven quarts of wine apiece each year, almost double their orange juice consumption. the Agriculture Department says.

title: Three Missing Crewmen Saved
description: MIAMI, Nov. 26 (AP)  Three crewmen missing for two days after abandoning a burning freighter were rescued today aboard a life raft in the Florida Straits southwest of Key West, the Coast Guard said. The nine other crewmen were rescued by a passing banana boat Fri4ay night after tjte 160foot Cari Traler, a freighter of Phnamanian registry, caught fire.

title: Supplementary OvertheCounter Listings
description: Week Ended, Nov. 24, 1978 The foflowing supplementary weckly list of mutual fianus prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (hid ) or aslwrI) last Friday.

title: Welfare Reform on the Same Old Rocks
description: STANFORD, Calif.Last year President Carter boldly announced his new radical welfarereform program. He asked that Congress totally scrap our existing welfare system, and . replace it with a program for better jobs and income, which will provide job opportunities for those able to work, and a simplified uniform cash assistance program for those who are unable to work.

title: CREDIT MARKETS FedMoves May Signal Higher Rates
description: The Federal Reserve last Friday. flashed conflicting signals that may portend higher interest rates.

title: Yonkers, With Spending Curbed, Takes Control From State Today
description: YONKERS, Nov. 26  On the second floor of the greendomed City Hall here there is a doorway marked Emergency Financial Control Board. Tomorrow, that statecreated board, which has monitored Yonkers's fiscal affairs for the last three years, will meet to dissolve itself, and the sign will be taken down in a formal recognition that the city's budget has been purged of red ink and its fiscal practices reformed.

title: HOCKEY
description: Rangers win shootout with Capitals, 94, P. 3

title: Rafshoon Resists the Label of Image Maker
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  From its corner by the window, it dominates the office: a huge, twoheaded eagle fashioned into a chair by the artist Joan Danziger. It is a fantasy throne and indicates this is no ordinary bureaucrat's office, but when the photographer asks Gerald Rafshoon to pose in it, he blanches.

title: Tribute With Lemmon Opens on Coast Next Year
description: Jack Lemmon, star of Tribute on, Broadway, will open next spring in West Coast productions of the play produced by Morton Gottlieb. He will appear in San Francisco for six weeks beginning Apri1.30, and in Los Angeles for eight weeks beginning June 11.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: HERE come the Arabs, again. If you don't have Arabs, or Nazis, or moles, or the Mob, you dont have a contemporary thriller. What the Arabs are up to time is the bombing of the Lincoln Tunnel so that hundreds of people will drown, among them Moshe Dayan, who is on his way into Manhattan from Newark after a secret transatlantic flight in the private Rothschild airPleane.

title: Market Place
description: A fascinating aspect of the United Technologies tender offer for the Carrier Corporation is thar Carrier contends that the combined company would be capable of producing better airconc,iitioning systems for skyscrapers than Carrier car nrnritirr Mom!.

title: Carters to Honor Five Arts Leaders
description: The first recipients of the annual honors program of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington will be the principal guests at a reception given at the White House next Sunday evening by President'and Mrs. Carter. They are Marian Anderson, Fred Astaire, George Balanchine. Richard Rodgers and Arthur Rubinstein.

title: Electronic Trading Gains Favor
description: Boca Raton, Fla., will be filled with handshakes tomorrow as the Securities Industry Association opens its 1978 annual convention, but the brokers and investment bankers attending can be expected to pay particular attention to one  the electronic handshake, or Intermarket Trading System, which has been in operation seven months as a first step toward the national market system mandated by Congress.

title: U.S. Explains Policy Toward Sect
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  The State Department knew very little about the People's Temple community in Guyana, before the mass suicides and killings of last week, and virtually nothing about Jonestown's relations with the Guyanese Government, officials here said today.

title: Heavy Travel Ends Holiday; Snow Is Forecast for Today
description: The fourday Thanksgiving holiday weekend drew to a close last night with crush of homebound traffic across the metropolitan area, and forecasts of plunging overnight temperatures and thg first snowfall of the season today. The forcast is for accumulations at up wan inch of snow turning to slush in the city and up to three or four inches of snow in some suburbs.

title: Canada Celebrates Football in 5Day Superbowl Frenzy
description: TORONTO, Nov. 26 Millions of Canadians celebrated their football SUperbowl today, the climax of more than five full nights and days of national frenzy that once a year gives this vast northern nation a sense of unity The Grey Cup, which is actually silver, was the prize for the winner of the frigid football feud here between the Montreal Alouettes and the Edmonton Eskimos, who wear little hand muffs on their uniform belts.

title: ButtonDowns and Defense: Red Is Bark
description: HOLZMAN'S team has been characterized as overpaid underachievers who have been treated too permissively  Holzman has already instituted small but significant measures to tighten discipline. But he would say only that he hoped they would be more aggressive on defense.

title: The New York Times/ Rick Delaney
description: 10 Killed, 25 Injured as Fire Rages Inside Holiday Inn Near Rochester

title: Caldwell Ready to Polish Ford's Tarnished Image
description: With all the fuss about Lee A. Iacocca joining Chrysler, there is a tendency to forget that Ford has a new president, too. He is Philip Caldwell, 58 years old, who was vice chairman of the Ford Motor Company, the No. auto maker, when Henry Ford 2d picked him to replace the deposed Mr. Iacocca last month.

title: Bridge:
description: DENVER, Nov. 26  The final day's play in the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals began here this afternoon with 11 of the country's top teams fighting for the Reisinger team championship and with it the right to compete in playoffs to determine the 1980 American international tenni.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: How many Americans are listed among the top 10 runners in the 1,500meter race and the mile,what arc their times, and who leads In each?

title: Sports World Specials
description: Why Was It So, Joe?It was bitter for Joe Pisarcii:, want (01Irterback, to have to listen to the ngry fans outside Giants Stadium tight days ago after his fumble with half a minute to play had given the Philadelphia Eagles, as surprised as Invone. a 1917 victory. Pisarcik, who had needed only to fan on tne Dan to put the game safely away, was jeered all the way from the stadium to his car in the parking lot, and even a subsequent trip of a thousand miles could provide little respite from the question Why?

title: ABROAD AT HOME A Question Of Trust
description: BOSTON, Nov. 26  The impasse in the negotiations between Israel and Egypt is harder to understand now that the draft peace treaty and one annex have been published. For those texts, in skillful and even elegant diplomatic language, meet what we would have thought were the fundamental concerns of both parties.

title: Pellosie's Electronic Hiring Tool
description: Many companies insist that the poly. graph, or liedetector, is a valid and im. portant management tool, especially in evaluating new employees. So does Carmine Pellosic. Mr. Pellosie, a forrner private investigator, is a vice president of Communication Control Systems, a manufacturer of sophisticated security devices. He is also an expert with something called a voice stress analyzer, which, he says, is a new concept in electronic lie detection.

title: Two Reserves Lead Bullets to Victory
description: LANDOVER, Md., Nov. 26 (AP) Two reserves, Charlie Johnson and Mitch Kupchak, scored 6 points each in the final minute today to spark the Washington Bullets to their seventh straight National Basketball Association victory, a 110102 triumph over the Golden State Warriors.

title: TV: White Shadow, New Series on CBS
description: WBILE CBS speaks confidently about its ratings future, the networks programming belies a pronounced nervousness about tactics. How simpleminded can techniques get without the overall schedule losing its muchvaunted claim to being the Tiffany of broadcasting?

title: Orchestra: Queens Group Comes of Age
description: THE Queens Symphony Orchestra, in the past a semiprofessional group, has now arrived at fully professional status and is reaching out for further recognition. In pursuit of that goal, the cream of the orchestra's string sections gave a concert at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon under the direction of David Katz, music director of the orchestra.

title: Bernard Brodie, at 68; A Political Strategist And Military Author
description: Dr. Bernard Brodie, an internationally known political strategist and the author of several books dealing with military affairs, died Friday in Los Angeles. He was 68 years old.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FROM AGES PAST Collectors of unusual objects should have a field day Thursday, when the furnishings of a local turnofthecentury church will be auctioned. Meanwhile, the public is invited, from today through Wednesday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., to inspect the items going up for sale at the All Angels Episcopal Church, West End Avenue at 81st Street. The building has been deconsecrated and is to be torn down now that the All Angels Parish has been relocated.

title: Iranian Workers Stage Strikes and Demonstrations
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 26  Demonstrations and work stoppages were carried out in all major cities of Iran today in response to a call from Shiite Moslem religious leaders for a oneday strike.

title: Events
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, ver di'sLuisa Miller. 8.

title: DE GUSTIBUS Tracing the Roots of Tea, a Liquid With a Legend
description: One of the first essays on food I ever wrote  it was nearly a quarter of century ago  dealt with tea, a beverage of which to this day I am passionately fond. That epic included what remains as one or my tavorite recipes for preparing beverages. The origin of the formula was attributed to a French missionary who, a couple of hundred years ago, recommended that tea leaves be allowed to steep no longer than is necessary to chant the Miserere psalm in a leisurely fashion,

title: Mass Membership of Japan's Ruling Party Helping to Pick Premier
description: TOKYO, Nov. 26  Japan's governing LiberalDemocratic Party this week chooses its president  who automatically becomes prime minister and leader of Japan  by an entirely new election system.

title: Vikings, Packers in 1010 Tie
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Nov. 26 Fran. cis Tarkenton, Terdell Middleton, Rick Danmeier and Chester Marco! were the most important names in today's game between the Green Bay Packers and Minnesota Vikings, the first two for their successes and the last two for their failures.

title: TOLL AT JONESTOWN IS SET AT 909 BY U.S. AS ARMY PULLS OUT
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Nov. 26 United States authorities put the final count of the number of dead at the Jonestown commune at 909 today and shipped the last bodies to the United States, but survivors were held here for a criminal investigation by Guyanese authorities into the killings and suicides.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Dow, Scoring 7th Gain in Last 8 Sessions, Rises 3.72
description: Stock prices edged higher yesterday as the market refused to give ground in the face of the latest round of tightening interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average, scoring its seventh advance in the last eight sessions, moved ahead in a finalhour rally to finish 3.72 points higher at 813.84.

title: Thorpe Hearing Told of Bungling
description: LONDON, Nov. 27  Andrew Gino Newton, who says he was hired to kill an alleged onetime homosexual lover of the former Liberal Party leader, Jeremy Thorpe, told a court today of laborious attempts to set up the murder and finally of taking an attempted killing to end the matter.

title: Uganda Charges a Tanzanian Invasion
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov 27  In the la: test twist of the fourweekold border conflict between Uganda and Tanzania, Radio Uganda said today that Tanzanian troops had captured the border town of Mutukula and were invading the country.

title: With Smallpox Wiped Out, Remaining Virus Stirs Controversy
description: THE conquest of smallpox, one of the greater accomplishments of modern public health, is now confronting medical science with one of its stranger dilemmas  what to do with the last remaining stocks of the smallpox virus.

title: G.M. Midmonth Sales Up; Rivals' Off
description: DETROIT, Nov. 27  A strong showing by the General Motors Corporation pushed sales of new Americanmade cars in midNovember 13.6 percent above the vearearlier level.

title: HIGH COURT REFUSES FARBER CASE REVIEW
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  The United States Supreme Court announced today that it would not review the contempt of court convictions of The New York Times and its reporter, M. A. Farber, for their refusal to turn over Mr. Farber's notes in a New Jersey murder case.

title: Westchester Board Votes 7.5% Raises for DelBello and 5 Commissioners
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 27  Crossing party lines, members of Westchester County's Board of Legislators voted today to increase the salary of Alfred B. Dcl Bello, the County Executive, by $4,495 over 18 months to bring it to $62,975 a year.

title: Bank Robbers Found to Suffer, Too
description: JOHN DILLINGER, Willie Sutton, Ma Barker, Bonnie and Clyde and other desperados have created an image of the bank robber as a cunning, almost heroic breed, willing to undertake a difficult and risky crime to gain a huge fortune.

title: Deaths
description: LEVITZKI  Grace, deeply loved and honored member of Metro Baptist Church, died November 26,1978. The viewing will be at Walter B.Cooke Funeral Home, 117 West 72 St. Tuesday until 9:30PM. Funeral at Walter B.Cooke 1PM Wednesday. Memorial gifts may be given to Research to Prevent Blindness, 598 Madison Ave., New York, N.Y.10022.

title: Egypt's Prime Minister To Confer With Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (Reuters) President Carter will meet with Egypt's Prime Minister, Mustafa Khalil, in Washington this week to discuss Egypt's latest position on the Middle East peace talks, American officials said today.

title: Death
description: DONAPHIN Forrest E. Beloved husband of Frances and devoted father of Robert. Loving grandfather and stepfather. Retired from the New York City Police Department. Member of the Guardian Society. Wake Tuesday 79, Paul Lane Funeral Home, Queens. Burial St Albans Congregational Church, Wednesday 10AM, 172.17 Linden Blvd, Wednesday

title: Some Inventors Skip Patents
description: An increasingly common alternative is to black box or pot new electronic components, encasing them in epoxy. If a competitor tries to dissolve the epoxy to learn the secret, the solvent destroys key parts of the hidden circuitry.

title: Curb Repairs to Resume
description: It seemed like an economic necessity in 1975. New York City, faced with mounting money problems, stopped repairing damaged street curbs.

title: Comparing His Church With Cult Irks Moon
description: BOSTON, Nov. 27 (AP)  The Rev. Sun Myung Moon told visiting scientists here yesterday that attempts by the news media to compare his Unification Church with cults like the Peoples Temple are outrageous accusations.

title: French Foreign Minister Reveals Resignation at Diplomatic Dinner
description: BONN, Nov. 27 (Reuters)  France's Foreign Minister, Louis de Guiringaud, announced tonight that he would resign shortly.

title: China Buys More Corn
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) .China has bought an additional 350,000 metric tons of United States corn for delivery through next Sept. 30, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Warner Is Winner by 0.4% In the Virginia Senate Race
description: RICHMOND, Nov. 27  Three, weeks after he was declared the apparent election winner with a lead of less than onehalf of one percentage point, John W. Warner was declared the winner of a seat in the United States Senate today, by 0.4 percent of more than 1.2 million votes cast.

title: 9 Named to Monuments Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP)  President Carter appointed nine persons today as members of the American Battle Monuments Commission. They are Alfred P. Chamie of Pacific Palisades, Calif.: Gen. Benjamin O. Davis Jr. of the Mr Force; T. Harry Cation, executive vice president of the North Carolina Bankers Association; Gen. James M. Gavin of the Army; Gen. Anna Mae Hays, chief of the Army Nurse Corps; Adm. James L. Holloway, Chief of Naval Operations; Oliver E. Meadows, national commander of the Disabled American Veterans; John N. Pope of Americus, Ga., and Gen. Lewis H. Wilson, commandant of the Marine Corps.

title: ShortTerm Rates Climb As Fed Lets Funds Rise
description: Shortterm interest rates rose yesterday as the Federal Reserve let the Federal funds rate  the rate at which banks lend reserves to each other inch upward without intervening in the money market to stop it.

title: Supreme Court to Review Ruling on Firm's Audits
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  The Supreme Court agreed today to review a ruling that customers of a securities firm can invoke Federal recordkeeping requirements to sue the firm's outside auditors for preparing false and misleading audits of the firm's financial condition.

title: Haley Testifies He Wrote All Major Parts of Roots
description: Alex Haley vehemently denied yesterday that any of the plot or characters in his book Roots had been copied from a previously published novel about slavery.

title: Obituary 9 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5.30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2.30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4.30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES 1914 WHITE FLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 747.0500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691600; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767

title: DR. DANIEL KIMBERG, INTERNIST, 45, DEAD
description: Dr. Daniel V. Kimberg, chairman of the department of medicine at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and director of the medical service at the Presbyterian Hospital in the City of New York, died Sunday of a heart attack in London. The 45yearold physician, a resident of Scarsdale, N.Y., had been scheduled to speak at an international medical meeting in England.

title: Frank Rosolino, Jazz Trumpeter
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 27 (AP)  Frank Rosolino, the jazz trombonist, apparently shot and killed his 11yearold son and critically wounded his 7yearold son before taking his own life, the police said today.

title: Baylor Upset of Texas Glows On a Tale of an Earthy Worm
description: WACO, Tex., Nov. 27 (UPI)  Putting an earthworm in his mouth and promising to swallow it was one of the ploys Baylor Coach Grant Teaff used to motivate his players to upset favored Texas, a spokesman confirmed today.

title: WORLD AROUND US
description: BIG city residents tend to assume that the night sky is so obscured by tall buildings, smog and light pollution that it's scarcely worth looking up to see the stars beyond. But it needn't be that way. On clear, cold nights the New York sky often sparkles.

title: Ford of Britain In Pay Dispute
description: LONDON, Nov. 27 (AP)  Executives of the Ford Motor Company of Britain met with top Government officials today in an effort to ward off sanctions for breaking the Government's pay guidelines.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4)What in the World Is ... (5)New Zoo Revue (13)Captioned ABC News

title: Atlantic City Drafts a Master Plan
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 27  Atlantic City disClosed a casinoera master plan today with space zoned for housing for displaced residents but no timetable for providing the housing.

title: Carter Acts to Double Quota of Vietnamese Allowed to Enter U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  The Carter Administration has decided to seek support in Congress to allow 15,000 more refugees from Vietnam into this country by next May, doubling the number previously set.

title: David Bromberg Gives Carnegie Hall Hoedown
description: FOR years now, David Brom berg, who performed at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night, has been a virtuoso musician without a proper vehicle, not to mention a standup comedian in search of a punch line. He is an extraordinarily nimble guitarist and a proficient fiddler with a musicologist's knowledge of American instrumental idioms, and his wisecracks would stand him in good stead at a Catskills resort. But it's hard to market a folkie with a funnybone, and tougher still to capture him on record.

title: An Almost Routine Assignment Led to Historic Case
description: In August 1975, Eileen Milling, a public relations consultant and writer, asked The New York Times to investigate series of suspicious deaths that had occurred at a small hospital in Oradell, N.J., a decade earlier. The Times, considering the account plausible, assigned one of its reporters, M. A. Farber, to look into it.

title: EDUCATION
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I.

title: WNETTV Refuses to Use Michener Documentary
description: The season's first James Michener documentary was not shown, as had seen scheduled, on WNET/13 Sunday ??ght after the station had learned that the program, Poland: The Will to ?? had been made ?? wholly owned ??sidrary of ?? company that under??rote it.

title: Soviet Official Is Said to Have Met Twice With Top Aides of Cult Leader
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Nov. 27 (AP)  Top aides of the Rev. Jim Jones conferred at least twice in Georgetown with an official of the Soviet Embassy who discussed their problems sympathetically and held out the promise of approval for the exodus of the whole Jonestown colony to Russia, according to a document made available to The Associated Press.

title: U.S. Oil Use Up 3% in Quarter
description: PARIS, Nov. 27 (AP) Oil consumption in the United States was 19.03 million barrels a day in the third quarter of this year, an increase of 3 percent over the same period of 1977 but virtually unchanged from the secondquarter level of 19.01 million barrels, latest statistics of the International Energy Agency showed today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Abbott Laboratories, Chicago, has named Thomas R. Hodgson a division vice president and general manager of the hospital products division. He replaces Daniel E. Gill, who resigned.

title: Looking Good Is the Best Revenge
description: To the tune of stormy weather, New Yorkers offered up a foretaste of winter fashions yesterday.

title: British Buy More 737's
description: LONDON, Nov. 27 (AP)  Britannia Airways, a British charter airline, today ordered three more Boeing 737 jetliners worth a total of $36 million. The airline plans to be flying 27 of the 737's by 1981.

title: Fringe Religions Find Fertile Soil in United States
description: Fringe religious groups, though always a feature of American life, have grown more eclectic and diversified in the last decade, increasing the possibility of explosive mixtures of belief and practice such as marked the People's Temple.

title: Theater: D.H. Lawrence's The Fight for Barbara
description: THE Fight for Barbara at the Nat Horne Theater is literary curiosity: a seldom perfomed, autobiographical play by D.H. Lawrence. It is not so much the work of a dramatist, however, as it is of a diarist, and in it Lawrence seems to have invented nothing It is the story of his romance.

title: Harvey Milk, Led Coast HomosexualRights Fight
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27  Harvey Milk, the 48yearold San Francisco Supervisor who was shot and killed today, was this city's first acknowledged homosexual official. He had been instrumental earlier this year in the passage of a homosexual rights ordinance that is considered the most stringent in the nation.

title: The Jets: Revival and Reunion
description: Atter a Jets game at Shea Stadium not long ago, their board chairman, Leon Hess, was inconspicuously sitting in a corner across from the desk in Coach Walt Michaels's office. Finding a coach is like finding oil, the oil baron said while Walt Michaels was in the locker room. You drill here... nothing. You drill there...nothing. But then you drill over here and you've got it. Now the Jets appear to have struck it rich with Walt Michaels, the coach who should have succeeded Weeb Ewbank in the 1974 season. But for his sake, perhaps it's just as well he did not. The Franchise, from top to bottom, was not as solid then. Walt Michaels might have been victimized by its inefficiency. Now it's different. Now the Jets, with Jim Kensil presiding over the football operation, are emerging as one of the National Football League's most astute organizations. That's how Super Bowls are won  with an organization, not merely with a team.

title: The Fabric of Life
description: Everybody has to get dressed and go about his business, so everybody must give a thought to what he wears, if only to feel comfortable in public and not like a fool.

title: J. Davis Danforth, a Retired Aide For Batten, Barton, Durstine, 75
description: J. Davis Danforth, a former executive vice president of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn Inc., died Saturday at Bethesda Memorial Hospital, Gulf Stream, Fla., of a heart attack. Mr. Danforth, who maintained homes in Del Ray Beach, Fla., and Centerville, Mass., and had lived in Rye, N.Y., was 75 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: AN AUTHORIZED biography of Alfred Hitchcock. What an appealing idea! The one and only Alfred Hitchcock, by whose inimitable films anyone over the age of 40 can date the progress of his life, Alfred Hitchcock. the most universally recognizable person in the world, argues the author of Hitch (though Muhammad All would make a plausable case for Muhammad Ali), yet whose intensely private nonprofessional life remains a mystery.

title: Inflation Slows A Bit in Europe
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 27 (AP) The rise in consumer prices, in the European Economic Community as a whole slowed to fivetenths of 1 percent in October, leaving prices up 7.1 percent in the last year, the community's statistical office, Eurostat, reported today.

title: Rights Group Accuses China of Political Arrests and Prisoner Abuse
description: VASJI1NGTON, Nov. 27  China was accused by Amnesty International today of making continued arrests for political reasons and of a variety of other deprivations of human rights.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The JohnsManville Corporation announced yesterday that it would buy 75 percent of the 5.86 million shares of Olinkraft Inc., an integrated forest products company, that were tendered in JohnsManville's recent offer for 49 percent of Olinkraft's outstanding shares at $65 a share. The number of shares to be purchased is 4.4 million, a $286 million transaction.

title: Pioneers To Begin Probing Mysteries Of Venus
description: SPACESHIPS from Earth are fast approaching Venus, and the first of four encounters with the hot, desiccated, cloudshrouded planet is expected to occur next Monday.

title: 2 Inches of Snow Fall in New York And Catch Commuters Off Guard
description: The season's first snowfall, arriving earlier than usual, dropped up to four inches on the New York metropolitan area yesterday, snarling commuter traffic and surprising  and sometimes dismaying those who did not expect to see snow before Christmas.

title: Four Race Tracks Are Snowed Out
description: The season's first snowstorm in t he eastern halt of the country yesterday canceled racing at four thoroughbred tracks, including the Meadowlands in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: Minnesota HighVoltage Power Line Stirs Protests
description: LOWRY, Minn., Nov. 27 (AP)  Some farm people report that the highvoltage power line now under test in Minnesota sometimes makes their skin itch, their tractors lose power, their radios crackle with static and their television sets produce a snowy picture.

title: Delaware Coroner Is Ready to Investigate Cult Deaths
description: DOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Del., Nov. 27  The state Medical Examiner, Dr. Ali Hameli, said today that he would be prepared to do an autopsy and investigate the death of the Rev. Jim. Jones and other victims of the mass deaths in Guyana before their bodies were cremated or buried in Delaware.

title: Carey to Name Burns to a Top Post
description: Governor Carey is planning to name John J. Burns, his campaign manager and former Democratic State Chairman, as appointments officer in the second Carey administration, aides to the Governor said yesterday.

title: Columbia Wins By 8264 From City College
description: Columbia outscored City College by 142 in the first four minutes of the second half to take a 4932 lead and then coasted to an 8264 victory last night at Levien Gymnasium in the inaugural basketball contest of the season for both teams.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1978

title: Winner in Fight for Japanese Premiership
description: TOKYO, Nov. 27  Masayoshi Ohira, who takes over from Takeo Fukuda as Prime Minister and as leader of Japan early next month, is to many on first impression a solemn, brooding person. Heavily built, unsmiling and heavylipped, Mr. Ohira  a son of a peasant  seems almost a caricature of an Oriental master politician, a man suited to the backwoods and backstairs, who would sit up stolidly all night to get his way with heavydrinking colleagues.

title: Court Rebuffs A.T.&T. On PhoneLinks Appeal
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UPI)The Supreme Court let stand today an order requiring the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to make available additional local phone connections that a competitor needs to expand its longdistance service.

title: Smith's Friends Help Pay His Legal Bills
description: One of the problems with being indicted, Peter P. Smith 3d said in a recent interview, is that all of a sudden you find yourself out of a job, and, to make things worse, you have tremendous legal bills to pay.

title: JordanianPalestinian Accord Reached
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 27 (Reuters) Leaders of Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization have agreed, after three days of meetings here, on a policy of noninterference in each other's internal affairs, it was announced today.

title: Vytautas Smetona Has His Own Ideas
description: EVEN when his interpretations verged on eccentricity, there was much to admire in Vytautas Smetona's playing Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall. The 23yearold pianist, a native of Cleveland, is clearly a musician with ideas of his own; more important, he manages to present them in a manner that seems ingenuous rather than willful.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCLDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, Nov. 27, 1978

title: Tension High as Basque Terrorists Press Campaign
description: SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain  The scene is almost ritualized by now. A fire, set by rampaging teenagers, blazes in the middle of the graceful boulevard lined with tamarisks and acacias. Gray police vans hurtle around improvised barricades of overturned automobiles and discarded construction materials. The dull pop of rubber bullets echoes in the deserted streets.

title: Eastman Trio Plays Beethoven
description: WHEN a piano, violin and cello trio plans a concert series and titles it Mostly Beethoven, one expects a selection from that composer's dozen familiar works for these instruments as a matter of course. The Eastman Trio did include one at the first of its three Mostly Beethoven concerts at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H,A. on Sunday night  No. 5 in E flat, Op. 70, No. 2 but the group also delved enterprisingly into a comparatively neglected area of Beethoven's output, the 100odd British folksong arrangements he made for voice, piano and strings.

title: McGee Let Go As Duke Coach
description: DURHAM, N.C., Nov. 27 (UPI) Mike McGee, head football coach at Duke University for eight years, was let go today and replaced by the Blue Devils' assistant athletic director, Shirley (Red) Wilson.

title: Desolate Scene Found at Ruined Jonestown Schoolhouse
description: JONESTOWN, Guyana, Nov. 27  It is a simple structure, little more than a ??n roof supported, by wooden posts, 12 by 40 feet in size. It stands just off Cussy Lane, across die way from Mary McCloud Bethune Terrace and down the street from Sojourner Truth Apartment.

title: Memory of Pain Haunting
description: JONESTOWN, Guyana, Nov. 27  The name is as plain as hometown America. Yet it will forever evoke the dread of a place of horror.

title: Malaysia Appeals to Carter on Asylum for Vietnam Boat Refugees
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 27  The Malaysian Government is addressing an urgent appeal to President Carter to take the lead in a major international effort to provide asylum for the mounting flow of refugees from Vietnam.

title: Events
description: ??ORNO STARS AT HOME ??Leonard ??

title: General Motors Strike Averted
description: DETROIT, Nov. 27 (UPI)  A strike by 5,000 workers at a General Motors body plant was averted at the last minute today by union and company negotiators who settled a dispute over production standards. Local 15 of the union had notified the company that it would call a strike at its Fleetwood plant at 10 A.M. today unless the union's grievances concerning production standards were resolved

title: Frontiers: Genetics
description: AT Yale University, seemingly normal mice have been born of six parents, showing in their piebald coloration characteristics derived from their three mothers and three fathers. In Britain, it has been reported that infants have regrown severed finger tips, including a knuckle joint, although such regeneration is unheard in human adults.

title: LEBANESE PRESIDENT TRAVELS TO FRANCE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 27  President Elias Sarkis flew to Paris today to seek French assistance in rebuilding the Lebanese army and in other efforts to restore stability to Lebanon.

title: A Court Limits Albany Inquiry On Bank Policy
description: A justice in New York State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the Assembly's Committee on Consumer Affairs and Protection lacked jurisdiction to look into the political and financial activities of savings banks in the state.

title: Ad Rates of Times To Go Up on Jan. 1
description: The New York Times announced yesterday that its advertising rates would be increased, effective Jan. 1. Fred D. Thompson, vice president for advertising, said the overall increase would be slightly less than 8 percent, within the Carter Administration's price guidelines. He attributed the increases to rising costs in all areas of production and distribution.

title: Joseph Genovese, Head Of Drugstore Chain, 75
description: Joseph Genovese, founder and chairman of the Genovese drugstore chain, died yesterday in St. Francis Hospital in Manhasset, L. I. He was 75 year old.

title: Strife Cripples Iran's Economy
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 27  The sixmonthold civil revolt that continues to grip Iran has brought the nation's economy to the brink of paralysis.

title: Building Activity Up In October
description: Contracts for new construction jumped to $14.9 billion last month, 8 percent above September's $13.8 billion and 40 percent higher than the $10.6 billion level in October 1977, according to the F. W. Dodge Division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company in a report released yesterday.

title: Harold Hall, 53, Filmstrip Writer And Editor With a Times Weekly
description: Harold B. Hall, a filmstrip writer and editor on the staff of The New York Times School Weekly, which is used in classroom work, died Thursday in Cape Cod Hospital, Hyannis, Mass. He was 53 years old and lived at 330 East 54th Street. He also maintained a home on Nantucket.

title: Teng Denies He Differs With Hua; Peking Crowd Chants Democracy
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 27  In an apparent effort to dampen speculation over the existence of a power struggle in China, Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping said today that he and Hua Kuofeng, chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, had always been in complete agreement over everything and that he had refused an offer to take over Mr. Hua's other job as Prime Minister.

title: Bronx Postmen Give for Cancer
description: A group that helps patients and their families and friends to deal with nonmedical problems of cancer received a $380 donation from Bronx Postal Service employees yesterday. The Bronx Postmaster, Frank Viola, presented the money to William Kip, the president of Living With Cancer.

title: President Warns Nation's Mayors Not to Expect New Help for Cities
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 27  President Carter told the nation's mayors today not to expect new Federal initiatives to assist what he called our troubled cities, but promised to preserve useful programs and not to make wholesale, arbitrary spending cuts.

title: World News Briefs
description: TEHERAN, Iran. Nov. 27 (AP)  More scattered violence was reported from provincial towns in Iran today as employces of the central bank and other Government agencies returned to work after a 24hour general strike called by opponents of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

title: Eight Held Hostage Six Hours
description: WYANDOTTE, Mich., Nov. 27 (UPI) A gunman, drinking heavily and demanding hospital treatment for depression, today held eight persons hostage in a bar for more than six hours and then surrendered. The gunman, identified as Gary Cornell, 47 years old, kept his finger on the trigger of his 22caliber rifle for prolonged times without firing, according to one hostage who escaped.

title: U.S.Women Score a Sweep In Cup Tennis
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 27 (UPI)  Billie Jean King, hinting again she might retire from major tennis competition, helped the United States beat South Korea, 30, today in the opening round of the $130,000 Federation Cup at the grass Kooyong courts.

title: Confidence Displaces Contention At Meeting of G.O.P. Governors
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 27  Republican governors and governorselect invoked the ghosts of Patrick Henry and Thomas Jefferson today before pondering revolutionary concepts of their own, such as an allout effort to win black votes and a thoroughgoing concern for the cities.

title: CBS Widens Morning News to Sunday
description: Having failed in some two decades of trying, to make a dent in the audience popularity ratings of NBC's Today program, The CBS Morning News is being put through another overhaul, its third since 1973.

title: Stage Set for Algerian Power Struggle
description: ALGIERS, Nov. 27  A behind the scenes struggle for the succession to Algeria's presidency may have been set in motion today by a Swedish specialist's pessimistic medical assessment of the condition of the gravely ill Houari Boumediene.

title: U.S. Suit Says Prepaid Health Plan In Florida Was Illegally  Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  The Justice Department charged in a civil antitrust suit today that a hospital and a county medical society in Florida had conspired to thwart competition from a health maintenance organization that provides prepaid medical care.

title: The Process Due the Press
description: By refusing to review the contempt convictions of The New York Times and its reporter, M. A. Farber, the Supreme Court has left uncorrected a sorry record of confusion about whether the Constitution offers any protection for a newspaper's confidential sources of information. Given the Court's recent record of insensitivity on the issues of press freedom, its inaction is not the worst result that could have been imagined. But surely some day the rights  and public benefits  of letting reporters protect their informants will be recognized as essential to the gathering and therefore printing of news. We and others feel obliged to keep asserting the need for it, despite the high cost of doing so.

title: U.N. Panel Asks Security Council To Cut Off Arm's Sales to Israelis
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 27 The General Assembly's Political Committee today approved a resolution requesting the Security Council to impose a mandatory arms embargo against Israel.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Andante Festivi Sibelius; Trio Sonata in D. W.F Bach; Allegretto in C minor, Schu bert; La Vida Breve, FaIla ; Con certino No. 6 in B flat, Pergolesi.

title: Mount Etna Eruption in 6th Day
description: CATANIA, Sicily, Nov. 27 (AP) Mount Etna, Europe's highest volcano, was spewing ash and smoke for the sixth day today in its most spectacular activity in 30 years. The activity peaked over the weekend when clouds of white smoke could be seen from about 2.5 miles away.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WORD OF MOUTH The Architecture of C??king has a form??b?? ??g and seven esperts will serve ?? ?? nourshing subject tonight at 8 ?? discussion at the National Academy of ??esign. 10?? Fifth Avenue, at 90th Street. For a d?? fee of ??, the public can hear the view of a panel of which Stanley Abe??ombie editor of Interors Magazine is chairman. Others on the panel are Julia Child. writer and television chef ; George Land, ?? staurateur will food consultant Paul Damaz architect: Pierre Franey, ch?? and writer. ?? holas Polites journalist, and Bill Sta?? ?? er.

title: Deadly Poison Stolen From Car
description: A search continued yesterday for 12 vials of a poison stolen over the weekend from a doctor's car in Greenwich Village, the police said. The poison, known as belladine, is deadly if injected, swallowed or absorbed through the skin, according to the police. The car, belonging to Dr. MiMel Silla of Glastonbury, Conn., was stolen frofn West 11th Street on Saturday night and recovered Sunday afternoon in a Housing Authority parking lot on the other side of Manhattan. The doctor's black medical bag with the poison, which was being used experimentally on rats, was missing, the police said.

title: Notes on People
description: The New York City Corporation Counsel's office said yesterday it was appealing a State Supreme Court judgment giving Fran Warren, the singer, $500,000 in her longstanding suit against the city for false arrest on marijuana possession charges. For 14 years Miss Warren has been fighting to clear her name, maintaining that because of her arrest in 1964, when such charges were much more serious than they are now, her career has declined radically.

title: Suicide Note Disclosed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27The Federal Bureau of Investigation released today the contents of what appeared to be a suicide note by a woman follower of the Rev. Jim Jones that was found on the cult leader's body by Federal officials.

title: Used Cars, Eyeglasses and Coffins
description: The Federal officials who tell businesses what they can and cannot do have been taking their lumps recently, and for good reason. The country has become skeptical of the need for Federal regulators to decide whether truckers can haul chicken fat to Memphis or whether the lights in a gas station restroom are bright enough. No wonder that the most popular man in Washington these days is Alfred Kahn, who earned his halo dismantling the Civil Aeronautics Board.

title: Lawyer Cleared in Terrorist Case
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Nov. 27 (AP)  A court today acquitted WolfDieter Reinhard, a Hamburg lawyer, of charges that he had persuaded members of a terrorist group, the June 2 Movement, to make false statements during a murder trial two years ago. The court said today that the prosecution's chief witness, Juergen Bodeux, who was sentenced to five years in prison after the 1976 murder trial, was not sufficiently trust worthy.

title: COMMODITIES
description: A number of warning signals flashed in the precious metals futures market yesterday, causing a general price retreat. The first signal was a firmer dollar in overseas markets, which helped lower cash bullion prices by $4.30 an ounce in London, based on the final fixing of $198.40 an ounce.

title: Weekly Output Of Steel Down
description: Steel production in the United States for the week ended Nov. 25 fell to 2.678 million tons, down 1.7 percent from the previous week's total of 2.723 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Police Pressing Search In Murder of a Nurse; Parole Issue Is Raised
description: A special force of 40 police officers in bulletproof vests searched through New York City yesterday for Nathan Giles, a 32yearold convicted killer who was on parole. The police believe he is the man who dragged Bonnie Anne Bush, 25, a Mount Sinai Hospital nurse, into an abandoned tenement on West 102d Street on Friday and, after shooting her twice in the head, set fire to her nude body.

title: Iowa Dismisses Commings
description: IOWA CITY, Nov. 27 (AP)  Bob Commings was dismissed today atter five years as head football coach at Iowa. Commings's teams were 1738, including a 29 finish this season.

title: Earliest Land Plants Reconstructed
description: ITHACA, N.Y. WHEN Harlan Banks hears of a dam or power plant about to be built or a road about to be cut through the Catskill hillsides, he races off to the site with the excitement of a little boy chasing, a fire engine. His goal is not to watch the impressive explosions of rock or to protest the environmental destruction but to collect the plant fossils that are exposed when the earth's rocky crust is blasted to bits.

title: Airline Sees More New York Jobs
description: American Airlines hopes to expand employment in the New York area in a few years to make up for the 1,300 jobs the airline plans to move out of Manhattan next summer, when it shifts its corporate headquarters to the DallasFort Worth Airport, the company's senior spokesman said yesterday.

title: Father Held in Death of Son
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Nov. 27 (AP)  A man was jailed in the fatal shooting of his 6yearold son in an apparent dispute over $1, the police reported today. Investigators said that the boy had been shot at close range in the forehead late Saturday. They said it appeared that Ralph Knute Cortez, 28, had demanded money from his son, Frank, who said he had none. But the father searched the boy and found a $1 bill in his pocket, the police said.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Around the Nation
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 27 (AP)  A Federal grand jury today indicted seven liquor companies and nine of the companies officers on more than 100 counts of misdemeanor bribery in connection with alleged payments to state officials.

title: Clendenin J. Ryan, 39, Executive In Jersey Banking and Insurance
description: Clendenin J. Ryan, a New Jersey banker and insurance executive, died Sunday at his home in Far Hills, N.J., after a long illness. He was 39 years old.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rise
description: With shortterm interest rates rising yesterday, sixmonth Treasury bills were sold at an average discount rate of 9.33 percent, enabling savings banks to offer sixmonth certificates yielding 10.2 percent.

title: Supreme Court Roundup
description: WASHINGTON., Nov. 27  Accepting an appeal from an upstate New York murder conviction, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the police can constitutionally hold a suspect for questioning when they do not have enough information to sustain a valid arrest.

title: German Steel Strike Looms
description: BONN, Nov. 27 (Reuters)  West German steel companies tonight ordered a partial lockout in eight mills in response to a union decision to call the country's first steel strike in 50 years.

title: S.E.C. Calls Earthworm Risky Bait
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  Earthworms are being used to lure people to invest in frequently fraudulent getrichquick promotions, the Securities and Exchange Commission warned today.

title: Truck Rate Rise of 6.2% Rejected
description: WASHINGTON Nov. 27  The Interstate Commerce Commission rejected today a proposal for higher truck freight rates, suggesting instead a smaller increase within the Administration's price guidelines

title: First Cultists Freed, but Many Expected to Be Held
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Nov. 27 The police here have begun releasing some of the approximately 80 cultists taken into custody in the investigation of the Jonestown murders and suicides, but United States authorities say they expect a large number of persons to be detained further.

title: Cardinal Trin Nhu Khue of Hanoi Is Dead at 78 After a Long Illness
description: ROME, Nov. 27 (AP) Joseph Marie Cardinal Trin Nhu Khue, Archbishop of Hanoi, is dead in Vietnam at age 78, Vatican Radio said today.

title: O.E.C.D. Payments Balance Expected
description: PARIS, Nov. 27 (AP)  The currentaccount balance of payments of the 24 member nations of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development  the world's major industrial nations  is moving close to equilibrium for the first time since the 1973 oil crisis.

title: George Moscone, a Firm Mayor Who Stressed Anticrime Effort
description: In his stewardship in San Vrancisco's City Hall, cut short after fewer than three years, George Richard Moscone had to cope with many challenges, political and otherwise. As Mayor, he did not walk away from a fight, and San Franciscans usually rallied in the corner of the hometown boy to watch him level the opposition.

title: The Region
description: YONKERS,  City Manager Pat Ravo, just hours after the Yonkers Emergency Financial Control Board was disbanded yesterday, proposed a fiveyear fiscal plan that calls for a city income tax.

title: Racing Bureau Discloses Material on New Ringers
description: NEW HYDE PARK, LI., Nov. 27 (UPI)  The Thoroughbred Racing Protective Bureau has uncovered evidence of ringer scandals at Waterford and Hawthorne race tracks and is investigating similar cases at tracks in Massachusetts and Kentucky, it was announced today.

title: Deaths
description: Abelson, Ida

title: Ballet: Quick Glimpse of City Repertory
description: JUST before its annual monthlong Nutcracker rite, the New York City Ballet offered a glimpse of its repertory. That brief twoweek season ended Sunday at the New York State Theater with several debuts in Jewels in the afternoon; the evening featured Swan Lake, Who Cares? and, in new costumes, In the Night.

title: About New York
description: The city retreated to its huddledmasses winter profile yesterday as the first snowfall finally shut off a balmy fall season that came eerily close to threatening New Yorkers with a California Christmas.

title: Deaths
description: STACKMANHy (Herman) a prince among men and a rare human being has gone and our entire orgeni:stion Is filled with grief. Hv served with great distinction as a Past President and Honorary Trustee of the Faun dation His memory will serve as an inspiring force in our humanitarian efforts. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to all members of the famt.. Iv

title: Yarrison Takes Fencing Crown
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 27 (AP)  Robert Yarrison of Boston upset the defender, Gil Pezza of Italy, 53, yesterday to capture the pe title in the Cleveland Grand Prix tournament. Elaine Ingram of New Haven defeated Iris Gericke of Detroit, 50, in a fenceoff to win the women's combined foil and epee title.

title: More Allies of Brezhnev Promoted To Soviet Leadership's Inner Circle
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 27The Soviet leader. ship promoted several allies of Leonid I Brezhnev to the inner circle of the Soviet leadership, but the shifts gave no hint of who the 71yearold Soviet leader's eventual successor might be.

title: F.A.A. Accused of Lagging on San Diego Collision
description: SAN DIEGO. Nov. 27  The Federal Aviation Administration was accused by a San Diego Congressman today of dragging its feet on safety measures recommended by the National Transpor. tation Safety Board after the midair collision here on Sept. 25.

title: Another Evacuation Plan
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 27  Jeff Dieterich, a State Department press officer, said today that the evacuation of Jonestown survivors by military aircraft would go forward as planned if a substantial number of survivors of the Jonestown tragedy want to leave Guyana together. But he cautioned that the State Department could not say how many survivors would be aboard such a flight.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Treasury will borrow 2.5 billion 3 bliilon German marks on the West German capital market by mid December as part of President Carter's plan to defend the dollar, an authoritative source disclosed in Paris. The public borrowing would the first in a foreign currency by the Treasury and would be the opening installment in a plan to raise $10 ?? eign currencies to support the dollar. [Page A1.]

title: Advertising
description: SCOTTSDALE, ARIZ. DESPITE everything, the 69th annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers was opened here yesterday on a high note and, just for a chance, under clear skies.

title: More Distant Worlds Are in Sight
description: While American and Soviet spacecraft concentrate on Venus next month, other American vehicles of exploration continue to radio photographs and data from Mars and to make their way toward more distant worlds.

title: Soviet Grain at Record
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 27 (UPI)  Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, announced today that the Soviet harvest brought in a record 235 million tons of grain. Mr. Brezhnev also said the cotton harvest exceeded eight million tons. The previous grain record was set in 1976, when 223.8 million tons were harvested.

title: Mortgage Rates Climb
description: Interest rates on home mortgages continued to climb yesterday, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation reported as it released the results of its weekly purchase of residential loans. Its figures also indicated that mortgage lenders believe rates are likely to move still higher over the months ahead.

title: CORRECTION
description: Sidney Simon, sculptor, will lecture tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Sculpture Center Gallery, 167 East 69th Street. The date was incorrectly listed in the Going Out Guide last Thursday

title: EARNINGS
description: Profits of N. V. Philips Gloeilampenfabrieken declined 14.3 percent in the third quarter and 1.4 percent in the first nine months this year despite increased sales, according to yesterday's report from the Netherlands.

title: SUSPECT SOUGHT JOB
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27  Mayor George Moscone was shot to death in his office at City Hall this morning, and a few minutes later Supervisor Harvey Milk, the city's first acknowledged homosexual official, was shot and killed in an office on the other side of City Hall.

title: A Broken Bond
description: On Sept. 17, 1976, a few days after returning from summer vacation, a student at Sanford, a private school in Hockessin, Delaware, was caught smoking marijuana and expelled. Hundreds of thousands of high school students use marijuana on campus with some regularity. A few get caught. What made this case different was that it landed in Federal court.

title: IN THE NATION
description: GABARONE, Botswana  One day last week, a Rhodesia DC3 flew over three refugee camps in northeastern Botswana. With pinpoint accuracy, the plane dropped loads of leaflets rom two ieet into tne camps. And in all three cases, the slowflying DC3, a World War II relic, got away before the surprised Botswana defense force could set up effective ground fire.

title: New York City Postpones Sale of ShortTerm Notes
description: New York City yesterday postponed its lOngawaited sale of shortterm notes after reaching a decision with its underwriters that the money was not needed now. The sale was to have taken place next month.

title: White Emigration From Rhodesia Sets Record of 1,582 in October
description: SALISBURY. Rhodesia, Nov. 27 (Reuters)  Official figures showed today that white Rhodesians emigrated in record numbers last month as the country moved toward disputed black majority rule and the guerrilla war was stepped up.

title: New Welfare Plan May Add $6 Billion to U.S. Costs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov; 27  The new welfare proposals that President Carter intends to submit to Congress early next year will be based on a Federal assistance package providing minimum aid to families at about 65 percent of the official poverty level in each state, an Administration official said today

title: U.S., Fearing New Instability in China, Views Events With Concern
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  Carter Administration officials said today that they were paying close attention to the political ferment in China because of concern that it might produce another period of instability there.

title: First of 16,100 Fire Detectors For Elderly Is Installed by Koch
description: The first of 16,100 smoke detectors, part of a. federally financed program aimed at saving the lives of elderly persons, was installed yesterday in an East Harlem apartment by Mayor Koch.

title: ExCity Aide's Trial Stirs Power and Ethics Issues
description: The trial of a former New York City commissioner, Peter P. Smith 3d, on Federal charges of defrauding his former law firm and one of its clients out of more than $70,000 will begin in Manhattan next Monday.

title: About Education
description: DON'T stare, the mother says to her child as they pass a youngster deformed by cerebral palsy. Don't stare, is intended to be a humane admonition to avoid offending the handicapped, part of the genteel etiquette that says, Don't point or even Don't laugh when someone behaves oddly.

title: Weiss, Leach Capture National Tennis Titles
description: HARVEY, III., Nov. 27 (UPI) Robby Weiss of Northbrook, III., won the national boys 12yearsandunder singles tennis championship today, while Rick Leach of Laguna Beach, Calif., took the boys 14 singles title.

title: Judge Sets Sentencing Date
description: HAIYIMOND, Ind., Nov. 27 (UPI) Judge Phil M. McNagny Jr. of United States District Court has set a Dec. 22 sentencing date for William Kampiles, 23 years old, a former employee of the Central Intelligence Agency who was convicted of espionage charges for selling secret plans for a United States spy satellite system to the Soviet Union. He could be sentenced to life in prison.

title: OBSERVER
description: President Carter comes in for his weekly consultation. It is an interesting case. He believes he is turning into Gerald Ford.

title: The City
description: Asserting that reports that Radio City Music Hall could turn a slight profit this year were erroneous, Rockefeller Center officials issued a statement last night that the hall would end the year with a substantial loss.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: It took Congress a long time to put together the new National Energy Act, but even the shadow of its coming proved to be as jolly as the jingle of a cash register to the building materials industry. Sales of such energyefficient items as insulation, caulking, storm windows and solar heating systems are booming.

title: CEAUSESCU RESISTING RISE IN ARMS OUTLAY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  President Nicolae Ceausescu has apparently affirmed Rumania's independent foreign policy by refusing a Warsaw Pact bid to increase military expenditurq of all member countries, United States officials said today.

title: Planet's Mythology Is Ending
description: IMAGINE a world covered with seas of carbonated soda water, fizzing and popping and revolving through space like a gigantic ginandtonic.

title: Market Place
description: IN swiftly declining markets, investors in overthecounter issues may be better off if they avoid the more actively traded issues. At least that is the way Ralph Coleman Jr., president of the OvertheCounter Securities Fund, sees it.

title: 5 New Shows Coming in '79 On ABCTV
description: Three new situation comedies, a new adventure series with Andy Griffith and a Sunday evening variety hour with the Osmond Family will enter the ABCTV primetime schedule after the first of the year, the network announced yesterday.

title: Milk Left a Tape for Release If He Were Slain
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27 (AP)  Supervisor Harvey Milk recorded a mes. sage to his supporters a year ago and asked a friend to release it if he were assassinated, the friend, John Wahl, a lawyer, said today.

title: John Challener In Piano Recital
description: JOHN CHALLENER'S most engaging piano playing Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall came in two encores  transcriptions of the Sinfonia from Bach's Cantata No. 106 (;Gottes Zeit ist die allerbeste Zeit) and of Kreisler's Liebesleid. The Bacb transcription received a poised, affectionate reading. The Kreisler was skillfully negotiated and charmingly characterized. For the most part, however, the concert was a puzzle.

title: Cult Members Wanted Coast Inquiry Dropped
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 27 (AP)  A recent letter from 653 members of the Peoples Temple in Guyana asked the Los Angeles County District Attorney to drop an investigation of the cult and threatened forcible resistance, The Los Angeles Times reported today.

title: PHYLLIS BEER KOEHLER
description: Phyllis Beer Koehler, from 1945 to 1964 the president of Irvington House, a convalescent home in Irvington, N.Y., for children with rheumatic heart disease, died yesterday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center. She was 74 years old.

title: Bronx Drug Program Called a Ripoff
description: The New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation and the state's Division of Substance Abuse Services were accused by a Brooklyn Democratic Assemblyman yesterday of protecting a ripoff drugtreatment program through years of continuing scandal at Lincoln Hospital in the South Bronx.

title: Fire Aides Term Upstate Inn Lax On Alarm Setup
description: GREECE, N.Y., Nov. 27  Fire Department officials here said today that they had twice urged the management of the Holiday Inn  where 10 persons died and 25 were injured in a fire yesterdayto renovate the 15.yearold hotel's alarm system. But, theofficlals said, the recommendations were ignored.

title: Elderly in U.S. Are Sold Unneeded Health Insurance As Medicare Supplement, Congressional Staff Finds
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  A Congressional investigation of insurance fraud has concluded that the nation's senior citizens are paying $1 billion a year in premiums for health insurance policies they do not need.

title: NCR to Market Big Computers
description: The NCR Corporation, the nation's largest producer of electronic cash registers, announced yesterday that it was entering the largebusiness computer market.

title: N.F.L. Rejects Delay, Then Steelers Win
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27 (AP) With the National Football League having rejected a request to postpone the game for 24 hours, the Pittsburgh Steelers improved the league's best wonlost record to 112 by sending the San Francisco 49ers, 112, to their eighth straight defeat, 247, tonight.

title: Fukuda Loses Party Vote in Japan And Yields Premier's Post to Ohira
description: TOKYO, Nov. 27  Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda suffered an unexpected defeat today in a primary election for the presidency of the governing LiberalDemocratic Party and decided to yield his post as head of Government. The victor, Masayoshi Ohira, is due to become Japan's new Prime Minister in 10 days.

title: The Theater: Henry IV, Parts I and II, Goes the Long Distance
description: WHEN it gave a consecutive performance of Richard II and the two parts of Henry IV last weekend, the Classical Stage Company billed it as a marathon.

title: Thousands in Peking Shout for Freedom
description: PEKING, Nov. 27 (Agence France Presse)  Thousands of people hailing freedom and democracy took part today in what they said was the first completely spontaneous demonstration held in China since the Communists took power in 1949.

title: New Wrinkle In Cotton Shirts
description: For those men who have declared that they would give the shirts off their backs for one which would combine the cool crispness of natural cotton and the practicality of permanentpress fabrics, there is welcome news. The Van Heusen Company is introducing an allcotton shirt that, the company says, comes out of the dryer all ready to wear. The shirts, labeled Cotton 100, will be in the men's departments of Macy's, Abraham & Straus and Gimbels early next week.

title: Poland's Debt High And Likely to Grow
description: WARSAW  When Prime Minister Piotr Jaroszewicz brought home $520 million in loans from a recent official visit to Japan, Poland's total indebtedness to freemarket countries rose to considerably more than $15 billion.

title: Deaths
description: HARRISWalter E.. on Nov 21, 1978, in his Oath year, loving husband of the late Edith, devoted father of Michael and Wally.'devoted fatherinlaw of Barbara and Ruth, adored grandfather of Patti and Buddy. Private services were held: Contributions in his memory can be made to Jewish Child Care Association, 345 Madison Ave, NYC.

title: Deaths
